DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Citing the Constitution, the Kuomintang says if Tang Fei is appointed by the President to head the Cabinet, he is constitutional eligible to appoint his own administration line-up.
The China Times:
The Kuomintang tends to agree Tang Fei's premiership in his private capacity while most KMT legislators suggest that Tang temporarily quit KMT party activities.
The United Daily News:
The Kuomintang backs down by not insisting on party-to-party negotiations any longer on Tang's appointment as premier.
The Liberty Times:
The KMT comprises on Tang's being appointed premier.
The China Post:
Chen rejects KMT coalition demand.
The Taiwan News:
KMT demands Tang decide Cabinet; Chen calls the idea 'impossible,' says he's not establishing a coalition government: prospective premier reiterates he will follow any instruction issued by KMT.
The Taipei Times:
Chen stands tough on Cabinet choices, saying he will not bargain with the KMT or let it influence the forming of his administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 1, or the 27th day of the second month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. The following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1572: Dutch War for Independence from Spain begins.
1578: William Harvey, British physician and anatomist who discovered the circulation of blood, is born.
1795: Martial law is declared in France as food shortages spark riots.
1815: Prince Otto Eduard Leopold von Bismarck, Prussian statesman and first chancellor of the German Empire, is born.
1908: Japan puts into practice a six-year compulsory primary education system.
1918: Britain founds its Royal Air Force.
1924: Adolf Hitler is sentenced by a court to five years in jail for high treason. He was released on Dec. 20.
1924: The Republic of China's Central News Agency is established in Canton by the ruling Kuomintang.
1930: Yen Hsi-shan, Feng Yu-hsiang and Li Tsung-jen revolt against the ROC National Government.
1938: The Emergency National Congress of the Kuomintang in Wuchang elects Chiang Kai-shek as its director-general and decides to organize a People's Political Council and a San-min-chu-i Youth Corps.
1940: The Nationalist government issues a circular to the all levels of the nation's governments to call Dr. Sun Yat-sen the "National Father of the Republic of China."
1945: US forces invade the Japanese island of Okinawa.
1948: Relations between former wartime allies are put under severe strain by the Soviet Union's sudden decision to impose tough checks on all Western traffic entering Berlin.
1954: The US Air Force Academy is established in Colorado.
1959: The Dalai Lama arrives in India from Tibet.
1960: The United State launches Tiros I, its first weather satellite.
1965: King Hussein of Jordan appoints Prince Hassan, his younger brother, as his heir.
1968: Ma Ssu-tsung, former president of mainland China's "National Music Academy," and his wife arrive in Taipei from the United States. This is their first visit Taipei.
1973: The Value Added Tax (VAT) becomes operative in Britain.
1975: The Central News Agency marks its 51st anniversary.
1975: Cambodian President Lon Nol flees to Indonesia as Khmer Rouge guerrillas close in on Phnom Penh.
1976: President Yen Chia-kan visits the Taiwan Machinery Show at the frounds of the China External Trade Development Council.
1976: President Yen receives Olympic officials R. Mollet from Belgium, J. Roosevelt from the United States, and R. Bridge from Jamaica.
1984: Chang Gung Memorial Hospital completes the first human pancreas transplant in Asia.
1984: US soul music singer Marvin Gaye dies on the eve of his 45th birthday after being shot during a violent argument with his father. The singer had threatened to take his own life and had become increasingly unpredictable, largely due to a drug addiction.
1986: The new Value Added Tax (VAT) system is inaugurated in Taiwan.
1988: Iraq is accused of using poison gas on Kurdish villagers.
1989: Namibia gains independence from South Africa.
1991: Martha Graham, US modern dance master, dies at the age of 96.
1992: President George Bush pledges that the United States will help finance the 24-billion dollar international aid fund for the former Soviet Union.
1995: President Lee Teng-hui starts a four-day visit to the United Arab Emirates and Jordan.
1996: Britain proposes slaughtering 15,000 of its cattle every week for the next six years in order to fight mad cow disease.
1996: Japan's Mitsubishi Bank and Tokyo Bank merge to become one of the world's largest banks, Tokyo-Mitsubishi Bank.
1998: Israel accepts a United Nations resolution calling for its withdrawal from south Lebanon.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is easy to serve, but difficult to please. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will not be pleased. But in his employment of men, he always takes into consideration their capacity. A fool, on the other hand, is easy to please, but difficult to serve. If you go beyond your duty to please him, he will be pleased. But in his employment of men, he expects them to be able to do everything."

DOC.HEADLINE: PANAMA'S PRESIDENT LIKELY TO POSTPONE ROC VISIT AGAIN
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, March 31 (CNA) (By H.T. Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The state visit to the Republic of China by Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso may be further postponed, probably to June, diplomatic sources here said on Friday.

Moscoso recently told ROC Ambassador in Panama Lan Chih-min that she may not be able to visit Taiwan in April as previous scheduled owing to factors concerning various domestic affairs, but added a postponement would have nothing to do with any "diplomatic intervention."
Moscoso was originally scheduled to visit Taipei in January but later changed her mind on the advice of relevant Panamanian officials concerning the ROC presidential election on March 18.

Moscoso, who accepted an invitation by former ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu last August, decided to postpone her first state visit to Taiwan until late March or early April, after the ROC's presidential election.
The state visit will now likely be delayed until June, but a definite schedule will have to be worked out by officials from Panama and Taiwan, Lan said.

Panama is one of the ROC's most important diplomatic allies in Central America. ROC Premier Vincent Siew attended Moscoso's inauguration in Panama City in August 1999 and President Lee Teng-hui traveled to Panama in September 1997 to attend the World Congress of the Panama Canal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWANESE GROUPS PROTEST JAPAN'S HANDLING OF WARTIME DEBTS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 1 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A delegation of members from five different groups representing former Taiwanese soldiers in the Japanese Imperial Army protested here on Friday the Japanese government's handling of debts owed to them for their service during World War II.

Led by Republic of China legislators Fan Yang-sheng and Yang Tso-tsou, the ten representatives of former Taiwanese soldiers in the Imperial Army or their relatives showed up Friday afternoon at the Tokyo headquarters of the Japan Interchange Association, a semi-official agency in charge of Taiwan affairs, and presented a letter of protest to its chairman Toshio Goto.

In the letter, the protesters criticized the Japanese government for compensating Taiwanese citizens by only 120 times the face value of money owed to them from more than five decades ago while giving Japanese debtors payments at 70,000 times the original amount owed.
The letter also expressed their opposition to the five year deadline which fell on March 31, after which the debts will be repaid at par value only.
They also demanded that any unclaimed funds, worth about 23 billion yen, should be deposited in banks pending any remaining claims by Taiwanese citizens in the future.
Officials from the Japanese foreign ministry were present when the protesters handed over the letter to Goto, who promised to convey it to the Japanese government.
In a press conference on Friday evening, Fan said that Japan should not unilaterally decide the amount they owe and the method of repayment without first consulting with Taiwanese claimants.

Kuo Lien-fu, a representative of former Taiwanese soldiers in the Japanese Imperial Army, complained at the press briefing that the Japanese government owed an average of 1,000 yen to each of the Taiwanese claimants they represent, which is equivalent in value to about 0.97 hectares of farmland in Taiwan at the time, or NT$10 million (34.1 million yen) now.
However, each of these claimants will only receive 120,000 yen (NT$34,800), or less than one month's wages for the average Taiwanese worker nowadays, under the Japanese government's formula.

This discriminatory and arbitrary treatment of wartime claimants has drawn the wrath of many Taiwanese citizens who would rather spurn the Japanese government's offer than accept the insulting "handouts." Therefore, more than two thirds of the claimants have refused to accept the Japanese government's compensation thus far, said Kuo.
He vowed to press ahead with the demands of Taiwanese claimants until the Japanese government grants them just compensation.

The Japanese government debts to Taiwanese citizens stem from 50 years of colonization of the island between 1895 and 1945. They consist mainly of the salary in arrears to Taiwanese who were recruited as soldiers at the end of War World II.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN HAS CAPABLE SELF-DEFENSE FORCES: COHEN

TEXT.P: US Defense Secretary William Cohen Friday declined to comment on a "highly classified" Pentagon assessment of Taiwan's military capability reported by The Washington Post, but he said he is satisfied that Taiwan still has a very capable military.

In response to a similar question about Taiwan's military capability, State Department spokesman Jamie Rubin told a routine press briefing that "I think Cohen noted that it was our view that Taiwan did have capable self-defense forces."

"The fact that we work on such reports is, in and of itself, a demonstration that this is a topic of concern to us and that it's something that obviously informs our decision-making, given our obligations under the Taiwan Relations Act," stressed Rubin.

The Washington Post quoted a new classified Pentagon report as saying that Taiwan is perhaps more vulnerable to Communist Chinese attack now because of its isolation and the fact that it cannot exercise with other countries using its weaponry.

After meeting the Ukrainian defense minister, Cohen told reporters that he is not in a position to comment publicly on the report on Taiwan, other than to say that Taiwan is still "very capable in terms of its military capability, but that there are recommendations -- there are always recommendations for ways to improve its capability through training and exercises and other types of activities."

"But we conduct a number of reports, consistent with the Taiwan Relations Act, to assess Taiwan's defense capabilities, and report accordingly. And that will continue in the future," added the defense secretary.

Cohen, the commander-in-chief of the US Pacific Command and some Pentagon officials have said they do not feel that China is now capable of attacking and taking over Taiwan. When pressed with the question, Cohen said that "what we have said is Taiwan should not seek independence, and China should seek to bring about a reconciliation through peaceful means."
Cohen also did not respond to questions regarding Taiwan's recent requests for Aegis-class destroyers and other advanced defensive weapons systems.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD CONTINUE TO SHOW STRONG SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN: EXPERTS
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 31 (CNA) (By Nelson Chung) (By Nelson Chung)

TEXT.P: Washington, March 31 (CNA Washington should continue to show strong support for democratic and free Taiwan, according to a Washington-based think tank.

The victory of Democratic Progressive Party presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian signals first and foremost that democracy is thriving in Taiwan, wrote Larry M. Wortzel, director of the Asian Studies Center at the Heritage Foundation, and Stephen Yates, a senior policy analyst at the center, in an executive memorandum published Friday.

But they also noted that it signals an important change in the relationship between Taipei and Beijing. "As long as the Kuomintang was in control in Taipei, Beijing could pretend that unification across the Taiwan Straits was possible through party-to-party negotiations. Taiwan's democratic transformation since its first direct presidential elections in 1996 may have chipped away at this myth, but Chen Shui-bian's victory has shattered it," pointed out the two experts on Asia.
To resolve the issue of reunification, they wrote, "Beijing must now deal with a government that carries no baggage from the days of China's civil war in the 1940s."

Since Taiwan's security and the survival of its democracy are vital US national security interests, Washington should send US representatives to attend the inauguration of the president-elect when the KMT relinquishes power to send a clear signal to Beijing that the American people support democracy, said Wortzel and Yates.

The authors added that the United States should also voice support for the principles of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act which passed the House of Representatives by a vote of 371-40. "The TSEA acknowledges the democracy on Taiwan and that the Republic of China no longer claims to rule the mainland. More important, it ensures that Taiwan can defend itself from military aggression."

In addition, they said, Washington should continue to seek the simultaneous entry of Taiwan and Communist China into the World Trade Organization, "which would help the mainland develop rules and norms that would improve economic ties and communication with Taiwan and bring China more fully into the international community."

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP ENVOY AGAIN CALLS ON BEIJING TO SHOW CREATIVITY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, March 31 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A top representative of the Republic of China's President-elect Chen Shui-bian to the United States on Friday once again called for Beijing to show creativity in cross-Taiwan Strait relations.

The Democratic Progessive Party's Chiou I-jen, at a press conference prior to his departure from Washington, D.C., urged Beijing not to stick to its own interpretation of `one China.' Instead, he said Beijing should have a more creative attitude toward the current impasse in the Taiwan Strait, saying that history is made by creativity. "Refusing to change is not conducive to creating history," Chiou added.

Chiou told reporters that it would be greatly conducive to creative interactions across the strait if Beijing would still give serious thought to the `one China' formula defined by Wang Daohan, chairman of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), several years ago.

Wang defined `one China' not as the Republic of China or the People's Republic of China, but as a unified China to be formed sometime in the future, according to Chiou. He said this definition is viable and feasible and is most likely to be accepted by Taiwan.
Chiou said the DPP's bottom line is similar to recent statements by US President Bill Clinton that any decision concerning Taiwan's future must be agreed to by the people of Taiwan.
He added that the DPP has set no prerequisites for Taiwan's future, noting that the party takes heed of the people's will -- whether it be for reunification with the mainland or for independence.

Chiou said Chen's stance is to understand through dialogue Beijing's definition of the `one China' policy, adding that Taiwan will not jump the gun to talk about whether or not to accept Beijing's `one China' policy before understanding the exact definition.
Over the past three days in Washington, D.C., Chiou has met with US officials, lawmakers and China hands on cross-strait and US-ROC-PRC relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MISSILE DEFENSE PLAN THREATENS NUCLEAR PEACE: EXPERTS

TEXT.P: Several well-known missile experts meeting in Ottawa Friday have joined in a chorus of rising concern over a United States missile defense plan, saying its implementation would seriously threaten global nuclear peace.
"We're playing with the fundamental (principles) of the non-proliferation treaty," said John Steinbruner, director of International Security Studies at the University of Maryland.
The 1972 Anti-Ballistic Missile pact that has kept nuclear peace between Russia and the US is at risk, he said.
He and others were expressing concern that US President Bill Clinton or his successor will proceed with the US$12.5-billion project, now in the testing stage.
The scaled-down Star Wars system is being touted as a capable defense against the potential launch of a few missiles by "rogue states" such as Iraq or North Korea.
Steinbruner said a better idea would be to work towards international agreements to share missile monitoring data, surveillance information and early-warning efforts.

North Korea has indicated it would get out of the nuclear arms business in exchange for compensation -- another option that should be explored, he added. "It's probably quite possible to buy them out."
Steinbruner and nine other ballistic missile experts discussed tougher missile control, including international early-warning and tracking efforts.

Implementation of a new US defense system would only deepen Russian paranoia and insecurity, said Taira Koybaeva. "We should be sensitive to that," said the Russian-born business and political communications professor at Utah State University.
Canada should weigh the reaction from other countries if it supports implementing such a system, said John Garnett, a missile expert in defense studies at King's College in London, England.
US Deputy Defense Secretary John Hamre recently urged Canada to join the system or risk being left out of key NORAD (North American Aerospace Command) decisions.
Canada contributes US$320 million a year to NORAD, 10 percent of the command's budget. But Canada's federal government has not been formally asked to make a decision.
Canadian Foreign Affairs Minister Lloyd Axworthy has raised concern about the system's destabilizing effect on the balance of nuclear power which has been achieved through treaties.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COUNTY CHIEF TO VISIT PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, March 31 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien of Taiwan's southern county of Kaohsiung is scheduled to arrive in Asuncion, Paraguay on Sunday for a three-day visit.

Yu, who will lead a Kaohsiung County delegation comprised of county government officials, advisers and county assembly members, will meet with Paraguayan President Luis Angel Gonzalez Macchi to exchange views on global affairs and on bilateral ties between Taiwan and Paraguay.
During the visit, Yu will also meet with the governor of Paraguay's Central Province to jointly sign an agreement creating sisterhood ties between the two administrative areas.

The Taiwanese and overseas Chinese community in Paraguay will hold a barbecue banquet on Monday to welcome Yu and his delegation and to mark the inauguration of Kaohsiung County-Central Province sisterhood ties.
After their visit to Paraguay, Yu and his group will proceed to Argentina to continue their fact-finding tour in Latin America.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES SURGE TO RECLAIM 10,000 LEVEL

TEXT.P: Share prices rose nearly two percent Saturday to reclaim the 10,000 level on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on strong buying of telecommunications and DRAM shares.
The weighted price index, the market's key barometer, soared 195.48 points to close at 10,050.43 points, following a 0.8 percent decrease in the previous session.
The bourse opened at 9,892.78 and drifted down to 9,816.22 before strong buying in the latter half of the session brought the weighted price index up to close at the day's high of 10,050.43.
A total of 2.98 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$221.83 billion (US$7.27 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 320 to 238, with 53 stocks remaining unchanged.

Four of the eight major categories gained ground, with electronics shares posing the greatest gain at 3.6 percent, followed by cement stocks at 2.4 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.4 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.1 percent. Textile shares remained unchanged.
Financial stocks posted the greatest loss at 1.5 percent, followed by construction shares at 0.9 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.5 percent.
The TAIEX will be closed on Monday and Tuesday to observe Children's Day and Tomb Sweeping Day.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures market also increased.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April surged 234 points to close at 10,149, with 2,487 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May surged 275 points to close at 10,250, with 142 contract transactions, while June futures surged 242 points to close at 10,297, with 30 contract transactions. September futures moved up 89 points to close at 10,389, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
Electronics futures (TE) and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, reported mixed results.
April TE futures surged 21.05 points to close at 565, with 1,211 contract transactions, while May TE futures surged 22.4 points to close at 571, with 59 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
April TF futures moved down 7 points to close at 1,025, with 300 contract transactions. While May TF futures moved down 2.2 percent, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEFENSE BUDGET FAR FROM SUFFICIENT SAYS ROC DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei on Saturday would not comment on a Pentagon assessment that Taiwan is more vulnerable to attack from mainland China than generally recognized.

Tang, who has been invited by President-elect Chen Shui-bian to be the next premier of the Republic of China beginning on May 20, said it is improper for him to comment on the latest and highly classified Pentagon assessment at present since he has not yet seen the contents of the report.
He noted, however, that "if the assessment proved to be correct, we should be willing to do some soul-searching and review our defense policy."
Tang, meanwhile, reiterated that Taiwan's defense budget, equivalent to 2.6 percent of the gross national product (GNP) this year, is far from sufficient in meeting national security needs.

He added that even if the budget were raised to 3.5 percent of the GNP next year, it would still be too low in terms of beefing up national defenses in the face of the growing military threat from mainland China.
Tang made the remarks at a workshop sponsored by National Taiwan University's Law School.

He noted that even if the defense budget is raised to 3.5 percent of the GNP, representing about 17 percent of the nation's overall budget, it won't be enough to help gear up Taiwan's combat readiness as about 50 percent of the budget will be allocated to paying the salaries of military personnel, who number about 382,000.

At the workshop, Tang, who declined to comment on the offer of the post of premier, said that in the face of Beijing's persistent sable rattling and verbal assaults, Taiwan must construct a nation-wide psychological and civilian defense that includes the entire population within one year.
Although remaining low-key on the topic of the premiership, Tang spoke broadly on his views concerning government organization, diplomacy, and cross-strait relations.

Tang said he feels the ROC Armed Forces should emulate the US Pentagon's efforts at keeping the nation's entire defense system flexible and able to quickly readjust itself every three or four years based on the current strategic situation and the appearance of any new threats to the nation's security.

On the diplomatic front, Tang said Taiwan should actively reach out to nurture trust with neighboring countries. He noted that no one will help the island unconditionally, so all the ROC can do is extend the offer of help to others first.

On cross-strait relations, Tang said mainland China will pose a genuine and serious threat to Taiwan by 2010, when its military modernization program is completed. In addition to continuing to work to improve cross-strait relations, Taiwan should at the same time upgrade its combat preparedness as well as surveillance capabilities of mainland Chinese military movements, he said.

On the question of possibly taking up the premiership, Tang reiterated that, as a Kuomintang-government official, he will follow the instructions of the party, saying the final decision is up to the Kuomintang.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO CARES FOR FORMER TAIWANESE SOLDIERS IN JAPANESE ARMY (I)

TEXT.P: Fifty-five years after the end of Japan's colonization of Taiwan, the deadline for Taiwanese claimants for compensation by the Japanese for war time services finally came to pass March 31, supposedly putting the issue to rest once and for all.

However, the Japanese government's handling of the compensation issue has given rise to more disputes than it was intended to resolve, and more than half of the eligible creditors have deliberately shunned the program rather than accept the petty compensation offered by Tokyo.

Many Taiwanese claimants consider the minuscule amount of repayment as an insult rather than as a settlement of compensation claims made by the people of Taiwan for debts owed to them by Japan during the period of Japanese rule of the island from 1895 to 1945.
Most of the claims stem from among the 207,000 Taiwanese who were recruited into the Japanese Imperial Army to serve as soldiers or paramilitary members near the end of World War II.
These "honorable" draftees were assigned to battlegrounds in mainland China, the Southern Pacific islands or for work in Japan. About 53,000 of them died in the war or are still unaccounted for.
Their payments in arrears and savings deposited at military post offices during the war constitute the major part of the Japanese government's debt to Taiwanese citizens.
Other claims include deposits made by ordinary Taiwanese citizens at post offices and payments due to Taiwanese life insurance policies holders.
The Japanese government, which estimated the number of claimants in Taiwan at 4.47 million, has set aside 35.3 billion yen to cover compensation claims over five years.

However, according to statistics released by the Japan Interchange Association, which is in charge of processing the claims in Taiwan, only 55,000 claims for late payments to soldiers have been filed out of a total of 84,000 cases. About 43,000 claimants, or 51 percent of the total, actually collected their compensation by the March 31 deadline.
As to the military deposits with post offices, about 53,000 claims were made, but only 29,000 claimants, or 48 percent, have collected their repayment. (MORE)

DOC.HEADLINE: WHO CARES FOR FORMER TAIWANESE SOLDIERS IN JAPANESE ARMY (II)

TEXT.P: As a result, only 11 billion yen of the 35.3 billion budget has been paid out.

Liu Yung-chung, a Taiwan activist for former Taiwanese soldiers in the Imperial Army, claimed the repayment program is unfair and the payment offered to Taiwanese citizens too low, leading most Taiwanese claimants to opt out of the program.

Liu said that it is ridiculous that the Japanese government established its policy for settling its debts with Taiwanese citizens without consulting with the claimants first. The rate of compensation and the time frame within which the creditors could make their claims were both decided upon without asking for Taiwanese creditors' input or approval.

To their indignation, the most insulting aspect of the program is its discriminatory nature. Taiwanese citizens were offered compensation at only 120 times the face value of the money owed to them while Japanese citizens who served in the army were given 7,000 times the original amount owed.
The Taiwanese claimants' calls for fair treatment seem to have fallen on deaf ears as Japan apparently is continuing it arrogant colonial attitude toward Taiwan, said Liu.

These former soldiers from Taiwan who fought against China during the World War II can hardly expect to get any help from authorities in the Republic of China government, which doesn't have diplomatic ties with Tokyo. Their only avenue of appeal to the Japanese government is through non-official channels.
Japan has actually repeatedly demanded that the debt issue be settled through negotiations with Taiwan, but only if China's debts to Japan are also included in negotiations and settled too.

Knowing that it owes much more to Japan, the Republic of China government has preferred to not open talks with Tokyo on this issue and leave the matter in the hands of legislators, encouraging them to negotiate with Tokyo in private.

In the absence of government leadership and backup, , Taiwanese claimants have formed different groups, numbered at about a hundred at its peak, to pursue their claims. They have aired conflicting demands and have never formed a joint front in talks with Japan to put pressure on the Japanese government.

The war has been over for 55 years, now these former Taiwanese soldiers in the Japanese Imperial Army are fading away, their lives having been divided between two former rival countries, with few people caring about their plight. It seems they can do nothing but blame their ill fortune and carry their grief with them to their graves.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG FEI'S APPOINTMENT SEEN AS OPPORTUNITY TO MODERNIZE ROC ARMY
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, March 31 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A researcher at a United States think tank said on Friday that Tang Fei's appointment as the premier of the Republic of China will present the best opportunity for modernizing the nation's army and upgrading its military capabilities.

Michael Swaine, a researcher at the California-based Rand Institute, made the remarks to CNA after Washington Post cited a classified Pentagon report as saying that Taiwan is perhaps more vulnerable to Communist Chinese attack now because the island's military capabilities have been weakened through years of diplomatic isolation.

Swaine pointed out that if one sees the purpose of the Pentagon report as prodding the US to sell Taiwan more advanced weapon systems, it will be a misinterpretation, saying that Taiwan does not lack military hardware but does need to improve training, maintenance, the execution of its software, and the integration of various systems.
Swaine said that Taiwan's advanced weapons are not being used to their fullest extent and that it is futile to accumulate a large volume of new weaponry.

Swaine, who criticized Taiwan on this point in his report last year, noted that Taiwan's army has been controlled by the Kuomintang over the past five decades, preventing it from engaging in real reforms.
He noted that even after related laws and regulations, such as the organic law of the Ministry of National Defense, have been passed, they have not been able to meet the nation's security needs.

But he said that with Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progress Party as the new president and with the KMT's Tang as the premier, the two parties will be able to work together to forge consensus on national defense policy and on the military budget.
Under a civilian leader, the army will be monitored closely, and this will be an important opportunity for the modernization of Taiwan's army.
Swain said that the report he presented late last year has some similar views with those expressed in the Pentagon report, but they are both irrelevant studies.
He said that even the ROC army has tacitly admitted that there are some problems with its military capabilities and that Taiwan has to seriously address the question.

Swain's report was presented to the Pentagon for reference prior to its recent classified report. He understands that the Pentagon thinks his report is "useful" and "helpful," judging from the fact that military information on both sides of the Taiwan Strait is very limited.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY TO CONVENE FIFTH SESSION ON APRIL 8

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Saturday issued a decree to convene the fifth session of the third National Assembly (NA) on April 8.
Acting NA Speaker Chen Ching-jang said that the main purpose of convening the NA session is to amend the Constitution to the effect that the NA will become an "empty-frame" institution.

He noted that NA deputies will adopt a resolution to ask the Central Election Commission to put off the May 6 NA election for one or two months so that they will have sufficient time to amend the Constitution.
Last September, the NA passed a bill to extend the four-year term of NA members by two years and 42 days until June 30, 1992. Their term was originally scheduled to expire on May 19, 2000.
But the Council of Grand Justices ruled last week that the decision was "invalid." As a result, the Central Election Commission decided to hold the new NA elections on May 6.

The NA caucuses of the Kuomintang and the Democratic Progressive Party have agreed to let the NA become an "empty-frame" institution and asked President Lee to issue a decree to convene the NA session to amend the Constitution.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONGRATULATIONS POUR INTO TAIWAN ON PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: A total of 72 countries around the world, including 43 which maintain no formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, sent messages to Taiwan congratulating it on successfully holding its presidential election on March 18, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Saturday.
All 29 governments that maintain formal diplomatic ties with the ROC have sent congratulatory messages to Taiwan over the successful process of the election, MOFA officials said.

Most of the congratulatory messages pointed out that the success of the election signaled the maturity and steady development of democracy in Taiwan and expressed the hope that bilateral relations between their country and Taiwan will remain close and cordial after the new ROC president is inaugurated.

MOFA officials said politicians and lawmakers in 43 nations maintaining no formal ties with Taiwan, including Czech Republic President Vaclav Havel, have conveyed congratulations to Taipei through Taiwan's liaison offices overseas, and expressed their hopes of further strengthening substantive relations with Taiwan.

Chief executives of three leading international organizations, including the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, have also sent felicitations to Taipei over the success of the election, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT REFORM COUNCIL HOLDS FIRST MEETING

TEXT.P: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan said on Saturday that he expects the party will rise again by winning the elections for legislators and county magistrates in two years and by regaining the presidency in 2004.
He made the remarks while speaking at the first meeting of the KMT Reform Council, established after the party suffered a disastrous defeat in the March 18 presidential election.
Forty-five of the 54 reform council members attended the meeting, presided over by Lien himself.
Lien stressed that the party must undergo self-examination and all-out reform so as to display a fresh image to the public, adding that "we must rise again from where we fell down."

During the three-hour meeting, members of the reform council exchanged views on the disposal of party assets and on the party's status and organization, as well as discussing how to carry out party policy more thoroughly and how to solicit the support of the younger generation.

In the coming weeks, ten groups made up of members of the Reform Council will visit counties and cities around Taiwan to listen to grass-roots opinions on reforming the party. They will then submit concrete suggestions on reform by the end of May.

In the recently held presidential election, the KMT ticket of Lien and Vincent Siew collected only 23 percent of the vote, compared with independent candidate James Soong's 36 percent, and the 39 percent garnered by the victorious Democratic Progressive Party ticket of Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu. (By Victor Lai) ENDITEM

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 2, or the 28th day of the second month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
742: Charlemagne, King of the Franks and founder of the first empire in Western Europe after the fall of Rome, is born. His court at Aix-le-Chapelle becomes the center of the Carolingian Renaissance.
1513: Ponce de Leon, a Spanish explorer who sailed with Columbus on his second voyage, explores Florida while looking for the legendary Fountain of Youth.
1792: The first silver dollar of the new US currency is struck in Philadelphia by the Bank of the United States.
1801: British admiral Horatio Nelson, aboard the HMS Elephant, sinks the pro-French Danish fleet off its home port of Copenhagen.
1805: Hans Christian Andersen, Danish writer of fairy tales including "The Emperor's New Clothes" and "The Ugly Duckling," is born.
1840: Emile Zola, French realist novelist whose books included "Therese Raquin," "Nana," "Germinal," and " La Terre," is born.
1905: The Simplon rail tunnel under the Alps linking Switzerland with Italy is opened.
1810: Napoleon Bonaparte marries Marie Louise, daughter of the Austrian emperor.
1872: Samuel Finley Breese Morse, American painter and inventor who refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name, dies at the age of 81.
1902: The first US movie theater is opened in Los Angeles, California.
1912: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China resolves to move the seat of the government to Beijing.
1914: Sir Alec Guinness, British actor who won an Oscar for "The Bridge on the River Kwai," is born.
1917: Thomas Woodrow Wilson, the 28th president of the United States and the winner of the 1919 Nobel Peace Prize, summons a special session of Congress to declare war on Germany. At the Paris Peace conference in 1919, he included the establishment of the League of Nations in the Treaty of Versailles.
1922: Soviet leader Nikolai Lenin appoints Joseph Stalin as general secretary of the Communist Party.
1938: The Spanish Civil War ends with General Franco's Fascists as the victors.
1947: The United Nations Security Council votes to appoint the United States as the trustee for Pacific Islands formerly held by the Japanese.
1951: General Dwight Eisenhower assumes command of all allied armies in Europe and the Western Mediterranean area.
1953: Karl L. Rankin becomes the American ambassador to the ROC.
1954: The ROC Legislative Yuan passes the Extradition Law.
1965: The ROC government declares that "protocols" signed recently by the Beijing regime with Afghanistan are illegal and not binding on China.
1971: Garuda Indonesia Airlines makes its maiden flight to Taipei.
1973: Brig. Gen. Majed Al Haj Hassan and two other members of a Jordanian military goodwill mission arrive in Taipei for a 10-day visit.
1974: Georges Pompidou, president of France, dies at the age of 62.
1974: Madame Gloria de Lopez Arellana, the first lady of Honduras, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1979: Prime Minister Menachem Begin becomes the first Israeli leader to make an official visit to Egypt.
1981: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo is reelected chairman of the Kuomintang by acclamation at the 12th National Congress in Taipei.
1982: Argentine military forces invade the British Falklands Islands.
1983: Chang Da-chien, a noted Chinese painter, dies in Taipei at the age of 85.
1991: Soviet coal miners go on strike across the USSR.
1991: Diego Maradona, star of Napoli soccer team, flies home to Argentina hours before being banned from every sporting activity in Italy after failing a dope test.
1996: Lech Walesa, Poland's first post-war democratic president, resumes his old job as an electrician at the Gdansk shipyard.
1997: US House of Representatives Speaker Newt Gingrich meets with President Lee Teng-hui during a four-hour visit to the ROC. Gingrich praises Taiwan's political progress and economic achievements.
1997: The Statute Governing Relations with Hong Kong and Macau is promulgated by President Lee Teng-hui to go partially into effect on July 1, 1997 for Hong Kong, and in 1999 for Macau.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise man is dignified, but not proud. A fool is proud, but not dignified."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT DENIES SENDING ENVOY TO BEIJING

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian denied on Sunday that he had sent an American scientist as special envoy to mainland China to discuss cross-strait relations with Beijing leaders.

Chen was responding to a report by the Washington Post that said Jeremy J. Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists, would discuss issues related to both sides of the Taiwan Strait with Beijing leaders on Chen's behalf.

Stone, who assisted in United States arms negotiations with Russia and is a close friend of Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh, president of the nation's highest research institute Academia Sinica, arrived at Beijing Friday night, the paper reported.
Chen said that he admires anyone that has the sincerity to make efforts to "contribute to the security and stability in the Asia-Pacific region."
He reaffirmed his "utmost sincerity and goodwill" in the normalization of cross-strait relations and his "determination to pursue cross-strait peace."

Chen, who is a member of the pro-Taiwan independence Democratic Progressive Party, had sounded conciliatory notes to the mainland after his victory in March 18 presidential election, which saw the Kuomintang end its 54-year rule of the island.
Meanwhile, journalists were unable to reach Lee Yuan-tseh for his comment on the reports as he did not make an appearance at a fruit promotion fair as scheduled on Sunday.

The Washington Post reported that Stone had visited Taiwan before going to Beijing. While in Taiwan, he met with Chen and Lee, Chen's top adviser who had previously expressed his willingness to help ease cross-strait relations.
The paper said that Stone and Lee have been close friends for years, and Lee played a role in encouraging Stone to take the trip.

Stone is scheduled to meet with mainland Chinese Vice Prime Minister Qian Qichen, the lead architect of China's Taiwan policy; General Xiong Guangkai, a top policy-maker with the People's Liberation Army; and officials at the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, the reports said.
Cross-strait relations sank to a new low after Beijing reacted furiously to President Lee Teng-hui's statement in July that cross-strait ties be conducted on a "special state-to-state" basis.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO EXPEL MEMBERS FOR DISLOYALTY DURING PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: The outgoing Kuomintang will dismiss a number of members on April 7 , including Yen Ching-piao, speaker of Taichung County Council, Legislator Lee Ching-an and Shao Tsung-hai, a staunch supporter of defeated Presidential Hopeful James Soong.

According to a KMT official, this will be the first batch of members to be dismissed for failing to support the party candidate in the March 18 presidential election. Party disloyalty is seen as one of the key factors that led to the KMT's loss in the election.
The official said that if such "political garbage" is not expelled, all efforts for reform will fail.
The KMT Discipline Commission has requested local chapters of the party to provide lists of members who supported independent candidate James Soong during the presidential election.
More than 10 members were on the list for punishment. They ar expeceed to be kicked out at a Discipline Commission meeting scheduled to be held on April 7.
The post-election purge will continue and the number of members to be punished may surpass 1,000, the official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SCHOLAR HAILS TAIWAN DEMOCRATIZATION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 1 (CNA) (By K.C. Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has gradually transformed into a democracy, said a US academician at a Saturday seminar held here.

Speaking at a symposium which was jointly sponsored by an ROC-funded academic foundation and New York University, Robert Scalapino, an honorary professor of the University of California at Berkeley, said Taiwan has gradually transformed into a full democracy from an authoritarian regime. He noted that late President Chiang Ching-kuo made a tremendous contribution in that peaceful process.

Pointing out that Taiwan's democracy may still face a strong challenge from dictatorship, he suggested that President-elect Chen Shui-bian join forces with all of Taiwan's political camps to reduce political tensions on the island and open political talks with mainland China to improve bilateral ties.

Although Taiwan's political culture is characterized by political localization, the identification of the so-called "new Taiwanese" concept, an aspiration for a civilian leadership, and political uncertainties in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, Scalapino stressed that Taiwan's leadership must pay heed to the people's desire that Taiwan maintain the current status-quo with mainland China.

Answering questions from the audience, Scalapino expressed his belief that the United States should continue sticking to its "one China" policy while abiding by the Taiwan Relations Act. He claimed that the United States must engage in dealings with mainland China, a superpower in the Western Pacific, in order to maintain peace there.

The seminar, which was attended by more than 50 political and economic experts from the United States and Asia, will run through Sunday. Charles Teng, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in New York, also took part in the gathering.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US ASSISTANT SECRETARY OF STATE TO VISIT TAIPEI, BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 1 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Winston Lord, former US assistant secretary for East Asian and Pacific affairs, is scheduled to visit leaders in Taipei and Beijing later this month.
Lord said that Douglas Paal, former White House National Security Council official, will accompany him on the trip, the itinerary of which is still being arranged.

Lord is scheduled to meet with President Lee Teng-hui and President-elect Chen Shui-bian in Taipei, and with mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin and Premier Zhu Rongji in Beijing. He would not rule out the possibility of adding a stopover in Shanghai so as to meet with Wang Daohan, mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan.
Lord expressed the hope that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can work together to reduce tensions and resume dialogues soon.
He stressed that the trip will be of a "private nature," and denied that he was carrying any messages from the Clinton administration.

Lord praised Chen's performance since winning the March 18 presidential election, saying that Chen's remarks are cautious. He said that Chen's expression of willingness to visit the mainland and his wish that cross-strait talks can be resumed soon are constructive.
Beijing has also shown restraint following its threats prior to the March 18 election, he added.

Lord also expressed his admiration for the achievements of President Lee, saying that Lee's role in the democratization of Taiwan is undeniable, and his promotion of democracy has brought economic development and prosperity to the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN COAST GUARD DETAINS 5 MAINLAND FISHING BOATS FOR POACHING

TEXT.P: Cutters of the National Coastal Guard Administration, Kinmen Chapter, captured five mainland Chinese fishing boats along with 20 crewmen that had been poaching in waters of Kinmen Island.

Two patrol vessels started a sweep operation on Sunday morning and discovered five mainland Chinese fishing boats operating illegally in 50-meter waters off Sangyi, Kinmen. The patrol boats captured these five fishing boats along with 20 crewmen and escorted them to Hsinfu Fishing Port for further investigation.
The captured boats were returned to the mainland after their fishing nets and catches were confiscated in accordance with regulations.
This was the third consecutive day that Kinmen Coast Guard has detained mainland fishing boats for poaching.

DOC.HEADLINE: SINGER VISITS LOCAL ORPHANAGE
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei County, northern Taiwan, April 2 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Judy Ong, a Taiwan singer now living in Japan, on Sunday visited a group of orphans who lost their parents and relatives in the disastrous earthquake on Sept. 21 last year to convey the concerns of overseas Chinese about the orphans' status quo.

On behalf of overseas Chinese in Japan, Ong donated three million Japanese yen (US$28,571) to the Chinese Children's Fund, Inc., a social welfare organization that the Tatung Orphanage, which houses the children, belongs to.

Ong held a charity concert last year following the 9/21 earthquake to raise funds for victims of the quake. The show won warm reactions from Japan's overseas Chinese community. The funds raised in the charity show were donated to the Red Cross Society, Republic of China, in December last year.
Later, overseas Chinese in Japan raised an additional three million yen and entrusted Ong with the task of donating the funds to Taiwan's victim children.
In return, Peng Ming-tsung, chairman of the Chinese Children's Fund Inc., presented a plaque to Ong to extend the organization's thanks for her kindness toward the orphans.
Peng also urged people in all walks of life to continue to extend their concerns about the orphaned children.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE CHINA' DISPUTE RESULTS FROM LACK OF MUTUAL TRUST: AIT HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, April 1 (CNA) (By Hui-Yen Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A lack of mutual trust is the key factor behind the differences between Taiwan and mainland China on the definition of the disputed "one China" principle, said the top US liaison official with Taiwan on Saturday.

Richard Bush, head of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT), which represents US interests in lieu of official relations between the two countries, said Taiwan and mainland China should try to seek terms acceptable to both sides so as to restart bilateral talks. The United States will not lean toward either side on this issue, he noted.

Commenting on mainland China's insistence that the "one China" principle drafted by Beijing should be a precondition of reopening bilateral talks and on Taiwan's stance that the "one China" framework is only one issue which needs further discussion, Bush reiterated that Washington acknowledges Beijing's "one China" position and that Taiwan forms a part of China.

Although the United States understands the reason behind the differences between Taiwan and the Chinese mainland over the definition of the "one China," the AIT chief said both sides should try to find a way to mend their differences. "The United States will not neither speak for nor seek to change either side," he asserted.
It's better for Taiwan and the mainland to talk than not to talk, Bush claimed, urging the two sides to find some sort of an agreement to resolve their problems.
The AIT chairman made the remarks while giving a speech on post-election Taiwan-US relations at a seminar.

Answering questions from the audience following the speech, Bush stated that although the proposed "Taiwan Security Enhancement Act" (TSEA) has a good name, the US administration does not think that the bill will substantively help strengthen Taiwan's security.

Saying that passage of the TSEA will produce many problems and will escalate tensions across the Taiwan Strait, he emphasized that Taiwan's security relies primarily on the determination of its people and the island's own military clout, followed by economic cooperation between Taiwan and mainland China and a US supply of defensive weapons.
The TSEA, already overwhelmingly approved by the US House of Representatives, still awaits passage by the US Senate.

Bush, the top liaison official in charge of United States' dealings with Taiwan, stressed that America will not do anything which would hurt Taiwan and that the United States has made very clear to the mainland that it will play a role should China launch a military attack against Taiwan.

Citing remarks by US President Bill Clinton that Taiwan and mainland China should resolve their disputes peacefully, Bush repeated that Washington will not force Taiwan to conduct negotiations with the mainland nor act as an intermediator between the two sides.

Considering the issue from a long-term prospective, Bush said, Taiwan security will be better safeguarded if it settles its disputes with the mainland. But he added that this does not mean that Taiwan should fully give in to mainland China's terms, while the mainland should also behave itself.

According to the AIT chairman, the United States has repeatedly urged the mainland China to explain the benefits of reunification to the people of Taiwan, rather than deploying missiles aimed at Taiwan or issuing sternly-worded statements to the island. Such conduct will only increase fears and resentment among the Taiwan people toward Beijing and damage bilateral links, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: GOOD TIES MORE IMPORTANT THAN NAME CHANGE: AIT HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, April 1 (CNA) (By Hui-Yen Chang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Maintaining good ties between the peoples of Taiwan and the United States is more important than changing the name of Taiwan's representation in America, said American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Chairman Richard Bush on Saturday.

Bush said the AIT has maintained very good relations with Taiwanese living across the United States and that is much more important than changing the name of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Offices (TECO) scattered in this country.
According to Bush, he had not previously heard a proposal that the Taiwan representation's name be changed into "Taiwan Economic and Cultural Office."

The AIT chief made the remarks while answering questions on the issue from W. C. Feng, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Houston. He flew here from Washington to give a speech to a Taiwan-US association at the invitation of Feng.

As to Taiwan's efforts to join the World Trade Organization (WTO), the leading US representative official in dealings with Taiwan said that the US' stance on this front is that Taiwan should be admitted into the WTO if the island completes all necessary preparations.
While expressing his belief that Taiwan's WTO membership should not be attached to other conditions, he acknowledged that other WTO member states may have a different viewpoint.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 3, or the 29th day of the second month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1682: Bartolome Esteban Murillo, Spanish painter of genre scenes, portraits, and religious subjects such as "Immaculate Conception," dies at the age of 65.
1862: Sir James Clark Ross, British polar explorer who located the magnetic north pole in 1831, dies at the age of 62. On an Antarctic expedition (1839-1843), he discovered Victoria Island and the Ross Sea.
1783: Washington Irving, American historian and author of short stories, including "Rip Van Winkle," is born.
1859: The Hsiahai Chenghwang Temple, one of the oldest temples in Taiwan, is formally inaugurated in Taipei.
1881: Alcide de Gasperi, the Italian statesman who became prime minister in 1945 and led Italy during its successful post-war reconstruction, is born.
1882: Jesse James, head of the notorious outlaw James Gang and mastermind of countless bank and train robberies, is gunned down by Robert Ford, one of his own gang, at his home in St. Joseph, Missouri.
1897: German composer Johannes Brahms dies in Vienna at the age of 64. His works, which blended classical tradition with the new romantic impulse, include concertos, symphonies, chamber music, and choral compositions.
1898: Henry Luce, the American publisher who founded Time, Life, and Fortune magazines, is born.
1903: Chou Jung, author of "The Revolutionary Army," dies in jail in Shanghai at the age of 21.
1922: Joseph Stalin is appointed general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party.
1924: Doris Day, the American actress and singer who delighted audiences with musicals such as "Young at Heart," "The Pajama Game," and "Calamity Jane," is born.
1924: Marlon Brando, the American actor who won Oscars for "On the Waterfront" and "The Godfather," is born.
1930: Helmut Kohl, the German chancellor who stayed in power for a record 16 years until his defeat by Gerhard Schroeder in 1998, is born.
1933: Four Britons in two Westland biplanes make the first flight over the peak of Mount Everest in the Himalayas.
1936: Bruno Haupmann, a German-born carpenter, goes to the electric chair in the US for the kidnapping and murder of the 20-month-old baby son of aviation hero Charles Lindbergh and his wife Anne.
1946: Directed by the Soviet Union, the so-called "Inner Mongolian Autonomy Movement Committee," is established in Chengteh, Jehol Province.
1948: US President Harry Truman signs the Marshall Plan, allocating US$6 billion in aid to 16 European countries to help reconstruction after World War II.
1961: Eddie Murphy, American comedian and film star, is born.
1962: President and Mme. Philbert Tsiranana of the Republic of Madagascar arrive in Taipei for a six-day state visit.
1964: The Dalai Lama establishes a Tibetan office in New York.
1971: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with the Republic of Cameroon.
1973: The International Federation of Asian and Western Pacific Contractors Association opens its 12th convention in Taipei.
1975: S. K Chow, minister of state, leaves for Riyadh to express the condolences of the Chinese government in the death of King Faisal.
1975: The Free China Relief Association marks its 25th anniversary.
1975: The ROC Control Yuan passes a resolution impeaching Hsu Chi-wei, commissioner of the Department of Education under the Taiwan Provincial Government.
1976: An 11-member Japanese Diet mission including former Prime Minister Nobusuke Kishi, arrives in Taipei to mark the first anniversary of the death of President Chiang Kai-shek.
1976: Dr. Montanaro, Paraguayan minister of the Interior, arrives in Taipei for President Chiang's memorial services.
1982: Bueno Aires celebrates the invasion of the Falkland Islands while the United Nations says Argentina must pull out.
1991: Martha Graham, American dancer and choreographer, dies at the age of 97. A central figure in modern dance, she founded the Dance Repertory Theatre in New York City in 1930.
1992: Two weeks after a non-communist parliament is elected, Albanian President Ramiz Alia resigns.
1996: A plane carrying US Commerce Secretary Ron Brown crashes in stormy weather on a hillside outside Dubrovnik, Croatia, killing all 33 aboard.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A man of strong, resolute, simple character approaches closely the true moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S PCB MANUFACTURERS MOVE PRODUCTION ABROAD TO LOWER COSTS
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 3 (CNA) (By Kevin F. and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Among Taiwan's major electronics products, PCBs (printed circuit boards) have been one of the leading foreign exchange earners, but rising production costs and a growing local environmental consciousness have led many PCB manufacturers to move their production lines out of Taiwan, with many choosing mainland China as their new site.

Taiwan's electronics industry began producing PCBs in the 1970s, and the island has become one of the world's leading sources of supply. As a labor-intensive processing industry, the PCB sector needs to either expand its production capacity or elevate its production technology to lower production costs.

Many of the medium and small-sized PCB factories in Taiwan, because of limited research and development resources, tended to lower their production costs mainly by boosting production capacity. This expansion has inevitably led to overproduction and has caused cut-throat competition. Since production costs in Taiwan are comparatively higher than those in neighboring countries, Taiwan's PCB manufacturers have sought to move their plants out of the country.

Another reason for these manufacturers moving production out of Taiwan is a growing environmental consciousness among local people who have begun to demand that waste water produced by PCB manufacturers be properly processed.

Because of the high costs of investing in environmental protection facilities, many of Taiwan's PCB manufacturers have chosen to move their production plants to countries with cheap labor and lower production costs while keeping their R&D and marketing divisions in Taiwan.

Among the leading PCB manufacturers, Compeq Manufacturing Co., WU's Printed circuit Board Manufacturing Co., Chin-Poon Industrial Co., Gold Circuit Electronics, Elite Material Co., Cadac Electronics Co., Unicap Electronics Industrial Co., Wertex Precision Electronics Co., Ya Hsin Industrial Co., Uniplus Electronics Co., and Csun Manufacturing Ltd. have all set up plants in mainland China. The mainland market has absorbed a considerable amount of these plants' output.

Southeast Asia is another choice for Taiwan's PCB manufacturers wanting to move their production lines closer to the market. Qualitek Electronics Co., for example, has invested NT$300 million in building a PCB plant in Malaysia. The PCBs produced at that plant supply telecommunications device manufacturers, including Motorola.

At present, not every manufacturer that has moved their production to mainland China is making profit, so they have applied the same strategy of boosting production capacity in order to lower production costs that they did in Taiwan years ago. This strategy will likely be effective given the enormous potential of the mainland market.

DOC.HEADLINE: US MISSILE SYSTEM CALLED `HIGH-TECH HAMMER FOR ROGUE FLEAS'

TEXT.P: A Canadian analyst on Sunday called US plans to spend US$13 billion on an anti-missile system "a high-tech hammer for a few rogue fleas."

Eric Margolis, foreign editor for the Toronto Sun, said the mushrooming folly called NMD, or National Missile Defense, makes about as much strategic sense as building a second Maginot Line along the Texas border to defend the US against invasion by Guatemala or El Salvador.
NMDs is to consist of 100 interceptor missiles and ground-based radars, plus a constellation of space-based warning and targeting satellites, he said.

The program has powerful backers in Congress, the military, and in industrial circles. America's NATO allies, the Persian Gulf emirates, and Japan are being pressed to participate in this scaled down version of the Star Wars program, he pointed out.
Canada, joined at the hip to the US through NORAD, the North American Air Defense Command, is under particular pressure, he added.

Margolis said NMD technology remains unproved, with only one questionably successful test in a string of failures. But leaving aside the difficulty of hitting an incoming warhead in space, what makes this concept so harebrained is what military men call "threat assessment."

According to NMD proponents, "rogue states" - Iran, Iraq, Libya, North Korea, Sudan, Afghanistan, and possibly Syria- may develop long-range missiles (ICBMs) capable of hitting North America. With the important exception of North Korea, such claims are preposterous and comical, Margolis said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BUSINESS AND INDUSTRIAL SECTORS ATTACH HIGH EXPECTATIONS TO CHEN

TEXT.P: Most members of Taiwan's business and industrial sectors have attached great expectations to President-elect Chen Shui-bian and his potential for helping accelerate the country's economic development after he is inaugurated.

Business and industrial sources said it is believed that Chen's election as the new president of the Republic of China will help expedite the implementation of major financial and industrial policies and thus will be conducive to a positive and long-term revitalization of the country's overall economy.

The proposed high-speed railway plan and the recently-approved "mini direct links" with mainland China are considered two centerpieces of the new government scheduled to take office on May 20, the sources noted.

Hsieh Shih-fang, president of Procomp Technology, said Chen's election would have a "negative impact on the business and industrial sectors in the short term but would become beneficial in the long run."
Hsieh estimated that Chen, from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), will try his utmost to change the stereotyped view of himself as an opposition leader after he takes office.
Hsieh said Chen will probably be low-key in his style as the head of state, at least for the urgent purpose of easing cross-strait tensions and for broadening his base of support.

Universal Scientific Industrial Chairman H.P. Chang said he hopes Chen will always put the nation's interests ahead of all other considerations and always bear in mind the future of the people and the country as well.

For the sake of the sustainable development of science and technology industries, which are now backbone of Taiwan's economic growth, Chang said the new government should accelerate moves to induce more talented Chinese from abroad to return to Taiwan to help raise the island's competitiveness in world markets.

An executive of Accton Technology urged Chen to put his high tech policy promises introduced in his white paper into action. He noted that one of Chen's promises included establishing a ministry of science and technology under the Cabinet.

The Ministry of Science and Technology, if established, will not only help Taiwan develop its high-tech and related industries, but will also provide these industries with formal channels to communicate with the government, the executive said.
Voices from the petrochemical industry, meanwhile, expressed concerns about the timetable for the implementation of the "mini direct links" with mainland China.

Noting that about 30 percent to 40 percent of all of Taiwan's petrochemical products, including PVC, PP and PE products, have been absorbed by mainland China over the past several years, leaders of the petrochemical industry said direct shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China are critically important for the survival and sustainable development of this sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES SAID BIGGEST CHALLENGE TO NEW ROC ADMINISTRATION
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 2 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The biggest challenge President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new administration faces will be the handling of cross-Taiwan Strait relations, scholars from Taiwan and the United States agreed in a seminar in New York on Sunday.
Chen Wen-yen of the US-based Formosan Association for Public Affairs stressed that Chen's major challenge will be how to ensure freedom and democracy in Taiwan despite pressure from mainland China.

Chen also said that the future of Taiwan will be decided by the people of Taiwan, and that it will be dangerous for the US to try to force Chen to accept the "one China" principle espoused by the mainland.

Cheng F. Lee, financial expert and a professor at Rutgers State University in New Jersey, said that Taiwan should not rashly lift its present ban on the "three direct links" -- trade, post, and transport -- with the mainland, saying the links should be established slowly and with patience.

He said the establishment of the "three links" will result in the loss of more than half of Taiwan's foreign reserves, which stand at more than NT$100 billion, adding that the amount of Taiwan's investments on the mainland is already too much.

Professor Kuo Chien-chung of Tamkang University noted that Chen, although from the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, has sounded conciliatory notes since winning the March 18 presidential election.

Kuo said that after Chen's inauguration, more urgent questions will be related to trade and investment with the mainland. These include whether he will continue to follow the present "go slow, be patient" policy toward investment on the mainland and also the question of political and economic contacts with the mainland after both Taipei and Beijing enter the World Trade Organization.

Kuo also said that a credible triangular relation between the US, mainland China, and Taiwan has to be established in order to help improve cross-strait relations. He added that Chen should also use all available channels to maintain contact with the mainland.

Kao Ying-mao of Brown University suggested that both sides put aside their dispute over the "one China" issue and focus on the maintenance of prosperity and stability on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Kao said that it is important for the two sides to continue to have dialogue and maintain contact and that talks should be "flexible and serious." He also said that he was glad to see the DPP support second track talks, even third track talks, to try to break the cross-strait stalemate.

Taipei's Straits Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait are the two intermediary bodies currently entrusted with conducting cross-strait talks. The talks, however, were suspended after Beijing reacted furiously to President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as "special state-to-state relations" in July 1999.

Kao criticized mainland China's assessment and strategy concerning the Taiwan issue, saying that Taiwan does not rule out unification with the mainland. He also stated the direct links with the mainland will only be achieved one step at a time.
He also noted that leaders in Beijing do not feel there is an urgent need for unification, but they do have to deal with pressure from within.

He said that Taiwan should adjust its traditional defense strategy to one of "intimidation" and also make the development of cruise missiles more of a priority, adding that Taiwan would also have to declare that it would not use the weapons first.
Kao also stressed that the US should not dance with Beijing's "one China" principle and not let the mainland dictate what it wants to do.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC ADMINISTRATION TO HONOR ARMS AGREEMENTS WITH US
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 2 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A visiting official of the Republic of China's Democratic Progressive Party said on Sunday that the new administration will honor any international agreements or contracts signed by the previous administration, including its military purchases with the United States.
Chiou I-jen, DPP representative to the US, made the remarks as he prepared to wind up his visit to the United States, which took him to Los Angeles, Washington D. C. and New York.

But Chiou said that he does not know if the US will sell advanced Aegis radar-equipped warships to Taiwan or about the situation regarding the present ROC administration's military purchases from the US.
Chiou said the policy of the new administration of Chen Shui-bian will be continuous and that Chen will honor any agreements reached by the previous government.

On reports in the New York Times that the mainland China is considering a possible compromise, meaning that talks would take place under the "one China" umbrella, but each side would define "China" in its own way, Chiou said that the news has yet to be confirmed.

He also said that Chen's approach and statements since his election victory have won a positive response from the US. But he would not say that tensions don't exist across the Taiwan Strait now, adding that Taiwan has made efforts to reduce tensions and that he hopes the mainland will do the same.

Chiou said that he met with lawmakers, officials, and members of US think tanks during his visit. He stressed that this was a routine visit, saying that he has come to the US seven times since assuming the post of DPP representative to the US.
Though Chiou has kept a low profile since his arrival on March 27, it is believed that he has carried messages from Chen and has tried to establish communication channels between Chen and the US.

DOC.HEADLINE: NOBEL LAUREATE'S CROSS-STRAIT AFFAIRS AD HOC GROUP BEGINS OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The supra-party ad hoc committee on cross-strait affairs chaired by Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh convened its inaugural meeting on Monday.

Lee's group is expected to discuss the latest cross-strait relations in the wake of Taiwan's presidential election and make its initial analysis so as to provide President-elect Chen Shui-bian with a clearer picture of the situation. Chen will then be able to refer to this analysis in formulating his cross-strait policies, sources closed to Lee said.

In his speech marking the election, President-elect Chen said that easing tension and seeking stable relations with mainland China are the top priorities among all the policies of his new government. Chen also said that he will push for direct trade, transport and communications links with mainland China before the end of this year.
Lee's ad hoc committee is expected to be the major advisory body to Chen on shaping Taiwan's cross-strait policies.

Apparently poised to replace part of the functions of the existing cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, Lee's committee is vitally important, particularly under Beijing's current insistence that cross-strait dialogue be resumed only under the "one China" prerequisite, the sources said.

Lee, the Nobel Prize winner for chemistry in 1986, has declined Chen's offer to head the new administration as premier and has said that he would like to keep his status as "neutral" in his capacity as president of Taiwan's highest research institute, Academia Sinica. However, he indeed promised Chen that he would contribute his wisdom and time to help solve cross-strait problems.
However, as of Monday, the ad hoc cross-strait committee was not fully organized yet as formal membership and their job descriptions had yet to be settled, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: 8.4 MILLION CC OF DONATED BLOOD DISCARDED ANNUALLY DUE TO FAT LEVELS

TEXT.P: Doctors on Monday warned Taiwan's potential blood donors not to eat too much fat in their daily diets, otherwise they may easily be disqualified from donating, sources from the Chinese Blood Services Foundation said.

Officials from the Chinese Blood Services Foundation, which runs the only official blood bank in Taiwan, said because donated blood is sometimes found to be "too fatty," the foundation must throw out an average of 8.4 million cc of donated blood every year.
The figure is equivalent to the donations of some 30,000 people who donated their blood in vain because the blood extracted from their veins was unusable, Foundation officials said.
Doctors suggested that when planning to donate blood, potential donors should consume less food containing high fat levels for one to two weeks before giving blood.

The foundation's analysis also found that blood containing high levels of lipids, a group of organic compounds that includes fats, oils, waxes, sterols and triglycerides, tends to appear in blood donated by male donors.

This hyperlipoproteinemic blood also tends to appear during wintertime. The analysts believe that the Taiwanese' habit of eating rich foods during the winter season is the major reason for the "fatty" blood.

In the meantime, the blood foundation called for potential blood donors not to make the donations if they were not healthy enough. It said people should refrain from donating blood if they have had their teeth removed within the previous 72 hours, and should never donate if they have heart disease, hypertension, asthma and even influenza.
Alcoholics, drug abusers, syphilis patients, HIV carriers and AIDS patients are of course definitely prohibited from making such donations, foundation officials assured.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG, LEGISLATORS TO DISCUSS LAW ON DEFENSE & DEFENSE ORGANIZATION

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Monday that he will invite legislators to a dinner party in the near future for the discussion of defense law and organizations law of the defense ministry, adding that the meeting will have nothing to do with the formation of the new Cabinet.

Tang, a senior member of the current ruling Kuomintang (KMT), has been President-elect Chen Shui-bian's choice for premier in the new Cabinet. However, Tang is still waiting for the approval of the KMT's Central Standing Committee (CSC) before accepting the offer.
Tang has repeatedly made clear that he would not head the new administration without the consent of the KMT.
The KMT will to decide during a CSC meeting on Friday whether to let him accept the premiership offered by Chen, Tang said.

After the president-elect's surprise offer for Tang to take the post as the premier of his new administration last Wednesday, KMT Acting Chairman Lien Chan convened an ad hoc CSC meeting to discuss the issue, but no decision has been reached to date.
The KMT has demanded that Tang and not Chen decide members of the Cabinet, a proposition the president-elect has dismissed as impossible.

Tang told the press that until the KMT decides under what conditions he could assume the premiership, it would be premature to talk about issues related to the "formation of a Cabinet" or "joining the Cabinet."
Tang stressed that he has made his stance clear to both Chen and the KMT, and he believed that the KMT CSC will make a decision soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP MAY NOT RULE OUT 'ONE CHINA' PRINCIPLE: PARTY CADRE

TEXT.P: The Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) needs to understand the content of Beijing's "one China" principle before considering to reopen talks with the mainland under the current framework, a ranking DPP official said on Monday.

Hsiao Bi-khim, director of the DPP's International Affairs Department, said the DPP may not rule out the possibility of accepting Beijing's demands to rekindle talks under the "one China principle," but added that it first must gain a deeper understanding of the "one China" framework drafted by Beijing.

Hsiao made the remarks in response to recent media reports that mainland China is willing to reopen negotiations with Taiwan if Taiwan accepts the "one China" principle agreed upon by both sides in 1992 -- there is only "one China" in the world, but the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can have its own interpretation of the meaning of the term.
