Pointing out that the reports about Beijing's stance were very encouraging to the DPP, she said the top priority for Taiwan and mainland China at present is to build mutual trust and strengthen bilateral communication in order to lay a sound foundation for future exchanges.
The DPP will become Taiwan's ruling party after President-elect Chen Shui-bian is inaugurated as the Republic of China's tenth president on May 20.
Chen's victory in the March 18 presidential election brought an end to the Kuomintang's five-decade long rule in Taiwan.

Echoing remarks made by Chen, Hsiao went on to say that the DPP views the "one China" principle as an issue which requires further discussion by both sides to see whether it would produce any benefit for people on the two sides across the Taiwan Strait.
Hsiao also expressed the hope that both Taiwan and mainland China can be more flexible in exchanging opinions so as to find common ground to compromise and conciliate.

Turning to the "special state-to-state relationship" theory aired by President Lee Teng-hui in July 1999 to describe the links between the two sides, Hsiao reiterated that the theory is just a description of the current status-quo between Taiwan and mainland China and that the DPP will not amend the Constitution to include it.

American Institute in Taiwan Chairman Richard Bush, the leading US liaison official in charge of the United States' dealings with Taiwan, also suggested at a Saturday seminar in Dallas that both Taiwan and the mainland should try to find new terms acceptable to both in order to serve as a foundation to restart bilateral talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4.3-MAGNITUDE QUAKE HITS CENTRAL TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake with a magnitude measuring 4.3 on the open-ended Richter scale the hit middle region of Taiwan at 10:43 a.m. on Monday, according to officials of the Central Weather Bureau (CWB).

The temblor occurred 17.6 kilometers west of Sun Moon Lake at 23.89 degrees north latitude and 120.73 degrees east longitude. It originated 7.5 kilometers beneath the earth's surface, said the CWB officials.

The quake had an intensity level of 5 in the village of Ming-chien in Nantou County, 3 in Li-Yu Tang of Hualien County, 2 in the cities of Changhua and Dou-liou, while Yunlin County and Chiayi City registered an intensity of 1, bureau officials added.
The magnitude of an earthquake is a measure of the amount of energy released by a quake, while the intensity indicates the strength of the temblor at various distances from the epicenter.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S EXPORTS OF HI-TECH PRODUCTS UP 50 PERCENT IN TEN YEARS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's exports of hi-tech products between 1990 and 1999 showed an increase of more than 50 percent, according to a report revealed Monday by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.
The report on research and analysis on trade development in Taiwan during the ten-year period was made by Prof. Chen Po-chih of National Taiwan University at the request from the BOFT.
The study found that:
--The proportion of labor-intensive export products decreased from 41 percent in 1990 to 35 percent in 1999.
--The ratio of capital-intensive export products increased from 51 percent to 64 percent during the ten-year period.
--The proportion of technology-intensive products increased from 27 percent of exports in 1990 to 42 percent of 1999's total.

Chen Ching-ho, an official of the BOFT, pointed out that the study shows that the structure of the ROC's export industry is developing toward an increased emphasis on less labor intensive, more capital-intensive and hi-tech products.

At the same time, he said, the quality of human resources has also shown a marked increase as employees with college educations and higher levels of education have increased from 16 percent of Taiwan's workforce ten years ago to 26 percent at the present.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN EXCHANGES VIEWS WITH BUDDHIST LEADER ON RECONSTRUCTION WORK
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, Eastern Taiwan, April 3 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian visited Master Shih Cheng Yen, founder of the Tzuchi Buddhist Compassionate Relief Association, in Hualien on Monday.
Their hour-long talks focused on post-earthquake reconstruction work, which had been affected by the recently-held presidential election.

Chen noted that he will order continued reconstruction work immediately after he assumes the presidency on May 20, and went on to say that his policy adviser Lee Yuan-tseh has proposed to name a minister without portfolio to take charge of efforts to rebuild.
Shih Cheng Yen said that measures must be taken to soothe the psychological impact that the quake had on its victims and to help rebuild their confidence as soon as possible.

She stressed that well-trained talent is the hope of society, and that the country's hopes rest on education. Therefore, priority must be given to reconstruction of educational institutions, including rebuilding damaged schools.

Chen asked the Tzuchi founder how to heal social wounds inflicted during the heated presidential election. Shih responded, "We have to love other people with true love, and to appreciate the merits of others."
"As the leader of the state, it is important to serve as model in speech and action," she further advised Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S TOP NEGOTIATOR WITH TAIPEI WON'T ATTEND CHEN'S INAUGURAL

TEXT.P: Beijing's top negotiator with Taiwan will not attend the inauguration of the Republic of China's President-elect Chen Shui-bian on May 20, the Hong Kong-based Wen Hui Pao daily quoted a mainland Chinese official as reporting Monday.

Chen said after his victory in the March 18 presidential election that it would be conducive to the development of cross-strait relations if Wang Daohan, chairman of mainland China's Association for Relations Across Taiwan Strait, were to come to Taiwan on May 20 to attend his inauguration.
The mainland Chinese official said that no matter what national name Taiwan uses during the inaugural ceremony, "We will not attend."

The official indicated that Chen has not yet definitely recognized the one-China principle and that the Democratic Progressive Party that Chen belongs to has not yet abandoned its Taiwan-independence platform. These are the main factors that hinder the resumption of cross-strait talks on the unification of China, he said.
He reiterated that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must engage in exchanges under the one-China principle.

Chen has extended an olive branch to Beijing by nominating the caretaker Kuomintang government's Defense Minister Tang Fei as the head of the new cabinet. The move is also seen as an effort to alleviate fears of Taiwan's population that Beijing would stage a military attack due to Chen's past support of Taiwan independence.

However, Chen recently remarked that "one-China" should be a subject to be discussed with Beijing, not a prerequisite to a renewed dialogue. His remark is seen as complicating efforts to break the impasse between Taipei and Beijing over the resumption of talks on unification.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTH AFRICAN PRESIDENT TO ATTEND EU-AFRICA SUMMIT IN CAIRO

TEXT.P: President Thabo Mbeki left here for Egypt on Sunday to participate as the head of the South African delegation to the EU-Africa summit to be held in Cairo on Monday and Tuesday.

Foreign Minister Nkosazana Dlamini-Zuma, who is part of Mbeki's delegation, said before departing that South Africa wants the EU-Africa summit to produce both a new tone in relations between the two continents and a road map for future cooperation.
"What we'd like is that their (EU) interests must coincide with our interests," she said.
The first-ever EU-Africa summit is aimed at forging a new partnership between the European Union and Africa and putting the bitter legacy of colonialism behind the two sides.
Commenting on the meeting, the South African foreign minister said, "It's important to identify issues that both sides feel strongly about, and then engage around those issues."

Fifty-three African and 15 EU countries will take part in the two-day summit. It is hoped that the meeting will enable all sides to work out ways to bridge disagreements on how to rid Africa of its massive debts, return looted treasures by past colonial countries and resolve other problems.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA GOVT. TO CONTINUE WITH PEACE TALKS, ADMINISTRATION MAINTAINS

TEXT.P: The Estrada administration has reassured Mindanao residents that will continue to pursue the peace process with rebel groups such as the Moro Islamic Liberation Front (MILF).

Presidential Peace Process Adviser Manuel Yan said that the government is now paving the way for the resumption of formal talks with the MILF scheduled for May 2. "We are going on as scheduled. The technical working group is meeting," Yan said in a radio interview.

He added that the recent skirmishes between MILF and government troops have not been a deterrent to the peace process, which President Joseph Ejercito Estrada wants completed before the end of the year. "We are still going on with the peace talks," Yan said.
Last Thursday, Estrada told reporters in Tacloban City that he is confident that the government can reach a peace accord with the MILF within the year.

Mr. Estrada added that he had received a message from MILF Chairman Hashim Salamat which said that he wants to develop Mindanao while the government and MILF discuss peace. "We will continue with the peace process and advance the development of Mindanao with the MILF," Estrada said.
The President noted that this has given him added inspiration to ignore his critics' brickbats, and concentrate instead on developing Mindanao into the country's next food basket.

According to the President, he is now waiting for Salamat's formal word that the MILF would join hands with the government in developing Mindanao. Earlier, the President received a similar commitment from Salamat that said the MILF will cooperate with the government's ongoing programs to develop Mindanao.
Mr. Estrada said his administration is likely to line up programs such as infrastructure for irrigation projects, schoolrooms and hospitals.

Once these programs are completed, Mr. Estrada said, investors are expected to go to Mindanao and generate jobs for the residents there. Such a development, he pointed out, would complement ongoing government efforts to transform Mindanao into the nation's food basket through integrated plans for agricultural modernization.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S SUGAR OUTPUT UNABLE TO MEET TARGET DUE TO FLOODING

TEXT.P: Australia's sugar production in 2000 is expected fail to reach the industry's original target of 5.5 million tons because of flooding and large scale damage caused by Cyclone Steve. However, its exports to Taiwan and other countries will not be affected, according to the Queensland Sugar Corporation in Brisbane.

In a news release faxed to the CNA on Monday, QSC executive director Ian White said that despite the shortfall, Australia's sugar production this year will reach about 5 million tons, up from 4.9 million tons in 1999.
Australia's sugar producers this year are facing a slump in world sugar prices, which have tumbled to a 14-year low, a situation which is expected to remain throughout this year, White said.
He said exports to major Australian markets will not be affected by the shortfall in production. Indeed, there will be increases to some markets, including the Middle East.

Taiwan is considered a large potential market and Australia wants to increase its shipments to the island due to the strength of Taiwan's purchasing power, a spokeswoman said. In 1999, Australia exported about US$10 million worth of sugar to Taiwan, down from US$13 million in 1998.
Australia exports about 80 percent of its sugar production and Queensland produces more than 95 percent of the country's total output.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MAGISTRATE ARRIVES IN ASUNCION FOR VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, Paraguay, April 2 (CNA) (By Raymond Huang and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien arrived in Asuncion on Sunday for a visit to the South American country.
Yu and his entourage were warmly welcomed by the governor of the Central Province and other Paraguayan officials as well as overseas Chinese upon their arrival at the airport.
The mayor of Luque City presented the "Key to Luque City" to Yu at the airport.
Yu said at a press conference held at the airport that the main purpose for his visit to Paraguay was to establish a sisterly ties between Kaohsiung County and Paraguay's Central Province.

In addition to attending the ceremony for the signing of the sisterly relationship, scheduled to be held on Monday morning, he will also study the feasibility of Kaohsiung County businessmen investing in Paraguay, Yu said. He added that after returning to Kaohsiung he will encourage businessmen in his county to form a delegation to fly to Paraguay to seek trade opportunities in the country.
Yu said he will, on behalf of Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian, invite Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi to travel to Taipei to attend Chen's inauguration on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG CHIEF EXECUTIVE DENOUNCES TAIWAN INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 3 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Calling Taiwan independence a "road to nowhere", Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa urged Taiwan's leader on Sunday to open negotiations with mainland China on peaceful unification with the theory of "one China" as a principle.

Speaking to leaders of Chinese community in Toronto during a trip to Canada, the head of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region under The People's Republic of China strayed from his prepared speech to comment on Taiwan's dispute with mainland China. The cross-strait controversy flared anew recently after a candidate from a pro-independence party was elected president in Taiwan on March 18.

"As the chief executive of Hong Kong, I should devote my energy to my job. But as a Chinese person, I cannot help be concerned with the future of Taiwan and Chinese reunification, as are all my fellow countrymen," said Tung who has rarely stepped into the thorny controversy between Taiwan and mainland China since he took the helm in Hong Kong in 1997.

"It is the common hope of all Chinese that their country will be reunified as soon as possible. I believe it is a wish harbored by all Chinese. Taiwan independence is a road that would lead to nowhere but war," he said.

"No one would like war - a peaceful reunification is the right way to go. I heartily hope Taiwan's leaders will realize this, and come to terms with reality as early as possible. Anything could be raised for discussion with Beijing if only Taiwan admits there is one China," he added.

"As for Hong Kong, I think it is my duty to fully carry out the 'one country, two systems' formula that Beijing devised for national reunification, and make Hong Kong an example to convince Taiwan that this formula does work," said Tung.
The Hong Kong leader brushed aside earlier reports that Taiwan might fire missiles at Hong Kong in retaliation for a Beijing missile attack against Taiwan.

"I think there is no question of Taiwan's missile attacks against Hong Kong. This report was ascribed to Liu Tai-ying, chairman of the Business Management Committee under Taiwan's Kuomintang, who made these irresponsible remarks while visiting Thailand late last year," he said.

He also played down the possible ill effects on Hong Kong of Taiwan's proposed direct trade links between its offshore islands and mainland China, saying that many mainland ports have long opened direct trade links with foreign countries, and that Hong Kong has not been the gateway to China for a long time.
Taiwan has thus far banned direct trade and transportation with mainland China. Transportation of goods and personnel between the two sides are made through Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT AGREES TO LET TANG SERVE AS CHEN'S PREMIER

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said on Monday that the KMT has agreed to let Defense Minister Tang Fei serve as President-elect Chen Shui-bian's premier in his "personal capacity."
During his tenure as premier, Lin noted, Tang will continue to be a KMT member, but he has to suspend his party activities within the KMT.

Lin said that once an application is presented to the KMT by Chen or Tang, the party will issue a formal announcement by himself or Acting Chairman Lien Chan, allowing Tang to become the first premier of the Democratic Progressive Party president.
Chen won the March 18 presidential election, ending the 54-year KMT reign on the island. He has decided to appoint Tang, a KMT member for 48 years, as premier.
Lin told reporters that in consideration of the interests of the country and the people, the KMT will agree to let Tang to serve as Chen's premier.
A KMT official said that the formula that allows Tang to join the DPP administration will be applied to other KMT members who might be recruited to the new government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S MAJOR PROJECT INVESTMENT IN FIRST QUARTER TOPS US$ 9.9 BILLION

TEXT.P: Taiwan's investment in major projects in the first quarter this year totaled NT$307.2 billion (US$9.9 billion), according to statistics released by the Economics Ministry on Monday.
A major project is defined as one that surpasses NT$200 million (US$6.45 million).

The statistics showed that in the January-March period, a total of 118 major investment projects were approved by the Economics Ministry, with the power-generating and electronic machinery industries taking the lead.

The Economics Ministry started to encourage the civil sector to make investments in major projects in 1996. The total amount of investment is expected to reach NT$3,077.7 billion (US$99.3 billion) in the coming few years.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANILA OFFICIAL DENIES RUMORS OF UPCOMING CHEN VISIT

TEXT.P: The Philippines will not play host to Taiwanese President-elect Chen Shui-bian before he takes the oath of office on May 20, Foreign Affairs Secretary Domingo Siazon Jr. said Monday.

Earlier, a foreign affairs official who requested anonymity claimed that there were groups in the Philippines who were rushing to prepare for a Chen visit before his inaugural, as Chen is still legally a private citizen, and could be allowed to enter the country.

Siazon said the decision to not host Chen would prevent any damage that a Chen visit would cause Manila's relations with Beijing. The Philippines adheres to a one-China policy and thus Taiwanese leaders are not granted visas to enter the country.
The secretary said that Beijing's Ambassador Fu Ying requested the Philippines to refuse to allow any visit by Chen.

"They just want us to keep out of the issue between China and Taiwan. I understand that we want to have a positive contribution to cross strait relations because we will be affected if they get worse. We don't want to aggravate the situation," Siazon stressed.
Siazon said Beijing merely wanted to guard against a Chen visit to the country, despite denials from Chinese businessmen and the Taiwanese carrier Eva Airways that any such plan existed.

"He's a president-elect and our role here is to contribute in calming and improving the situation the Taiwan Strait. We don't want to be players in the domestic internal problems between China and Taiwan," Siazon said.
The secretary said the country already has enough domestic problems, and doesn't need to add to them by hosting Chen.
Siazon also said Chen is hardly a private citizen even if he has yet to take his oath, since he is a president-elect.
Chen, who ran as head of the opposition Democratic Progressive Party, was elected president in an upset on March 18.

Foreign affairs officials said soon after Chen's election, Beijing summoned the Philippines Ambassador to China, Romualdo Ong, while Beijing Embassy charge d'affaires Sun Heping called on the authorities in Manila.

Both meetings were reportedly for the purpose of relaying mainland China's policies, which included its opposition to a Chen visit to Manila. Beijing also requested the Manila government to refrain from sending any congratulatory messages to the new administration, and to refrain from sending a representative to attend Chen's presidential inauguration in Taipei.

Beijing is extremely suspicious of Chen because his party supports independence for Taiwan, a move that mainland China has warned would lead to war. The two sides of the Taiwan Strait split after a civil war in 1949, and mainland China has repeatedly threatened use force to affect a reunification.
Chen is a former Taipei Mayor who lost office to a Nationalist Party challenger in 1998. He is untested in the international arena where he will face growing pressure to negotiate with Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE CONVEYS SYMPATHIES TO AILING JAPANESE PRIME MINISTER

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui expressed his sympathies to ailing Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi on Monday after Obuchi was hospitalized after suffering a stroke.
In a telegraph to be relayed by Taipei's representative office in Tokyo, Lee expressed his sympathies for Obuchi's illness and wished him a quick recovery.

Premier Vincent Siew, Minister of Foreign Affairs Che Chien-jen, and Lin Chin-chin, president of the Association of East Asian Relations, a semi-official agency responsible for dealing with Japan in the absence of diplomatic ties, also extended their wishes for Obuchi's speedy recovery to their Japan counterparts via the same representative office.

Obuchi went to see the doctor early Sunday after falling ill from overwork. He was diagnosed with having suffered a stroke and went into a coma Monday afternoon, according to his Chief Cabinet Secretary Mikio Aoki.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT STARTS NOMINATING CANDIDATES FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang, which lost its 54-year reign of power to the Democratic Progressive Party in the March 18 presidential election, on Monday started nominating candidates for the May 6 National Assembly election.
The nominations for 18 counties and cities were completed on the first day, with 87 candidates running for the 168 seats allocated for these areas.
The candidates for the seven other counties and cities, as well as those for the nationwide constituency, overseas Chinese communities and aboriginal regions will be decided on Tuesday.

Three central government officials have been nominated to run for the election. They are Chao Yi, director-general of the Government Information Office; Wei Duan, director general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics and Charles Wu, vice chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Japanese Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi in stroke-induced coma; Chief Cabinet Secretary Mikio Aoki acting prime minister.
The China Times:
Kuomintang agrees to let Tang Fei form cabinet as an individual.
The United Daily News:
Obuchi in coma; Chief Cabinet Secretary takes over his duties.
The Liberty Times:
Obuchi on artificial respirator.
The China Post:
Obuchi lapses into coma.
The Taiwan News:
KMT to let Tang serve as premier.
The Taipei Times:
Military has plans to go professional.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NOT FAIRLY TREATED SAYS ROC REPRESENTATIVE TO US
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 3 (CNA) (By K. C. Huang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's representative to the United States said that "there is a kind of unfairness" in the treatment Taiwan receives even though it is "a model student for freedom, democracy and a market economy."
Stephen Chen, the director of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Representative Office, made the remarks in an interview published in the New York Times on Monday.
"We don't mind if the United States has rapprochement with mainland China -- we think it's good to bring the PRC into the family of civilization," said Chen.
But the 66-year-old diplomat said what "we ask is that the interests of Taiwan not be sacrificed."

The report said that Chen represents the interests of 22 million of the freest and richest people in Asia, but as the US maintains no diplomatic relations with Taiwan and has recognized the Beijing government as the sole representative of the people of China, Chen and his staff of nearly 200 are barred from the premises of the State Department.
They are also not invited to White House parties, and meetings between them and US government officials often take place in hotel coffee shops, or as Chen put it, "in a neutral setting."

The New York Times story described Stephen Chen as "at an embassy that is not an embassy, an ambassador who is not an ambassador and who can only imagine what it is like to be a full-fledged member of Washington's diplomatic corps."
Chen said he has been snubbed because of America's "obvious effort to appease Beijing," the paper reported.
The paper gave a brief introduction to Chen's career life and his work after the US severed diplomatic ties with the ROC in 1979.

The report said that since Washington switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing, Taiwanese diplomats have learned how to be innovative, especially in Washington, where they "employ some of the city's most powerful lobbyists and retain close ties to many prominent conservative members of Congress."
Chen said his office has an annual lobbying budget of about US$1.2 million and contracts with 15 firms, according to the report.
Chen has been a frequent visitor to Capitol Hill in recent weeks as Taiwan seeks congressional approval for the sale of a list of sophisticated weapons, said the report.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRMS CREATE 5,000 JOBS IN HONDURAN INDUSTRIAL ZONE
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 3 (CNA) (By Oscar Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Seven Taiwan firms will invest US$70 million in the Formosa industrial park in northern Honduras, helping create 5,000 job opportunities, Honduran Vice President William Handal announced on Monday.

The Formosa industrial park, located in San Pedro Sula in northern Honduras, will be inaugurated within just a few days. Seven Taiwan textile firms have set up plants in the complex, providing 5,000 job opportunities for local people, according to Handal.
Three Honduran ship building companies will also move into the Formosa industrial park, the largest industrial zone in Honduras, he noted.
Currently, a total of 22 Taiwan businesses are operating in this central American country, statistics released by the trade division of the ROC Embassy in Tegucigalpa showed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 4, or the 30th day of the second month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1581: Sir Francis Drake, who in 1580 became the first Englishman to circumnavigate the globe, is knighted in London by Queen Elizabeth I. The English naval hero later became vice admiral of the fleet that destroyed the Spanish Armada in 1588.
1617: John Napier, the Scottish mathematician who invented logarithms and introduced the use of the decimal point in writing numbers, dies at the age of 67.
1758: Pierre-Paul Prud'hon, French historical and portrait painter who was a favorite of both Napoleon Bonaparte's empresses, is born.
1841: William Henry Harrison, the ninth president of the United States, dies of pneumonia at the age of 68 after only one month in office.
1849: Prussia's Frederick William IV is elected Emperor of Germany but refuses to take the crown.
1887: Susanna Salter becomes the world's first woman mayor when she is elected in Argonia, Kansas.
1896: Gold is discovered in the Yukon.
1900: Prince Edward, heir to the throne of England, narrowly escapes death when a teenage anarchist fires two shots at the prince who is on a train in Brussels station.
1905: An earthquake rocks Lahore, then part of British India, killing some 19,000 people.
1919: A Soviet Republic is declared in Bavaria.
1928: Maya Angelou, American poet, playwright, and novelist whose four volumes of autobiography became best-sellers, is born.
1932: The Republic of China observes its first Children's Day. Children have the day off from school.
1942: Japanese forces sink three British warships in the Bay of Bengal.
1949: The foreign ministers of Belgium, Britain, Canada, France, Holland, Luxembourg, Norway, Denmark, Iceland, Italy, Portugal and the United States sign the North Atlantic Treaty in Washington to protect Western nations from Soviet aggression.
1950: The Chinese Refugees Relief Association is inaugurated.
1963: The Beatles snatch the first five-places on the US singles charts with "Can't Buy Me Love," "Twist and Shout," "She Loves You," "I Want to Hold Your Hand," and "Please Please Me."
1967: Australian Prime Minister Harold E. Holt arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1968: Dr. Martin Luther King, the American civil rights leader who won the 1964 Nobel Peace Prize, is assassinated at a motel in Memphis, Tennessee. His eloquence and commitment to nonviolent tactics formed the foundation of the civil rights movement of the 1950's and 1960's.
1973: The Republic of China and the Khmer Republic conclude a temporary air transport agreement with an exchange of notes in Phnom Penh.
1974: The 21-member women's national basketball team returns after a tour of the United States and Brazil. The team won 24 games and lost six.
1974: The Republic of China suspends diplomatic relations with Botswana.
1974: US Ambassador and Mrs. Walter P. McConaughy leave Taipei for retirement. He is succeeded by Ambassador Leonard Unger.
1975: A US Air Force transport plane carrying Vietnamese orphans crashes after take-off in Saigon, killing 199 people aboard.
1976: Chinese at home and abroad mark the first anniversary of the passing of President Chiang Kai-shek with solemn ceremonies, tributes and prayers.
1979: Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, Pakistan's former president who was deposed by Gen. Zia ul-Haq in 1977, is hanged in Rawalpindi for the alleged murder of a political opponent.
1980: ROC President Chiang Ching-kuo presides over a ceremony marking the inauguration of the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1983: The United States grants political asylum to Hu Na, a noted tennis player from mainland China.
1989: The Ministry of Education approves the applications of three mainlanders to visit Taiwan.
1990: Communist China's legislature approves the Basic Law, the constitution that will govern Hong Kong after it reverts to Chinese sovereignty in 1997.
1990: Britain publishes a bill to grant citizenship to up to 225,000 Hong Kong residents in the run-up to the colony's handover to mainland China in 1997.
1994: A communist Chinese court sentences Si Yang, a reporter at Hong Kong's Ming Pao newspaper, to 12 years in prison for "stealing and probing national secrets."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A gentleman must be sympathetic, obliging and affectionate: sympathetic and obliging to his friends and affectionate to the members of his family."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AS PRIME DESTINATION FOR MACAU STUDENTS MAY BE CHALLENGED
DOC.DATELINE: Macau, April 4 (CNA) (By C. H. Jen and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Taiwan has always been the favorite destination for Macau high school students in pursuit of a higher education overseas, but whether this trend will continue remains to be seen.

Over the past decade, the number of Macau students taking part in exams to enter Taiwan college and university has continued to rise. The number who took the examination last year totaled 663, up from only 181 in 1990.

One noteworthy phenomenon during that period was that despite the fact that it was generally believed that most Macau students would avoid coming to Taiwan in 1997 because of the sensitive nature of the political climate due to the return of Hong Kong to mainland Chinese rule, 468 students still took the entrance examination in that year. The number rose to 539 in 1998.

The number further rose to a new high of 663 in 1999 even though Macau was returned to mainland Chinese rule that year, demonstrating that Macau students would not let a changed political environment affect their plans for an advanced education in Taiwan.

Analysts said the continued flow of Macau students to the Republic of China has been due to several reasons, including the fact that studying in Taiwan is cheap, Macau is geographically close to Taiwan, and Taiwan openly welcomes overseas students.

Another important reason is the fact that after their return to Macau, graduates of Taiwanese universities and colleges usually enjoy very promising career prospects. Official estimates put the number of Macau students that have studied in Taiwan at between 2,000 and 3,000, with most of them now serving in major positions in Macau.
The opening up of mainland China in recent years however has begun to affect Taiwan's dominance in this area as more and more students from Macau are choosing to study there instead.

A Macau official in charge of handling student entrance examinations recently noted that he is not ruling out that perhaps the unique political situation in Macau, along with mainland China's threats against Taiwan prior to March 18 presidential election, may have led some Macau parents to be reluctant about sending their children to study in Taiwan.
He added that these parents' misgivings may have further increased when Chen Shui-bian of Taiwan's pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party won the March 18 presidential election in Taiwan.
Whether there will be any major changes in the number of Macau students coming to Taiwan for advanced studies remains to be seen, he said.
Taiwan is scheduled to accept registration for Macau students between April 10 and 15 and will hold entrance examinations on June 3 and 4.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP OFFICIAL RETURNING FROM US TRIP

TEXT.P: Chiou I-jen, the Democratic Progressive Party's representative to the United States, returned to Taiwan Tuesday after a visit to the US.

Chiou said that during his nine-day stay in Los Angeles, Washington D. C. and New York, he met with lawmakers, officials and members of think tanks to collect their views for reference in the formation of DPP policy.
Though Chiou had kept a low profile during his trip, it is believed that he delivered messages from Chen and tried to establish communication channels between Chen and the US.
On media reports that he may serve as the secretary-general of National Security Council, Chiou only said that he hopes the present Secretary-General Ying Chung-wen will remain on his post.

On another report that President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the DPP had sent American scientist Jeremy Stone to the mainland as a secret envoy, Chiou said that as far as he understood, Stone has frequently traveled between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet related officials. However, he said that he did not believe that Stone was contacting anyone on the behalf of anybody.

Washington Post reported last week that Stone, president of the Federation of American Scientists and a close friend of Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh, met Beijing leaders over the weekend. Lee is the major advisor to the President-elect on cross-strait issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA SINGLED OUT BY US FOR IMPOSING TRADE BARRIERS

TEXT.P: Australia has been singled out by the U.S. trade representative for imposing trade barriers on American food, its "minimalist approach" to intellectual property rights and its export enhancement schemes.

In a dispatch from Washington, the Australian Financial Review reported on Tuesday that Australia has been cited along with the European Union, Canada and Mexico for imposing unfair trade barriers on U.S. agricultural products, which may lead to complaints being filed with the World Trade Organization.

Australia is also being listed for imposing restrictions on U.S. foods, and the U.S. industry is also concerned that the digital agenda legislation now being prepared by the Howard government would allow "unfettered worldwide trafficking" in devices and services which are able to hack through encryption, password protection and other technologies.
The United States has an annual US$6.5 billion trade surplus with Australia, according to the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPE CONCERNED ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT SITUATION: ROC ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 3 (CNA) (By James Kuo and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: European researchers are concerned about the situation across the Taiwan Strait and widely believe that ties between Taiwan and mainland China have reached a critical stage to choose between war and peace, an ROC envoy said here on Monday.

Lu I-cheng, an ambassador-at-large of the Republic of China, said that this widely held belief of European experts on the current cross-strait situation represents a marked difference from the general feeling of the Taiwan population, who he said appear to remain defiant despite mainland China's sternly worded verbal attacks prior to the country's March 18 presidential election.

Lu, who is currently on a European tour to introduce Taiwan's development, told CNA that most European political analysts and media organizations seem to assume that the election of Chen Shui-bian, candidate of the pro-Taiwan independence Democratic Progressive Party, has led Taiwan-mainland relations to a critical point -- war or peace.
Pointing out that his current European trip had been planned before the presidential election, the ROC envoy said he has been asked about the election result at every stop he has made.
However, he admitted that European researchers have a better understanding of Taiwan than he had thought, which is an indication that Taiwan's pragmatic diplomacy has borne fruit.

As to the question of why the people of Taiwan can remain so defiant in the face of fierce pressure from Beijing, Lu attributed the phenomenon partly to Taiwan leaders' fullness of understanding about the interactions between Taiwan and mainland China, and partly to a lack of understanding on the same issue among the Taiwan population.
But the ROC envoy said he agrees with the view that there is no danger of war at present between the two sides.
Lu, who has already visited Britain and France, is slated to proceed to Brussels on Wednesday, where he will call at the headquarters of the European Union before flying back to Taipei on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG FEI MEETS WITH TOP KMT OFFICIAL TO DISCUSS PARTY'S DECISION

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei paid a visit on Tuesday to Liu Chao-shiuan, the deputy convener of the outgoing Kuomintang's (KMT) reform committee, to discuss the party's intention behind its decision on his prospective acceptance of the premiership of the new Cabinet.

The KMT reportedly has decided to allow Tang to accept as an individual the premiership offered by President-elect Chen Shui-bian, but only after Tang files for a suspension of both his party membership and his right to participate the party's activities.

Since Tang has to date not received any formal notice about the matter, he went to the Executive Yuan to meet Liu, who is also the vice premier, to gain a more thorough understanding of the KMT's inclinations and its final decision.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng was reported Monday as having said that the KMT would allow Tang as an individual to form a Cabinet for Chen's new government. "As soon as Tang and Chen have talked the issue over and submitted an application to KMT Acting Chairman Lien Chan for approval, the KMT will make an announcement upon the matter," Lin said.
However, the KMT will neither endorse Tang's administration nor be responsible for it, Lin stressed.

Tang stayed in the Executive Yuan for an hour before leaving. After returning to the defense ministry complex, Tang and his staff discussed the timing and procedures for declaring to the KMT Central Committee that he has accepted President-elect Chen's offer as premier and is applying for a suspension of the his party membership as well as the participation in any KMT activities.
Tang will meet with Chen in the near future to discuss matters pertaining to the rights of the formation of a new Cabinet and the nomination of its members, according to informed sources.
Tang was offered the premiership by Chen last Wednesday but insisted that he would accept the offer only after the approval of the KMT.
Since the KMT has indicated that the party has agreed in principle to Tang's taking the post as premiership, the issue is seen as being likely to have a happy ending.
The KMT secretary-general was reported as saying that the nation's interests are ahead of the interests of the party and that the KMT is pleased to see its members make contribution to the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE TOURISTS FROM TAIWAN VISIT CHINESE MAINLAND

TEXT.P: A total of 425,000 tourists from Taiwan visited mainland China in the first two months of 2000, an increase of 19.8 percent compared to the same period last year.

According to new statistics released by the national tourism bureau of mainland China, some 12.52 million tourists entered mainland China in the first two month of this year, representing an increase of 13.86 percent in comparison with the same period of 1999.
Of the total, the bulk of the tourists came from Hong Kong, amounting to 9,070,000; followed by Macao, at 1,730,000; and Taiwan, at 425,000.

The number of tourists from other countries and areas also showed a marked increase, with tourists from South Korea surging the most at more than 50 percent, followed by tourists from the Philippines, Russia, and Indonesia, at over 40 percent respectively.
The data also shows that during the two months, foreign exchange earnings from tourism amounted to US$2.3 billion, an increase of 17.5 percent compared to the same period of last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT CHEN PAYS TRIBUTE TO NATIONAL MARTYRS

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Tuesday went to the Martyrs Shrine to pay tribute to the Republic of China's revolutionary martyrs and military personnel killed in action.

Accompanied by Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung, Gen. Lai Chen-sheng and Maj. Gen. Chen Te-chin, Chen offered incense, presented flowers and bowed in front of memorial tablets of revolutionary martyrs and military personnel killed in action.

Chen said after completing the ceremony that the new government will provide armed forces personnel and their families with all the best service as outlined by the "three-stability" prerequisite, which calls for stability of personnel affairs, stability of policies and stability of systems.

The stalwart of the Democratic Progressive Party, Taiwan's biggest opposition party, who will take the helm of the state on May 20, also urged the people of Taiwan, no matter where they hail from and no matter which parties they belong to, to join together in developing the nation.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC EXPANDING AGRO-TECH AID TO PANAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Panama City, April 3 (CNA) (By H.T. Chung and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's plans to extend agricultural technology aid to Panama will remain unchanged after the new ROC president and his administration take office on May 20, an ROC official stationed in Panama said on Monday.

In fact, Taiwan is increasing budget allocations to Panama to expand the scope of its agricultural technological assistance to the Central American country, said Li Hsieh-pei, chief of the ROC agricultural mission in Panama.
In the aid expansion, an extra budget of US$1.5 million will be allocated to the mission, Lee said.

Of the budget, US$400,000 will be used on a milk fish aquaculture plan to be initiated in Gatun Lake in central Panama. If the plan proves workable, and it is shown that the fish farm doesn't cause biological imbalance and pollution in the lake, further investment will be made, said Lee.

Another US$300,000 will be used to finance the development of 30 cooperative farms around Panama, which will be part of a "Poverty termination" project initiated by Panamanian President Mireya Moscoso.

The Taiwan mission will not only put up the cash to help develop the farms, Lee said, it will also have its own technicians assist with the development, helping the Panamanian farmers to gain their own expertise and experience in agriculture.

Meanwhile, the Taiwan mission is also helping Panamanian farmers in Los Santos in central Panama to improve their tomato crops. By applying advanced genetic techniques, rather than using fertilizer and pesticide chemicals, the Taiwan mission is helping the Panamanians to grow better tomatoes, Lee said.

The Taiwan mission is currently also working in El Valle, helping local farmers grow environmentally-friendly and chemical-free organic vegetables; in Veraguas, helping fishermen gain harvest from the ocean; and in both areas, helping farmers with rotation farming techniques to grow fruits while letting the farmlands lie fallow, Lee noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO RELY ON NEW AD HOC GROUP'S ADVICE FOR HIS INAUGURATION SPEECH

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday that he would rely heavily on the consensus expected to be reached by the recently-created ad hoc committee on cross-strait affairs as basis to formulate his inauguration speech.

Chen said it is expected that the supra-party cross-strait affairs ad hoc committee chaired by Nobel laureate Lee Yuan-tseh will reach a consensus on Taiwan's latest cross-strait policy within a month. The consensus would be seen as the common thought of the general population, the government and the opposition parties in Taiwan.
Chen noted that cross-strait relations is one of the most challenging tasks to his new administration, and added, "We should give Lee more time and more room to elaborate on the issue."

Chen said he hopes that through Lee's ad hoc group, which will be a high-performance think tank manned by 15 to 20 China scholars and strategists, his cross-strait policies will be shaped and made public when he delivers his inaugural speech on May 20.

Meanwhile, Lee, the Nobel Prize winner for chemistry in 1986, stressed that the supra-party ad hoc committee on cross-strait affairs is a private unofficial mechanism organized to offer opinions and suggestions on cross-strait issues to the president.

The president-elect's top private consultant said top goal of his ad hoc committee is to come up with ideas which will help break the cross-strait impasse and begin a new era in cross-strait relations.

Lee, who declined Chen's offer to be premier and insisted on continuing at his post as president of Taiwan's highest research institute, Academia Sinica, said as a top advisor of the president on cross-strait relations, he will "do his utmost -- whenever and whatever is needed."
Lee noted that if necessary, he would like to travel to the mainland, in his capacity as Chen's private adviser, to meet mainland Chinese leaders for talks.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLDWIDE AIR SAFETY RECORD IMPROVES IN 1999

TEXT.P: The world's air safety record improved in 1999 despite some major crashes which included the Egypt Air flight that went down Oct. 31 off the coast of Massachusetts, killing 217 people on board, the International Civil Aviation Organization (ICAO) reported Monday.

The Montreal-based organization said that 20 airplane accidents with passenger fatalities occurred worldwide during last year, killing a total of 492 passengers. The year 1998 saw the same number of accidents, but with a total of 905 fatalities.

The number of air passengers on scheduled services exceeded 1.5 billion worldwide in 1999. The ratio of passenger fatalities per 100 million passenger-kilometers dropped significantly to 0.02 in 1999 from 0.035 in 1998.

On non-scheduled air services, made up mainly of charter flights, there were 24 airplane accidents involving deaths. These accounted for 142 fatalities, compared with 210 deaths in 25 accidents in 1998.
The airplane accident statistics excluded light aircraft that carry one to seven people.

Meanwhile, there were six illegal incidents in 1999 involving hijackings or other crimes in which two persons were killed and two injured. The previous year saw nine such incidents resulting in one injury.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO INCREASE IMMIGRATION INTAKE BY 2000-01

TEXT.P: Australia will increase its immigration intake level by nearly 10 percent in fiscal year 2000-01, boosting the number to 76,000 from the current level of 70,000 in a bid to meet the growing demand for skilled workers throughout the country as a result of a strong economy.
In a statement faxed to the CNA on Tuesday, Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said the 76,000 places will include an increase of 5,000 spots in the Skill Stream.

"The further shift in the balance of the program towards the Skill Stream will deliver additional economic, budgetary and employment benefits, particularly given the skill shortages that have emerged in the Australian economy," he said.

He added that the increase in the number of places in the Skill Stream has become possible because of the success of the new points test in attracting young immigrants with strong English language skills and qualifications in high demand occupations such as IT and accounting.

To increase the attraction of Australia to skilled labor, Ruddock mentioned the government will also allow a small increase in the intake level of family members, with the number rising to 34,400 from the present level of 32,000 between July 1, 2000 and June 30, 20001.

In addition to the overall intake level of 76,000, the Australian government will also reserve 12,000 spots a year for people seeking entry based on humanitarian reasons, representing no change from the current level.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON NOTES EVEN ROC PRESIDENT WANTS MAINLAND CHINA IN WTO

TEXT.P: While pressing the US Congress to grant Communist China permanent normal trade relations status, President Bill Clinton emphasized Monday that even Taiwan's newly elected leader Chen Shui-bian wants to see mainland China in the World Trade Organization.

Rep. Dick Armey (R-Texas), the House majority leader, meanwhile, told reporters that the House of Representatives will vote before May 29 on the historic US trade agreement with China, saying "I want it done as quickly as possible, by the end of May at the very latest."

In an address to the Democratic Leadership Council in San Jose, California, Clinton said it is quite significant that the people with the greatest interest in seeing mainland China change agree with his administration's efforts to bring China into the world trading system.

"The citizens of Taiwan, despite all their tensions with Beijing, by and large want to see China in the WTO. And so does Taiwan's newly elected leader. It's a very important point," noted the president.

Clinton also announced that the chief executive officers of over 200 high-tech firms and more than 40 governors from across the United States and its territories have sent letters to senators and members of Congress urging them to grant China permanent normal trade relations status in order to maintain economic growth and prosperity for high-tech companies as well as families in their states and territories.

The president reiterated his stand that opening mainland China to the internet and other aspects of free trade will liberalize its society and ease the grip of the Chinese Communist Party. He also warned that voting down the trade bill will cost the United States both in terms of trade and in its ability to influence Chinese policy.

"The main consequence of this will be to hurt America economically and to dramatically strain our relations with China at a time when we need to maintain a positive ability to impact their conduct," stressed Clinton.

Republican leaders have said previously that they would only schedule a vote once President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore had rounded up 90 to 100 Democratic votes to ensure House passage of the PRC-WTO agreement.

White House officials said they were confident enough that Democrats would support the US trade agreement with China to ensure passage. But Armey said that "we'll all have to redouble our efforts. The Senate is clearly committed. The problem is in the House."
Rep. David Bonior (D-Mich.), the House minority leader, estimated last week that at least 135 of the 211 Democrats in the House opposed the legislation.

And 25 of the Democratic opponents, including Bonior himself and the only Taiwan-born congressman David Wu from Oregon, urged President Clinton in a March 31 letter to oppose granting China permanent normal trade status until there is visible progress in such areas as human rights, environmental protection, and the transfer of missile and nuclear technology to countries the US considers rogue states, such as North Korea, Iran and Iraq.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERT SAYS BEIJING'S WAIT-AND-SEE APPROACH BODES ILL FOR TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 4 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Beijing's wait-and-see approach toward Taiwan since the island's election of a president who is a member of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) bodes ill for Taiwan over the long term, said a Chinese affairs expert here on Monday.

Bates Gill, a researcher at the Brookings Institution, told a symposium organized by Washington-based think tank The Heritage Foundation that Beijing is closely monitoring Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian's words and deeds. He said that they are awaiting a positive sign, hopefully from Chen's inaugural speech when he is sworn in on May 20.

Another reason behind Beijing's foot-dragging on issuing an official response to the election of Taiwan's new president is the current debate in the US Congress over granting permanent normal trade relations (NTR) status with the US to the mainland. A vote on the issue is scheduled in May.
Beijing would rather wait until its NTR status has been granted before resuming a heavy-handed approach toward Taiwan, said Gill.

The looming power struggle in the run-up to the scheduled reshuffling of Beijing's ruling team in 2002 is further prompting leaders there to get tough with Taiwan as a way to boost their position within the Chinese Communist Party, Gill added.
Unless both sides of the Taiwan Strait are willing to be more flexible in defining their "one China" policy, any dialogue between them would be scuttled by deep-rooted discrepancies, said Gill.

Tien Hung-mao, director of the Institute for National Policy Research in Taipei, told the forum that Chen has already sharply compromised his pro-independence stance because of Beijing's fierce hostility toward an official independence declaration.

However, Chen is not ready to accept Beijing's "one China policy" which runs head-on against his long-standing preference for an independent Taiwan, said Tien. The conflict has deepened since Beijing's Taiwan policy shifted from a "blockade of Taiwan independence" to "pressing for national reunification", and talks with Beijing under Beijing's terms is nothing less than capitulation, said Tien.
Tien urged Beijing to mitigate its stance or the policy will backfire, as Taiwan's public think that Chen has already conceded too much to Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEADERS PAY TRIBUTE TO LATE PRESIDENTS
DOC.DATELINE: Taoyuan, Northern Taiwan, April 4 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Outgoing President Lee Teng-hui led other central government leaders to pay tribute to the late President Chiang Kai-shek and President Chiang Ching-kuo on Tuesday, the nation's Tomb-Sweeping Day.
Lee, who will step down from the presidency on May 20, arrived at Chiang Kai-shek's mausoleum at Tzuhu on 10:05 a.m., accompanied by Vice President Lien Chan and other government leaders.
They presented flowers and bowed to pay their respects at the site, and then proceeded to Chiang Ching-kuo's mausoleum at Touliao 10 minutes later.
Lee made no remarks after the ceremonies.

The Kuomintang, under Lee's chairmanship, lost its 54-year reign of power to the Democratic Progressive Party in the March 18 presidential election. Lee resigned his KMT chairmanship to take responsibility for the defeat.

Meanwhile, President-elect Chen Shui-bian paid his respects to the war dead at the Martyrs Shrine in Taipei on the same day. He pledged that the new government will provide the best service and care for all Taiwan people, including soldiers and their dependents.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE PRESIDENT ESTRADA ANNOUNCES NEW MECO CHIEF

TEXT.P: Philippine Press Secretary Rodolfo Reyes will assume the post as chief of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office in Taiwan effective April 15.
President Estrada Tuesday announced Reyes' new appointment as television executive Ricardo "Dong" Puno takes over as the new press secretary.
Reyes said that he welcomes his new assignment which he considers to be "very challenging" though less strenuous compared to the office of the press secretary.
"The president has really been much concerned about my present health condition. The President and I feel the post in Taiwan is a less strenuous position," he said.
Reyes has a heart problem had a bypass operation early last year.
The MECO post had been left vacant since the death of its former chief, former Congressmen Jose Aspiras last year.
Immediately concluding an air agreement with Taiwan is the most urgent issue that he would address upon assuming the MECO post, Reyes said.

He said the Philippines-Taiwan air row is not only detrimental to Filipino workers in Taiwan who have to fly between the countries via Hong Kong due to the absence of direct flights, but is also affecting the country's trade relations with Taiwan.
"I am also concerned about the plight of our workers in Taiwan," he said
Reyes said he would also push for more Taiwanese investments and tourism to the Philippines.
"I have much to offer to Taiwanese officials," he said. (CNA Manila)

DOC.HEADLINE: ESTRADA CALLS FOR SCIENTISTS TO AID EFFORTS TO BOOST FOOD PRODUCTION

TEXT.P: Philippine President Joseph Ejercito Estrada called Tuesday on scientists based at the International Rice Research Institute (IRRI) to help resolve the problems of poverty and food security in the Philippines and the rest of Asia.

Speaking at the 40th anniversary of the IRRI held at the Heroes Hall of Malacanang, the Chief Executive said that without science finding new ways to increase food production, the gap between the rich and poor of this world will remain well into the millennium.

He noted that the onset of the 21st century presents enormous challenges such as poverty, hunger, environmental distress and population growth which continue to put pressure on food supplies everywhere.
Rice research is one of the few hopes that the Philippines has to overcome these challenges, the President said, as he stressed that the country is fortunate to have "IRRI here with us."

The IRRI is an autonomous, non-profit agricultural research and training center the purpose of which is to increase total food production from rice-based farming systems, while protecting the environment and sustaining resources.

Established in 1960 by the Ford and Rockefeller Foundations in cooperation with the Philippine government, most of IRRI's research is done in cooperation with national agricultural research and development institutions, farming communities, research institutions and other groups that share its goals. (CNA Manila)

DOC.HEADLINE: WEI JINSHENG WARNS OF BEIJING ATTACK IF TAIWAN DECLARES INDEPENDENCE
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 3 (CNA) (By M.J. Tsou and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Top mainland Chinese democracy activist Wei Jinsheng on Monday warned of genuine military actions to be taken by mainland China in the face of Taiwan independence.

Wei, now living in exile, told a French weekly that according to reliable sources from mainland China, the Chinese communists have actively geared up preparations for military, political and diplomatic moves against Taiwan after Chen Shui-bian, candidate of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, was elected president of Taiwan on March 18.
"The communist Chinese are preparing a sweeping military action against Taiwan any minute when Taiwan declares independence," Wei said in an interview with the New Observer (Nouvel Observateur).
Wei noted that unless the international community stands out in opposition, Beijing is likely to jump the gun and launch an assault across the strait.

Wei said he is in firm opposition to Beijing using force to bring Taiwan under its control, and he would call for an international convention if Beijing indeed launches a military assault against Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Wei called for Taiwan to discard the idea of independence. For one reason, Beijing would not sit idly by towards Taiwan's declaration of independence, and for another, independence is not necessary as democratization is a road that mainland China is certain to walk on soon, he said. He added that after mainland China has been democratized, Taiwan would find reunification with the mainland easier.
Wei stressed that Taiwan is asking for a war if it declares independence.

Wei also lambasted France's promotion of "useful dialogue diplomacy" with Beijing as a means to maintain cordial relations with mainland China, saying that the French government has been used by Beijing as one of its major diplomatic blue chips for political gains in the international community.

Wei, who maintains close watch on domestic affairs in mainland China despite living in exile, said he has been in constant worry that human rights abuses have gotten only worse and worse on the mainland.

Excessive prostitution, increasing numbers of labor strikes, a skyrocketing suicide rate, frequent reports of employees murdering their employers and some 30 million jobless people wandering from city to city around the mainland are only part of the picture of today's China, Wei said.
Beijing's strangling human rights policy on the mainland has been increasingly tightened, encouraged by the Western governments' weakness and timidity, Wei pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG AGREES TO ACCEPT KMT'S CONDITIONS FOR SERVING AS CHEN'S PREMIER

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei, a Kuomintang (KMT) member for 48 years, said on Tuesday that he agreed to accept the KMT's condition to form the cabinet for Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new government.

KMT Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng told the media on Tuesday that the KMT has decided to let Tang serve as the premier in his "personal capacity", and that he has to suspend his party activities during his tenure of office.
Lin acknowledged that Tang will maintain his KMT membership, but the KMT will neither endorse nor take responsibility for what he would do as a premier in the DPP government.
