DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 5, or the first day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1725: Giovanni Casanova, Italian adventurer famous for his amorous conquests, is born.
1793: President George Washington approves plans for new public buildings and roads in the American capital city.
1827: Joseph Lister, British surgeon and discoverer of antiseptic agents is born. He demonstrated in 1865 that carbolic acid was an effective antiseptic.
1895: Oscar Wilde, the author of the highly successful plays "The Importance of Being Earnest," and " Lady Windemere's Fan," sues the Marquess of Queensberry for libel.
1896: The first modern Olympic Games begin in Athens.
1900: Spencer Tracy, American actor who won an Oscar two years in a row for "Captain Courageous" (1937) and "Boys Town" (1938), is born.
1915: Jack Johnson, the first black world heavyweight boxing champion, losses his title to the "Great White Hope" Jess Willard.
1916: Gregory Peck, American actor noted for both his fine film performances and his work for humanitarian causes, is born.
1941: Allied forces recapture Addis Ababa in Ethiopia during World War II.
1944: The Germans begin the deportation of the Jews from Hungary.
1949: The Chinese national government begins talks with Chinese Communists.
1950: The Executive Yuan grants Taiwan authority to carry out self-government by popular elections in counties and cities within two months.
1951: Julius and Ethel Rosenberg are sentenced to death in the United States for giving away atomic weapons secrets to the Soviet Union.
1954: More than 14,000 Chinese Communist POW's in Korea, who refused to return to the Chinese mainland, take their oath to join the ROC armed forces.
1955: British Prime Minister Sir Winston Churchill announces his resignation. He is succeeded by Foreign Secretary Sir Anthony Eden.
1960: The film "Ben Hur" wins 10 Oscars.
1964: Douglas MacArthur, American general who served as US chief of staff and commanded the Allied forces in the South Pacific during World War II, dies at the age of 84. He commanded UN forces in Korea until a conflict over strategy led to his dismissal by President Harry S. Truman.
1964: Prime Minister Jigma Dorji is assassinated in Bhutan while the king is in Europe.
1970: Count Carl von Spreti, West German ambassador to Guatemala, is found murdered six days after being kidnapping by guerrillas.
1975: President Chiang Kai-shek passes away in Taiwan at the age of 89.
1976: Howard Robard Hughes, American film producer, aviator, and multimillionaire, dies at the age of 71. He founded Hughes Aircraft Corporation, broke the air speed record in 1935, and flew around the world in record time in 1938.
1976: The National Youth Commission reports helping some 31,000 youths find jobs since its establishment 10 years ago.
1982: The British task force to oust Argentinian forces from the Falkland Islands sets sail.
1988: Arab gunmen seize a Kuwait Airways Boeing 747 flying from Bangkok to Kuwait. The 111 hostages aboard were freed on April 20 when the hijackers surrendered in Algiers.
1989: Vietnam announces it will withdraw its troops from Cambodia by September, 1989.
1989: A political pact between the independent trade union federation Solidarity and the government of Wojciech Jaruzelski ends Communist rule in Poland.
1990: The Republic of China reestablishes diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Lesotho. Peking (Beijing) severs ties with Lesotho two days later.
1991: President George Bush orders US Air Force transport planes to begin dropping supplies to Kurdish refugees in northern Iraq.
1994: Israel begins to withdraw from the Gaza Strip.
1998: Japan's 3,911 meter-long Akashi Kaikyo Bridge, the world's longest suspension bridge linking the main islands of Honshu and Shikoku, is opened to traffic.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A good honest man, after educating the people for seven years, will be able to lead them to war."

DOC.HEADLINE: US ENVIRONMENTAL GROUP CAUTIONS AGAINST APPLES FROM WASHINGTON STATE
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 4 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian wu)

TEXT.P: An environmental protection group in the United States has cautioned importers of apples from Washington State to be on guard against pesticides.

The Environmental Working Group (EWG) said tests on apples from Washington State found pesticides on two of 25 apple samples at levels that exceed the US government's daily safe exposure level for children.

For years, Taiwan had been the largest importer of Washington state apples, with their ranking only falling to third place last year after Canada and Mexico sharply increased their imports. Some 60 percent of America's annual apple exports come from Washington State.

The EWG said tests conducted by an independent laboratory found a total of eight pesticides present on the apples, including one, endosulfan, that has been banned by Taiwan's Council of Agriculture. Methyl parathion, which has been banned by the Environmental Protection Agency in the US, was also found to be present.

In an interview with CAN, EWG's scientist Richard Wiles said that in the group's view, all importers, including Taiwan, should take note of the test results, although he did stress that this does not mean Taiwan should ban US apple imports.

Wiles said that the US and Taiwan last year signed a memorandum of understanding on the inspection and quarantine of agricultural products. He noted that it seems that Taiwan has lowered its inspection standards under US pressure, adding that the EWG thinks Taiwan should stick to its original standards.
The EWG has urged supermarkets to adopt "test and tell" initiatives to protect the interests of consumers.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE SPEAKS AT BIODIVERSTIY SYMPOSIUM

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Wednesday reaffirmed the nation's determination to protect and preserve the island's biodiversity, as well as to actively take part in world conservation efforts.

Lee, addressing the International Symposium on Global Biological Diversity 2000, said the purpose of the meeting was to draw on the experience of experts in the push for the preservation of biological diversity.
The president noted that protected areas in Taiwan, including national parks and preservations, now represent 19.1 percent of the nation's total land area.

Ling Shiang-nung, president of the symposium and chairman of the Council of Agriculture, noted that 2000 has been designated as biodiversity year, adding that it won't only be a slogan and that the nation is committed to genome research.
More than 100 representatives, including foreign and domestic environmental officials, experts, and scholars took part in the one-day meeting held at the Grand Hotel.

Hank Jenkins, chairman of Animal Committee of CITES, International Wildlife Section, spoke on the efficiency of conservation strategies in the 20th century. Meanwhile, Elizabeth Dowdeswell, former director of United Nation's Environmental Programme, delivered a speech titled For Life on Earth.
The COA will deliver a report on the nation's strategy concerning the preservation of the island's biodiversity.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK, FUTURES MARKETS

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 135.74 points to close at 10,186.17.

Affected by a ruling on Microsoft, which was found guilty of abusing its power, the bourse opened at 9,923.74, about 126 points lower than last session's closing, but moved up later with heavy purchases of electronics and other major stocks. It fluctuated between 10,238.11 and 9,923.74 during trading.
A total of 3.88 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of 279.15 billion (US$9.18 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 379 to 175, with 56 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only construction shares posted losses, moving down by 0.7 percent. Cement stocks remained unchanged.

Shares in other major categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical stocks moving up the most at 4.5 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 2.2 percent, bank and insurance stocks and textile issues, both at 1.3 percent, electrical shares at 1.1 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.5 percent.
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures market were also higher.
The Taiwan Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April moved up 203 points to close at 10,352, with 2,820 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May surged 220 points to finish at 10,470; June futures closed at 10,476; September futures gained 206 points to finish at 10,595; and December futures moved up 203 points to close at 10,867.
The number of contract transactions for May, June, September, and December futures were 181, 37, three and one respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar was down NT$0.016 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 30.465.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 30.427 and was traded between 30.423 and 30.467.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$474 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TE FUTURES, DOWN ON TF FUTURES

TEXT.P: Electronic (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results on Wednesday.
April TE futures moved up 21.05 points to close at 565, with 1,211 contract transactions, while TE futures gained 22.4 points to close at 571, with 59 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures lost seven points to finish at 1,025, with 300 contract transactions, while May TF futures edged down 2.2 points to close at 1,030, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN WILL MAINTAIN CLOSE TIES WITH TAIWAN: CEPD CHIEF

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang said on Wednesday that new Japanese Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori, like his predecessor, will continue to maintain close substantive relations with Taiwan.
Mori, 62, had just been elected prime minister by the two houses of the Japanese Diet (parliament) to succeed Keizo Obuchi, who remained in a coma after suffering a stroke a few days earlier.
Chiang said that like Obuchi, Mori is very friendly toward Taiwan.

He noted that he became acquainted with Mori more than 20 years ago when he worked for the Republic of China Embassy in Tokyo, and added that when he was the ROC economics minister, he held talks with Mori, who was Japan's minister for international trade and industry at the time.

Chiang recounted that two years ago, Mori, who was serving as secretary-general of Japan's ruling Liberal Democratic Party (LDP), reminded Chiang that economic and trade relations between Japan and Taiwan were no longer as close as in the past.
That was why he decided to bring together major Taiwan enterprises to form the so-called "Three-Three Society" to promote economic and trade relations with Japan, said Chiang.
He expressed the belief that Taiwan-Japanese relations will be further strengthened under the Mori administration.
In the premiership election, Mori was supported by the LDP, the Komei (Clean Government) Party and the Conservative Party. He retained all the Cabinet ministers of the Obuchi administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHOULD KEEP SILENT ON ARMS FROM US: ROC DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan should keep mum about US arms sales to Taiwan in order to ensure the maximum benefit for the country, according to National Defense Minister Tang Fei.

Remaining silent is the best policy for Taiwan with regard to US arms sales to the island, because by so doing, Taiwan honors its promise to the United States and avoids infuriating Beijing, Tang has reiterated.

Since many different factors can affect the United States' decision to sell weapons to Taiwan, the Ministry of National Defense (MND) has always adopted a low profile, and has traditionally declined to comment publicly on such issues, in order not to complicate the situation for the US side, according to MND officials.

The remarks came on the heels of recent media reports about the US sale of four Aegis destroyers to Taiwan. In addition to these vessels, Taiwan also hopes to purchase early warning radar systems, conventional submarines and updated Patriot missiles from America.

Although earlier reports said the United States has agreed to provide Taiwan with the state-of-the-art Aegis warships, the latest news in Taiwan on Wednesday was that the United States has made a decision not to sell Taiwan any of the vessels this year.

The conflicting reports were released through various different channels, and sources familiar with the MND's military procurement operations said the motives behind the release of the information were unclear.

A local analyst also pointed out that in addition to strong pressure from Beijing, the US administration also has to face internal pressure from the US Congress on arms sales to Taiwan. The issue is expected to be a topic of hot debate between the Republican and Democratic parties prior to America's presidential election later this year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIR FORCE EXPLAINS UNSCHEDULED LANDING OF F-16
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, Southern Taiwan, April 5 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China Air Force officer at Chiayi airbase denied on Wednesday that the unscheduled landing of an Air Force F-16 jetfighter in Makung, Penghu, was a forced landing.

Col. Chien Chien-chun told reporters that the Chiayi-based single-seater F-16, piloted by Col. Hsu Sze-yao, was on a training sortie and landed at Makung Airport at around 1 p.m. that day because one of the plane's instruments was not working properly.
Chien stressed that the landing was a "correct landing for examination," not a "forced landing" as reported by the media.
He said that a "forced landing" means the jet is unable to fly, and added that such a landing might cause damage to the jet.
Chien said the F-16 would remain at Makung Airport until air force maintenance personnel could be dispatched from the Chiayi airbase to conduct an examination of the aircraft.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACTING KMT CHAIRMAN HOLDS TALKS WITH PREMIER-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan on Wednesday received Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated by President-elect Chen Shui-bian as the new government's premier.

According to KMT spokesman Jason Hu, Lien told Tang that the KMT has agreed to allow the staunch KMT defense minister to serve as Chen's premier in a "personal capacity." Chen was the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) candidate in the March 18 presidential election.
During his tenure as premier, Tang will maintain his KMT membership, but will have to suspend his party activities.

Hu said that during the talks, Lien told Tang that he will sign Tang's application for KMT approval to work for the DPP government, and that there is no need to submit the application to the KMT Central Standing Committee.
As for other KMT members who may be recruited to the Chen government, Hu said the KMT's basic stance is neither to encourage nor endorse such moves.

It is believed that the DPP government will retain and recruit some ranking KMT officials in the new administration which Chen intends to make a supra-party government serving all the people of Taiwan.
The new government is to be inaugurated on May 20, and Chen said that his Cabinet line-up will be fixed by the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEPD CHAIRMAN DENIES HE WILL BE NEW VICE PREMIER

TEXT.P: Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman P.K. Chiang denied on Wednesday that he is to take the job of vice premier in the administration of President-elect Chen Shui-bian.

He said that incoming Premier Tang Fei had not discussed the matter with him, and that reports to the contrary are nothing more than media "fabrications." He added that the Democratic Progressive Party should find its own vice premier.
Chiang also refused to comment on whether the new government had asked him to stay in his post as CEPD chairman.

Chiang and Tang have maintained a close relationship ever since they served together as economic counselor and military attache, respectively, at the former Republic of China Embassy in South Africa 21 years ago.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT TO MEET FOREIGN ENVOYS

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian will meet foreign envoys stationed in Taipei on Thursday to explain the foreign policy he will adopt after being sworn-in as president on May 20, Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen said on Wednesday.
According to Chen, 21 foreign envoys, including 17 ambassadors whose countries all maintain formal diplomatic relations with the Republic of China, will attend the briefing.

The incumbent foreign minister said he will also attend the meeting, but added that he will only help the president-elect by introducing the foreign dignities, since he did not take part in the formulation of the new government's foreign policy. All the major principles of the ROC's new foreign policy will have to be decided by the soon-to-be ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), he noted.

Expressing his hope that the new DPP-led administration will have a broad, forward-looking vision in setting the correct course for the country's long-term foreign policy, Chen called on the president-elect not to overlook any small matters which may be ignored by other countries but are of great importance to Taiwan.
Turning to speculation that he will probably be asked to remain at his post, Chen said that he has not heard anything in this regard, and declined to comment further on the issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOF TO SELL NT$ 20 BILLION-WORTH OF TREASURY NOTES

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Finance (MOF) is scheduled to sell a batch of 161-day treasury notes with a total value of NT$20 billion on Thursday, in a bid to cope with capital adjustments to the national coffers.
The MOF will issue the treasury notes on Friday to those who place winning tenders. They will expire on Sept. 15.

In addition to the treasury notes, the MOF also plans to sell by tender a batch of 20-year treasury bonds with a total value of NT$33.5 billion on April 18 and to issue them on April 21. The money raised will be used for the construction of major traffic infrastructure projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK MARKET TRADING SESSION TO BE EXTENDED NEXT MARCH

TEXT.P: The trading session of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) is expected to be extended in February or March next year, an official of the Ministry of Finance (MOF) revealed on Wednesday.

Tzong-Yeong Lin, chairman of the Securities & Futures Commission (SFC) under the MOF, noted that his commission will submit a proposal on the matter during the first half of this year under which daily trading sessions will be extended, but the market will be closed on Saturday.
As for the current upper and lower daily price fluctuations of no more than 7 percent in either direction, Lin said the commission will also consider loosening these limitations.
Meanwhile, a new system for after-hours trading formally began operation on Wednesday, in which investors can continue trading based on the noon closing prices on the same day.

At present, the Taipei stock market opens at 9 a.m. and closes at noon, Monday to Saturday. The new system provides opportunities for investors to conduct trading through stocks and securities firms from 12:30 p.m. to 1 p.m.
Lin explained that the new system provides another investment channel for investors.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN DISCUSSES NA ISSUES WITH PFP CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin I-hsiung paid a visit on Wednesday to James Soong, chairman of the newly founded People First Party (PFP) to seek PFP support for the abolition of the upcoming National Assembly election.

Lin, accompanied by DPP Secretary-General Yu Shyi-kun, were seeking Soong's support for canceling the National Assembly election currently slated to take place on May 6, and for diluting the power of the body.
In response to the DPP request, Soong said that the PFP is not opposed to a revision of the Constitution or to the abolition of the assembly.

However, he said the most important issue is whether matching measures will be established to take account of any changes, so that the responsibilities formerly undertaken by the assembly will be taken care of.

The DPP and the outgoing Kuomintang went into negotiations last week on the issue of constitutional revisions, and reached an agreement on seven points, which included canceling the National Assembly election and freezing its powers.
It remains to seen whether an emergency meeting of the current assembly can be convened and whether this inter-party agreement can be transformed into a Constitutional amendment before the election.

There has been a great deal of speculation lately that the KMT intends to avoid giving an opportunity to the PFP to find a new political arena in the National Assembly, and it has been reported that the KMT would rather cooperate with the DPP to abolish the institution altogether.

Both the KMT and the DPP have been obliged to adopt a two-pronged approach to the issue -- start handling nominations for the May 6 assembly poll while simultaneously proceeding with plans to strip the institution of its powers and abort the election.
As to the stance of the PFP, Soong said that the party has been preparing for the election but would not insist on the holding of such an election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN MINISTER HAILS POWER TRANSITION IN JAPAN

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen on Wednesday hailed Japan's democratic system, as Yoshiro Mori moved to become Japan's new prime minister earlier the same day.

Japan's quick political rehabilitation is an indication that transition of political power is fully ensured by the country's constitution, which in turn is an impressive trait which demonstrates Japan's mature democracy, according to Chen.

Chen also said that President Lee Teng-hui, Premier Vincent Siew and his own ministry, through the ROC representative office in Tokyo, have all sent messages of condolence to express Taipei's regret over the stroke suffered by former Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, who slipped into a coma on Monday night.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE GOVERNMENT CHANGE WILL NOT AFFECT TAIPEI-TOKYO TIES: FM

TEXT.P: Republic of China Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen said on Wednesday that Wednesday's change in the Japanese government will not affect relations between Taipei and Tokyo.
The ROC and Japan have long maintained close substantial relations, and newly appointed Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori has always been friendly toward Taiwan, Chen said.

Mori became Japan's 85th prime minister after winning an overwhelming majority in Japan's Upper and Lower Houses on Wednesday to replace Keizo Obuchi, who remained in a coma caused by a stroke two days ago.

Although some aspects of bilateral relations could be stronger, the ROC and Japan have close relations in the cultural and economic fields, and any changes in the Japanese Cabinet will not affect the current Taipei-Tokyo relations, Chen said.
Chen pointed out that Mori, who has visited Taiwan on a number of occasions, has always had a friendly attitude toward Taiwan, which is good news for the ROC.

He also said he had heard nothing from either the Presidential Office or the Ministry of Foreign Affairs about a possible visit to Japan by President Lee Teng-hui after he steps down from office on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PARAGUAYAN PRESIDENT INVITED TO ATTEND PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, April 4 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Visiting Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien on Tuesday extended an invitation to Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macci to attend the inaugural ceremony of President-elect Chen Shui-bian on May 20
Gonzalez said that he will seriously consider the invitation and that if he can not come, he will assign his foreign minister or congressional leaders to attend the presidential inaugural ceremony.
Yu, who headed a Kaohsiung County delegation to visit Paraguay, called on Paraguayan President Gonzalez on Tuesday in the company of Republic of China Ambassador to Paraguay Augustin Liu.
Kaohsiung County and Central Province of Paraguay entered into sisterhood ties on Monday. Yu and Martin Sannemann, governor of Central Province, inked the document on behalf of their constituencies.

Gonzalez expressed thanks for the assistance rendered by the Republic of China's government and people to Paraguay over the years, and reiterated that friendly relations between the ROC and Paraguay will remain unchanged.

After hearing that Kaohsiung County and Central Province had entered into sisterly relations, President Gonzalez praised their cooperation and expressed the hope that it would be an example for other provinces of Paraguay.

ROC Ambassador to Paraguay Augustin Liu noted that Yu and his group was the first ROC delegation to officially visit Paraguay since the March 18 presidential election. Also very significant was the fact that Magistrate Yu, who has maintained close relations with Taiwan's president-elect, had extended the invitation to Gonzalez on behalf of Chen, Liu said.
Yu and his group concluded a three-day visit to Paraguay on Monday and left for Buenos Aires to continue their second leg of the current Mercosur member-nation visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: GIO HEAD REJECTS KMT OFFER TO RUN IN RACE FOR NATIONAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: Chao Yi, director of the Government Information Office, on Wednesday issued a polite rejection of the Kuomintang's (KMT) nomination as one of the party's candidates in the forthcoming National Assembly election.

Chao, who was nominated to stand for the party on Monday, turned down the offer over the telephone. He notified both the KMT Central committee and its Taipei City branch office, saying that he would rather pass the opportunity to younger party members.

Given the simple task the new National Assembly delegates are to be charged with, Chao said it is an good opportunity for the KMT to groom leaders from the next generation by giving them the experience of running in this election. He said he prefers to stump for party candidates as a volunteer in the campaign rather than compete for a seat for himself.

A professor of journalism at Shuan Tsang Universty before joining the administration in November, Chao said he will return to teach at Shuan Tsang after a new administration under President-elect Chen Shui-bian is formed in May, and will serve as the head of a private firm that he will establish along with friends.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA REMINDS TRAVELERS NOT TO CARRY US-EXPORTED TOBACCO BACK TO US

TEXT.P: EVA Airways on Wednesday urged people who travel to the United States not to bring US-exported tobacco products into the United States in accordance with US regulations.

The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms under the US Treasury Department began in January of this year to strictly enforce laws banning US-exported tobacco products, including those bought from duty-free shops in the United States, from re-entering the United States.
The regulation is part of Article 9302 of the Balanced Budget Act promulgated in 1997.
Passengers who violate the regulation are subject to a fine of US$1,000 or of five times the value of the tobacco products' regular commodity tax, according to the regulation.
EVA Airways has suspended the sale of US-exported tobacco products aboard its US-bound planes.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE DECORATES GEN. TANG YAO-MING
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 5 (CNA) (By David Hsu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 5 (CNA): President Lee Teng-hui decorated on Wednesday Gen. Tang Yao-ming, chief of the general staff, with the Medal of Yun-hui, First Grade. The medal was granted in recognition of Tang's contributions in implementing rescue efforts after the killer earthquake which jolted the Central Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, and his longtime promotion of national defense.

Gen. Tang had led members of the Armed Forces of the Republic of China in carrying out rescue efforts and reconstruction in the earthquake-stricken areas, and had won praises from the quake's victims.
Tang, a graduate of Whampoa Military Academy, is the third native Taiwanese to have been promoted to the rank of general.
According to news reports, the incoming Premier Tang Fei recommended Tang to take the over the post of the minister of national defense, which Tang himself will vacate after he becomes premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING FEELS THREATENED BY TAIWAN'S DEMOCRACY, SAYS TAIWAN ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Berlin, April 4 (CNA) (By Kuo Wu-heung & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: In stark contrast to its threatening rhetoric against Taiwan before the island's presidential election, Mainland China kept a low profile after the outcome of the election for fear of the impact of Taiwan's democracy on its own society, said an envoy of the Republic of China on Tuesday.

Loh I-chen, an ambassador at large from Taipei, told a group of German politicians, academics and journalists here on Tuesday that what scares Beijing most is the defeat of the ruling Kuomintang (KMT) in the election and the oncoming transfer of authority in Taiwan, which indicates the maturity of Taiwan's democracy.

Beijing has kept a muted reaction to the results to avoid bringing the issue to the attention of the mainland Chinese public, not least because it could inspire its people to take their cue from Taiwan and demand democracy, said Loh.

This could explain why Beijing trotted out its leaders to lambaste Taiwan during the run-up to the March 18 election but then refused to comment on the results, other than saying that it will keep watching the new leader's policies.

Beijing was in the grip of similar apprehension in 1991 when a burgeoning democracy took hold in Russia following the collapse of the Soviet Union. But Russia's political development is seen as less menacing as that in Taiwan, which is ruled by the same ethnicity as mainland China and is separated from it only by a narrow strait.

Although President Lee Teng-hui is blamed by critics for the election defeat of his own party, the KMT, Loh said that Lee has ensured himself a position in history by bringing Taiwan's democracy to a level of maturity that will soon see the peaceful transfer of authority via election.

Although speculation was rife in Taipei before the ballot-casting day that President Lee preferred to have the opposition candidate Chen Shui-bian as his successor, rather than the KMT candidate Lien Chan, Loh said there is no indication that Lee has not supported Lien with all his heart.
Loh arrived in Berlin early this week. He is currently on a tour of Europe, and is slated to head for Brussels on Wednesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GOVERNMENT WANTS TO RECRUIT KMT TALENT, SAYS CHEN'S ADVISOR

TEXT.P: Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, who is also head of President-elect Chen Shui-bian's national policy advisory group, said on Wednesday that Chen's new government wants to recruit Kuomintang (KMT) talent on financial and economic issues.
He made the remarks while conferring with three KMT legislators -- Hsu Chung-hsiung, Lee Chia-hsiung and Lin Yao-hsing -- at Academia Sinica.
According to the lawmakers, Lee admitted that Chen has encountered difficulty forming his new government mainly because of factional strife within his Democratic Progressive Party.

He told the visitors that the KMT has been the ruling party on the island for five decades, and, therefore, possesses a lot of expertise. He went on to say that the new government is especially keen to recruit KMT talent in the financial and economic areas.
At the suggestion of the national policy advisory group, Chen has decided to name KMT Defense Minister Tang Fei as premier.
The new government will be inaugurated on May 20, and the line-up of the new cabinet will be fixed by the end of this month.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIGHT BREWING OVER MAINLAND CHINA'S PURCHASE OF ISRAELI AWACS PLANES

TEXT.P: Controversy is brewing over Israel's sale of aircraft equipped with advanced early warning radar systems to mainland China, the Far Eastern Economic Review reports in its April 13 issue.

According to the report, the mainland Chinese military has signed a contract believed to be worth US$250 million to buy an Airborne Warning and Control System, or AWACS, plane from Israel Aircraft Industries and is expected to exercise options to buy more.

The United States is concerned that the acquisition of more such surveillance aircraft will give mainland China a big edge over Taiwan. The aircraft are Russian Beriev A-50 planes fitted with Israeli radar.
During his April 2-3 visit to Israel, U.S. Defense Secretary William Cohen tried to dissuade Israeli leaders from selling mainland China any more such aircraft.

Mainland China, though, is very keen to acquire the sophisticated spy planes. Hard on the heels of Cohen's visit, mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin is due to arrive in Israel on April 12. Prominent on his itinerary is a visit to Israel Aircraft Industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: REGISTRATION FOR ASSEMBLY ELECTION SCHEDULED FOR APRIL 9-13

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CLC) announced on Wednesday that it will accept registrations for candidates who wish to run in the National Assembly election between April 9 and 13, and that the election day will be May 6, a Saturday.

Because the fifth session of the Third National Assembly will meet on April 8 to discuss questions concerning the future status of the assembly, acting CLC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng said that if the assembly adopts a resolution to abolish itself or to call a halt to the election before May 6, the election could be canceled.
In the upcoming election, 339 assembly deputies will be elected from 25 counties and cities, including three lowland and three highland aboriginal representatives.
Eighty others will be selected from the nationwide constituency and 20 others from the overseas Chinese community through a party proportional representation system.
The Kuomintang, which lost its 54-year reign of power to the Democratic Progressive Party in the March 18 presidential election, has already nominated its candidates for the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: STOCK TRADING SESSION TO BE EXTENDED NEXT YEAR

TEXT.P: The daily trading session of the stock market will be extended into the afternoon early next year, said a stock regulator on Wednesday.

Lin Tsung-yung, chairman of the Securities and Futures Commission under the Ministry of Finance said a plan is on the drawing board that will prolong trading from its current noon closing time to an undecided time in the afternoon.

Noting that computer reprogramming to adapt to the prolonged session will take six to nine months, Lin said that the new trading session will be launched sometime next February or March to coincide with the expected introduction of an island-wide five-day workweek.
The seven percent daily limit on the movement of stock prices will be relaxed, and set at about 10 percent along with the introduction of the longer trading day, said Lin.
The stock regulator said that his commission is still weighing whether the longer session should run without interruption from morning till afternoon or should halt for a lunch break.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Acting KMT Chairman and outgoing Vice President Lien Chan meets with Defense Minister Tang Fei, giving nod to Tang's being appointment by DPP President-elect Chen Shui-bian as premier.
The China Times:
Outgoing President Lee Teng-hui admits worries over communist Chinese military assaults across the strait.
The United Daily News:
The National Police Administration under the Ministry of the Interior likely to be upgraded to a Cabinet-level agency before May 20.
The Liberty Times:
Seven percent cap of local stock market price movements may be lifted in February or March next year.
The China Post:
SFC chairman vows to extend trading hours; all-day stock action one step closer with start of trade extension yesterday.
The Taiwan News:
New Japanese prime minister installed; political vacuum filled with election of Mori to replace Obuchi, who remain in coma; no major changes in policy are expected.
The Taipei Times:
SFC considers easing 7 percent cap -- The nation's top stock and futures watchdog thinks the limit on price movements could be widened in line with other market-opening moves.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 216.89 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Thursday, with the benchmark-weighted price index moving down 216.89 points to close at 9,969.28.
Market turnover amounted to NT$260.22 billion (US$8.56 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 216.89 points to close at 9,969.28.
Affected by poor performances on the New York Stock Exchange as well as heavy profit-taking selling, the bourse opened at 10,225.77 and fluctuated between 10,328.98 and 9,969.28 during trading.
A total of 4.11 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$260.22 billion (US$8.56 billion).
Losers outnumbered gainers 274 to 271, with 69 remaining unchanged.

Half of the four major categories gained ground, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 4.6 percent, followed by construction stocks at 1.7 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.2 percent, and cement stocks at 0.3 percent.

Other major categories posted losses, with electrical shares moving down the most at 3.3 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.1 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.3 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent.
Both the volume and value of market turnover for after-hours trading on Thursday were 0.6 percent, the same as Wednesday, the first day of the implementation of the new system.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP CHAIRMAN CALLS ON BEIJING TO ACT LIKE A `GREAT COUNTRY'

TEXT.P: Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung on Thursday called on mainland China to act like a "great country" and try its best to seek mutual benefits for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Lin said the DPP, turning from Taiwan's major opposition party to the ruling party on May 20, has always advocated goodwill as a means of fostering exchanges across the strait.

He added that as a "small country," Taiwan should not provoke mainland China in any way. Instead, Taiwan should try "soft touches" to enable Beijing to understand that its existence is not capable of causing any threat to mainland China.
For Beijing's part, Lin said it should demonstrate the "magnanimity" of a major country towards Taiwan, rather than constantly saber-rattling and causing anxiety in the international community.

Lin stressed that any ideological differences across the strait can wait to be discussed later, while practical affairs concerning the immediate interests of the people on both sides should be solved quickly. When mutual trust is built up through increased cooperation over practical affairs, leaders from the two sides will then find it easier to conduct higher-level talks, noted Lin.
Lin made the remarks during an exclusive interview with a local radio broadcasting corporation.

On party politics in Taiwan, Lin said it is too early and too optimistic to say that the split of the Kuomingtang, which has ruled Taiwan continuously for 55 years, will lead to the DPP becoming the long-term ruling party in Taiwan.

As DPP chairman, Lin said he would like to stress that "only by nurturing deep attachments to the people and the land, will the DPP survive and prosper. And only by constantly maintaining a fresh approach in formulating policies, will the party have a bright future."
It is useless for the DPP simply to rely on the split of another party for its own success, he said.

On plans to reduce the functions of the National Assembly, Lin said the DPP will invite representatives from the KMT and the newly-established People First Party to jointly discuss relevant issues so as to work out the most viable and satisfying solution concerning the National Assembly.

The usefulness of the National Assembly has been widely questioned since its major function of electing the president of the Republic of China ended eight years ago when Taiwan held its first direct presidential election.

On complaints by Vice President-elect Annette Lu about her "not being consulted" by President-elect Chen Shui-bian concerning the new Cabinet line-up, Lin said that the VP has no specific powers under the ROC Constitution beyond replacing the president when he is unable to perform his duties.

Lin said all politicians grow in experience over time, adding that he hopes that Lu will pay closer attention to the contents of the ROC Constitution and at the same time discard her self-centeredness.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES PLUNGE ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's futures market reported heavy losses on Thursday with the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for April plunging 342 points to close at 10,010, with 3,023 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for May lost 340 points to close at 10,130, while June futures moved down 246 points to 10,230, and September futures lost 195 points to close at 10,400.
The number of contract transactions for May, June, and September futures were 195, 41, and one, respectively.
No transactions were recorded for December futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were: 10,352 for April; 10,470 for May; 10,476 for June; 10,595 for September; and 10,867 for December.
Electronic (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, also posted losses.

April TE futures plunged 24.95 points to finish at 548.05, with 1,217 contract transactions; May TE futures lost 19.1 points to close at 556, with 49 contract transactions; and June TE futures moved down 18.8 points to finish at 566, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 13.8 to close at 1,016.2, with 387 contract transactions, while May TF futures lost 15 points to finish at 1,047, with 15 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BECOMES BIGGEST PERCEIVED THREAT T0 US

TEXT.P: Communist China has replaced Russia as the nation perceived by Americans to be the most threatening to the United States and Americans have become more worried about Communist Chinese threats to invade Taiwan, according to a new public opinion poll.

In back-to-back presentations at the Nuclear Security Decision Makers Forum in Albuquerque, two University of New Mexico researchers said their surveys also show most Americans support a strong nuclear weapons arsenal, with that support growing over the last several years, reported the Albuquerque Tribune on Wednesday.

Survey interviews suggest Americans are worried more about Communist Chinese threats to invade Taiwan, terrorist incidents around the world, and a generally more confusing and unstable world, said Kerry G. Herron, associate director for security studies at UNM's Institute for Public Policy, adding that "the world is not perceived as being safer than during the Cold War."

Institute Director Hank Jenkins-Smith pointed out that while Americans in surveys in 1993, 1995 and 1997 generally supported stable funding of the US nuclear weapons program, last year's survey revealed much stronger support for increasing that funding.

Support for nuclear weapons appears to be driven by the American public's concern about the political turmoil in Russia, Communist China's saber-rattling in Asia, and the potential for nuclear terrorism by nations opposed to US interests, explained Jenkins-Smith.

The surveys, conducted in the fall of 1999 to gauge public knowledge about and support for US nuclear policy, were paid for by Sandia National Laboratories. But Herron said the labs have taken a "completely hands-off approach" to the surveys while continuing to finance them.
He added that two researchers will brief Sandia executives next month on the 1999 survey results. But he declined to detail most of those results before the Sandia briefing.
Generally, Herron said, Americans see more benefits than risks from nuclear weapons, though women are concerned more than men about the risks from the United States' own nuclear arsenal.

The 1999 data also shows that more Americans see a need for nuclear weapons and more believe that funding should be increased to support nuclear weapons programs. The 1993 survey found 63 percent of Americans favored the retention of US nuclear weapons, and that response rose to 79 percent in 1999.
While 51 percent of those Americans surveyed in 1993 believed that nuclear weapons funding should decrease, last year 61 percent favored increased spending on them, said Herron.

DOC.HEADLINE: CLINTON ASKED TO BLOCK PETROCHINA'S LISTING ON NYSE

TEXT.P: Twenty-five members of the US House of Representatives have appealed to President Bill Clinton to block the PetroChina Corporation, a subsidiary of Beijing's China National Petroleum Company (CNPC), from being listed on the New York Stock Exchange Friday.

Meanwhile, a diverse collection of business groups, human rights activists and political leaders gathered in Washington Wednesday calling on President Clinton to halt PetroChina's planned initial public offering, claiming that the company's ties to the Beijing regime make it likely that the money generated will support activities that undercut American foreign policy.

In a letter to Clinton dated March 31, Rep. David Bonior (D-Mich.), the House minority whip, and 24 colleagues noted that the money raised by PetroChina on the New York Stock Exchange would be used to finance exploration and development operations that "would pose a direct threat to the population, resources and fragile environment of Tibet."

The money will also help the Sudanese government intensify its civil war against its non-Muslim minority in the south. CNPC is currently engaged, or preparing to engage, in oil exploration and development activities in Sudan "in violation of official US policy," emphasized the lawmakers.

Groups gathered here to denounce the PetroChina initial public offering and calling on the Clinton administration to halt it included Amnesty International, Students for a Free Tibet, America's largest labor organization the AFL-CIO, Freedom House, and the US Business and Industrial Council.

The congressmen pointed out that PetroChina is a subsidiary of CNPC, which owns 40 percent of Sudan's Greater Nile Petroleum Operating Company. It is scheduled to be listed on the New York Stock Exchange and hopes to bring a US$5-7 billion initial public offering to market.

DOC.HEADLINE: US HOUSE TO VOTE ON NTR STATUS FOR CHINA IN MAY

TEXT.P: US Rep. Dennis Hastert (R-Ill.), speaker of the House of Representative, announced Wednesday that the vote on permanent normal trade relations status for Communist China will be held in late May.

President Bill Clinton immediately welcomed the decision by Hastert to hold a vote on the US-PRC trade agreement during the week of May 22 and promised an all-out effort to persuade reluctant Congress members to support the controversial measure.

Although the Senate is clearly committed to approving the measure, Rep. David Bonior (D-Mich.), the House minority whip, estimated last week that at least 135 of the House's 211 Democrats opposed the legislation. Many Democrats argue that by giving up the annual congressional review on Communist China's trade status, the United States will lose its ability to influence Beijing's human rights practices.

But in welcoming Hastert's announcement at a White House conference on the new economy, Clinton insisted that the tariff-cutting deal will liberalize mainland Chinese society. "It also slashes those tariffs which protect the state-run industries in China which in large measure have been the instrument of single-party control there. So I think it will lead to an opening of the society and a rise of freedom and personal choice," said the president.

The White House wants an early House vote on permanent normal trade status for Communist China, fearing that support for the historic US-PRC trade agreement on Beijing's accession to the World Trade Organization will erode with the approach of the November elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: BAUER CRITICIZES CLINTON'S TRADE POLICY TOWARD BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Republican conservative leader said that the distortions produced by the trade-trumps-all China policy continue to mount, with Secretary of Defense William Cohen publicly rebuking Israel for selling an advanced airborne radar system to Communist China, while allowing U.S. ambassador Joseph Prueher to throw a gala dinner party in Beijing for Communist Chinese military representatives and U.S. defense contractors under investigation for illegally providing secret missile data to Communist China.

The Washington Times reported Tuesday on a dinner hosted by former U.S. Pacific commander-in-chief Prueher at his residence in Beijing for executives of Hughes Electronics, SpaceSystems Loral, ChinaSat and representatives of Communist China's military space program.

The dinner was held at the request of a Loral executive to discuss the delayed launch of a mainland Chinese civilian communications satellite. The lauch was postponed when the two U.S. contractors had their export licenses suspended.

"Hughes and Loral are under investigation for illegally sharing missile data with China. ChinaSat, a government-owned company, recently launched the first of a series of advanced military satellites giving China a new command, control and intelligence capability that will dramatically enhance the People's Liberation Army's ability to manage its armed forces in combat.

He added that "In view of recent congressional reports detailing China's illegal acquisition of U.S. arms secrets, including nuclear weapons, it is inappropriate for the American ambassador to be aiding Chinese companies engaged in military activities." (by Nelson Chung)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC GOVERNMENT TO BOLSTER TIES WITH EUROPE SAYS CHEN

TEXT.P: Bolstering ties with the European Union (EU) will be one of the top diplomatic priorities of the new Republic of China government to be inaugurated on May 20, President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Thursday.

As time passes and the situation in the world changes, the EU will become a focus of attention by the new ROC government, Chen said during a meeting with envoys from 12 EU member countries that maintain representative offices in Taiwan.

Organized by the French Institute in Taipei, top liaison officers of the 12 European representative offices in Taiwan paid a courtesy call to Chen to exchange views with him on possible changes of Taiwan's relations with the EU.
The representatives included those from France, Britain, Spain, Germany, the Netherlands, Austria, Finland, Sweden, Ireland, Switzerland, Denmark and Italy.

Chen said that despite the intensity of campaigning during the hotly-contested presidential election, he had taken the time to visit Britain, the Netherlands and Belgium to learn about the EU's allied government, regional integration of the union, and the so-called Third Road or Middle-Road politics so as to broaden his knowledge in world politics.

He noted, however, that the existing formula of cooperation among parties in the EU is not applicable to Taiwan's current political situation, adding that a non-party or supra-party government is reckoned to be more viable after he takes office on May 20.

Chen said in the past, the Kuomintang-ruled ROC government focused its diplomatic efforts on the United States and Japan. As the world situation has changed over time, he said his new government will shift part of its attention to Europe so as to strengthen bilateral relations with that part of the world.

Chen added that his new government will be a multipurpose government that will pay attention to all affairs, and which will attach great importance to human rights protection, humanity and environmental protection diplomacy. The EU also attaches great importance to these issues, he said.

Taiwan, despite its overt difficulties in world diplomacy, is more than willing to take greater responsibility as a member of the international community and would like to play a greater role in non-government and cross-government organizations, Chen emphasized.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 6, or the second day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1199: Richard I, king of England known as "The Lion-Hearted," dies at the age of 42 from an infected wound received while besieging Chaluz Castle during the Crusades. He was captured in Austria in 1192 and held as a prisoner by Holy Roman Emperor Henry VI until England ransomed him in 1194.
1520: Raphael, Italian Renaissance painter and architect, dies on his 37th birthday.
1528: Albrecht Duerer, German painter, engraver, designer of woodcuts, and art theorist, dies in his home town of Nuremberg at the age of 57.
1580: Earthquake rocks London, damaging St. Paul's Cathedral.
1789: George Washington is unanimously elected the first president of the United States.
1814: French Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte is forced to abdicate unconditionally.
1830: The Church of the Latter-day Saints, whose followers are known as Mormons, is founded in Fayette, New York, by Joseph Smith.
1868: Japanese Emperor Meiji establishes the Charter Oath which was to change the form of government. He also promises an assembly.
1890: Anthony Fokker, Dutch-born American aircraft designer and manufacturer who revolutionized aerial warfare by synchronizing a front-mounted machine gun with the rotations of a propeller, is born.
1896: A modern version of the ancient Olympic Games is opened in Athens, initiated by French aristocrat Baron Pierre de Coubertin, who hopes to stimulate interest in physical fitness and promote understanding between nations.
1909: On his third attempt, American naval officer and Arctic explorer Robert Peary reaches the North Pole as the head of an expedition.
1913: The provisional Senate of the Republic of China is dissolved.
1917: President Woodrow Wilson signs a resolution entering the United States into World War I on the side of Great Britain and France.
1933: The Ministry of Finance of the Republic of China orders the implementation of a yuan currency system instead of the tael currency system.
1935: Emperor Henry Pu Yi of Manchukuo, a puppet regime installed by the Japanese, visits Japan.
1938: The ROC armed forces score a major victory over Japan in the battle of Taierchuang, killing more than 30,000 Japanese troops.
1938: A Polish defense pact is signed by Britain, France and Poland in London.
1941: German bombers raid Belgrade, killing some 2,500 people. Hundreds of buildings were burned down during the attack, including the National Library with its countless medieval manuscripts.
1942: Japan bombs India and attacks ports in Madras during World War II.
1944: The Pay-As-You-Earn Income Tax is introduced in Britain.
1945: US naval forces score a major victory against the Japanese at Kyushu.
1953: Scrap bombs explode on a hillside in Nanshihchiao, Taipei County, killing and injuring more than 300 people.
1963: The Executive Yuan proclaims December 25 "Constitution Day" and a national holiday.
1965: The United States launches Early Bird I, the first commercial communications satellite, from Cape Kennedy, Florida.
1968: Pierre Trudeau becomes prime minister of Canada, succeeding Lester Pearson.
1971: Igor Stravisky, Russian-born composer who was one of the 20th Century's leading musical figures, dies in New York at the age of 89.
1975: Yen Chia-kan, vice president of the Republic of China since 1966, takes the oath of office as the nation's second constitutional president.
1976: Millionaire recluse Howard Hughes dies in a plane while being flown to a hospital, leaving a fortune of US$2 billion.
1976: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo renews his call to communist cadres and mainland China military personnel to rise up against the Maoist regime following the April 5 riots at Tienanmen Square in Peiping (Beijing).
1976: Dr. Erik Lundberg, president of the Royal Swedish Academy, arrives in Taipei for a three-week visit.
1984: Zola Budd, 17, South African runner, is granted British citizenship only 13 days after signing her application so that she can run for the British team in the Los Angeles Olympic Games.
1993: Two mainland Chinese youths, Liu Bao-zai and Huang Shu-kang, hijack a Southern Airlines' Boeing 757 passenger plane to Taiwan.
1994: A missile hits a plane as it attempts to land in Rwanda, killing all people aboard, including President Cyprien Ntaryamira of Burundi and President Jubenal Habyarimana of Rwanda.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE TOPS ADMINISTRATION PRIORITY SAYS PREMIER-DESIG.

TEXT.P: The cross-strait issue will be the top priority of the new administration to be sworn in on May 20, said Premier-designate Tang Fei on Thursday.

Tang, defense minister in the outgoing Kuomintang (KMT) government, said seeking a solution to the thorny cross-strait issue will be the first priority of the new government, followed by reforms of internal affairs and policies.

Although the new government has vowed to conduct sweeping administrative reforms, Tang said, almost all existing administrative policies will need to be extended, so the reforms will not result in a complete turnabout.
It is unlikely that more than 80 ministerial-level officials in 36 Cabinet agencies will be given to new faces overnight.

Tang noted that the KMT has agreed in principle to his premiership in his capacity as an individual rather than a KMT member, adding that he will soon submit an "application" to the KMT for the party's official approval which would allow him to take up the new post.

On possible differences in policy formulation between himself and President Chen Shui-bian, Tang said that as government leaders, they should patently understand that democracy necessitates compromise, respect for different opinions, and a willingness to seek agreement when differences occur.

On reports that President Lee Teng-hui has expressed worry over the ROC military's combat readiness, Tang said it is true that the ROC Armed Forces have sustained great pressure, mainly because of the increased military threats from mainland China, and partly because of a relatively low defense budget.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW GOV'T TO HONOR ALL ACCORDS, COMMITMENTS WITH FOREIGN NATIONS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Thursday that the administration under his leadership will honor all accords and commitments that have already been inked with foreign countries.
Chen made his assurance at a meeting with envoys of allied countries. The envoys were accredited before the ROC government on Thursday afternoon.

Chen went on to say that foreign policy of the new administration will maintain continuity and stability, and will also further participate in international organizations so as to meet the challenge of globalization.
He stressed that the new administration must demonstrate Taiwan's creativity and strength to the world, and that Taiwan's international presence must be developed on the global stage.
Chen also expressed his hope that heads of state of countries that have maintained diplomatic relations with the ROC will attend his inaugural ceremony on May 20.
Burkina Faso Ambassador Jacques Y. Sawadogo, who is also dean of the Diplomatic Corps in Taipei, on behalf of that organization expressed high praise for democratization in Taiwan.
He hopes that relations between the ROC and allied countries will further solidify in the future, he said.
Earlier in the day, Chen had also met with representatives of 12 member nations of the European Union, for the same purpose.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS TO VISIT JAPAN

TEXT.P: A 13-member delegation from the Legislative Yuan led by its Vice President Yao Eng-chi will leave here for Tokyo on Friday to call on Japanese leaders and overseas Chinese groups in Japan.
Wu Po-hsiung, senior adviser to the President, and Chu Chien-yi, vice chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission(OCAC), will also join the group.
Members of the delegation will attend the 34th Annual Meeting of the Hakka Clan Association in Tokyo on Sunday, and meet with members of the ROC-Japan Dietmen Council on Monday.
They will call on the Overseas Chinese Association in Yokohama and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in that city on Monday.
Part of the delegation will call on the overseas Chinese communities in Osaka and Kobe and the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Osaka.
The delegation is expected to return to Taipei on April 14.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN AND TANG DISCUSS PRINCIPLES OF FORMING CABINET

TEXT.P: Defense Minister Tang Fei, who is expected to serve as premier of President-elect Chen Shui Bian's incoming government with the formal approval of Acting Kuomintang (KMT) Chairman Lien Chan, said on Thursday that he and the president-elect have to date only talked about the principles of forming a new Cabinet.

Tang, a senior member of the outgoing KMT, had repeatedly said he would not leave the party to assume the premiership. He has been allowed by the party to serve as head of Chen's cabinet as an individual after a temporary suspension of his KMT membership, but the KMT would neither endorse nor be responsible for his performance.

Tang stressed that he and the president-elect, a stalwart of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), have not discussed specific individuals to head the various departments -- they only discussed principles for the formation of the new Cabinet.

As to the speculation that Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman Chiang Pin-kung, a close friend of Tang, is being considered for the vice premiership, Tang said that the matter has not been discussed.
Tang made the remarks in a TV interview with Jaw Shau-kong, a former New Party heavyweight.

Tang noted that there are more than 70 ranking administrative officials in the government. He said that replacing them all in a one-time reshuffle would be imprudent, if normal operations of the government are taken into consideration.

Since almost all departments under the Executive Yuan need professionals to run them, he decided while discussing the issue with Chen that getting the right person in the right place is most important, he noted.
Furthermore, the political party affiliation is another problem he must face when making his choices for the Cabinet, said Tang.

Tang noted that there are 35 organizations under the Executive Yuan, and that time is running short before Chen takes the helm of the administration on May 20. Therefore, he added, discussion between the president-elect and himself has been limited to principles, instead of details, about appointments for the new Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP AIDE DENIES MEETING WITH RANKING BEIJING OFFICERS IN US

TEXT.P: Chiu I-yen, representative of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) to the United States, denied a report on Friday that he had met with ranking Beijing military officers during a recent trip to America.

Chiu categorically denied the Washington-dispatched report by Japan's Sankei Shimbun on the same day. He reiterated that there are no envoys acting as mediators between Taiwan and mainland China, and that neither are there any special communication channels between the two sides.

Brushing aside the report that he held an unofficial meeting on the "one China" issue with ranking mainland Chinese military leaders during a recent tour in America, Chiu clarified that the major purpose of his trip to the United States was to attend a seminar.

But Chiu admitted that it is true that the seminar was attended by experts from Taiwan, mainland China and the United States, including one officer of the People's Liberation Army who had expressed his viewpoint on some topics related to the military situation between Taiwan and mainland China.
"Maybe that is the reason resulting in the misunderstanding," the DPP official explained, stressing that he personally had never discussed the "one China" issue with the mainland Chinese officer.
Chiu made the remarks while answering questions from reporters after participating in a meeting between President-elect Chen Shui-bian and foreign envoys stationed in Taipei.

Asked whether Chen had dispatched an envoy to mainland China following his election as president on March 18, the DPP cadre ruled out such possibilities, emphasizing that no special communication channels exist between Taiwan and the mainland, except the cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council and the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation.
Chiu returned to Taipei on Tuesday after a nine-day tour of the US, where he met lawmakers, officials and members of think tanks.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE LOOKING FORWARD TO WORKING WITH PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: Chief of the General Staff Gen. Tang Yiau-min has turned down an offer from President-elect Chen Shui-bian to head the Ministry of National Defense under his administration, incumbent Defense Minister Tang Fei said on Thursday.
Tang Fei, who has been designed as Chen's premier, said in an interview with a local radio station that he and Chen are now weighing other candidates.

Given the complexity of defense affairs, it is impossible to have a civilian take the reins at the ministry before the Organic Law of the Ministry of National Defense Affairs is enacted, and the new defense minister should be chosen from among career servicemen, said the fighter pilot-turned-minister.

He dispelled concerns that his appointment as premier, like that of former military leader Gen. Hau Pei-tsun who took the helm of government under President Lee Teng-hui in 1990, will open the door to military interference in politics.

"Instead of pursuing the post, I have been asked, or summoned, to head the government, and there is a mechanism in democracy to prevent military men from unduly influencing government that works by cutting the links between military men-turned-politicians and the armed forces. There is no way in which any leader can interfere with the democratic system by riding on the back of the armed forces," said Tang.

He brushed aside questions on whether he has been asked to form a Cabinet for Chen or invited to join a Cabinet put together by Chen, saying he will line up the new Cabinet subject to Chen's approval.

Tang, who met with Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng earlier in the day to officially inform his party that he will accept Chen's job offer, said in the interview that he understood the KMT's "no support, no endorsement" stance on his decision, and that he would rather earn public support through comprehensive policies than through the backing of any political party.

Noting that compromise is quintessential to a democracy, Tang said he will not insist on having everything his own way. Instead, he said, he will concede when his opinion clashes with that of the president to ensure a smooth working relationship with the head of state.

He also said that contrary to the opinions of some "analysts," he is not worried that he is destined to be a short-term premier used as a stop-gap until Chen can foster a premier from his Democratic Progressive Party.

Tang said he expects to remain in the job until the end of 2001, when the current legislature comes up for election, and added that whether he will stay on after that will depend on his job performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR RISES SLIGHTLY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar rose on the Taipei Foreign Exchange market on Thursday, ending the day up NT$0.004 at NT$30.469.
A total of US$397 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$30.464, and was traded between NT$30.448 and NT$30.508.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP MEMBERSHIP EXCEEDS 200,000 AS OF WEDNESDAY

TEXT.P: The membership of the newly founded People First Party (PFP) exceeded 200,000 as of Wednesday, a party spokesman said on Thursday.

Sun Ta-chien said he is confident that the membership will surpass one million within six months, and is convinced that the PFP will grab 100 National Assembly seats in the National Assembly election scheduled for May 6.
Sun said the PFP will propose on Friday or Saturday a list of nominees who will run in the National Assembly election.
The Central Election Commission stipulates that all candidates must register with the commission from April 9 through April 13.

After the finalization of the list of nominees, the PFP will hold two or three press conferences and public hearings to introduce the nominees and to issue a statement on the party's participation in the election.

The PFP was founded on March 31 by James Soong, an independent candidate in the March 18 presidential election. Soong was chosen to be party chairman and Chang Chao-hsiung, Soong's running mate in the presidential election, was picked as vice chairman.
The party immediately started to enlist members through Soong's presidential election campaign organizations, all of which will eventually become local PFP headquarters.

Sun said the PFP hopes that membership will surpass two million within two years, and pointed out that if this goal can be achieved, the party will be Taiwan's largest political party competing in the legislative elections scheduled to be held at the end of next year.
Sun, who was also a spokesman for Soong during the presidential election campaign, said the PFP has yet to finalize its structure, but added that when complete, the structure will be "streamlined."

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS DENIES CHAIRMAN'S MEETING WITH CHEN'S ENVOY
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 6 (CNA) (By S.C. Peng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Beijing will not engage in any form of dealings with Taipei unless President-elect Chen Shui-bian recognizes the "one China" principle, an official with the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) said on Thursday.

The official told CNA that ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan, who currently lives in Shanghai, would not have met with Chen's envoy in Beijing, and that reports to the contrary in the Taiwan media should be checked carefully. He pointed out that Wang, in his capacity as mainland China's top negotiator with Taiwan, will only act in compliance with Beijing's policy.
Beijing will only decide its next move toward Taiwan after weighing Chen's inaugural speech on May 20, according to the official.

A Taiwan-based Internet newspaper reported recently that Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party dispatched a secret envoy to the mainland the very next day following his election as Taiwan's president on March 18.

Meanwhile, a spokesman for the mainland Chinese Foreign Ministry declined to comment on the report about Chen's secret envoy, saying only that any comments on the issue should come from the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DEFENSE CONTRACTOR ACCUSED OF ASSISTING PRC

TEXT.P: The US State Department has accused Lockheed Martin Corp. of violating the Arms Export Control Act by providing an assessment of a motor on the Asiasat-2 communications satellite to a state-owned communist Chinese conglomerate.

But a spokesman for Lockheed Martin denied that the company had violated export laws and said it obtained a Commerce Department license before its scientists assessed the mainland Chinese-made satellite motor.

Both The Washington Post and The Washington Times reported on Thursday that the State Department's Office of Defense Trade Controls informed Lockheed Martin of its findings in a letter dated April 4, and gave the largest American defense contractor 30 days to respond to the civil charges, which could result in a fine of as much as US$15 million and ban the company from exporting satellites or satellite technology for up to three years.

The allegations are similar to those lodged in 1998 against Hughes Electronics Corp. and Loral Space & Communications, two other US satellite manufacturers which have been under criminal investigation for possibly passing sensitive data to mainland China.

The Hughes and Loral investigations triggered intense controversy in Congress, with Republican lawmakers accusing the Clinton administration of being lax in its oversight of high-tech exports to mainland China due to the influence of illegal campaign contributions and intensive lobbying.

Although the Lockheed Martin case does not involve violations of criminal laws, State Department spokesman James Rubin called it "a serious matter" and said export control officials decided to take action "based on the facts and the gravity of the charges."

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMICS MINISTER MIGHT TAKE OVER ITRI CHAIRMANSHIP

TEXT.P: Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang hinted on Thursday that he will take over the chairmanship of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI), Taiwan's largest non-profit research institute.

Wang, a member of the Kuomintang, will step down together with Premier Vincent Siew before President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new government is inaugurated on May 20, because the KMT lost to the Democratic Progressive Party in the March 18 presidential election.
He has turned down the KMT's nomination to run in the National Assembly election slated for May 6, saying that his major interest is to teach or engage in research.
When asked to confirm a report that he will serve as ITRI chairman when incumbent chairman Sun Chen's second three-year term expires in May, Wang indirectly confirmed the report.

Founded in 1973 by the Economics Ministry, the ITRI serves primarily to develop industrial technologies and transfer them to domestic private enterprises to sharpen their international competitiveness.
Wang said that in the next few days he will meet with representatives from the industrial sector to gain an understanding of their needs.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO ARRESTED ON CHARGES OF ABDUCTING TUNGSHIH TOWNSHIP CHIEF

TEXT.P: Taichung police on Thursday announced the arrest of two men on charges of abducting Tungshih Township Chief Chang Chin-hu for ransom on March 2.

Tungshih, Taichung County, was one of the hardest-hit townships in last September's devastating earthquake. The two abductors said that they targeted Chang in the belief that he might have possessed huge post-quake reconstruction fund for the area.
According to police, Chang was kidnapped by Wu Lien-tsung, 22, Chen An-ming, 37, and two other culprits at 6 p.m. on March 2. The abductors demanded a ransom of NT$30 million (US$967,000).
Chang was released after his family managed to raise NT$7.95 million (US$256,000) and handed it over to the culprits.
After a month-long secret investigation, police located two of the suspects and arrested them in Taichung City on Wednesday night.
During the raids, police also confiscated two pistols, 34 bullets, 1.2 grams of heroin, a mobile telephone, a forged ID card, and NT$70,000 in cash.
After learning of the two arrests, Taichung County Magistrate Liao Yung-lai presented a reward of NT$200,000 (US$6,400) to the police for their efforts in breaking the case.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT WILL PLAY A ROLE AS DOGGED OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: Kuomintang Secretary-General Lin Fong-cheng said on Thursday that the KMT will serve as a dogged opposition party after Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) President-elect Chen Shui-bian takes office on May 20.
He made the remarks after a 30-minute meeting with Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated by Chen as the new government's premier.
Lin praised Tang as an outstanding talent, and went on to say that the KMT is happy to see Tang devote himself to the country.
Now that the KMT has been defeated by the DPP, Lin said that the former ruling party will play the role of dogged opposition to Chen's new government.
He said that the KMT will support the policies which benefit the people, and will not endorse any moves which are against the interests of the people or the KMT's own policies.

Meanwhile, acting KMT Chairman Lien Chan said on Thursday that the party will engage in an all-out, thorough and quick review of the party's functions regarding organization, mobilization, propagation and personnel appointment, so as to allow the party to rise again as soon as possible.
He also expressed his appreciation for the support lent to him and his running mate, Premier Vincent Siew, in the March 18 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO EXPEL AROUND 40 MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Another 40-odd prominent members of the Kuomintang are expected to be punished or expelled by the party on Friday for supporting independent presidential candidate James Soong in the March 18 presidential election.
All the members of the outgoing party had been expected to rally behind the party's candidate Lien Chan in the election which saw the KMT ousted after more than 50 years in power on Taiwan.

The party's Evaluation & Discipline Committee will gather on Friday to mete out the punishments. Notably on the list of those for the chop was Yen Ching-biao, speaker of the Taichung County Council, who publicly declared his support for Soong in the run-up to the election.

The punishments are part of the party's post-election efforts to rid the party of defectors after Lien finished a distant third in the presidential election behind the victorious Chen Shui-bian and runner-up Soong.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC-ARGENTINA ECONOMIC CONFERENCE OPENS IN BUENOS AIRES

TEXT.P: A joint economic conference between the Republic of China and Argentina opened in the South American state's capital of Buenos Aires on Tuesday.

An 80-member delegation from Taipei consisting mainly of business leaders attended the conference to exchange views with about 300 Argentina business leaders on ways of promoting bilateral trade and investment.
Also present at the meeting were Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, and Larry Y.Y. Wang, the ROC's representative in Buenos Aires.

The meeting was the key event for the ROC delegation and took place at the end of a four-day stay in Argentina, the third leg of a five-country tour of South America following visits to Brazil and Paraguay.
The delegation left Argentina for Chile later on Tuesday, after which it was scheduled to visit Uruguay before returning to Taipei.
