DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 7, or the third day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1348: Charles IV, king of Bohemia, founds Prague University, the first university in central Europe.
1506: Saint Francis Xavier, Spanish Jesuit missionary, is born. A co-founder of the Jesuit order in 1534 with Ignatius of Loyola, he established missions in Japan, Ceylon, and the East Indies.
1509: France declares war on Venice.
1827: John Waller, a chemist in northern England, sells the first matches, which he invented.
1862: General Ulysses Grant's troops vanquish the Confederate army at the Battle of Shiloh in the US Civil War.
1891: Ole Kirk Christiansen, Danish toy maker who created the first Lego products, is born.
1897: Turkey declares war on Greece.
1906: Hundreds of Italians living in the vicinity of Mount Vesuvius are killed in a cataclysmic volcanic eruption.
1928: Chiang Kai-shek resumes the Northward Expedition at the order of the National Government.
1932: A National Emergency Conference in Loyang decides on continued resistance against Japanese aggression.
1934: Mahatma Gandhi suspends his campaign of civil disobedience against British rule in India.
1939: Fascist Italy invades Albania.
1939: Francis Ford Coppola, American director and film producer, is born. He won Oscars for "The Godfather" and "Apocalypse Now."
1943: John Maynard Keynes, British economist, launches a plan for post-war reconstruction.
1943: Chemist Albert Hoffman synthesizes the drug lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) in his laboratory in Switzerland.
1945: The Yamato, Japan's largest battleship, is sunk by US aircraft carrier warplanes.
1947: Henry Ford, American car manufacturer, dies at the age of 84. He developed a gasoline-powered automobile in 1893, founded the Ford Motor Company in 1903, and mass-produced the Model T from 1908 to 1927.
1948: The World Health Organization (WHO) is founded in Geneva.
1953: Dag Hammarskjold, Swedish diplomat and political leader who won the 1961 Nobel Peace Prize posthumously, succeeds Trygve Lie as secretary-general of the United Nations.
1954: Jackie Chan, Hong Kong movie star who is noted for his action films, is born.
1956: Spain and Morocco sign a declaration recognizing Morocco's independence.
1963: The Socialist Federal Republic of Yugoslavia is set up with Marshal Tito as president for life.
1968 Jim Clark, British world racing-champion known as "Flying Scot" who had a record 25 Grand Prix wins, is killed today when his Lotus hurled out of control at an estimated 120 mph during the first race of the Formula Two championship in Hockenheim, Germany.
1969: Traffic courts are set up in Taipei City and other places in Taiwan to begin to handling traffic violation cases.
1971: US President Richard Nixon promises to withdraw 100,000 troops from Vietnam by Christmas.
1976: Simon Kuznets, 1971 Nobel Prize winner for economics, arrives in Taipei for a three-week-visit.
1976: The Communist Party of China's Political Bureau decides at a meeting to appoint Hua Kuo-feng (Hua Guofeng) as premier and to depose Teng Hsiao-ping (Deng Xiaoping) as deputy premier after riots in Peking (Beijing).
1976: Hishan M. Nazer, Saudi Arabian minister of planning, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: US President Jimmy Carter backpedals on building the Neutron bomb.
1979: The International Olympic Committee (IOC) decides the ROC can retain its membership while admitting communist China as a new member.
1981: Voters in the Philippines approve a new constitution, giving President Ferdinand Marcos sweeping powers.
1987: US President Ronald Reagan announces that American diplomats will not occupy the new embassy in Moscow until he is sure that it is secure from Soviet eavesdropping.
1989: Cheng Nan-jong, the person in charge of the "Era of Freedom" magazine, immolates himself after refusing arrest for involvement in an insurrection case.
1989: The Chinese Taipei Olympic Committee announces that ROC athletic teams and organizations will participate in international sports events held on the mainland under the name "Chinese Taipei."
1990: Communist China launches a US-made telecommunications satellite into orbit.
1998: Indonesia and the International Monetary Fund (IMF) agree on a package of measures to get a US$43 billion bailout package on track.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 48.25 points to close at 9,921.03.
Affected by heavy profit-taking selling, the bourse opened at 10,035.26 and fluctuated between 10,128.26 and 9,908.88 during trading.

A total of 3.30 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$209.34 billion (US$6.89), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.11 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$260.22 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 312 to 216, with 77 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only two gained ground, with cement stocks moving up the most at 0.4 percent, followed by textile issues at 0.2 percent.

Other major categories posted losses, with bank and insurance shares moving down the most at 1.7 percent, followed by plastics and chemical stocks at 1.2 percent, foodstuff shares at 1.1 percent, construction stocks at 0.9 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.7 percent, and electrical shares at 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSIONAL DELEGATION TO CHINA URGED TO DEMAND FACTS

TEXT.P: Prominent leaders of human rights, environmental, labor and animal welfare organizations in the United States Thursday called on members of Congress preparing to visit mainland China to demand the facts on the state of human rights and the fate of religious, democratic and labor rights leaders there.

Meanwhile, the Humane Society of the United States (HSUS), the largest animal protection organization with over 7.5 million members, Thursday announced its opposition to granting Communist China permanent normal trade relations status. HSUS and the Animal Welfare Institute are also organizing a peaceful demonstration against granting permanent NTR to China on Capitol Hill on April 12.

The coalition of various organizations that support the annual congressional review of China's human rights record wrote in a letter released Thursday that "truth is off limits in China. That Beijing is uniquely able to obtain vital intelligence about the fate of human rights, religious, democratic and labor rights leaders in China creates a moral obligation to do so."

The group, which includes renowned mainland Chinese human rights activists Wei Jingsheng and Harry Wu, is planning a "Going Away Party" for the House delegation. At the farewell gathering just before they leave for China, the group will present members with "propaganda survival kits."

Constituents in each delegation member's congressional district are also organizing local town hall meetings to hear the results of their representative's investigation of the human rights concerns outlined in the letter to the delegation.

"Unlike their Chinese hosts who remain accountable only to a powerful Communist elite, members of Congress are still accountable to the people they serve," said George Becker, president of the United Steelworkers of America.

The letter to the congressional delegation called on the members to ask "tough but fair questions" in four major areas of concern: democracy and free speech; religious freedom; forced labor, starvation wages and crushed independent unions; and environmental and animal welfare.

The letter urges the delegation to insist on being allowed to see imprisoned journalists, religious and labor leaders and leaders of the democratic opposition to the Communist regime. It also calls on the delegation to visit a forced-labor camp, the site of the Three Gorges Dam project, a garment manufacturing sweat-shop, and a dog and cat fur processing plant.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATORS URGE CLINTON TO SUPPORT TAIWAN'S ENTRY INTO WHO

TEXT.P: Twenty-one US senators have urged President Bill Clinton to take concrete steps to support Taiwan's participation in the World Health Organization, saying that denying the people of Taiwan access to the benefits of the highest possible level of health is "a gross dereliction of duty by the WHO, and should not stand unchallenged."

Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC), chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and 20 colleagues from both the Republican and Democratic Parties wrote in a March 31 letter to President Clinton that the most recent government report concerning Taiwan's participation in the WHO describes the practical problem of Communist China's opposition to, and the limited international support for, Taiwan's participation.

But they stressed that "the report fails to address the crux of the issue -- the people of Taiwan are being systematically denied access to the benefits of organizations such as the WHO, the primary objective of which is the attainment by all people of the highest possible level of health."
Since April 7, 2000 has been declared World Health Day by the WHO, the senators added that "we are presented with a unique opportunity to address this important issue."

While the Clinton administration report concludes that Taiwan's entry into the WHO should be supported, the senators pointed out that "it does not create a systematic plan for reaching that objective. We believe it is incumbent on the administration to support more vigorously humanitarian efforts by the people of Taiwan to gain access to international health policy planning."

They told the president that "in the case of Taiwan's membership in the WHO, functional humanitarian concerns greatly outweigh matters of organizational form. Accordingly, a failure by your administration to properly champion the participation by Taiwan in the WHO would be a decision to place matters of mere political convenience above overriding humanitarian concerns."

"Good health is a basic right of every citizen of the world and access to the highest possible standards of health information and services is necessary to help guarantee this right," stressed the senators.

They added that "unless the United States is willing to stand up and take the lead on this issue, the definition of `all people' will continue to exclude the people of Taiwan. We urge you to take concrete steps to ensure that no people are denied the highest possible standards of health or other human rights by the political limitations of international organizations to which the United States is a party."

DOC.HEADLINE: HOLY STONE IS TAIWAN'S STOCK MARKET CHAMP

TEXT.P: High profits from comparatively low investments have made Holy Stone Enterprise Co., a MLCC (multi-layered ceramic capacitor) producer, Taiwan's stock market champion, with its stock price rising to NT$700 from NT$72 when it was first listed on Taiwan's OTC(over-the-counter) securities market on Jan. 13, 2000.

Holy Stone President Bill Tang emphasized that the company's performance in the stock market won't cause any complications in the company's culture or in the working habits of its employees, saying he expects that they will apply the fortunes they've made from the stock market toward benevolent purposes.
Following are excerpts from CNA reporter Chang Liang-chih's interview with Bill Tang:
Q: What is the situation in the passive components market?

A: In the passive components market, the supply is currently not sufficient to meet the demand. In the meantime, the Japanese manufacturers are cutting down their production volumes. The insufficient supply situation is expected to last until the third quarter of this year. While most of the manufacturers are boosting their production capacities, the insufficient supply problem will likely be solved by the end of this year or early next year.

If the market situation turns from insufficient supply to over supply, prices of passive components are likely to decrease. The impact on individual companies will depend on their production processes and capacities, as well as their marketing strategies.
Q: How has Holy Stone been able to achieve such high profits?

A: The passive components and semiconductor manufacturing industries have recovered from a gloomy market last year and Holy Stone has benefited from the market recovery. The company's strong performance can be attributed to a good strategy -- market-oriented research and development planning and R&D-oriented manufacturing.

As a matter of fact, passive components are applied components for its downstream assembled products. Holy Stone started its business as a professional agent for electronic components. As a manufacturer, the company has learned to see things from the customer's standpoint when designing its products. Holy Stone became a passive components manufacturer last year, after it has already become well aware of the market.

As a manufacturer with its own market channel, Holy Stone can keep up with the latest market trends and concentrate on products with high profits. Even if market prices make a downward adjustment in the fourth quarter of this year, Holy Stone will be able to handle the price cut.
Q: What is your biggest concern at the present time?

A: The hike in the company's stock price has made our employees the new rich in the electronics sector. I hope that the newly won fortunes won't cause any complications to the company's culture or to our people's working habits. Holy Stone is a big family, and each member of the company should share their achievements with their family members.
In terms of company developments, I care most about production quality and capacity and personnel development. The market, personnel, and technology are all vital to a company's growth.
Q: What are Holy Stone's future prospects concerning production capacity and R&D planning?

A: Referring to MLCC production, Holy Stone expects to achieve an annual production growth rate of between 70 percent and 100 percent with the completion of our second MLCC plant in Luntan, central Taiwan early next year. The production capacity is set at 2 billion pieces. It is estimated that company revenues will reach NT$5 billion next year.
The production capacity of our first plant in Luntan is expected to reach 500 million MLCC units by the fourth quarter of this year, with an annual growth rate of 66.67 percent.
In view of the booming telecommunications market, Holy Stone is also working on specific small-sized products for mobile phone sets.

As many downstream customers have moved their production lines out of Taiwan, Holy Stone should study ways of remaining close to the market. The Holy Stone board of directors recently held a meeting where they approved the planning of indirect investments in mainland China's coastal regions. (translated by Lillian Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC CONCERNED ABOUT ISRAELI ARMS SALES TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday that it has expressed Taipei's grave concern to Israel about the country's planned arms sales to mainland China.

MOFA officials said that the ministry, through its representative office in Israel, has conveyed the ROC government's deep concern about planned sales of an early warning radar system and advanced aircraft to mainland China, which it warned may hinder peace and security in the Taiwan Strait and the Asia-Pacific region.

S.Y. Chiang, vice director of MOFA's West Asian Affairs Department, said at a news conference that Israel decided to transfer the hi-tech facilities to the mainland last November in compliance with an agreement clinched with Russia in 1997.

Although US Defense Secretary William Cohen has repeatedly expressed the United States' opposition to such military purchases by mainland China from Israel, Chiang added that the Israeli government has so far not indicated any intention of changing its plans.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO SEND MINISTERIAL-LEVEL OFFICIAL TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 6 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A business council has urged the White House to send a ministerial-level official to Taiwan to attend a business conference slated for mid-June.

Rupert J. Hammond-Chambers, acting president of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council, confirmed on Thursday that its chairman, Frank Carlucci, sent a message to the National Security Council urging the Clinton administration to send the official to attend the annual meeting to promote trade relations with Taiwan.

The council noted that Taiwan is the United States' seventh-largest trade partner, its eighth-largest export market, and its fifth-largest buyer of agricultural produce, adding that bilateral trade has grown 7.5-fold over the last two decades.

The 24th Annual Joint Business Conference of the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council and ROC-USA Business Council is slated for June 14-16, four weeks after the May 20 inauguration of Chen Shui-bian as president of the ROC.

With the annual joint conference held right after the inauguration of Chen and the nation's other economic and financial leaders, Hammond-Chambers is expecting keen interest among US businessmen in attending the meeting to learn more about the changes in Taiwan and its new leaders.

The Clinton administration is now scrambling to solicit support for awarding permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) status to mainland China. If Congress votes to give PNTR status to Beijing by the end of May, it is expected that arranging for financial officials to visit Taiwan in mid-June will be less difficult.

A former US government official said that the Clinton administration has in the past sent a ministerial-level official to attend the major conference. If the United States fails to send the same level of official to Taiwan, it will send the wrong message to both sides of the Taiwan Strait, which he said would be an unfortunate development.

During the last joint conference in San Antonio, Texas, ROC Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang invited US Commerce Secretary William Daley to attend the Taipei meeting. Daley was the first US commerce secretary to attend the joint conference, but whether he will be the first commerce secretary to visit Taiwan will be up to the White House.

The Clinton administration sent Energy Secretary Bill Richardson to Taipei to attend the 22nd joint conference in 1998, and Transportation Secretary Federico Pena to the 20th joint conference in 1996.
Meanwhile, the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council said in a press release that David Laux, president of the council over the past decade, resigned from the post on April 1.

The press release said that Laux will now serve as the head of the US-Taiwan Business Forum, an organization dedicated to cultural, educational, and business exchanges between the United States and Taiwan. The forum solicited donations last year to help relief efforts following the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake.

The 73-year-old Laux, formally a Taipei Office Managing Director of the American Institute in Taiwan, served as president of the US-ROC Business Council in 1990, which later changed its name to the US-ROC (Taiwan) Business Council.

Laux accompanied Carlucci to visit Taipei in late March and early April, and met with President Lee Teng-hui, President-elect Chen Shui-bian, and various other high-ranking officials to exchange views on the Taiwan situation in the wake of the March 18 presidential election which saw the Kuomintang end its five-decade rule in Taiwan.
However, the press release stressed that Laux's resignation had nothing to do with the KMT ouster.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES DROP

TEXT.P: Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves at the end of March totaled US$113 billion, registering a drop for the first time in 21 months, according to figures released on Friday by the Central Bank of China (CBC).
The figures show that Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves rank third in the world, behind only Japan and mainland China.

Although the volume of reserves at the end of March was down by US$636 million compared with the previous month, it registered an increase of US$19.99 billion as compared with the same period of last year.
Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves at the end of February achieved a record high of US$113.6 billion as a result of factors such as sustained foreign capital inflow.

The plunge in March was mainly due to the quarterly demand at the end of each season, a rush by importers to purchase US dollars, and a reluctance among exporters to sell US dollars, according to an analysis by CBC officials.

Some importers and the general public rushed to purchase US dollars on March 20, the first business day of the monetary market after the March 18 presidential election, leading to a drop in the government's foreign exchange reserves, said market observers.
The turnover of the Taipei foreign exchange market rose to US$1.88 billion on March 30, the highest single day volume in 30 months, which required an intervention by the CBC, the observers added.

The intervention, which was needed to avoid a large-scale depreciation of the NT dollar and which was aimed at coping with the public rush for US dollars, consisted of the CBC dumping a large amount of US dollars, which led to the drop in the island's foreign exchange reserves, Taipei foreign exchange traders noted.

Taiwan's foreign exchange reserves have nevertheless exceeded the benchmark of US$100 billion for eight consecutive months since August 1999, according to officials of the Foreign Exchange Department under the CBC.

DOC.HEADLINE: DYING CHINESE DISSIDENT' FAMILY ASKING FOR HELP

TEXT.P: Mainland Chinese dissident An Fuxing is dying from liver disease and his family is unable to pay for his medical treatment, a human rights group said here Friday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said that An, 49, of Changchun city in northeastern Jilin province, was a leader of the banned "China Democratic Party". Before he joined the party, he had been imprisoned for five years for participating in the 1989 pro-democracy movement in Beijing. He contracted the liver disease hepatitis B while in prison, and became dangerously ill at the end of last month.

His father, An Wen, hopes that people in the outside world will give him a helping hand, because he is dying from the disease and his family is no longer able to pay for his medical treatment, the information center said.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP APPROACHES MAC VICE CHAIRMAN ON JOINING NEW GOVERNMENT

TEXT.P: Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said on Friday that several political parties, including the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), have asked him about his intention to join the new government.

The lineup of the new government has become a focus of interest following the March 18 presidential election which saw the pro-independence DPP take power and the end of five decades of Kuomintang rule on Taiwan.
With his knowledge of cross-Taiwan Strait relations and international affairs, Lin has been widely tipped as a possible member of President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new Cabinet.
Lin said that some of his friends in the DPP have inquired about his intentions, and have invited him to accept the offer of a Cabinet post in Taiwan's first peaceful transition of political power.

Lin said that at such a critical juncture in cross-strait relations, anyone who can contribute his "expertise and services" should do so. He also expressed the hope that he will be able to continue to study mainland China's military.
He also said that he is willing to provide his experience in cross-strait ties and international affairs.

However, he added that he does not agree with the DPP's pro-independence stance, and that he hopes to maintain the cross-strait status quo. He also said that national interests and the welfare of the people should be the top priority.

Lin denied news reports that he worked for the United States' Central Intelligence Agency during a 29-year period when he lived in the United States, saying that the reports may be linked to the fact that he and James Lilley, a former US ambassador to mainland China who had close links to the spy agency, and with whom he developed a close friendship, had both worked for the American Enterprise Institute, a US think tank.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROSY MARKET PROSPECTS FOR PASSIVE COMPONENTS THIS YEAR
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 7 (CNA) (By Lilian Wu) (By Chang Liang-chih and Lillian Lin)

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 7 (CNA): Taiwan's passive components manufacturers have been enjoying brisk sales since the second half of 1999 when several leading suppliers in Japan shifted their production lines to other products with higher added value. Their Taiwanese counterparts then took up the vacated production role.

Resistors, capacitors and inductors are major passive components for all kinds of electrical appliances. Demand for passive components in the international market has continued to grow over the past 10 years amid booming popularity of electronics, telecommunications and household electrical appliances.

Taiwan's passive components manufacturing industry has experienced many ups and downs in its 40 years of history. The key to its success in this high-tech, capital intensive industry has been expanding production capacity to an economically feasible scale.

In 1998 downstream PC manufacturers initiated the low-price marketing strategy, and Taiwan's passive components suppliers suffered severely due to profit cutting. In order to cut down their production costs, leading manufacturers such as YAGEO Corp., Pan-Overseas Industrial Corp. and Team Young Advanced Ceramics Co. moved their production lines to mainland China and other developing countries.

The world outlook for passive components turned rosy early last year amid escalating demand for mobile telephones. Among Taiwan's passive components manufacturers, multi-layered ceramic capacitors (MLCC) for mobile telephone handsets are most graced by the recovering market.
Meanwhile, Japanese passive components makers have shifted their production lines to components for high added value telecommunications devices.

While Taiwan's passive components manufacturers have taken over the market for computer components vacated by the Japanese, they have also developed production lines of MLCCs to meet the continuously growing demand of the telecommunications market.

Moving their production lines to countries with lower production costs and expanding production capacities are the typical strategies of Taiwan's passive component suppliers. Most manufacturers expect that the market will continue to grow and good profits will pile up at least until the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT CONTINUES PURGE OF TURNCOAT MEMBERS

TEXT.P: In the latest of a series of "house cleanings," the Kuomintang stripped 53 prominent party members of their party memberships for supporting non-KMT candidates in the March 18 presidential election.
In addition to Yen Ching-piao, speaker of Taichung County Council, one legislator, eight National Assembly deputies, 19 councilmen, and nine party deputies received their marching orders.
All of them were supporters of independent presidential candidate James Soong, with the exception of one, who was punished for stumping for Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian.

Chien Wei-chang, director-general of the KMT Evaluation and Discipline Committee, told a press conference after his committee handed down the punishments that some committee members had suggested mercy, but the committee decided to follow the precedent set up in the handling of other party defectors.
Admitting that the party's power base has been jeopardized by divesting so many local party leaders of their memberships at one time, Chien said nevertheless that discipline should be the priority.
More heads will roll, said Chien, when his committee turns to grassroots party members who supported non-KMT candidates in defiance of the party's call to rally behind party candidate Lien Chan.

The KMT finished a humiliating third in the presidential election after its members split the vote between KMT candidate Lien Chan and former KMT secretary-general James Soong, who was expelled from the KMT for entering the race as an independent without party approval.

DOC.HEADLINE: 23 FOUNDING MEMBERS QUIT INDEPENDENCE PARTY

TEXT.P: Almost two-dozen founding members of the hard-line Independence Party (IP) announced on Friday their decision to drop out of it, as they say that the party has completed its mission.
IP founding chairman Lee Cheng-yuan and the party's first secretary-general Lee Sheng-hsiung called a conference to make public their declaration, endorsed by a total of 23 members.
Although they suggested that the whole party should be disbanded, they claimed that they will not join the soon-to-be ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
DPP candidate Chen Shui-bian won Taiwan's March 18 presidential election and will be inaugurated as the Republic of China's tenth president on May 20.

Since the IP has completed its current mission of terminating the Kuomintang's 55-year rule in Taiwan, Lee Cheng-yuan said it is no longer necessary to stay in an organization that is increasingly losing its importance as an opposition party.

Stressing that they fully respect the wishes of those who want to stay in the party, they said from now on they will join forces with all the people of Taiwan to strive for sovereignty and to fight mainland China's attempts to invade or swallow up this island.
The IP, set up in 1997, was a splinter-group of the pro-independence DPP.

Later in the day, incumbent IP Chairman Cheng Pang-cheng also called a news conference to express his regret, shock and consternation over the former stalwarts' collective decision to withdraw from the party.

Describing such a move as an "example for failure," Cheng said he just does not understand the real motive behind their decision, claiming that "they still can fight for Taiwan's future should they continue to stay within the party."

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING PRESIDENT SAYS HE WILL WORK MORE FOR MINORITY GROUPS

TEXT.P: Outgoing Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said in Kaohsiung on Friday that after he leaves his presidential post on May 20, he will do more to benefit Taiwan's minority groups.
He told some 700 representatives of local organizations over a luncheon that he resigned his Kuomintang chairmanship on March 24 because he felt that he had completed his mission for the country.
Once he steps down as president next month, Lee stated that he will use his more neutral stance do more to care for the poor, the handicapped and other minority groups.
The president was in Kaohsiung to extend his appreciation for the support lent to him by the people there over the past 12 years.
He was accompanied by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng, former Presidential Secretary-General Huang Kun-huei and former Presidential Deputy Secretary-General Huang Cheng-hsiung.

Lee told the gathering that the ROC on Taiwan has undergone enormous changes in the past 12 years, but added that the island's democratization is just in the starting stages, and that it will require a great deal more effort in the future.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILL NOT HAVE CONTROLLING GRIP ON GOVERNMENT, SAYS PARTY LEADER

TEXT.P: Although the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has won the presidential election, it will not have a controlling grip on the government as the Kuomintang did, said the DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung.

In a meeting with Raymond F. Burghardt, director of the American Institute in Taiwan Taipei Office, Lin said his party will fully respect President-elect Chen Shui-bian's authority in lining up Cabinet members.
However, the DPP chairman said, it is the duty of any party member who is elected to public office to toe the party line on national policy.

Lin dismissed as "impossible" media reports that Chen has sent a secret messenger to Beijing, saying that his party denounces back-channel diplomacy. Any government's activities should be conducted publicly and under the vigilant eye of the public, he said.
Chen had boasted about forming a non-partisan administration long before he was elected on the DPP ticket. Since his election victory, he has designated a KMT government minister as his premier.

DOC.HEADLINE: MANDARIN AIRLINES TO OPEN TAIPEI-SAIPAN FLIGHT ROUTE ON MAY 1

TEXT.P: Mandarin Airlines will open a direct Taipei-Saipan flight route on May 1, sources with the airlines said on Friday.
With an area of 124 square kilometers (48 square miles), Saipan is the biggest of the Northern Mariana Islands. The central Pacific island was the scene of fierce fighting during World War II.
The attractions of Saipan and the surrounding islands include scenic splendors and maritime activities. It is the nearest tourist resort to Taiwan.

In the past, Taiwan tourists had to transfer planes to reach Saipan. Japanese holiday-makers had accounted for the majority of arrivals on Saipan before the outbreak of the Asian financial turmoil in 1997.
Since then, the number of Japanese tourists to Saipan has decreased significantly. Saipan authorities are now actively tapping Taiwan's tourist market.

After considering Saipan's prospects as a destination for Taiwan tourists, Mandarin Airlines decided to open the direct Taipei-Saipan flight route on May 1. During the initial stage, the airline plans to offer two flights per week, on Mondays and Fridays. Flight time will be three-and-half hours.
Mandarin Airlines merged with Formosa Airlines in August 1999. The firm now operates the domestic flight routes left by Formosa Airlines, and is actively expanding its international flight routes.

In November and December of last year, Mandarin Airlines began flying to Taipei-Rangoon (Myanmar) and Taipei-Chiang Mai (Thailand), respectively. The Taipei-Saipan link is Mandarin Airlines' third international flight route.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT APPROVES NOMINATION OF CANDIDATES FOR ASSEMBLY ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang Central Standing Committee on Friday approved the nomination of the party's candidates for the May 6 National Assembly election.
Of the candidates, 127 will represent the party to run for 239 seats in 25 counties and cities, as well as lowland and highland aboriginal regions.

The KMT nominated 59 candidates to run for the 80-seat nationwide constituency, including Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang, Finance Minister Paul Chiu and Council of Labor Affairs Chairman Chan Hou-sheng.
For the 20 seats representing overseas Chinese communities, the KMT nominated 18 candidates.
Deputies from the nationwide constituency and the overseas Chinese communities are elected through a party proportional representation system.

The Central Election Commission has decided to hold the upcoming assembly election on May 6. Nevertheless, this date is still uncertain because the fifth session of the Third National Assembly, to be convened on Saturday, might pass resolutions to postpone the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNTERFEITED GOLF EQUIPMENT SEIZED IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: Counterfeited golf gear with a street value of about NT$100 million (US$3.33 million) was seized in a Taipei sports shop on Friday, said prosecutors at the Taichung District Prosecutors' Office.

Investigators found 700 false club heads, shafts and golf bags bearing the well-known brand names of Call Away, Mizuno, S. Yard and Honma in a golf shop's warehouse. The shop's owner was accused of selling bogus golfing gear last year by the US television network the National Broadcast Corporation (NBC).
The shop owner had been caught by a hidden camera selling false clubs to NBC reporters who pretended to be buyers.
Following the report, Taiwan investigators launched a probe, but were unable to obtain evidence because the shop owner had already removed the illegal products after NBC broke the news.
Friday's raids on storehouses of the shop were carried out after a fake golfing equipment manufacturing ring was busted in Taichung early last month.
On tips provided by members of the ring, investigators raided the shop and its warehouses in Taipei City and Taipei County, and found the phony products.
The shop owner was not present at the time of the raid, and has been asked to report to prosecutors to answer questions.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE GOVERNMENT ISSUES ENTRY VISA FOR DALAI LAMA
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 7 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Japanese government has issued an entry visa for the Dalai Lama to visit Japan between April 13-20, despite Beijing demands for Tokyo to deny him the visa.
According to newspaper reports, the Tibetan spiritual leader has been invited by a university in Kyoto to attend a symposium there on March 16-17.
The Dalai Lama plans to address the symposium with the subject of Buddhism and environmental protection, said the report.
A Japanese official was quoted as saying that the entry visa was issued to the Dalai Lama, whose application completely complied with the government's regulations.
This will be the Dalai Lama's eighth visit to Japan. He is scheduled to confer with Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, a hawkish writer-turned politician, on April 18.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
National Assembly meets today, mainly to discuss freezing of election of its deputies.
The China Times:
Taiwan Strait on crossroads of war and peace, says premier-designate.
The United Daily News:
Consensus seen easily to be reached at National Assembly on it power reduction.
The Liberty Times:
Mainland China and Taiwan will be admitted to the World Trade Organization simultaneously, says the US.
The China Post:
KMT, DPP conspire to thwart Soong's National Assembly plans.
The Taiwan News:
Assembly meets today in attempts to weaken itself -- four parties agree to act on consensus basis; election plans proceed despite delay efforts.
The Taipei Times:
Taiwan's independence party runs out of steam -- Party officials say that with Chen Shui-bian's victory in the presidential election, the hardline independence party has fulfilled its historical mission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SHARE PRICES UP

TEXT.P: Share prices were up on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 13.54 points to close at 9934.57.
Market turnover amounted to NT$219.78 billion (US$7.22 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: EARTHQUAKE SHAKES EASTERN, SOUTHERN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: An earthquake measuring 5.1 on the Richter scale rocked Taitung in eastern Taiwan on Saturday, causing renewed fears of another devastating earthquake, according to the Central Weather Bureau (CBC).
The temblor, which occurred at 10:41 a.m., had its epicenter about 26.2 km west of Taitung at a depth of 31.3 km.
The quake had an intensity of four in Shantimen in the southern county of Pingtung, and an intensity of three in Tainan County's Chiali, Pingtung City and in Taimali of eastern Taiwan.

The temblor was also felt in Mt. Alishan, Kaohsiung County, Kaohsiung City, Chiayi City, Tainan City in the south, Nantou and Yunlin counties in central Taiwan, and Hualien County in the east, according to CBC seismologists.

DOC.HEADLINE: REKNOWNED US CRIMINOLOGIST TO RETIRE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 8 (CNA) (By David Wang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The office of Connecticut Governor John Rowland confirmed on Wednesday that Henry Lee, reknowned criminologist and commissioner of the state's Public Safety Department, will retire in July.
The 61-year-old Lee will then head the criminal investigation works for the state as well as a honorary commissioner of the state's Public Safety Department.
Lee, considered one of the leading forensic experts in the world, was invited to serve as commissioner two years ago by Governor Rowland, his close friend.
After his retirement in July, Lee is not expected to enjoy more leisure, as he still has more than 800 criminal cases on hand waiting for his expertise.

Lee graduated from Taiwan's Central Police University with a degree in police science. After working in the Taipei Police Department for several years as a police captain, he came to the United States for further study, earning his Ph.D. in biochemistry from New York University in 1975.
Taiwan's Criminal Investigation Bureau has invited Lee to return to Taiwan several times to help solve some major criminal cases.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT MEETS FORMER CHIEF OF GENERAL STAFF

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Saturday paid a brief courtesy call on Adm. Ni Yue-si, former chief of the General Staff and a strategic consultant to the president.

Chen lauded Ni as an outstanding military leader who can serve as an example for the Taiwan public not only because of his extraordinary expertise in his profession but for his methods of learning, working and treating people.

The 86-year-old former military strongman insisted on standing from his wheelchair to salute the new head of state who is scheduled to be inaugurated on May 20, according to Ni's son, John, who is currently director-general of the Small- and Medium-Sized Business Administration under the Ministry of Economic Affairs.

There had been speculation that Chen's visit to Ni was related to his imminent appointment of a naval brass-hat as his defense minister to replace incumbent Defense Minister Tang Fei of the outgoing Kuomintang government, who has been appointed premier.
Ni was a navy chief before being appointed Republic of China ambassador to Turkey and chief of the general staff.

After the meeting, Chen declined to comment on whether he will name a naval officer as defense minister, saying only that the appointment will be based on the principle of seeking balance in the military.

Observers say that the appointment of Adm. Ku Chung-lien, the incumbent Taiwan representative in the Netherlands, would best suit the "balance" principle, as Tang is from the air force while incumbent Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming is an army man.
