DOC.HEADLINE: HK CHIEF URGES GRANTING OF PNTR TO MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Hong Kong Chief Executive Tung Chee-hwa told US President Bill Clinton on Friday that granting mainland China permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) status would give Hong Kong's recovering economy a further boost.

Tung said after meeting Clinton that they discussed the importance of the PNTR legislation, which "is obviously important for China, for Hong Kong, and I made the point it is important for Hong Kong because we are in the beginning stage of an economic recovery and China's accession to the World Trade Organization would give Hong Kong's economy a further boost," he said.

Joining Clinton at the meeting were White House Chief of Staff John Podesta, National Security Adviser Sandy Berger, Deputy National Security Adviser James Steinberg, and National Security Council Senior Director of Asian Affairs Ken Lieberthal.
Tung said he also pointed out that PNTR legislation is very important to the United States "because the American businesses will have unlimited access to a market of 1.2 billion people."

"It is in America's labor movement interest because it will create more jobs in America. It is in America's environmental group interest because free trade creates wealth in America and in the developing nations."

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA EXPLOITS AUSTRALIA'S ATTACK ON UN HUMAN RIGHTS SYSTEM

TEXT.P: Mainland China has quickly exploited Australia's recent attack on the UN human rights system, with its envoy in Canberra allegedly saying both countries share common frustrations with the world organization.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday reported that a counselor from the mainland Chinese embassy in Canberra made the comment in talks with officials of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), and offered Beijing's sympathy with Australia's stance on mandatory sentencing laws now being introduced in the Northern Territories and Western Australia.
However, when the daily contacted the mainland Chinese embassy in Canberra, a spokesman flatly denied that the counselor had made any such comment during his routine talks with DFAT officials.

Australia made a scathing attack on the UN Human Rights Commission (UNHRC) after its committee described the laws as racially discriminatory. Under the laws, minor crimes such as shoplifting by kids, mainly Aborigines, can be severely punished by jail terms.
Mainland China is now in the midst of an international campaign to defeat a US-sponsored resolution to condemn Beijing's human rights abuses and violations now being considered by the UNHRC.

The Clinton administration has asked Australia to support its resolution to condemn mainland China, but Foreign Minister Alexander Downer has signalled that Canberra will refuse to give Washington such backing, the daily reported.

Australia has since 1997 refused to support any condemnation on mainland China's human rights abuses. Instead, Canberra uses bilateral annual talks with Beijing to voice its warning or opposition to widespread mainland Chinese violations, preventing public disputes over this issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY MOVES TO ABOLISH GRAND JUSTICES

TEXT.P: Irritated by a ruling of the Grand Justices Council against the National Assembly (NA), one NA delegate moved on Saturday to abolish the council through a constitutional amendment.

Speaking on the first day of a snap meeting, assemblyman Hsieh Ming-hui accused the Grand Justices of overstepping their authority by annulling a decision by the country's supreme lawmaking body responsible for amending the Constitution.

The Grand Justices Council ruled late last month that the NA's decision by a secret ballot last September to extend its members terms is invalid because of its self-interested nature and the lack of transparency in the vote.

Riding on the backlash of his colleagues against the ruling, Hsieh accused the Grand Justices Council of infringing on the law-making powers of the assembly and of threatening to upset the democratic process by abusing its power to explain the Constitution.

He also derided the Grand Justices as hypocritical, and claimed the council has itself issued a self-serving ruling to guarantee its members the stature of regular judges with a lifetime salary, despite the fact that their terms are for just eight years.

Noting that the Grand Justices Council have handed down a total of 499 rulings in the last 55 years, or 10 rulings on average per year, Hsieh said it is not worthwhile to have a body which does such little work but for which each of the 15 grand justices are paid a staggering NT$350,000 (US$11,600) per month by the taxpayer.

He claimed a proposal to do away the Grand Justices Council has already been signed by about 70 NA deputies, above the minimum requirement of 63 signatures for any constitutional amendment proposal. He added that he will present the initiative for debate in the near future.

The NA concluded its preparatory meeting for a snap conference on Saturday, during which delegates took turns to lambaste the Grand Justices Council as one of the causes of the country's "constitutional chaos."
Acting NA Speaker Chen Ching-jang said after the meeting that the delegates will try to make the assembly a nominal organization elected and convened only as the need arises.

Under a plan negotiated by NA delegates of the Kuomintang and Democratic Progressive Party, the body will shift its main job of amending the Constitution to the Legislative Yuan, while keeping the rest of its responsibilities.
If everything goes as planned, the proposal to eviscerate the assembly will pass the third and last reading on April 25, just in time to prevent the next National Assembly election slated for May 6.

Tired of being described as the culprits of Taiwan's "constitutional chaos" because of their tinkering with the country's basic law, many delegates are more than willing to abolish the National Assembly for good.
During Saturday's meeting, they tabled a proposal to ask the Central Election Commission to postpone the National Assembly election pending the outcome of the current session.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH EXPORTS AND IMPORTS HIT SINGLE-MONTH HIGH

TEXT.P: Taiwan's import and export trade each hit single-month highs in March, marking resounding double-digit growth for the sixth consecutive month, the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Saturday.
Taiwan exported US$11.98 billion-worth of products in March, and imported US$11.54 billion-worth of commodities, for a monthly surplus of US$440 million, said MOF officials.
The shining performance indicates that Taiwan's brisk foreign trade has not been affected by the March 18 presidential election, the officials noted.

They attributed the March growth -- 15.2 percent for exports and 23.8 percent for imports -- mainly to a continued expansion of business in major trading areas including the United States, Asia and Europe.

In March, Taiwan exports to Japan, South Korea and Southeast Asian countries soared 35.1 percent, 43 percent and 22 percent, respectively, while imports from the United States, Japan and Southeast Asia surged an average of 15 percent, the officials noted.

Cumulatively, Taiwan exported US$32.90 billion-worth of commodities in the first quarter of this year, up 18.5 percent from the same period of the previous year, while it imported US$31.57 billion-worth of goods, up 25.7 percent.
As a result, Taiwan posted a trade surplus of US$1.33 billion for the first three months of the year.

While electronics, telecommunications, machinery, iron and steel products and optical goods and equipment enjoyed brisk export trade in the first quarter, products from traditional manufacturing industries also posted improved sales, they said.
By area, exports to the United States grew 9.2 percent in the first quarter, while exports to Asia jumped 27.5 percent.

Capital equipment and agricultural and industrial raw materials made up the bulk of Taiwan's imports from abroad in the first quarter. Imports from the United States, Japan and Southeast Asia all soared 25 percent during the period, according to MOF tallies.
MOF officials estimated that the upturn trend in two-way trade will continue to gain momentum for the rest of this year as world economies pick up steam and global demand grows.

DOC.HEADLINE: WHITE-COLLAR WORKERS CARE MOST ABOUT GETTING ALONG WITH CO-WORKERS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's white-collar workers' principal concern is getting along with co-workers, according to the results of a survey released on Saturday.

The survey conducted by Cheers, a quarterly magazine launched by the monthly Commonwealth, found that getting along with colleagues and superiors is the major source of happiness or worry for the country's white-collar workers, estimated at 3.56 million.

Asked about the most painful facet of the workplace, the top two answers from the respondents had to do with human relations: not getting along with direct superiors (35.7 percent}, and not getting along with colleagues (34.5 percent).

The survey of 396 college graduates aged over 20 also found that 42 percent feel their sense of achievement in their work falls far short of their expectations, while 43 percent feel it more or less matches their expectations.
Sixty-six percent of those polled said work is one of the most important parts of their lives, equal to family and religion.
Asked about their impressions of their top three favored jobs, only 17.7 percent said their most desired job would be challenging, while 17.3 percent said their favorite job would pay a high salary.

On the other hand, 35 percent said they are not satisfied with their wages, with manufacturing industry workers expressing the greatest discontent (41.5 percent), followed by telecommunications industry personnel.

High-tech industry workers expressed dissatisfaction with their working hours, with 86 percent of the respondents saying they work more than eight hours a day, and up to 12 percent working more than 12 hours a day.

Asked about their loyalty to their companies, it was found that the respondents tended to show more loyalty to themselves than to their companies, hardly surprising in this time of mergers and reorganizations.

Asked what they would do in the face of company belt-tightening and a 10-percent salary cut when the company is in trouble, the survey found that 31.1 percent of those polled would work even harder to help tide the company over its difficulties, but 53.6 percent said they would do their share of work but would not shoulder the company's difficulties.
On the other hand, 6.7 percent said their working attitude would become more lax, while 8.7 percent said they would jump ship for a new job as soon as they could.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIEF OF GENERAL STAFF NOT MULLING OFFER OF DEFENSE MINISTER JOB

TEXT.P: Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming said on Saturday that out of consideration for national stability, he will not take the helm of the Ministry of National Defense (MND).

Tang explained at a press conference that as a subordinate of National Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been invited by President-elect Chen Shui-bian to serve as the nation's premier, and for a personal promotion, he should accept the offer to serve as national defense chief.
But he noted that Chen's inauguration on May 20 will see a drastic change of political scene, and if this was to be coupled with similar changes in the military, it would affect national stability.
Tang said that he had already exchanged views with the commander-in-chiefs of the three branches of the armed services, and that they had accepted his decision.
But he also stressed that he will not interfere or comment on the lineup of the new administration, adding that the military will fully support whoever serves as the defense chief.

The lineup of Chen's Cabinet has become the focus of intense scrutiny in the wake of the March 18 presidential election, which saw an end to more than 50 years of Kuomintang rule in Taiwan, and the victory of Chen and his pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 8, or the fourth day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
217 AD: Caracalla, or Marcus Aurelius Antonius, the Roman emperor who was obsessed with and sought to imitate Alexander the Great, is assassinated after a bloody reign.
1513: Juan Ponce de Leon, the Spanish explorer who completed the conquest of Puerto Rico, discovers Florida and claims it for the Spanish throne.
1838: The Great Western, a new 236-foot steamship which is the first to cross the Atlantic regularly, leaves Bristol on her maiden voyage to Boston.
1861: Elisha Graves Otis, the American inventor of the passenger elevator which was first installed in 1857, dies at the age of 50.
1893: Mary Pickford, the American actress who became known as "America's Sweetheart," is born in Canada as Gladys Smith.
1902: China's Ching court and Russia reach agreement on the evacuation of Manchuria. After the Boxer Uprising in 1900, Russia took the opportunity to occupy Manchuria. When the troops of the other foreign powers withdrew from Chinese territory, Russia refused to leave Manchuria.
1904: Britain and France sign the Entente Cordiale, a mutual recognition of each other's interests with particular regard to France's in Morocco and Britain's in Egypt.
1907: France and Britain sign convention confirming the independence of Siam (now Thailand).
1914: The Republic of China's first Congress is organized in Beijing.
1919: Russian communist army enters the Crimea.
1913: Brazil officially recognizes the Republic of China, which was founded on Jan. 1, 1912, becoming the first country in the world to do so.
1919: Ian Smith, the Rhodesian prime minister who unilaterally declared independence from Britain in 1965 in the interest of retaining white supremacy, is born.
1925: The Australian government and the British Colonial Office offer low-interest loans to encourage 500,000 Britons to emigrate to Australia.
1946: The League of Nations holds its final session in Geneva. It was later replaced by the United Nations.
1950: Pakistan and India sign pact in New Delhi on the treatment of minorities.
1953: The British colonial administration in Kenya sentences Jomo Kenyatta, alleged to be the leader of the secret terror organization known as the Mau Mau, and five others to seven years' hard labor.
1958: US President Dwight D. Eisenhower proposes mutual inspection as means of enforcing nuclear test ban.
1962: Cuban leader Fidel Castro offers to ransom prisoners held since the US invasion of the Bay of Pigs on April 19, 1961.
1965: The ROC severs diplomatic relations with the Republic of Dahomey.
1966: Leonid Brezhnev is elected general secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. He later became president of the USSR in 1977.
1973: Dr. Mohammed Abder Rahman Basbeer, minister of communications of Jordan, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1973: Pablo Picasso, the Spanish artist who was one of the most prolific and influential artists of the 20th century, dies in his chateau at Mougins at the age of 92. He excelled in painting, sculpture, etching, stage design, and ceramics.
1977: Israeli Prime Minister Yitzak Rabin admits violating Israel's currency laws. He later resigned.
1979: Lee Pao-chen, a noted Chinese musician, dies in Taipei at the age of 73.
1981: Omar Nelson Bradley, the American general who played a major part in the Allied victory in World War II, dies at the age of 88. He commanded the US forces in the Normandy invasion and later led the 12th Army Group as France was liberated.
1986: Clint Eastwood, the screen tough guy famed for his portrayal of "Dirty Harry," is elected mayor of Carmel, a Californian resort town.
1989: More than 60 Soviet submariners die after a nuclear-powered "Mike" class submarine refuses assistance from nearby Western merchant ships after catching fire off the coast of Norway.
1990: ROC Economics Minister Chen Li-an and Singaporean Minister of Trade and Industries Lee Hsien Loong preside over the first ministerial-level conference on economic cooperation between the two countries.
1991: The second extraordinary session of the First National Assembly is convened in Taipei to discuss constitutional reforms.
1992: Palestinian leader Yasser Arafat is found alive 12 hours after his plane crashes in the Sahara desert, killing three crew aboard.
1994: Japanese Prime Minister Morihiro Hosokawa resigns over a loan scandal.

DOC.HEADLINE: US DOLLAR DIPS SLIGHTLY IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The US dollar dipped slightly against the NT dollar on the Taipei Foreign Exchange Market on Saturday, dropping NT$0.078 to close at NT$30.36.
A total of US$364 million changed hands.
The greenback opened at NT$30.397 and was traded between NT$30.345 and NT$30.405.

DOC.HEADLINE: SENATE LEADER PRESSES FOR ARM SALES TO TAIWAN WHILE SUPPORTING TSEA
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 7 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: US Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott (R-MS) is pressing for arms sales to Taiwan while aggressively supporting a bill designed to strengthen military ties with the island, his spokesman said on Friday.

John Czwartacki dismissed as an "irresponsible piece of journalism" a report in Friday's Washington Times that Lott intended to kill the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) in exchange for the administration's promise to sell four Aegis guided-missile destroyers to the island.
Lott "wants both the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act and a robust package of arms for Taiwan", Czwartacki stressed.
President Bill Clinton's administration opposes the TSEA, which calls for closer military ties with Taiwan, and is reviewing Taiwan's request to purchase the four Aegis destroyers.

Claiming it will tilt the power balance across the Taiwan Strait and embroil the United States more deeply in the Taipei-Beijing dispute, Clinton's administration had lobbied against the TSEA even before the bill cruised through the House of Representatives on Oct. 26. It has since been shelved by the Senate at the request of the White House.
By the same token, the Pentagon is being cautious in weighing the sale of the destroyers that would address the island's weakness in defenses against a Beijing missile attack.
The Washington Times said Lott, one of the co-sponsors of the TSEA, tried to use the bill as leverage against the government to press it for concessions on arms sales to Taiwan.

If the Pentagon approves the deal, two of the four destroyers -- with a price tag of US$1 billion each -- will be built in Lott's home state of Mississippi, and will boost the senator's re-election campaign in November.
The newspaper quoted sources as saying that defense officials opted to offer Taiwan a "watered-down" version of the destroyer without the air defense system or Tomahawk cruise missiles.

DOC.HEADLINE: SHARE PRICES RISE MODESTLY

TEXT.P: Share prices rose 0.1 percent on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted price index, the market's key barometer, rising 13.54 points to close at 9,934.57.
Analysts said that with the bullish sentiment unchanged, and steady buying on the part of investors, they are expecting share prices to reclaim the 10,000-point mark next week.

The bourse opened higher on Saturday but soon began a downward drift. Electronics shares showed the only increase, rising 1.3 percent, while most other categories, including plastic and chemicals, textiles, foodstuffs, financial, paper and pulp and construction stocks registered modest drops.
Losers outnumbered gainers 358 to 186, with 53 shares remaining unchanged.
Saturday's turnover totaled NT$219.78 billion (US$7.22 billion).
Meanwhile, prices on Taipei's stock index futures market also dropped.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighed Index Futures (TAIEX Index Futures) for April dropped 35 points to close at 10,044, with 1,689 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May surged 75 points to close at 10,149, with 183 contract transactions, while June futures rose 19 points to close at 10,199, with 13 contract transactions. September futures dropped 169 points to close at 10,300, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CETRANET'S VIRTUAL TRADE MART SERVING BUSINESS COMMUNITY

TEXT.P: As Taiwan's leading trade promotion organization, the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) plays a pioneering role in the business world, and in the new Internet era, CETRA has been keeping up with developments.
The "Virtual Trade Mart" proves its effectiveness in this regard.

For the last two years, CETRA has gradually developed an Internet service of all its trade information. The CetraNet website provides not only information on CETRA activities, but also data on international trade opportunities, an introduction to Taiwan manufacturers and traders, and official statistics.

The "Virtual Trade Mart" is a service for Taiwan traders and foreign buyers. The online mart includes over 35,000 Taiwan companies and 150,000 product items. Foreign buyers can locate whatever products or services are listed on the website through e-mail or fax.

CETRA Deputy Secretary-General Thomas Tsou said that many manufacturers are amazed by the effectiveness of the online trading system, and some of them report receiving online orders or inquiries every week.

Tsou attributed the effectiveness of the "Virtual Trade Mart" to CETRA's years of efforts in developing an enormous data bank with over 100,000 items of business information, including Taiwan manufacturers, traders, foreign buyers and international trade fairs. This data bank is open to CETRA members free of charge.
Many small- and medium-sized businesses took their first step into the Internet world through the "Virtual Trade Mart," according to Melody Lin, deputy director of CetraNet Center.

Lin said that 37,000 Taiwan manufacturers have registered with the "Virtual Trade Mart," and claimed that trade revenue of these manufacturers accounts for 95 percent of the nation's foreign trade value. These manufacturers can be taken as an index of the development of e-commerce in Taiwan, she said.

In many international conferences and seminars on e-commerce, CETRA delegates are very often questioned on online trading by their counterparts from Thailand, Malaysia and Indonesia, and Taiwan, together with Japan and Hong Kong, is considered advanced in e-commerce among Asian countries, according to Lin.

Tsou emphasized that CETRA hopes to further explore trade opportunities for Taiwan traders with all the convenience provided by the Internet environment. Since the concept is well accepted by industry, CETRA is now studying possibilities to provide more services in cash flow, commodity flow and logistics through the Internet.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA TO VISIT TAIWAN AGAIN THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The Dalai Lama, the exiled spiritual leader of Tibet, will make his second visit to Taiwan later this year, sources from the Tibet Religious Foundation said on Saturday.

However, owing to his tight schedule for this year, which was arranged a year ago, the Dalai Lama will be unable to visit in May to attend President-elect Chen Shui-bian's inauguration slated for May 20, a foundation spokesman said.
Although the Dalai Lama cannot come in May, he will definitely visit Taiwan before the end of this year to propagate Buddhism and to meet some "old friends" of his, the spokesman added.
The Tibetan leader, revered among his people as a god-king, paid a four-day visit to Taiwan in March 1997.

The spokesman said bilateral relations between Taiwan and Tibet have grown by leaps and bounds ever since the 1997 visit, and religious exchanges became increasingly close between the two sides, enabling the Tibet Religious Foundation to be established in Taipei smoothly in September of the same year, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELECTION COMMISSION TO CONSIDER PUTTING OFF NA ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will convene a meeting to discuss putting off the May 6 National Assembly election after receiving formal notification from the assembly, CEC Deputy Secretary-General Tsai Li-hsueh said on Saturday.

The assembly adopted a resolution earlier in the day to shelve the election for the time being because assembly deputies will amend the Constitution in the coming weeks to eviscerate the assembly into an "empty-frame" institution.
As the National Assembly election is expected to cost more than NT$1 billion (US$32.3 million), the deputies thus moved to call for the election to be shelved for the time being.

The CEC has already announced that it will accept registrations between April 9-13 from those wishing to participate in the election scheduled to be held on May 6. The four-year term of the incumbent assembly deputies expires on May 19.

Now that the assembly has adopted the resolution to call for postponement of the election, however, the CEC will convene a meeting of its members after the resolution is forwarded to it through the Executive Yuan.

The assembly has 339 seats, of which 239 are elected from among 25 counties and cities, as well as lowland and highland aboriginal regions. Eighty others are elected from the nationwide constituency, with a further 20 elected from among overseas Chinese communities, both through a system of proportional representation.

The Kuomintang, which lost its 54-year reign of power on Taiwan to the Democratic Progressive Party in the March 18 presidential election, has completed its nomination of candidates for the assembly election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Satellite park of the Tainan Science-based Industrial Park will be set up in Luchu, Kaohsiung County.
The China Times:
National Assembly (NA) demands delay of next election.
The United Daily News:
The lineup of military and intelligence chiefs in the new administration becomes clearer.
The Liberty Times:
NA moves to put off next election.
The China Post:
NA demands postponement of new election.
The Taiwan News:
NA votes to ask election delay.
The Taipei Times:
Vice President-elect Annette Lu shrugs off China's attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 9, or the fifth day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1241: Batu Khan, grandson of Genghis Khan, leads his Mongol horsemen to victory over the Teutonic Knights at Liegniz, Silesia.
1626: Sir Francis Bacon, English philosopher, essayist, courtier, jurist, and statesman, dies at the age of 65. His writings include "The Advancement of Learning," and the "Novum Organum," in which he proposed a theory of scientific knowledge based on observation and experiment that came to be known as the inductive method.
1667: The world's first art exhibition opens in Paris, and lasts for 15 days.
1682: La Salle, the title of Robert Cavelier, the French explorer of North America who claimed Louisiana for France in 1682, reaches the Gulf of Mexico after traveling down the Mississippi River.
1806: English engineer Isambard Kingdom Brunel is born. His achievements included the Clifton suspension bridge in Bristol, the Great Western steamship, and the Great Western railway.
1865: Confederation Gen. Robert E. Lee surrenders to Union Gen. Ulysses S. Grant at the Appomattox Courthouse in Virginia, ending the US Civil War.
1926: Tuan Chi-jui resigns as provisional chief executive of the Republic of China.
1928: Islam is no longer recognized as the state religion of Turkey.
1940: German troops invade Norway and Denmark.
1942: American and Filipino forces on Bataan surrender to the Japanese after a four-month siege.
1945: Dietrich Bonhoeffer, the German theologian who involved himself with anti-Hitler conspirators, dies in Buchenwald concentration camp.
1957: Egypt announces the opening of the Suez Canal after the withdrawal of invading troops from Great Britain and France from Port Said.
1961: The Republic of Vietnam holds its first presidential elections with Ngo Dinh Diem elected as president.
1963: British Prime Minister Winston Churchill is proclaimed an honorary US citizen at the White House.
1965: The ROC and the United States conclude in Taipei an accord to establish a Sino-American fund for economic and social development in Taiwan.
1969: Concorde, the supersonic passenger jet, makes its maiden flight from Bristol to Fairford in England.
1970: Singer-songwriter Paul McCartney issues a High Court writ winding up the business partnership of the squabbling Beatles.
1973: Hedley Donavan, editor-in-chief of Time magazine, arrives in Taipei for a two-day visit.
1973: Lt. Gen. Thomas K. McGebee, commander of the US Aerospace Defense Command, arrives in Taipei from Bangkok for a three-day visit.
1974: Nguyen Van Kieu, newly elevated Vietnamese ambassador-extraordinary and plenipotentiary, presents a copy of his credentials to ROC Foreign Minister Shen Chang-huan.
1976: The fifth congress of the Federation of Asian Photographic Arts opens with 200 representatives from South Korea, the Philippines, India, Indonesia, Sabah and the ROC attending.
1976: Bernard B. Matawali, permanent secretary of the Ministry of Agriculture of Malawi, arrives in Taipei for a five-day visit.
1977: The Spanish Communist Party is legalized.
1988: Mainland China's National Peoples Congress names Li Peng as premier.
1990: The Democratic Forum of Hungary sweeps to power in elections, after 40 years of communism.
1991: Georgia declares independence from the Soviet Union.
1998: More than 100 Muslim pilgrims are crushed to death in a stampede at the Haj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "When there is justice and order in the government of the country a man may be bold and lofty in the expression of his opinions as well as in his actions. When, however, there is no justice and order in the government of the country, a man may be bold and lofty in his actions, but should be reserved in the expression of his opinion."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-FINANCED FLOWER DISPLAY CENTER INAUGURATED IN PARAGUAY
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, April 8 (CNA) (By Raymond Huang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Paraguay's first flower exhibition center was inaugurated in the Central Province city of Caacupe on Saturday, with Paraguayan President Luis Gonzalez Macchi and Republic of China Ambassador to Asuncion Liu Ting-tsu cutting the ribbon.
Gonzalez said that the center will play an important role in promoting the development and exports of his country's horticulture industry.
He was impressed by the modern design of the center, and expressed the hope that the ROC agricultural mission in Paraguay will be able to help improve the garden design of the presidential office.
Liu noted that the inauguration of the center will not only increase the income of local horticulturists, but will also help the development of that country's tourism.
The center was constructed with the help of a donation of US$280,000 from the ROC International Cooperation and Development Fund and other sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: US IGNORING MAINLAND CHINESE THREAT TO TAIWAN, ANALYSTS CLAIM

TEXT.P: The United States has totally ignored the nature and magnitude of the mainland Chinese threat to Taiwan, according to American defense analysts.

Brian Kennedy, vice president of the Claremont Institute in California, claimed recently that Taiwan does not have effective air or missile defense systems. "But the US commitment appears to be somewhat unclear, and that is the real danger for Taiwan," he went on.

"A very dangerous situation will occur if we are ambiguous about our willingness to defend Taiwan. We should be very willing to discuss with China and Taiwan future relations so that a democratic unification can occur. But we should make very clear that we are not willing to acquiesce to a reunification by force," emphasized Kennedy.

The defense analyst said US ambiguity on whether it will come to Taiwan's defense in the event of an attack by mainland China is inviting a situation similar to that which existed in the Middle East immediately before the Gulf War. By not unequivocally stating its intention to stand by Kuwait, the United States led Iraqi President Saddam Hussein to believe he could attack Kuwait with impunity.

"They say the mainland is not going to attack and even if it wanted to, it could not do it. But in the past year people have been forced to admit there is a threat to Taiwan's security that is new and potentially more dangerous," noted Stephen J. Yates, a senior policy analyst in the Asian Studies Center at the Washington-based Heritage Foundation.

He was commenting on questions raised by a new, unpublished Pentagon report, which says Taiwan is more vulnerable to attack from mainland China than generally recognized because Taiwan's isolated military has fallen behind technologically.
The highly classified Pentagon report points out problems with the Taiwanese military's ability to defend against aircraft, ballistic missiles and cruise missiles.

The United States has presumed Taiwan is strong enough to defend itself and does not need more advanced US weapons, Yates said. "But in the last few months people have begun to realize that Taiwan's defense systems and equipment have atrophied after two decades of diplomatic isolation. Not only is there a greater threat from the mainland, but Taiwan is less capable of efficiently marshaling its own resources to defend itself."

Taiwan is unnecessarily -- and some say unlawfully -- being penalized for lack of diplomatic recognition from the United States because of the Taiwan Relations Act of 1979. According to this Act, the Clinton administration is required to consult with Congress and to provide Taiwan with defense articles and services based solely on Taiwan's defense needs, "not based on the politics of US-China relations and certainly not based on any expressed opposition by Beijing to arms sales to Taiwan," stressed Yates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN VISITORS TO MACAU RISE SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Visitors traveling to and from Macau via Taiwan airports last year topped 1.72 million, up 23.7 percent over the preceding year, according to statistics released on Sunday by the Ministry of Transportation and Communication (MOTC).
As Macau was returned to mainland China by Portugal last December, MOTC officials said that more visitors are expected to use the Taiwan-Macau route to enter mainland China in the future.
The statistics show that travelers between Taiwan and Hong Kong reached 5.9 million, up 10.9 percent over 1998, and travelers between Taiwan and Japan were up 3.3 percent to 3.78 million.
At the same time, travelers between Taiwan and the Philippines registered a 21.6 percent decrease, mainly because of the suspension of Taiwan-Philippine air services.
Meanwhile, as more Taiwan investors are eyeing the market in Vietnam, travelers between Taiwan and Vietnam amounted to 630,000 in 1999, an increase of 18.9 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: Largest fuel-cell power test plant to be build in Canada

TEXT.P: The world's largest prototype heat and power plant using solid oxide fuel-cell technology will be built in Canada under a joint project with the United States.
The C$18-million project is being jointly funded by the Canadian government, the US Department of Energy and Siemens Westinghouse Power Corp.

Solid oxide fuel-cell systems convert chemical energy directly to electrical energy. The fuel-cell concept dates to the 1830s but has only recently been developed for practical applications as an environmentally friendly energy technology.
Once commercially available, the system will have great potential to serve commercial and industrial customers.

DOC.HEADLINE: TZU CHI FOUNDATION TO START SCHOOL-BUILDING IN QUAKE-STRICKEN AREAS
DOC.DATELINE: Chunghsing New Village, Nantou, April 9 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The Tzu Chi Buddhist Compassionate Relief Foundation is to start rebuilding schools in earthquake-stricken areas of central Taiwan this week.

The Hualien-based Buddhist group, headed by Master Shih Cheng Yen, has pledged to reconstruct 45 middle high and elementary schools in Nantou, Taichung and Chiayi counties, all of which suffered extensive damage in last September's temblor. Eleven of the schools are under the commission of the Education Ministry.
Ceremonies to mark the start of construction work on the first group of five schools will take place in Taichung and Nantou counties on Monday and Tuesday, and will be attended by Shih Cheng Yen.
Tzu Chi has so far raised about NT$5 billion (US$161.3 million) for the school reconstruction projects, but an additional NT$2 billion (US$64.5 million) is still required.
During the construction period, some 5,000 Tzu Chi volunteers throughout the island will be mobilized to support the projects.

DOC.HEADLINE: NETHERLANDS REPRESENTATIVE WIDELY TIPPED AS NATIONAL DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: Adm. Ku Chung-lien, the Republic of China's representative to the Netherlands, could emerge as the candidate to succeed Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been named premier, local reports said on Sunday.

With his naval background, Ku fits the "balanced" principle for the military espoused by President-elect Chen Shui-bian. Tang comes from the air force, while Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming is an army man.

Pressed by reporters on Sunday about the best candidate to fill the Defense Ministry vacancy, Tang said that the ideal man will be one who has integrity, who enjoys high esteem in the military, and who can work well with government agencies.
He added that there are not many choices who can meet these conditions.
Ku, who shares a similar military and overseas background with Tang, will therefore find it easy to communicate with the new premier, reports said.
Tang has previously served as Associate Air Attache in the ROC embassy in the United States and as Armed Forces Attache in the ROC embassy in South Africa.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS ATTEND ANNUAL MEETING OF HAKKA PEOPLE IN TOKYO
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 9 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: The 34th annual meeting of the Tokyo Chungcheng Council, formed by Hakka people residing there, was held in Tokyo on Sunday, attended by more than 400 members and dignitaries.

A large-scale mission from Taiwan also attended the meeting. Members included Legislative Yuan Vice President Yao Eng-chi, Presidential Senior Adviser Wu Po-hsiung and Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission Vice Chairman Chu Chien-yi.

In a speech on the occasion, Wu expressed his hearty appreciation for the relief fund and materials raised by overseas Chinese residents for the victims of last September's devastating earthquake in Taiwan.

Turning to the March 18 presidential election, he said that democratic politics in Taiwan has matured, and added that although the administration has changed, the new president will still have to care about the welfare of the people.
The 20-member Taiwan mission will also confer with leaders of the Japan-ROC Parliamentarians' Council on Monday to exchange views on the promotion of bilateral substantive relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: ABOLISHING GRAND JUSTICE COUNCIL WON'T RESOLVE ISSUE: SOONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, April 9 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Chairman of the newly established People First Party (PFP) James Soong said on Sunday that a National Assembly (NA) proposal to abolish the Grand Justice Council will not resolve the problem.
Soong said that the system of government must be respected and that any abolishing or establishing of government institutions should be carefully evaluated beforehand.

The NA proposal to abolish the Grand Justice Council because it is dissatisfied with the council's explanation of a constitutional issue is a knee-jerk reaction which does not resolve the issue but is no more than a quarrel over a matter of emotion rather than reason, Soong said.
Soong made the remarks at the inauguration of the office of the PFP's Hualien chapter.
He also said a NA resolution last August to extend the tenure of NA deputies runs counter to the voice of the populace, violates democratic, social and procedural justice.
Asked about the future of NA, Soong said that although the PFP has agreed to the establishment of a unicameral parliament, a lot of related measures must be addressed to achieve that end.

Soong also said that both the Kuomintang and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) should echo the voice of people and not monopolize national policy because of party interests. If they do not, he went on, the populace will "use their votes to express their opposition," he added.
Asked about news reports that Legislator Liao Fu-pen (KMT-Yunlin) wants to join the PFP, Soong said that the PFP welcomes those who share the ideals of the PFP's four-point assertion.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUBLIC ENDORSEMENT URGED TO ABOLISH NATIONAL ASSEMBLY

TEXT.P: An alliance formed among more than 20 social activity organizations on Sunday launched a public drive to abolish the National Assembly (NA), and urged major political parties to join forces with them.

The "Public Alliance to Abolish the National Assembly" urged the public and the four leading political parties -- the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the People First Party (PFP), the Kuomintang (KMT) and the New Party -- to give their endorsement by signing on at the "www.taiwanrepublic.com/sayno.htm" website, and announced that they will sponsor a large-scale rally next Sunday to demonstrate their bid.

Although abolishing the NA has been a common aspiration of the people of Taiwan, according to a spokesman for the alliance, he added that it is inconceivable that the political parties are preparing for a re-election of NA deputies on the one hand, while shouting for the abolishment of the body on the other.
"Another NA election will only cost more money and make the issue more complicated," he argued.
The Council of Grand Justices ruled last month that a two-year term expansion by the current NA was unconstitutional and that an election should be held to elect new deputies.

A number of NA deputies from the DPP and KMT were to hold a meeting on Sunday to study ways to abolish the body before the May 6 election date, thus preventing the PFP, led by former Taiwan Governor James Soong, from gaining a foothold in the NA.
Soong lost the March 18 presidential election to the DPP's President-elect Chen Shui-bian by a slim margin of 2.5 percent.

Meanwhile, the Central Election Commission (CEC) and its branches around the island began receiving registrations for the fourth NA as scheduled, despite a demand from the current NA that the election be postponed.

The registration will run through Thursday, and candidates will draw their campaign numbers on April 22, three days before the election campaign officially kicks off, CEC Vice Secretary-General L.S. Tsai said.

As to the NA's election postponement demand, Tsai said the CEC will discuss the issue after receiving formal notification from the NA, while all election arrangements will continue to be made in compliance with the law.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP HAS NO PLANS TO BUY TV STATION: CHAIRMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien County, eastern Taiwan, April 9 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The People First Party (PFP) has neither the financial resources nor the intention to buy into news media, PFP Chairman James Soong said on Sunday.
Soong made the statement to deny a rumor that the PFP intends to buy the floundering privately run Global Television Station.
He stressed that the objectivity of the media should be protected, and that political parties should not get involved in the news media.

Soong pointed out that high-ranking officials of the outgoing Kuomintang controlled all three of Taiwan's terrestrial TV stations -- Taiwan Television Enterprise Ltd., China Television Co. and Chinese Television System -- during the campaign period of the March 18 presidential election.

He referred to the KMT's abuse of privilege in its monopolization of the three stations' advertising, giving priority to the KMT's presidential candidate and preventing Soong's campaign advertisements from being broadcast.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDB: NEXT 3 YEARS WILL BE EXPLOSIVE ERA FOR E-BUSINESS SOFTWARE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs foresees that the coming three years will be an explosive era for the e-business software industry.
The IDB called on the local software industry to redouble their efforts to develop e-business software technology.

The IDB also estimated that the proportion of Taiwan's software industry in the world market will rise from 0.063 percent in 1999 to 1 percent in 2002 as it gradually becomes an important player in the international market.

Statistics compiled by the IDB show the worth of local Internet Service Providers and e-business increased by NT$30 billion in 1999. Taiwan also exported NT$20 billion-worth of software and NT$5 billion to NT$10 billion-worth of compact discs in 1999.
The IDB also predicted that the total business of the software industry will break the NT$200 billion mark in the coming three years.
It said that the current capital investment of a local software company averaged NT$230 million, with dividends averaging NT$2.45 per share.

More than 20 software companies will be listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TSE) before the end of 2001, the IDB said, adding that the revenue of leading software companies will register a 30 percent-50 percent growth rate in the coming three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: `TOURIST ERA' HAS COME IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: With a per capita GDP (gross domestic product) reaching US$900, the tourist era has come to mainland China, a spokesman for mainland China's National Tourism Administration (NTA) said on Sunday.
The Hong Kong-based Wen Hui Pao daily quoted Wei Xiaoan, an NTA department director, as reporting that mainland China's tourism industry has boomed over the last few years.

Wei cited official statistics as showing that during the Chinese New Year holiday, 200,000 Beijing city residents traveled to suburban Beijing, and 100,000 traveled abroad, while 600,000 Shanghai residents left the city, which he described as an all-time boom in the two major cities' tourism industry.
Another recent survey shows that travel has become one of the key "quality of life" elements sought by mainland Chinese under the age of 35.
Wei also cited three conclusions outlined by the World Tourism Organization in 1997:
-- By 2020, an annual average of 1.6 people/journeys will be recorded around the world, three times the current level;
-- The world's average annual touring expenditure will be US$2 trillion, with an average daily expenditure of US$5 billion, 4.5 times the current level.
-- The average annual growth rate of tourist numbers is 4.3 percent, while the average annual growth rate of tourism revenue is 6.7 percent.
Wei estimated that by 2020, an annual average of 16 billion people/journeys will be recorded in mainland China, with a total expenditure of US$20 trillion.

DOC.HEADLINE: THREE DIRECT LINKS NOT POSSIBLE THIS YEAR: TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 9 (CNA) (By S.C. Peng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan businessmen with operations in mainland China are pessimistic about the likelihood of the establishment of the "three direct links" between Taiwan and mainland China within this year.

Although the setting up of direct trade, transport and postal links across the Taiwan Strait ranks high on the policy agenda of Taiwan's President-elect Chen Shui-bian, mainland-based Taiwan businessmen feel that the issue is no longer a bargaining chip for Taiwan in its dealings with mainland China.

"If Chinese communists promised to open the three direct links now, it undoubtedly would be a big face-saver for Chen," one businessman commented, pointing out that "mainland China will not do so at present judging from the current situation between the two sides."

"In fact, the establishment of the three direct links has a greater political than economic effect for the mainland," the businessman, a Beijing-based transport operator from Taiwan who requested anonymity, told CNA.

The mainland Chinese authorities are fully aware that Taiwan businesses will be the major beneficiary of the proposed opening of the three direct links across the Taiwan Strait because of Taiwan firms' greater competitiveness, he said, adding that "the Chinese communists understand very well that the establishment of such ties will not benefit the mainland on the economic front."

As the matter will bring only political benefits to mainland China, Beijing is in no hurry to talk about the issue with Taiwan at present," he observed, claiming that "Chinese communists are waiting for the best moment to discuss the issue with Taiwan in order to seek the maximum benefits on the political front."

Even though direct transport ties were to be opened between the two sides, the setting of the status of the cross-strait routes would also be another problem, another Taiwan businessman surnamed Huang told CNA.

While Taiwan wishes to set the cross-strait routes as "international" freight routes, mainland China's desire is to designate Taiwan-mainland routes as "domestic" ones, he elaborated, saying that a better solution might be to assign the cross-strait routes as "regional lines" which would in return affect the number of flights and price-setting between the two sides."

As for Taiwan media reports that mainland Chinese authorities have accused some Taiwan companies of cashing in on the mainland while supporting pro-independence forces in Taiwan, a businessman from Taiwan told CNA that they are not worried about any retaliation by Beijing.

The businessman, a supporter of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) who also asked not to be named, asserted that backing the DPP and its President-elect Chen does not mean he backs Taiwan's split from the mainland.

Lamenting the fact that some ranking Beijing officials hold exactly this belief, the Taiwan businessman claimed that Chen will be able to bravely broaden Taiwan-mainland relations, and added that he does not think Chen would sell Taiwan out, pointing to the example of former US President Richard Nixon, who he said was an staunch anti-communist but was able nevertheless to break a decade-old impasse between Beijing and Washington.
Furthermore, most large Taiwan companies should have taken measures to avoid political risks before investing in the mainland, he noted.

Turning to the question of the personal safety of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China, most Taiwan executives working there said they are not troubled by the problem as they are "simple businessmen" who are not interested in politics.
No matter which party is in power, stabilizing public confidence should be the top priority for the government, they contended, voicing the belief that "there will be no retaliation from Beijing."

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD SOCIETY URGED TO HELP CHINESE DISSIDENT ZHOU YONGJUN

TEXT.P: The family of Chinese dissident Zhou Yongjun recently urged world society to put pressure on Beijing for an early release of him from a labor camp, because the inner part of his nose is decaying and his family is in extreme poverty.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Sunday that Zhou, who is serving a three-year term in an "education through labor camp" in Mienyang city in southwestern Sichuan province, has a nasal infection and a constant fever. The mucous membrane in his nose is decaying.

Zhou, 33, was one of the student leaders in the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement. After being imprisoned for two years after the Tiananmen crackdown, he fled to the United States. He was sentenced to three years in a labor camp after he was arrested in the southeastern city of Guangzhou when he tried to sneak back to China in December, 1998 through Hong Kong to see his parents. His family has been in absolute poverty since then, the information center said.
His wife, Zhou Lan, hoped that the United Nations would do something to secure his early release from the labor camp, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT CHEN TALKS ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS

TEXT.P: In an interview with Washington Post columnist Lally Weymouth in Taipei, Chen said "Of course we want to move in a direction of reconciliation and dialogue. We do not want conflict. But in cross-strait relations, we feel it is important to have goodwill and sincerity. Only then can relations improve. But goodwill and sincerity cannot be only one way."

As to the Democratic Progressive Party's long-standing pro-independence position, Chen told Weymouth that "We do advocate the right to self-determination, but that is not the same as advocating Taiwanese independence. Our platform says that Taiwan's independence must be decided by the people of Taiwan (in a referendum). But having the right to hold a referendum does not mean that one must immediately do so. As president-elect, I will not initiate a referendum on the independence-unification question. Unless China invades or uses force, we will not declare independence unilaterally."

As to the "one China" principle, the president-elect pointed out that "If the 'one China' principle is defined as Taiwan being a province or local government of the People's Republic of China, this is not acceptable to the vast majority of people in Taiwan. Nor can (China) expect Taiwan to become the second Hong Kong. How can they expect me, as president of this country, to accept Taiwan's demotion in status to a province?"

Chen added that "If the mainland insists that acceptance of 'one China' is a precondition, it will be hard to resume dialogue. We prefer to see it as an issue that can be discussed (in talks). We can discuss the definition of 'one China' and arrive at a consensus."

Chen said "We hope talks can start with no predetermined outcome and that both sides can respect each other on an equal basis. But if China does insist on a precondition and an ultimate outcome, then such talks would not appear equal."

Chen noted that whether he would like to visit mainland China "is not a matter of whether I want to go but whether the PRC has the goodwill to let me go. I would like to lead a delegation on a friendship visit to the PRC. I also sincerely want to invite China's leaders like President Jiang Zemin or Premier Zhu Rongji to come to Taiwan. And I have invited Mr. Wang Daohan (China's veteran cross-strait negotiator) to attend my inauguration. But according to newspaper reports, they are not interested in such an invitation."

As to Taiwan's relationship with the United States, Chen said there are three key areas for improving or consolidating: to continue upholding the universal values of democracy and freedom, to maintain peace and stability in the Asia-Pacific region, and to continue to increase trade and commercial relations between the two countries.

"We feel that a democratic China will contribute to permanent peace in this region. Therefore, we support U.S. efforts to improve its relations with China. While we seek to normalize the cross-strait relationship -- especially in the area of business and trade -- we are happy to see the United States and China improve their economic relations. Therefore, I am willing to support the U.S. normalization of trade relations with the PRC. The improvement of U.S.-China relations is not necessarily harmful for Taiwan," said Chen.

He is convinced that Taiwan's military preparedness has improved significantly over the past few years, but there certainly is also room for improvement, especially in areas of professional training and ability to use modern or high-tech defense equipment. "We also need to improve U.S.-Taiwan military cooperation," stressed Chen.

When talking about the outgoing Kuomintang government's arms purchasing strategies, Chen said "We have only one national interest: The welfare of the people must not be endangered by a transition of government. And therefore, we have said that the (annual U.S.-Taiwan arms sales) talks scheduled for April should not be delayed simply because of a transition of government."
