DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 10, or the sixth day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: James V of Scotland, who became king at the age of 17 months, is born. He allied Scotland with France against the English.
1633: Bananas appear in stores in Britain for the first time.
1809: Austria declares war on France and invades Bavaria.
1810: Pirate chieftainess "Dragon Lady" Cheng Yi-sao surrenders herself and the 1,800 junks under her command to China's Ching court.
1814: British and Spanish forces defeat Napoleon's army at the Battle of Toulouse, leading to his abdication and exile to the island of Elba the next day.
1829: William Booth, the British religious leader who founded the Salvation Army with his wife Catherine Mumford Booth and who served as its first general, is born.
1841: Horace Greeley, former editor of Thurlow Weed's political campaign weeklies, launches the New York Tribune.
1847: Hungarian-born American journalist Joseph Pulitzer is born. The newspaper publisher owned newspapers in St. Louis and New York City and established and endowed the Pulitzer Prizes for achievements in journalism and literature.
1849: Walter Hunt of New York patents his safety pin in the United States.
1858: Chinese Governor-General Ye Ming-chen of Canton and a prisoner of Britain, dies in Calcutta during an Anglo-French expedition against Beijing in 1858.
1864: Archduke Maximilian of Austria becomes Emperor of Mexico.
1898: France obtains concessions from China's Ching court.
1919: Mexican revolutionary Emiliano Zapata, 30, is cut down in a hail of bullets after being ambushed by soldiers of the Carranza regime. He led a revolt (1910-1919) for agrarian reforms during which he captured Mexico City three times.
1921: Dr. Sun Yat-sen is elected president of the Republic of China.
1932: German general and politician Paul von Hindenburg is re-elected president of the Weimar Republic with 19 million votes to Adolf Hitler's 13 million. He appoints Hitler chancellor in 1933.
1932: Omar Sharif, the Egyptian actor whose many films include "Lawrence of Arabia," and "Doctor Zhivago," is born in Egypt as Michael Shalhoub.
1938: Most (99.75 percent) Austrians vote for a merger with Germany in a referendum.
1944: Russian troops recapture Odessa from the Germans.
1944: Brigadier General Charles de Gaulle, who is number one on the hit list of the collaborationist Vichy government of Marshal Petain, becomes commander-in-chief of all Free French forces.
1945: US forces liberate a Nazi concentration camp at Buchenwald, Germany.
1946: Japan holds general elections with women voting for the first time.
1953: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the resignation of Taiwan Governor Wu Kuo-chen and names Yu Hung-chun as his replacement.
1956: Popular jazz musician Nat King Cole is attacked by racists during a live appearance before a segregated audience in Montgomery, Alabama, his home town.
1958: Dr. Hu Shih assumes office as president of the ROC's Academia Sinica.
1960: The US Senate passes the Civil Rights Bill.
1963: USS Thresher, a US atomic submarine, sinks in the northern Atlantic, killing all 290 aboard.
1971: Ethnic Chinese hold a mass rally in Washington, D.C., to show their support for the protection of a disputed territory known to the Chinese as the Tiaoyutai Islands.
1972: Earthquake rocks southern Iran, killing over 5,000 people.
1972: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with the Kingdom of Tonga.
1972: The United States and the Soviet Union sign a treaty banning biological warfare.
1974: A 14-member Greek commercial mission headed by Remis Hajisawas, president of the Commercial Agent and Importers Association, arrives in Taipei for a week-long purchasing tour.
1974: Golda Meir resigns as prime minister of Israel over differences within her Labor Party.
1976: Miguel Urrutia Montoya, director of the national planning department of the Republic of Colombia, arrives in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1979: US President Jimmy Carter signs legislation permitting continued commercial and cultural relations between the US government and the ROC following the break in their diplomatic ties.
1980: Mainland China and the Soviet Union end a friendship pact they signed in 1950.
1983: US President Ronald Reagan's Middle East peace plan collapses when King Hussein of Jordan fails to reach accord with the Palestine Liberation Organization on the terms of the deal.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 192.91 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Monday, with the benchmark-weighted price index moving up 192.91 points to close at 10,127.48.
Market turnover amounted to NT$249.83 billion (US$8.22 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT FORMALLY GIVES GREEN LIGHT TO TANG SERVING AS NEW PREMIER

TEXT.P: Acting Chairman of the Kuomintang Lien Chan has approved National Defense Minister Tang Fei's request to serve as the premier in the next administration.
Tang requested the approval from the KMT Central Committee in a written report on Friday, and Lien formally gave him the green light on Sunday.

Tang, a KMT veteran, was invited by President-elect Chen Shui-bian to help form the Cabinet in the wake of the March 18 presidential election, which saw Chen of the Democratic Progressive Party come to power, ending more than five decades of KMT rule on the island.

Tang said in his report that, considering the tense state of cross-strait relations and the stark national security situation, he decided to assume the post of premier without giving too much thought to possible criticism from others.
But "as there is no precedent" in KMT party history for a KMT member serving in the major post under a different political party, Tang said he asked for the KMT Central Committee's approval.
Lien agreed to Tang serving as the premier, but said that he must do so in his own capacity and suspend all political activity during the period of his premiership.

KMT Spokesman Jason Hu also said the stance of the KMT is clear, which is that in the true spirit of party politics, the DPP's invitation to KMT members to serve in the new government should be conducted through party-to-party consultations. If they are not conducted in this manner, the KMT will not endorse KMT members who join the new cabinet, Hu added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT CONTINUES MEETING POLITICAL, SOCIAL HEAVYWEIGHTS

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian continued to meet with political and social heavyweights on Monday in an apparent bid to seek support for his efforts to put together a broad-based Cabinet.

To broaden the base of support for his government, which is scheduled to take office on May 20, Chen has taken the valuable time before his inauguration to consult with key figures of other parties and independents to exchange views in order to govern effectively.

Garnering only 39.3 percent of the vote, Chen won the March 18 presidential election and became a "minority" president. Meanwhile, his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) is still in a minority in the legislature.
Chen met with Premier Vincent Siew of the Kuomintang government on Monday to exchange views on administrative affairs.

During the one-hour closed-door talk, according to government spokesman Chao Yi, Chen expressed appreciation to Siew for the out-going government's decision to use money from the National Stabilization Fund to stabilize the Taiwan stock market and for convening an emergency national security conference immediately after the presidential election.

For his part, Siew said he hopes that the major policies started by his Cabinet will continue after Premier-designate Tang Fei takes office. These policies include a sweeping reform of the country's police rank and file, and an up-ward adjustment of the military's salary and treatment.
Chen also consulted with Siew over his appointment of Defense Minister Tang Fei as premier. Siew gave a thumbs-up to Tang's performance during his tenure as defense minister.
Also on Monday, Chen met with UFO Radio Chairman Jaw Shao-kang to exchange views "mainly on political ideas," according to the government spokesman.

Chen said he has long admired Jaw for his superb communication skills -- as a legislator, a Cabinet-level official, as well as a media executive -- demonstrating extraordinary abilities and charisma in all of these posts.

Jaw lost to Chen in Taipei's mayoral election six years ago. Two years ago, when Chen determined to seek a re-election, Jaw forecast that Chen would win the presidential election if he lost the mayoral bid. Even though almost nobody took his prediction very seriously back then, it proved to be amazingly accurate.

After his meeting with Jaw, Chen declined to disclose whether he is going to offer Jaw a Cabinet post, but did stress that he will recruit all the high-caliber men and women he can to work in his new government, including talent from the Kuomintang, the New Party, and the newly-formed People First Party.

Chen also told Jaw that he is fully confident that he will open a new era for Taiwan on the thorny issue of cross-strait relations during his tenure as president. He called on decision makers in Beijing to follow suit by demonstrating goodwill and sincerity so as to help break the impasse across the strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 192.91 points to close at 10,127.48.
Due to heavy purchases on semi-conductor shares and other blue chip stocks, the bourse opened at 9,962.65 and fluctuated between 10,168.72 and 9,934.57 during trading.
A total of 3.71 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$249.83 billion (US$8.22 billion).
Gainer outnumbered losers 379 to 161, with 72 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories gained ground, with Cement stocks moving up the most at 3.1 percent, followed by electrical shares at 2.4 percent, contruction stocks at 1.7 percent, textile issues at 1.5 percent, pulp and paper issues at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.3 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 0.7 percent, and foodstuff shares at 0.5 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES SURGE ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Monday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for April surged 218 points to close at 10,262, with 2,374 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May soared 197 points to finish at 10,346, with 329 contract transactions; June futures moved up 140 points to close at 10,355, with 44 contract transactions; and September futures increased 121 points to close at 10,496, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 10,044 for April; 10,149 for May; 10,215 for June; 10,375 for September; and 10,559 for December.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, both reported positive results.

April TE futures moved up 13.25 points to close at 572.2, with 1,015 contract transactions; May TE futures surged 15.9 points to finish at 585.5, with 119 contract transactions; and June TE futures edged up 2.75 points to close at 573, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
April TF futures increased 12 points to finish at 997, with 257 contract transactions while May TF futures moved up 3 points to close at 1,008, with 29 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT APPEALS FOR `PATIENCE' ON REFORMS

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang spokesman on Monday appealed for "patience" from the public and "a little more time" to carry out party reforms.

Jason Hu made the remarks in a radio interview before the KMT held the second meeting of its reform committee, which was formed after the party's humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election.

Vice President Lien Chan, the candidate of the KMT, which boasts 2 million members, finished third in the election, managing only 23.1 percent of the vote, far behind Democratic Progressive Party Chen Shui-bian's 39.3 percent, and independent candidate James Soong's 36.8 percent.

Hu said that the public may not yet see signs of the party's reforms, but he asked for "a little more time," saying that members of the party will travel around the island to gather grassroots opinions and then spend one or two weeks compiling this information before having the report ready in about six months time.
Hu said the work needs to be done cautiously as it may involve reforms in the party's organization.

Hu stressed that Lien Chan, the KMT's acting chairman, has told him that if there are diverse views on how to reform the party, the public will have to have patience as the reforms will take time since they are not going to be based on the views of one person.

As for the defection of KMT members and disciplinary actions taken against them, Hu said the KMT must deal with them resolutely according to the party's regulations. If the party fails to do so, he asked how can it expect voters to support KMT-nominated candidates in the next election.
The KMT has launched a series of disciplinary actions against several of its members for openly supporting candidates other than the KMT's Lien Chan in the March 18 presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF READY TO READJUST ITS POSITION, FUNCTIONS

TEXT.P: The quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), consigned by the ROC government to conduct actual exchanges with mainland China, is scheduled to meet Wednesday to review its previous work and its role in the future.

C.V. Chen, the first SEF secretary-general and incumbent board director, initiated the SEF meeting of board directors and supervisors, saying that it is time for the SEF to discuss its future position and functions now that a new government is taking shape. He also pointed out that, according to the ROC National Reunification Guidelines, Taiwan is entering the middle-stage era, or the era of starting an official dialogue with the mainland.

SEF Vice Chairman Shi Hwei-yow said the SEF is ready for a major personnel reshuffle as a new government gets ready to take office following opposition Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian's election as the new ROC president on March 18.

Shi said the SEF will remain open on its future as well as on its personnel arrangement. The foundation will continue its commitment to doing things for the government and will continue to strengthen its functions as a private-run body as well, Shi stressed.

The SEF was founded in 1991 on the commission of the ROC government to handle cross-strait exchanges in the absence of formal contacts between the two sides. Fifty-three donors jointly raised NT$670 million (US$21.6 million) to finance SEF activities.

As about half of its board directors and supervisors are government officials, and its ranking executives, including the chairman, secretary-general and deputy secretary-general, were appointed by the government, a major personnel reshuffle is seen as imminent and inevitable with the inauguration of President-elect Chen on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD GOURMET SUMMIT TO BE HELD IN SINGAPORE

TEXT.P: Twelve of the world's greatest chefs will be in Singapore this month to showcase some of the best cuisine the millennium has to offer at the fourth annual World Gourmet Summit.
Master chefs from Europe, North America, Oceania and Asia will craft their signature dishes between April 9 and 15 under the theme "The Best of the New Millennium."

Jointly organized by the Singapore Tourism Board (STB) and Peter Knipp Holdings Pte. Ltd., this year's World Gourmet Summit will feature great food, fine wine and some of Singapore's best restaurants.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT CHEN MEETS US SENATOR ROCKEFELLER

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Monday met with US Senator John Rockefeller (D-WV) at Chen's campaign headquarters for a discussion on a wide range of issues.

Rockefeller, who maintains close connections with both Taiwan and mainland China, said both sides of the strait should exercise restraint to avoid conflict at a time when mainland China faces various internal difficulties and Taiwan is seeing a change of government.

Currently chairman of the US-ROC Business Council, Rockefeller told Chen that he is more than willing to play a greater role in efforts to bolster US-Taiwan relations, whether they be military or political.
Rockefeller said he has noticed that President-elect Chen has been "intelligently careful" in making decisions about the line-up of his new government.
He added that he is particularly impressed with Chen's strong efforts in trying to reduce cross-strait tension and in fostering even closer ties with the United States.

When asked by Taipei reporters whether he approves of a second visit to the United States by President Lee Teng-hui, Rockefeller said he does not see such a visit as a plus to relations among the US, Taiwan and mainland China, at least for the moment. He said any move that may cause misunderstandings or unnecessary provocations is the last thing that is needed at this time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA LAUNCHES CAMPAIGN TO TIGHTEN GRIP ON FREE SPEECH

TEXT.P: Mainland China is launching an anti-Western campaign in order to tighten its control over free speech by purging outspoken reform-minded intellectuals at high-level institutions and in the media, according to a report by the Australian on Monday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily reported several academics have lost their jobs, and the editor and founder of two popular publications in Beijing -- Jingping Consumer Guide and the national weekly China Business -- has been ordered sacked.
Another daily in Nanking -- Jiangnan Times -- was ordered closed down after it reported on the murders of a Daimler Chrysler representative and his wife and two children, the daily reported.

The purge follows warnings by president Jiang Zemin against "bourgeois liberalism," a Communist Party catch-all phrase, and an editorial in a party newspaper proclaiming that "Marxism is the leading ideology at higher institutions."

The daily quoted a sacked Beijing Academy of Social Sciences academic as saying that "political persecution is mainly happening at state-run work units and institutions and is aimed at taking away the economic livelihood of people advocating liberalism."

The daily reported the crackdown also follows a February riot by 20,000 miners in a town 400 km northeast of Beijing in which police and soldiers fought pitched battles with workers protesting over reforms at their state-owned mine.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG COMPUTER BUSINESS EYEING MAINLAND MARKET

TEXT.P: Eyeing the huge and potentially lucrative market of mainland China, computer and peripherals suppliers in Kaohsiung are organizing a trade promotion tour to Fujian Province's Xiamen City.

The trade mission, scheduled to depart for Xiamen Thursday, is planning to secure a base in Xiamen's Electronics City to promote sales of Taiwan-made computers and peripheral products, said Chen Chin-ho, chairman of the Kaohsiung Computer Association.

According to the Association's survey, sales of computers and related products in Xiamen City alone totaled 5.6 billion renminbi (US$700 million) in 1996, and soared to reach 10 billion renminbi (US$1.25 billion) in 1999.
It is hoped that the Xiamen base will serve as an eventual gateway for Kaohsiung computer and electronics businesses to expand their sales to all parts of the mainland, Chen said.
The Kaohsiung Computer Association currently has more than 1,000 companies as its members.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP SHOULD NOT BECOME SINGLE MAJOR PARTY: FORMER DPP LEGISLATOR

TEXT.P: Former Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Legislator Hsu Kuo-tai said on Monday that the DPP, which will be the ruling party after May 20, should not be allowed to become the single major party in Taiwan.

Hsu made the remarks when he paid a visit to the legislative caucus of the newly founded People First Party (PFP). He filed an application for the membership of the PFP in order to maintain consistency in his role as a member of the opposition, Hsu announced. He added that he would also urge his brother Hsu Hsin-liang, to interact benignly with PFP Chairman James Soong.
Hsu Hsin-liang is a founding member of the DPP and served two terms as its chairman before he broke ranks to run as an independent in the March 18 presidential election.

Hsu Kuo-tai pointed out that Hsu Hsin-liang would not retire from the island's political arena after his defeat in the presidential election. Moreover, the former DPP chairman shares some ideology with Soong, Hsu Kuo-tai added.

Hsu Kuo-tai was received by Chiu Chuang-huan, convener of the PFP legislative caucus. Chiu noted that positive interaction between Hsu and Soong is very likely, adding that the general public has called for the PFP to recruit Hsu Kuo-tai, so that he can run as a PFP member for a deputy-at-large seat in the National Assembly.

Joining the PFP three days ago, Hsu Kuo-tai said that the future political direction of the Hsu family is still up in the air. He was referring to his brother Hsu Hsin-liang and Hsu Hsin-liang's wife Hsu Chung Bi-hsia, who is also a DPP legislator.
As for himself, said Hsu Kuo-tai, he will do his best to assist the PFP in its campaign for the upcoming National Assembly election scheduled in early May.

The "people first" ideology of the PFP is the main reason for his joining the party, Hsu Kuo-tai said, adding that the PFP must be strong enough to balance the power of the DPP, so that the incoming ruling party doesn't follow the example of the outgoing Kuomintang and become the single major party on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE SENATOR SAYS DATE OF LEE'S VISIT TO JAPAN UNDECIDED
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 10 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A Japanese senator said on Monday that he believes the appropriate time to invite Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui to visit Japan will be at the year's end, but the exact date has yet to be decided.

Masakuni Murakami, vice president of the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council, made the remarks after a meeting between his council and a ROC legislative delegation led by Jao Eng-chi, vice president of the ROC's Legislative Yuan.

Murakami noted that Japan is scheduled to host this year's G-8 summit of industrialized nations in July, and the elections for Parliament's lower house must be held by October. At the same time, President Lee is also preoccupied with things at home, so that it will be convenient for both sides to arrange for the visit late this year.

The senator announced on March 7 that he will launch an organization committee to welcome Lee to visit Japan after his retirement from the presidency on May 20. Tokyo Governor Shintaro Ishihara, said at the time that he will join hands with Murakami to support Lee's visit to Japan.
Meanwhile, a major daily in Taipei said that President Lee will visit Japan in mid-November as a private citizen.

The United Daily News reported that Lee will attend the Asia Outlook Forum in Nagano, a seminar that has taken place over the past nine years, alternating between Taiwan and Japan. Lee is scheduled to speak as a distinguished alumnus at his alma mater, Kyoto Imperial University.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENT AN FUXING DIES OF ILLNESS

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese dissident, who was imprisoned for five years for participating in the 1989 Tiananmen pro-democracy movement, died Monday from a liver disease, a human rights group said.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said An Fuxing, of Changchun city in northeastern Jilin province, contracted the liver disease hepatitis B while in prison.
The information center quoted his family as saying that he became very sick on March 30, when complications from the liver disease caused unbearable pain. He died at 49.

The center said that An contracted the liver disease in 1991 and that his liver had been badly damaged by the disease before he was released from prison in 1995. In his later years, he was jobless and could not afford medical treatment.
This is a typical sad case experienced by many other Chinese political dissidents, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose for the third consecutive day against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, increasing NT$0.058 to close at 30.302.
The local currency opened Monday at 30.295 and was traded between 30.287 and 30.320.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$633 million.
Monday's closing level was the highest in nearly 30 months.

Dealers attributed the NT dollar's bullishness mainly to the continued inflow of foreign capital into the Taiwan stock market as the local bourse continues to rise, as well as booming exports since the beginning of the year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO OIL PRICE HIKES BEFORE MAY 20: ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: There will be no further oil product price hikes before May 20, Economic Affairs Minister Wang Chih-kang said on Monday.

Wang made the promise during a meeting with a group of lawmakers from the Kuomintang (KMT) and the soon-to-be ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), who suggested that the minister avoid adjusting oil prices before May 20, when the DPP's President-elect Chen Shui-bian takes over the helm of the central government from the KMT.

Wang said that although price increases of oil products should be made in compliance with relevant regulations, he accepted the proposal after considering possible consumer price hikes resulting from the move.

Statistics released by the Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) showed that the state-run company fell short of its revenue target by NT$5.77 billion by the end of March, and another round of price hikes are expected if it is to meet its annual target of NT$17.7 billion.
The CPC raised prices of its oil products in the domestic market by 2.99 percent on March 29. There has been speculation that the CPC may announce another round of price adjustments in May.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG-TERM MAINLAND OPERATIONS NOT AFFECTED BY ELECTION: TAIWAN BIZMAN
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 10 (CNA) (By S. C. Peng and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Long-term activities of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China should not be affected despite current pressure from Beijing in the wake of the election of Chen Shui-bian as Taiwan's next president, a Taiwan businessman with operations here said on Monday.

As Beijing is seeking to attract even more Taiwan companies to invest in the mainland, the Taiwan businessman, who asked not to be named, told CNA that Chinese communists will not scare away all investors from Taiwan. Taiwan investment in the mainland already totaled US$40 billion.

At present, Beijing is principally asking large Taiwan companies to clarify their political preference. This is seen as an attempt to force Chen to give a clear endorsement to the "one China" framework in his inaugural speech slated for May 20, according to the same source, who maintains close relations with relevant mainland Chinese officials.

On the question of whether long-term operations by pro-independence Taiwan businesses in the mainland will be affected, he admitted that Beijing will continue to pressure such firms over the short term. However, he added that there should be no such problem over the long run, since no Taiwan company has ever been purged by mainland authorities in the past because of its political position.

In the wake of the reported closure of a preparatory office belonging to the Taiwan-based Evergreen Group in Shanghai on Sunday, officials with the Taiwan Affairs Office under the State Council told CNA that Evergreen shut down the office on its own volition.

As to the question of whether a planned trip to Beijing slated for April 26 by Stan Shih, chairman of Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group, has hit a snag, the officials said they need to further check the issue.
Acer and Evergreen executives stationed in Beijing could not be reached for confirmation of the news.

Li Bingcai, deputy director of the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office, recently issued a stern statement to those Taiwan businesses of promoting the independence movement on the island while cashing in on in the mainland. His remarks were publicized by the official Xinhua news agency.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH STOCK EXCHANGE TAX REVENUE SETS SINGLE MONTH RECORD HIGH

TEXT.P: Stock exchange tax revenue totaled NT$14.5 billion during the month of March, setting a single month record for the past three years, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Finance on Monday.
The MOF said that total national tax revenue reached NT$156.4 billion (US$5 billion) in March, representing an increase of NT$5.8 billion or 3.8 percent over the same period during the previous year.
The stock exchange tax topped the list with an 89.4 percent growth rate, followed by business income tax with an 11.2 percent increase.
However, revenues from business tax, income tax and unitary income tax showed negative growth of 6.9 percent, 1.6 percent and 10.7 percent, respectively.

Apparently affected by the March 18 presidential election, the Taiwan Stock Exchange fluctuated wildly in March. The weighted index plummeted 617 points in a single day on March 13. Transaction volume on the first trading day after the election totaled a paltry NT$79.6 billion, only to soar to reach a record high of NT$292.1 billion on March 28.
The MOF forecasts that revenue from stock exchange tax will break the NT$122 billion mark by the end of this year.
As of the end of March, total national revenues from tax had accumulated to NT$938.1 billion (US$30 billion), a decrease of NT$7.4 billion or 0.8 percent as compared with the previous year.
Business tax decreased by NT$24.4 billion or 11.4 percent, land tax income decreased by NT17.9 billion or 14.1 percent, and revenues from tariffs and duties fell NT41.5 billion or 1.9 percent.

However, revenues from stock exchange taxes increased by NT$36.8 billion or 66.5 percent in comparison with the previous year. The MOF said that 46.7 percent of its projected annual tax revenues have already been raised.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIEX TO INK INFORMATION EXCHANGE MEMORANDUM WITH TSE

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) is planning to sign a memorandum of information exchange with the Tokyo Stock Exchange (TSE), a TAIEX official announced on Monday.
The official said that the TAIEX plan has already been approved by the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) under the Ministry of Finance.

Chu Chao-chuan, vice chairman of the SFC, said the TAIEX has already signed information exchange memoranda with more than 10 major stock exchanges around the world, including the New York Stock Exchange.
Under the terms of the agreement, each party must provide its counterpart with information on a mutually reciprocal basis so as to prevent multinational stock speculation transactions.
The SFC also approved applications from two foreign investment cases to operate in the local stock exchange.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT DECORATES FORMER AIT DIRECTOR

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on David Dean, former Taipei director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) on Monday.

The ceremony was held at the Presidential Office, and was witnessed by Presidential Secretary-General Ding Mou-shih, Presidential Deputy Secretary-General Lin Pi-chao, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, and AIT Taipei Director Raymond Burghardt.
In an acceptance speech, Dean thanked the outgoing president for what he described as a great honor.

Dean noted that he first began working in Taipei in 1947 and witnessed Taiwan's tremendous changes and progress over the past 54 years. He said he will continue to maintain his connections with Taiwan and will continue to devote himself to promoting various cooperations and exchanges between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: ITRI FORESEES DECT-PRODUCING VALUE TO BREAK NT$ 3 BILLION MARK

TEXT.P: The production value of digitally enhanced cordless telecommunications (DECT) is forecast to break the NT$3 billion mark this year, an official of the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) said on Monday.

Lu Chung-hsin, deputy director of ITRI's Telecommunications Department, said that research and development for DECT technology in Taiwan is well developed and has already been approved by the European Experiment Institute.

Lu said that his department began to develop the European-type DECT system technology eight years ago. The department successfully developed a prototype mono- and multi-communication system in 1996, and Lu added that ITRI is currently cooperating with local phone makers.

He went on to say that ITRI's Electronic Checkup Center has established its own testing technology and conditions, and he predicted that Taiwan will become one of the leading DECT-producing nations within three years.

DOC.HEADLINE: FREE INTERNET-ACCESSIBLE PHONES PREDICTED BY YEAREND IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The number of Internet-accessible mobile phone users are expected to reach 3 million in Taiwan by the end of this year and will unleash a price war which might see phones offered free to subscribers, a cell phone operator said on Monday.
The number of mobile phone users hit 10 million last year in Taiwan, and is expected to reach 14 million this year, which will make the island the second-largest mobile phone market in Asia.

In light of the development pattern overseas, the Internet-accessible, or Wireless Application Protocol (WAP) mobile phone introduced to the island early this year will reach numbers similar to web surfers who use Internet Service Providers -- 3 million in Taiwan -- within the first year of its debut on a market, said Chen Fung-shen, president of a local mobile phone operator.

Predicting that four or five brands of WAP phones will hit the market in Taiwan by May, Cheng said a fierce price war similar to that for cellular phones last year, is looming, whereby companies will offered free handsets to potential users on condition that they subscribe to their systems for a fixed period of time.

Citing an overseas survey, Cheng said Internet users through WAP phones will account for 41 percent of the total by 2005, compared with 46 percent through fixed-line telephones, and 4 percent through cable TV lines.
He predicted that the manufacture of WAP phones will emerge as a leading information technology industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT CONSIDERING EUROPEAN TRIP AFTER STEPPING DOWN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui is mulling a tour of several European countries after his term expires on May 20, senior government sources revealed on Monday.
The tour, tentatively slated to take place between June and July, will include the Czech Republic, Hungary, and Austria, according to the anonymous sources.
No European states recognize the Republic of China diplomatically, with the exception of the Vatican and Macedonia, but neither state will be included in Lee's trip, said the sources.

However, Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) spokesman Chen Ming-cheng denied that his ministry has any knowledge about such a trip, and pointed out that it has not been asked to make any arrangements in this regard.
He further noted that owing to Lee's "special status," it would take time to prepare such a tour for him, even after his departure from public office.

Lee's trips to nations without diplomatic ties with Taiwan have stirred up controversy in the past because mainland China, which deems Taiwan a part of its territory, is paranoid about Lee's presence in any country which recognizes Beijing.
Most notable in this regard was Lee's private visit to the United States in 1995 which led to such a furious protest from Beijing that even ties between Washington and Beijing were strained.
Lee's most recent official trip overseas was to Panama for the World Congress on the Panama Canal, and to three other Central American allies in September 1997.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT NATIONAL CONGRESS SCHEDULED FOR JUNE 24-25

TEXT.P: The outgoing Kuomintang has decided to hold an extraordinary national congress from June 24-45 in Taipei to elect a new chairman, party Spokesman Jason Hu said on Monday.

The KMT, which suffered a humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election and lost its 54-year control of Taiwan, made the decision at a meeting of the party's Central Committee earlier in the day.
The congress will also focus its discussions on revising the KMT charter and on setting up a series of reform programs.
KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui stepped down from his post late last month to take responsibility for the party's election defeat, and Vice Chairman Lien Chan was named acting chairman.
Lien has pledged to reform the party in order to win back the party's ruling status in the next presidential election four years hence.

Addressing calls by some party members for a popular election of the party chief by all KMT members rather than just by the congress delegates as has traditionally been the case, Hu said that no decision has been made in this regard.

However, Hu went on to say that the new election may still need to be elected by delegates in accordance with existing protocol because a change in the electoral process would necessitate a charter revision, a move which he described as inappropriate at present.

To show its determination to undertake reforms, the meeting also decided to hold the congress at the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall instead of the International Convention Center because the center gives the impression of being too "luxurious," other party sources said.
The party has previously held its congresses at the center, which is considered Taipei's highest-class convention site.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 11, or the seventh day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1512: French troops defeat Spanish and Papal forces at Ravenna in one of the bloodiest battles of the 16th century.
1689: William III, Prince of Orange and champion of Protestantism, and his wife, Mary II, Protestant daughter of the deposed Stuart king James II, are crowned joint monarchs of Great Britain.
1713: France cedes Newfoundland and Gibraltar to Britain.
1775: James Parkinson, the British physician who defined Parkinson's disease, a progressive disease of the nervous system also called paralysis agitans or shaking palsy, is born.
1814: Louis XVIII accedes to the throne as Napoleon Bonaparte abdicates and is banished to the island of Elba under the Treaty of Fontainebleau.
1893: Dean Acheson, the US politician and secretary of state who helped to formulate the Truman Doctrine and the Marshall Plan, and who promoted the setting up of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), is born.
1899: Spain transfers the Philippines to the control of the United States.
1913: French aviator Gustave Hamel sets a record by flying the English Channel from Dunkirk to Dover and back in 90 minutes.
1919: The International Labor Organization (ILO) is founded in Geneva in affiliation with the League of Nations to improve living standards and working conditions.
1926: American horticulturist Luther Burbank dies at the age of 77. He developed countless new varieties of fruits, vegetables, and flowers, including the Burbank potato and the Shasta daisy.
1929: The cartoon character Popeye appears for the first time, in a William Hearst newspaper.
1935: Dust storms wreak havoc in the so-called "Dust Bowl" states of Kansas, Colorado, Wyoming, Oklahoma, Texas, and New Mexico in the United States.
1945: US forces capture the German towns of Essen and Weimar and liberate the Buchenwald concentration camp near the end of World War II.
1950: The Bank of Taiwan issues its first lottery.
1950: China lodges a complaint with the United Nations against Soviet aid to the Chinese communists, the Soviet invasion of China and Soviet violation of the UN Charter.
1951: Scotland's Stone of Scone in England's Westminster Abbey is recovered following a 107-day hunt after it was taken by Scottish Nationalists who wanted it returned to Scotland, its rightful home.
1951: US President Harry Truman relieves Gen. Douglas MacArthur, the World War II hero who accepted the Japanese surrender in Tokyo Bay in 1945, of all his commands, including that of UN forces in Korea.
1957: Singapore is granted self-government by the United Kingdom.
1961: Nazi war criminal Adolf Eichmann enters a Jerusalem court to hear 15 charges against him, 12 of which carry the death penalty.
1969: Taiwan's Executive Yuan approves the "Guidelines for the Population Policy of the Republic of China."
1970: The government of Prime Minister Lon Nol announces abolishment of the monarchy and proclaims Cambodia a republic.
1974: US Secretary of Agriculture Earl L. Butz, leading a party of 19, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: Golda Meir resigns as Israeli prime minister.
1974: The ROC Executive Yuan approves the Sino-Honduran Fishery Technical Cooperation Agreement.
1976: An ROC education mission headed by Education Minister Y.S. Tsiang leaves for the Middle East on a visit.
1976: Col. Carlos Humberto Romero, secretary of defense and pacific security of El Salvador, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1978: The Taiwan Province Black Foot Disease Control Center is inaugurated in Peimen Village, Tainan County.
1979: A combined force of Ugandan exiles and Tanzanian troops capture the Ugandan capital of Kampala, ending the eight-year rule of Idi Amin.
1981: Chen Ta, a noted singer of Taiwanese folk songs, dies at the age of 76.
1984: Konstantin Chernenko is appointed president of the Soviet Union.
1989: English soccer clubs are readmitted to the European Cup after a ban imposed because of the behavior of English soccer hooligans.
1990: British customs officials seize at Teesport, Middlesbrough, an Iraq-bound shipment of heavy "oil pipes" that look suspiciously like sections of a large gun.
1994: US President Bill Clinton orders trade sanctions against Taiwan in accordance with the Pelly Act.
1995: Chen Yun, one of communist China's leading veteran hardliners and one of its leading economic planners, dies in Beijing at the age of 90.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Tuesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for April moved down 81 points to close at 10,181, with 1,692 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May decreased 86 points to finish at 10,260, with 246 contract transactions; June futures lost 74 points to close at 10,281, with 14 contract transactions; and September futures plunged 96 points to finish at 10,400, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for December futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were: 10,262 for April; 10,346 for May; 10,355 for June; 10,496 for September; and 10,777 for December.
Electronic (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, reported mixed results.

No transactions were reported for other months.

April TF futures increased 14 points to close at 1,011, with 277 contract transactions, while May TF futures moved up 23 points to close at 1,031, with 19 contract transactions. June TF futures moved down 5 points to finish at 1,017, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG'S `SLIGHT ILLNESS' WON'T AFFECT HIS TAKING PREMIERSHIP

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday that he is confident of Premier-designate Tang Fei's speedy recovery from his "slight malaise."
Chen said that Tang had reported the results of his physical examination to him, and he had "full confidence in his full recovery."
Chen also said Tang's "slight malaise" will not affect his ability to assume the post of premiership or the lineup of the new Cabinet.
Tri Service General Hospital reported on Tuesday that Tang was found to have a tumor in his chest. Doctors have advised that he undergo surgery to remove the benign thymoma.
The 68-year-old Defense Minister has undergone regular physical checkups every year since 1989 and has always received a clean bill of health, except for a slightly higher level of fat in his blood.

Tang began to feel an abnormal lowering of his upper eyelid in late March. A hospital checkup found that he was suffering from ptosis, an abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid caused by muscle weakness, said doctors.
Further tests found a tumor, measuring 3.2 x 2.6 x 1.8 cm in Tang's chest, doctors said.
They added that after surgery, Tang is expected to be released from hospital in mid-April and will be able to resume his normal duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 59.43 points to close at 10,068.05.
Affected by a 258 point plunge in the NASDAQ index and heavy profit-taking selling, the bourse opened at 10,104.87 and fluctuated between 10,194.91 and 10,059.41 during trading.

A total of 4.21 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$254.77 billion (US$8.41 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session that saw 3.71 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$249.83 billion.
Losers outnumber gainers 292 to 255, with 69 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories gained ground, with bank and insurance stocks moving up the most at 1.8 percent, followed by electrical shares at 1.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 0.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.8 percent, cement shares at 0.5 percent, textile issues at 0.4 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.3 percent, and construction shares at 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CKS SECOND TERMINAL TO BE OPENED IN MAY: CAA

TEXT.P: The second terminal of Chiang Kai-shek (CKS) International Airport near Taipei may be opened in mid-May, Director General Y. H. Chang of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA) said on Tuesday.
However, Chang said the CAA will hold a task force meeting on Thursday to set a specific date for the opening.

Chang, leading a 40-member delegation composed of CAA officials and experts, made the remarks after conducting a sixth inspection of the new terminal. Relevant service facilities and equipment at the complex have been noticeably improved, according to the experts.

Air New Zealand, Air Canada, EVA Airways Corporation, Uni Airlines and Japan Asia Airways are all scheduled to use the second terminal for aircraft landing and take-off following its opening. Some aviation companies expect that the opening will actually take place in late May.
