DOC.HEADLINE: US-PRC STRAINS COULD LEAD TO CHANGES IN PRC NUCLEAR POLICY: STUDY

TEXT.P: Whether Communist China holds to a low alert-minimum deterrence posture remains to be seen as strains in US-PRC relations and Beijing's militant stand toward Taiwan could lead to changes in its `no-first-use' nuclear weapons policy, according to a new US study.

William Burr, an editor at Washington's National Security Archive, wrote in his study on the Chinese nuclear weapons program that the US missile defense program could also have a destabilizing effect.

Even though US missile defense programs are supposedly aimed at countering threats from rogue states such as Iraq and North Korea, if the systems are ever actually deployed, they could encourage major Communist Chinese investments in both intercontinental and sea-launched ballistic missile deployments and spark a new arms race.

Informed public debate about US-PRC relations and Beijing's nuclear posture would be advanced if the US intelligence establishment released older studies on Beijing's nuclear policies, said Burr, adding that unfortunately that may not happen soon.

He pointed out that congressional panic over espionage in the wake of spying allegations against Taiwan-born scientist Wen Ho Lee and the Communist Chinese nuclear program has led to a more hostile climate for declassification and also legislation forcing executive branch re-review of millions of pages of documents that had been slated for archival release.

Besides delaying the release of older documents, the backlash in Congress has undoubtedly bolstered anti-declassification recidivism in the intelligence agencies, noted Burr. For example, the Central Intelligence Agency has so far refused to declassify National Intelligence Estimates on Communist Chinese nuclear forces from as far back as the mid-1960s.

Fortunately, Burr said, before Congress checked White House declassification programs, some intelligence reporting and analysis on the earlier phases of the Communist Chinese nuclear program became available through the Freedom of Information Act at the National Archives.

A selection of US Air Force, State Department, Defense Intelligence Agency and CIA documents suggest considerable competence in tracking Communist Chinese nuclear and missile tests, as well as missile training activities. But what also comes across is "a very limited, as well as rather inaccurate, knowledge of Chinese missile deployments during the late 1960s," added Burr.

For example, even though Beijing had begun to deploy the Dong Feng-2 medium range ballistic missiles in the fall of 1966, US intelligence failed to detect the deployment until later in the decade, said the study.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S INAUGURATION SPEECH WILL PUT PUBLIC AT EASE: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) heavyweight said on Tuesday that he doubted that President-elect Chen Shui-bian, who is a DPP member, will offer any surprises on cross-strait policy in his inauguration speech.

But DPP Secretary-General You Hsi-kun said Chen in his inaugural address will "make some statement" that will put the public at ease, and that Chen is currently working with experts and scholars on the speech.

You, in an interview with a local radio station, said the policy of the DPP has been public knowledge over the years, and he doubted that Chen will announce any major policy changes in his inauguration speech on May 20.

Since Chen won the election in the March 18 presidential election, he has shown caution in addressing cross-strait relations and has sounded conciliatory notes to Beijing, which has a deep-rooted mistrust of the pro-independence DPP.
You noted that the Taiwan public has high hopes for Chen's inauguration speech, as it is an opportunity to assuage Beijing's misgivings about the DPP and help smooth cross-strait relations.
On local reports that mainland China is trying to boycott Taiwan investors in the mainland who are in support of Chen, You said that he will gather more information on this issue.
He said that cross-strait relations are more at ease now than before the March 18 presidential election, which saw Chen win the fierce election, ending more than five decades of Kuomintang rule.
You said that the DPP is making efforts to express its utmost good will, hoping that there will be positive exchanges between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

You also commented on reports that Professor Chiu Hungdah of the University of Maryland has decided to resign as a member of the National Unification Council (NUC) and as an ambassador-at-large because he does not think Chen identifies with the three-stage process to national unification. You said he hopes Chiu will communicate with the DPP and think twice before making the decision.

Though mainland China has insisted on "one China" principle as the precondition for restarting cross-strait talks, Chen has said that as long as it is considered as one issue and not the guiding principle, he is willing to talk about anything.
Cross-strait talks were interrupted after Beijing reacted angrily to President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait ties as "special state-to-state relations" in July 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT TIES TOP ISSUE FOR NEW GOVERNMENT: VICE DEFENSE HEAD

TEXT.P: Relations with mainland China are the top priority Taiwan's new government must handle following the election of Chen Shui-bian as the island's new president, Vice National Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen said on Tuesday.

Speaking at a monthly meeting of the Ministry of National Defense, Wu said that the danger of war has always existed in the Taiwan Strait, and that the Republic of China's military will neither "provoke war" nor "be afraid of war" during the current situation between Taiwan and mainland China.

Although things have remained quiet in the Taiwan Strait since the end of Taiwan's March 18 presidential election, the vice national defense minister stressed that cross-strait ties are the greatest challenge facing the new government.

Quoting reports by Hong Kong newspapers, Wu said the Chinese Communist Party's Central Military Commission has in recent months established new high-tech military facilities and deployed advanced weapons in its Nanjing and Guangdong military zones. This only indicates that the danger of war always exists between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he noted.

Recently, a litany of invective from mainland China against Taiwan has refocused international attention on the Taiwan Strait as one of the world's hot flash points, the vice national defense chief pointed out, adding that Beijing's continued verbal attacks and military intimidation still cast a shadow of uncertainty over the future of bilateral relations.

In compliance with the ROC's constitution, the ROC military must obey the nation's head of state and protect its 23 million people should the island be attacked, Wu said, but also expressed his hope that Taiwan and the mainland can cooperate on a basis of reciprocity and mutual trust to create a "win-win" situation for both sides.
Taiwan's recent presidential election, he claimed, is a reflection of the island's full-fledged democracy and a proof of the implementation of the "popular sovereignty" concept.
Wu, who has been designated the new national defense minister by Chen, said he will continue to follow the current national defense policy after taking over the post from present minister Tang Fei.
In the face of fierce pressure from Beijing, Wu said safeguarding national security and maintaining social order will be his top policy priority.
In order to lay a solid foundation for Taiwan's security, the minister-designate said the military will focus its reform on organizational restructuring and promotion of military education.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE NAMES PART OF HIS CABINET

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Tang Fei on Tuesday named part of his Cabinet after holding a series of meetings with President-elect Chen Shui-bian, according to sources from Tang's office.
Tang announced that You Hsi-kun, secretary-general of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), has been named vice premier, replacing Liu Chao-shiuan of the outgoing Kuomintang (KMT) administration.

Wei Chi-lin, incumbent chairman of the Cabinet-level Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, has been named secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, succeeding the KMT's Hsieh Shen-shan, Tang noted.

Meanwhile, incumbent Vice Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen will be promoted to defense minister to fill the vacancy that will be left by Tang, who is the current defense minister under the KMT administration.
Tang has been appointed premier of the new government by Chen, who is apparently making every effort to put together a broad-based Cabinet.
The entire line-up of the new Cabinet will be announced in the days leading up to Chen's inauguration on May 20, the sources said.

Speculation has it that three women heavyweights from the DPP will be recruited to accept ministerial-level posts in the new administration, as Chen strives for balanced politics of equal participation by talented people from both genders, all political parties and all ethnic groups possible.

The women hopefuls included Chen Chu, director of the Bureau of Social Affairs under the Kaohsiung City Government, who is likely to be appointed head of the Cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs; Yeh Chu-lan, legislator, who may be named head of the soon-to-be-established Hakkah Affairs Commission; and Chang Fu-mei, legislator, who may be named head of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN ASSOC. ASKS ARGENTINE COAST GUARD TO RELEASE SHIP AND CREWMEN
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, Southern Taiwan, April 11 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Area Oceanic Squid Fishing Exports Association has asked the Argentine Coast Guard to inmediately release the Kaohsiung-based fishing vessel King Chuan Hsiang and 28 crewmen captured by an Argentine cutter on April 9.

A spokesman for the association said that the vessel was detained by Argentine coast guard cutter at midnight of April 9 on the high seas, four nautical miles from the 200-nautical mile limit of Argentine economic waters.
He said that the Argentine action violated the international law of the sea, and Argentine coastal force authorities confirmed later that the detained vessel was operating outside Argentine waters.
The spokesman said that the association, in addition to lodging a protest against the Argentine coastal force authorities, has also asked for the inmediate release of the vessel and its 28 crewmen.

According to news reports from Argentina, the 922-ton fishing vessel with a 28-member crew on board was escorted by an Argentine cutter to Port Deseado, where further investigations were to be made. The reports said that at present, both ship and crewmen were safe.

The vessel was detained by the Argentine cutter when it was operating on the high seas at 47 degrees 14 minutes 18 seconds south latitude and 60 degrees 46 minutes 02 seconds west longitude, or four nautic miles outside of the Argentine economic waters.

The Argentine cutter reportedly fired its guns to warn the vessel to stop for inspection. The captain of the fishing vessel refused, as he regarded that his ship was not within Argentine economic waters. Argentine coast guard officers then forcefully boarded the vessel at 1:00 a.m. to check its navigation diary and related documents, the reports said.

According to the ship's owner, Argentine officers conversed with him by satellite telephone and confirmed that the fishing vessel was not located in Argentine economic waters. However, he said that he lost contact with the vessel, only to later receive a notice from the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Buenos Aires informing him that the vessel had been detained and escorted to Port Deseado.

According to the navigation record provided by the shipowner, the fishing boat did not poach in the Argentine economic waters. If this record is correct, the Argentine coastal force has apparently violated the international law of the sea.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CABINET TO INTRODUCE TALENT FROM ALL PARTIES: PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian paid a visit to the Legislative Yuan on Tuesday, and said he will invite talent from all Taiwan's political parties to join his new government.

Chen and Vice President-elect Annette Lu, who have both served as legislators during their political careers, were warmly welcomed by Legislative Yuan President Wang Jin-pyng and the various party whips.

Noting that his five years of parliamentary service has given him the training and inspiration necessary for him to win presidential election Chen said he was returning to the legislature with gratitude and humility, and he invited all legislators to attend his inauguration ceremony on May 20.
With just over a month to go before his inauguration, Chen said he must exert extreme caution in his deeds and words, pointing out that "not only Taiwan people but the whole world are watching him."
"Achieving domestic stability and reviving the confidence of the people of Taiwan" will be his top priority, Chen said.

Saying that his challenges only began after his victory in the March 18 presidential election which ended the Kuomintang's five decades of rule on the island, Chen also explained that the lineup of his new government will also include talent from the New Party and the People First Party.

Explaining his decision to invite National Defense Minister Tang Fei, a veteran KMT member, to serve as premier, Chen said that the 225-seat Legislative Yuan is still dominated by the KMT, and that he offered Tang the premiership for the sake of stability of domestic politics and peace in the Taiwan Strait.

By garnering 39.3 percent of the vote in the election, Chen's administration is expected to be a weak government, but Chen said that after full communication with all sides, he is confident of his ability to form a strong and accountable government.
He said he will also make good of his campaign promise by soliciting three women to join his 10-member Cabinet.

On complaints from Lu that she has been left out in the cold in the selection of the new Cabinet, and her suggestion that a future constitutional amendment should be considered to adjust the duties of the vice president, Chen also promised that Lu will not be a "voiceless deputy."

Chen said that considering the diplomatic plight of the nation, he might be unable to leave Taiwan after his inauguration, even though he hopes to make more overseas visits, but added that Lu will have "a plenty of chances" to visit other countries on his behalf.

Saying that he will invite DPP legislators to serve in various government agencies of the Executive Yuan, the Presidential Office and the Examination Yuan, he said the new Cabinet will be finalized by the end of the month.

New Party whip Elmer Fung, who was also the NP's vice presidential candidate, congratulated Chen on his victory, and expressed the hope that there will be no war, no added taxes, and an eradication of "black gold," -- official corruption and links with gangsters -- in Chen's new administration.

Fung also offered his views on the "one China" principle, saying that "one China" should not mean the People's Republic of China, that relations between mainland China and Taiwan should not be one of a central to local government, and that Taiwan should not be deemed a province of the mainland.

However, Chen pointed out to him that even the United States and mainland China have different views on "one China," and added that domestic consensus must be forged on what exactly is the "one China" issue before it can be fully discussed.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAO TUNG UNIVERSITY PRESIDENT HONORED BY US ACADEMY

TEXT.P: Chang Chun-yen, president of National Chiao Tung University, has been chosen as an overseas member of the National Academy of Engineering of the United States, becoming the first local Ph.D. to receive the honor.
The academy bestowed the honor upon Chang for his contribution to the electronics industry, education, and material technology in Taiwan. The ceremony will be held on July 27 at Stanford University.
Chang said that the honor is significant in that it shows that local Ph.D. holders and scholars can gain recognition from the academic community so long as they make enough effort.

In a celebration tea party at Chiao Tung University, Chang pointed out that overseas members of the academy cannot exceed one-tenth of the members chosen annually. This year, some 78 members from the United States and six members from overseas have been chosen from Germany, Britain, France, the Republic of China, and Japan.

Former Education Minister Wu Jin has also been chosen in the past as a member of the National Academy of Engineering, but he received the honor while he was residing in the United States, and was not counted as an overseas member.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI NOT TO EXPAND MARKET BEFORE CONCLUDING WTO AGRICULTURAL TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan will not expand its market for agricultural products if the island joins the World Trade Organization (WTO) before the body completes its new round of agricultural talks, according to a government official on Tuesday.

Wang Ming-lai, deputy director of the International Cooperation Department of the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan, was referring to the difficulties facing the new round of WTO agricultural negotiations.

Since the new round of WTO agricultural talks has been boycotted by a "Non Trade Concern" headed by the European Union and Japan, it seems unlikely that the talks will conclude anytime soon, said Wang.
An ad hoc agricultural meeting was convened by the WTO for the promotion of the new round of talks. Wang is the representative of Taiwan who took part in the first meeting held in Geneva recently.

Wang disclosed after returning to Taipei that confrontations between interest groups were evident. For instance, he said, the Non Trade Concern, consisting of Japan, South Korea, Norway, and the European Union, has sided against Australia and New Zealand. Meanwhile, a group of "Third World" countries headed by India have also formed a united front to fight for their own interests.

The United States has advocated that the new round of talks should be concluded within a period of three years, with topics strictly limited in order to shorten the process. However, in view of the present situation, said Wang, the new round of talks will probably not be concluded within that period of time.

If Taipei joins the WTO before the new round of talks end, the island's opening of import quotas for agricultural products will be frozen at the level to which Taiwan has already committed for 2000, Wang noted. In other words, said the Taipei delegate, Taiwan would not lower tariffs or increase the volume of imports of agricultural products until the related WTO talks had been completed.

The world trade regulatory body has decided to hold ad hoc agricultural meetings in June, September and November, respectively. The meetings will be aimed at reaching a common understanding and consensus between different interests groups, Wang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NSC CHIEF NOT TO STAY IN POST

TEXT.P: National Security Council (NSC) Secretary-General Yin Tsung-wen will not accept an invitation by President-elect Chen Shui-bian to stay on his post, informed sources said on Tuesday.

Local press reported that Chen and Vice President-elect Annette Lu called on Ying on two occasions to ask him to stay on his post after Chen's inauguration on May 20, despite the fact that he spent four months in hospital last year with lung cancer.
The NSC said in a news release that Yin has never agreed to stay in the new administration and that he hoped Chen will understand his decision.
The statement reiterated that Yin will tender his resignation as planned shortly after President Lee Teng-hui steps down on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO KOREAS SET GOOD EXAMPLE FOR CROSS-STRAIT TALKS

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China should first put aside the "one China" dispute and then sit down to talk through their problems, Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) Chairman Lin I-hsiung said on Tuesday.
Lin's remarks came on the heels of the latest news that the leaders of South and North Korea are to meet for their first-ever summit in June.

Meanwhile, Jonathan Pollack, a senior East Asian affairs expert at the Rand Corp., a US-based think tank, said Taiwan-mainland China ties cannot be compared to those between the two Koreas. The US expert made the remarks during a visit to the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs.

In contrast to the long-term impasse between the people of North and South Korea, Taiwan and mainland China have long enjoyed good substantive ties, and this should provide many good opportunities for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to develop even better links, he said in an analysis.

However, Pollack also pointed out that the future of two-way ties will be decided by Beijing's attitude, given that the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) President-elect Chen Shui-bian has offered many friendly overtures to Beijing on cross-strait issues of major concern to both sides.

At the legislature, meanwhile, Lin's call was echoed by lawmakers from the pro-independence DPP, the People First Party (PFP) and the Kuomintang, all of whom urged Beijing to follow the lead of the two Koreas by showing goodwill and holding talks with Taiwan.

Stressing that the new DPP-led Taiwan government will not declare independence from mainland China as long as the mainland does not attack the island militarily, DPP lawmaker Yeh Yi-Chin said the two sides would be able to start talks as soon as Beijing decided to come to the negotiating table.

Mainland China should understand that it is better for the two sides to talk than not talk, and should demonstrate its goodwill by signing a cease-fire agreement with Taiwan as soon as possible, commented Yu Cheng-tao, another DPP legislator.

PFP lawmaker Chen Chin-ting argued that the fact that the two Koreas have been able to agree to start negotiations after so many years of separation shows there is no reason why Taiwan and mainland China cannot do likewise.
Chen also asked President-elect Chen to shrug off ideological stereotypes in his efforts to push up for cross-strait dialogue.

According to KMT Legislator Ho Chih-hui, cross-strait economic exchanges have helped boost progress in the mainland, and the Chinese communists should provide better treatment for Taiwan businessmen by separating economics from politics as a way of moving toward more peaceful interchange.

At the same time, remarks on the Korean situation made recently by Robert Scalapino, a well-known China hand at the University of California at Berkeley, were seen as a surprising coincidence in light of the subsequent events in the divided Asian country.

Scalapino said in a seminar held at Berkeley that Taiwan and mainland China could consider the "peaceful co-existence" model adopted by Seoul and Pyongyang to develop bilateral ties, a week before the surprise announcement that negotiations will take place between the two Koreas in June.

Although Scalapino admitted that the possibility of putting the proposal into practice is not high in the short-term, he raised two concepts -- "concert of power and balance of power" -- for Taiwan and the mainland to ponder.

According to the US scholar, the United States and Japan should have greater participation in discussions on cross-strait issues, because these two countries share common interests in the region and could serve as a balance mechanism in the process.
He pointed to the example that the United States, mainland China, Japan and Russia have all actively taken part in the negotiations between Seoul and Pyongyang.

But Scalapino also admitted that Beijing will not allow any foreign country to meddle in cross-strait issues and added that Washington will continue to follow its current policy of encouraging Taiwan and mainland China to strengthen contacts rather than directly interfering in Taiwan-mainland disputes.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT DECORATES US SENATOR

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui on Tuesday conferred the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on US Senator John D. Rockefeller (D-W.Va), in recognition of his contributions to ROC-US relations.

Robert Six, an aide of Rockefeller, Secretary-General to the President Ding Mou-shih, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Lin Pi-chao, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee, and Raymond Bughardt, director of the Taipei Office of the American Institute in Taiwan witnessed the award presentation ceremony.
In an address following the ceremony, Rockefeller said he was greatly honored to receive the decoration.

DOC.HEADLINE: `LIFE LINE' FINDS SUICIDE TENDENCIES RISING RAPIDLY AFTER EARTHQUAKE

TEXT.P: A local telephone help line has found that a record high 38 percent of calls handled by the emergency assistance organization over the past six months involved suicidal inclinations, a figure which has rarely been so high in the past.

The Taipei Life Line, an affiliate of the ROC Life Line International, linked the high percentage of suicidal calls to the impact of the catastrophic Sept. 21 earthquake that killed over 2,400 people, injured some 8,000 and left 100,000 others homeless.

Since the quake, 21.4 percent of the calls received by the Taipei Life Line were from callers who had thought about committing suicide "every now and then," 7.1 percent were from callers who thought about committing suicide "often," and 9.5 percent were from callers who had thought about killing themselves "once," said Taipei Life Line Secretary-General Chu Kai-yu.
In contrast, similar calls showing suicidal inclination constituted only 11.6 percent of all calls handled by the Taipei Life Line in 1999, Chu noted.

Chu said that over the past 30 years, romance and marriage problems have always made up the bulk of the Taipei Life Line casebook, with the number of female callers nearly doubling that of male callers.
Meanwhile, Chu added, about 32 percent of the calls over the last six months were made by elderly people, which was also an unusually high percentage compared with ratios of previous years.
Chu called for society to pay more attention to senior citizens' mental health care and to make more effort to prevent the elderly from committing suicide.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S INVESTMENT IN PETROCHEMICAL INDUSTRY TOTALS US$ 26.31 B.

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) said on Tuesday that major investments in the domestic petrochemical industry have now reached a total of more than NT$800 billion (US$26.31 billion).

IDB officials noted that the petrochemical industry is one of the nation's most important infrastructure industries, pointing out that around 80 percent of the raw materials used in information, electronics, engineering, and other local industries are petrochemical products.
They said that the nation has to continue to promote major investment projects in the petrochemical industry so as to upgrade Taiwan's self-sufficiency rate in petrochemical products.

The officials said that except for problems with the eighth naphtha cracker project, with an estimated investment of NT$196.3 billion (US$6.45 billion), and the seventh naphtha cracker plant, with an estimated investment of NT$250 billion (US$8.22 billion), all other petrochemical investment projects are progressing smoothly.

DOC.HEADLINE: SFC TO OPEN TRADING IN SECOND-TIER STOCKS ON APRIL 18

TEXT.P: The Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) under the Ministry of Finance (MOF) will permit the trading of second-tier stocks on the island's over-the-counter (OTC) market from April 18, SFC Chairman Lin Tzong-yeong said on Tuesday.

Requirements for companies to be listed in second-tier stock market are not as strict as for those companies currently listed in the Taiwan Stock Exchange and the OTC market, so as to allow small- and medium-sized enterprises and emerging industries to raise funds on the nation's capital market, he said.
At present, five companies have applied to list their second-tier shares on the OTC market and three of them have already been given the green light by the SFC, said Lin.

He said he expects that more enterprises to apply for second-tier listing after May 1, by which time their financial statements will have been released, and estimated that the number of companies listing second-tier stocks this year will reach to between 50 and 100.

DOC.HEADLINE: NAM ENDORSES CODE FOR SOUTH CHINA SEA DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Foreign ministers of the 113-member Non-Aligned Movement on Tuesday endorsed the Philippine-led regional code of conduct in the South China Sea to promote peace and stability in the region.

In a statement, the Philippine Department of Foreign Affairs (DFA) said Secretary Domingo Siazon Jr. spearheaded the discussions in the historic first gathering of NAM ministers in Cartagena de Indias in Colombia on the political situation in the South China Sea and the wider regional, political and security situation in Southeast Asia.
NAM ministers urged all claimants to exercise restraint with a view to creating a positive climate for the eventual resolution of the conflict.
They supported the Philippine position to resolve all sovereignty and territorial disputes in the South China Sea by peaceful means without resorting to force, the DFA statement said.
NAM is the largest political negotiating bloc in the world and a political forum for developing states for coordinating approaches towards global issues.
It stands for the vision of general and complete disarmament under effective international control.

The Association of Southeast Asian Nations (ASEAN) has already agreed on the code but it has yet to convince mainland China to adopt it, with debate continuing as to the wording and coverage of the code.
Siazon also presented during the NAM meeting the "five building blocks" of the Philippines' "global peace agenda."
Siazon issued a call for more concerted international efforts in preventive diplomacy, true disarmament, United Nations reform, the promotion of human rights and development of global partnerships.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MECO HEAD VOWS TO PROTECT FILIPINOS IN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Protecting the national interest and the welfare of 118,000-Filipino workers in Taiwan will top the concerns of outgoing Press Secretary Rodolfo T. Reyes when he assumes his new post as chairman of the Manila Economic Cultural Office (MECO).
Reyes, who leaves for Taipei on April 25 to assume the MECO post, also said he will assure the public of transparency in his new assignment by ordering a thorough audit of MECO coffers.
Citing briefings he has so far received on his new post, Reyes said there are many complaints from Filipinos in Taiwan who say that they are not getting full assistance from MECO.
He said that aside from the 118,000 documented Filipino workers in Taiwan, about 3,400 more are considered runaways.
"We have to attend to their needs. Some are exploited by brokers in Taiwan or by recruiters in the Philippines. Some are victims of rape and theft. We have to protect our contract workers," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NEW ECONOMY' SYMPTOMS SEEN TO OCCUR IN TAIWAN IN FIVE YEARS

TEXT.P: Taiwan is likely to undergo the same changes in its societal values in the next five years as are taking place in the United States as a result of the swift development of the dotcom world and "new economy," a local entrepreneur said on Tuesday.

Swift development in the dotcom world and "new economy" have brought rapidly growing wealth to some Americans, but the phenomenon has created an unprecedented impact on American society and has completely changed traditional American values, said Morris Chang, chairman and CEO of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co.
A similar impact is expected to affect Taiwan in about five years from now, Chang predicted, as Taiwan inevitably follows in the footsteps of the United States.
Chang made the forecast on Tuesday in a speech at National Chiao Tung University on the impact of "new economy" on society.

According to Chang, the change of traditional American values as a result of the development of "new economy" is demonstrated in the fact that "money rules all" has become the mainstream value in American society and that marriage and family are accorded subordinate values.
He attributed the arrival of "new economy" in the United States mainly to the swift development of the dotcom world and to tech shares becoming cash cows on Wall Street.
The tech-crazy market has in recent years created wealth worth several trillion US dollars in America, Chang noted.
However, he went on, the rapidly growing wealth is shared by no more than 5 percent of the country's citizens, and has resulted in a reshuffle of the major fortune holders in the United States.

The "new economy" has also turned on its head the American mainstream value of considering basic salary as the major source of income, he said, adding that in 1974, only 200,000 of all American employees possessed company shares, a number which had shot up to 10 million by 1999. This development, he continued, has resulted in reduced loyalty to companies.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Premier-designate names part of his Cabinet.
The China Times:
President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Premier-designate Tang Fei jointly made apppointments of new faces into the Cabinet, including Tien Hung-mao, academic, to be foreign affairs minister; Lin Yi-hsin, entrepreneur, to be economic affairs minister; Chen Tin-nan, former magistrate of Ilan, to be justice minister; Chen Chu, social affairs administrator of Kaohsiung City Government, to be chairman of Council of Labor Affairs; and Chen Yu-hsiu, music professor, to be chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs.
The United Daily News:
New Chen-Tang Cabinet is taking shape with new faces, mostly from the Democratic Progressive Party, being appointed.
The Liberty Times:
Three parties and one faction reached consensus on constitutional amendment.
The China Post:
May 20 speech won't work miracle says Chen.
The Taiwan News:
Tang surgery planned for tumor removed; Chen says he's sure premier-designate will fully recover.
The Taipei Times:
Tang names two more to Cabinet; Along with the two confirmed members, a list of possible candidates was leaked to the press yesterday, comprised of academics, people from the business community and politicians with experience at all levels of government.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 12, or the eighth day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1606: The Union Jack becomes England's official flag.
1860: Vajirananavarorasa, prince and patriarch of Buddhism in Siam, is born. He institutionalized Thai Buddhism.
1861: US Civil War breaks out as Confederate forces under Gen. Pierre Beauregarde take Fort Sumter in Charlestown harbor, South Carolina.
1877: Britain annexes the Transvaal, causing deep resentment among the Boers.
1927: The Kuomintang starts a "purification" movement by expelling communist members.
1945: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt dies in office at the age of 63. Vice President Harry S. Truman is sworn in as his successor.
1949: The 37.5 Per Cent Farm Rental Reduction Program goes into effect in Taiwan.
1953: The Legislative Yuan passes a bill submitted by President Chiang Kai-shek, extending the term of office for legislators by an additional year, to May 7, 1954.
1958: The first national meeting for commending "Good Men and Good Deeds" is held at the Chung Shan Hall in Taipei.
1961: The Russians put the first man into space when Cosmonaut Yauri Gargarin is launched in the Vostok I space vehicle for a single orbit of the earth.
1963: Indonesian forces launch the first armed attack against Malaysia as part of a new policy of confrontation.
1965: Twisters attack six US midwestern states, killing 239 people.
1966: Cheng Wan-fu, former chairman of the "Taiwan Democratic Party" and a leader of the "Taiwan Independence Movement" in Tokyo, returns to Taipei after 20 years of self-imposed exile in Japan.
1966: US bombers carry out their first raids over North Vietnam.
1973: Deng Xiaoping, who was purged during the Cultural Revolution, resumes his position as the vice premier of communist China.
1973: Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Economic Affairs Vice Minister K.S. Chang, leading a group of government officials and businessmen, depart for San Francisco to attend a Sino-US conference on economic relations.
1974: Albert Zettermayor, vice president of Lehigh University, and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1974: Tsinghwa University completes the installation of its second nuclear reactor for research purposes. This is the fourth research reactor installed in Taiwan.
1974: Ralph E. Vandervort Jr. and eight US congressional assistants arrive in Taipei for a week-long visit.
1975: President Yen Chia-kan calls on the people to carry out the Last Testament of the late President Chiang Kai-shek.
1975: Taipei building contractors pledge NT$1 million to start a fund-raising campaign for the proposed Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall.
1975: The Central Committee of the Kuomintang calls on people of the Chinese mainland to join the free Chinese in toppling the Beijing regime.
1976: Gonzalo J. Facio, minister of foreign affairs of Costa Rica, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1976: The Kuomintang, ruling party of the ROC, issues a statement urging the Chinese people on the mainland to join the anti-Communist struggle.
1976: Kalus Senegelmann, Nicaragua's minister of agriculture and livestock, arrives in Taipei for a six-day visit.
1979: Taiwan's first geothermal power plant formally starts operation.
1980: President William Tolbert of Liberia is assassinated in a military coup.
1981: Joe Louis, American prize fighter, dies at the age of 67. He held the heavyweight title for nearly 12 years (1937-1949), successfully defending it a record 25 times.
1981: Columbia, the world's first re-usable space shuttle, is launched at Cape Canaveral.
1983: China Airlines inaugurates its regular flight service to Amsterdam as the first step toward establishing a worldwide commercial air service.
1989: Honduran President Jose Azcona Hoyo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1991: The United States and Vietnam agree to set up an office in Hanoi to help locate US soldiers listed as missing in action during the Vietnam War.
1994: The Mainland Affairs Council decides to suspend all cultural and educational exchanges with the mainland until Beijing provides reasonable and satisfactory explanations for the Qiandao Lake tragedy on Mar. 31 in which 24 Taiwan tourists are killed.
1996: The Petronas Towers in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, are declared the world's tallest buildings.
1997: King Leka I returns to Albania after 58 years in exile.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 156.66 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Wednesday, with the benchmark-weighted price index moving down 156.66 points to close at 9,911.39.
Market turnover amounted to NT$231.57 billion (US$7.64 billion)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Wednesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for April moved down 231 points to close at 9,950, with 2,169 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for May plunged 250 points to close at 10,010, with 369 contract transactions. June futures lost 189 points to close at 10,092, with 36 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for September and December futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were: 10,181 for April; 10,260 for May; 10,281 for June; 10,400 for September; and 10,696 for December.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, both reported negative results.

April TE futures moved down 18.55 points to close at 546, with 971 contract transactions, while May TE futures decreased 20.1 points to finish at 552.9, with 210 contract transactions, and June TE futures edged down 4.35 points to close at 561, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures decreased 13 points to close at 998, with 309 contract transaction, while May TF future moved down 16 points to close at 1,015, with 54 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months. (BY Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: MND DENIES REPORTS IT WANTS TO PULL TROOPS OUT OF FRONTLINE ISLETS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) on Wednesday denied categorically that it wants to pull troops out of two outlying islets near mainland China's coastal city of Xiamen in Fujian province.

MND Spokesman Kung Fan-ting was responding to reports that the Kinmen Defense Command has proposed turning over the defense of Tatan and Ertan, less than 2,000 meters from Xiamen, to Kinmen County in order to help boost tourism.
Reports said that Kinmen County is hoping to use the two islets to help attract tourists. Tourism in Kinmen has been on the decline since being opened to tourists in 1993.
Kung stressed that the military has never been lax in the defense of its offshore or outlying islands.
The Army's Commander-in-Chief Chen Cheng-hsiang echoed Kung's words by saying that the Kinmen Defense Command has never contemplated the pullout of troops from the two islets.

But Kung said the MND will carefully asses the proposal based on the following considerations, namely whether the military security of the two islets can be assured, whether the local police force can fully take over the security duties now being carried out by the military, and whether the local government will apply to the MND according to related regulations.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORTY MEMBERS OF US CONGRESS CONGRATULATE CHEN'S ELECTION
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 11 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Forty members of the US Congress signed a letter written on Monday to congratulate Chen Shui-bian on his recent election as president and to congratulate the people of Taiwan for their historic vote that has strengthened democracy on the island.

The letter, introduced by Representative Robert Wexler (D-Fla.), said the Taiwanese people should be praised for their commitment to the democratic ideals of freedom and human rights and for the dramatic voter turnout -- greater than 80 percent of registered voters -- in the recent presidential election.

The US congressmen and congresswomen who signed the letter also included Democratic party whip in the House of Representatives David Bonior (D-Mich.), Sam Gejdenson (D-Conn.) and Tom Lantos (D-Calif.). In the letter, they reassured President-elect Chen that they are committed to the security and prosperity of the people of Taiwan.

They said that there will be several important issues that Chen's administration will undoubtedly have to address, none greater than the future of relations with the People's Republic of China. "We hope that you will advocate for the continuation of cross-strait dialogue with the government of China that we believe will help reduce tensions in East Asia," they said.

The representatives said they were also extremely encouraged by Chen's first public comments following the election and his reference to "a journey of reconciliation to China with good intentions, active cooperation and eternal peace."

"A successful cross-strait dialogue must also include cooperation from the Chinese government. Unfortunately, recent statements issued by Beijing threatening to use military force against Taiwan if prolonged negotiations to reunify the two entities are not successful are unacceptable," the letter continued.

The representatives said they will continue to insist that Beijing renounce the use of force against Taiwan. "Taiwan should not be compelled to accept Beijing's `one country, two systems' formulation that presupposes the final results of any negotiations that is not in accordance with the will of the Taiwanese people," they stressed.

They noted that they also support expanding trade and economic relations between the United States and Taiwan. Taiwan is currently the seventh largest trading partner of the United States. They said they believe that Taiwan's economic fortunes and those of the United States would be greatly enhanced if Taiwan were able to join international multilateral economic institutions, including the International Monetary Fund and the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 156.66 points to close at 9,911.39.

Affected by the continued poor performance of the NASDAQ index in the United States, the bourse opened at 10,067.27, almost at the same level as at the close of the previous trading session. It fluctuated between 10,149.32 and 9,906.32 during trading.

A total of 4.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$231.57 billion (US$7.64 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.21 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of 254.77 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 329 to 207, with 74 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only two posted gains, with pulp and paper issues moving up the most at 5.3 percent, followed by construction stocks at 0.5 percent.

Other major categories lost ground, with electrical shares moving down the most at 2.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 1.3 percent, textile issues at 0.9 percent, foodstuff shares at 0.8 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 0.6 percent, and bank and insurance shares at 0.4 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: JIH SUN HI-TECH FUND MANAGER CONFIDENT ABOUT ELECTRONICS STOCKS

TEXT.P: The Jih Sun Securities Investment Trust Co. Ltd. will introduce a high-technology fund to the market in mid April, with the fund-raising ceiling set at NT$10 billion. Fund Manager Liao Shih-kuei is confident about a bullish stock market for electronics.

Liao said that the electronics industry usually enters its brisk season by the third quarter of the year, with monthly revenue continually rising. He believes that Jih Sun has chosen the right moment to introduce the new hi-tech fund to the market.
Following are excerpts from an interview with Liao by CNA reporter Teresa Tung:
Q: What are the investment targets of Jih Sun's new hi-tech fund?

A: We have targeted the manufacturing industries of IC (integrated circuit), DRAM manufacturing, non-volatile memory cards, thin film transistors-liquid crystal display (TFT-LCD), telecommunications and fixed-network facilities, e-commerce, and especially those electronics stocks with a high dividend payout ratio, such as main boards, components, notebooks, and channels.
Q: What makes electronics stocks the most favored?

A: Electronics stocks have had high investment returns. In the past five years, the investment return ratio for electronic stocks has been nearly as high as 500 percent, far ahead of those for other industries.

Indexes of electronics manufacturing industries in all leading industrial countries showed remarkable growth in the past year. Among the top 10 open equity funds of Taiwan issued last year, six were hi-tech funds and their average investment return ratio was 71 percent. Transactions of electronics stocks accounted for 70 percent of Taiwan's stock transactions. Good prospects are predicted for the next three years.

The export value of the electronics manufacturing industry represents 30 percent of Taiwan's overall export value. Stock price fluctuations in the electronics sector were comparatively moderate, judging from the skyrocketing growth in the electronics stock indexes of JSDAQ (Japanese Securities Dealers Automated Quotation), KODAQ (Korean Securities Dealers automated Quotation), and NASDAQ (National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotation). Taiwan's electronic stock prices may yet achieve new highs.
Q: What is the difference between Jih Sun's hi-tech fund and those issued by other securities investment and trust companies?

A: Jih Sun's hi-tech fund is targeted at the five "star industries" of the electronics sector for 2000 -- namely IC designing and manufacturing, optical electronics, telecommunications, the internet, and software. The economic fundamentals of the industries are taken into consideration, with an emphasis on the growth of each individual stock.

The internet, telecommunications and electronics sectors can be further divided into more than 30 sub-groups. Jih Sun will look at the seasonal factors affecting each sub-group and apply great flexibility in making investments in order to reduce risks and guarantee good profits.
Q: The weighted index of the Taiwan Stock Exchange has now reached 10,000 points. Is it a good time to make investments?

A: The weighted index should not be the only concern. The market trend indicates the prospect of good profits in the hi-tech industries. After the market turbulence during the presidential election period, the long-term investment value of hi-tech stocks is obvious. The second and third quarters of the year are usually the brisk season for the electronics industry. For short-term investments, now is also the right moment.

Evaluating the nation's economic fundamentals, export orders continue to pour in, foreign capital keeps coming into the stock market, and daily purchases in the stock market after the presidential election have mostly exceeded daily selling, and stock market prices are expected to achieve new record highs in the coming months.
Q: What about Jih Sun's deployment of investments for its new hi-tech fund?

A: Since many listed companies on the Taipei Stock Exchange and the over-the-counter market are launching their dividend payout rallies, Jih Sun will invest in mostly those electronics stocks with high growth, high profitability and a high dividend payout ratio. Emphasis will also be put on IC designing and manufacturing, and DRAM and fixed network. The internet and e-commerce are also sectors of high interest. (translated by Lillian Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN URGES KMT TO UNITE TO PLAY ROLE OF CAPABLE OPPOSITION

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan, in his capacity as the acting chairman of the Kuomintang, on Wednesday urged KMT members to unite in order to play the role of a capable opposition party.
Lien made the remarks while meeting with KMT legislators to express his appreciation for their stumping efforts during the presidential campaign.

Lien, noting that the nation's executive power will be turned over to the DPP after Chen Shui-bian is inaugurated on May 20 , said the KMT's political operation center will now be in the Legislative Yuan.

Lien said that despite the election defeat, the KMT is the real majority party in the legislature, considering the fact that the KMT commands more than 100 seats in the 225-seats Legislative Yuan, while the DPP only has 70 seats.
Lien urged all KMT members to join together to play the role of a capable opposition party in order to monitor the performance of the DPP's administration.

At the same time, Lien said the KMT will initiate good legislation that will benefit the public, stressing that the KMT must make the welfare of the people its first priority in order to win back the people's hearts and reverse the public's "twisted, wrongful" impression of the KMT that was the result of the opposition party's campaign.

Lien also said that reform of the KMT must encompass every aspect of the party, including its organization, campaign literature, personnel, and operations, adding that the KMT needs to humbly review itself so that it can rise up from where it has fallen.
