DOC.HEADLINE: MILITARY REITERATES ROC STANCE AGAINST NUCLEAR, BIO WEAPONS

TEXT.P: Chief of the General Staff Tang Yao-ming on Wednesday reiterated the military's determination to follow the government's set policy of never seeking the development of nuclear or biochemical weapons.
Tang said even in the face of heightened military threats from mainland China, Taiwan has vowed not to possess, manufacture, or use nuclear or biochemical weapons under any circumstances.

Tang, however, noted that the armed forces of the Republic of China are striving to research and develop defensive and deterrent technologies and know-how against nuclear and biochemical weapon attacks.

Addressing the opening of a symposium on nuclear and biochemical weapons prevention and defense, Tang said the armed forces are actively building up pre-warning, defense, surveillance, and emergency readiness systems to deal with nuclear and biochemical weapons assaults.

Tang called on Taiwanese citizens of all walks of life to be aware of the dangers of nuclear and bio-chemical weapons attacks and their aftermath, saying that Taiwan is a small island with a high population density and any such attack would be an indescribable disaster.

During the symposium, 13 papers introducing nuclear and biochemical weapons and their powers of destruction will be presented, including one entitled "the PRC's nuclear and biochemical warfare preparedness by 2010 and an assessment of its possible threats to Taiwan."

DOC.HEADLINE: JASON HU DENIES REPORTS OF BEING ASSIGNED AS ROC ENVOY TO UK

TEXT.P: Jason Hu, the spokesman of the Kuomintang, on Wednesday denied reports that he will be assigned to the post of ROC representative to the United Kingdom.
Local reports said that President-elect Chen Shui-bian would invite Hu to serve as the ROC's representative to the UK, considering his academic and political background.
Hu holds a PhD. from Oxford University and has served as the Director-General of the Government Information Office and as the ROC Foreign Minister.
Hu said that "nobody has approached him" about the matter, and that even if someone did ask him to serve in the post, it would be "impossible," saying that "there will be no changes."

On the KMT's attitude toward its members serving in the new Cabinet, Hu said that the party has no idea how many of its members will be in the new Cabinet, reiterating the KMT's basic stance of "not encouraging or endorsing" its members to do so.
Hu served as foreign minister before he was invited to serve as the secretary-general for the KMT presidential campaign office.
Chen Chien-jen took over the post of foreign minister after Hu left. It has been reported that Chen has been assigned to the post of ROC representative to the United States.

The lineup of the Cabinet has become a focus of interest in Taiwan in the wake of the March 18 presidential election. By garnering only 39.3 percent of the vote, Chen's administration will likely rely on talent from other parties to fill many of the major posts and broaden support for the government.

DOC.HEADLINE: CONSUMERS WARNED AGAINST MIXING ST. JOHN'S WORT WITH SOME DRUGS

TEXT.P: St. John's Wort, an herbal product used to treat mild depression, may interfere with medications taken for HIV infection, heart conditions, blood clots, asthma, depression and migraines, Health Canada warned Tuesday.

Health Canada was following Britain's lead in issuing the warning about mixing St. John's Wort with some prescription drugs. The herbal product may also interfere with the oral contraceptive pill, the Department of Health said.

The herbal remedy decreases the efficacy of certain prescription medicines by stimulating the production of liver enzymes that break drugs down into inactive substances. Decreased drug levels in the blood stream may result in the loss of a medicine's therapeutic benefits.
Health Canada has sent a letter to doctors, pharmacists and practitioners of complementary medicine alerting them about the possible reactions.
The department noted that when used on its own, St. John's Wort has not shown any significant health risks.

But consumers are reminded that use of St. John's Wort in conjunction with conventional antidepressants may cause "serotonin syndrome," an excess of serotonin which can cause tremors, headaches and restlessness.

British and US authorities have both issued similar warnings last month after an article was published in the medical publication "Lancet" that raised the alarm about St. John's Wort interacting with medication.

DOC.HEADLINE: TRADE WITH CHINA MUST BE TWO-WAY STREET: US SENATOR

TEXT.P: US Sen. John Ashcroft (R-Mo.) told a Senate hearing Tuesday that trade promises made by Communist China "may well prove hollow unless America is ready to insist that China abide by its commitments to cut its high tariffs and remove other trade barriers."

Renowned mainland Chinese dissident Harry Wu, meanwhile, testified before senators that it is true that permanent normal trade relations and World Trade Organization entry for China will further help American companies economically, but the other major beneficiary will be the Chinese Communist Party.

"The Chinese Communist Party maintains political and economic control in China, and WTO entry would not change that," emphasized the former labor camp prisoner. He then showed pictures to remind the senators of the People's Liberation Army crackdown in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

Sen. Ashcroft cited clear gains that the state of Missouri would make under the US-PRC trade agreement, if Beijing keeps its side of the agreement. But to win congressional approval for the pact, he said, the Clinton administration must be prepared to demonstrate that it is prepared to enforce the terms of the agreement if China tries to back away from its commitments again.

"In the 1992 US-China agreement, promises were made and broken. This must not happen again. It will deprive our people of benefits they have been promised. It will undermine American support for a free and open trading system, because Missourians, and others, will conclude that our government does not have the will to enforce our rights. Fair trade must be a two-way street," stressed the senator.

DOC.HEADLINE: IDEA OF ASEAN, NZ, AUSSIE FREE TRADE ZONE REVIVED

TEXT.P: Australia and some members of the Association of Southeast Asian Nations are reviving the idea of merging the ASEAN Free Trade Zone (AFTA) and Closer Economic Relations (CER), covering 12 countries with a total population of 550 million.

The Australian on Wednesday reported that the joining together of the 10-member regional free trade zone ASEAN and CER, which is made up of Australia and New Zealand, offers gains to the member countries of both organizations.
The daily reported the new regional merger would not undermine the cause of global trade liberalization and, in particular, liberalization within the Asia-Pacific Economic Forum.
There are distinct gains to be made by Australia because while its tariffs are low, ASEAN has significant protectionist barriers against Australian manufactured, agricultural and services exports.
In addition, the Australian business community has already decided it wants the AFTA-CER link.

The idea of merging AFTA and CER originally came from Thailand, and was taken up by the Labor Party government of Australia in the early 1990s. In October 1999, Singapore encouraged the idea and Australia's Trade Minister Mark Vaile seized the opportunity to promote the idea, the daily reported.
Other ASEAN countries such as the Philippines, New Zealand and Indonesia also agreed with the idea of an AFTA-CER merger, the daily reported.
The only stumbling block to the idea could be Malaysia because its Prime Minister Mahathir remains hostile towards Australia, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRC, ROC WTO ENTRY IMPORTANT TO CROSS-STRAIT STABILITY: CLINTON

TEXT.P: US President Bill Clinton on Tuesday pointed out that if both Beijing and Taiwan are admitted into the World Trade Organization, it will increase their interdependence and the cost to Beijing of a military confrontation, but if China is not admitted, tensions in the Taiwan Straits will likely rise.

After meeting with his national security team, Clinton said in a written statement that "it's no surprise that Taiwan's President-elect Chen Shui-bian strongly supports China's membership in the WTO and wants us to grant Beijing permanent normal trade relations. He understands the importance of the stability that will come from good US-China relations and China's membership in the WTO."

Clinton noted that the economic reasons for permanent NTR status for China are clear-cut, but the national security implications are even more far-reaching. "Bringing it into the WTO will entwine China in the global economy, increasing its interdependence with the rest of the world. It will bring the information revolution -- with the knowledge and freedom of thought that entails -- to millions of people in China in ways its government cannot possibly control.

He added that "it will accelerate the dismantling of China's state-owned enterprises -- a process that is getting the government out of people's lives and sparking social and political change all over China. It will strengthen China's reforms and the reformers behind them."

The president said that is reason enough for Congress to vote for permanent NTR status, adding that he is also concerned about what a vote against it would do. "It would have extremely harmful consequences for our national security. Because the economic case for PNTR is so strong, the Chinese will see a rejection as a strategic decision by the United States to turn from cooperation to confrontation, to deal with China as an adversary," emphasized Clinton.

"That would undercut the reform-minded leaders who signed this agreement with us, and strengthen the hand of hardliners who believe cooperating with the United States is a mistake. Those are the same forces most threatened by our alliances with Japan and Korea, the same forces that want the Chinese military to sell dangerous technologies, and the same forces that would pursue confrontation with Taiwan rather than dialogue," he added.

Clinton promised that his administration will spare no efforts in the coming days and weeks to make sure that Congress and the American people understand what the stakes are. And he is confident that when the debate is over and the votes are cast, "Congress will do what is right -- both for our prosperity and our security."

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA MIGHT ALLOW MORE TOURISTS TO WORK

TEXT.P: The Australian government is negotiating agreements with Singapore, Hong Kong, France and Spain whereby young holidaymakers will be able to take temporary work, in a bid to attract more tourists.
In an interview with CNA on Tuesday, a spokesman for Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said the number of young tourists coming to Australia has increased rapidly in the past few years.

An estimated 3.5 million visas were granted to young tourists in fiscal 1994-95 and the figure increased to 6.5 million in 1998-99. The figure is expected to further rise to 7.8 million in 1999-2000 because of the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney.
Immigration officials said the short-term work agreement could eventually cover other countries in the future.
Australia currently has similar agreements with the United Kingdom, Ireland, Japan, Canada, the Netherlands, Malta, South Korea and Germany, the spokesman said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TOUGHENS STANCE ON DEFIANT KOSOVAR REFUGEES

TEXT.P: Australia, backed by UN support, is toughening its stance on sending home more than 180 Kosovar refugees after 32 of them were found to have fled safe havens in Tasmania and New South Wales to avoid being deported.
At one stage, Australia was a safe haven for almost 4,000 Kosovar refugees who fled Serbian ethnic cleansing in the Yugoslav province.

Most of the Kosovar refugees are reluctant to leave Australia, saying they will be killed or face torture if they return home, and had been seeking legal protection to delay their departure. But the High Court of Australia on Monday rejected their pleas.

Immigration Minister Philip Ruddock said the government will use troops and police to hunt the 32 fleeing Kosovar refugees and then deport them within two weeks. As of Tuesday night, some of them had agreed to return to their homeland, but others remained at large.

DOC.HEADLINE: WORLD CONGRESS ON INFORMATION TECH TO BE HELD IN TAIPEI IN JUNE

TEXT.P: The 2000 World Congress on Information Technology (WCIT 2000), is scheduled to be held in Taiwan from June 11-14, with 1,200 representatives from 50 countries and areas participating, government sources said on Wednesday.

It will be the first time the World Information Services and Technology Alliance (WISTA) has hosted the WCIT in Taiwan. Previous biennial meetings have been held in Europe, the United States and Asia, said officials from the National Information Infrastructure Committee (NIIC) under the Executive Yuan.

Executives of big-name companies in the sci-tech world, including Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates, Hewlett-Packard President and CEO Carleton Fiorina and Cisco President and CEO John Chambers will be invited to be keynote speakers at the congress, said NIIC officials.

Meanwhile, the WCIT is also sponsoring an election of outstanding information technology men and women from five continents. Those elected in the voting scheduled to be completed by mid-April are expected to be cited at the Taipei congress.
According to an NIIC spokesman, the Taipei International Computer Exhibition is scheduled to be held from June 5-9 at the Taipei International Convention Center as a kind of run-up to the congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATE COMMITTEE TO HOLD HEARING ON TRA IN LATE APRIL
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The US Senate's Foreign Relations Committee is slated to hold a public hearing on the Taiwan Relations Act (TRA) late this month, committee chairman Jesse Helms said on Tuesday.

Helms (R. North Carolina), said the major purpose of the planned public hearing is to review the administration's performance in implementing the TRA and to demand that US officials explain their decisions on US arms sales this year to Taiwan.

According to Helms, the committee originally decided to call a public hearing in February on Taiwan's military purchase requirements from the United States. However, it was canceled when US officials declined to take part in the event because they thought it might allow Congress to have a greater voice on the issue.

The US administration failed to submit a report to Congress on the development of mainland China's military before March 1, while Beijing issued a "notorious white paper" threatening the use of force against Taiwan prior to the island's March 18 presidential election, the senator noted.
Expressing his belief that US administration officials will be present at the upcoming hearing, Helms added that the Senate will resume its session on April 25 following the Easter recess.
Meanwhile, Taipei and Washington are slated to hold an annual meeting on US arms sales to Taiwan by the end of this month in Washington, D.C.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIG FUND MANAGER SPEAKS ON INVESTMENT IN INTERNET FUNDS

TEXT.P: The AIG Securities Investment and Trust Co. will introduce a new fund for Internet commerce, encouraged by the success of the Core Pacific Investment and Trust Co. in issuing a telecommunications and Internet fund.
In an interview with CNA, AIG fund manager Fang Shi-shin spoke on investment trends as they relate to Internet commerce. Following are excerpts of the interview:

Q: One securities investment and trust company has issued the first fund for Internet commerce, and several similar funds are being screened by the Taiwan Securities and Futures Institute. What is the uniqueness of AIG's new fund?

A: Most of the funds for Internet commerce are more related to the electronics manufacturing sector for Internet appliances. The AIG fund concentrates on Internet business and e-commerce, the trends, and the future. Good prospects can be predicted for Internet funds in the coming five years, taking the example of the success of hi-tech funds in the past three years.
Q: The new Internet fund will be introduced to the market at the end of April. What is the significance of the timing?

A: A bullish stock market is almost sure, judging from Taiwan's economic fundamentals and capital market situation. The fluctuations in the stock market will calm down one month after the presidential election, since cross-Taiwan Strait relations and the domestic political situation were actually the disturbing factors to the stock market. I would say that late April is a proper time for the new fund to enter the market.
Q: The AIG Internet commerce fund has set broadband network facilities as its investment target. How do you see the prospect for profit?

A: Broadband network has changed the horizon of telecommunication services. Standardization of the products and services, including Wireless Applications Protocol, General Package Radio Service and Code Division Multiple Access has created enormous business opportunities for mobile phone manufacturers and service providers. Profit margins in this sector is very high.
Q: What are the available e-commerce stocks in Taiwan? What are the investment prospects?

A: E-commerce in Taiwan is still at an initial stage. Many conventional industries are seeking new roles in the Internet era through the application of e-commerce. Internet business is developing at an accelerated speed. An early entry into the market may guarantee better chances. While it is a good time to invest in e-commerce, it is the right time to introduce the new fund for Internet business.
Q: Knowing that Internet business is the trend, investors are likely to have an interest in this sector. Would you suggest direct stock investment or fund-buying?

A: Internet-related stocks are attractive because of the high investment returns and high risk. These stocks are often described as two sides of a coin. An average stock investor may not be able to make good judgments, while fund managers specialized in this business can help investors make evaluations and reduce the risk. I would therefore suggest that private investors should buy funds.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND SANDSTORM TO HIT TAIWAN AGAIN ON FRIDAY

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to be hit by another blast of sand from mainland China on Friday as a cold front from Mongolia sweeps the yellow dust south, sources from the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) reported on Wednesday.
EPA officials noted that Taiwan is not usually badly afflicted by the sandstorms which plague northern China between late winter and spring every year.

The island has been affected by mainland sandstorms about two or three times a year for only two to three days each time in previous years, but the frequency and intensity are apparently much higher this year, as Taiwan has been under the storms' influence since March 23, and new blasts of sand keep coming, with affected areas much wider than before, the EPA officials noted.

In past years, areas beyond the southern county of Tainan were seldom affected, but this year, the whole of western Taiwan and part of eastern Taiwan have been enveloped in yellow smog since late March. Reports said the sandstorms have even reached as far as the Philippines this year, the officials said.

Local meteorologists are sure that the yellow smog in Taiwan's skies is caused by the dust from northern China rather than by local air pollution. They pointed out that observation centers on Yangmingshan and in towndown Wanhua have found that their air filters are showing thick yellow layers of dust instead of the black granules that are results of air pollution from local vehicles or factories.
The experts attributed the cause of the mainland sandstorms to global weather changes, as well as improper development on the Chinese mainland.

They suggested that as it lies so close to the mainland, Taiwan should not remain ignorant or indifferent to the annual phenomenon. Local government authorities should encourage Taiwan private businesses to finance tree-planting on the mainland to try to prevent drought-affected areas of northern China from suffering further desertification.
These Taiwan businesses can also help the mainland develop more hydraulic power plants and reduce the number of thermal power plants, which are major culprits of air pollution, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TECO TO NEGOTIATE WITH ARGENTINE AGENCIES FOR FISHING BOAT RELEASE
DOC.DATELINE: Asuncion, April 12 (CNA) (By Ramon Huang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: All efforts have been made to secure the early release of a Taiwan trawler and its 28 crewmen detained by the Argentine coast guard on April 9, a spokesman for the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Buenos Aires said on Wednesday.

Larry Y.Y. Wang, the Republic of China's representative in Argentina, met on Tuesday with officials of Argentina's Foreign Ministry and Fishery Agency to discuss the issue of the King Chuan Hsiang fishing vessel and its crew, currently detained in the southern Argentina port of Deseado.

The Kaohsiung-based vessel was detained for allegedly poaching in Argentine waters, although the ships owner has claimed the ship was stopped four nautical miles outside Argentina's 200-nautical mile limit.
However, Argentine mass media quoted the Argentine coast guard as reporting that the ship had been monitored for a long time as it crossed into Argentine waters again and again to poach fish.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2,297 DEATH CERTIFICATES ISSUED AFTER 921 QUAKE: DOH

TEXT.P: A total of 2,297 death certificates were issued for victims of last year's devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, the Cabinet-level Department of Health (DOH) reported on Wednesday.

According to the sobering DOH statistics, some 67 percent of the victims were killed by falling objects, loss of blood, or from being crushed in crumbling buildings, while others were buried alive, burned to death or asphyxiated.

In terms of time of death, about 56 percent of the casualties succumbed within the first two hours of the temblor, while around 10 percent died of their injuries in the days following Taiwan's worst quake in a century.

At the same time, the DOH said it is worth noting that the number of suicide attempts has increased in recent months. This follows patterns previously observed in Japan, and can be attributed to the fact that the six months immediately after a catastrophe is the most difficult period for people living in affected areas.

DOC.HEADLINE: SPECULATION RAMPANT ON CABINET APPOINTEES

TEXT.P: Speculation on the makeup of President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new Cabinet has been rampant, as the alleged appointees have been guarded as to their future jobs, according to reports.
Most have responded by refusing to comment, or by saying they are undecided, or by saying they have no intention of accepting a Cabinet post.

In the wake of Premier-designate Tang Fei's confirmation of appointments to the incoming government -- those of vice premier, cabinet secretary-general and defense minister -- the prospective new economics minister, Lin Hsin-yi, who is vice board chairman of the China Motor Corporation (CMC), has told reporters he is "not clear and not sure" about his possible appointment.
He declined to confirm a news report regarding his new post, although the CMC public relations department claimed the speculation is likely to be proved true.

Lin Chung-hsiung, board chairman of the E. Sun Bank, who is supposedly to be the finance minister in the new administration, stressed that he has no inclination to assume the post due to personal considerations.

Meanwhile, Patrick Liang, chairman of the Chiao Tung Bank, has been reported to be up for the post of chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) due to his past experience as deputy governor of the Central Bank of China and vice chairman of the CEPD.

Lin Chuan, professor at National Chengchi University, has been reported to be the choice for director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics, and Lin has said he will make his decision by Saturday after discussing the appointment with colleagues and friends.
Lin served as director of the Bureau of Finance in the Taipei City Government during Chen's tenure as mayor, and has described working with Chen as a pleasant experience.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW MEETS WITH FORMER GERMAN ECONOMICS MINISTER

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier Vincent Siew met on Wednesday with Guenter Rexrodt, a former German economics minister, to exchange views on bilateral relations between the two countries.

Siew told his visitor that ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian has promised that his administration will maintain current foreign policy, and that Germany is one of the most important European partners for the ROC. Communications channels and routine meetings between the two countries will continue to function as normal, Siew said.

Rexrodt, in return, said that the outgoing Kuomintang has not only created an economic miracle but also promoted successful democratization in Taiwan. These remarkable achievements are worthy of the world's praise, Rexrodt said.

Rexrodt, who served as German economics minister from 1992 to 1998, is member of the Bundesrat (the Federal Council). Rexrodt arrived in Taipei on Tuesday in the company of Michael Fuchs, chairman of the Taiwan Committee of German Enterprises Association.

Rexrodt also extended an invitation to Premier Siew to visit Germany after he steps down from office on May 20 and hoped that Siew, who he described as an old friend, will continue to promote bilateral relations between Taiwan and Germany.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEF PLEDGES TO HELP NEW ROC GOVERNMENT IMPROVE TIES WITH BEIJING

TEXT.P: The Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) will do its best to help the new government to improve ties with Beijing, Chairman Koo Chen-fu said on Wednesday.

In its first board meeting after the March 18 presidential election, the chairman of the agency set up in 1991 by the government to deal with cross-Taiwan Strait contacts, stressed the irreplaceable role played by the SEF in bilateral ties and the valuable experience it has accumulated in the last ten years in engagement with Beijing.

Recalling his latest visit to mainland China in October, 1998, Koo seemed to be disappointed at the nadir in bilateral ties prompted by Beijing's furious attack against President Lee Teng-hui's characterization of Taipei-Beijing ties as "a special state-to-state relationship" in 1999.

Koo said during his 1998 visit, he personally extended an invitation to his Beijing counterpart, Wang Daohan of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait to visit Taiwan, and expressed willingness to visit mainland China again if necessary. However, he went on, all his efforts were made to no avail after bilateral ties nose-dived.

In a sign that he was breaking with Lee's so-called "special state-to-state" advocacy, Koo urged Beijing to stick to a consensus reached between the two sides in 1993 that both sides share the concept of "one China," but with the definition subject to each side's different interpretation as to the meaning of the phrase.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER CEO : NO CHANGE IN INVESTMENT IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Although criticized by a Beijing newspaper for his alleged pro-Taiwan independence stance, Stan Shih, chief executive official of Taiwan's computer giant Acer Group, said that his group will continue its investment projects in mainland China.

Launching the group's 2000 exhibition on a new digital lifestyle, Shih refused to comment on reports by Beijing's Cai Jing Shi Bao (Financial Times) on Tuesday that branded him and three other Taiwan business tycoons who support Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian as being in favor of Taiwan independence.
Beijing authorities warned recently that it will boycott Taiwan businessmen who favor a schism.

Claiming that stories of his pro-Taiwan independence stance are the result of a false impression, Shih said he hoped to clarify his stance to Beijing, and stressed that his group will not stop its projects in mainland China.
The Acer group has relocated some of its manufacturing plants to mainland China in the last few years and has pumped about US$150 million into the mainland.
One of its subsidiaries, Acer Digital Services Group, is expected to funnel as much capital as it takes to set up more than 100 Internet firms in mainland China over the next five years.

At Wednesday's opening of the five-day exhibition, Shih said his group will hand out 3 million discs on how to use the Internet to help bring at least one million households in Taiwan into cyberspace.

He announced that the firm will launch a series of Internet accessible appliances within the coming year while inaugurating a new portal of Acer Digital Services Group that will be linked to Acer Group's 10 websites.

Touting Acer as a group that integrates manufacturing, service providing, and advanced research and development, Shih said his group is better positioned for the web appliance market than other firms.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOTHER OF 24 HOLDS TAIWAN'S RECORD FOR MOST CHILDREN

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Museum of the Guinness Book of Records has found that Pan Hsiu-tao, a 61-year-old aborigine, has had the most children in Taiwan. She has given birth to 24 children.
To mark the upcoming Mother's Day, the Guinness Records Museum, located in Taichung, Central Taiwan, has been searching for Taiwan's "record mothers" in order to seek to challenge world records.

In addition to finding the mother with the most children, the museum is also seeking the oldest mother to give birth to a child, the mother of the most children with doctoral degrees, and several other categories.
Pan, who lives in Taitung County on Taiwan's eastern coast, gave birth to her first child at 15. Over the next 32 years, she was pregnant 22 more times, and once gave birth to twins.
According to the world Guinness Book of Records, the mother of the most children in history was a 17th century Russian woman who had 69 children.
The current world record holder is a Chilean woman who has mothered 55 children.

Two of Pan's children are deceased, two others were given up for adoption, and the remaining children have scattered throughout the island. The museum also announced that it will also help Pan to find her extant children who are still on the island.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSTS 7.5 PERCENT ECONOMIC GROWTH IN FIRST QUARTER

TEXT.P: Taiwan posted a 7.5 percent economic growth rate in the first quarter of the year, and exports also registered double digit growth over the past six consecutive months, according to statistics released by the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) on Wednesday.
The same statistics show that this year's economic growth will surpass the government's target of 6.5 percent, due to a massive increase of private sector investment.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan estimated in February that first quarter economic growth would reach 7.53 percent, close to the figure released by the CEPD on Wednesday.

But the huge increase in private sector investment, orders received for exports, and industrial manufacturing during the first quarter of the year are seen as driving economic growth for the entire year. Yearly economic growth is therefore expected to surpass the projected target of 6.54 percent.
The DGBAS said the weighted indices of the stock exchange (TAIEX) and over-the-counter (OTC) market rose 16.6 percent and 40.3 percent, respectively, compared with last year's first quarter
Transaction volume in the TAIEX and OTC stock exchanges also increased by 20 percent and 40 percent, respectively, DGBAS said.

As of the end of March, foreign investors poured a total of US$29.19 billion into the local stock market, an increase of US$16.76 billion over the same period in the previous year. Capital inflow in the first quarter reached US$7.56 billion, representing a four-fold increase over the previous year.
This indicates that it needs to pay attention to continued inflows of foreign capital, which may affect Taiwan's future economic development, the DGBAS added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN BROADBAND MODEM MAKERS TO ACCOUNT FOR HALF OF WORLD'S OUTPUT

TEXT.P: Taiwan's broadband modem production will surge to account for about half of the world's total output next year, said an telecommunications expert on Wednesday.

In a meeting organized by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA), Huang Teh-tai, a telecommunications expert at the Industrial Technology Research Institute (ITRI) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, said that cable modems used in broadband cable networks are emerging as a backbone of Taiwan's telecom products industry.
Huang said that Taiwan's US$120 million worth of cable modem production in 1999 was 40 times that of the previous year.

In light of a forecasted worldwide annual production growth rate of 250 percent for this product over the next two years, Huang predicted that Taiwan's shipments of these products will grow four times annually.
Wednesday's meeting brought 10 Taiwan-based broadband multiple media firms and their foreign suppliers together to explore the possibility of forging alliances among them.

DOC.HEADLINE: FTSE INTERNATIONAL TO INCLUDE TAIWAN STOCK MARKET INDEX
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 11 (CNA) (By Ou Chun-lin and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: The Financial Times-Stock Exchange Index International (FTSE International) will announce in the near future the inclusion of the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) index on its global stock market indices list.
A source with the securities industry in London made the revelation when attending a seminar sponsored by Taiwan's National Securities Co., in celebration of the founding of its European subsidiary.

The source said that because Taiwan made many restrictions on foreign investment on Taiwan's stock market in the past, FTSE International did not include the TAIEX on its list of global stock market indices.
In view of the fact that Taiwan's status in international business circles is growing more and more, FTSE International decides to include the TAIEX on its indices list, said the source.
Besides Taiwan, another 16 nations, including South Korea and mainland China, will also be included on FTSE International's list, he said.

The source said FTSE International will probably choose stocks of 50 to 100 Taiwan companies as components of the index it made to place on its global stock market indices list. The stocks of seven of the Taiwan companies will be much weighted in the calculation of FTSE International's Taiwan index, the source said.

The seven Taiwan companies to be weighted are Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Ltd., United Microelectronics Corp., Asustek Computer Inc., Cathay Life Insurance Co., Hon Hai Precision Industry Co., Ltd., Nan Ya Plastics Corp., and China Development Industrial Bank.

DOC.HEADLINE: IMF FORECASTS TAIWAN ECONOMY TO EXPAND 6.2 PERCENT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Taiwan is forecasted to post economic growth of 6.2 percent in 2000, according to a biannual report released by the International Monetary Fund (IMF) on Wednesday.

That figure means that Taiwan is expected to have the third fastest growing economy among 28 advanced countries worldwide. The island will be second only to Ireland and South Korea, at 7.4 percent and 7 percent, respectively, predicts the IMF's Report on World Economic Prospects.

The fund predicts Taiwan's inflation rate, or consumer price index, will rise from the 0.2 percent mark of the previous year to 1.8 percent, while unemployment will decline from 2.9 percent to 2.6 percent.
It predicted that the island will keep its place as third fastest growing economy in 2001, with expansion of 6 percent, a jobless rate of 2.3 percent, and inflation of 2.1 percent.
The report also revised upward the IMF's October estimate of mainland China's growth in 2000 from 6 percent to 7 percent, which it expects to dip to 6.5 percent in 2001.
The outlook for Asia's biggest economy, Japan, is dim. The report gives it a 0.9 percent growth for 2000 and 1.8 percent growth for 2001.
As a whole, Asian developing countries lead the world with an average 7.2 percent expected growth this year and 5.9 percent expected growth for next year, said the IMF.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 13, or the ninth day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1589: Britain launches an expedition of 150 ships and 18,000 men to Portugal.
1732: Frederick North, the English prime minister who introduced the Tea Act that led to the "Boston Tea Party," is born. His policies finally led to Britain's loss of America.
1743: Thomas Jefferson, the third president of the United States, is born. He drafted the Declaration of Independence in 1776. His presidency was marked by the purchase of the Louisiana Territory from France in 1803, and the Tripolitan War from 1801 to 1805.
1848: Sicily declares its independence from Naples.
1852: Frank Winfield Woolworth, the American chain store magnate, is born.
1862: France and Annam (now Vietnam) sign the Treaty of Shanghai, annexing the province of Cochin China to France.
1898: Prompted by the success of the Meiji Reformation in Japan, Kang Yu-wei initiates a reform movement and submits a report to Emperor Kuang Hsu of China's Ching dynasty, requesting government reformation.
1904: In the Russo-Japanese War, a mine sinks the flagship of the Russian fleet at Port Arthur (Lushun) in northeastern China, killing 600.
1906: Samuel Beckett, Irish dramatist and winner of the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1969, is born.
1912: The Royal Flying Corps, an armed air service, is formed in Britain.
1919: British troops under the command of Brig.-Gen. Dyer open fire on some 380 followers of Mohandas K. Gandhi in an incident known as the Amritsar massacre.
1939: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini's forces invade Albania.
1941: Japan and the Soviet Union sign the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact in Moscow.
1945: Allied bombers launch massive bombing raids over Japan, destroying a large part of Tokyo.
1960: The construction of an atomic reactor at Taiwan's National Tsinghwa University in Hsinchu, the first of its kind in Southeast Asia, is completed.
1964: Sidney Poitier wins an Oscar for his performance in Ralph Nelson's "The Lilies of the Field," becoming the first black actor to receive the award.
1966: Iraq's President Abdul Salam Arif is killed in a helicopter crash.
1978: Communist China and Portugal formally sign a "joint statement" that clears the way for the return of Macao to Beijing on Dec. 20, 1999.
1980: Twenty-three-year-old Spanish golfer Severiano Ballesteros becomes the youngest-ever and the first European to win the US Masters in Augusta, Georgia.
1982: US Secretary of State Alexander Haig returns to Washington following failed attempts in London and Buenos Aires to settle the Falkland Islands dispute.
1988: Hainan Island becomes the 23rd province and the fourth "special economic region" of mainland China under communist rule.
1990: The Soviet Union admits that its secret police was responsible for the 1940 systematic murder of 1,500 Polish army officers at Katyn, Poland.
1991: Heavy fighting ensues between the Kurds and Saddam Hussein's army in Iraq.
1995: Ukraine agrees to close the Chernobyl nuclear reactor by 2000.
1995: Lang Chin-shan, known as "China's father of photography," dies at the age of 104.
1999: Willi Stoph, chairman of the Council of Ministers of the former German Democratic Republic, dies at the age of 84.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Where there is affection, exertion is made easy; where there is disinterest, instruction will be neglected."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 248.79 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued its downward streak on Thursday, with the benchmark-weighted price index moving down 248.79 points to close at 9,662.60.
Market turnover amounted to NT$209.65 billion (US$6.92 billion).

DOC.TEXT:

Three parties and one political faction come up with a common reform bill on the 'marginalization' of the National Assembly.
