DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S CITIZENS 18TH RICHEST IN THE WORLD SAYS IMF
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: The Taiwanese people are the 18th richest people in the world, with the nation's average annual per capita income based on purchasing power parity expected to reach US$16,854 this year, sources from the International Monetary Fund (IMF) reported on Wednesday.

In its latest World Economic Outlook report, the IMF for the first time used purchasing power parity (PPP) as a basis for comparing living standards among countries. PPP is more accurate than simply translating figures for a nation's per capita gross domestic product (GDP) from the domestic currency into some common currency (like the US dollar) by using exchange rates.

If Taiwan's economy continues to pick up momentum over the next several years, the country's per capita income is expected to surpass those of Britain, France and even Japan within a decade, IMF researchers said.

According to the IMF report, Taiwan's PPP stood at US$759 in 1900, but the figure dramatically increased 21-fold to US$16,854 in 2000 to become the second highest in Asia behind only Japan's US$20,616.
Taiwan would rank 25th in the world if Taiwanese citizen's wealth were calculated based on per capita GDP using exchange rates, said IMF researchers.

According to the IMF ranking, the 10 countries with the wealthiest citizens on average are the United States, Norway, Canada, Denmark, Switzerland, Japan, Australia, the Netherlands, France and Sweden, in that order.
Ranking between 11th and 20th are Belgium, Austria, Britain, Finland, Ireland, Germany, Italy, Taiwan, New Zealand and Spain.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Thursday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for April moved down 230 points to close at 9,720, with 2,516 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May decreased 210 points to finish at 9,800; June futures plunged 262 points to finish at 9,830; September futures moved down 19 points to finish at 10,150; and December futures lost 15 points to close at 10,450.
Contract transactions for May, June, September, and December futures were 673, 59, one, and three respectively.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were: 9,950 for April; 10,010 for May; 10,092 for June; 10,169 for September; and 10,465 for December.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TE) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, reported mixed results.

April TE futures moved down 22.2 points to close at 523.8, with 1,441 contract transactions, while May TE futures lost 22.9 points to finish at 530, with 340 contract transaction, and June TE futures decreased 26 points to close at 535, with 10 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures moved up 3 points to close at 1,001, with 291 contract transactions; while May TF futures edged down 0.2 points to finish at 1,014.8, with 81 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES CONTINUE TO SLIDE ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low and closed even lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 248.79 points to close at 9,662.60.
Affected by continued heavy NASDAQ index losses, the bourse opened at 9,720.67 and fluctuated between 9,911.39 and 9,564.72 during trading.

A total of 3.48 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$209.65 (US$6.92 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 4.13 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of 231.57 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 467 to 96, with 38 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3.9 percent, followed by electrical shares at 3.2 percent, textile issues at 2.6 percent, foodstuff stocks at 2.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.6 percent, cement stocks at 1.2 percent, construction shares at 1.0 percent, and bank and insurance stocks at 0.4 percent. (BY Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: US FAILS TO DISSUADE ISRAEL FROM SELLING FALCON PLANE TO PRC

TEXT.P: United States President Bill Clinton and Secretary of State Madeleine Albright failed to get a concrete commitment from Israeli Prime Minister Barak to stop the planned Israeli sale of airborne early warning equipment to Communist China.

State Department spokesman Jamie Rubin said during a routine press briefing Wednesday that both Clinton and Albright told Barak on Tuesday that things would become uncomfortable and problematic if Israel went ahead with its planned arms sale to China and expressed Washington's deep concerns over this issue.
But, Rubin said "Prime Minister Barak indicated that he understood these concerns, and that we will be discussing this issue further with Israeli officials."

In a background briefing on President Clinton's meeting with Barak Tuesday night, a senior Clinton administration official told reporters that the focus of the four-hour meeting in the White House Oval Office was the Palestinian issue and that Israel's planned sale of Falcon early warning planes was also discussed.

US Secretary of Defense William Cohen had also failed to stop the planned Israeli arms sale to China when he visited there last week. But a Pentagon spokesman pointed out Tuesday that even if Israel agreed to cancel the planned sale, the United States could not prevent such countries as the United Kingdom or France from selling similar equipment to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: US WORKERS VOICE OPPOSITION TO PERMANENT NTR STATUS FOR PRC

TEXT.P: Over ten thousand American labor union members gathered on Capitol Hill here Wednesday to lobby against President Bill Clinton's call for Congress to grant Communist China permanent normal trade relations status.

John Sweeney, president of the AFL-CIO, the largest labor organization in the United States, said that "our message is that until there is a permanent change of values in China, there will be no permanent NTR with China."

Rep. Nancy Pelosi (D-Calif.) commented to reporters that union members can help determine the vote in the House of Representatives, which is scheduled for the week of May 22. The Senate is set to pass the legislation granting Communist China permanent NTR status.

Rep. David Bonior (D-Mich.), the House minority whip, told the rally that "workers everywhere have a right to be treated with dignity and respect," saying that the Clinton administration's trade accord with China would "force workers here to compete with men and women who earn sweatshop wages."

Reform Party presidential contender Patrick Buchanan said "the Chinese Communists are selling us 40 percent of all their exports. They are taking only one percent of ours. Who is negotiating these deals?"

The conservative commentator promised that if he became president, "it won't be US Trade Representative Charlene Barshefsky sitting down in Beijing. It will be Teamsters President Jim Hoffa sitting down" to negotiate with China on trade issues.
Hoffa said that "as long as they imprison Chinese labor leaders, we say no to this agreement," which helps pave the way for China's accession to the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL POLICY ADVISORY GROUP DISSOLVED AFTER COMPLETING MISSION

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian's ad hoc National Policy Advisory Group was dissolved Thursday after accomplishing its historical mission, said group leader Lee Yuan-tseh.

Lee, the president of Academia Sinica, the top research institute in Taiwan, said the National Policy Advisory Group had come together for three meetings over the past 24 days since Chen's election. The group helped Chen make a decision on the appointment of a premier and helped give form to the future national policies of the new government scheduled to be inaugurated on May 20.

Some of the 13 members of the group have been recruited into the Cabinet to be headed by Premier-designate Tang Fei, some have accepted offers to be advisers or consultants to the president, and some will return to their previous prestigious posts, Lee noted.
Lee, the Nobel Prize winning chemist, has been appointed by President-elect Chen to be one of his senior advisers.
In the group's last meeting on Thursday, members focused the discussion on the new government's future administrative policies, during which President-elect Chen wrote four pages of notes, said Lee.
Now that the group has been dissolved, Lee said the members will not make any further suggestions to Chen or Premier-designate Tang on the line-up of the Cabinet or related personnel issues.

Over the past several days, the group has offered its opinions on appointments to the new Cabinet. Although only part of the Cabinet has been named so far, several new faces have been appointed to posts in the new government.

These include Vice Premier Yu Shyi-kun; Defense Minister Wu Shih-wen; Executive Yuan Secretary-General Wea Chi-lin; Coast Guard Administrator Wang Chun; Yang Teh-chih, chairman of the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen; National Science Council Chairman Chen Tang-shan; Foreign Affairs Minister Tien Hung-mao; Chen Chien-jen, chief Taiwan representative in the United States; Chen Yu-hsiu, chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs; and Chang Fu-mei, chairman of the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC MAINLAND AFFAIRS OFFICIAL SPEAKS IN D.C.

TEXT.P: On the thorny issue of cross-strait relations, Taiwan is striving for a dialogue with mainland China that will maintain its dignity, rather than seeking independence, said a Republic of China official in charge of mainland Chinese affairs in Washington, D.C.
Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said the United States should advocate Taiwan's democratization as a role model for the Chinese mainland.

In a keynote speech at a seminar hosted by Goldwater Chair of Arizona State University, Lin said the United States should help protect Taiwan from the military intimidation of the People's Liberation Army, and the US should help protect the Taiwanese economy so as to allow it to serve as an example of efficiency for mainland China to emulate.

Lin said in recent years, the PLA has considered a military takeover of Taiwan as its most important task, and has viewed the United States as an inevitable barrier to accomplishing that goal. Therefore, the PLA has envisaged the US as its top enemy in the future, he added.
When faced by occasional PLA strategic challenges, Washington and Taipei share common interests in maintaining regional stability, Lin noted.
He added that the national interests of the United States and the ROC are more compatible than those between the United States and mainland China.
History is on the side of the ROC and communist China will not last in its present form, Lin concluded.

Lin, a respected military strategist and mainland Chinese affairs expert in Taiwan, arrived in Washington on Tuesday for the exclusive purpose of delivering the speech. He departed for home on the same day.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE DENIES RIFT WITH PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Tang Fei said on Thursday that he has no serious disagreements with President-elect Chen Shui-bian over Cabinet selections.
The incumbent defense minister made the remarks before delivering a speech on leadership at National Taiwan University's College of Management.

Tang said although he and Chen are sometimes divided on the principles and major criteria for selecting a qualified person to fill a high-ranking government post, such differences have never hindered their communication and consultations.
"Neither of us has ever insisted on the appointment of any specific person for any specific post," Tang stressed.
Tang, a former chief of the General Staff and a former ROC air force commander-in-chief, revealed that several Cabinet ministers have already been selected.
For instance, Tang said the post of foreign minister will be filled by Tien Hung-mao, a political science and international affairs expert.

Meanwhile, Tang said incumbent Vice Foreign Minister David Lee will remain on his current post in the new administration, and that outgoing Foreign Minister Chen Chien-jen will serve as new Republic of China representative to the United States.

Tang went on to say that Chen Yu-hsiu, dean of the College of Fine and Applied Arts of National Taiwan Normal University, will head the Cabinet-level Council for Cultural Affairs; and that Wang Chun, incumbent deputy director-general of the National Police Administration, will be promoted to the top post of the Coastal Guard Administration.

Tang further said Yang Teh-chih, commander-in-chief of the Combined Service Force, will retire from active military service to head the Vocational Assistance Commission for Retired Servicemen, and that Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-chan has agreed to serve as chairman of the National Science Council.

As for the new chief of the Government Information Office (GIO), Tang said he is still mulling the issue, adding that he has ruled out the possibility of naming a media professional to head the GIO because such an appointment would violate current regulations.

Commenting on press reports that he had rifts with Chen over the selection of top financial and economic officials, Tang said the reports were sheer speculation and had apparently "politicized" the Cabinet formation issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MA YING-JEOU MEETS WITH DOMINICAN REPUBLIC ENVOY

TEXT.P: Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou met on Thursday with Dominican Republic Ambassador to the Republic of China Victor Manuel Sanchez to exchange views on strengthening relations between Taipei and the Dominican capital, Santo Domingo, which maintain sisterly ties.

During the meeting, Ma expressed a warm welcome to Sanchez, and extended an invitation through the ambassador to the mayor of Santo Domingo to attend the 2000 World Congress of Information Technology (WCIT). The 2000 WCIT will run from June 20-24 in Taipei.
Sanchez said that the mayor of Santo Domingo has already planned to visit Taipei in June or July to observe transport, garbage disposal and traditional markets.

DOC.HEADLINE: HONG KONG, MACAO OBSERVERS PRAISE TAIWAN'S PRESIDENTIAL ELECTION

TEXT.P: Observers from Hong Kong and Macao who came to Taiwan to watch the March 18 presidential election gave high praise to the poll's procedure, officials of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Thursday.

The MAC was referring to 269 members of 14 observer groups from Hong Kong and Macao who visited the island in the run-up to the election. The remarks were made during the MAC's briefing to the weekly meeting of the Executive Yuan.

Hong Kong observers included: The Taiwanese Association in Hong Kong & Macao; The Journalist's Observer Group; The Political, Academic and News Critics Visit Group; The Democratic Party; The Liberal Party; The Front Line Observer-group; The Citizen Power Visit Group; The Association of Hong Kong Legislative Councilors; Representatives from the Hong Kong Region; and The Students Election Observing Group from the University of Hong Kong.

249 visitors came from Hong Kong, including 10 members of the Legislative Council, 70 members of the District Council, 18 experts from Hong Kong universities and colleges, as well as 20 journalists and commentators. The remainder are professionals or politicians.
A total of 20 scholars and media workers came from Macao.

After returning to Hong Kong and Macao, the visitors expressed extensive comments and opinions to the local media. They gave high evaluations of Taiwan's mature democratic development and the efficient operations of the political parties, as well as the general public's enthusiasm for election activities, said the MAC officials.
However, the visitors from Hong Kong and Macao held a reserved attitude toward the island's election funds' operations, and the government's system for auditing those funds , MAC officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: TOTAL SALES OF TAIWAN-MADE PRODUCTS STEADILY DECREASING IN US

TEXT.P: The market for Taiwan-made products in the United States is decreasing yearly because of the products' similarity in design and quality to products from mainland China, according government statistics.

The Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics under the Executive Yuan said that Taiwan-made products accounted for 3.5 percent of US consumption in January. The figure is roughly the same as last year, but represents a decrease of 1.34 percent compared with that of January 1991.
The DGBAS said that Canada, Japan, Mexico and mainland China have emerged as the US' main suppliers after the North American Free Trade Agreement (NAFTA) was established.

Taiwan-made products were ranked sixth, leading the list of Asia's so-called tiger economies. Taiwan, South Korea, Hong Kong and Singapore together accounted for 9.6 percent of the US market, a decrease of 2.6 percent from last year.
Meanwhile, Taiwan-made products accounted for 4.4 percent of the Japanese market, slightly higher than the 4.1 percent registered last year, the DGBAS said.
The United States itself topped the list of market penetration with 19.3 percent, followed by mainland China with 13.3 percent. South Korea came in third, and Taiwan was ranked fourth.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10-PLUS FOREIGN LEADERS TO ATTEND ROC PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: More than 10 foreign heads of state and prime ministers are expected to attend President-elect Chen Shui-bian's inaugural ceremony on May 20, a spokesman for the Presidential Office's transitional team said on Thursday.

The spokesman made the statement after the transitional team held a meeting with relevant government agencies, including the Ministry of Foreign Affairs, to discuss issues related to the upcoming presidential inauguration.

It was decided during the meeting that Chen's swearing-in ceremony will be held in the Presidential Office's Chieh-shou Hall in the morning of May 20, with Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng supervising.

During the ceremony, Acting National Assembly Speaker Chen Chin-jan will transfer the national seal and the president's official seal to Chen to symbolize the peaceful transfer of administrative power from the Kuomintang to the opposition Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
After the oath-taking ceremony, Chen will deliver his inaugural speech at a rally of more than 10,000 people gathered in the Presidential Office plaza.

The transitional team said the scale of Chen's inaugural ceremony will be larger than that of outgoing President Lee Teng-hui's four years ago, as Chen's inauguration marks the first transfer of administrative power in the Republic of China's political history.
Initial tallies show that more than 10 heads of state and prime ministers from Central American and African countries will attend the ceremony.

Relevant government officials also said that the US government is expected to send a delegation, but added that it remains unclear whether Japan, Hong Kong, Macau and the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait will send delegates to the ceremony.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN RANKS WORLD'S 14TH-LARGEST EXPORTING COUNTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 13 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwan was ranked as the world's 14th-largest exporting country, and the 15th-largest importing country in terms of merchandise in 1999, according to statistics released on Thursday by the World Trade Organization (WTO).
The statistics also show that Taiwan was ranked the world's 21st-largest commercial service trade exporting country during the same period.

Taiwan exported US$126.1 billion-worth of goods in 1999, representing 2.2 percent of global exports overall. During the same period, Taiwan imported US$111 billion-worth of goods, or 1.9 percent of the total goods imported around the world.
In terms of commercial service trade, Taiwan exported US$14.8 billion-worth, or 1.1 percent of the global figure, while it imported US$23.2 billion-worth, or 1.7 percent of the global total.

The United States topped the list in all categories, exporting US$695 billion-worth of goods, or 12.4 percent of the global total, and US$251.7 billion-worth of business service exports. It imported US$1,051.7 billion-worth of goods, or 18 percent of the world total, and US$182.3 billion-worth of business service imports, or 13.7 percent of the world total.

The same statistics listed the world's top ten large merchandise-exporting countries as the United States, Germany, Japan, France, Great Britain, Canada, Italy, Holland, mainland China and Belgium-Luxembourg. The top ten importing countries were the United States, Germany, Great Britain, Japan, France, Canada, Italy, Holland, Hong Kong and Belgium-Luxembourg.

The top ten commercial service-exporting countries were the United States, Great Britain, France, Germany, Italy, Japan, Spain, Holland, Belgium-Luxembourg and Hong Kong, while the top ten importing countries were the United States, Germany, Japan, Great Britain, Italy, France, Holland, Canada, Belgium-Luxembourg and mainland China.
The global export total was US$5,610 billion, while global imports were worth US$5,875 billion.
In commercial services, the world export total was US$1,340 billion, while imports amounted to US$1,1450 billion.

DOC.HEADLINE: H.K. GOVERNMENT URGED TO SAFEGUARD PRESS FREEDOM

TEXT.P: More than 10 representatives of the political group Frontier Thursday staged a demonstration before the Hong Kong government headquarters, urging the government to safeguard press freedom in the territory.

The demonstration was held after Wang Fengchao, deputy director of Beijing's Liason Office in Hong Kong, said Wednesday that the news media of Hong Kong have the responsibility and obligation to support China's position on unification with Taiwan and to uphold China's unity. The media should not treat pro-independence speeches and views of Taiwan people as normal news items, he said.

Wang made the remarks after a Hong Kong cable TV station reported last week an interview with Taiwan's vice president-elect Annette Lu on cross-strait relations. She was subsequently called "the scum of the nation" by official Chinese news media for making "separatist remarks" in the interview.
The demonstrators said they were worried by Wang's remarks and asked the government to safeguard press freedom in Hong Kong.
Meanwhile, Wang was criticized Thursday in the editorials of Hong Kong newspapers, including the Apply Daily, Ming Pao, and the Economic Times, for having violated press freedom in Hong Kong.

The editorials said that the position of Beijing, as indicated in Wang's remarks, may hinder the implementation of "one country, two systems" in Hong Kong and may defeat the functions of the press in free society.
Beijing has promised to let Hong Kong keep its democratic systems for 50 years after its reversion to China in July, 1997 under the so-called "one country, two systems" policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: US CONGRESSMEN HAVE GOOD IMPRESSION OF ROC PRESIDENT-ELECT
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: US House Majority Whip Thomas D. DeLay (R-Texas) on Wednesday lauded Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian as a "straightforward, no-nonsense type of person."
Delay further said he believes that Chen, a lawyer-turned-politician, will be "a good representative of Taiwan in the world community."
Delay made the remarks after Chen held hour-long talks with several influential members of the US Senate and House of Representatives via a satellite link-up.
Delay said the meeting offered a good opportunity for Chen to exchange views with US congressional members on matters of mutual concern.

The meeting also allowed US senators and congressmen to convey their warm congratulations on Chen's election victory and to express their admiration for Taiwan's achievement in setting the record of first peaceful transfer of power in Chinese society, Delay said.
"We want him to know that he has friends here in the Congress that he can call on if he needs us," Delay added.

Meanwhile, Chen was quoted as having told the American congressmen that numerous public opinion polls conducted in Taiwan indicate that the people of Taiwan do not think that Taiwan is a province of the People's Republic of China as Beijing would have the rest of the world believe.
Chen also assured the US congressional leaders that he will do his utmost to forge a consensus among the people of Taiwan on the so-called "one China" issue.
As for Taiwan's security needs, Chen was quoted as having said that his administration will "keep the dialogue open with both the US executive branch and Congress."
The satellite conference was arranged by a US think tank and took place on the American end at a conference room on Capitol Hill.

Other US congressional members present at the meeting included Rep. William Barrett (R-Neb.), chairman of the House Subcommittee on Asia-Pacific Affairs; Rep. Mary Bono (R-Calif.), a member of the House Committee on Security Affairs; Sen. Jeff Sessions (R-Ala.), a member of the Senate Committee on Armed Services; and Sen. Mitch McConnell (R-Ky.)

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER IN US TO SEEK SUPPORT FOR WTO ENTRY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 12 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu visited the US Trade Representative (USTR) Office on Wednesday to seek US support for ROC entry into the World Trade Organization (WTO).
Lin called on Deputy USTR Richard Fisher, Assistant Asia-Pacific USTR Donald Phillips and several other officials to exchanged views on the progress of Taipei's and Beijing's WTO entry applications.

Fisher told Lin that the Clinton administration is mobilizing to lobby members of the House of Representatives for passage of the bill governing permanent normal trade relations status for mainland China. The administration hopes that the House of Representatives will pass this bill by the end of May.

Taiwan has already completed the signing of bilateral agreements on its WTO entry with all other WTO members who demanded negotiations, with the exception of Hong Kong. It reached agreement with the United States in February 1998.
The subsequent stagnation of Taiwan's WTO entry process has been due mainly to hindrance from Beijing.

The United States has expressed its stance that the entries of Taiwan and mainland China into the WTO should be dealt with separately, But some WTO members think that mainland China should enter the world trade regulatory body prior to Taiwan.

Mainland China has yet to sign bilateral agreements on its WTO entry with seven WTO members -- the European Union, Costa Rica, Ecuador, Guatemala, Latvia, Mexico and Switzerland -- before it can join the WTO, and has provided the United States with a verbal promise that once it is admitted to the WTO, it will not prevent Taiwan from joining the international organization.
After his Washington, D.C. meetings, Lin left for Geneva, Switzerland where he will meet with WTO officials to gain an understanding of the latest developments concerning Taiwan's WTO entry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO BY-ELECTIONS FOR COUNTY MAGISTRATES, MAYORS JOINING CABINET: MOI

TEXT.P: No by-election will be held for county magistrates or city mayors appointed to the Cabinet if the remaining tenure is within two years, a Ministry of the Interior (MOI) official said on Thursday.
Instead, the Executive Yuan will appoint an acting magistrate or city mayor to fill the vacancy, the official added.

Annette Lu, incumbent magistrate of Taoyuan County, was elected the 10th vice president of the Republic of China in the March 18 presidential election, and Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-shan will be also appointed as chairman of the National Science Council in the new administration of President-elect Chen Shui-bian.

Lin Tzu-ling, director of the Civil Affairs Department of the MOI, noted that by-elections must be held within three months if an official tenders his or her resignation, is dismissed, or dies, in accordance with regulations stipulated in the self-government law, but only if tenure has two years or more to run.

The four-year tenure for the current county magistrates runs from Dec. 20, 1997 to Nov. 20, 2001, which means that if any magistrate or city mayor is named as a Cabinet member, their remaining tenure will have less than two years to run, so that no by-election will be needed, she stressed.
The MOI has also submitted a report to the Executive Yuan, which will appoint an acting official to administer the local government, she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT-ELECT VOWS TO IMPROVE CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian assured US Congress members on Thursday that his administration will attach great importance to improving relations across the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the assurance during talks with several influential members of the US Senate and House of Representatives through a satellite link-up.
During their hour-long talks, Chen also reaffirmed that unless mainland China attempts to use force against Taiwan or invade Taiwan, the island will not declare independence.

The lawyer-turned-politician further assured the American congressional leaders that he has full sincerity and goodwill to forge rapprochement with mainland China and will make every effort to avoid adding up to any new trouble in cross-strait relations.
According to Chen's office, the satellite conference focused discussion on Taiwan's security, defense needs and cross-strait relations.
During the meeting, Chen said reopening of constructive dialogue and communication channels and establishment of stable, normal cross-strait relations are in the interest of both Taipei and Beijing.
Chen said he believes that both the United States and other Asian countries will be pleased to see cross-strait relations develop in such directions.
Therefore, Chen said his administration will make it a priority to improve cross-strait relations and maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen also reaffirmed Taiwan's "three noes" policy toward mainland China during his presidential tenure: no inclusion of the special state-to-state relationship theory into the ROC's constitution; no referendum on the sensitive "unification or independence" issue; and no change of the ROC's national title.
Chen further said he believes that normalization of cross-strait trade ties will offer a new opportunity for resumption of bilateral dialogue because both sides will benefit from such developments.

Noting that simultaneous entry into the World Trade Organization can help boost normalization of cross-strait relations, Chen urged the United States to help Taiwan and mainland China enter the WTO as early as possible.

Chen also expressed his hope that the annual Taipei-Washington meeting on Taiwan's arms purchase requests can be held as scheduled. The first-ever transfer of power in Taiwan should not become an excuse for any delay in holding such an important routine event.

On the cross-strait issue, Chen urged the outside world not to hold unrealistic high expectations of his inaugural address, stressing that cross-strait disputes have existed for more than 50 years and cannot be resolved simply by a single speech.

Chen further said as Taiwan's new leader, he cannot ignore the public opinion, adding that Beijing's "one China" definition and "one country, two systems" unification scheme are unacceptable to the majority of Taiwan people.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FUGITIVE REPORTEDLY ARRESTED IN MAINLAND CHINA

TEXT.P: Police said on Thursday that they are checking reports that a Taiwan fugitive has been arrested in mainland China, and said they will ask for his extradition if possible.

Sources from the Criminal Investigation Bureau said that rather than having been killed by mainland Chinese gangsters as had been reported in Thursday's newspapers, Jan Lung-lan, a fugitive wanted by Taiwan for at least a dozen kidnappings and some 30 other criminal cases, was arrested by public security officials in Yunnan Province, southwestern China.

Jan was caught on March 31 in Kunming, the capital of Yunnan Province, by public security officers in a drug sting set up by mainland gangsters who were angered by Huang's extortion of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China and eager to get him off their turf, said the sources.
Taiwan police are looking into the reports and will try to have him extradited through the appropriate channels, the sources went on.

Huang fled to mainland China in March 1995 while being hunted by Taiwan police in connection with several high-profile kidnappings. He later began extorting money from Taiwan businessmen in mainland China and engaged in drug deals, said the sources.

DOC.HEADLINE: DIESEL AND COAL OIL OF PRIVATE LOCAL COMPANY TO BE PERMITTED ON MARKET

TEXT.P: Diesel and coal oil produced by a private local company are expected to be permitted to enter the market soon, ending the monopoly on the oil market held for many years by the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC).

The Formosa Plastics Group (FPG), a local petrochemical giant, has applied to the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) to sell its diesel and coal oil on the local market, and the application is expected to be approved soon, a MOEA official said on Thursday.

Chen Chao-yih, executive secretary of the Energy Commission of the MOEA, said the move will further liberalize the oil supply on the local market, and added that prices will be determined by market forces.

Chen said CPC produces 770,000 barrels of oil per day, an amount which already satisfies local demand, while FPG will add a daily production of 450,000 barrels to the market, making it likely that fierce competition will emerge between the two petrochemical behemoths.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE DENIES CONFLICT WITH PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Tang Fei denied on Thursday that he has clashed with President-elect Chen Shui-bian over the makeup of the incoming Cabinet.

Asked by reporters about a newspaper article on Thursday that said he had conflicted with Chen over who should take charge of finance and economical affairs under his administration, Tang said that Chen and he have different opinions on what qualities are required of candidates for those posts. However, he added, neither Chen nor he had insisted on any position, much less argued with each other.

Denying the China Times report that he and Chen had conflicted over his insistence that Wu Jung-ming, an activist of the newly-formed People First Party, be included in his Cabinet, Tang said both Chen and he appreciate Wu's talent, but that they would consult Wu before asking him to join the government.
Tang make the comments before delivering a speech at National Taiwan University's College of Management.

DOC.HEADLINE: 673 REGISTER TO RUN FOR 339 NA SEATS

TEXT.P: A total of 673 people have registered to run for the 339 seats in the National Assembly (NA), although it is still not clear whether an election will actually take place, the Central Election Commission (CEC) said on Thursday.

Of the 673 candidates, 472 have registered to contest the 239 regional NA seats, and 201 have signed up to take the 80 non-regional and 20 overseas Chinese representation seats which will be allocated to political parties according to the proportional representation system.

The Kuomintang, which lost its 50-year ruling status to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) in the March 18 presidential election, have nominated a total of 211 candidates in various seat categories, and the DPP have recommended 159.

The newly established People First Party (PFP) of former Taiwan Governor James Soong filed 156 candidates, followed by the tiny New Party with 36, and nonpartisans, who are contesting 109 regional seats.

However, it is still uncertain, with only about three weeks to go until the May 6 election date, whether the vote will take place, as the incumbent NA members are attempting to marginalize the NA through an amendment to the Constitution.

The NA passed a resolution late last year to extend the tenure of incumbent NA members by two years and two months to January 2002, but the Council of Grand Justices ruled last month that the resolution is invalid, paving the way for the election.
Under these circumstances, the political parties are desperately preparing for the new election on the one hand, while trying to stymie it on the other.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ROC CABINET TAKING SHAPE

TEXT.P: Republic of China Premier-designate Tang Fei reported on Thursday that his Cabinet is taking shape, with most of the Cabinet posts already filled by "suitable" people.
You Hsi-kun, secretary-general of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) will sever as vice premier.

Minister of Foreign Affairs Chen Chien-jen will be reassigned as Taipei's representative to the United States, and the vacancy left by him will be filled by Tien Hung-mao, director of the Institute for National Policy Research, a private think tank.

Vice Minister of Foreign Affairs David Ta-wei Lee will be retained, while Chen Yu-hsiu, the dean of the College of Fine and Applied Arts at the National Taiwan Normal Universty and widow of late Democratic Progressive Party Legislator Lu Hsiu-yi, will become the chairman of the Council for Cultural Affairs.
Chang Fu-mei, another woman and a member of the Control Yuan, will take the reins at the Overseas Chinese Affairs Commission.

Deputy Director-General of the National Police Administration Wang Chun will head the newly established Coast Guard Administration, while Commander of the Combined Services Force Gen. Yang Teh-chih will be appointed chairman of the Veterans Affairs Commission.
Tainan County Magistrate Chen Tang-san has verbally agreed to serve as chairman of the National Science Council, pending the final approval of President-elect Chen Shui-bian.
Vice Minister of National Defense Wu Shih-wen will be promoted to the post of minister of national defense.
Chang Po-ya, former director-general of the Department of Health, has been designated as minister of the interior, and businessman Lin Hsin-yi has been nominated as minister of economic affairs.

Wei Chi-lin, chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission will be reassigned as secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, while the vacancy he leaves will be filled by Lin Chia-cheng, a professor at Soochow University.

Shea Jia-dong, deputy governor of the Central Bank of China is to be named minister of finance. Tseng Chih-lang, president of the National Yang Ming Universty will be the minister of education, and Legislator Yeh Chu-lan will be the new minister of transportation and communications.

Lin Chuan, a professor at National Taiwan University, will serve as the director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, while Chen Chu, director of the Bureau of Social Affairs under the Kaohsiung City Government will be the chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs.

Lin Neng-pai, Dean of the College of Management at National Taiwan University, will be the chairman of the Public Construction Commission, while Tsai Ing-wen, adviser to the National Security Council, will become chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council.
Tang added that the candidates for the remaining Cabinet posts will be named soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Friday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
KMT members will be authorized to elect party chairman.
The China Times:
The new Cabinet line-up has not yet been fully finalized.
The United Daily News:
President-elect Chen and Premier-designate Tang are at odds over some Cabinet selections.
The Liberty Times:
Outgoing President Lee Teng-hui and Premier-designate Tang Fei are worrying about mainland China's missile threats.
The China Post:
President-elect Chen Shui-bian pledges new 'three noes.'
The Taiwan News:
New foreign-policy team is confirmed.
The Taipei Times:
Cabinet selection is almost finished.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES CONTINUE DOWNWARD STREAK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's stock market continued its downward swing on Friday, with the benchmark weighted Taiwan Stock Exchange price index losing 287.99 points to close at 9,374.61.
Daily market turnover totaled NT$185.43 billion (US$6.06 billion) in volatile trading.
