DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT COMMERCE EXPERT NAMED GOV'T SPOKESMAN

TEXT.P: Chin Chung, a fellow researcher at the Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER), was named on Friday by Premier-designate Tang Fei as the next spokesperson for the government of the Republic of China.

Chung, 47, is currently a doctorate candidate in business at Cornell University and has been with the private think tank CIER since she returned from the United States some 10 years ago. She is an expert in cross-strait business and trade exchanges.

Confirming her appointment as government spokesperson, formally known as director-general of the Government Information Office (GIO), Chung said the people of Taiwan are attaching a lot of expectations to the new government which is scheduled to be inaugurated on May 20. She said she is one of the few people lucky enough to be recruited into the new administration.

Chung, who gave concrete suggestions on cross-strait trade and investment exchanges after President Lee Teng-hui began advocating the "No haste, be patient" policy towards mainland China six years ago, said the greatest challenge she will face in the new post will be how to create new ideals within the existing framework of the system.

An independent scholar and the daughter of parents who came from mainland China, Chung said she has had little formal contact with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) over the years, except for taking part in several symposiums hosted by the party.

In related news, the local labor sector on Friday welcomed the appointment of Kaohsiung City Labor Affairs Administrator Chen Chu as the chairman of the Council of Labor Affairs -- the nation's top labor affairs post.

The labor sector lauded Chen as a humanitarian practitioner who has contributed a lot to taking care of the welfare of aborigines, women and other less-privileged groups in society for a long time, and has also maintained close ties with human rights groups abroad.

According to Premier-designate Tang Fei, who has been busying himself with the new Cabinet's line-up over the past few days, more new appointments to the Cabinet will be announced over the next several days as some posts are still under discussion.

Tang on Friday also confirmed two other appointments -- Lin Hsin-yi, an entrepreneur who is currently vice chairman of Chung Hua Motors, to the post of economic affairs minister, and Chen Tang-shan, who is currently the magistrate of Tainan County, as new chairman of the National Science Council.

Meanwhile, Hao Lung-ping, convenor of the New Party's National Election Campaigning and Development Committee, said he is giving serious consideration to an offer of a Cabinet post by Premier-designate Tang. Hao said his father, former Premier Hao Pei-tsun, was pleased with the offer but wanted Hao to make his own decision. Hao said he will make the final decision after consulting with senior New Party officials.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE FIRST PARTY COULD WORK WITH KUOMINTANG: PFP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official of the newly-formed People First Party (PFP) said on Friday that to work with the Kuomintang to run in the next presidential election should be the direction of the party's efforts.
PFP Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung made the remarks during an interview on a local radio station.
As for himself, Chang said he has no intention of staying in politics and James Soong has to choose "someone who is younger to be his running mate."

Soong and Chang ran together as independents in the March 18 presidential election, garnering 36.8 percent of the vote, behind only the Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Shui-bian and Annette Lu who received 39.3 percent of the vote, but far ahead of the Kuomintang's Lien Chan and Vincent Siew who received only 23.1 percent of the vote.
Despite loosing the fiercely fought election, Soong was termed the most "intriguing" figure because of his strong performance despite not having party support.

Chang noted that PFP chairman Soong, a former KMT heavyweight, had said before the presidential election that he would not return to the KMT and that he hoped bipartisan politics similar to that in the United States could be maintained in Taiwan.
But Chang said that in response to the strong call from the voters after the presidential election, the PFP was inaugurated on March 31.

As for the development of the PFP, Chang admitted that the ethnic question will be a big challenge, saying that the long-term rule of the KMT has forced many opposition elites to turn toward the Democratic Progressive Party.
But Chang also noted that a dozen native Taiwanese legislators from other parties have expressed their intentions of joining the PFP caucus in the Legislative Yuan.
He said that recruiting more young elites will be crucial to the party's development.

He said that a coalition with the KMT will be the direction in which the party will focus its efforts, though he said such cooperation will also depend on reforms within the KMT and on the development of the PFP.

Chang, a famous heart surgeon and the president of a medical school before being invited to be Soong's running mate, said that "there are gains and losses in life," noting that he learned a lot during the campaign and made a lot of new friends.
He said his horizons have been broadened by learning more about some of the nation's problems at the grass-roots level and about the development gap between the southern and northern parts of Taiwan.

But the newcomer to politics said the fervor generated during the election should be channeled into broader actions of concern for the general public, such as the formation of roving medical missions and volunteer groups, which he said he is considering contributing to within the party.

DOC.HEADLINE: SAO TOME AND PRINCIPE AMBASSADOR PRESENTS CREDENTIALS

TEXT.P: Ovidio Manuel Barbosa Pequeno, the new Sao Tome and Principe ambassador to the Republic of China, presented his credentials to President Lee Teng-hui on Friday.

Ambassador Pequeno, accompanied by John Feng, director general of the Department of Protocol of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), presented his credentials to President Lee. Witnessing the solemn ceremony at the Presidential Office included the Secretary-General of the Presidential Office Ding Mou-shih and Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen.

President Lee, in welcoming the ambassador from the western African nation to his new post, said that after the establishment of diplomatic relations in May 1997, the two countries have become closer with many cooperation projects now under way.
The president expressed the hope that the ambassador will get into close contact with the MOFA in order to keep tabs on the bilateral cooperation projects.

Ambassador Pequeno, 46, served as an international radio broadcaster (editor) at Voice of America in Washington D.C. over the past decade before coming to Taiwan early this year to assume his new post.
The ambassador said he was honored to be chosen to serve in the position and conveyed Sao Tome and Principe President Miguel Trowoada's greetings to President Lee.
Pegueno also said that he appreciated the assistance provided by the MOFA after his arrival and pledged that he would do his utmost to promote relations between his country and the ROC.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK MARKET PLUNGES FURTHER

TEXT.P: Share prices continued plunging on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, shedding 287.99 points to close at 9,374.61.
Affected by continued heavy NASDAQ index losses, the local bourse opened lower at 9,517.45 and fluctuated between 9,662.12 and 9,374.61 during the highly volatile trading session.

A total of 3.12 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$185.43 billion (US$6.1 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 3.48 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$209.65 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 451 to 95, with 55 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electronics issues registering the steepest fall at 3.9 percent, followed by pulp and paper issues at 3.6 percent, electrical stocks at 3.1 percent, cement issues at 2.9 percent and auto stocks at 2.7 percent. In contrast, plastics, chemical and tourist stocks recorded smaller losses.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN TO MAKE OVERSEAS VISITS AFTER STEPPING DOWN FROM OFFICE

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Friday that he is planning to visit many countries, including mainland China, after he leaves office next month.

Lien was responding to KMT Legislator Chen Shei-saint's suggestion that he engage in a peace mission between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and around the world given the fact that Lien is well versed in international affairs.
Chen is one of the KMT legislators that Lien met in recent days to discuss party reforms in the wake of the KMT's humiliating defeat in the March 18 presidential election.

Lien also criticized some of the policies proposed by the Democratic Progressive Party, whose candidate Chen Shui-bian won the presidential election, as "not feasible," saying that a lot of problems will ensue.
But Lien urged the KMT legislators to play the role of a real opposition party and not be in too much of a hurry to lash out at the DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: 3-YR-OLD CHINESE BOY WINS HIGH COURT APPEAL TO STAY IN AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: A three-year-old Chinese boy has won a high court appeal to remain in Australia under the classification of refugee because it was ruled that he and his parents would face persecution if they were sent back to China as a result of the mainland's one-child policy.
The Australian on Friday reported Chen Shi-hai, also known as Martin Chen, was entitled to refugee status, the Australian High Court ruled on Thursday.

Chen's parents, who have been detained at Port Hedland in western Australia, had attempted several appeals through legal process, but failed to win refugee status for their child until the High Court overruled previous rulings, the daily reported.

The latest ruling, the first of its kind for detained illegal immigrants from mainland China, will not only allow Martin to stay in Australia, but also his parents and older brother, ending the years-old legal fight, the daily reported.

The Chens were not allowed to marry in 1989 when they were in China, so they took the chance of taking their eldest son illegally to Australia aboard a boat in 1994. They were arrested at the time and have been held in detention ever since. Martin was born in the detention center two years later.
Under the one-child policy, the Chens and their two sons would face persecution if they were deported to the mainland.
In the unanimous ruling, the five High Court judges stressed the innocence and powerlessness of children born in breach of China's population policy.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS `COCKTAILS' PIONEER PURSUING VACCINE STRATEGY

TEXT.P: Dr. David Ho, a leading AIDS researcher in the United States, said Friday in Taipei that he is working on a vaccine strategy in the hopes that a cheaper and more convenient method of combating AIDS will soon be available.

Ho, who pioneered the use of "cocktails" treatment to combat HIV and provided the first glimmers of hope to people with AIDS for better and longer lives, said he is working in pursuit of a vaccine against AIDS.

While the "cocktails" treatment is only a meaningful option in developed countries where patients and governments can afford it, Ho said AIDS vaccines, if proven viable, will effectively stem the spread of AIDS in developing countries.
It is hoped that clinical studies of the AIDC vaccine will begin next year in mainland China, Ho noted.

Ho, who was born in the central Taiwanese city of Taichung and moved to Los Angeles with his family in 1965 at the age of 12, was named by Time Magazine as its "Man of the Year" in 1996 for "helping lift a death sentence on tens of thousands of AIDS sufferers, and for pioneering the treatment that might lead to a cure."

The "cocktails" treatment has actually proven to be effective for a large number of AIDS patients over the last four years. According to Ho, more than two-thirds of the patients who have received "cocktails" treatments have seen their symptoms controlled, allowing them to lead better and longer lives.
Ho arrived in Taipei Thursday to take part in a series of activities in Taiwan aimed at promoting public awareness of AIDS and efforts to help AIDS patients and their families.

Ho made his vaccine strategy known at a press conference hosted by the Department of Health (DOH) on Friday. Once the vaccines are proven applicable to humans, they are expected to help stem the deadly disease in Taiwan as well, he added.

Also present at the press conference was renowned Chinese writer Pai Shien-yung, who has made the United States his home for more than 20 years. Pai, who has never been married, is known for his many novels, including one about gays which is believed to be based on his own life story.
Local rock singer and song writer Chi Chin vowed at the press conference to be a lifetime AIDS prevention volunteer in Taiwan.

Addressing the press conference, DOH Deputy Director-general Chang Hung-jen said that although the AIDS occurrence in Taiwan is a relatively low ratio of 100,000:2.5, one of the lowest in the world, Taiwan's youths are considered increasingly vulnerable to the killer disease as their attitude toward sex is less conservative than the older generations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDC COOPERATING WITH SIKORSKY, AIRBUS

TEXT.P: Taiwan's state-run Aerospace Industrial Development Corp. (AIDC) is expanding cooperation with foreign helicopter and aircraft manufacturers in the hope of further upgrading its level of production, company sources said on Friday.
After five years of strenuous research and development, AIDC recently saw its fifth S-92 helicopter -- a revised version of Sikorsky's UH-60 helicopter -- roll off the production line.
AIDC began a cooperation deal with US-based Sikorsky in 1996 for research, development and commercial production of S-92 helicopters.

In May 1997, AIDC rolled out the first Taiwan-made S-92, a 20-seat, twin turbo-engine helicopter with a maximum range of 910 km and maximum navigating speed of 287 kph. The model is good for mid-range transportation for both passengers and cargo, and is also recommended for use in rescue operations, exploration for natural resources and for ferrying news workers.

Over the subsequent three years, AIDC produced four more of the helicopters, and it is expected that AIDC will receive contracts from Sikorsky later this year, paving the way for the company to make formal delivery of the S-92 helicopters to Sikorsky beginning in June 2001.
Meanwhile, AIDC signed a memorandum with French aircraft manufacturer Airbus on Thursday in Paris for a mammoth project to produce super jumbo A3XXs.
The A3XX is envisaged as a super jumbo jet capable of carrying 480-650 passengers and suitable for use by Asian airlines.

AIDC became the first Asian company to become involved in the A3XX production project, which calls for an initial budget of 12.2 billion euros, with each aircraft expected to carry a price tag of 200 million euros. Planning of the project is scheduled to begin at the end of 2000.
The AIDC, formerly run by the military and currently owned by the Ministry of Economic Affairs, has so far completed 80 percent of a privatization process.

If all goes smoothly, the company of 4,000 staff members which earned its reputation by producing Taiwan's "Chingkuo," or Indigenous Developed Fighter (IDF), is expected to become fully privatized at the end of this year, the sources said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 14, or the 10th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1470: The Yorkists under Edward IV defeat the Lancastrians under Warwick at the Battle of Barnet in the English War the Roses.
1527: Philip II, king of Spain (1556-1598), of Naples and Sicily (1554-1598) and of Portugal (1580-1598) as Philip I, is born. He sent the Spanish Armada to conquer England in 1588 and met with total defeat and the loss of his fleet.
1629: Christiaan Huygens, the Dutch physicist and astronomer, is born. He discovered Saturn's rings in 1655, pioneered the use of pendulum in clocks in 1657, and formulated Huygens' principle.
1865: US President Abraham Lincoln is failing fast after being shot in the back of the head at point-blank range by actor John Wilkes Booth, a Confederate fanatic, at the Ford Theater in Washington, D.C. He died the next day and was succeeded by Andrew Johnson.
1889: Arnold Toynbee, British historian and author of a 12-volume work entitled "A Study of History," is born.
1903: The typhus vaccine is discovered by Dr. Harry Plotz in New York.
1907: Francis Duvalier, Haitian president and dictator nicknamed "Papa Doc," legendary for his corruption and brutality, is born.
1912: The Titanic strikes an iceberg and sinks in the North Atlantic, killing 1,500 people.
1931: Spain's King Alfonso XIII flees his native country for Rome after a landslide win for Republican parties in the municipal elections. Alcala Zamora becomes president of the provisional government.
1941: Condemning the Soviet-Japanese Neutrality Pact, Foreign Minister Wang Chung-hui of the Republic of China declares that Outer Mongolia and the northeastern provinces are Chinese territory and that the Soviet-Japanese statement is not binding on China.
1945: US bombers pound Japan's Imperial Palace during World War II.
1949: The Taiwan provincial administration announces a decision to carry out the "37.5 Percent Farm Rental Reduction" and the "Land-to-the-Tiller" policies.
1956: USS Saratoga, a US Navy aircraft carrier which joined the fleet in 1927 as the largest warship in the world, is formally decommissioned.
1956: The first videotape is demonstrated in Chicago.
1962: French Prime Minister Michel Debre resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1971: The new Tourism Bureau of the Ministry of Communications is inaugurated in Taipei.
1972: The first satellite observation station in the Republic of China is inaugurated at National Cheng Kung University.
1973: President Nguyen Van Thieu of the Republic of Vietnam leaves Taipei for home after a three-day visit.
1973: Dr. Jesus Soto Amesty, chairman of the Venezuela Senate Foreign Policy Committee, arrives in Taipei for a ten-day visit.
1975: Sikkim abolishes its monarchy and seeks full Indian statehood.
1976: A ROC good-will mission of businessmen leaves for the United States Bicentennial celebrations.
1976: An agricultural mission headed by Chang Hsuinshwen, commissioner of the Department of Agriculture and Forestry of the Taiwan Provincial Government, leaves for a visit to Saudi Arabia.
1976: A total of 3,460 students from 642 middle schools compete in the Taiwan Area Games.
1976: US Senator Robert B. Morgan arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1977: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces severance of diplomatic relations with the Hashemite Kingdom of Jordan.
1982: Armed bandit Lee Shih-khe robs the Land Bank of Taiwan's Kuting Branch in Taipei City of more than NT$5 million, a major criminal case at that time.
1986: Simone de Beauvoir, the French feminist writer and philosopher, dies in a Paris hospital at the age of 78.
1988: The Soviet Union ends its intervention in Afghanistan and allows its troops to withdraw.
1989: After nationalist demonstrations, the Communist Party chief and prime minister of Soviet Georgia are replaced in a purge of the Republic's leadership.
1993: On International Women's Day, a Chinese newspaper asks 100 women what they would most like to be. Sixty say that they want to be men.
1994: Two US F-15 fighters shoot down two American helicopters over northern Iraq killing 26 people.
1995: The United Nations Security Council votes to ease sanctions on Iraq, giving it easier terms in trading oil for food.
1999: Pakistan test-fires a 2,000-km range ballistic missile.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "To be poor without complaining is not easy; but it is easy to be rich without being proud."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.072 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 30.460.
The local currency opened Friday at 30.449 and was traded between 30.407 and 30.477.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$582 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATORS URGE BEIJING NOT TO BULLY TAIWAN BUSINESSMEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China legislators called on Friday for the Beijing authorities not to intervene in the island's affairs by bullying mainland China-based Taiwan businessmen.

The lawmakers were referring to a warning made by Beijing over the weekend that it will not permit Taiwan businessmen to pursue economic benefits in mainland China while at the same time supporting the Taiwan independence movement at home.

Tsao Er-chung, a Kuomintang lawmaker, said during a legislative forum on national affairs that the current cross-Taiwan Strait situation is worse than that of 1996, when a missile crisis emerged between the two sides. The island, noted Tsao, is now facing an imminent threat of war.

Tsao said he is very much concerned about the island's future, especially as President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) warned the nation the other day not to expect any breakthrough in cross-strait relations resulting from his inauguration speech on May 20.
Chen's inaugural speech is widely expected to outline the new government's relations with Beijing and set the tone for cross-strait relations during his four-year tenure.
Tsao urged Chen to support the concept of "one China, with different interpretations as to its meaning."

Meanwhile, Hong Hsin-jung, a KMT legislator from Changhua County, called for the Beijing authorities not to intervene in the internal affairs of the island as long as Taiwan does not declare independence.
If mainland China would like to have closer relations with Taiwan, he said, the Beijing authorities should pursue its goal through exchanges of trade, culture and education with the island.
Lai Shi-bao, a New Party legislator from Taipei City, remarked that it is regrettable that some Taiwan businessmen have been penalized by Beijing for exercising their political rights.
He was referring to the fact that a number of local business tycoons reportedly have seen their planned mainland trips or projects delayed at the request of the Beijing authorities.

Furthermore, continued Lai, in view of the fact that the newly appointed head of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council, Taipei's chief policy-making body on cross-strait issues, is actually a drafter of President Lee Teng-hui's "two states theory," he is deeply worried about the future of Taiwan businessmen in mainland China.

Since there are more than 40,000 Taiwan tradespeople doing business in the mainland, it is urgent that officials of the ROC government, whether they are outgoing or members of the incoming administration, should do their best to safeguard the interests of these businessmen, Lai concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PROFITS OF FOREIGN INVESTORS IN TAIEX TOPS IN ASIAN REGION

TEXT.P: Total earnings of foreign investors in the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) topped the list of foreign investors in the Asian region markets, a Central Bank of China (CBC) official said on Friday.
Foreign investments in the stock market as a whole enjoyed a return of 17.68 percent during the period between the end of 1999 and April 13, the official said.
The total earnings comprise profits from both stock investments and foreign exchange dealings.
This indicates that TAIEX investment has enjoyed the highest return in Asia, which will help lure more foreign investors to invest in Taiwan, according to CBC Governor Perng Hei-nan.

The TAIEX was followed by Malaysia's stock exchange, with 14.78 percent, with Japan in third place with 5.1 percent. Hong Kong came next, posting a 3.78 percent negative income, followed by Thailand with minus 14.99 percent, South Korea with minus 15.96 percent, Singapore with minus 16.34 percent, the Philippines with minus 21.9 percent and Indonesia with minus 24.9 percent.

In terms of foreign exchange rates, the new Taiwan dollar appreciated 3.31 percent during the same period, followed by the Korean won and the Malaysian ringgit at 2.62 each, while the Hong Kong dollar depreciated 0.18 percent, followed by the Thai baht at 0.99 percent, the Philippine peso at 2.07 percent, the Singapore dollar at 2.79 percent, the Japanese yen at 3.3 percent and the Indonesian rupiah at 8.32 percent.

In terms of stock weighted indices, Malaysia topped the list with a rise of 14.78 percent, followed by Taiwan at 14.37 percent and Japan at 8.41 percent. Hong Kong was down 3.59 percent, Singapore dropped 13.37 percent, Thailand fell 14 percent, Indonesia was down 16.58 percent, South Korea dropped 18.58 percent and the Philippines fell 19.46 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: INAUGURAL SPEECH NOT TO COMMENT ON `ONE-CHINA' PRINCIPLE: CHEN

TEXT.P: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui bian said on Friday that his inaugural speech on May 20 will not formally comment on Beijing's "one China" principle, as he must first wait until Taiwan reaches consensus on the issue.

Chen made the remarks during a visit to the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) under the Executive Yuan in the company of Vice President-elect Annette Lu, where they were briefed on the current cross-Taiwan Strait situation.

Chen pointed out that big differences on the so-called "one China" issue still exist between the government and opposition, and noted that a non-partisan ad hoc committee led by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan Tseh has not yet touched on the issue.

He went on to say that one speech would not be able to resolve all the disputes which have occurred across the Taiwan Strait in the past 12 years, and added that he will not create more trouble with his inaugural speech.

Instead, he continued, his speech will show to the Beijing authorities that his government is ready to try its best to alleviate cross-strait tension and contradiction with sincerity and goodwill, so as to improve cross strait relations.

DOC.HEADLINE: EP PASSES RESOLUTION TO BACK TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 13 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The European Parliament (EP) passed a resolution on Thursday urging the 15-nation European Union (EU) to further boost ties with Taiwan.

Most of the 626 EP members attending a session in Strasbourg voted in favor of the resolution that calls on EU member-states and the European Commission (EC) to strengthen relations with Taiwan in order to help the island play a greater role in international organizations, including the World Trade Organization.

The EP resolution also urges the EC, the EP's executive arm, to set up a representative office in Taipei, and also welcomes the result of Taiwan's March 18 presidential election, which it describes as additional proof of Taiwan's transformation into a full democracy.

Touching on the issue of Taiwan-mainland China relations, the EP resolution voices its firm opposition to "any military intimidation," and appealed to the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to avoid military conflict by holding dialogue to resolve their problems.
It also voices the EP's agreement with Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian's proposal to open direct trade and transport links with mainland China.

The resolution marks the first time that the EP has demonstrated its backing for Taiwan, and illustrates its grave concern over the situation across the Taiwan Strait following the island's presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Friday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for April shed 402 points to close at 9,318, with 1,467 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May decreased 370 points to finish at 9,430; June futures plunged 314 points to finish at 9,516; September futures dropped 330 points to close at 9,820; and December futures lost 60 points to close at 10,390.
Contract transactions for May, June, September, and December futures were 1,010, 56, three and one, respectively.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were 9,720 points for April; 9,800 for May; 9,830 for June; 10,150 for September; and 10,450 for December.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also registered heavy losses.

April TE futures moved down 26.3 points to close at 497.5, with 869 contract transactions, while May TE futures lost 26.7 points to finish at 503.3, with 361 contract transaction, and June TE futures declined 17 points to close at 518, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

April TF futures fell 19 points to close at 982, with 173 contract transactions; while May TF futures dropped 14.8 points to finish at 1,000, with 72 contract transactions. June TF futures edged up one point to close at 1,008, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER-DESIGNATE VOWS TO WIPE OUT `BLACK GOLD'

TEXT.P: Justice Minister-designate Chen Ting-nan pledged on Friday that he will do his utmost to eradicate official corruption and "black gold" politics after he assumes office.

Chen, an incumbent legislator from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), made the vow at a news conference held after he formally accepted Premier-designate Tang Fei's invitation to join his Cabinet as justice minister.

Chen, who was known for his integrity and no-nonsense working style during his eight-year stint as Ilan County magistrate in the 1980s, said he takes it as a great honor to join the new Cabinet and help establish clean politics in Taiwan.

He said he will make it his top priority to root out the "handful" of government officials who have links with organized crime, in order to wipe out "black gold" politics -- connections between the government and underworld criminal rings.

"Cutting off any connection between the government and organized crime will be my top goal after assuming office," Chen said, adding that he will pool the wisdom and resources from various quarters to eliminate official corruption and "black gold" politics in order to rebuild public confidence in the government.

He said he will handle issues related to central-level elected representatives with links to organized crime strictly in accordance with the law. "I'll neither hesitate nor show any undue lenience in dealing with issues related to legislators with links to organized crime," he stressed.

Chen said all Taiwan's political parties should learn from the DPP's experience in nominating candidates for parliamentary elections. Noting that the DPP has an "anti-organized crime provision" in its nomination regulations, Chen said the DPP has never nominated a hopeful with links to organized crime to represent the party in any legislative election.
Chen said the country's Election and Recall Law should also adopt such a clause to ban any person with links to criminal rings from taking part in parliamentary elections.
In addition, Chen said he believes that the adoption of a "single seat for a single constituency" election system can also help prevent people with links to organized crime from entering parliament.

Turning to prosecution and criminal investigation issues, Chen said he will solicit opinions from low-echelon law enforcement officers and various social quarters concerning restructuring the way in which criminal investigations and prosecution systems and procedures are carried out.
Chen also gave his assurance that he will accelerate all necessary judicial reforms. "Reform measures will be implemented very quickly," Chen said firmly. "Nobody will be disappointed."
He further said he will continue to push for legislation of various "sunshine bills" and government ethics bills to ensure that Taiwan can enjoy clean and transparent politics.
As for the function of the Investigation Bureau under the Ministry of Justice, Chen said he has no intention of phasing out the bureau.

He was referring to the situation a few years ago during the notorious Pai Hsiao-yen kidnap-murder case, when the bureau and the Criminal Investigation Bureau under the National Police Administration traded accusations and counter-accusations that the two bodies were hampering one another in the resolution of the case, prompting Chen to call for abolishing the Investigation Bureau in his capacity as a legislator.

But now Chen said he will push the bureau to adjust the focus of its work to fighting corruption and drug trafficking, as well as intensifying surveillance and monitoring of spies from mainland China who have infiltrated local society.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT MULLING RECRUITMENT OF MAINLAND HIGH-TECH TALENT

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Friday his administration will study the feasibility of recruiting high-tech experts from mainland China and foreign countries to make up for a shortage of such personnel in Taiwan.
Chen made the statement during a courtesy call on Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh.
Chen said Taiwan needs a large number of trained science and technology personnel to develop the island into a high-tech manufacturing and service center.
Against this background, Chen said the Republic of China must upgrade its basic education level and consider recruiting high-tech talents from foreign countries and even mainland China.

Noting that talent recruitment should not be hindered by national boundary and political ideology, Chen said he hopes the Examination Yuan will help clear legal obstacles to recruiting mainland Chinese high-tech experts who have worked in other countries for a specified period of time.

Turning to the March 18 presidential election, Chen said his election victory signifies the importance of establishing a sound civil service system. Chen's election marks the first peaceful transition of power in Taiwan in more than five decades.

"Transition of power among major political parties is all too common in mature democratic countries," Chen said, adding that so long as civil servants maintain administrative neutrality and avoid involvement in election, they need not worry about change of the head of state.

Meanwhile, Chen said he will push for revisions of current regulations to allow high-ranking civil servants to work at private enterprises for one year or two to "experience" the vitality and competitiveness in the private business sector.
"By so doing, I believe that our civil service system will receive new vitality, new thinking and new vision to improve operational efficiency," Chen noted.

The president-elect also said he is very pleased to learn that Lin Hsin-yi, vice chairman of China Motor Corp., has agreed to serve as economics minister in his administration. "I'm convinced that having a professional manager to head the economics ministry will facilitate economic reforms and upgrading of national competitiveness," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA PREPARING FOR OPENING OF EU OFFICE IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday that it is preparing for the opening of a European Union representative office in Taipei.

Liu Hsiang-pu, director of the MOFA's European Affairs Department, was responding to a resolution adopted recently by the European Parliament, the EU's legislative arm, which calls for closer relations between the Republic of China and the 15-member EU as well as for the opening of an EU representative office in Taiwan.

Liu said the resolution marks an important step forward in ROC-EU relations, adding that the MOFA has ordered the ROC's representative office in Belgium to strengthen contact with the EU headquarters in Brussels.
Liu said the MOFA is planning to set up a special unit to take charge of all EU-related affairs.

Nevertheless, Liu said it remains unclear when the EU will open a representative office in Taipei as the EU is now using most of its budget to help finance reconstruction projects in the war-torn Yugoslav province of Kosovo.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING WELCOMING LIEN TRIP TO M'LAND WITH UNITED FRONT END: SCHOLAR
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 14 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Beijing, April 14 (CNA): A mainland China scholar said on Friday that the united front against Taiwan independent was being shaped as a Beijing high ranking official expressed to welcome Acting Kuomintang Chairman Lien Chan to visit Beijing if he uses a proper status and supports the unification of China.

Legislator Chen Hsueh-sheng(KMT- Taipei City) proposed on Friday Acting KMT Chairman Lien Chan to make a trip for peace to mainland China after he steps down as the vice president of the Republic of China on May 20.
In response, Zhang Ming-ching, director of Press Bureau of the Office of Taiwan Affairs under the State Council, expressed a welcome to Lien's future trip.

The scholar who likely kept his name said that Beijing will try to unite with a force who opposes to Taiwan independent to contain the development of Taiwan independent movement as Beijing is worrying about Taiwan's President elect Chen Shui-bian who may lead Taiwan toward independent.

He recalled that KMT and Communist had experienced various times of cooperations in the past years and he believed that the Communist Party will take the chance of cooperation with KMT so as to arrive at the expansion of Taiwan independent proposed by the Democratic Progressive Party(DPP).

At the same time, the KMT will become an opposition party after President elect Chen Shui-bian's inaugurates on May 20. Lien Chan's visit to Beijing in his capacity of acting KMT chairmanship will not run encounter the principle that no official interchange will be made between accross of Taiwan Strait before the so-called one China principle is resolved, he pointed out.

It was understood that the knotted problem for Lien to visit mainland China will be facused on the timing and contents of the visit. In addition to winning confidence from the people on Taiwan, Lien should demonstrate his goodwill to Beijing and avoid becoming an instrument of Beijing united front trick so as not to further complicate the cross strait issues, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE TO HIT 6.66%: THINK TANK

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's economic growth rate will reach 6.66 percent this year, a local private think tank predicted on Friday.
The Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) said its optimistic forecast was based on the steady growth in global trade and economic development.

The CIER forecast was the highest among all figures predicted by relevant domestic research institutions. The Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics predicted earlier this year that the country's 2000 economic growth rate will be about 6.54 percent, while the Council for Economic Planning and Development has projected the growth rate at 6.5 percent.
In its first-quarter domestic economic performance report, the CIER predicted that the Taiwan economy will grow at an annual rate of 6.05 percent this year.

The CIER said it has decided to upgrade its growth forecast to 6.66 percent mainly because of the country's better-than-expected export performance in recent months as well as continued increase in private consumption and investment.
The institute pointed out that international trade has become the driving force behind Taiwan's economic recovery since the second quarter of last year.
The CIER predicted that Taiwan's annual merchandise and service exports will grow 8.33 percent this year and that its imports will increase by 7.05 percent.

Against this background, the CIER said Taiwan will enjoy an estimated trade surplus of NT$257.5 billion (US$8.47 billion) this year, which the institute said will help boost Taiwan's annual economic growth.
The CIER also forecast that the annual growth rate for private consumption will reach 6.75 percent this year and total domestic investment will hit 9.14 percent.

With booming exports and widening trade surplus, the CIER said, the New Taiwan dollar's exchange rate against the US dollar will rise steadily and that the exchange rate may break the NT$30:US$1 barrier by the end of this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY ELECTION DELAYED

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew approved on Friday a request by the Ministry of the Interior to order the postponement of the scheduled May 6 election of National Assembly (NA) delegates.

The Executive Yuan will inform the Central Election Commission (CEC) to follow its decision, and it is up to the CEC to decide how long the election should be delayed, said Shieh Shen-san, secretary general of the Executive Yuan.

The National Assembly has currently gathered to revise the Constitution with the purpose of doing away with itself. If assembly delegates vote to wipe out the body by April 25, as some members have vowed to do, then the election will be canceled, said Shieh.

Chen Li-hui, secretary-general of the CEC under the Executive Yuan said on Friday that the commission will meet soon to reschedule the election and discuss how to handle funds deposited by those who have already registered as candidates.
The Ministry of the Interior recommended on Friday that the Executive Yuan order the postponement after being urged by the National Assembly to do so.

Minister of the Interior Huang Chu-wen, speaking at a press conference earlier on Friday, said that he thought the National Assembly's request is appropriate and necessary, because there is not enough time to call an election before current NA delegates' terms expire on May 20.
It is difficult for some of the National Assembly delegates who intended to run for re-election to juggle their schedules between their ongoing NA duties and extra electioneering, he added.
Furthermore, preparations for the election would be in vain if the current National Assembly abolishes the body before April 25.
Fresh from the March 18 presidential election, the island could not have another general election without further exciting the public's already heated emotions, said Huang.

Most of the 334 NA delegates were relieved Friday to learn that the election has been postponed, especially those who intended to run for re-election. The decision spares them the trouble of attending the NA session in Taipei while campaigning in their home constituencies.
But Sun Ta-chien, a spokesman for the newly founded People First Party, criticized the postponement as "an ill-thought decision and a reckless move."

The National Assembly election was originally scheduled for March 18, but delegates voted on September 4, 1999 to extend their own terms by nearly two years, to June 2001. Much to their embarrassment, this decision caused a public uproar, and was overruled by the Grand Justices Council on March 24.

The assembly's former speaker, Su Nan-cheng, a non-elected NA member, had been stripped of his KMT party membership and lost his NA seat because of his role in steering the extension bill through the NA floor.
The CEC had put the election back on track after the Grand Justices Council's ruling. The vote had been slated for May 6.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA URGED NOT TO PRESSURE TAIWAN BIZMEN

TEXT.P: Lawmakers with Taiwan's leading political parties on Friday urged mainland China not to use pressure on Taiwan investors there as a way to interfere in Taiwan affairs.

Relations between Taiwan and mainland China are at the point where the sides must choose between making war or peace, a situation even more dangerous than the 1996 missile crisis, said Kuomintang Legislator Tsao Erh-chung. He also urged the public to pay great heed to President-elect Chen Shui-bian's inaugural speech on May 20.

As Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party has called on the public not to have overly high expectations about his inaugural speech when touching on the cross-Taiwan Strait issue, Tsao said Taiwan must not abandon the "one China" principle.
"For the sake of our own security, we must support the 'one China principle' under which each side is allowed to have its own interpretation," Tsao stressed.

Pointing out that Chen has noticeably interfered in the formation of the new cabinet's lineup by selecting pro-independence figures to serve as foreign affairs minister, Mainland Affairs Council chief and vice national defense minister, KMT lawmaker Wang Tein-ging suggested that Premier-designate Tang Fei should now refuse the post.

Since Tang evidently does not have much power in the new cabinet's personnel arrangements, Tang, as a staunch anti-independence figure, should not remain a part of a government that is seeking independence, commented Wang.

However, another KMT lawmaker, Hung Hsing-lung, called on the Beijing leadership not try to involve itself in Taiwan affairs by meddling in the mainland operations of Taiwan businesses, which he said is a reflection of Beijing's hegemonic mindset and goes against mainstream opinion in Taiwan.

It was Beijing's verbal attacks that helped Chen garner the most votes in Taiwan's March 18 presidential poll, Hung said, asserting that mainland China should instead seek to build closer relations with Taiwan through bilateral cultural and economic exchanges.
Lai Shih-pao, a lawmaker with the pro-unification New Party, described Beijing's attempts to impose its ideology on mainland-based Taiwan businessmen a "reversal of world trends."

Blaming the current KMT government led by Premier Vincent Siew for failing to take measures to secure the future of the more than 40,000 Taiwan firms in the mainland, Lai said Siew's administration and the incoming cabinet should join forces to work out ways to help improve the situation of Taiwan businessmen there.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHENG KUNG UNIVERSITY GRADUATES MOST WELCOMED BY BUSINESS CIRCLE

TEXT.P: Graduates of National Cheng Kung University are most welcomed in domestic business circles, according to the results of a survey released on Friday by the Cheers quarterly of Commonwealth magazine.
This is the fourth consecutive year that National Cheng Kung University graduates top the list of the domestic business circle's favorite college graduates.

National Taiwan University graduates are the second most sought after, followed by National Tsinghua University, National Chiao Tung University, National Chungshing University, Tamkang University, National Chengchi University, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, Feng Chia University and Soochow University, the survey showed.

National Cheng Kung University kept its ranking because of its generally sound performance in various factors, including professional capability, working attitude, learning ability, working stability, and respect for work, the survey revealed.

Graduates of National Taiwan University and National Tsinghua University are highly regarded for their working capability, while graduates of Feng Chia University and Tamkang University scored high marks for their working attitude, according to the survey.

In the field of business management, the survey found that master's degree graduates from National Chengchi University's College of Commerce are most favored, followed by National Taiwan University, National Cheng Kung University, National Chiao Tung University, National Sun Yat-sen University, National Chungshing University, National Central University, Soochow University, Tunghai University and National Chung Cheng University.

For engineering, master's degree graduates of National Chiao Tung University's College of Engineering are most highly favored, followed by National Tsinghua University, National Cheng Kung University, National Taiwan University, National Taiwan University of Science and Technology, National Taipei University of Technology, National Central University, National Sun Yat-sen University, National Chung Cheng University and Tatung University, the survey indicated.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'DO WHAT YOU CAN,' SAID FOREIGN MINISTER-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: What is pragmatic diplomacy? That is "doing what you can," according to Tien Hung-mao, the foreign minister-designate, on Friday.

In his first meeting with the press after being selected as foreign minister in the incoming administration of President-elect Chen Shui-bian, Tien played down expectations for radical changes in the island's diplomacy. Continuity in the country's diplomacy will be maintained, he said, and he will outline his agenda after he consults with outgoing foreign minister Chen Chien-jen.

The US-educated doctor of political science dismissed as "incorrect" a story by Reuters on Thursday wherein he is quoted as saying that Taiwan would review its bid to rejoin the United Nations. He stressed that continuity is the essence of diplomacy, and adjustments in the island's UN bid, if any, will be done by the new government through that normal process of policy formation.
Noting that it is too early to announce any new diplomatic policy, Tien said he would in the future be more gaurded when making comments, to avoid being misquoted by the press.
However, he said he will continue the pragmatic diplomacy, which he characterized as "doing what you can and not indulging in dreams about that which is beyond your reach."

Asked about whether ties with Beijing should take precedence over the island's diplomacy, Tien said it is not a question of mathematics and there is no simple answer. But he said he would work on both.

Tien has served as national policy adviser to the president, adviser to the Executive Yuan, and adviser to the National Unification Council before taking a position at a private think tank, the Institute for National Policy Research. He has remained on that job until now.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 15, or the 11th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1865: Andrew Johnson is sworn in as the 17th president of the United States following the assassination of Abraham Lincoln.
1912: The British luxury liner the Titanic sinks after hitting an iceberg during her maiden voyage to New York. More than 1,500 people are feared drowned in the icy waters of the North Atlantic.
1923: Insulin is made available for general use by diabetics when Canadian physiologist Sir Frederick Grant Banting shares a 1923 Nobel Prize for the discovery of insulin.
1927: Chiang Kai-shek, Commander-in-chief of the National Revolutionary Forces, organizes the Republic of China government in Nanjing.
1942: Japanese artillery blasts US position on Corregidor in the Philippines.
1945: Looted Nazi art treasures, including paintings by Rubens, Goya, Raphael, and Leonardo da Vinci, are found in an Austrian mine shaft.
1949: The Chinese communists demand ROC government acceptance of their eight-point proposal by April 20, following talks which began in Beijing on April 5.
1952: US President Harry S. Truman signs peace treaty between the United States and Japan.
1955: The first McDonald's hamburger store opens in San Bernardino, California.
1958: The first meeting of African independent nations is held in Accra, Ghana.
1959: US Secretary of State John Dulles resigns due to illness. The American diplomat and politician pursued a policy of opposition to the USSR largely through military and economic aid to American allies.
1966: A team of American virologists develop a vaccine for German measles, known medically as rubella.
1971: President Joseph Desire Mobutu of Congo and his wife arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1971: London and Beijing agree to the reopening of a telephone link between London and Shanghai which had been closed for 22 years.
1975: Praising the late ROC President Chiang Kai-shek as "an old friend and a great leader," Vice President Nelson A. Rockefeller of the United States arrives in Taipei to attend the National Memorial Services for the generalissimo.
1975: ROC Premier Chiang Ching-kuo reveals President Chiang's last written instruction to him. The late leader told his eldest son to assume full responsibility for the fate of the nation without regard to his personal fate.
1976: India and communist China resume diplomatic relations.
1976: Dr. Alfredo Lamaison, a member of the State Council of Uruguay, and Arg Gustave Nicolich, president of National University, arrive in Taipei for a nine-day visit.
1980: Jean-Paul Sartre, the French writer and philosopher who declined the 1957 Nobel Prize for literature, dies in Paris at the age of 74. A leading existentialist, he wrote literary works such as the autobiographical novel "Nausea" and the play "No Exit," as well as philosophical volumes that include "Being and Nothingness."
1988: President Kim Il Sung receives 43,000 gifts as he celebrates his 76th birthday in style. The North Korean dictator died in 1994.
1989: Hu Yaobang, former general secretary of China's Communist Party, dies of a heart attack in Beijing at the age of 73. A democracy movement is launched by Beijing University students following his death.
1989: Ninety-five soccer fans are crushed to death and 200 injured at Sheffield's Hillsborough Stadium in Britain's worst-ever sports disaster.
1990: Greta Garbo, the Swedish-born American actress known for her reclusiveness and her performances in such films as "Queen Christina" in 1933 and "Camille" in 1937, dies in New York at the age of 84.
1994: The Uruguay Round of talks on General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) concludes with ministers from more than 100 of the world's trading nations signing the GATT pact, the biggest market-opening treaty in history, and with the announcement of the setting up of the World Trade Organization (WTO).
1996: The United States and Japan announce the closure of six more US military facilities on Okinawa.
1997: During the Haj, as 2 million Muslims gather for sacred rituals, a fire sweeps across an encampment outside Mecca, killing at least 300 pilgrims and injuring several thousand others.
1997: The first locally developed Ching Kuo (IDF) tactical combat aircraft wing, a second generation of warplanes of the ROC Air Force, is founded at the Chingchuankang air force base in Taichung.
1998: Pol Pot, former Khmer Rouge leader, dies of a heart attack.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE ECONOMICS MINISTER SEEKING EU SUPPORT FOR TAIWAN'S WTO BID
DOC.DATELINE: Brussels, April 14 (CNA) (By P.C. Tang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu is currently in Brussels seeking the European Union's support for Taiwan's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Lin met with officials from the European Commission, the executive body of the 15-member European Union, on Thursday to exchange views on last-stage consultations concerning Taiwan's WTO accession and to seek their support. Lin, however, declined to say which EC officials he has met or is going to meet.
Before heading to Brussels, Lin visited the WTO headquarters in Geneva to exchange views with relevant WTO officials on the timetable of the 11th working group meeting on Taiwan's WTO accession.
An expert on the WTO and a talented negotiator, Lin is scheduled to depart Belgium for home on Saturday.

Taiwan has completed most of the bilateral consultations with and sealed agreements with key WTO members on its bid to join the organization. The EU represents the major exception, with talks and an agreement still not being finalized.

On Thursday, the European parliament (EP) passed a resolution urging the 15-member EU to further boost ties with Taiwan. Most of the 626 members attending the session in Strasbourg voted in favor of the resolution that calls on EU member states and the European Commission to strengthen relations with Taiwan in order to help the island play a greater role in international organizations, including the WTO.
It is widely believed that Taiwan will enter the major world trade regulatory body before the end of this year, at the same time as mainland China.
Taiwan was granted observer status in 1992 by the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, which was superseded by the WTO in 1995.
