DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI STOCK MARKET PLUMMETS ON WALL STREET MELTDOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's share prices plummeted an average of 5.4 percent on Saturday amid panic selling triggered by Friday's Wall Street meltdown.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index shed 507.81 points to close at 8,866.8, following a 3-percent decline in the previous trading session. Altogether, the index has lost nearly 1,000 points in the past few days.
The local bourse opened weak amid bearish sentiment caused by record point dives on both the New York Stock Exchange and the tech-heavy Nasdaq index on Friday.

Market analysts attributed the Taiex index's drastic fall mainly to sell-off by foreign investors, who have been on the selling side over the past few days and even worked overtime on Saturday to sell more stocks to cope with heavy redemption pressure.

The Taiex opened lower at 9,086.36 points and soon plunged below the 9,000-point psychological barrier. The index hit a low of 8,780.08 at one point but managed to recover some grounds in the last few minutes of trading.

A total of 2.84 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$155.72 billion (US$5.12 billion), down from the previous trading session which saw 3.12 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$185.43 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 554 to 27, with 13 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories lost grounds, with cement issues registering the steepest fall at 6.3 percent, followed by construction stocks at 5.8 percent, textile stocks at 5.7 percent, electrical issues at 5.5 percent, and foodstuff, financial and pulp issues at 5.3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE TAIPEI WINS FOUR MEDALS ON 1ST DAY OF TAEKWONDO CHAMPIONSHIP
DOC.DATELINE: Lyons, April 14 (CNA) (By Tzou Ming-jhic & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Chinese Taipei won one silver and three bronze medals on Friday during the first day of the 2000 World Taekwondo Championship.

Chu Mu-yen won a silver in the men's fin weight division. He dominated the three rounds in the final against France's C. Civiletti, but his French rival, cheered on by the crowd, scored with a kick to Chu's face and won the gold.
Chu was unsatisfied with the referee's judgment, but politely accepted the result.
Meanwhile, Lee Chang-jung won a bronze medal in the men's bantamweight division.
Hung Chia-chun won a bronze medal in the women's flyweight division, while Meng Mei-chun also won one in the women's bantamweight division.

Sung Seng-teng, the coach of the Chinese Taipei team, said afterward that all three of the bronze medalists were capable of winning gold in their own divisions but were given unfavorable scores by the judges.

Chen Wen-fu, the captain of the team, said the championship is a forerunner to the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney. He encouraged his competitors to accumulate international competition experience in order to lay the groundwork for better performances in Sydney.
The 2000 World Taekwondo Championship has brought together about 500 competitors from 29 countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE CONTINUES CABINET APPOINTMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Tang Fei on Saturday continued to make fresh appointments to ministerial-level posts for the new administration which is scheduled to be inaugurated on May 20.

Tang, who was resting at his residence Saturday due to a mild illness, confirmed that former Deputy Taiwan Governor Wu Jung-ming has accepted his offer to become the minister of personnel under the Examination Yuan.

Wu, a key member of the newly-established People First Party, is considered a good choice by Tang based on his previous experience as the secretary-general of the Examination Yuan and also as a minister without portfolio.

Meanwhile, Tang also confirmed that Chen Tin-nan, former Ilan County magistrate and the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) candidate in the last election for governor of Taiwan, has accepted his offer to become the new justice minister.

Other posts that have been filled include the position of head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting, and Statistics by Lin Chuan, a finance professor at National Cheng Chi University, and the post of chairman of the Public Construction Commission by Lin Neng-po, dean of National Taiwan University's management school.

Meanwhile, Hsu Cheng-kuang, director of the Institute of Ethnology under Academia Sinica, will be the new chairman of the Mongolian & Tibetan Affairs Commission, and Lin Chia-cheng, former deputy mayor of Taipei, will be chairman of the Research, Development and Evaluation Commission, said Tang.

Tang, who is scheduled to check into hospital Sunday for treatment of a benign thymoma in his chest, said other people have also been offered appointments, including Tseng Chih-lang, president of National Yang Ming University, who has been offered the post of education minister. Tseng, however, is unlikely to accept the appointment because of strong voices of opposition from within his school.

Kaohsiung County Magistrate Yu Cheng-hsien, meanwhile, has been offered the position of head of the National Sports Council but has said he will need more time to think about it. Yeh Chu-lan, a DPP legislator, has been offered the post of minister of transportation and communications. Yeh said there are still some personal factors she needs to consider before she makes her final decision.
Tang said he is still contacting people regarding the post of interior minister, which Chang Po-ya, the independent mayor of Chiayi City, evidently turned down on Friday.

Hao Lung-ping, convenor of the New Party's National Election Campaigning and Development Committee, also turned down an offer by Tang to be the top official of the Environmental Protection Administration (EPA)

Hao, the son of former Premier Hao Pei-tsun, a legislator, and a holder of a doctorate in nutritional sciences, said he appreciates Tang's offer, particularly after having strongly challenged and questioned Tang on defense issues during legislative sessions in the past.

Hao said his post as the convenor of the New Party's major committee does not allow him to leave the party, particularly at a crucial time when the National Assembly is having a new round of elections of its deputies.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES TUMBLE ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported drastic falls on Saturday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for April shed 618 points to close at 8,700, with 2,118 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for May plunged 620 points to finish at 8,810; June futures lost 628 points to finish at 8,888; September futures dived 682 points to close at 9,066; and December futures plummeted 726 points to close at 9,664.
Contract transactions for May, June, September, and December futures were 1,827, 118, nine and one, respectively.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were 9,318 points for April; 9,430 for May; 9,516 for June; 9,748 for September; and 10,390 for December.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial stocks, also registered heavy losses.

April TE futures moved down 31 points to close at 466.5, with 958 contract transactions, while May TE futures lost 32.8 points to finish at 470.5, with 558 contract transaction, and June TE futures declined 36.25 points to close at 481.75 with 24 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

April TF futures fell 15.4 points to close at 966.6, with three contract transactions; while May TF futures dropped 70 points to finish at 930, with 153 contract transactions. June TF futures shed 53 point to close at 955, with seven contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: WEATHER BUREAU ISSUES MONSOON RAIN ALERT

TEXT.P: The Central Weather Bureau on Saturday continued to issue warnings that the heavy rains Taiwan is experiencing may trigger devastating floods and landslides in the northern and central parts of the island.

Weathermen said the thunderous monsoon rains that slammed into Hong Kong on Friday morning, overturning motorbikes, swamping cars, and driving residents from flooded homes, reached Taiwan in the small hours of Saturday morning.
The monsoon rains, brought by a cold front from northern China, forced Hong Kong schools to close and six flights to reroute to Taiwan on Friday.
By Saturday morning, weathermen said, 55 mm of rainfall had been recorded on Yangmingshan north of Taipei city and 17 mm of rainfall had been recorded in the central Taiwanese township of Wuchi.

Although the torrential rains are expected to subside beginning Sunday, weathermen have still urged residents in central Taiwan, particularly in mountainous areas, to stay alert against possible mudslides and landslides caused by the heavy rains.

The heavy rains over the last day were accompanied by strong winds, weathermen said, adding that vessels operating off Taiwan's north and northeastern coasts and in the northern section of the Taiwan Strait, as well as in the Bashih Channel, should be particularly careful.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.03 against the US dollar on the Taipei foreign exchange market Saturday to close at 30.49.

Market analysts said the NT dollar's fall was sparked by panic selling on the Taiwan Stock Exchange caused by Friday's Wall Street meltdown. They pointed out that if the local stock market continues its downward streak, the NT dollar will face heavy pressure of depreciation.

The local currency opened lower at 30.456 Saturday and was traded between 30.445 and 30.5 throughout the whole session. Interbank greenback trading shrank to US$204 million from Friday's US$582 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: LU URGES WORLD LEADERS TO ADOPT 'PREVENTIVE DIPLOMACY'

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Annette Lu on Saturday expressed the hope that world leaders will adopt a "preventive diplomacy" to forestall any possible "irrational" moves by mainland China after the inauguration of the new ROC government.
Lu also urged United States President Bill Clinton to consider inviting leaders from both sides of the Taiwan Strait to meet in Washington D. C. for a dialogue.

Lu said that world leaders who have expressed concern about security in Taiwan Strait should "waste no time" in dealing with the issue of cross-strait relations before Beijing attempts any irrational moves because it is not satisfied with President-elect Chen Shui-bian's inaugural speech on May 20.
Chen said on Friday that his inaugural speech will not touch on the "one China" principle espoused by Beijing because he must first seek domestic consensus on the issue.

Chen also said the speech won't solve all the disputes that have developed across the Taiwan Strait over the last dozen years, although he did add that he will express to Beijing his government's intention of doing its utmost to ease cross-strait tensions.
Because of the recent unfriendly remarks coming from the mainland, Lu expressed the hope that world leaders will swiftly adopt a "preventive diplomacy" on the issue of cross-strait relations.
Lu also said that Beijing's remarks have not only been directed against her, but the "people of Taiwan," and she urged Taiwanese citizens to show unity behind the new government.

Before Taiwan's presidential election, Beijing issued a white-paper policy saying that it will use force against Taiwan if it puts off reunification negotiations indefinitely. It also sternly warned the people of Taiwan against voting for any pro-independence candidates, indirectly referring to the Democratic Progressive Party's ticket of Chen and Lu.
After the election, Beijing also lashed out at Lu, calling her a "lunatic," traitor, and the "scum" of the Chinese nation for her remarks stressing Taiwan's sovereign status.

DOC.HEADLINE: PUTTING TSE ACT NOW ON SENATE AGENDA OPPOSED

TEXT.P: US Senate Democratic leader Thomas Dsachle Friday expressed his opposition to putting the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) on the Senate agenda at the present time.
He was responding to the Senate majority leader, Sen. Trent Lott's decision to put the TSEA on the Senate agenda soon.

Dsachle told reporters that "there are many of us who are very concerned about the implications of the TSEA and are deeply concerned that it could send the wrong message at the wrong time and could have profound consequences, both diplomatically and regionally within Asia."

He added that "I don't know where the votes lie at this point, but I would say that you certainly couldn't predict that the legislation would pass today. I think that there is a good deal of opposition, and it may be growing."
Despite the strong opposition from both the White House and China, the US House of Representatives passed the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act by an overwhelming majority in early February.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUBIN TALKS ABOUT PNTR STATUS FOR CHINA

TEXT.P: US State Department spokesman Jamie Rubin said Friday the US-PRC agreement that helps pave the way for China's World Trade Organization entry is a national security issue and if Congress rejects it, it will be a major setback for relations between the two countries and could have an effect on Taiwan.

While addressing a conference of the US National Newspapers Association in Washington, Rubin pointed out that US-PRC relations are always in a fragile state and "a setback in our relationship could have an effect on Taiwan, where there is a very sensitive situation, where we are trying to walk a very careful line between our support for Taiwan unofficially, while still holding to a policy of `one China.'"

In addition, the spokesman said, "we need China's help on real problems, such as the North Korea problem. The North and South Korean leaders are about to meet in a historic summit in June and it holds the potential to really change dramatically the danger presented by a heavily armed Korean Peninsula."
"So these are concrete foreign policy needs that we think would be harmed and jeopardized severely by a major setback in China relations that would occur if this vote is turned down," added Rubin.

The US Senate is almost certain to pass the legislation that grants China permanent normal trade relations status, but the House of Representatives is still divided on whether to pass similar legislation in a vote scheduled for the week of May 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: BIRDS SHOT AT VANCOUVER AIRPORT FOR FLIGHT SAFETY

TEXT.P: The Vancouver International Airport Authority has had to kill more than 3,000 birds a year to keep them from colliding with aircraft.
Many bird lovers say the authority's program goes too far. In 1999, the airport shot 3,234 birds.

Defending its method of maintaining flight safety, airport authorities said they have shot birds only when necessary and have frightened away close to a million birds using border collies, noisemakers, and bird distress calls.
More than half of the birds killed last year were ducks, while dunlin, starlings, gulls, crows, swallows, Canadian geese, killdeer, owls, pheasants and pigeons were also killed.

DOC.HEADLINE: STUDY FINDS LINK BETWEEN DEMENTIA AND LONELINESS

TEXT.P: Old people without a network of friends and family have a much higher risk of developing dementia, according to a new research study out of Sweden.

The Sydney Morning Herald on Saturday reported that the Swedish study of 1,200 people over the age of 75 over three years showed for the first time a link between social contact and dementia among the elderly. Previously, a link was established between depression and loneliness among old people.

It said a poor or unsatisfying social network increased the risk of dementia by 60 percent. The study was observational, meaning it did not identify any biological mechanisms which might have caused the higher rate of dementia among lonely people.

DOC.HEADLINE: MRT TO BE EXTENDED TO SUNGSHAN AIRPORT

TEXT.P: Taipei's Mucha mass rapid transit line will be extended to Sungshan Airport, and an observation deck will also be built at the airport's terminal, announced Chang Yu-hern, director general of the Civil Aeronautics Administration (CAA), on Saturday.
The CAA chief made the announcement while attending a celebration ceremony to mark the 50th anniversary of Sungshan Airport.

Chang said a total of 17 million passengers made domestic flights in Taiwan last year, with 76 percent of them using Sungshan Airport as their departure or arrival point, showing that the airport provides a valuable service to the public.

Noting that up to 50,000 passengers arrive and depart from Sungshan Airport every day and that about 80 percent use taxies or personal automobiles to get to and from the airport, he said more careful planning will be needed to relieve traffic congestion near the airport.
He said that after lengthy consultations with the Taipei City Government, an extension of the Mucha Line to Sungshan Airport was agreed upon.
Chang stated that the Sungshan stop will be completed in about five or six years time, at which time an underground shopping arcade at the airport will also be opened.

An observation deck will also be built in the west wing of the airport, allowing the public to observe the take off and landing of planes, said Chang, adding that the project is expected to be completed by 2003.

In addition, he said that out of all 17 of the domestic and international airports in Taiwan, only those in Taipei and Kaohsiung, as well as CKS International Airport, make money. In order to increase profitability, he said he will introduce the idea of corporate management to Taiwan's other airports, adding that improvements in the airports' eateries will also be made in this direction.

DOC.HEADLINE: STAFF HOPES NEW MINISTER WILL RID MOTC OF CRONYISM

TEXT.P: Workers at the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) hope Legislator Yeh Chu-lan, their minister-to-be, will boost the staff's morale by disposing of the rampant cronyism in the ministry.

The MOTC staff was surprised by the appointment of Yeh as their head, because the Democratic Progressive Party legislator has had no previous experience in MOTC affairs and has never served as an administrator.

It will likely take some time for the newcomer to become aquatinted with the MOTC's business, especially with the complicated issues involved in aviation, telecommunications, shipping, and road and railway transportation.

Although the MOTC staff have said they don't care who their new head is, some of them have expressed the hope that Yeh will be able to rid the ministry of the cronyism which has dampened the workers' morale.

A MOTC employee who spoke on condition of anonymity blamed the last several MOTC heads for packing the ministry with their associates, especially the outgoing minister Lin Fong-cheng, who brought his confidants from the Ministry of Interior where he served as minister into the MOTC and placed them in senior posts.
As a result, the staff said, most of the senior posts were filled by outsiders to the great disappointment of the MOTC staff.
He said it is the hope of MOTC staff that Yeh will get rid of these practices after she is sworn in on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: AVERAGE WAGES OF TAIWAN WORKERS SIMILAR TO THOSE OF S. KOREA, HK

TEXT.P: The average hourly earnings of Taiwan's production workers is at about the same level as those of Hong Kong and South Korea, but is slightly lower than that of Singapore, government sources said on Saturday.

According to an international survey of production workers' earnings in economies around the world by the Bureau of Labor Statistics of the US Department of Labor, the average hourly wage of workers in South Korea's manufacturing sector stood at US$5.00 in 1998, the lowest figure among the four "Asian dragons," said officials from the Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
The hourly wage of production workers in Taiwan averaged US$5.20, compared with Hong Kong's US$5.50 and Singapore's US$7.80, said CEPD officials, quoting the US Department of Labor figures.
The CEPD officials added that the figures are considerably different if calculated in the respective currencies of the four states instead of US dollars.

When calculated in their own national currencies, the average hourly wages of production workers in South Korea and Hong Kong in 1998 were 1 percent higher than those in 1997, while the average in Taiwan increased 4 percent and the average in Singapore surged 6 percent over the same period.

Meanwhile, the US Department of Labor survey also indicated that Hong Kong had a ratio of 3.2:100 between non-wage earnings and all the labor earnings of production workers, the lowest among the four "Asian dragons." The ratio was 9.1 in Taiwan, 16.9 in Singapore, and 17.5 in South Korea.
The ratio of non-wage earnings and all labor earnings is a gauge of the flexibility of a job market. A higher ratio indicates a lower flexibility of a job market, the officials noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT MEMBER PROPOSES OMITTING 'CHINA' FROM PARTY NAME

TEXT.P: Pai Sheng-san, the honorary Chairman of the Consumers' Foundation of the Republic of China and a senior member of the Kuomintang, suggested on Saturday that his party omit "China" from its name.
In a meeting of the Koumintang's reform committee, Pai moved to rename the Kuomintang, which translates into English as the "China Nationalist Party."

Calling himself a party member of many years, Pai said he found the political trend in Taiwan is away from mainland China, adding that the KMT will isolate itself from mainstream opinion by sticking to its present name.
Although Pai's proposal raised the eyebrows of those attending the meeting, Ou Ching-teh, the deputy mayor of Taipei City who chaired the meeting, called Pai's idea deserving of serious study.

In the two-hour meeting, the reform committee did agree to clean up the party's image by cutting KMT links with business tycoons and gangsters and by delivering on party chairman Lien Chan's promise during the presidential election to set up a trust fund to manage the party's assets and enterprises.

Furthermore, the committee urged the party to aggressively engage in public service for minorities and the disadvantaged within Taiwan's society; to democratize the party's administration; to set up a system where party candidates for public office are chosen through primaries; and to set up a think tank to study public policies.
Ou said at the meeting that KMT should refrain from nominating candidates with links to organized crime or with corrupt backgrounds, even if it means having less seats in the legislature.
Meanwhile, in a symposium organized by the KMT Department of Women's Affairs in Kaohsiung, a party member criticized the KMT for alienated itself from Taiwan's youth.

Lee Chao-rung, an associate professor of finance at I-Shou University in Kaohsiung County, said the aging KMT has lost its attractiveness among the young people of the island and will not be able to rejuvenate itself unless it can attract their support.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN'S MAINLAND VISIT TO CONTRIBUTE TO CROSS-STRAIT TIES: HU

TEXT.P: Outgoing Vice President Lien Chan's planned visit to mainland China, if realized, will have a positive effect on relations across the Taiwan Strait, ruling Kuomintang spokesman Jason Hu said on Saturday.
Lien, who now serves as KMT acting chairman, has expressed his hopes to visit some major foreign countries and mainland China after stepping down from the vice presidency on May 20.

Hu, a former minister of foreign affairs, said he believes that if Lien can realize his mainland travel plan, it will certainly contribute to the Republic of China's national interest and cross-strait rapprochement.

"Given Lien's longtime immersion in cross-strait and diplomatic affairs, I'm convinced that his mainland visit will help boost constructive engagement between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and even the ROC's national development," Hu explained.

KMT sources said several party stalwarts, including Hu, KMT Deputy Secretary-General Shao Yu-ming and Legislators Ting Shou-chung and Chen Shui-saint, are actively promoting Lien's mainland travel plan.
As mainland China is still unwilling to resume dialogue with Taipei, Hu said Lien's mainland travel plan cannot be unilaterally "planned."
Meanwhile, the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said it will be pleased to see Lien make a "journey of peace" to mainland China after his vice presidential tenure ends on May 20.

MAC Vice Chairman Wu An-chia said the MAC has coordinated with other government agencies to set up a mechanism for screening applications by retired high-ranking government officials or political appointees to visit the mainland.

Under current government regulations, Lien will have to file his application with the Ministry of the Interior (MOI). "So long as Lien's mainland travel plan does not involve any major national secret, the MOI's screening panel is unlikely to reject his application," he added.

During a Friday meeting with KMT legislators, Lien said after he steps down from the vice presidency, he plans to first visit some major foreign countries and then make a trip to the mainland where Lien spent his childhood and formative years.

In response to Lien's statement, a Beijing official said Friday evening that if Lien supports unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, he would be welcome to visit the mainland in a "proper capacity."

DOC.HEADLINE: RALLY CALLING FOR ABOLISHMENT OF NATIONAL ASSEMBLY POSTPONED

TEXT.P: A large-scale rally scheduled to be held on Sunday calling for a public drive to abolish the National Assembly (NA) has been postponed, according to a news release issued by an alliance on Saturday.

The Public Alliance to Abolish the National Assembly (PAANA), a body comprised of more than 20 social activity organizations, noted that since the Executive Yuan has decided to postpone the NA elections scheduled for May 6, and since such a development is beneficial to the revision of the constitution, a demonstration calling for the abolishment of the NA is not necessary for the time being.
However, the alliance will keep a close watch on future developments concerning the NA, said a PAANA spokesman.

The majority Kuomintang (KMT) struck a deal earlier with the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and the newly founded People First Party (PFP) to reduce the assembly to an ad hoc body with most of its powers to be taken over by the legislature.
Under the tri-party accord, the NA in the future would only meet to decide constitutional reform plans and presidential impeachment resolutions initiated by the Legislative Yuan.

The government on Friday decided to postpone the elections for NA members, whose tenures expire this May 20. According to reports, Premier Vincent Siew signed a directive to the Central Election Commission to postpone the NA elections as a response to a resolution passed by the NA urging a delay while they handle the constitutional amendments that will decide the future of the body.

Both the KMT and the DPP Assembly caucuses favor constitutional amendments that would drastically weaken the NA and would thus make an immediate election unnecessary. The two parties hold sufficient votes to pass the amendments if members abide by their caucuses' decision. However, some have shown their opposition already.

This being the case, the PAANA urged in its news release that the public continue to pay close attention to upcoming meetings of the NA, which is scheduled to hold an open vote on Sunday to take up the proposed constitutional amendments for their first reading.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL SPORTS GOODS EXHIBITION OPENS

TEXT.P: The 27th Taipei International Sports Goods Exhibition opened at the World Trade Exhibition Hall on Saturday, with 352 sports goods makers participating.
The exhibition is being sponsored by the Taipei-based China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) and supported by two local organizations formed by sports goods makers.

The four-day event is the largest exhibition of its kind in Taiwan, with sports goods makers setting up a total of 1,329 booths to display their products, a 17 percent increase in the number of booths from the previous exhibition.
The focus of this year's exhibition is on high quality products and the application of science and technology.
In addition to sports goods traders, the public is also welcome to buy tickets to visit the exhibition between 1 p.m. and 5 p.m. every day.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN CALLS FOR RESOLVING CROSS-STRAIT DISPUTES WITH WISDOM

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian again sent a goodwill message to mainland China on Saturday, saying the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are like brothers and sisters and share same blood and cultural backgrounds.
"Therefore, our two sides should use wisdom and innovative thinking to resolve our disputes and improve bilateral relations," Chen urged in a speech delivered at a Lions Club meeting.

The lawyer-turned-politician said all people on the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should have confidence in their capability to resolve thorny cross-strait problems and work out a mechanism for constructive consultation and interaction.

Noting that ethnic and partisan disputes will undermine national unity and strength, Chen said national interest should always come above any personal and partisan interests. "We should stand united and forge a national consensus to enhance our bargaining chips vis-a-vis mainland China," he added.
Chen reaffirmed his determination to do his utmost after assuming office on May 20 to push for the establishment of an effective mechanism for constructive cross-strait dialogue and consultation.

Turning to domestic affairs, Chen dismissed as "sheer speculation" press reports that he is at odds with Premier-designate Tang Fei over Cabinet selections and that some members of the just-disbanded "National Affairs Advisory Group" had actively recommended candidates for various Cabinet posts.

"All those reports were unfounded," Chen said categorically, adding that he has never had any difficulty communicating with Tang and that none of the National Affairs Advisory Group members have ever recommended any hopeful for any government post.

Chen lauded Tang, incumbent defense minister, as an open-minded person with democratic thinking. "We respect each other and have consistently exchanged views and discussed issues freely and frankly," he explained, adding that they have had no difficulty working out mutually acceptable options when they were divided by some Cabinet selections.
Chen said many recent press reports concerning Cabinet selections were simply speculation, adding up to confusion and hindrance to finalizing a new Cabinet line-up.
Chen further said the disbanding of the National Affairs Advisory Group didn't involve any behind-the-scenes tricks or maneuvering.
Chen said some Group members will join the new Cabinet and that the remaining others will either be named senior advisers to the President or national policy advisers after he assumes the presidency.

Chen said Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh, also head of the just-disbanded National Affairs Advisory Group, will be the "top senior adviser" to him, adding that Lee will have an office in the Presidential Office after the May 20 presidential inauguration.
According to Chen, Lee will head a cross-party panel to help forge a national consensus on highly sensitive issues concerning the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S POSITION ON FREEDOM OF THE PRESS IN H.K. OPPOSED

TEXT.P: An association of university students in Hong Kong Saturday issued a statement criticizing the remarks made Wednesday by a Beijing official on the responsibility and obligation of the press in Hong Kong.

Wang Fengchao, deputy director of Beijing's Liaison Office in Hong Kong, said Wednesday that the news media of Hong Kong are obliged to support China's position on the issue of unification with Taiwan. The media should not treat speeches advocating Taiwan independence as ordinary news items, he said, adding that Hong Kong news media have the responsibility and obligation to uphold China's unity.

Wang made the remarks after Taiwan's vice president-elect Annette Lu talked about cross-strait relations last week in an interview with a Hong Kong cable TV station. She was called "the scum of the nation" by China's official news media for making "separatist remarks" in the interview.

The statement said that Wang had trampled press freedom in Hong Kong and that, only when freedom of speech and freedom of the press are ensured, can the news media cover news events objectively and fairly. The students also urged Beijing to refrain from attempting to restrict press freedom in Hong Kong.
The statement was delivered Saturday to the Liaison Office by some 20 student representatives of three universities in Hong Kong.
Wang's remarks also caused public outcry earlier this week from news media and political groups in Hong Kong.

DOC.HEADLINE: RUSSIAN RESCUERS CITED BY ROC GOVERNMENT
DOC.DATELINE: Moscow, April 15 (CNA) (By Chang Hung-kuang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Russian rescuers were cited by the Republic of China government on Friday for their rescue efforts after last September's devastating earthquake hit central Taiwan.
A citation plaque, signed by ROC President Lee Teng-hui, extended the government's appreciation for the rescue squad's arrival in Taiwan shortly after the temblor struck.
The citation ceremony was held at the Moscow Garden Hotel and was presided over by ROC Representative to Russia Chang Wen-chung. Members of the rescue squad were given commemorative golden coins.
The leader of the Russian rescue squad asked Chang to forward a five-minute documentary film featuring their rescue operations in Taiwan to President Lee.
He went on to say that following last September's rescue mission, he again recently visited Taiwan to help in the establishment of local emergency rescue groups.
Last September's quake was the worst one to strike Taiwan in nearly a century, killing 2,400 people.

DOC.HEADLINE: PFP RULES OUT PARTY-TO-PARTY EXCHANGES WITH MAINLAND

TEXT.P: People First Party (PFP) Vice Chairman Chang Chao-hsiung said on Saturday that his party will not promote party-to-party exchanges with mainland China.

Chang said in an interview with CNA that as the Republic of China faces many hindrances and obstacles on the diplomatic front, the PFP will actively promote party-to-party engagements with major political parties in the United States, Japan, European countries and even Russia.

"I believe increased contact and exchanges with major political parties in those countries will help expand the ROC's diplomatic frontiers and enhance its presence and visibility in the international community," said the cardiologist-turned-politician who teamed up with independent presidential candidate James Soong to run in the March 18 election.
Nevertheless, Chang said the PFP will not forge any party-to-party exchanges with the mainland as the political system there remains a one-party dictatorship.

Chang went on to say that the PFP, which was established after the Soong-Chang team lost the hotly contested presidential election with a razor-thin margin, would be willing to support President-elect Chen Shui-bian in negotiating with mainland China to safeguard Taiwan's security, dignity and national interests so long as Chen does not promote Taiwan independence.

Chang said Taiwan need not provoke mainland China but should also not be easily daunted by Beijing's saber-rattling, adding that the PFP supports Chen's call for forging a national consensus on the development of relations across the Taiwan Strait.

"We must stand united in dealing with mainland China," Chang said, adding he hopes that Chen's administration will take the initiative to boost cross-strait interaction and break the current cross-strait impasse.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENTIAL OFFICE OPENED TO PUBLIC FOR 21ST TIME

TEXT.P: The Presidential Office on Sunday was opened to the public for the 21st time. It will be the last public opening during President Lee Teng-hui's tenure.

Although more than 420,000 people have visited the Presidential Office, many people living in other parts of Taiwan still rushed into Taipei in charted buses in efforts to grab the last glimpse of Lee's office before he steps down from office on May 20.

Lee's current office is on the fourth floor of the Presidential Building, but President-elect Chen Shui-bian has chosen the office used by the late President Chiang Ching-kuo, on the third floor, to be his office.
Many visitors said they would like to visit the Presidential Office again to see what changes Chen will make after he takes over the post from Lee.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN TO USE 'SOFT' APPROACH IN DEALING WITH CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Sunday invoked the wisdom of a soft and subtle approach advocated by ancient Chinese philosophers in his dealing with thorny cross-strait relations.

In the latest of his conciliatory gestures to the mainland since winning the March 18 presidential election, Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party has used reassuring words to try to assuage misgivings about the his new government.
He said that the soft and subtle approach is "not a sign of weakness, or capitulation," but rather "a determined mind and a higher form of wisdom."
Chen said his defeat in the Taipei mayoral election in late 1997 has taught him to be "humble" and learn to rise up from losing.

He also said a soft approach can "diminish rivalry and bridge distances" and that it also can "help communication and prevent making enemies." He further stated that so long as there is "goodwill and sincerity," he is confident of easing tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Chen said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait share the cultural heritage of such an approach advocated by classic thinkers Lao-tsu (604 B.C. - 531 B.C.) and Chuang-tsu (C 300 B.C.). He advocated using ancient Chinese wisdom to help solve cross-strait issues, rather than one side imposing its will on other.
Chen also reiterated his ideas in forming a government of the people, saying that he has to consider all factors, including party and factions, gender and ethnic groups, in forming the government.
He said he will use "love and patience" in running the government, and he expressed the hope that the public will allow the members of the new Cabinet to show their mettle.
Chen made the remarks when he was speaking to the annual meeting of Multiple District 300 Lions Clubs International members in Taichung, central Taiwan.
Chen vowed that after his inauguration on May 20, he will try to bridge the gap of development between cities and townships, and also speed up the development of Taichung.

He said that he would make good on his campaign promises to upgrade Taichung city to a municipality; to establish an international airport in Taichung, the third one in Taiwan after CKS International Airport and Kaohsiung Airport; and to set up a science-based industrial park in Taichung after similar ones in northern and southern Taiwan.
He also said that the new government attaches great importance to post-quake reconstruction after the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake, which hit central Taiwan severely.

Chen vowed that a minister-without-portfolio in the Executive Yuan will be in charge of the reconstruction efforts and that he would visit the quake-affected areas at least once every month to hear the voice of the people and monitor reconstruction efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 16, or the 12th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1828: Francisco Jose de Goya, Spanish artist whose paintings and etchings reflected the political and social turmoil of his time, dies at the age of 82.
1850: Madame Marie Tussaud, Swiss founder of the famous waxworks museum in London, dies at the age of 89.
1889: Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin, known as "Charlie," film actor and comedian much loved for his portrayal of a tramp in baggy pants and bowler hat, is born in Britain. His productions include "The Kid," "The Gold Rush," and "The Great Dictator."
1912: American pilot Harriet Quimby becomes the first woman to fly the English Channel.
1917: Vladimir Ilyich Lenin returns to Russia after three years of exile in Zurich.
1923: Japanese Crown Prince Hirohito arrives in Keelung for an "inspection" tour of Taiwan, which is under Japanese rule.
1925: In commemoration of Dr. Sun Yat-sen, who died in Peking on March 12, 1925, at the age of 59, the Kwangtung Provincial Government changes the name of Hsiangshan County, the place of birth of Dr. Sun, to Chungshan County.
1941: German troops enter Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, and the main synagogue is destroyed.
1948: The Organization for European Economic Co-operation (OEEC) is established in Paris by Western European nations in accordance with the Marshall Plan.
1960: The Taiwan Provincial Government begins the implementation of labor insurance regulations by establishing the Labor Insurance Bureau.
1972: Yasunari Kawabata, Japanese writer who won the 1968 Nobel Prize for literature, commits suicide at the age of 73. His novels, including "Thousand Cranes," often concern alienated, lonely individuals in search of beauty and purity.
1972: The Apollo 16 mission is launched from Cape Kennedy, Florida, to make the fifth manned moon landing.
1975: The communist Khmer Rouge seize Phnom Penh, capital of Cambodia.
1978: A tornado strikes the eastern state of Orissa in India, killing some 180 people.
1981: The Kaohsiung C.K.S. Cultural Center is inaugurated.
1982: Queen Elizabeth proclaims Canada's new constitution, severing the colonial links with Britain.
1985: The first test tube baby in the Republic of China is born at the Veterans General Hospital in Taipei.
1990: In London, Freed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela publicly thanks the world for its support during his 26-year imprisonment by the South African government.
1998: Khmer Rouge leader Pol Pot is reported dead of a heart attack in his Cambodian jungle stronghold at the age of 73. During his four-year reign of terror some two million Cambodians died.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Men in old times educated themselves for their own sakes. Men now educate themselves to impress others."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN REAFFIRMS 'THREE NOES' TO SHOW GOODWILL IN CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian said that "maintaining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait and safeguarding the interests of Taiwan are the highest goals and moral obligations" for him as a president.
Chen made the remarks in an interview with a Japanese daily, the Sankei Shimbun, which published the interview on Sunday.

Chen reaffirmed the "three noes" policy to show his good will and sincerity in easing cross-strait friction. He said that he would not promote "special state-to-state relations" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, which was vehemently opposed by the mainland after President Lee Teng-hui first broached it in July 1999.
He also said that he will not put the question of Taiwan independence or unification with the mainland to a referendum, and will not change the name of the Republic of China.
To ease troubled cross-strait relations, Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party has sounded conciliatory notes to the mainland since winning the March 18 presidential election.

However, Chen also said that "Taiwan's independent sovereignty is a historical and political fact," and that both sides of the Taiwan Strait should use "one China" as an issue, not as a principle as espoused by the mainland for cross-strait communications and exchanges.
He also urged Beijing not to pin overly high hopes on his inaugural speech on May 20, saying that the cross-strait issue is a complex one which has remained unsolved over the past five decades.
But he said that he will stress "sincerity and goodwill" in the speech, and he hopes that there will be reciprocal response from the other side of the Taiwan Strait.

He said that Beijing has demanded that Taiwan accept the "one China" principle as the cross-strait dialogue, but as both sides have different interpretations of what "one China" means, it will not be possible to accept the principle without first reaching a consensus on the issue among Taiwan's public.

Trying to assuage misgivings of the public, he also said that he will continue to uphold the national flag of the Republic of China, and will not change the content of the national anthem. He said that he is most concerned about "peace in the Taiwan Strait, security of the nation, and how to pursue reforms with stability," and that the national flag and anthem will not even be a question.

On the prospect of ROC-Japan relations, Chen said that he met with the new Premier Yoshiro Mori when he visited Japan last year and that their friendship will continue. Mori was then the secretary-general of the Liberal democratic Party.
Though there are no diplomatic relations between the two nations, he foresees that younger political figures from both nations will have more exchanges and promote bilateral cooperation.
He lauded the outgoing President Lee as the "father of reform," and that he will continue to pursue the reforms pioneered by Lee.
He also said that he would not visit Japan before his inauguration, but he expressed the hope that President Lee will be able to visit Japan after stepping down from office.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT ELECT CHEN TO NAME HO TSUN-MU AS HIS SENIOR ADVISER
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 16 (CNA) (By Mike Chang and Lilian Wu) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taichung, April 16 (CNA President elect Chen Shui-bian called on former Taiwan Provincial Assembly delegate Ho Tsun-mu on Sunday, and said that he will name Ho as his senior adviser.
Ho served as president of the Association of Friends for Chen Shui-bian during the March 18 presidential election.
Chen, accompanied by Taichung Mayor Chang Wen-ying and Legislators Tsai Ming-hsien (DPP-Taichung City) and Wang Hsih-hsun (DPP-Taichung City), visited Ho on Sunday morning.
Later in the day, the president-elect attended the 23rd annual convention of the Taiwan Provincial Chapter of Multiple District 300 Lions Clubs International, held in Taichung City.
Chen expressed his heartfelt thanks to members of the Lions Club for support they extended to him during the March 18 Presidential election.

Chen also spoke highly of efforts and money contributions made by members of the Lions Club for rescue and reconstruction work after the earthquake last year. Central Taiwan was devastated by a killer earthquake that jolted Taiwan on Sept. 21, 1999, claiming more than 2,400 deaths and causing heavy damage to property.

Chen also said that he will keep promises made while campaigning for the March 18 presidential election. These include upgrading the metropolitan Taichung area to a special municipal status during his upcoming four year tenure as president.
Chen will be formally sworn into office on May 20, thus becoming the tenth President of the Republic of China.

During the March 18 presidential election campaign, Chen also promised to build an international airport at Ching Chunag Kan Air Base in central Taiwan. He also promised to build a Science-Technology base industrial park in Taichung

DOC.HEADLINE: SEOUL CONSIDERING SENDING NEW REPRESENTATIVE TO ROC
DOC.DATELINE: Seoul, April 16 (CNA) (By Y. C. Chiang and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Park Doo-Bok is expected to serve as South Korea's new representative to the Republic of China after Presdient-elect Chen Shui-bian's inauguration, sources said on Sunday.

The sources told CNA that Park, 60, a graduate of Kyunghee University in South Korea and a Ph.D. in politics from Taiwan's Chinese Culture University in 1974, is expected to head the Korean Mission in Taiwan, taking over from Yun Hai-Jung.

Park, who has been the director general of the Department of China Studies in Korea's Institute of Foreign Affairs and National Security since 1994, has taught in universities in the United States and wrote several books on mainland China and cross-strait relations.
It is understood that South Korea is now approaching Taipei to obtain its views about the new representative.

DOC.HEADLINE: MORE THAN 10 THAI LABORERS INJURED IN FIGHT

TEXT.P: More than 10 Thai laborers were injured on Sunday as a result of group fighting at a Thai restaurant where they were marking Thailand's National Day, police reported.

Police said that a group of Thai laborers, who work at Formosa Group's Sixth Naphtha cracker plant at Mailiao Township, quarreled with the wife of the restaurant's owner. Another group of Thai laborers employed at Tachiang Industrial Park took the side of the woman, and a fist between the two groups ensued.
Both groups of Thai laborers had gathered at the restaurant to mark National Day of Thailand, police said.
The fight occurred at 2:45 p.m. and resulted in more than 10 injuries, three of which were critical, police said.
Police added that they were still investigating the cause of the fight.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT ASKS CHIAYI MAYOR TO SERVE AS INTERIOR MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, Central Taiwan, April 16 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Sunday repeated his request to Chiayi Mayor Chang Po-ya that she concurrently serve as interior minister and Taiwan governor.
However, Chang did not give an affirmative reply, saying that she will decide whether to accept such an offer after considering her unfinished duties as mayor and the expectations of her countrymen.
Chang, 58, returned to Taiwan from a Japan trip on Friday. During her stay in Japan, Chen and Premier-designate Tang Fei had asked her by telephone to serve as interior minister.
But she told the local media upon her return from Japan on Friday that she had turned down the offer.
In order to persuade Chang to chang her mind, Chen came to Chiayi to visit her on Sunday and asked her to reconsider the offer.
If Chang agrees to accept the offer, she will become the first female Taiwan governor.
A professor-turned-politician, Chang has served as legislator and director general of the Cabinet-level Department of Health.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT POISED TO ENSURE PEACEFUL POWER TRANSITION: GIO HEAD
DOC.DATELINE: Paris, April 15 (CNA) (By M. C. Chou and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang will continue to promote government operations during the current period, although the party is to hand over the helm of the central government to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) next month, ROC Government spokesman Chao Yi said on Saturday.

Chao, a KMT member who serves as the incumbent head of the Government Information Office (GIO), vowed that the KMT-led cabinet will fulfill its obligations as a "care-taker" government during the present period before the DPP's President-elect Chen Shui-bian is inaugurated as the Republic of China's next president on May 20.

The KMT has learned a lesson from its defeat in Taiwan's March 18 presidential race, and will do its best to ensure a smooth power transition in compliance with democratic rules, the GIO head stressed. Taiwan is determined to stick to its democratization goal regardless of the election result, he added.

As the KMT has also played a role in Taiwan's democratization, Chao claimed that it is natural that the party will continue to advocate that path, although it must bow out following a rule of 54 years on the island.

The KMT's top priority at present is to help ensure a smooth transition of power and maintain social order, he emphasized, pointing out that the KMT, for the sake of national interest, is also willing to allow its members to be recruited by the DPP-led new government.
The GIO chief, on behalf of the ROC government, also expressed gratitude to European media for their support of Taiwan during the most difficult times for the country.

Chao made the remarks while answering questions from reporters with major international journals, such as Figaro and Le Monde. He flew into Paris earlier the same day on the first leg of a two-week European tour.
When asked about whether a pro-independence Chen would proclaim Taiwan independence, Chao ruled out such a possibility.

Describing Chen as a mild man and singling out his "new middle way" philosophy to rule the country, Chao asserted that the president-elect will not risk Taiwan's security and added that Chen, who has claimed several times to be President Lee Teng-hui's best successor, will undoubtedly handle Taiwan's relations with mainland China with great care.

Chen, as an idol for Taiwan's younger generations and a symbol of Taiwan's future hope, will not act as a strongman, he noted. According to the GIO chief, Chen will do his best to promote ethnic unity in Taiwan and maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait as a way to meet the high expectations that the vast silent majority have for him.

Although the KMT will soon become an opposition party, Chao forecast that there will ample room for his party and the People First Party (PFP) to cooperate in the future on working toward common goals.
Former Taiwan Governor James Soong, who lost the March 18 presidential poll to Chen of the pro-independence DPP by a slim margin of 2.5 percent, serves as the PFP's chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN PARLIAMENTARIANS ARRIVE FOR WEEKLONG VISIT TO ROC

TEXT.P: A six-member Canadian Parliamentary Delegation, led by M.P. John McKay arrived in Taipei on Sunday for a weeklong visit to the Republic of China.

Other members of the delegation include Ms. Yolande Thibeault (Liberal Party), Hee Clouthier (LP), Larry McCormick (LP), Ms Caroline St. Hilaire (Bloc Quebecois) and Peter Mancini (New Democratic Party).

On hand at the airport to greet them upon arrival were Liu Chih-kung, director of the North American Affairs Department of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs(MOFA), and David Mulroney, director of the Canadian Trade Office in Taipei.

During their weeklong stay, the visitors will call on President-elect Chen Shui-bian, Minister of Foreign Affairs Chen Chien-jen, Vice Chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Lin Chong-pin, Vice Economics Minister Lin Yi-fu and other government officials, as well as members of the Foreign Affairs Committee of the Legislative Yuan.
They will also visit several economic and cultural establishments of the Republic of China.
The group is scheduled to leave Taiwan on April 22.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG'S TUMOR REMOVING OPERATION SMOOTH AND SUCCESSFUL: SURGEON

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Tang Fei's operation to remove a tumor was smooth and successful, the Veterans General Hospital said on Sunday.
"Everything is all right and smooth," said chief surgeon Huang Min-hsiung when he emerged from the operating room at 12:20 p.m.
The incumbent defense minister checked into the hospital on Saturday to undergo a surgery to remove a thymoma tumor, measuring 3cmx3cmx2cm in size.

Tang was diagnosed to have suffered from a thymoma, a chest tumor between the lungs, and also myasthenia gravis, a nerve disease that carries the symptoms of weakness and fatigue of the facial muscles, after a check-up early this month to the hospital.
President-elect Chen Shui-bian visited Tang in the hospital shortly after a trip to Chiayi city, which is in southern Taiwan.
Initial studies indicate that the tumor was benign, and it would take Tang two weeks to recover, the hospital said.
Meanwhile, President-elect Chen went to the Shin Kong Memorial Hospital on Saturday afternoon for treatment of decayed teeth.
Chen and Tang have been busy in the past few days picking ministers for the new Cabinet. Chen will take office on May 20 and the line-up of Tang's Cabinet will be fixed by the end of this month.
Chen had called on Chiayi Mayor Chang Po-ya at noon the same day to persuade her to accept the post as new cabinet's interior minister. Chang has not yet agreed to take the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: CBC FOREIGN EXCHANGE RESERVES TOP US$ 113.6 BILLION

TEXT.P: The foreign exchange reserves of the Taipei-based Central Bank of China totaled US$113.6 billion as of the end of February this year, according to official statistics released on Sunday.
A CBC official said that this accounted for 80.9 percent of the central bank's total assets.

Meanwhile, the statistics show that the central bank's business revenues between July 1999 and February this year amounted to NT$134.2 billion (US$4.36 billion), with total expenditures during that period reaching NT$85.6 billion (US$2.78 billion), leaving a surplus of NT$48.6 billion (US$1.58 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: UN URGED TO CENSURE BEIJING FOR VIOLATING BASIC HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: Some 400,000 employees and family members of the businesses affiliated with China's Zhong Gong meditation group jointly sent an open letter to the United Nations Human Rights Commission Sunday, urging it to censure Beijing for violating their basic human rights.

In the letter, sent through the Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China, they said that since last October the Chinese government has closed down more than 3,000 firms affiliated with Zhong Gong and confiscated 810 million yuan (US$98 million) of their assets in a government crackdown on the organization.
The petitioners said that by doing so the Chinese government has deprived them of their right to work, and that they now live in abject poverty.
Along with Falun Gong, Zhong Gong was banned last July as an "evil cult."

The letter said Zhong Gong, which claims to have some 10 million followers in China, has done nothing evil or illegal. Like Falun Gong, Zhong Gong is an organization dedicated to the promotion of a traditional breathing and meditating method better known as "qi gong" in China.

The petitioners requested the UN commission to censure Beijing for violating human rights, and also urge it to observe international convenants on basic human rights and respect its citizens' right to work, to worship, to run private enterprises, and to have private property.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
