DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET REBOUNDS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market rebounded on Monday after several days of drastic falls last week, with the benchmark weighted price index gaining 126.88 points to close at 8,993.68.
Market turnover amounted to NT$164.99 (US$5.42 billion) amid volatile trading.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND FISHING BOAT INTERCEPTED FOR POACHING
DOC.DATELINE: Keelung, northern Taiwan, April 17 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A mainland Chinese fishing boat was intercepted by Taiwan maritime police Sunday for poaching in Republic of China territorial waters, sources from the Coast Guard Administration (CGA) reported on Monday.

The Fujian-registered fishing boat "Minchangyu F306" was forced to anchor at Patoutzu fishing port near Keelung and its skipper, Wang Jin, was taken in for questioning. All the fishing gear and about 2 metric tons of fish catch aboard the boat were confiscated.
The "Minchangyu F306" was discovered to be illegally fishing in an area about 12 nautical miles from the Pengchiayu Isle off Taiwan's northeastern coast at around noon on Sunday.

Two CGA patrol vessels approached the fishing boat at around 1:00 p.m. and told it over loudspeaker to leave ROC waters. After the warnings were ignored, the coastal police boarded the "Minchangyu F306" and ordered the mainland Chinese fishing boat to sail to the nearest Taiwan port.
The maritime police released the skipper, 52, from Fujian Province, and 13 crew members after Wang was questioned.
The Fujian fishing boat was then escorted out of the 24-nautical mile zone defining ROC territorial waters.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIAN ENVOY PAINTS ROSY TRADE PICTURE WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: The Australian representative to the Republic of China painted a rosy picture concerning his country's trade and people-to-people relations with Taiwan, particularly in the period after Taipei joins the World Trade Organization as expected, possibly later this year.

In an interview with the Australian, Sam Gerovich, head of the Australian Commerce and Industry Office in Taiwan, said that "we are confident that the dynamics of our commercial relations will continue to develop irrespective of whom is president."

"We do need to consider whether changes in cross-strait relations create problems for potential investors or traders. We can expect the economic and people-to-people relationships to move forward," he added.
Meanwhile, in a dispatch from Taipei, the Australian reported that Australia's two-way trade with Taiwan rose to US$4.81 billion in 1999, with Canberra enjoying a huge trade surplus.

Gerovich noted that the memorandum of understanding signed between the Tuntex Group and the Australian LNG consortium last year would pave the way for the annual importation by Taiwan of four million tons of LNG from the Northwest Shelf in western Australia for the next 20 years.
Gerovich said there are no major outstanding trade issues between Australia and Taiwan and Canberra looks forward to Taiwan's entry into the WTO.
"Once Taiwan is in the WTO, the existing tilt in the playing field toward the United States and the resulting market distortions will be eliminated," he told the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET REGAINS STRENGTH

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market staged a rare rally on Monday after losing more than 1,000 points last week, thanks to active buying by four government-related funds.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index surged 126.88 points to close at 8,993.68. The gain came as a sharp contrast to drastic falls in Monday morning trading sessions in major other Asian countries.

Market analysts said panic sell-offs on major other Asian bourses were triggered by last Friday's Wall Street meltdown. As the Taiex already reflected that woe on Saturday, it didn't see heavy selling pressure this morning.
The Taiex opened slightly higher at 8,848.16 points and hit a high of 9,013.14 at one point, but weakened mildly in the final session.
A total of 2.74 billion shares changed hands during the three-hour trading session on a market turnover of NT$164.99 billion (US$5.42 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 334 to 197, with 70 stocks remaining unchanged.

The eight major categories registered mixed results, with pulp and paper issues gaining 2.9 percent; electrical stocks rising 2.2 percent; plastics and chemical stocks picking up 1 percent; textiles advancing 0.5 percent; foodstuff issues edging up 0.1 percent; while financial, construction and cement issues losing 0.2 percent, 0.3 percent and 1.5 percent, respectively.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORGED ROC PASSPORTS SAID AVAILABLE AT NT$ 200,000 PER COPY

TEXT.P: A legislator on Monday called for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) to pay closer attention to the problem of stolen Republic of China passports being sold illegally for high prices.

At an interpellation session at the Legislative Yuan, New Party Legislator Lai Shih-pao said a forged ROC passport has a market value of about NT$200,000 (US$6,555) and questioned whether MOFA officials have any idea about this problem.

Ku Fu-chang, director-general of the MOFA's Bureau of Consular Affairs, answered that he had heard that figure quoted before but added that he doubts whether such a market exists with the price being so high.

Ku admitted that forged ROC passports have been in high demand in recent years as an increasing number of Asian people are trying to get their hands on one in order to be able to leave their countries.

Quoting an MOFA survey, Ku said that out of the some 1.2 million to 1.4 million passports issued each year by the MOFA, about 21,000 are reported lost. Of the lost copies, only about 200 are found to be forged and used by other people.

Lai ridiculed the MOFA's handling of the issue of forged passports, saying that the MOFA has helped create illicit business opportunities worth over NT$4 billion (US$131 million) annually for organized crime rings simply because it has not improved its policies to prevent illegal practices.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT HEAVYWEIGHTS PRESENT VIEWS ON PARTY REFORMS

TEXT.P: Members of the Kuomintang Central Advisory Council Presidium expressed their concerns about the fate of the party in a seminar on Monday.

More than 10 members attended the seminar on the KMT's party reform and cross-strait policies. They plan to take their views to acting KMT Chairman Lien Chan with whom they have a scheduled meeting on Wednesday.

Wang Tso-jung, the former president of the Control Yuan, said that the urgent question now for the party is how to regain power in the next four years, adding that he is "pessimistic" about the prospects of this judging from the KMT's current approach and situation.
Wang said the election defeat of the KMT, which boasts 2 million members but could only manage a third finish in the March 18 presidential election, could mean the collapse of the party.
Wang suggested that Lien Chan should have an open mind and seek the return of those KMT members who were stripped off their membership because of political reasons.

He also said the KMT should have direct elections for the party's chairman, instead of the current practice of KMT delegates choosing, adding that only by doing so can there be any hope of retaking political power.

Several members also suggested that not only the party's chairman, but also its Central Standing Committee members be directly elected, and that the party's congress be held every two years, instead of every four years, to enliven the party's organization and galvanize the unity of KMT members.
They said the KMT should seek to attract those who have ideals back into the party's fold and make the party more appealing to young voters.

Irwine W. Ho, former secretary-general of the National Assembly, said that the crisis of the century-old party stems from the loss of confidence of veteran KMT members and the party's unattractiveness to young voters.
Clement C. P. Chang, former Minister of Transportation and Communications, suggested that the party begin nurturing talent now for future elections.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA FACING SOCIAL, ECONOMIC, AND POLITICAL HURDLES

TEXT.P: Things will get worse for mainland China economically, politically and socially before they get better as the new millennium begins, according to a survey by the Australian.
In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily on Monday carried a report that stated China is facing a lot of headaches as it formulates its tenth Five Year Plan for the period between 2001 and 2005.

The daily reported that China must begin to dismantle its arcane system of protective tariffs, cut subsidies to its failing state-run enterprises, dig its banks out from under a mountain of bad debt, and allow foreign competitors to a slice of its domestic industries following its entry into the World Trade Organization later this year.

The daily quoted a senior official of China's State Development and Planning Commission as predicting that its economy will grow between 7 and 8 percent in the next five years following growth of 7.1 percent in 1999.

But a 7 to 8 percent growth rate will only be achieved if China succeeds in entering the WTO later this year. If it fails to, then it will find it difficult to achieve an average growth rate of 6 percent during its tenth Fifth Year Plan, the official said.
The daily reported that China has been slow to publicize industry-specific policies aimed at complying with WTO membership conditions, though it has shown great willingness to make changes.
The slow changes are being caused by the fact that domestic interests are protecting industries and jobs following massive layoffs over the past two to three years, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA BECOMES AUSTRALIA'S 2ND LARGEST TRADING PARTNER

TEXT.P: Mainland China overtook South Korea to become Australia's second largest trading partner, and Taiwan ranked fifth on the same list in 1999, according to a report in the Australian on Monday.
The daily reported that China's two-way trade with Australia totaled A$10.66 (US$7.1) billion in 1999, compared to A$10.15 (US$6.8) billion between Australia and Korea.

Australia also expects to begin selling liquefied natural gas to mainland China, but the project appears unlikely at present as China has no receiving terminal and Beijing has not made any firm commitments to buy from Australia.

On the contrary, the magazine reported that Australia would begin exporting LNG to Taiwan earlier as the island already has a receiving terminal in place in Kaohsiung and a formal agreement is likely to be signed in June this year.

The magazine reported that despite ranking second, the amount of China's two-way trade with Australia remains far behind the amount of Japan's two-way trade with Australia, which totaled US$20 billion last year.
Korea ranked third and Singapore fourth on the list for 1999, followed by Taiwan, Malaysia, Indonesia, Hong Kong, Thailand, and India, rounding out the top ten.

DOC.HEADLINE: MEDICINE, LAW TOP SUBJECTS FOR TAIWAN STUDENTS SEEKING IN MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Law and medicine, particularly Chinese traditional medicine, were top choices for Taiwanese students seeking higher education on the Chinese mainland.

The two areas were most popular with Taiwanese students because qualification thresholds in China are much lower than those in Taiwan, and graduates of those subjects are likely to have promising career future, according to Taiwanese student circles in Shanghai and Beijing.

Currently there are about 200 Taiwanese students studying medicine in Shanghai. Due to the relatively low entrance requirements, Taiwanese students who cannot attend medical schools in Taiwan find it much easier to enroll in China.

Some Taiwanese students who have even failed to pass the mainland's entrance examinations were nonetheless admitted into medical schools after their parents made donations to the schools, said a Taiwanese student surnamed Lee at Shanghai Medical University.

Lee said he chose to study medicine in Shanghai because students on the mainland have greater access to clinical experience than students in Taiwan. For example, he said, more than 20 students would have to share one clinical table for an anatomy class in Taiwan, compared with four students on the mainland.

However, Lee admitted that, on the whole, teaching facilities in mainland Chinese medical schools lag behind most of Taiwan's. Furthermore, Taiwan authorities do not recognize academic degrees conferred by mainland schools, prompting Taiwanese students who have studied on the mainland to seek further education beyond China.

On average, Lee noted, about 30 percent of such students turned to the United States for further studies, 20 percent stayed on the mainland after they obtained a medical degree, and many of the rest turned to other career areas.

A Taiwanese student studying at Beijing University's law school said he chose to study law on the mainland in the belief that laws and related expertise will be in great demand in years to come as the era of cronyism, where one must depend on personal connections for societal achievements, will soon pass in China. Rule of law is expected to become the norm in the not-too-distant future.

The student, surnamed Yang, said that experts who know both mainland Chinese and Taiwanese legal systems will be in great demand after both Taiwan and mainland China enter the World Trade Organization.
The number of students from Taiwan, Hong Kong and Macau who applied to study in law schools in Beijing totaled about 100 this year, evidently an increase over past years, Yang added.

DOC.HEADLINE: QUAKE VICTIMS IN NANTOU COUNTY NOT SATISFIED WITH RELIEF EFFORTS

TEXT.P: An alliance of quake victims in Nantou County in central Taiwan on Monday demanded that quake relief efforts there match those of neighboring Taichung County.

Teng Shuang-ching, spokesperson for the alliance, noted that more than seven months have passed since the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake that hit Taiwan. Taichung and Nantou Counties bore the brunt of damage during the massive temblor.

Teng said that reconstruction works in Nantou County have repeatedly let quake victims there down. He added that not only the is the assessment of damaged housing still incomplete, but subsidies and compensation for the quake-affected areas don't compare to those of Taichung County.
The alliance demanded that relief efforts in Nantou County should be at least the same as that in Taichung County, if not better.
Teng also demanded that Nantou County government publicly reveal how NT$1.6 billion (US$52.46 million) of donated quake relief funds is being used.
The alliance had originally planned to stage a protest in front of the Nantou County government building, but had instead decided to meet with county officials.
Deputy County Magistrate Lai Ying-fang promised that the county government will consider the views of the quake victims in future relief efforts.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.049 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Monday, closing at 30.539.
The local currency opened Monday at 30.495 and was traded between 30.495, the highest level of the day, and 30.569.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$555 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 17, or the 13th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1421: More than 100,000 people drown when the sea breaks through a dike in Dort, Holland.
1790: American public official, writer, scientist, and printer Benjamin Franklin dies at the age of 84. He played a major part in the American Revolution, negotiated French support for the colonies, signed the Treaty of Paris and helped draft the US Constitution.
1824: The United States and Russia define respective rights in the Pacific Ocean and on the northwest coast of America.
1894: Nikita S. Krushchev, Soviet politician, is born. As Soviet leader he denounced Stalin and thwarted the Hungarian Revolution of 1956. He was deposed in 1964 for his failure to improve the Soviet economy.
1895: The Treaty of Shimonoseki is signed, compelling the Ching court to pay a huge indemnity, open its seaports, recognize the independence of Korea, and cede the Liaoning Peninsula, Taiwan and the Pescadores to Japan.
1897: During a revolt in Ottoman-held Crete, war breaks out between Greece and the Ottoman Empire.
1906: A Pacific cable between China and the United States is completed.
1938: Chang Kuo-dao, governor of the Chinese communist government that controls the region comprising Shensi, Kansu and Ningsia issues a statement in Hankou distancing himself from the Chinese Communist Party.
1941: US President Franklin D. Roosevelt approves initial military aid US$45 million for China.
1946: Communist troops enter Changchun, Kirin Province, in northeastern China.
1950: The Chinese Women's Anti-Aggression League is formally inaugurated.
1964: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the Republic of China issues a statement severing diplomatic relations with The Congo.
1968: US President Lyndon B. Johnson meets with South Korean President Park Chung Hee in Honolulu, pledging US protection for noncommunist Asia.
1971: Egypt, Syria and Libya sign an agreement to form a confederation.
1971: East Pakistanis declare their homeland an independent nation which they rename Bangladesh. Sheik Mujibur Rahman serves as the nation's first prime minister.
1973: President Lon Nol of Cambodia announces the resignation of his Cabinet.
1980: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) accepts mainland China as a member, and the Republic of China is forced to pull out of the organization.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council passes a proposal to allow teachers and staff of public schools to travel to the Chinese mainland for family visits.
1992: Legislative proceedings are completed for the National Employment Act, which is to serve as the basis for employment of foreign nationals in the Republic of China.
1994: Mainland China's public security unit announces it has solved a criminal case in which 24 Taiwan tourists were killed at Qiandao Lake on March 31, 1994.
1995: Fire breaks out at a KTV on Hankou Street in Taipei, killing 12 people and seriously injuring 14 others.
1996: US President Bill Clinton signs a joint declaration on security cooperation with Japanese Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto pledging to maintain American military levels in Japan and elsewhere in Asia.
Confucius' lesson of the day: " A wise man is ashamed to say much; he prefers to do more."

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER-DESIGNATE TANG RECOVERING WELL AFTER SURGERY

TEXT.P: Defense Minister and Premier-designate Tang Fei was recovering well Monday after undergoing an operation to remove a chest tumor the previous day, according to the hospital.

Tang took some rice gruel for breakfast Monday morning, and was to undergo breathing therapy in the afternoon. He is expected to be moved from the intensive care ward to an ordinary one on Tuesday, said Chief Surgeon Huang Min-hsiung of Taipei's Veterans General Hospital.

The tumor, known as a thynoma, was discovered when Tang underwent a check-up earlier this month. He reportedly has gone for the check-up as he was experiencing symptoms of myasthenia gravis, a nerve disease that leads to symptoms of weakness and fatigue of the facial muscles. The condition is a side-effect of the tumor.

According to the initial examination of the tumor, it was benign, and Tang is expected to take at least two weeks to recover. However, Huang said the hospital would make a follow-up investigation and continue its evaluation for six months.

The chief surgeon also noted previously that the thynoma, a tumorous growth on Tang's thymus gland, had not spread to Tang's surrounding internal organs. He added that the thymus gland had been completely removed, as is common practice during such operations.
Huang said to the public after the operation that with the aid of medicine, over 90 percent of patients recover to some extent from myasthenia gravis.

In view of the fact that the new government of President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Premier-designate Tang is to be inaugurated on May 20, Tang's current health condition is of particular public concern.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN, MAINLAND EXPECTED TO ENTER WTO BY END OF YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan and mainland China are expected to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) by the end of this year, Vice Economic Affairs Minister Lin Yi-fu said on Monday.

The matter will be clarified in early June after the US Congress makes its decision granting "permanent normal trade relation (PNTR)" to the mainland in late May; and whether an additional round of talks between the mainland and the European Union, slated for next month, will conclude smoothly, said Lin.

As long as the two major factors affecting Taiwan's bid to join the WTO can be duly addressed before late May, the vice economics minister said that the timing for Taiwan's entry into the Geneva-based world trade regulatory body will be easier to estimate.
However, Lin pointed out that the international community has come to a consensus that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should join the WTO at the same time.
In addition, Lin also revealed that Taiwan should be able to act as an observer in the WTO's next round of negotiations, slated for the near future, before the WTO grants formal membership to Taiwan.

Meanwhile, Chung Chin, a research fellow at the Chung-hua Institute for Economic Research and the director general-designate for the Government Information Office, said at a seminar that trade liberalization is a global trend and that the entry of Taiwan and mainland China into the WTO will impact Taiwan's market and help local businesses improve their competitive edge.

Turning to the political significance the WTO membership would bring to the both sides, Chung commented that Taiwan should try to seek an equal footing with the mainland in the organization in order to prevent increased pressure from Beijing.

Taiwan and mainland China were allowed to join the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum at the same time in 1991, but Taiwan was facing greater isolation within the body due to Beijing's political pressure, pointed out Chung.

Urging the incoming government of President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party to adopt new and open thinking to deal with the problem, she forecast that the future of cross-strait economic activities will develop by leaps and bounds.

Tsai Hung-ming, executive secretary of the Chinese National Federation of Industries, forecast that Taiwan will continue to receive discriminatory treatment in international trade organizations if mainland China stands in the way and views Taiwan as an economic zone under its jurisdiction.

Nevertheless, H. T. Lu, a business management professor at Chung Yuan Christian University expressed his opinion that the inclusion of Taiwan and mainland China in the WTO will provide a channel for the two sides to strengthen two-way exchanges.

Mainland China wishes to enter the WTO as a means of underscoring its powerful role in the Asia-Pacific region, while Taiwan wants to join it in the hope of increasing contacts with its non-diplomatic allies, the academic said.

In addition to seeking to form business alliances across the globe, he also suggested that the Taiwan business community consider the mainland Chinese market as an international outlet and further upgrade the quality level of their production.

Echoing his view, W. J. Lee, director of the business management school of Ming Chuan University who chaired the symposium, called on the government to work out a comprehensive package of measures to deal with the situation Taiwan will face after its admission into the WTO.
According to Lee, the local economy will be hard hit by Taiwan's WTO membership in the short term, and the government should make necessary arrangements for the impact.

All opinions voiced in the seminar will be referred to Chen's new government to help it deal with relevant problems, and the seminar will be broadcast on the Public Television Network this coming Sunday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC'S TRANSPORTATION AND COMMUNICATIONS SECTORS GROWING SHARPLY

TEXT.P: Taiwan's transportation, storage and communications sectors grew substantially last year, making up 20 percent of the country's real economic growth, according to statistics released by the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) on Monday.
The MOTC attributed the growth mainly to the effects of liberalization of the island's communications market.

The statistics indicate that the gross product of Taiwan's transportation, storage and communications sectors in 1999 totaled NT$671 billion (US$21.6 billion), up 17.47 percent over the preceding year, and accounting for 7.41 percent of the nation's gross domestic product.
Taiwan registered a 5.67 percent real economic growth rate last year, 20 percent of which consisted of the transportation, storage and communications sectors.
MOTC officials expect that these sectors will contribute even more to growth in 2000 because of further liberalization of the communications market this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: AIDS 'COCKTAILS' PIONEER TO SERVE AS ROC'S TOP BIOTECH ADVISER

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Monday invited David Ho, a leading AIDS researcher in the United States, to serve as the Republic of China's top adviser in biotechnology development.

Chen extended his invitation during a meeting with Ho, who is currently on a weeklong visit to Taiwan to take part in a series of activities aimed at promoting public awareness of AIDS and efforts to help AIDS patients and their families.

Chen said he hopes that Ho, who was born in the central Taiwan city of Taichung and moved to Los Angeles with his family in 1965 at the age of 12, can help upgrade Taiwan's biotechnological development.

Chen further said he believes that technological development, particularly in the biotechnology field, can serve as a bridge for dialogue and communication among Taiwan, mainland China and the United States.
"I earnestly hopes that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait and the United States can forge closer technological cooperation to help ensure lasting peace in the region," Chen added.

Ho has pioneered the use of "cocktails" treatment to combat HIV, which causes AIDS, and provided the first glimmers of hope to AIDS patients for better and longer lives. He is now working on a vaccine strategy in the hopes that a cheaper and more convenient method of fighting the deadly disease will soon be available. A Ho-led US research team may begin clinical testing on AIDS vaccine in mainland China next year.
Chen said he hopes that Ho's research activities in the United States, mainland China and Taiwan can benefit all the three sides and further help ensure peace in the Taiwan Strait.
Ho, also an academician of the ROC's highest research body Academia Sinica, said he is more than willing to assist in Taiwan's biotechnological development.

Ho said Taiwan should focus efforts on three key points in boosting biotechnological development -- talent cultivation, attracting overseas ROC experts to return to Taiwan for research work and research program financing.
According to Ho, many overseas ROC scientists are willing to contribute to their homeland so long as the government here can offer suitable working terms and research climate.

Ho, who made friends with Chen during Chen's stint as Taipei mayor from 1994 through 1998, said he hopes that Chen's administration will take more active steps to support various high-tech and biotech research programs. If Chen offers a formal invitation after assuming office, Ho said he will be very pleased to serve as a biotech adviser to the new ROC government.
Ho was named by Time Magazine as its "Man of the Year" in 1996 for "helping lift a death sentence on tens of thousands of AIDS sufferers, and for pioneering the treatment that might lead to a cure."

The "cocktails" treatment has actually proven to be effective for a large number of AIDS patients over the last four years. According to Ho, more than two-thirds of the patients who have received "cocktails" treatments have seen their symptoms controlled, allowing them to lead better and longer lives.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES RISE ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Futures prices for Taipei's stock index rebounded on Monday, as Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Index (TAIEX) futures for April rose 303 points to close at 9,003, with a volume of 1,287 contract transactions.

TAIEX futures for May soared 230 points to finish at 9,040, with 2,500 contract transactions; June futures moved up 133 points to close at 9,021, with 51 contract transactions; and December futures lost 663 points, with four contract transactions.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on electronics shares and financial stocks listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, both reported positive results.

April TE futures moved up 20.5 points to close at 487, with 502 contract transactions; May TE futures surged 21.5 points to finish at 492, with 864 contract transactions; and June TE futures edged up 16.25 points to close at 498, with 18 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

April TF futures increased 17 points to finish at 933, with 149 contract transactions; May TF futures moved up 6 points to close at 936, with 121 contract transactions; and June TF futures surged 10 points to finish at 965, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR 2000 TREND SETTING & TECHNOLOGY CONFERENCE HELD IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Year 2000 Trend Setting & Technology Conference was held in Taipei on Monday with more than 100 experts and industrialists from home and abroad participating.

The conference was jointly sponsored by Stanford University's Scholastic Foundation and the Taiwan Chapter of the Stanford University Alumni Association. The meeting's purpose is to promote the interchange of ideas and experiences in the semiconductor, Internet, and information technology industries.

Morris Chang, chairman of Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., Ltd. (TSMC), said that the local integrated circuit (IC) industry must cultivate more design talent and strengthen basic industrial know-how.

Chang said that although the use of peripheral products are increasing as a result of the emergence of the Internet, the PC still is the mainstream worldwide trend. He added that semiconductors will enjoy brisk sales in the future, and cited an expected 25 percent annual growth rate for TSMC over the next two years.

Chang says that the local semiconductor industry must cultivate technological skills and improve basic industrial studies in the face of a strong challenge from the mainland China semiconductor industry. He predicted that the semiconductor market in mainland China will be larger than that of Japan in 10 years, Chang noted.

Jim Plummer, a world-renowned semiconductor expert, and Annelee Saxinian, an expert on trend analysis, delivered keynote speeches at the meeting. They argued that a thorough diagnosis and analysis of the direction of Taiwan's future industrial development and competitiveness must be conducted.

Hsih Chin-tai, director of the Industrial Institute for Research and Development, pointed out that the global population of Internet users has topped the 50 million mark, the highest number since figures became available four years ago. The population will only increase further as emerging broadband technologies increase web connection speed and ease of use, Hsih said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TWO TAIWAN INSURANCE FIRMS ALLOWED TO SET UP OFFICES IN PRC

TEXT.P: The Republic of China Finance Ministry on Monday allowed two local insurance companies to set up offices in mainland China, marking the first mainland foray for the island's insurance industry.

A Finance Ministry official said that Fubon Insurance Company has been permitted to set up offices in Beijing, Shanghai, Guangzhou and Amoy, with Cathay Life Insurance Co. allowed to set up offices in Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou.

The official said that since the government amended regulations to allow Taiwan insurance companies to establish offices in mainland China in March this year, nine local companies have presented their applications to the ministry's Department of Insurance for approval.

Now that two companies have obtained approval, the official said, similar applications from Shin Kong Life Insurance Co., Tungtai Insurance Co. and Mingtai Fire and Marine Insurance Co. are being reviewed, while the remaining four applicants have been asked to provide additional data.

According to government regulations, the operations of local insurance companies' mainland offices are restricted to researching relevant market information. They are not allowed to engage in the insurance business at the present stage.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE DISSIDENT SENTENCED TO TWO YEARS IN LABOR CAMP

TEXT.P: A Chinese dissident, who was a member of the banned "China Democracy Party" in Shanghai, was sentenced recently to two years in an "education through labor camp," a human rights group said here Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights and Democratic Movement in China said Yao Zhenxiang was detained by police in early April on his way to a city in northwestern Shaanxi province to take part in a meeting of Chinese dissidents, but he was subsequently given the sentence on charges of "having sex with prostitutes."

The information center said that since the end of 1998 Chinese authorities have sent five other dissidents to labor camps on charges of having sex with prostitutes, and that Yao's family hope the United Nations Human Rights Commission will condemn Beijing for sending political dissidents to labor camps on false criminal charges. By doing so, Chinese authorities hope to avoid international criticism that they suppress political dissent.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNI AIRLINES PLANE FORCED TO LAND BY MECHANICAL PROBLEMS

TEXT.P: A UNI Airlines passenger plane was forced to abort a flight from Taipei to the southern city of Chiayi and land at a central Taiwan airport on Monday due to mechanical problems, according to an airline source.
The DASH-300 plane landed safely at Taichung's Shui Nan airport at 9:02 a.m. after an "abnormal" engine sound was detected, said the source.
No injuries were reported among the 56 passengers, and all continued their journeys to Chiayi via alternative means, the source continued.
The plane was still grounded for further inspection as of press time.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PASSPORT VALIDITY TO BE EXTENDED TO 10 YEARS

TEXT.P: The Republic of China's passport validity period will be extended from the current six years to 10 years in line with the practice adopted by major democratic countries around the world.

The move is a key point included in a passport regulations amendment bill passed at a joint meeting of the Legislative Yuan's foreign and overseas Chinese affairs committee and several other relevant legislative committees on Monday.

Vice Foreign Minister Wu Tzu-dan said the proposed extension of ROC passport validity is aimed at reducing the workload of relevant government agencies and meeting the standards of advanced democratic countries.
According to the draft amendment bill, the validity period for diplomatic and official passports will be extended to five years from the current three years.

The amendment bill also eases restrictions on passport requirements for adult men who have not yet fulfilled mandatory military service. Under the revised rules, those men will no longer be required to apply for government approval before filing passport applications. Instead, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) will add a stamp to the passport indicating that the holder has yet to fulfill compulsory military service.

Meanwhile, the draft bill adds regulations detailing the scenarios where MOFA can legally reject passport applications, such as at the request of judicial offices or where applicants are found to have presented false personal data. Current regulations do not include any such provisions.

DOC.HEADLINE: PENTAGON RECOMMENDS POSTPONEMENT OF ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Pentagon is to recommend against the sale of four Aegis destroyers to Taiwan, but will agree to sell the island long-range radar and advanced medium-rang air-to-air missiles (AMRAAM), the Washington Post reported on Monday.

At the beginning of two-day negotiations in Washington, D.C. between the United States and Taiwan on arms sales, the paper quoted sources close to the talks as saying that the Defense Department will also recommend putting off decisions on the sale of several other weapons such as submarines and P-3 Orion anti-submarine aircraft.

The sources said that the Pentagon's opinions could prevail in the Clinton administration because of the sensitivity in Taipei-Beijing ties following Taiwan's election of a pro-independence president.

Given Washington's desire to see Beijing opening dialogue with Taipei, it would be inappropriate to encourage Taiwan's attempt to secede from mainalnd China and thereby worsen the climate between the two by arms sales to Taiwan at present, said the sources.

Instead, the sources said, Washington will wait and see how Taiwan's president-elect Chen Shui-bian will deal with Beijing after he is sworn in on May 20 before making any decision on sensitive arms sales.
However, the Pentagon will favor sale of a long-range radar system known as PAVE PAWS, to Taiwan, so long as Taipei can show how it would be integrated into its air defense system, said the Post.
The radar would allow Taiwan to peer deep into mainalnd China's airspace and guard against any attack by ballistic missiles.
The Pentagon also backs the sales of AMRAAM to Taiwan, provided the system is stored on US soil and Taiwanese forces are trained in its use in the United States.
Under the Pentagon's recommendation, the missiles would be moved to Taiwan only when mainland China acquires a similar, Russian-made missile called the AAX-12.
Another weapon the Pentagon will not oppose to selling to Taiwan is an upgraded version of the Maverick air-to-ground missile.

Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, who plays a vital role in arms sales to Taiwan, could also add Orion aircraft to the shopping cart to soothe Taiwan's allies on Capitol Hill, said the Post.

Taiwan's request to buy Aegis destroyers, which can track more than 100 targets on land, in the air and at sea simultaneously, posed a dilemma for the White House, which is carefully walking a tightrope between Taiwan's supporters in Congress and Taiwan's archrival, Beijing.

Taiwan is outdated in military technology and is more vulnerable to Beijing's attack than generally supposed, according to a Pentagon report leaked late last month, and under the terms of the Taiwan Relations Act, the United States has committed itself to supplying Taiwan with arms for its self defense.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT NATIONAL CONGRESS BROUGHT FORWARD

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang has brought forward the date of its party congress from June 24-25, to June 17-18, a party spokesman said on Monday.

The congress, called after the party was soundly defeated in the March 18 presidential election, was originally scheduled for June 24-25 at the posh Taipei International Conference Center, but was relocated to the more modest Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall in Taipei to show the party's shame for its humiliating performance in the election and its determination to make a comeback.
KMT spokesman Jason Hu said the date for the congress had to be brought forward because the Sun Yat-sen Memorial Hall had already been leased for other use on June 24 and 25.
The party congress is expected to elect a party chairman and members of the Central Standing Committee, the party's policy-making group.
A meeting of the party's Central Advisory Committee, consisting mainly of elder KMT statesmen, will be held a day before the congress, said Hu.

Former KMT Chairman Lee Teng-hui, who is also the country's president, was forced to step down one week after the presidential election to take the blame for the party's failure. His place is expected to be succeeded by Vice Chairman Lien Chan, who has already taken the helm of the party as acting chairman.

DOC.HEADLINE: FIRST GROUP OF SECOND-TIER STOCKS TO ENTER MARKET

TEXT.P: The first group of Taiwan's second-tier stocks will be listed on the market as scheduled on Tuesday, despite big losses of Internet companies on the Nasdaq over the weekend, Vice Finance Minister Yen Ching-chang said on Monday.

It is expected that more companies will apply to be listed as second-board Taiwan Innovative Growing Entrepreneurs (TIGERs) at the end of April, said Ding Ke-hwa, vice chairman of the Securities & Futures Commission (SFC) under the Ministry of Finance.
The first three TIGER companies to be listed on Tuesday will be Trade-van Information Services Co., Info Pro Group Inc. and Yem Chio Co.

Ding also said that the SFC will try to enlarge the scale of the Taiwan stock market to permit more promising companies on the over-the-counter market to be listed in the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX).
At present, only around 470 companies enjoy TAIEX listing.
Ding noted that the number of TAIEX-listed companies is far fewer than the more-than 600 in the Hong Kong stock market and the some 700 in South Korea's stock market.

After the FTSE International and Morgan Stanley Capital International announced that they will gradually increase Taiwan's weighting in its own indices, the enlargement of the scale of the Taiwan stock market will help attract more foreign capital and stabilize the market, Ding pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: US LAWMAKER ARRIVES IN TAIPEI FOR THREE-DAY VISIT

TEXT.P: US Senator Frank Murkowski (R, Alaska), arrived in Taipei on Monday for a three-day visit.
He will receive a medal from President Lee Teng-hui, meet with President-elect Chen Shui-bian, Foreign Minister-designate Tien Hung-mao, and various other politic and business leaders.

As a long-standing friend of Taiwan, Murkowski has succeeded in opening the Taiwan market to Alaska crude oil. He is scheduled to call on officials of Taiwan Power Company and the Chinese Petroleum Corp., the two major local customers for Alaskan crude.
He is slated to return home on April 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT-ELECT WORRYING ABOUT CROSS-STRAIT CONFLICT
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 16 (CNA) (By David Wang and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President-elect Annette Lu has said she is worrying that Beijing leaders may take irrational action against Taiwan if they are dissatisfied with ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian's May 20 inaugural speech.
Lu made the remarks in an interview with Newsweek, which will appear in the weekly's April 24 issue scheduled for distribution on Monday.
Lu, a dissident-turned-politician, said she is afraid that Beijing's recent harsh criticism of her may signal that Beijing leaders are losing rationality toward relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Lu, who will be the ROC's first female deputy head of state after her May 20 inauguration, said she is particularly worrying what will happen if Beijing leaders are not satisfied with Chen's inaugural address. Beijing leaders have demanded that Chen make a positive response to its so-called "one China" principle, which downgrades the ROC to a local-level government.

Lu, incumbent Taoyuan County magistrate, said both she and President-elect Chen worry about the eruption of a conflict between Taiwan and mainland China. And this is why they have remained very cautious and prudent since they won the March 18 election, Lu added.
Chen's election victory marks the first transition of power from the Kuomintang, Taiwan's ruling party of 55 years, to his Democratic Progressive Party.

Asked whether she thinks that the United States is overly leaning toward Beijing, Lu didn't make a direct reply. She instead said that in the past, most world leaders and politicians and even journalists consistently took as "truth" Beijing leaders remarks concerning Taiwan.
"We have no intention of provoking them," Lu said, adding that the people of Taiwan have consistently worked hard and have managed to achieve good results.

Lu said Taiwan has never created any trouble for the world. "We have overcome all sorts of difficulties in a peaceful, optimistic manner. We have never made any mistake. But we have been treated as a troublemaker," she lamented.

Asked about Taiwan's bid to join the United Nations, Lu said she has devoted much energy to promote Taiwan's UN bid because without Taiwan's participation, the United Nations can't be a perfect organization. Noting that South Korea and mainland China had waited for 50 years and 22 years, respectively, before they managed to obtain UN seats, Lu said Taiwan will promote its bid patiently.

Lu went on to say the most urgent task for the new ROC government is to strengthen cross-strait cooperation. She stressed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait do not have any feud. Stressing that the people on the two sides of the strait have same ancestry and cultural backgrounds, Lu said the soon-to-be-inaugurated DPP government has sincerity and determination to terminate any cross-strait confrontation and boost rapprochement.

Lu expressed her hopes that the US government will consider allowing senior ROC officials to visit the United States and inviting leaders from both sides of the Taiwan strait to hold talks at the White House in order to boost regional peace and stability.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUDICIAL YUAN CHIEF COMMENTS ON NA MOVE TO ABOLISH GRAND JUSTICES

TEXT.P: Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng issued a statement on Monday which said that if the National Assembly passes a resolution to abolish the Council of Grand Justices, it will "hurt the interests of the people."

He said that the Judicial Yuan will respect the decision of the assembly, but claimed that since its establishment, the council has made great contributions to the nation's constitutional development.

Weng was commenting on a move by the National Assembly deputies to abrogate the council, apparently in retaliation for a recent council decision to pronounce invalid the assembly's resolution of last September which extended the four-year term of assemblymen by two years and 42 days.
The assembly deputies also moved to amend the Constitution to disqualify the grand justices from holding the office for life.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MIGHT BE NAMED ON US 'SPECIAL 301' WATCH LIST: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan could be named again on the US "special 301" watch-list this year, given Washington's dissatisfaction with the island's protection of intellectual property, a Taiwan trade official said on Monday.

Speaking upon his return from a visit to Washington, D.C. where he talked with US trade officials on the island's bid for World Trade Organization membership and the island's commercial ties with the United States, Chen Ruey-long, director-general of the Board of Foreign Trade, said that his US counterparts were far from satisfied with Taiwan's implementation of intellectual property laws.

As a result, he went on, Washington could name Taiwan on the general watch list under the special 301 provisions of its 1989 Omnibus Trade Acts. Countries on the list are not in danger of immediate trade sanctions, but could face a process leading to sanctions if they fail to address alleged flaws in trade practices.
The list will be disclosed by Washington by the end of April when it finishes its annual review of the trade practices of its trading partners around the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK-BASED HUMAN RIGHTS GROUP ANNOUNCES NEW NAME
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 17 (CNA) (By Belle Chou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong-based Information Center of Human Rights & Democratic Movement in China announced on Monday that it will rename itself the Information Center of Human Rights & Democracy, effective immediately.
The center's head, Lu Suqing, noted that the old name was too long for foreign news media to cite and it is simpler to use the new name, saying that democratic movement is similar to democracy.
It is also well known that the center's focus is on mainland China issues, so the center also decided to omit the words "in China" from its name, Lu said.
It has also renamed its web site www.-.com and aims to supply more and updated information, he continued.

The center has taken the initiative in contacting media in Hong Kong and overseas to report on human rights and the democratic movement on the mainland since 1995, becoming one of the major sources of information on these issues.

TEXT.P: Buoyed by a Wall Street rebound, the Taiwan stock market continued its upward swing on Tuesday, with the benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index gaining 313.35 points to close at 9,307.03.
Market turnover amounted to NT$193.22 billion (US$6.34 billion).
