DOC.HEADLINE: US ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN DOWN 62.4% IN FY1999
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 17 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The United States sold US$559 million worth of weapons and military equipment to Taiwan in fiscal 1999, marking a significant decline of 62.4 percent from the previous fiscal year, according to a Pentagon report.

The annual report, which was referred to Congress on Monday, said Taiwan was the fifth largest buyer of US weaponry and military equipment in the fiscal year from Oct. 1, 1998 to Sept. 30, 1999, down from its third-place ranking in fiscal 1998.

US arms sales reached a peak in the following year after the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis when mainland China test-fired missiles and conducted live-fire war games at Taiwan's doorstep in an apparent attempt to influence the outcome of the island's first-ever direct presidential election.
Pentagon tallies show that Taiwan's US arms purchases totaled US$852 million in 1996, US$5.7 billion in 1997, US$1.5 billion in 1998 and US$559 million in 1999.
According to the annual Pentagon report, the United States exported a total of US$12 billion worth weaponry and military equipment in fiscal 1999, up 44 percent from the previous year.
Israel was the top US arms buyer in 1999, purchasing US$2.3 billion worth of weapons and military equipment. It was followed by Egypt, Saudi Arabia, Singapore and Taiwan, in that order.
In contrast, the top three US arms clients in fiscal 1998 were Saudi Arabia, Israel and Taiwan.
The Pentagon predicted that US arms sales will continue rising in the next two years, with its total arms exports estimated at US$15.7 billion for fiscal 2001.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC LEGISLATORS CALL FOR POSITIVE RESPONSE FROM MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Several legislators on Tuesday appealed for mainland China to respond positively to the goodwill gestures made by President-elect Chen Shui-bian on cross-strait relations amid reports that the United States has decided against the sale of high-tech Aegis warships to Taiwan under pressure from the mainland.

Legislator Hung Tu of the Kuomintang said that the reason behind the cross-strait tensions lies in Beijing, adding that as the mainland has targeted many missiles against Taiwan, Taiwan needs anti-missile weaponry for its own protection.

Hung expressed the hope that Beijing will show its goodwill by taking substantial action, such as destroying its missiles and disarming its submarines, so that Taiwan can reallocate money from its national defense budget to domestic development.

Another KMT Legislator Huang Mu-tien noted that Beijing has used vitriolic verbal attacks and military intimidation against Taiwan, saying that the mainland government has not realized many of the people on Taiwan are originally from the mainland and it should show its goodwill toward Taiwan's people.

He noted that the two Koreas have agreed to talk and the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait should do the same to try to bridge their differences and promote the welfare of the peoples on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

Tang Pi-er of the Democratic Progressive Party also said that Beijing should respond positively to Chen's "soft and subtle" approach toward cross-strait relations, adding that Beijing's big brother mentality has caused tensions across the Taiwan Strait.

Beijing had implicitly warned Taiwan voters against choosing Chen Shub-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party prior to the March 18 presidential election, but Chen has sounded conciliatory notes toward the mainland since his election victory.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CONTINUES UPWARD STREAK ON WALL STREET RALLY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market continued its upward swing on Tuesday because of a Wall Street strong rebound on Monday.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index advanced 313.35 points to close at 9,307.03. The gain marked a 3.5 percent rise from Monday's finish.
Market analysts attributed the rise mainly to the technology-heavy Nasdaq index's sharp rebound on Monday.
Led by electronics issues, the Taiex opened at 9,220.96 points and hit a high of 9,389.35 at one point, but weakened mildly in the final session.
A total of 3.15 billion shares changed hands during the three-hour trading session on a market turnover of NT$193.22 billion (US$6.34 billion).
Gainers outnumbered losers 537 to 41, with 34 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories registered encouraging gains, with pulp and paper issues gaining 1.1 percent; electrical stocks rising 4 percent; plastics and chemical stocks picking up 3.8 percent; textiles advancing 3.1 percent; foodstuff issues edging up 1.1 percent; financial stocks surging 2.4 percent; construction issues gaining 2.8 percent; cement issues advancing 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP LEGISLATOR IN GUANGZHOU FOR E-COMMERCE FORUM

TEXT.P: Legislator Hsu Jung-shu of the Democratic Progressive Party led a group to mainland China to attend a two-day e-commerce forum being held in Guangzhou beginning on Tuesday.

Hsu has become the first ROC legislator to enter mainland China since the DPP's Chen Shui-bian won the March 18 presidential election. Beijing had implicitly warned Taiwan voters against voting for Chen because the DPP had advocated independence in the past.
Hsu told the CNA in a telephone interview that she hopes both sides of the Taiwan Strait can ease tensions through various exchanges via such activities as high-tech seminars.

Hsu, who is a convenor of the Technology Committee in the Legislative Yuan, will preside over a discussion Wednesday on issues related to Taiwan businesses taking part in the mainland's high-tech sector.
Hsu said her group which include her son and aides was well received upon arrival in Guangzhou, Guangdong province Monday night via Hong Kong.
Hsu said that she will visit the mainland again to attend an international business conference being held in Beijing in September.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET RALLIES ON STOCK GAINS

TEXT.P: Futures prices for Taipei's stock index continued rising on Tuesday, as the Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Index (TAIEX) futures for April rose 299 points to close at 9,302, with a volume of 612 contract transactions.
Market analysts attributed the continued Taiex index futures' rise mainly to the local stock market gains triggered by a Wall Street rebound.

TAIEX futures for May soared 247 points to finish at 9,302, with 612 contract transactions; June futures moved up 269 points to close at 9,329, with 50 contract transactions; September futures edged up 2 points to finish at 9,435, with three contract transactions; and December futures picked up 630 points to close at 9,631.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on electronics shares and financial stocks listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, both reported positive results.

April TE futures moved up 19 points to close at 506, with 247 contract transactions; May TE futures surged 15.1 points to finish at 507.1, with 1,015 contract transactions; and June TE futures edged up 15.3 points to close at 513.3, with 19 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

April TF futures increased 17.8 points to finish at 950.8, with 121 contract transactions; May TF futures moved up 20 points to close at 956, with 158 contract transactions; and June TF futures surged 3 points to finish at 968, with one contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT CHEN SHUI-BIAN HONORED BY HOUSTON MAYOR
DOC.DATELINE: Dallas, April 17 (CNA) (By Chang Hui-yen and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu were honored by Houston Mayor Lee Brown as "honorary citizens and friendly ambassadors" of the US city.

According to W. C. Feng, representative of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Houston, Brown sent a congratulatory message and certificates to Chen and Lu via his office on April 12. TECO then submitted the documents from Houston to the ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs in Taipei.

Feng had reportedly paid a visit to Brown at the Houston city government building following Chen's victory in the ROC's presidential election on March 18. He also sent a letter to the Houston's city councilors informing them of the election result.

Brown said in his letter that he, on behalf of all Houston citizens, wished to congratulate Chen for his victory in Taiwan's March 18 presidential election. He also praised Chen for his capable performance when serving as Taipei city mayor, and expressed his belief that the welfare of the people of Taiwan will be further improved under his leadership.
Brown also said that Houston is deeply proud of its twin-city ties with Taipei, which allow for increased cultural, educational and commercial exchanges between the two cities.
"Because of the efforts made by the Houston TECO office and Taiwan immigrants, I believe that the special links between the two cities should continue," he added.
Taipei and Houston forged their sisterhood ties more than 30 years ago, in the first-ever twin-city agreement for both cities.

In addition, Houston City Councilor Rob Todd, who maintains very close ties with Taipei government figures, also sent a congratulatory letter to TECO in Houston for Chen's election as "the ROC's tenth president."

Taiwan and the United States have shared a common history in Asia-Pacific affairs, and the time now seems right to adjust bilateral relations to better reflect the close trade and commercial ties between the two countries, Todd pointed out.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 18, or the 14th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important evens that have occurred on this date in the past:
1480: Lucrezia Borgia, the illegitimate daughter of Pope Alexander VI, is born in Italy. She was married three times by the age of 18 to further her father's political ambitions.
1906: An earthquake devastates San Francisco, killing more than 1,000 people and making 300,000 others homeless.
1925: The first world women's exposition is opened in Chicago.
1927: The national government is established in Nanking by the Kuomintang.
1933: Fighting spreads in North China, as several strategic passes along the Great Wall fall to the Japanese.
1942: Planes from a US aircraft carrier bomb Tokyo for the first time. They were commanded by Lt. Gen. James Doolittle.
1943: Isoroku Yamamoto, Japanese naval officer, is killed when his plane is shot down by US warplanes over the Solomon Islands. He planned Japan's naval strategies during World War II, including the attack on Peral Harbor in 1941.
1946: The League of Nations is formally dissolved.
1948: By a two-thirds majority, the first National Assembly approves temporary provisions granting emergency powers to the president during the ongoing anti-Communist campaign.
1949: The Republic of Ireland is formally proclaimed in Dublin.
1954: Gamal Abdel Nasser becomes prime minister of Egypt.
1955: Albert Einstein, the German-born American theoretical physicist who won a Nobel Prize in 1921 for his explanation of the photoelectric effect, dies at the age of 76. His specific and general theories of relativity revolutionized modern thought on the nature of space and time, and formed a theoretical base for the exploitation of atomic energy.
1968: Army officers in western Africa's Sierra Leone take over the government, dissolve the legislature and suspend the constitution.
1977: A boat capsizes near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan, killing 32 college students and teachers on board and injuring 16 others.
1980: The former Rhodesia becomes independent Zimbabwe under President Canaan Banana.
1982: Monaco's Prince Rainier III and his wife, Princess Grace Kelly, arrive in Taipei for a visit.
1988: The ROC Red Cross Society begins forwarding mail from Taiwan residents to mainland China.
1989: The Mainland Affairs Council under the Executive Yuan decides to permit Taiwan citizens to gather news and make films in mainland China.
1998: Official talks between South and North Korea end with the two sides failing to resolve a dispute over aid to the starving North and the reunion of separated families.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man may be known in three ways which I am not able to show in my own person. As a moral man he is free from anxiety; as a man of understanding he is free from doubt; and as a man of courage he is free from fear."

DOC.HEADLINE: THIRTEEN US SENATORS EXPRESS SUPPORT FOR TSEA

TEXT.P: Thirteen United States senators have voiced their support for the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act in a letter to Sen. Trent Lott (R-Miss) urging the Senate majority leader "to take the necessary steps to ascertain support in the Senate for the TSEA and call up this legislation at the earliest possible date, before the Senate votes on matters relating to China."

The senators said in the letter, initiated by Sen. Tim Hutchinson (R-Ark.) and dated April 10, that they were writing to request bringing before the Senate the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, which the House passed by a vote of 341-70 on February 1, 2000. "We believe that we must bring greater clarity to our relations with Taiwan and China by passing this legislation in the Senate," said the senators.

"We believe that China's threats (to use force) will only increase as Taiwan progresses down the path of democracy. In addition, a recent study by the Department of Defense indicates that the Taiwanese military faces a multitude of problems stemming from technological shortcomings, including an inability to adequately defend against air attacks, ballistic missiles and cruise missiles. These deficiencies can be attributed, at least in part, to the military's isolation," they pointed out.

The senators stressed that "the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act will underscore US support for Taiwan by increasing military exchanges with Taiwan, by establishing a direct military communications link with Taiwan, and by reestablishing Congress as a consultant in the annual arms sales process, as intended and required by the Taiwan Relations Act. We believe that these provisions will correct some of the inadequacies of the Taiwanese military and bring greater security to the people of Taiwan."

The letter was co-signed by Senators Robert Torricelli (D-NJ), Russ Feingold (D-Wis), Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska), Slade Gorton (R-Wash), Mike DeWine (R-Ohio), Jeff Sessions (R-Ala), Jon Kyl (R-Ariz), Susan Collins (R-Main), James Inhofe (R-Okla), Bob Smith (R-NH), Rick Santorum (R-Pa), and John Ashcroft (R-Mo).

The addition of another Democratic voice of support by Sen. Feingold for the TSEA "is a quantum leap forward," said Chen Wen-yen, president of the Formosan Association for Public Affairs, adding that "hopefully this will open the door for other Democratic senators to get behind this important legislation."

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.004 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Tuesday, closing at 30.535.
The local currency opened Tuesday at 30.555 and was traded between 30.483 and 30.555.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$776 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: HELMS BLASTS ADMINISTRATION'S HANDLING OF TAIWAN'S DEFENSE REQUEST

TEXT.P: US Senate Foreign Relations Committee Chairman Jesse Helms (R-NC) on Monday blasted the Clinton administration's politicized handling of Taiwan's defense request, stressing that this is "a clear demonstration of why the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act is so urgently needed."

In response to press reports that the Pentagon has recommended putting off Taiwan's request to purchase Aegis destroyers, Helms said "I am extremely disappointed to learn that the Pentagon has apparently succumbed to pressure from the State Department and the White House to sacrifice Taiwan's security in order to appease the dictators in Beijing."

Sen. Helms pointed out that for months "we in Congress were led by Defense Department officials to believe that the Pentagon was leading the fight to sell Aegis destroyers to Taiwan. Now we learn that they are doing no such thing. Moreover, we are learning that the Pentagon has apparently backed off its earlier commitment to provide Taiwan with urgently-needed early warning radars, recommending a delay until Taiwan can prove that it can integrate the radar into its system."

"This adds insult to injury. Any problems Taiwan's military would face integrating these systems would stem from no fault of its own, but rather from the 20 years of isolation that the United States has imposed on Taiwan. This administration has sunk to a new low indeed when they don't even have the courage to fulfill a commitment to sell a civil defense item to Taiwan for fear of offending Communist China," emphasized the senator.

"There is, quite simply, no military justification to deny Taiwan these critical defensive items. These denials are driven by a knee-jerk appeasement on the part of the White House and the State Department," noted Helms.

He said that "if the Pentagon will not stand up for Taiwan, then it is clear Congress will have to take action. If the administration follows through on these recommendations and denies Taiwan these critical defensive items, then the time will have come for the Senate to join the House in passing the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act."

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPERTS SEE LANDSCAPE CHANGING AFTER TECHNOLOGY STOCK SHAKEOUT

TEXT.P: The latest shake-out of technology stocks is expected to change the information technology landscape over the next two years and as many as three quarters of all "vapourware" operations will likely disappear, industry experts predicted.
Only companies with solid underlying technology or commercial applications providing logical revenue streams will remain and prosper, according to Pricewaterhouse Coopers.
Deutsche Asset Management agreed, saying that "companies with technology that makes a significant improvement in the way business is conducted will still flourish."

Experts from these and other companies believe the stock market fluctuations will have the most impact on investors less familiar with the technology end of the market who expected a speculative return, the Australian reported on Tuesday.
But other experts believe the slight deflation of the bubble will benefit the IT industry in the long run, leaving behind more sustainable businesses, according to the daily.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE CASINOS BECOMING POPULAR PLAYGROUND FOR RICH ASIAN STUDENTS

TEXT.P: Australian casinos in major cities are becoming popular playgrounds for rich students from Asian countries, including Indonesia, Taiwan, Japan, South Korea, Singapore, Malaysia and Hong Kong.

The casinos' attractiveness to young Asians came into the spotlight this week when Burswood Casino in Perth attracted a media report that a 17-year-old student from Asia lost A$200,000 (US$130,000) in one night.
Under the current gambling laws, the minimum age for entering casino venues is 18 years, gaming experts said.
They said casinos in Australia not only attract domestic and foreign tourists, but also Asian students who are studying in major cities throughout the country.

Student associations in Perth, Melbourne, Sydney and Brisbane said many students from Indonesia, Hong Kong, Taiwan, and other Southeast Asian countries are feeling bored in their studies and are turning to gambling dens for excitement.
"It is a common playground for these people who come from wealthy families," Fernando Widjaja, the president of the Indonesian Student Society in Perth, told the Australian on Monday.
He said problem student gamblers usually come from rich families in Singapore, Malaysia and Indonesia.
"Normally they are losing about A$400 to A$500 (US$250 to US$315) a night, but the maximum I have heard is about US$2000 or US$2500," he said.
He said many of the Asian students use their parents' credit cards to engage in gambling.
The daily quoted Jimmy Chu, president of the Association of Malaysian Students, as saying that he knew of students who had incurred big losses at casinos in Melbourne and Sydney.
Other student associations said casinos along the Gold Coast and in Brisbane are also common playgrounds for Asian students coming from rich Asian families.

As a result of the Burswood Casino newspaper report, gaming officials and police are now conducting a series of investigation into whether casinos in Perth and other Australian cities are breaching age restriction laws.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MAY SIGN TRADE ACCORDS WITH 4 LATIN AMERICAN COUNTRIES

TEXT.P: Taiwan is expected to sign trade accords with four Latin American countries to boost bilateral commerce and investment relations, Board of Foreign Trade Director-general Chen Rui-lung said on Tuesday.

According to Chen, Argentina, Brazil, Chile and Uruguay are considering agreements on investment guarantees and the avoidance of double taxation with Taiwan. The move is seen as an attempt by the Latin American nations to attract greater foreign investment.

Chen, who returned to Taiwan on Sunday from a five-nation South American tour which also took him to Paraguay, said that South American economies are gradually improving and that Taiwan's trade with those countries is expected to expand this year.

Both Argentina and Chile have in recent years lodged anti-dumping complaints against Taiwan-made textiles. In response to concerns about these actions, Chen said that Taiwan has made it clear to the two countries that any trade disputes should be resolved in compliance with the regulations of the World Trade Organization.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHIAYI MAYOR AGREES TO JOIN NEW CABINET AS INTERIOR MINISTER
DOC.DATELINE: Chiayi, southern Taiwan, April 18 (CNA) (By Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: Chiayi Mayor Chang Po-ya finally agreed on Tuesday to accept President-elect Chen Shui-bian's sincere invitation to join his administration as interior minister.

Chang, a former legislator and director-general of the Cabinet-level Department of Health, will concurrently serve as chairman of the Taiwan Provincial Government after Chen's administration is inaugurated on May 20.

With tears in her eyes, Chang told a news conference that it was a difficult decision for her to accept the new job because she was unwilling to part with Chiayi citizens whom she has regarded as her brothers and sisters.
"And I had found it was also very hard to turn down Chen's offer because the president-elect had made his invitation with such warm-heartedness," Chang explained.
Chen personally visited Chang at her residence in the southern Chiayi city on Sunday to persuade Chang to assume the top post at the Ministry of the Interior.
"Chen had repeatedly asked me to put national interests about any personal considerations and to take up the new challenge," said Chang, a non-partisan doctor-turned-politician.

Chang said Premier-designate Tang Fei had also sincerely invited her to join his Cabinet as the interior minister before he checked into Taipei's Veterans General Hospital last weekend to undergo an operation to remove a chest tumor.

Chang said Chen had assured her that his administration will delegate more power to local-level governments. "After I assume the ministerial post, I will faithfully reflect grassroots public opinion and demand to the central government," she assured Chiayi residents, adding she believes that her experience in local government administration will be useful to her new work.

Chang will be the first interior minister to concurrently serve as chairman of the Taiwan Provincial Government, which has been downsized in line with the government's plan to cut red tape and improve administrative efficiency and national competitiveness.
Chang promised to take good care of every provincial government staff member in concluding the difficult provincial government downsizing work.

Chang, who has a master's degree in public health from US-based Johns Hopkins University and a doctoral degree in medicine from Japan's Kyorin University, came from a noted political family in Chiayi. Chang stressed that her initial reluctance to accept the new Cabinet post has nothing to do with her family interests.

Chang had served two Chiayi mayoral terms before becoming a legislator. After serving as a lawmaker for just about six months, she was appointed director-general of the Department of Health. During that period, her elder sister Chang Wen-ying was twice elected Chiayi mayor. And Chang was again elected Chiayi mayor in late 1997 for a four-year term.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE EDITORIAL URGES GOODWILL & SINCERITY ACROSS TAIWAN STRAIT
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 18 (CNA) (By Huang Kui-mei and Eva Chen)

TEXT.P: The Sankei Shimbun in its Tuesday editorial urged Beijing authorities to demonstrate reciprocal goodwill and sincerity to match to that recently shown by President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the Republic of China.

In an editorial, the Japanese daily paid tribute to Chen's remarks to its reporters made during an exclusive interview on Sunday. In the interview, Chen reaffirmed his "three noes" policy, and noted that his May 20 inaugural speech will be based on goodwill and sincerity, and will be aimed at easing cross-strait tensions.

Chen said that as long as Beijing does not use force against Taiwan, the "three noes" policy can be maintained. This policy refers to his pledge that he will not promote "special state-to-state relations" between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, will not put issues of Taiwan independence or unification with the mainland to a plebiscite, and will not change the name of the "Republic of China."

The editorial highly praised the President-elect's remarks that "maintaining peace and stability across the Taiwan Strait is not only the supreme goal but also a moral obligation" for him as president of the country.

Chen's "soft" approach in dealing with cross-strait ties was construed as having some connection with the 39.3 percent of votes he garnered in the March 18 presidential election. With over 60 percent of voters not throwing their support behind him, he has to deliver a peaceful message to the Chinese mainland, the editorial pointed out.

The Beijing authorities have done their best to avoid criticizing Chen to date. They have instead adopted a wait-and-see attitude toward Chen's May 20 inaugural speech, which Chen has disclosed will be based on "goodwill and sincerity." The editorial expressed the hope that Beijing will respond with the same mentality.

In view of the fact that Taiwan's leader is directly elected by the island's voters, Beijing should have a clearer understanding of the matter, the editorial concluded. The editorial is referring to Beijing's February 21 white paper on Taiwan, which was followed by mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji's warnings to the pro-independence forces in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATIVE YUAN APPROVES ROC-MACEDONIA PARLIAMENTARY EXCHANGE PACT

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan, the nation's highest law-making body, approved on Tuesday the Republic of China-Macedonia Parliamentary exchange project proposed by the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) as a means of strengthening bilateral relations between the two countries.

Under the program, the two parliaments will share cultural, science and technology interchanges. Parliamentarians from both countries will visit and meet with their counterparts in the opposite country every six months.

Wang Jin-pyng, president of the Legislative Yuan, said that a Macedonian Parliamentary Delegation to be led by Savo Klimovski, speaker of the parliament, will visit Taipei in May to take part in the first parliamentary exchange between the two countries.
Vice President of the Legislative Yuan Yao Eng-chi will head a 20-member Republic of China delegation to participate in that meeting.
The project, officially known as the Joint Parliamentary Council between the Republic of China and the Republic of Macedonia, will have a three-year duration.
The project contains a 10-point platform which can be broken down as follows:
--To monitor cooperative pacts between the two countries, and to implement related cooperative projects;
--To build an export processing zone in Macedonia to promote economic interchanges between the two countries;
--To cooperate on the development of science, culture and the arts;
--To hold a comparative seminar on the political and jurisprudence systems of the two countries;

--For Macedonia to share its experiences as a participant in the International Parliamentary Union, the European Parliamentary Council, the European Security Cooperation Organization, the Western European Union and the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO);

--For the president and vice president of both parliaments to lead a delegation to the opposite country every six months; and for members of the foreign relations committees of the two parliaments to visit each other every year;
--For staff members of the two parliaments to strengthen interchanges by attending the seminars;
--To encourage the interchanges and cooperation of non-governmental organizations from both countries; and
--To allow for extraordinary meetings when both parliaments agree that such meetings are necessary.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMOSA PLASTICS GROUP TO ENTER LOCAL DIESEL MARKET

TEXT.P: Diesel produced by a naphtha cracker operated by the Formosa Plastics Group (FPG) will be put on the domestic market soon, breaking the monopoly of the state-run Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC).

Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) officials said on Tuesday that FPG-produced diesel and kerosene have completed quality testing, and that the MOEA is expected to approve the group's application to market diesel commercially later this month.
It has also been reported that Taiwan Power Co. (Taipower), a major diesel customer, has received a letter from FPG demanding that it start buying its diesel through open bidding.

Taipower procures about 400,000 kiloliters of premier diesel and 70,000 kiloliters of ordinary diesel per year for use in thermo-power generation, at a cost of NT$7 billion (US$225.8 million) at current prices.
Other major prospective customers include Taiwan Motor Transport Corp., Ret-Ser Engineering Agency, and China Engineering Corp.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN VOWS NOT TO ALLOW `POLITICAL' TAMPERING WITH CONTROL YUAN

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday that his administration will not interfere with Control Yuan operations simply for political reasons.
He made the pledge during a visit to the Control Yuan, the Republic of China's highest watchdog body.

Chen noted that during his stint as Taipei mayor from 1994 through 1998, he was once censured by the Control Yuan and that some other Taipei city government officials were even impeached by the watchdog body.
"I was grateful for the Control Yuan's move because it prompted me to do some soul-searching and to make the necessary improvements," Chen recalled.

The lawyer-turned-politician urged all domestic political groups and factions to refrain from interfering with Control Yuan operations so that the watchdog body can maintain its neutrality and fulfill its function of helping ensure clean politics in Taiwan.

Chen went on to say that in the new millennium, he will exhort his administration to adopt a forward-thinking attitude, practice constant self-reflection and self-improvement, and strengthen communications with the general public to cope with changing social trends and allow the smooth implementation of policy.
Chen further said he feels that politicians' happiness lies in "acquiring peace of mind."
In their talks with Chen, Control Yuan President Fredrick Chien and several other Control Yuan members expressed hope that the watchdog body's functions can be strengthened under the new government.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE DECORATES VISITING US SENATOR

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui conferred on Tuesday the order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon on US Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) for his contributions to promoting bilateral relations between the ROC and the United States.

The award presentation ceremony, held at the Presidential Office, was witnessed by various local and American dignitaries, including Secretary-General to the President Ding Mou-shih, Vice Secretary-General to the President Lin Pi-chao, Vice Foreign Minister David Lee and Director of the American Institute in Taiwan (AIT) Taipei Office Raymond Bughard.
In an address following the ceremony, Murkowski described the award as a great honor, and he pledged to continue his staunch support for the ROC.
The senator also invited Lee to visit his home state after he steps down as president on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: AEGIS CRITICAL TO TAIWAN'S DEFENSE: DEFENSE MINISTER-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: Defense Minister-designate Wu Shih-wen said on Tuesday that Aegis destroyers are critical to defend Taiwan's security.
Wu, incumbent vice defense minister, made the remarks while attending a meeting at the Legislative Yuan.
Wu said he has not yet received any information concerning whether the United States will sell Aegis warships to Taiwan this year.
Delegates from the Republic of China and the United States are meeting in Washington, D.C. to review Taiwan's defense needs and its weaponry and military equipment procurement plan.

Press reports from Washington said the Clinton administration has deferred a decision to sell four highly sophisticated Aegis destroyers to Taiwan as part of its efforts to avoid a new confrontation with mainland China.

According to those reports, the Clinton administration has instead agreed to sell some other weaponry systems and military equipment to Taiwan, including advanced AIM-120 medium-range air-to-air missiles and a long-range radar, known as PAVE PAWS, that can peer deep into mainland China to detect missile launches.
Wu declined to make any comment on those reports, saying he has not yet received any information concerning ongoing arms purchase talks between the two sides.

Wu explained that the Aegis-equipped destroyers can serve as a seaborne base for anti-ballistic missile defense systems. In view of Beijing's mounting missile threat to Taiwan, Wu said, Aegis destroyers are crucial to defend Taiwan's security.

Asked whether Taiwan has a strong desire to acquire Aegis destroyers, Wu said the ROC military has many expectations concerning acquisition of sophisticated defensive weapons. "Whether we can realize our goal will depend on our effort," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT MUST EXCHANGE VIEWS WITH US ON TSEA: US SENATOR

TEXT.P: US Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) on Tuesday called on Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian to exchange views on how to strengthen bilateral ties between Taiwan and the United States.

The visiting senator told Chen that he hopes that after his May 20 inauguration, he will formally and completely address the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) issue now at a crucial juncture and being deliberated by the US Senate.

Murkowski said that cross-Taiwan Strait relations are stalemated and noted that the Clinton Administration has postponed selling Aegis destroyers to Taiwan but has agreed to sell the long-range radar system known as PAVE PAWS to Taiwan.

He said that before he left for his ROC trip, he talked with his colleagues in Congress about the proposed TSEA and American military commitments to Taiwan's security, and added that the issue is important to the security of Taiwan and should be closely monitored by the Taiwan authorities.

Chen for his part expressed the hope that Murkowski will support the ROC's bid to enter the World Trade Organization (WTO) and the World Health Organization (WHO). Taiwan is currently seeking observer status in the WHO.

DOC.HEADLINE: US AGREEES SALE OF ARMS BUT NO DESTROYERS TO TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 18 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The US administration gave a greenlight to the sale of a package of arms to Taiwan but has deferred a decision on the controversial sale of four destroyers with the Aegis combat management system, US officials said on Tuesday.

President Bill Clinton met with top administration officials on Monday and agreed to postpone decisions on Taiwan's requests for the Aegis destroyers, P-3 Orion anti-submarine aircraft and diesel submarines, pending a comprehensive review of Taiwan's defense needs, said the officials who requested anonymity.

The Aegis destroyer, with a price tag of about US$1.1 billion, is an Arleigh Burke-class destroyer equipped with an array of radar and computer equipment which can monitor, track and engage up to 100 targets simultaneously at ranges of up to 461 km.

However, the White House approved the sale of a long-distance radar system known as PAVE PAWS, with the caveat that Taiwan should demonstrate how it will integrate the radar with its existing air defense system.
PAVE PAWS radar can detect missile launches within a distance of 3,000 miles and can link up with anti-missile systems under development by the United States.
US officials hinted that the PAVE PAWS radar to be sold to Taiwan will not be as powerful as the version used by the US armed forces, but will greatly boost Taiwan's early warning capability.
Also approved were the sales of advanced medium-range air-to-air missiles (AMRAAM), and an upgraded version of the infrared-guided Maverick anti-ship missiles.

AMRAAM, which has not been sold to Asian states before, will be kept on US soil, and Taiwan pilots will be trained to use it in the United States. To avoid an arms race in the region, the missiles will not be moved to Taiwan unless mainland China acquires equally advanced Russian-made missiles, said the officials.

In interviews with the New York Times and the Washington Post, Undersecretary of Defense Walter B. Slocombe described the sales as a robust package, and said the United States does not have to feel sorry about the items left out of the package.

The Washington Post said that pro-Taiwan members of the US Congress could still press the administration to reinstate the Aegis destroyers into the package, or replace them with something else as compensation.

US Senate Republican Leader Trent Lott, who favored selling the Aegis destroyers (which would have been built in his home state of Mississippi), said he will reserve his comments until the official announcement of the decision.
Meanwhile Republican Sen. Jesse Helms criticized the Pentagon, saying it has no military justification in denying Taiwan "these crucial defensive items."
He criticized the Pentagon for bowing to pressure from the White House and the State Department "to sacrifice Taiwan's security in order to appease the dictators in Beijing."

"The politicized handling of Taiwan's defense request is a clear demonstration of why the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act is so urgently needed," said Helms. He was referring to a bill sponsored by Taiwan supporters in Congress in defiance of the White House's opposition to strengthened US military ties with Taiwan.

The chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee derided the Pentagon's decision to sell Taiwan the PAVE PAWS radar system only after the island has shown how it could be integrated into Taiwan's air defense system, describing it as "adding insult to injury."

DOC.HEADLINE: 14 MAINLAND CHINESE FISHING BOATS INTERCEPTED FOR POACHING

TEXT.P: Kinmen-based maritime patrol police on Tuesday intercepted one trawler and 13 motorized sampans from mainland China caught poaching in Republic of China territorial waters.

Officials from the Kinmen squadron of the Cabinet-level Coast Guard Administration (CGA) said they believed that better weather and calmer seas have encouraged mainland Chinese fishermen to cross the tacit central demarcation line in the Taiwan Strait dividing Taiwan and mainland China waters.
According to the CGA Kinmen officials, seven motorized sampans, with 14 fishermen aboard, were first discovered off the coast of Kinmen's Liaoluo Bay at around 8:30 a.m. on Tuesday.

The sampans were told via loudspeaker to leave ROC waters, but the warnings were apparently ignored, and the Kinmen maritime police approached the cluster of vessels and ordered them to sail to the nearest Kinmen fishing port.
Soon after the interception, another seven mainland Chinese vessels, including the trawler and six more motorized sampans, were caught poaching in waters near Kukang, a harbor on Kinmen.

The Kinmen maritime police confiscated the fishing gear and catch aboard the 14 vessels and after interrogation, escorted the boats and fishermen out of the 24-nautical-mile zone defining ROC territorial waters at around noon.

Kinmen maritime police said since the Kinmen CGA squadron was established more than four months ago, it has intercepted more than 200 mainland Chinese fishing boats for poaching, including using dynamite to bomb fish, and has brought in nearly 1,000 mainland fishermen for questioning.

The Kinmen maritime police said they have tightened surveillance and increased arrests for poaching, as local fishermen are making increasing complaints about their livelihoods being affected by depleted fish stocks caused by their rivals from the mainland.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL SPORTING GOODS FAIR ATTRACTS RECORD VISITORS

TEXT.P: The 27th Taipei International Sporting Goods Exhibition concluded at the Taipei World Trade Center on Tuesday after attracting more visitors than ever before, according to the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA).
An official of CETRA, which sponsored the event, said that the four-day fair attracted about 8,000 visitors, representing a 10 percent increase over the last sporting goods exhibition.
The official noted that of the visitors, 2,500 were from foreign countries, mainly Japan, the United States, South Korea, Hong Kong and Australia.

A total of 352 local sporting goods manufacturers and traders set up 1,329 booths to display their products at the exhibition, and some of the exhibitors reported considerable orders, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC UNIVERSITY SIGNS COOPERATION CONTRACT WITH JAPANESE UNIVERSITY

TEXT.P: The Tainan-based National Cheng Kung University on Tuesday signed an academic cooperation contract with Japan's Kanazawa Industrial University.

The contract was signed by National Cheng Kung University President Ongg Cheng-yi and his Japanese counterpart Kenichi Ishikawa, following which Ongg stressed the importance of implementing concrete cooperative plans between the two universities.

Ishikawa for his part said that the two universities have in the past cultivated many outstanding talents in the field of industrial technology, and added that he believes bilateral exchanges will help advance the further development of the two universities.

Kanazawa Industrial University is the second foreign university to enter a cooperative relationship with National Cheng Kung University, following a similar agreement with Tokyo Industrial University.

DOC.HEADLINE: DALAI LAMA MIGHT SEND ENVOY TO TAIWAN PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Tibetan spiritual leader the Dalai Lama might send an envoy to the May 20 inauguration of Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian, an official at the Tibet Representative Office in Taipei said on Tuesday.

However, contrary to some wire service reports, the Dalai Lama will not be able to attend Chen's inauguration in person because of schedule conflicts, said the official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
He will travel to Germany and the Nordic states in May for visits planned a year ago, making an additional trip to Taiwan out of the question, said the official.

However, a personal envoy might show up at the gala on behalf of the Dalai Lama given the close ties between the people of Taiwan and Tibet and between Chen's Democratic Progressive Party and the Tibet Youth Congress.
The Dalai Lama, who visited Taiwan for the first time in 1997, has not ruled out the possibility of visiting the island sometime after May 20, the official added.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAJOR PARTIES AGREE NOT TO ABOLISH COUNCIL OF GRAND JUSTICES

TEXT.P: The National Assembly (NA) caucuses of the four major political parties on Tuesday agreed not to abolish the Council of Grand Justices.
On Monday, the assembly had adopted a controversial bill to call for the abolishment of the Council of Grand Justices.

Judicial Yuan President Weng Yueh-sheng issued a statement to stress that passage of the bill would be harmful to the interests of the people, and several legislators also criticized the assembly move.

In order to quell the controversy, the NA caucuses of the four major parties -- the Kuomintang, the Democratic Progressive Party, the New Party and the People First Party -- met on Tuesday, and reached an agreement to block the bill from its second reading, because "the timing is not appropriate."

Regarding whether the grand justices will continue to enjoy the privilege of holding their status as justices -- and their salaries -- for life, the caucuses agreed to let the NA give the matter further debate.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT LAWMAKER JOINS PEOPLE FIRST PARTY

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang lawmaker announced on Tuesday that he is quitting the KMT and joining the People First Party (PFP) of former Taiwan Provincial Governor and KMT stalwart James Soong.
Legislator Wang Tein-ging of the Legislative Yuan's committee on national defense made the announcement at a press conference held at the PFP's office at the Legislative Yuan.

Wang said that he made the decision in light of the fact that the party's outlook is similar to his own, and refuted allegations that he decided to join the PFP to gain the military dependents' votes in the next election, saying "such wording is beneath me."

A majority of ballots from military dependents' villages around the island were cast for Soong, who ran as an independent in the March 18 presidential election. Soong lost to the Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Shui-bian, and a group of his supporters formed the PFP on March 31.

Until the KMT's election debacle, military dependents' villages had long been considered a "vote granary" for KMT-nominated candidates. The KMT's Lien Chan suffered a humiliating defeat in the election, coming in a distant third behind Chen and Soong and marking an end to the party's 54-year rule on the island.

Wang slammed high-ranking KMT officials for failing to meet a call from grassroots KMT members for pushing a ticket of Lien and Soong hard enough in the election. It is believed that had the KMT nominated the Lien-Soong combination, it would have easily won the election.

He said another factor that caused him to decide to join the PFP is that the KMT cadres have not conducted serious self-criticism in the wake of defeat, but have instead blamed others for the party's failure to hold on to power.

Wang's wife has already joined the PFP, and has decided to race in the upcoming National Assembly election, originally slated for May 6 but postponed indefinitely while arguments continue as to whether the body should be abolished.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S CHOICE FOR MAC CHAIRMAN: NO `THREE LINKS' WITH BEIJING THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: The setting up of direct postal, trade and transportation links with mainland China this year is out of the question, Taiwan's possible incoming mainland affairs head said on Tuesday.
Tsai Ing-wen, a professor at National Chengchi University and an adviser to the National Security Council, made the comment after a meeting with President-elect Chen Shui-bian.
Tsai has been earmarked as chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) under Chen's administration.

Although Chen has declared his hope that the so-called "three links" can be implemented, Tsai ruled out such a possibility this year, even if Taiwan and mainland China can both be admitted this year to the World Trade Organization (WTO).

Rather than direct trade and transportation links between Taiwan and the mainland, said Tsai, WTO membership will be a better method of enabling the two sides to conduct negotiations and build a framework based on mutual trust.
"WTO entry would be an opportunity for both sides to open negotiations rather than an obligation to open each other's ports or to trade directly with each other," said Tsai.
Tsai said she has not yet decided whether she will accept Chen's offer to head the MAC, although she is reported to be impressed with Chen's keenness to have her as a member of his Cabinet.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The National Assembly will kill the constitutional reform proposal to abolish the Council of Grand Justices.
The China Times:
Tsai Ying-wen, a National Chengchi University professor, said to head the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council.
The United Daily News:
US President Bill Clinton approves arms deals with Taiwan.
The Liberty Times:
Chiayi Mayor Chang Po-ya agrees to join the new Cabinet as interior minister.
The China Post:
Clinton decides to sell weapons, but no destroyers.
The Taiwan News:
Clinton holds off Aegis sale to Taiwan.
The Taipei Times:
Missiles yes, Aegis no, says the United States.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET PLUNGES

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market weakened on Wednesday after two days of rally, with the benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index losing 202.63 points to close at 9,104.4.
Market turnover totaled NT$183.83 billion (US$6.03 billion) during the three-hour trading session.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET WEAKENS DESPITE WALL STREET RALLY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market declined on Wednesday despite continued Wall Street rally.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index lost 202.63 points to close at 9,104.4. The drop marked a 2.2 percent fall from Tuesday's finish.

Market analysts attributed the decline mainly to continued sell-off by foreign institutional investors to meet overseas redemption demands. Taiex tallies show that foreign financial institutions have sold more stocks than made purchases over the past seven consecutive trading sessions.

Encouraged by a Wall Street rally, the Taiex opened strong and surged 138 points in the first half hour of trading, but weakened after 10 a.m. amid profit-taking. Heavy selling in the final session drove the Taiex index to close at the day's low of 9,104.4.
Market turnover totaled NT$183.83 billion (US$5.66 billion), down from Tuesday's trading volume of NT$193.22 billion.
Gainers outnumbered losers 344 to 136, with 39 stocks remaining unchanged.

Some market analysts said the Taiex may drop further this week as foreign financial institutions are not expected to actively buy local stocks before the May 20 inauguration of Taiwan's new government. Meanwhile, several other market experts said they believe that the Taiex's future development will hinge on Wall Street performance and foreign institutional investors' operational directions.
