DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET PLUNGES ON STOCK SLUMP

TEXT.P: Futures prices for Taipei's stock index dropped on Wednesday in tandem with a slump in the local stock market.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Weighted Index (TAIEX) futures for April plummeted 141 points to close at 9,161, with a volume of 432 contract transactions.

Buoyed by a rise in the Taiex spot market, the Taiex index futures market opened higher and hit a high of 9,430 points for April futures at one time, but weakened steadily after mid-session due to poor performance of the spot market.

TAIEX futures for May declined 235 points to finish at 9,045, with 3,372 contract transactions; June futures fell 217 points to close at 9,112, with 52 contract transactions; September futures dropped 284 points to finish at 9,151, with one contract transactions; and December futures shed 400 points to close at 9,201.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on electronics shares and financial stocks listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, both reported negative results.

April TE futures moved down 12 points to close at 494, with 138 contract transactions; May TE futures dropped 15.6 points to finish at 491.5, with 991 contract transactions; and June TE futures edged down 10.3 points to close at 503, with 25 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
April TF futures slid 20.8 points to finish at 930, with 65 contract transactions; May TF futures moved down 18 points to close at 938, with 172 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: SMALL TOWN DOCTOR OFFERED POST IN NEW CABINET

TEXT.P: Chen Chin-huang, a community doctor who practices in Hsinkang, Chiayi County, said on Wednesday that he will try his best to be a bridge between the government and the people after he assumes his new post as a minister without portfolio in the new Cabinet.

Chen, 48, who graduated from National Taiwan University's prestigious medical school and has continued his medical practice for 19 years in the small town of Hsinkang, accepted an offer on Tuesday to be a minister without portfolio charged with the task of taking up function-oriented jobs in the Cabinet.

A medical professional who is also concerned with upholding the local culture and moral values, Chen helped establish the Hsinkang (New Port) Cultural and Educational Foundation 13 years ago. The foundation's goal is the moral regeneration of the port township where values have apparently weakened with the appearance of such things as lottery-style gambling and strip dancing troupes.

Since being formed, the foundation has sponsored numerous events giving local people more opportunities to interact socially in a more wholesome setting. It has supported the renowned "Cloud Gate" Ensemble financially, enabling it to survive and continue performing. It has also promoted a "clean up the streets" drive during the annual Matsu Traveling event where hundreds of thousands of Matsu worshippers pass through Hsinkang during their town-to-town parade.

Upon accepting the post of minister without portfolio, Chen said he will use the opportunity of working in public office to convey the desires and needs of the people to the government. Previously, he said, people could only express their wishes through legislators or city and county councilors, whom often were connected with either special interest groups or organized crime rings.

Chen is the first expert from the private sector to be recruited into the new Cabinet as a minister without portfolio. At least three or four more people are expected to be appointed to similar posts in the following days prior to the inauguration of the new government and president on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN URGED TO COOPERATE WITH US TO TAP ENERGY RESOURCES

TEXT.P: Taiwan would be better off if it tried as hard to secure energy resources from the United States as it does striving to obtain more and higher-grade defensive weapons, said a US senator in Taipei on Wednesday.

Senator Frank Murkowski (R-Alaska) said Taiwan should pay more attention to preparing for an energy shortage, which is likely to occur in the future, than to seeking to secure arms from the United States, which seems to be more concerned about Beijing's attitude on the issue.

Addressing a general meeting of the Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce, Murkowski urged Taiwan to cooperate with the United States to jointly explore the rich natural gas resources in his home state of Alaska.

Murkowski, a long-standing friend of Taiwan who strongly supports the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA), said the TSEA, now at the crucial juncture of being deliberated on by the US Senate, is expected to win more support than expected before in the Senate this spring.

He added that the Clinton administration's refusal to sell Aegis destroyers to Taiwan on Monday has outraged the pro-Taiwan US members of Congress and has further raised the possibility that the Senate will pass the TSEA.

Emphasizing the importance of energy resources, Murkowski said 56 percent of America's annual energy needs depend on imports from OPEC countries. For example, the US imports an average of 700,000 barrels of crude oil from Iraq each day, at a cost of US$4.6 billion. Ironically, the United States has kept bombing the Middle Eastern country while continuing to import crude oil from it, he said.
And some people believe that the collapse of share prices on Wall Street last week was mainly triggered by heightened oil prices, Murkowski noted.

He quoting Alan Greenspan, chair of the US Federal Reserve, as saying that for every 1 percent increase in the unit price of imported crude oil, the United States' financial burden increases by 0.5 percent because of the volume of crude oil it imports.

Taiwan's economy definitely will not be able to maintain long-term development if it gets caught in an energy shortage, particularly since its rival, mainland China, possesses large quantities of natural energy resources and has maintained close ties with OPEC governments for a long time, Murkowski noted.

So he urged Taiwan to accelerate its moves to cash in on Alaska's liquefied national gas (LNG) exploration project. By joining hands in the exploration project, Taiwan and the US can work together to lower the potential energy threat posed by the PRC and by OPEC and can help secure long-lasting mutual economic development as well, he added.

Murkowski, accompanied by his wife, arrived in Taipei on Monday for a three-day visit. He has met with President Lee Teng-hui, President-elect Chen Shui-bian, and other political figures and opinion leaders in Taiwan during the stay.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSTS TRADE DEFICIT FOR 1ST-HALF OF APRIL

TEXT.P: Despite double-digit growth in both export and import trade, Taiwan in the first half of April posted a trade deficit of US$312 million, officials from the Ministry of Finance (MOF) reported on Wednesday.

In the first 15 days of the month, Taiwan exported US$5.438 billion-worth of products, up 16.2 percent over the year-earlier level, while importing US$5.750 billion-worth of commodities, up a whopping 37.9 percent, MOF officials said.

According to MOF tallies, Taiwan sustained a slight trade deficit of US$20 million in February, but by the end of March, the deficit had shrunk and in fact became a surplus of US$440 million. It remains to be seen whether two-way trade for the whole of April will turn out to be a deficit or a surplus, and the officials said they are paying close attention to the situation.
Cumulatively, Taiwan's exports totaled US$37.978 billion between Jan. 1 and April 15 this year, marking a remarkable increase of 20.1 percent over the same period of the previous year.
During the same period, Taiwan's imports grew by 27.4 percent to the tune of US$36.444 billion.
As a result, Taiwan posted a surplus of US$1.534 billion in its two-way trade in the Jan. 1-April 15 period, MOF officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CRASHED AIR PHILIPPINES PLANE NOT SUPPLIED BY TAIWAN'S U-LAND

TEXT.P: Taipei-based U-Land Airlines said on Wednesday that it did not supply Air Philippines with a passenger plane which crashed earlier that same day.

Under the terms of a cooperative accord clinched by the two aviation companies in June 1998, U-Land originally agreed to provide three MD-83 airplanes to Air Philippines, but a U-Land spokesman said that one unit has already been recalled.

Although U-Land controls a one-third stake of Air Philippines, the spokesman said the Taipei-based aviation company does not participate in Air Philippines' operations, and stressed that the passenger plane which crashed near the southern Philippine city of Davao early on Wednesday does not belong to U-Land.

U-Land will therefore not be involved in any compensation issue related to the crash, the spokesman noted, and added that his company wishes to renew its cooperation talks with Air Philippines following the tragedy.
The Air Philippines Boeing 737-200 jet took off from Manila, but crashed near the southern Philippines city of Davao, killing all 126 passengers and crew on board.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUMAN RIGHTS WATCH CRITICIZES UN COMMISSION'S CHINA DECISION

TEXT.P: Human Rights Watch on Tuesday strongly condemned the United Nations Commission on Human Rights' decision not to consider a US-sponsored resolution criticizing Communist China's human rights record.
"By turning a blind eye to China's worsening human rights record, the delegations in Geneva have given the wrong signal to Beijing's leaders," said a Human Rights Watch spokesperson.

While saying the United States deserves credit for putting forward the resolution, the New York-based human rights group criticized the apparent lack of high-level White House involvement, including President Bill Clinton himself, in lobbying for the resolution.

Although White House Deputy Press Secretary P.J. Crowley said the United States is disappointed with the UN decision not to take action, the State Department pointed out in a Tuesday statement that the US had accomplished its goals, saying the trend of decreasing support for the "no-action" motion means that "a growing number of countries now recognize that China should not be permitted to escape scrutiny of its human rights record and should not prevent the Commission from fulfilling its mandate."

The statement, issued by US Ambassador to the UN Commission on Human Rights Nancy Rubin and Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor Harold Hongju Koh, said the intention of the United States was "to speak up for the Chinese people and to focus international attention on the marked deterioration in the human rights situation in China during the past year."

Human Rights Watch also criticized the European Union, Australia, Canada and Japan, all of which had professed concern about the human rights situation in mainland China, for declining to co-sponsor the resolution or to actively lobby against the no-action motion.
The procedural "no-action motion" was adopted Tuesday by a vote of 22 for and 18 against, with 12 abstentions.

"The credibility of the UN Commission has been seriously damaged by its unwillingness to censure China, or even to discuss its human rights performance," said the Human Rights Watch spokesperson, asking: "What incentives will Beijing now have to go beyond dialogue and legal exchanges to make serious improvements in its human rights practices?"

In 1999, a resolution condemning China's human rights record sponsored by the US and Poland was also blocked by a no-action motion. However, a similar resolution came up for debate in 1995 and was only defeated by a single vote. That year, the EU and the US both co-sponsored the measure and coordinated a high level campaign to counter Beijing's worldwide lobbying effort to defeat it, noted the spokesperson.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEN. HELMS BLASTS INADEQUATE US ARMS SALES TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: US Sen. Jesse Helms (R-NC), chairman of the Senate Committee on Foreign Relations, on Tuesday again blasted the Clinton administration's failure to consult with Congress on arms sales to Taiwan, saying "it has once again flagrantly violated the Taiwan Relations Act by giving Beijing a veto over Taiwan's defense requests."

Following Clinton's decision on Monday to put off accepting Taiwan's request for four Aegis destroyers, Sen. Helms criticized the politicized handling of Taiwan's defense request, adding that "this is a clear demonstration of why the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act is so urgently needed."
The legislation is still pending in the Senate after the House of Representatives passed it by an overwhelming 341-70 vote on Feb. 1.

Sen. Helms pointed out that the administration's decision on defense sales to Taiwan is totally inadequate, saying "they would have us believe that they approved a robust package for Taiwan, but in fact, only one of Taiwan's six major requests, the Maverick missile, was approved."

He added that "given the Orwellian spin the administration is putting on the long-range early warning radars, in which repeating last year's deal is being touted as a new agreement, why should the American people be confident that the Maverick sale will ever take place?"

"Similar deja vu surrounds the AMRAAM announcement. The training package announced yesterday was also announced in April 1999. Moreover, the notion of selling the missiles to Taiwan, but not letting them take possession of them, is an insult. What is Taiwan to do, call FedEx for its AMRAAMs after China attacks?" asked the senator.

Helms added that "the American people's gullibility is likewise assumed with the so-called maritime assessment. The air defense assessment of 1999 argued for providing Aegis systems to Taiwan but the Clinton administration has refused to provide them. Why should the American people believe the maritime assessment's recommendations won't also be sent to the circular file as well?"

DOC.HEADLINE: US ARMS SALES PACKAGE TO TAIWAN PART OF ONGOING PROCESS

TEXT.P: The US Defense Department stressed Tuesday that the arms sales package recommended by the Pentagon and adopted by both President Bill Clinton and his national security team this year is another part of the ongoing process of helping Taiwan meet its defensive needs.

While declining to describe the package in detail, Pentagon spokesman Kenneth Bacon told reporters that "I think the important thing to stress is that it is part of a process, that over the years the United States has authorized fairly extensive arms sales to Taiwan under the Taiwan Relations Act, which commits us to helping Taiwan meet its defensive needs."

Bacon emphasized that the United States has sold approximately US$18 billion worth of arms to Taiwan over an extended period of time, including F-16s, Knox-class frigates, air defense missiles, radars, tanks to defend against amphibious invasion, Patriot missiles, among other types of military equipment.

As to whether Pentagon officials have discussed the arms sale to Taiwan with visiting People's Liberation Army Navy Commander Shih Yunsheng, Bacon said "we do not consult with the People's Republic of China about our responsibilities in helping Taiwan meet its defensive needs."

"Obviously, the Chinese have strong views about our relationship with Taiwan. as do we. Our relationship with Taiwan is well-specified in law and we have explained that law to the people from the mainland many, many times, and I think they understand what the law requires us to do," noted the spokesman.

Bacon added that "we have made it very clear to the PRC that because we, under the law, help Taiwan respond to defensive needs, the greater the threat posed by China, the greater Taiwan's defensive needs will be. And we have called on both sides to show restraint -- particularly on the Chinese -- to show restraint in their arms developments and deployments and use of arms."

On the topic of the PLA's missile deployments along the mainland coast opposite Taiwan, Bacon said, "(Commander-in-Chief of the US Pacific Command) Admiral Blair quantified it here in a briefing. He said they're adding about 50 surface-to-surface missiles a year, and nothing has changed that pace as far as I know."

On the question of whether the US arms sale package to Taiwan this year includes any weapons to counter the Chinese missile threat, Bacon replied that "in the past we have sold Taiwan versions of the Patriot missile, and it's no secret that last year we made a decision to help Taiwan upgrade its early warning radars, and that process will continue."
He also pointed out that this arms sales package also includes "several weapons that the US approved for the first time, some that we have denied in the past and approved this time around."

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 19, or the 15th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1832: Jose Echegaray y Eizaguirre, Spanish dramatist, mathematician, statesman and Nobel Laureate, is born.
1853: Russia claims to be the protectorate of Turkey in a prelude to the Crimean War.
1882: British naturalist Charles Darwin dies at the age of 73. He revolutionized the study of biology with his theory of evolution based on natural selection. His most famous works include "Origin of Species," and "The Descent of Man."
1906: French chemist and physicist Pierre Curie is run over and killed in Paris at the age of 47. He and his wife Marie shared the 1903 Nobel Prize for fundamental research into radioactivity.
1928: Japanese troops occupy Shantung Province in northern China.
1942: Chinese Expeditionary Forces led by Gen. Sun Li-jen capture Yenangyuang in northern Burma, rescuing more than 7,000 British and Burmese troops from Japanese encirclement.
1948: The first National Assembly elects Chiang Kai-shek as the China's first president under the new Constitution, garnering 2,430 out of 2,704 votes.
1956: Prince Rainier of Monaco marries American screen actress Grace Kelly in Monte Carlo. Over 1,200 guests attend the televised Catholic wedding ceremony.
1959: The Dalai Lama, the Tibetan leader fleeing a communist Chinese invasion of his country, finds sanctuary in India.
1960: South Korean President Syngman Rhee is toppled in a nationwide pro-democracy student uprising that was protesting election fraud.
1966: Australian troops leave Sydney to join American forces in Vietnam.
1974: The Blood Donation Association of the Republic of China is inaugurated.
1975: India's first satellite is launched by a Soviet rocket.
1977: ROC Education Minister Tsiang Yien-si resigns to take responsibility for an incident in which 32 college students and teachers were killed when their boat capsized near Suao Port in eastern Taiwan. Tsiang was succeeded by Li Yuan-zu.
1992: Dutch Minister of Foreign Trade Yvonne van Rooy visits Taipei to seek stronger bilateral relations.
1993: A total of 87 Branch Davidian cult members, including their leader David Koresh, are killed when federal agents storm their compound in Waco, Texas, after a 51-day standoff. Nine other members are freed.
1995: A huge truck bomb destroys the Alfred P. Murrah government building in Oklahoma City, killing 168 people and injuring more than 400 others.
1995: Malawi President Bakili Muluzi pays a state visit to Taipei.
1997: The SS Sheng Da, a mainland China container freighter, steams into Kaohsiung Port on its maiden voyage, becoming the first ship to sail directly to Taiwan from the mainland in 48 years, and completing an historic crossing of one of the world's great political divides.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be not concerned that men do not know you; be concerned that you have no ability."

DOC.HEADLINE: US SENATOR CALLS ON CPC EXECUTIVE

TEXT.P: US Senator Frank Murkowski (R, Alaska) visited Chinese Petroleum Corp. (CPC) President W.Y. Pan on Wednesday in an effort to seek cooperation opportunities between Taiwan and Alaska.
Following the meeting, a ranking CPC official said the CPC will further assess Murkowski's proposal that the two sides jointly explore for natural gas in Alaska.

However, according to the official, local demand-supply level for natural gas is evenly balanced. As the state-run enterprise has already inked three purchase agreements with other foreign companies, it will be hard for the CPC to sign any new pact to buy natural gas in the short term, he noted.

Although the state-owned Taiwan Power Company is set to complete construction of a power generation station in Tatan in northern Taiwan which will require about 1.9 million tons of natural gas each year, the CPC official said it remains unclear at present whether the CPC or other local companies will undertake to supply natural gas to the facility.

It is understood that the Tuntex Group and the China Development Corp. are also seeking to set up a natural gas power supply station in northern Taiwan or to play the role of natural gas supplier to the planned establishment.

Nevertheless, the CPC official also pointed out that the chances of CPC-Alaska cooperation will be greater if Murkowski's proposal referred to joint exploration of Alaska's natural gas resources for sale to other overseas markets.
"In that case, the CPC will not pass up such a good profitable investment opportunity," he added.
Murkowski, a long-term supporter of the Republic of China, is currently visiting Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The new Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.015 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Thursday, closing at 30.550.
The local currency opened at 30.560 and was traded between 30.505 and 30.640.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$660.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: APPLICATIONS FOR ALTERNATIVE MILITARY SERVICE ACCEPTED FROM MAY 1

TEXT.P: Local-level governments will begin to accept applications from men wishing to participate in alternative military service from May 1, Interior Minister Huang Chu-wen announced on Wednesday.

This will be the first time that the Republic of China has introduced alternative military service for conscripts. Huang said the ROC is also the first non-European country to implement such a system to ensure more efficient, fair and just use of its manpower resources.

Huang said all male ROC nationals who were born in 1980 or before and have not yet completed mandatory military service can file applications with village, township or city governments of their legal abodes between May 1 and May 20.
Some 1981-born males who have not received notice for regular military service before May 1 can also apply for alternative military service, Huang said.
According to an initial estimate by the Ministry of the Interior, about 100,000 male nationals will be eligible to apply for alternative military service.
"As only 5,000 alternative service vacancies are available this year, applicants will have to draw lots to decide whether they can do alternative service," Huang explained.
The minister further said this year's alternative service will include jobs such as firefighting, social services, environmental protection and medical services.

Under the alternative service regulations, those who have passed special national examinations and have obtained professional licenses will enjoy preferential opportunities to land alternative service jobs, while other applicants will have to draw lots.
Meanwhile, those who are not suitable for normal military service due to family factors or special religious beliefs can also apply to do alternative service.

The conscription period for alternative service will be two years and two months, four months longer than regular military service, and those who assume alternative service posts for religious reasons will have to serve up to two years and nine months.
Salaries and other fringe benefits for those who do alternative service will be similar to those for military conscripts.
Huang said the Interior Ministry will publish detailed application procedures for alternative service in major local news media and on its Internet website.

Huang said it has taken two years of concerted effort by the Interior Ministry's conscription department, the Ministry of National Defense and other relevant government agencies and the Legislative Yuan to put in place all the necessary legal provisions and administrative preparations for implementing the alternative military service.

According to Huang, the Interior Ministry set up an executive panel on March 1 to handle the preparatory work. A central government-level conscription administration will also be inaugurated to take charge of all alternative service affairs after the legislature completes screening of a draft bill on the administration's organic structure.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT'S ASSETS INCREASE BY NT$ 17 MILLION

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui's assets increased by NT$17 million from last year, according to data on public functionaries' registered assets released by the Control Yuan on Wednesday.

According to the data, the Republic of China's first couple held NT$38 million in deposits, NT$21 million in stocks and securities, NT$16 million-worth of jewelry, and seven golf and country club memberships.
Lee submitted his last assets registration last November as he will step down from public office on May 20.
He had registered assets with a combined worth of NT$59.58 million in 1998, and the figure had jumped to NT$76.64 million last November.

DOC.HEADLINE: E-COMMERCE TASK FORCE TO BE SET UP: BOFT

TEXT.P: In line with the global world trend toward the boom in e-commerce, the government is to set up an e-trade task force to handle external negotiations, Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) Director-General Chen Rui-lung said on Wednesday.

According to Chen, the BOFT will call an inter-ministerial meeting to prepare for the establishment of the planned ad hoc group with an aim of promoting foreign trade talks and multilateral negotiations via the Internet.

Since that is also a goal keenly advocated by the World Trade Organization, the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation forum and the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development, Chen said the BOFT schedule is to have an electronic trade and negotiating channel up and running by 2005.

A sound climate for on-line trading will also help promote the development of the local distribution industry and push Taiwan a big step forward toward its goal of becoming a business operations center in the Asia-Pacific region, Chen added.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING BULLYING WILL `HURT BOTH SIDES': CNAIC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: If Beijing bullies Taiwan people doing business in mainland China, it will hurt both sides of the Taiwan Strait, the head of the Taipei-based Chinese National Association of Industry & Commerce (CNAIC) said on Wednesday.

CNAIC Chairman Jeffrey Koo was referring to reports that the Beijing authorities plan to bully Taiwan businessmen in the mainland with the aim of reducing the more-than US$20 billion trade surplus enjoyed by Taiwan over the mainland.

Speaking to reporters after presiding over a CNAIC meeting, Koo described such a policy as a double-edged knife which would hurt both Taiwan and mainland businessmen, and one which Beijing could ill-afford.

If mainland businessmen do not purchase products from Taiwan, they will have to do business with the other countries, which will "inevitably" result in increased operational costs, Koo claimed, adding that this would have a negative impact on the mainland's economic development in the long run.

Gao Chi-shang, vice chairman of I-Mei Food Company, who attended the meeting, told the reporters that although the story about Beijing's intimidation measures against Taiwan businessmen has not been confirmed, "all the foreign investors, including those from Taiwan," would leave the mainland if the situation indeed develops in this direction.
The Beijing authorities would not be so foolish as to scare away foreign capital, according to Gao.

There have been reports that Beijing announced last week that it will not permit Taiwan businessmen to pursue economic benefits in mainland China while at the same time supporting the Taiwan independence movement at home, as a number of Taiwan business tycoons have been reported to have been doing.

The Beijing-based Central Office for Taiwan Affairs has already started retaliatory measures against several Taiwan plastics manufacturers by suspending imports of their products, according to recent reports.

DOC.HEADLINE: SLOW PROGRESS IN FINANCIAL REFORM AFFECTS ROC'S COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: A senior economics planner said on Wednesday that he was not surprised by a drop in Taiwan's international competitiveness rating because Taiwan has dragged foot on financial reforms in the past couple of years.

Chi Schive, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, was responding to an annual report released recently by the Swiss-based International Institute for Management Development (IMD) which ranked Taiwan's national competitiveness at 22nd place, down from its 1999 rating of 18th place.

"Our ranking decline on the IMD global national competitiveness rating didn't come as a surprise to me," Schive said, adding that Taiwan's failure to accelerate financial and banking reforms was the main reason behind its decline in national competitiveness rating.
As a member of the Republic of China government's economic and financial policy planning team, Schive said he feels regret over the slow progress in the country's financial and banking reforms.

Schive said if the incoming administration of President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party really wants to promote Taiwan's globalization, it must speed up financial and banking reforms.
"The new government should also listen more to opinions of foreign experts and should not formulate relevant policies behind closed doors," Schive said.
Taiwan saw its ratings drop in all the eight major categories measured by the IMD for compiling the annual report on overall national competitiveness of 47 major countries and areas around the world.

The most serious drop were seen in the "globalization" category, down from a 27th-place rating to 34th. The rating for "business management" also slid from ninth to 18th, and the rating for "financial and banking management" fell from 23rd to 26th. Taiwan's 2000 ratings in these three categories were the lowest since the IMD began to compile a global national competitiveness rating from 1996.
Schive said South Korea has taken bold steps to overhaul its financial and banking structure after the 1997-1998 Asian financial meltdown.

"As a result, South Korea's IMD rating has surged 10 notches this year, indicating that its sweeping financial reforms and economic recovery have won international recognition," Schive said, adding that Taiwan should draw inspiration from South Korea's example.

Schive pointed out that Taiwan's plunge in "business management" was most alarming because many noted domestic large conglomerates had exposed their drawbacks in internal management during the 1997-98 Asian financial crisis.

The drop in the "globalization" rating was also noteworthy, Schive said, adding that Taiwan need not overly worry about the inflow of foreign capital for stock investment. "We should further liberalize capital flow," he added.
Schive further said Taiwan should also largely revise its corporate law to offer much greater freedom for business operations to sustain Taiwan's economic vitality and development.
Taiwan ranked 18th in the IMD's 1996 global rating, 23rd in 1997, 16th in 1998 and 18th in 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: JUSTICE MINISTER-DESIGNATE SAYS HE'LL MAINTAIN STATUS QUO

TEXT.P: Justice Minister-designate Chen Ding-nan on Thursday categorically ruled out the possibility of a widespread replacement of staff based on party affiliations at the Ministry of Justice Investigation Bureau (MJIB) after he assumes office next month.

Nevertheless, Chen, a heavyweight in the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), which is replacing the Kuomintang as Taiwan's ruling party after its candidate Chen Shui-bian was elected president, did say he will see to it that MJIB agents and staff members will be rejuvenated -- allowing younger men and women bigger opportunites to help the MJIB operate more efficiently during his term.

During a talk show interview Thursday morning, Chen made reassurances that there won't be a major change in staff at the MJIB after he takes office. He pointed out that he also did not make any major staff changes 19 years ago when he won the city and county chief elections to become magistrate of Ilan County, replacing the ruling KMT in the eastern country for the first time.
Chen stressed, however, that any staff members at the MJIB who have undesirable disciplinary records might be transferred to other units within the Ministry of Justice to perform different jobs.

Since the MJIB has until now been supervised by both the Ministry of Justice and the National Security Council because of its special duties, Chen said he will not try to alter the MJIB's existing functions and structure after he takes office. "Maintaining the status quo is the best policy for a new government to begin with, at least for the time being," Chen emphasized.

In the future, the MJIB, which may be transformed into the National Bureau of Investigation (NBI) shortly after the new government is inaugurated on May 20, will continue to be charged with duties which include anti-communist espionage and working against official corruption, drug trafficking and money laundering, added Chen.

DOC.HEADLINE: PAY RAISE UP TO NEW CABINET TO DECIDE SAYS PM SIEW

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew said on Thursday that whether or not the plan for a pay raise for the country's public functionaries is put into force in July is up to the new government to decide.

Siew said the outgoing Cabinet will leave the question of the pay raise plan to the new government, to be led by Premier-designate Tang Fei, on the grounds that the scheduled implementation of the pay raise is July 1, at which time the new government will already be in office.

When deciding on the pay raise issue, the new government will first take into consideration the government's balance sheets and the current financial situation of the different levels of government, said Central Personnel Administration Director-general Chang Che-tsen.

Chang said that as of mid-April, the central government revenues are sufficient enough to implement a proposed 3 percent pay raise for government employees, mainly because of increased revenues from stock transaction taxes. However, he added that several city and county governments may have difficulties in coping with the plan due to long-standing financial strains, he noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: NUMBER OF FOREIGN LABORERS EXCEEDS OFFICIAL LIMIT

TEXT.P: The number of legal foreign laborers has exceeded the government sanctioned ceiling of 300,000, with the number of Indonesian and Vietnamese workers increasing most significantly, the Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) said on Thursday.

According to the latest CLA tallies, a total of 301,447 foreign laborers had come to Taiwan legally for work as of the end of March 2000. The Cabinet-level council promised to keep the total number of blue-collar foreign workers from exceeding 300,000 to avoid affecting local people's job opportunities.

CLA statistics show that Thailand remained the largest source of foreign laborers in Taiwan, despite the fact that the number of Thai workers had been declining steadily. A total of 140,133 Thai nationals were working in Taiwan at the end of March.
The number of Philippine workers has also been falling at a pace of about 1,000 people per month since last September partly because of the suspension of direct air links between the two countries.

At the end of March, 112,859 Filipinos were working in Taiwan, accounting for 37.44 percent of total foreign workers here and making the Philippines the Republic of China' second largest source of alien workers.

In contrast, the number of legal workers from Indonesia and Vietnam has been rising steadily. In March, 46,762 Indonesians were working in here, up 1,767 persons from the February level. During the same period, the number of Vietnamese workers increased from 842 to 1,550. Taiwan began to allow imports of Vietnamese workers early this year.
In March, 143 Malaysian nationals were working in Taiwan, down four persons from February.

CLA officials said the number of Indonesian household helpers has increased rapidly in recent months. There were 31,678 Indonesian family helpers in Taiwan in March, accounting for 44.19 percent of total foreign household helpers here.

In the past, local families liked to hire Filipinas as household helpers because most of Philippine nationals can speak English. However, the trend has gradually changed. The ratio of Filipino family helpers fell below 50 percent for the first time to 49.77 percent in March, with the number standing at 35,680.

DOC.HEADLINE: REPORT EMPHASIZES AMERICA'S TOP NAT'L SEC'Y PRIORITIES

TEXT.P: A United States government chartered study emphasized Wednesday that assisting the integration of China, Russia and India into the mainstream of the emerging international system must be one of America's top national security strategy priorities in the new century, but the US should remain committed to the peaceful resolution of the Taiwan issue.

The 14-member US Commission on National Security/21st Century said in its phase two report "Seeking A National Strategy" that the United States should engage China constructively and with a positive attitude, politically and economically, adding that it must also recognize that the potential for competition between the US and China may increase as China grows stronger.

China's increasing adherence to global economic, legal and cultural institutions and norms will be a positive factor, and the US should encourage and assist this process of integration, said the report.

At the same time, the report pointed out that "the US should maintain its deterrence strength and its alliance system in the Asia-Pacific region. It should remain committed to the peaceful resolution of the Taiwan question, consistent with the terms of the three Sino-American communiques and the Taiwan Relations Act."

The panel, headed by former senators Warren Rudman and Gary Hart, said that beyond its efforts to bring China, Russia and India into the mainstream of a new cooperative international order, the United States has a strong interest in limiting the further proliferation of sophisticated conventional weapons around the world.

The US should therefore seek support for a multilateral approach to devising limitations on such proliferation first with its closest allies and friends, and thereafter with Russia, China, India and other significant arms producing countries.

The Commission on National Security wrote in its phase one report "New World Coming: American Security in The 21st Century" that of all the potential problems that could throw East Asia for a proverbial loop, none is as portentous or controversial as the future of China because such a huge country is bound to affect East Asia's future.

The report noted that if Chinese authoritarianism declines as per capita income reaches around US$7,000, and the political system moves toward bounded pluralism, even if not genuine democracy, optimism about East Asia's future will receive a major boost. If Beijing undergoes major political reform after the terminal, but essentially peaceful, crisis of the Communist system leading to the creation of a system no less democratic than Taiwan's, then so much the better.
But the commission also pointed out that at least two other possibilities exist concerning mainland China's future, and they are far less positive from a US perspective.

One scenario is that China will continue to get rich while authoritarianism remains. What could happen is that the country metastasizes from a Communist command economy into a looser corporatist system, bound together by a network of interwoven political, military and economic elites, and sustained at large by appeals to nationalism, said the report.

"Such a new nationalist China could become decidedly hostile to the US, and that hostility could be reciprocated. Several triggers for such hostility exist even today, and they will not go away soon," stressed the report. Among them is a possible crisis over Taiwan in which the US strongly sides with Taipei, a crisis made much more likely by Taiwan's renunciation of its `one China' policy in July 1999.

Another possibility is that China collapses politically and violence erupts. Elements of a political collapse include the loss of ideological legitimacy on the part of the Communist Party, massive corruption among the political and economic elites, the pressure of separatism in Tibet and Xinjiang, a failure to reform the state-owned enterprises that produces simultaneously a financial default and massive unemployment, the continued rise of cults, and a series of poor political judgments.

The panel is convinced that a collapse could produce a return to warlordism, economic disaster, humanitarian catastrophe, the potential scattering of Communist China's weapons of mass destruction, and terrorism.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GROUP SENDS CHARITY PACKAGE TO SENEGAL

TEXT.P: A Taiwan charity organization on Thursday donated nearly 70 cartons of toys and stationery supplies to Senegal, hoping that the donation will help Senegalese children lead happier lives.

The donation, raised by the non-profit Chinese Fund for Children and Families, Taiwan, was received by Senegal Ambassador to the Republic of China Ahmed Tijane Kane during a presentation ceremony attended by ROC Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen.

Addressing the ceremony, Chen lauded the compassion shown by the Taiwanese public for Senegalese children through the donation. He said Senegal is an important diplomatic ally of Taiwan. The average number of children per Senegalese family is six, and only 60 percent of all children in the West African country attend school, while up to 22 percent of them are on the brink of starvation, he continued.

Upon receiving the donation on behalf of his country, Ambassador Kane said the Taiwanese donation is highly appreciated, particularly after Taiwan itself was hit by a devastating earthquake last September.
The donation, which weighs a total of 1,635 kg, will be transported to Senegal free of charge by the giant US express carrier UPS, said Fund officials.

Senegal's opposition leader Abdoulaye Wade defeated President Abdou Diouf in an election on March 20, ending 40 years of uninterrupted Socialist Party rule. The change of power in Dakar has planted the seeds of uncertainty concerning the country's formal diplomatic relations with the ROC, political observers said.

Officials from the Chinese Fund for Children and Families, Taiwan, said that in addition to the underprivileged children living in Senegal, there are children in other areas of Africa who are also in dire need of help.

For example, they noted, there are currently about 15 million people in Ethiopia suffering famine conditions as a result of a severe drought in that country located in the horn of Africa. Fund officials are urging the people of Taiwan to pitch in with efforts to help the people of that country, preferably by sponsoring individual Senegalese children through monthly cash donations.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA'S POLICY TOWARD PRC, ROC, INDIA SAID OUTMODED

TEXT.P: The Australian government's policy of pursuing engagement with mainland China while at the same time disdaining both Taiwan and India was criticized by a veteran Australian writer as "misguided and outmoded."
In his recent article in the Australian Financial Review, Brian Toohey said Asia as the coming dynamo of growth has been a tenet of Australian policy for years, but this policy is misguided.

He says the intellectual and entrepreneurial forces shaping the information and bio-technology revolutions have come from the United States and Europe and not Asia, which is only a potential market for the end product of innovative ideas nurtured elsewhere.

These revolutions are the products of free and democratic societies in the US and Europe, and a similar process may be underway in India and Taiwan, the two Asian democracies which "Australian policy makers have treated with disdain," he noted.

He cites a quip heard frequently in Silicon Valley on the west coast of the US that refers to the "I" in IT as standing for Indian and the letter "T" standing for Taiwanese because many of the recent innovative breakthroughs appear to be the work of emigrants from these two countries.

"The great lesson of this revolution appears to be that geographical proximity matters less and less and intellectual and political freedom counts for more and more. In this context, it does not make a lot of sense to try to pick regional winners, especially where authoritarian institutions still predominate," he says.

Toohey says John Vinocur, a senior correspondent of the International Herald Tribune, who has been jailed in Singapore, is at a loss to understand why Australian policy makers are not more relaxed about their country's place in the world rather than being so preoccupied with seeking the approval of authoritarian Asian regimes.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO LODGE COMPLAINT WITH WTO ON US LAMB IMPORTS

TEXT.P: The Australian government said it will lodge its first complaint with the World Trade Organization against US restrictions on lamb imports from Australia and New Zealand.
In a statement faxed to the CNA on Thursday, Trade Minister Mark Vaile said the restrictions imposed by the US on the import of Australian and New Zealand lamb are not justified.

The US last year restricted Australian lamb imports to 35,000 tons, equal to the 1998 level plus a 9 percent tariff. According to the US restrictions, any imports above this level face a huge 40 percent tariff, which will cost Australian lamb producers and exporters about US$6.3 million a year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET REBOUNDS

TEXT.P: Futures prices for Taipei's stock index rebounded strongly on Thursday in contrast to modest gains in the spot market.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index (TAIEX) Futures for May soared 199 points to close at 9,209 amid brisk trading, with a volume of 4,011 contract transactions.

Affected by a drop in the technology-heavy Nasdaq index on Wednesday, the Taiex index futures market opened lower in thin trading, but reversed its downward trend after mid-session and rose significantly in the final session.

TAIEX futures for June also rose 150 points to finish at 9,216, with 98 contract transactions; September futures surged 87 points to finish at 9,310, with eight contract transactions; and December futures picked up 59 points to close at 9,260.

And the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for Taiex index futures trading were 9,052 points for May, 9,048 points for June, 9,100 points for September, and 9,105 points for December.

Meanwhile, Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on electronics shares and financial stocks listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, both reported positive results.

May TE futures moved up 11.2 points to close at 501, with 1,612 contract transactions; June TE futures rose 10 points to finish at 509, with 23 contract transactions; September TE futures gained 11.2 points to close at 526; and next March TE futures advanced 11.2 points to close at 528.9.
May TF futures edged up 18 points to finish at 951, with 399 contract transactions; June TF futures rose 35.4 points to close at 969.6, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARITAL INFIDELITY TOPS 10 BIGGEST ONLINE 'CRIMES'

TEXT.P: Marital infidelity is considered the leading crime in the virtual online world, results of a recent survey of Internet surfers in Taiwan showed.

In the survey, Taiwan Internet surfers ranked online extramarital affairs as the number one social problem in the virtual world. This is due to the frequency and convenience of such trysts, said Seednet President Cheng Chia-chun.
Garbage mail, virtual trash that wastes time and occasionally causes PCs to crash, was the second most serious problem on the Internet, according to the poll.
Online rumors, neo-gossip that only smart brains can resist, was the third.

Internet addiction was deemed the fourth most serious problem. Victims of mild cases of this syndrome can simply exhibit restlessness when offline. For hard-core addicts, symptoms include uncontrollable trembling and excessive perspiration if they are kept from a computer monitor for one single day.
Online pornography was ranked the fifth worst problem. Moral campaigners have suggested parents move fast to find and block pornographic websites from their home computer.

Physical complications from spending too much time online were judged the sixth worst problem. This latest illness of the high-tech age includes symptoms of degeneration of language ability, hand joint deformities and other physical abnormalities.
Online gambling came in seventh in the poll. The Internet has created unprecedented convenience for cross-border or borderless gambling.
Compulsive online shopping was ranked eighth. The Internet enables compulsive shoppers to bankrupt themselves by making excessive purchases with a push of a keyboard button.

Societal alienation was ranked the ninth worst problem. Long-term surfers can become mentally isolated and can eventually become completely alienated from family members and from real life, said the poll organizers.

Distortion of democracy won the 10th and final spot on the list. Some surfers make irrational condemnations and verbal assaults online, resulting in a distortion of the freedom of speech and having an adverse effect on democracy, according to Cheng.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET REBOUNDS ON GOVERNMENT BUYING

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market closed slightly higher on Thursday mainly because of buying of large blue-chip stocks by four government-run funds in the final session.
The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index edged up 4.65 points to close at 9,109.05.
The market opened weak in a bearish mood due to a fall in the technology-heavy Nasdaq index in the United States on Wednesday as well as profit-taking by short-term investors.
The Taiex index fell more than 100 points around mid-session, but recovered all lost grounds in the last half hour of trading, with large blue-chip stocks leading the rally.

Market analysts said the steady rises in prices for such large blue-chip stocks as Taiwan Semiconductor Corp. and United Microelectronics Corp. indicate that the local bourse will gradually stabilize following last week's drastic fall.

Nevertheless, some Intel Corp.-related stocks weakened on the Taiex on reports that the US-based computer chip maker is being troubled by a shortage of CPUs. It remains to be seen whether these stocks can regain steam in the near future.
Market turnover shrank further to NT$133.47 billion (US$4.38 billion) as many investors adopted a wait-and-see attitude.
Losers outnumbered gainers 331 to 197, with 80 stocks remaining unchanged.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSSIE FM TO REAFFIRM CROSS-STRAIT ISSUE BE SETTLED PEACEFULLY

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer is expected to reiterate Australia's "one-China" policy while calling on Beijing to resume a dialogue with Taiwan in order to settle the cross-strait issue peacefully when he visits Beijing on April 23-24.
In a news release on Thursday, Downer said he will go to Beijing to attend the Asia-Australia Institute's Asia Leader's Forum and the 2000 Asia-Australia Institute Council Meeting.
Downer will meet his Chinese counterpart, Tang Jiaxuan, to discuss matters of mutual interest and help maintain the positive momentum in Australia's relations with mainland China, the statement said.

The Australian government switched diplomatic ties to China from Taiwan in late 1972 and has since maintained its "one-China" policy, but Canberra also wants both sides of the Taiwan Strait to settle their disputes peacefully, according to a senior official at the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT), who requested anonymity.
The DFAT spokesman told CNA that any military confrontation across the Taiwan Strait could possibly force the United States to participate, and would be the last thing Australia wants to see.
"If that happens, Australia is highly likely to be asked by Washington to support America because both countries are traditional allies," the official said.

Prime Minister John Howard recently told Zheng Qinhong, a personal secretary for President Jiang Zemin and a Politburo member, that Australia would continue to maintain its "one China" policy but at the same time, would continue to have commercial ties with Taiwan.
Howard also urged China to peacefully resolve differences with Taiwan through negotiations.

DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET EDGES UP

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market traded in a narrow range on Friday, with the benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange weighted price index edging up 11.43 points to close at 9,120.48.
Market turnover shrank further to NT$120.8 billion (US$3.96 billion) as many investors remained at sidelines.

DOC.HEADLINE: EXPORT ORDERS HIT US$12.64 BILLION IN MARCH

TEXT.P: Export orders for March totaled US$12.64 billion, representing the highest level since last October and the sixth consecutive month of double-digit growth, said the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) on Friday.

Chang Yao-chung, director general of the MOEA's Accounting Department, said that because of the rosy economic picture this year, export order growth estimates could be adjusted to double digits from the original eight percent.
Chang said the continued dramatic growth in export orders could be attributed to the continued economic turnaround in the United States, Asia and Europe.
Orders in March for information and telecommunications products totaled US$2.42 billion, US$2.2 billion for electronics products, and US$1.3 billion for textile products.
Accumulated export orders from the United States totaled US$10.75 billion in the first quarter of this year, up 7.48 percent from the same period last year.

Accumulated export orders in the first quarter from Japan totaled US$3.52 billion, up 24.86 percent, while orders from Hong Kong totaled US$6.02 billion, up 25.45 percent. Export orders from Europe totaled US$6.01 billion, up 14.38 percent.

Chang noted that domestic economic prospects continue to look good, with the only uncertain factor being cross-strait relations. He added that when mainland China test-fired missiles in waters near the Taiwan Strait prior to the island's 1996 presidential election, Taiwan's exports suffered, but overall, the impact on the mainland's economy was bigger.
Chang said that with the continued economic boom, the MOEA is worrying more about whether domestic manufacturers' production capacity can meet the growing number of export orders.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK MARKET CLOSES SLIGHTLY HIGHER

TEXT.P: The Taiwan stock market traded in a narrow range on Friday amid slow trading as many investors remained on sidelines due to unstable trend in America's technology-heavy Nasdaq index.

The benchmark Taiwan Stock Exchange (Taiex) weighted price index edged up 11.43 points to close at 9,120.48. Market turnover shrank further to NT$120.8 billion (US$3.96 billion), with 3.48 billion shares changing hands.
Market analysts said uncertain market prospects of the technology-heavy Nasdaq has made local investors reluctant to purchase electronics issues, particularly high-priced ones.
The Taiex opened flat at 9,130.32 and hovered between 9,243.04 and 9,105.31 throughout the three-hour trading session.
Gainers outnumbered losers 292 to 208, with 105 stocks remaining unchanged.

Of the eight major categories, only electronics and electric issues registered a 0.2 percent decline Thursday's finish. In contrast, cement stocks rose an average of 1.2 percent; pulp and paper issues jumped 5 percent; plastics and chemical stocks edged up 0.5 percent; textiles advanced 0.1 percent; foodstuff issues inched up 0.1 percent; both financial and construction issues surged 0.2 percent.
