DOC.HEADLINE: GERMAN-ROC ECONOMIC COOPERATION SUCCESS STORIES ENCOURAGING

TEXT.P: Successful German ventures in the Republic of China and Taiwanese ventures in Germany have enhanced economic cooperation between the two countries, said German Institute Director-general Dr. Hilmar Kaht, emphasizing that these success stories have been inspiring and encouraging.

Dr. Kaht said that the economies of Germany and Taiwan, in terms of structure, quality and export-orientation, are rather complementary. "Especially remarkable is the high share of trade exchanged both ways in identical or similar branches of production, such as machinery, electronics, precision engineering and optics and chemicals," he added.

As German technologies are highly appreciated in Taiwan's industrial circles, there have been numerous technology transfer cooperation projects over the past years, the most recent case being the 0.14 micron technology developed by Germany's Infineon and applied by Taiwan's ProMOS Technologies Inc. to 12-inch integrated circuit chip production.

Dr. Kaht pointed out that Germany remains Taiwan's largest trade partner in Europe. Taiwan's exports to Germany grew in 1999 by 3 percent to US$4.3 billion. Taiwan is the third largest market for German exports in the Asian-Pacific region, with the island importing US$5.3 billion worth of goods from Germany in 1999.

There are more than 140 German companies with a presence in Taiwan. Dr. Kaht said he expects even more will come as Taiwan approaches its goal of becoming an Asia Pacific Regional Operations Center and continues its process of economic liberalization.

In his capacity as Germany's representative to Taiwan, Dr. Kaht said that Germany is greatly in favor of Taiwan's access to the World Trade Organization as he believes it will set the framework for greater exchanges and cooperation between the two countries.

Although economic exchanges seem to form the major part of the relationship between Germany and Taiwan, Dr. Kaht stressed that exchanges in the scientific, academic and cultural sectors have also been booming in recent years.

He said that Sino-German academic exchanges have a history of more than one hundred years, and there are quite a few successful examples of German-Taiwanese scientific cooperation. In 1999, for instance, Cheng Kung University in Tainan and the University of Rostock in northern Germany jointly organized a seminar on coastal engineering and sustainable development in the coastal zone.
These exchanges and activities are important elements in forming a durable relationship, said the diplomat on leave.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET PLUNGES

TEXT.P: Futures prices for Taipei's stock index plunged on Friday in contrast to modest gains in the spot market.
The Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index (TAIEX) Futures for May slid 77 points to close at 9,132 amid slow trading, with a volume of 3,008 contract transactions.

Affected by poor performance of the technology-heavy Nasdaq index on Thursday, the Taiex index futures market opened lower in thin trading and hovered in a narrow range throughout the whole trading session.
TAIEX futures for June also dropped 60 points to finish at 9,156, with 60 contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.

And the Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for Taiex index futures trading were 9,209 points for May, 9,216 points for June, 9,310 points for September, 9,250 points for December, and 9,686 points for next March.

Meanwhile, Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on electronics shares and financial stocks listed on the Taiwan Stock Exchange, reported mixed results.

May TE futures declined 10 points to close at 491, with 1,022 contract transactions; June TE futures fell 15 points to finish at 494, with 10 contract transactions. No transactions were reported for other months.
May TF futures edged up 4 points to finish at 955, with 274 contract transactions; June TF futures slid 13.6 points to close at 956, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SAYS CONCEPT OF `CONFEDERATION' WARRANTS DISCUSSION

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Friday that the formation of a confederation between both sides of the Taiwan Strait is one idea that can be discussed.
Chen made the remarks while calling on Sun Yun-suan, the former premier and currently a senior advisor to President Lee Teng-hui.

Chen said that the Republic of China has not changed despite undergoing a transition of power after the March 18 presidential election, adding that the only change may be that it has become more democratic.
He said that as the new leader of the nation, he will not just pursue his own will in handling cross-strait relations, saying that he will listen to views and opinions from all sides.

Chen said the idea recently proposed by Sun of both sides forming a confederation is a "new concept," and whether the concept is "feasible" will depend on forging a consensus among the people, adding that there is much room for discussion on the idea.
Chen reiterated that if mainland China continues its strategy of verbal attacks and military intimidation, it will only "delay an improvement in cross-strait ties."

He urged mainland China to adopt new thinking so that the people of Taiwan will be more attracted to it, saying that "warm sunshine" will help melt the ice, and it is useless to use a "spade and shovel."
He also lauded Sun as one of the most outstanding civil servants in ROC history, adding that if he had not quit as premier for health reasons in 1984, he would be the president today.
Chen also invited Sun to continue serving as a senior advisor to the president so as to help him handle cross-strait relations and other administrative duties.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT-ELECT SEEKS TO IMPROVE TIES WITH KOREA

TEXT.P: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian told a leading Korean newspaper that it is time for the Republic of China and South Korea to demonstrate goodwill and sincerity so as to improve their bilateral ties.

In an exclusive interview with the Chosun Ilbo that appeared on the Korean daily's front page on Friday, Chen said the people of Taiwan and South Korea used to be close friends, leading similar lives and sharing similar backgrounds and experiences.

As both countries have witnessed successful power transfers from decades-old ruling parties to opposition parties, and as the people of both countries share long-standing friendship, there is no reason why Taiwan and South Korea cannot improve relations, including the resumption of direct air links, Chen told the Chosun Ilbo.
Chen said that after its inauguration on May 20, the new ROC government will actively seek to improve bilateral ties with the South Korean government and to resume direct air links.

The Korean newspaper with a circulation of 2.5 million copies quoted Chen as saying that the ruling Kuomintang has faced difficulties over the past several years in its efforts to improve ties with Seoul as well as to resume direct air links because of the issue of "face."
Chen said his new government is not hindered by this "face" issue and so he sees no barriers to addressing differences between the two sides and to resuming talks based on goodwill and sincerity.

On cross Taiwan Strait relations, Chen told the Korean daily that the new government will retain parts of the KMT's policies, but will at the same time create some new approaches toward the cross-strait relations issue. A special committee headed by Academia Sinica President Lee Yuan-tseh will serve as that creative arm charged with working out measures to cope with the cross-strait relations issue, Chen said.

He added that while he makes it the responsibility of his new government to seek to improve cross-strait relations, it should be the common goal of both Taiwan and Beijing to strenuously pursue permanent peace in the Taiwan Strait.

When asked about the impact on Taiwan's security of Tuesday's decision by the United States to postpone the sale of Aegis destroyers to Taiwan, Chen said the US government has not killed the Aegis destroyers sales plan but only postponed it. It is believed that through further negotiations, the ROC Ministry of Defense will eventually obtain the weapons that the ministry has asked for to help defend the country.
Chen added that Taiwan's present strategy to combat a potential Communist Chinese air, sea, or guided missile attack is to use defensive missiles.

He, however, stressed most of all that peace in the Taiwan Strait is not only in line with the interests of Taiwan, it is also vitally important to Japan and other nations in the Asian-Pacific region.

On the reasons behind his victory in the March 18 presidential poll, Chen quipped that he is obliged to three persons who greatly contributed to his campaign. He mentioned DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung for his capable leadership of the party's rank and file, and also his election rival James Soong for running in defiance of the Kuomintang, which caused a fatal split within the ruling party.

Chen also said he is grateful to mainland Chinese Premier Zhu Rongji for his strong verbal blustering on the eve of the election, which Chen said he believes outraged many Taiwanese voters who previously weren't hostile towards Beijing and who were undecided on their choice of candidate.

When asked whether he will follow ROC founding father Dr. Sun Yat-sen's "Three Principles of the People -- Nationalism, Democracy and Livelihood--when leading the country, Chen said that the KMT did not implement these ideals during its rule even though the party was founded by Sun himself, just as the communist rulers on the mainland have not properly implemented a communist system.
Chen said he will follow the Third Way -- a new political perspective -- in leading the Republic of China.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SAYS IT WELCOMES TALKS ON CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: The Clinton administration on Thursday stated that it welcomed the resumption of human rights dialogue with Communist China at the earliest possible time.

State Department spokesman Jamie Rubin told a press conference that "we think the more we talk about human rights, the better it is for the human rights of the people of China, whether its talking about them with China bilaterally or in Geneva at the UN Human Rights Commission."

Asked about the decision to oppose permanent normal trade relations with China announced Wednesday by House minority leader Rep. Richard Gephardt (D-Mo), Rubin said that Secretary of State Madeleine Albright has had a lot of discussions, especially with Democratic members of Congress, about their concerns on human rights and how the US should express its concern about Chinese human rights abuses.

Albright's role in these discussions, in addition to arguing that granting China permanent normal trade relations status is a win-win proposition for American consumers and producers, has been to focus on the national security argument.

In the secretary of state's judgment, Rubin said, "to vote down permanent normal trade relations would be a major setback to the US-China relationship which would harm our national security" regarding North Korea and non-proliferation issues.

"If members of Congress care about questions like the danger of North Korea developing nuclear missiles and the subject of the transferring of missile technology, they should want to avoid a major setback to the US-China relationship because China's role has been helpful," Rubin added.

"We think that cutting off our nose to spite our face by failing to get the economic benefits of this agreement (on China's accession to the World Trade Organization) and putting at risk the national security benefits of our relations with China is the wrong decision to make," Albright was quoted by Rubin as telling the members of Congress.

DOC.HEADLINE: VATICAN REFUSES BEIJING'S REQUEST TO CONDEMN TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Beijing's efforts to pressure president-elect Chen Shui-bian on the diplomatic front suffered a setback when the Vatican refused to condemn Taiwan's `two states' theory, the Hong Kong Standard reported today.
The report quoted sources as saying that mainland authorities had attempted to ask the Vatican, one of Taiwan's longtime diplomatic allies, to denounce the theory, but the Holy See refused.
The statehood claims were made last July by Taiwan's outgoing President Lee Teng-hui during an interview with the German media.
According to the report, Beijing has linked the theory to the island's independence movement, which it has condemned as splittist.
Aside from the Vatican, the mainland is also aiming to persuade Panama, another one of Taiwan's diplomatic allies, to switch its recognition to Beijing after Chen's inauguration on May 20.
Negotiations between the Holy See and Beijing are still ongoing, but so far there has been no breakthrough, the report quoted the source close to the Vatican as saying.
The Holy See said a public statement against Taiwan independence is inappropriate as the island has never declared independence.
It has always supported the `one-China policy' and sees no need to interfere in Taiwan's domestic affairs, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING'S THREATS AGAINST TAIWAN HOLLOW SAYS ANALYST

TEXT.P: Although Communist China and Taiwan could inflict a large amount of damage on each other in a military conflict, it is difficult to imagine a scenario where a mainland invasion of the island could facilitate Beijing's goal of eventual reunification, said James H. Nolt, a senior fellow at the World Policy Institute here.

Nolt wrote in a recent analysis on US-PRC-Taiwan military relations that although China has disputes with most of its neighbors, it has not resorted to force to resolve them since its border war with Vietnam in 1979, except for a brief clash with Vietnam over the Parcel Islands in 1988. The most persistent remaining problem is Beijing's threat to use force against Taiwan if it declares independence.

But "Beijing's threats against Taiwan are hollow, because China lacks the military capability to inflict damage on Taiwan without suffering immense damage to its own economy and coastal regions," said Nolt. For example, Taiwan's air force, though much smaller than mainland China's, has been completely re-equiped with modern aircraft, outnumbering Beijing's few modern Russian-built fighters by more than six to one.

Besides, mainland China is now more dependent on foreign trade than it was during the Taiwan Straits crises of the 1950s and its economy would consequently suffer much more in the event of an armed conflict. Taiwan is also more powerful relative to mainland China than it was in the 1950s. "The Taiwanese could defend themselves adequately even without US intervention," added the senior fellow.

Despite frequent alarms about the supposed China threat, it is not an emerging superpower. Although it has experienced rapid economic growth, China has been in relative decline militarily since the 1970s, said Nolt.

Its high economic growth rate is now slowing, and its pattern of growth has actually undermined its ability to become an autonomous military power able to manufacture its own weapons systems and sustain a war effort without support from abroad. "China does not, and will not in the foreseeable future, pose the kind of military threat to the US that the Soviet Bloc did," he pointed out.

Former US secretary of state Henry Kissinger also said in a speech on Tuesday in Pasadena that China "is not in any position for the next 30 years to be a mortal threat to the United States.....So for the next 20 years we need to think, 'Do we want to put them down?'"

Many policymakers have voiced concern that an influx of US dual-use technology into mainland China could facilitate its military modernization. However, Nolt noted, in industries such as aerospace, the trend has been for foreign involvement to relegate mainland Chinese producers to merely subcontracting low-tech components rather than manufacturing entire systems.

Beijing's incapacity to design and manufacture the most modern weapons has forced it to rely, like most developing countries, on arms imports. Communist China's limited acquisition of modern foreign weapons, mostly from Russian, is a tiny fraction of what would be needed to replace its aging arsenal.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW UMC WAFER FOUNDRY FACING SUSPENSION

TEXT.P: A new microchip wafer manufacturing plant being built by United Microelectronics Corp. (UMC) faces suspension of operations as allegedly no environmental impact study was carried out before trial production began.

The Cabinet-level Environmental Protection Administration (EPA) on Friday officially informed the National Science Council (NSC) that a permit for the establishment of UMC's 8F Foundry will be canceled because the plant has begun production trials before passing a government-authorized test designed to assess the plant's impact on the environment.
The NSC, meanwhile, demanded UMC authorities to present a comprehensive environmental impact assessment report within a week in order to avoid being deprived of a license for the new plant.
NSC officials also said UMC must suspend the 8F Foundry's production trials until it receives official approval regarding the environmental impact assessment.

UMC officials, outraged over the sudden demand for the new plant's suspension, met the press on Friday at the Taiwan Stock Exchange to explain the situation to individual and institutional investors holding UMC stock, numbering between 400,000 and 500,000 people.

The official said UMC obtained approval from the relevant government agencies before beginning construction of the new wafer plant, and added that the company, the second-largest microchip wafer processor in Taiwan, will sue for "national-level" compensation if plant operations are forcefully suspended and cause financial losses to investors.

Currently, the 8F Foundry -- the fifth of its kind owned by UMC -- is at the stage of installation and testing of facilities and has yet to begin commercial production. Consequently, its immediate fate will not influence UMC's overall turnover or income, according to the officials.

It was previously expected that once the 8F Foundry begins commercial production in June or July this year, its monthly output of microchip wafers will reach 15,000 units by the end of the year, with maximum capacity reaching 30,000 units per month.
UMC has targeted an annual turnover of NT$88 billion (US$2.89 billion) for 2000, with a prospective annual output of 2.4 million silicon wafers.

The 8F Foundry, which uses sophisticated 0.18 micrometer design rules, is expected to contribute some NT$8 billion (US$262 million) to UMC per year once it begins commercial production, the UMC officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.022 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Friday, closing at 30.530.
The local currency opened Friday at 30.541 and was traded between 30.511 and 30.560.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$338.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: US FOREIGN POLICY THINK TANK HEAVYWEIGHTS TO VISIT TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Four US East Asian affairs experts from an influential think tank -- the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) -- are scheduled to arrive in Taipei on Saturday for a four-day visit.
Among the visitors will be Winston Lord, a former assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs and a former US ambassador to mainland China.

The three other visitors are Douglas Paal, who once served as Asian affairs chief of the National Security Council under the Bush administration; NCAFP President George D. Schwab; and professor Donald S. Zagoria, head of the NCAFP's roundtable discussion program.

The four-member mission will meet with Republic of China government leaders, heads of major local political parties and officials in charge of national security, diplomatic affairs and relations across the Taiwan Strait.

Following its Taipei visit, the group will travel to mainland China for a similar fact-finding visit with a view to gaining first-hand information about the current political, military and security situation on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The NCAFP was founded in 1974 with the purpose of offering foreign policy counseling to the US government in order to boost national interests. Its current honorary chairman is former US Secretary of State Henry Kissinger.

The prestigious think tank has so far held five closed-door roundtable meetings on US and mainland China policies and cross-strait relations since the 1996 Taiwan Strait crisis when Beijing lobbed missiles and conducted live-fire war games on Taiwan's doorstep in an attempt to sway Taiwan voters in the run-up to the island's first-ever direct presidential election.

The NCAFP is expected to present foreign policy recommendations based on the group's findings during its current visits to both sides of the Taiwan Strait to be used as reference for hopefuls intending to run in the US presidential election scheduled for November this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 21, or the 17th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1634: Jan van Riebeeck, Dutch naval surgeon and founder of Cape Town, South Africa, is born.
1898: The United States declares war on Spain.
1910: Mark Twain, pen name of Samuel Langhorne Clemens, American author and humorist, dies at the age of 74. He drew on his childhood along the Mississippi River to create masterpieces of humor and sarcasm, including "Tom Sawyer" and "The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn."
1926: Elizabeth II, Queen of England since 1952, is born.
1930: Fire breaks out at the Ohio state penitentiary, killing 355 people.
1935: An earthquake hits central and northern Taiwan, killing some 3,000 people.
1937: Steamships formally begin plying a regular weekly route between Shanghai and San Francisco.
1946: British economist John Maynard Keynes dies at the age of 63. He proposed that high unemployment, being a result of insufficient consumer spending, could be relieved by government-sponsored programs.
1948: Republic of China troops evacuate Yenan.
1949: The Chinese communists resume an all-out offensive and cross the Yangtze River.
1954: The United States flies a French battalion to Indochina to defend Dien Bien Phu, which is overrun by Vietnamese forces three weeks later.
1957: Taiwan voters go to the polls for the third time to elect county magistrates, city mayors, and provincial assemblymen.
1958: The Taiwan Provincial Assembly Building in Wufeng, Taichung County, is inaugurated.
1960: Brazil moves its capital from Rio de Janeiro to Brazilia, the brain-child of President Juselino Kubitschek.
1966: The ROC and Dahomey resume diplomatic relations.
1971: Haitian dictator Francois Duvalier, known as "Papa Doc," dies at the age of 64. Elected president in 1957, he declared himself president for life in 1964 and ruled in an authoritarian manner until his death. He was succeeded by his son Jean-Claude, who fled the country in 1986 after widespread civil unrest.
1975: South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu resigns after denouncing the United States as untrustworthy.
1987: Terrorists detonate a bomb near the main bus station in Colombo, Sri Lanka, killing and injuring more than 400 people.
1989: More than 10,000 workers and students shouting for democracy and human rights march from campuses to converge on Tiananmen Square in Beijing in defiance of official warnings against anti-government protests.
1997: An advance contingent of communist Chinese troops enter Hong Kong in preparation for the handover of the British crown colony to communist China on July 1.
1998: Seoul drops efforts to receive Japanese compensation for women held as sex slaves during World War II and says it will pay the surviving women.
Confucius lesson of the day: "A good horse is considered so not because of its mere brute strength but because of its moral qualities."

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S TILT TOWARD KMT'S CROSS-STRAIT POLICY LINE WELCOMED

TEXT.P: A ranking official of the Kuomintang said on Friday that he welcomes President-elect Chen Shui-bian tilting toward the KMT's policy on cross-strait relations.

Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the KMT's Department of Mainland Research, noted that Chen had in the past advocated the abolishment of the National Unification Council, but as he won less than 40 percent of the votes in the March 18 presidential election, he has to adjust his course in cross-strait relations.

But Chang also said that although Chen has said that he has no intention of abolishing the National Unification Council and the National Unification Guidelines, it does not necessarily mean that he won't.

Furthermore, as the NUC charter states, the ROC president serves as the NUC chairman and the ROC vice president as the NUC vice chairman. Chang said that whether Chen and Vice President-elect Annette Lu assume these positions will be worth watching.

Chang also said that incumbent President Lee Teng-hui had cited National Unification Guidelines to explain cross-strait relations to foreign dignitaries when meeting with them, and whether Chen does the same will also be worth watching.

He said that the KMT's mainland policy is deemed by Beijing as the safest, and this is the reason behind Chen's stating that he will not abolish the National Unification Council and National Unification Guidelines.
But Chang added that Chen will have to come up with a comprehensive policy toward the mainland soon, and if he doesn't, the KMT's will be the most ideal point of reference.

Chang noted that Beijing is presently forming its attitude toward Chen by "listening to his words, and watching for his deeds," and if Chen doesn't form a mainland policy soon, he will face mounting pressure from Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: SECURITY ADVISER NAMED NEW MAC HEAD

TEXT.P: Tsai Ying-wen, an adviser to the National Security Council (NSC) and a professor at National Chengchi University's International Trade Department, was confirmed on Friday as chairwoman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC).

Tsai, who holds a master's degree in economics from Cornell University and an LL.D. from the London School of Economics, confirmed her acceptance of the post, saying she is grateful for the wide support accorded to her but will not spell out her administrative ideas and policies until she returns from a trip abroad over the next week.

MAC Vice Chairman Lin Chong-pin expressed a hearty welcome to Tsai's appointment. Lauding President-elect Chen Shui-bian and his team for making a wise choice, Lin said Tsai will be a capable leader of Taiwan's top agency in charge of formulating policies towards mainland China due to her expertise in international affairs and cross-strait issues and her personnel skills.
Lin commended Tsai as a practical, poised and rational person who maintains a low-profile style while demonstrating high-caliber performance.
Having chaired a number of international working group meetings sponsored by the World Trade Organization (WTO), Tsai is also believed to be Taiwan's foremost WTO expert.

Meanwhile, as a national security adviser to the president, Tsai was one of 8-10 specialists, mostly academics, who comprised a group responsible for authoring President Lee Teng-hui's redefinition of cross-strait relations as "a special state-to-state" relationship last year.

An economics and law expert who also has an excellent command of English, Tsai authored the English speech delivered by Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, Chairman Koo Chen-fu of the quasi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, during an ice-breaking meeting in Shanghai in 1998 with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait.

Despite her high-profile career, however, Tsai is described a "shy lady" who still wears her hair in a "student style," prompting local political observers to liken her to the fairy tale character "little red riding hood," who eventually defeated the big bad wolf -- a less-than subtle depiction of the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China.

DOC.HEADLINE: 68% OF TAIWAN HOUSEHOLDS OWN TWO OR MORE TELEVISIONS

TEXT.P: Results of a survey released on Friday show that 68 percent of Taiwan households have two or more televisions, higher than the 52 percent registered in both Shanghai and Hong Kong.

The survey, conducted by ACNielsen (Taiwan) last year among people in Taiwan, Hong Kong and Shanghai, also shows that 26 percent of Taiwan households own three or even four televisions, and that some children have their own televisions.
However, in terms of Internet access, the percentage of online households in Taiwan is 16 percent, trailing the 21 percent in Hong Kong, but higher than the 7 percent in Shanghai.

The survey also shows that 55 percent of Internet users in Taiwan are young people aged between 15 and 24, with 39 percent of them students, while 73 percent and 87 percent, respectively, of Hong Kong and Shanghai surfers are working people.

An ACNielsen official analyzed that the high percentage of working people in Hong Kong surfing Internet indicates that Hong Kong has the highest e-commerce potential in the Greater China Area, while another official noted that mainland China's 3,000-plus TV channels represents a promising market for media sector.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI INTERNATIONAL GIFT & STATIONERY SPRING SHOW OPENS

TEXT.P: The Taipei International Gift & Stationery Spring Show opened at the Taipei World Trade Center on Friday, with a record-breaking number of participants taking part, according to the sponsors.

The exhibition is being sponsored by the China External Trade Development Council (CETRA) with assistance from the Taiwan Handicraft & Gift Export Association, the Taipei Handicraft Association, and the Taiwan Educational Stationery Association.

A total of 1,168 manufacturers are taking part in the five-day show, one of the 18 international expositions sponsored by CETRA this year. In addition to local manufacturers, foreign manufacturers from 13 countries and regions, including the United States, Britain and Italy, are taking part in the exhibition.

This year's show is bigger than ever, with a 15-percent jump over last year in the number of participants, and the manufacturers have set up a total of 2,204 booths in both the main Taipei World Trade Center exhibition hall and the second expo building nearby.

In addition to the exhibition proper, 74 creatively designed products selected from work submitted by 11 local colleges and universities will be on show, and will be auctioned off to the manufacturers taking part in the exhibition.
Products being highlighted at the show include gifts, festival ornaments, souvenirs, household appliances, stationery and handicrafts, as well as pottery and porcelain ware, office and school goods.
The exhibition, which is open to trade buyers only, is expected to attract about 8,000 buyers from foreign countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: IF `ONE CHINA' MEANS PRC, TAIWAN PEOPLE ARE NOT CHINESE: LU

TEXT.P: Vice President-elect Annette Lu said on Friday that if "one China" means the "People's Republic of China," then she does not think that the people of Taiwan can be described as Chinese.
Lu, a political dissident-turned-politician, made the remarks during a meeting with visiting Canadian and American lawmakers who had expressed concern about Taiwan's attitude toward "one China."

The Beijing regime insists that there is but one China -- the People's Republic of China -- of which Taiwan is inalienably a part. This opposes the Republic of China view that agrees that there is only one China, but that it is now ruled separately on either side of the Taiwan Strait.

Lu said Taiwan has shown a great deal of goodwill toward mainland China, and added that the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait are not involved in a feud and should not resort to war simply over ideological issues.
Noting that Taiwan and mainland China need each other economically, Lu said the two sides should co-exist peacefully.
"Do we need to waste so much time arguing whether one China should be a `precondition' or a `topic,' and even to go to war over the issue?" Lu asked.

Commenting on visiting mainland Chinese scholar Yu Keli's calls for incoming President-elect Chen Shui-bian's administration to uphold Beijing's so-called "one China" policy and for Chen to identify himself as Chinese, Lu said the remarks were "old cliches."
As for Chen's statement that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait can discuss the feasibility of forming a confederation, Lu said Chen's suggestion mainly reflects his openness toward the issue.

Lu said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait now need diversified, innovative and constructive thinking, not destructive ideas. She further said the two sides should shelve the highly sensitive "unification or independence" issue for the moment and stop meaningless verbal sparring in order to forge rapprochement.

She also expressed worry that Beijing's leaders might be losing patience and rationality toward the Taiwan Strait issue, and added that she is afraid that mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin's March 20 statement that Beijing will monitor Taiwan President-elect Chen's "words and deeds" was just a smokescreen.

"The reality is that mainland China is stepping up military deployment along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan," Lu said, adding that senior Beijing leaders' increased overseas trips in recent weeks have also been deliberately designed to suppress Taiwan in the international community.

DOC.HEADLINE: MOFA CLARIFIES MAINLAND MEDIA'S FALSE REPORT

TEXT.P: The ROC Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Friday that the United States has not changed the cornerstone of its "one China" policy that demands mainland China use strictly peaceful means to resolve issues across the Taiwan Strait.

The ministry was commenting on a Beijing-based China News Service (CNS) report on March 30 that quoted US National Security Adviser Sandy Berger as having told mainland Chinese Foreign Minister Tang Jiaxuan that the United States recognizes that Beijing's "one China" principle is the only basis for resolving the Taiwan Strait issue.
Liu Chih-kung, director of the MOFA's North American Affairs Department, said the mainland media report was not true.

Liu said the Republic of China government had asked the Clinton administration whether the CNS report was correct. "Relevant US authorities have clearly told us that the United States has not changed its stance on the 'one China' principle," he noted.

Liu pointed out that in May 1996, then US Secretary of State Warren Christopher said in a speech in New York that Beijing using peaceful means to resolve cross-strait issue is the basis of the US "one China" policy.
"Christopher's statement indicates that there is a wide gap between the US stance on 'one China' and the CNS report on Berger's remarks on the issue," Liu noted.

"And the CNS claim that the United States has accepted Beijing's stance that the "one China" principle is the basis and precondition for peaceful unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait is apparently a misleading distortion of Berger's remarks," Liu added.
Under Beijing's "one China" principle, one China means "People's Republic of China" and Taiwan is a breakaway province of the PRC.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT-RUN NEWSPAPERS TO CONTINUE OPERATIONS

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang (KMT) will continue to run the Central Daily News and the China Daily News in its new role as a powerful opposition party, said KMT Vice Secretary-General Shao Yu-ming on Friday.

Although the KMT lost the March 18 presidential election to the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Shao said the KMT has decided to continue publishing the two daily newspapers in order to promote the party's philosophy, to effectively monitor the new DPP-led government and to reflect grass-roots voices to the new government.
According to Shao, the KMT will consider selling some shares of the two newspapers to the private sector in a bid to invite the public to take part in the operations of its press empire.

DOC.HEADLINE: VISITING MAINLAND SCHOLARS MEET NEW PARTY LEADERS

TEXT.P: A delegation of Taiwan affairs researchers from Beijing's China Academy of Social Sciences met with leaders of the Republic of China's right-wing opposition New Party on Friday for wide-ranging talks.

The six-member mainland Chinese delegation, led by Yu Keli, deputy director of the Taiwan Research Institute under the China Academy of Social Sciences, arrived in Taipei on Wednesday for a fact-finding trip.

It was the first mainland academic group to visit Taiwan after Chen Shui-bian, a stalwart of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, won the ROC's March 18 presidential election in a victory that marks an end to the Kuomintang's 55-year rule of Taiwan.

New Party Legislator Hau Lung-pin, who concurrently serves as convener of the New Party's National Campaign and Development Committee, told a news conference after 40 minutes of closed-door talks with the visiting mainland scholars that the two sides didn't reach a consensus on the "one China" issue.

"We have told the mainland researchers that its a consensus of the people of Taiwan that each side of the Taiwan Strait should be allowed to have its own definition of 'one China,'" Hau said. "However, Yu told us that this 'one China, different definition' stance is unacceptable to Beijing."

Hau and his New Party colleagues also expressed their hope that cross-strait interaction can be based on the ROC's National Unification Guidelines which call for "phased" development of relations and cooperation between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait.

"We also suggested that Beijing declares that 'one China' doesn't refer to the People's Republic of China," Hau said, adding that the mainland visitors frankly replied that the proposal is unacceptable to Beijing.

Touching on President-elect Chen's proposal that Taiwan and mainland China discuss the feasibility of forming a confederation, Hau quoted Yu as having said that Beijing cannot accept the so-called confederation proposal because such a scheme cannot resolve Tibet and Xinjiang issues.

During their talks, Hau said he has advised the mainland visitors to listen more to the mainstream public opinions here. "We hope they can take advantage of their stay here to listen to the views of various local social quarters and convey those opinions to mainland leaders as reference for formulating mainland China's future policy toward Taiwan," Hua said, adding that he hopes Yu's mission can help boost cross-strait mutual understanding.

Yu said the New Party, which supports Taiwan's eventual unification with mainland China under freedom and democracy, believes that bilateral dialogue and communication are needed to maintain peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: TSMC DONATES FUNDS FOR RESTORATION OF FORMER US CONSULATE

TEXT.P: Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Corp. (TSMC) donated NT$60 million (US$1.97 million) to the Taipei City Hall on Friday for restoring the former US consulate in Taiwan.
Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou said at the donation ceremony that the TSMC's move has set a model for industry-government cooperation in preserving cultural heritage.

The building, located on Taipei's tree-dotted Chungshan N. Road, was built in 1901 during the imperial Ching dynasty. The US government leased the building as its consulate in Taipei in 1926, and closed its consular affairs in Taiwan in December 1941 when the United States declared war with Japan. Taiwan was then still under Japan's colonial rule.

After World War II, Taiwan was returned to The Republic of China's fold and the United States refurbished the building into the official residence for its ambassador to the ROC. From 1953 through 1979, all US ambassadors lived in the building. When Richard Nixon visited the ROC in his capacity as the US vice president in the 1950s, he also stayed in the building.

The United States switched diplomatic recognition to Beijing in 1979 and sold the building back to the ROC's National Property Bureau in 1982 for NT$250 million. In 1997, the Ministry of the Interior designated the building as a third-class historical relic and the Taipei City Hall took over the responsibility for restoring the building last year.

Lung Ying-tai, director of the Bureau of Cultural Affairs of the Taipei City Hall, said the bureau will immediately begin planning work and is scheduled to finalize all restoration projects by the end of next year. If all goes smoothly, Lung said, the building will be formally open to the public in early 2002 for cultural and artistic activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: INCOMING GOVERNMENT RELEASES LIST OF MORE GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS (I)

TEXT.P: Another list of designated officials of Chen Shui-bian's new central government was released by the incoming administration on Friday.
Yu Hsi-kun, the president-elect's choice for vice premier, confirmed that Deputy Governor of the Central Bank of China Shea Jia-dong will serve as minister of finance under the new administration.
Chu Wu-hsien, an official of the Examination Yuan will serve as the director-general of the Central Personnel Administration under the Executive Yuan.
Ovid J. L. Tseng, president of National Yang Ming University, has been designated as the minister of education.
Youharni Yisicacafute, an aboriginal minister who is also known as Sung Kuo-hsien, will be appointed as chairman of the Council of Aboriginal Affairs.
Hsu Cheng-kuang, director of the Institute of Ethnology under the Academia Sinica, will serve as Chairman of the Mongolian & Tibetan Affairs Commission.
Tu Cheng-sheng, director of the Institute of History and Philology at Academia Sinica, has been earmarked as director of the National Palace Museum.
Chen Hsi-huang, a National Taiwan University professor, will take helm at the Council of Agriculture.
Tsai Ing-wen, a professor at National Chengchi University, will head the Mainland Affairs Council.
Legislator Yeh Chu-lan will take the reins of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications.
Chang Po-ya, mayor of Chiayi City, will be the new administration's minister of the interior.
The new administration is still searching for officials to head six agencies under the Executive Yuan, said Yu.

They are the Department of Health, Environmental Protection Administration, National Sports Council, Council for Economic Planning and Development, Atomic Energy Council and National Youth Commission.

Chen Hsi-huang, who was confirmed as the new government's agriculture head on Friday, had previously worked at the Council of Agriculture (COA) and its predecessor, the US-ROC Joint Commission on Rural Reconstruction. (MORE)

Youharni Yisicacafute, the new head of the Council of Aboriginal Affairs, is a minister of the Presbyterian church. An aboriginal rights activist, he has been sentenced to three months imprisonment for organizing an illegal demonstration demanding land for aborigines.

DOC.HEADLINE: WANG LI-CHENG SWEARS INTO POST AS "GO SAGE" IN JAPAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 21 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taiwanese "Go" player Wang Li-cheng won the title of "Go Sage", the highest title and honor for any Go professional in Japan, on Friday.
Wang obtained the title after he defeated his Korean opponent, Chao Chih-shun, 4-2 in the 24th Go Sage Tournament on March 9.
This was the first time that the highest title has been conferred on a player from Taiwan.
The title presentation ceremony was held in a hotel in downtown Tokyo and was witnessed by more than 100 Go players. Wang obtained the title and also pocketed US$310,000 in prize money.
Matsuo Kagami, board chairman of the National Japanese Go Association, praised Wang for his fighting spirit.
Takeo Kogawa, board chairman of the Kansai Go Association, expressed his admiration, saying that Wang deserved to receive the title because he is a hard worker.
Chung Ming-yao, ROC representative in Japan, also attended the title presentation ceremony and said that all Taiwan's people would share the honor with Wang.
Wang moved to Japan at the age of 12. He was promoted to the rank of ninth grade Go player when he was 27.
Wang also holds the titles of "King Post" and "Tsuru Sage," in addition to the "Go Sage" honor.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNMENT ACTS TO TRAIN INDUSTRIAL TECHNICIANS

TEXT.P: The Industrial Development Bureau (IDB) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs will appropriate an annual NT$200 million (US$6.45 million) from this year to finance a project to cultivate industrial personnel, said an IDB official on Friday.
The official noted that the project will be contracted out to private educational or research institutions, and added that open bidding will be held in the second half of this year.

In the first year, he said, 1,400 courses will be opened to train about 37,900 industrial technicians in 16 sectors, including quality control, industrial automation, electrical machinery, food, industrial design, software, chemistry, textiles, shoe-making and printing.
The IDB project is designed to help local manufacturers cultivate technical skills to improve the nation's industrial development, according to the official.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY GOVERNMENT TO PROMOTE EDUCATION REFORM

TEXT.P: Taipei's city government will promote pluralistic teaching, or the so-called "Taipei New Education," to reduce high educational pressure on students, a city government official said on Friday.

Lee Hsi-chin, director of the Bureau of Education of the Taipei city government, said he was very worried about the increasingly high percentage of junior and senior high school students who have ever been driven by stress to think of suicide.
He said he will stimulate teachers and parents to change the way that they evaluate children, so that students who perform well in non-academic areas are also valued and praised.

According to a survey of City Councilor Chen Hsueh-fen, 23 percent of third-grade students of junior and senior high schools have thought of suicide because of educational pressure. Frighteningly, 9.5 percent of those students admitted that they were thinking of terminating their lives at the very time the survey was conducted.
More worrisome is the fact that 42.75 percent of the students have ever thought of suicide for unknown reasons, said the city councilor.

Lee said his bureau will stimulate schools to organize more activities like dance parties and athletic contests for children, so that students who are interested and skilled in these areas can have a chance to exhibit their skills, allowing them to enjoy life instead of considering suicide.

Lee added that teachers, parents, and society as a whole should also change the way that they judge and value children. Children's lives are about more than just appreciating only academic performance, he said, adding that too much emphasis on academics makes many children endure boring lives.
He said his bureau is promoting actively "Taipei New Education" and has invited teachers from more than 20 schools to participate in a research camp on the new methodology.

DOC.HEADLINE: MND WATCHES CLOSELY TO BEIJING'S PSYCHOLOGICAL WARFARE TROOPS

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) is closely watching the newly founded Chinese Communist psychological warfare corps, a source with the MND said on Friday.

Formed in response to President Lee Teng-hui's announcement last July of his "special state-to-state" cross-Taiwan Strait relations policy, the Communist psychological warfare corps is the first of its kind in mainland China. It was formed last fall in Shenyang, northeastern China, the source cited the mainland Chinese Liberation Army Daily as saying.

The report said that the corps is seen as experimental in its initial stage, and is affiliated with the Shenyang Military Region. It staged a live-fire exercise before Taiwan's March 18 presidential election to test training effectiveness. Taiwan troops were used as an imaginary enemy in the exercise.
It was reported that Beijing authorities will establish another psychological warfare corps in the Nanjing Military Region.

The main task of the psychological warfare troops is to create various propaganda materials and send them to enemy troops via remote-control planes. The purpose is to deal a blow upon enemy morale and incite defection among Taiwanese if war breaks out across the Taiwan Strait, the report said.
The source with the MND said the MND has kept abreast of new developments of the Communist psychological warfare troops and will continue to closely monitor the corps' activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN APPROVES 18 NEW MAINLAND CHINA INVESTMENTS

TEXT.P: The Investment Commission under the Ministry of Economic Affairs on Friday approved 18 new investments in mainland China, with capital totaling US$130 million.
Fourteen of them are new investments with a value of US$83.7 million. The remaining four cases are increases on earlier investments, totaling US$46.6 million.
Most investment are in the electronics, computer and paper manufacturing sectors.
Acer Peripheral Inc. will invest an additional US$20 million in its manufacturing plants in Suchow, Jiangsu Province.

DOC.HEADLINE: 10 PERCENT OF TAIWAN PEOPLE THINK THEY ARE CHINESE: SEF SURVEY
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, April 21 (CNA) (By Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: According to long-term research, the percentage of Taiwan people who think of themselves as Chinese has dropped to a little more than 10 percent, said an official in charge of cross-Taiwan Strait dealings on Friday.

Speaking at a seminar held at the Hualien-based National Dong Hwa University in which ten visiting academics from mainland China also took part, Jan Jyh-horng, vice secretary-general of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), said he is deeply worried about the trend.

Citing the results of a long-term SEF-commissioned poll on the sensitive issue of the Taiwan public's ethnic identification, Jan said the ratio among local residents who think they are both Taiwanese and Chinese has fallen to just around 10 percent at present from the 40 percent posted before 1994.

According to Jan, the percentage has noticeably declined since 1994, when scores of tourists from Taiwan were burned to death on board a sight-seeing boat in the Qiandao Lake of mainland China's southeastern Zhejian province.
The SEF has long postponed releasing the results of its investigation for fear of stirring up controversy on the issue, Jan noted.

Turning to the danger of a potential military conflict between Taiwan and mainland China, the SEF aide expressed his opinion that war should be avoided because the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait wish to enjoy a better life and greater freedom.
If either side unilaterally suspends the current boom in two-way economic exchanges, it will damage the two sides at the same time, he pointed out.

As to the "one China" principle set by mainland China as the precondition for rekindling cross-strait talks, Jan argued that the "one China" framework must be further discussed now that Beijing had claimed that the two sides can even talk about issues related to the national flag and national designation.
He asserted that Taiwan and mainland China should first put aside their "one China" dispute and find ways to cooperate in order to break the current impasse.

As cross-strait financial flows have become so common, no political party or leader on either side would risk cutting bilateral relations, Jan stressed, claiming that there is no need to worry that Taiwan and the mainland will become alienated from each other.

Although negotiations between the SEF and its mainland Chinese counterpart -- the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) -- have been temporarily suspended, Jan said, the SEF is fully prepared to reopen bilateral talks at any time, including inviting ARATS Chairman Wang Daohan to visit Taiwan.
Quoting SEF Chairman C.F. Koo, Jan said Koo is willing to visit the mainland again should Wang not be able to travel to Taiwan.
Jan added that if the two sides cannot sit down and talk through their problems, it is of no use for Beijing to put even more preconditions forward.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN FIRM TO INVEST US$ 40 MILLION IN NEW ASIA-PACIFIC CABLE NETWORK

TEXT.P: Taiwan's Chunghwa Telecom Co. on Friday signed an agreement in Singapore with 26 other companies from eight Asian countries to construct a new Asia Pacific cable network.
A spokesman for Chunghwa Telecom said that the project calls for a total investment of US$1 billion, of which Chunghwa will contribute US$40 million.
Chunghwa Telecom was represented in the contract-signing ceremony by its Chairman Chen Yao, said a Chunghwa press release.

The 19,000-km Asia Pacific Cable Network 2 will connect mainland China, Taiwan, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Malaysia, the Philippines and Singapore. Japan's NEC will be responsible for the construction work.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING PRESIDENT TALKS ABOUT DEMOCRATIC REFORM
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, Eastern Taiwan, April 21 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Outgoing Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui said in Hualien on Friday that successful reform in Taiwan will be helpful to mainland China's democratization.

He said that Taiwan's democratization and liberalization is only in its beginning stage, and added that it will require a long time to complete the process. He added that the process would involve a general renovation in the ways of living, thinking and spirituality.
Lee, who is to step down as president on May 20, said that reforming in mainland China will be difficult, unless Taiwan continues its reform and serves as a model for mainland China.
If Taiwan fails to achieve a successful reform, he said, mainland China will not be able to attain a fruitful reform.
Lee said that Taiwan's survival depends on its continued democratization. He expressed his appreciation for public support for his democratization efforts over the past 12 years as president.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC AIR FORCE C-130 MAKES SUCCESSFUL FORCED LANDING IN PINGTUNG
DOC.DATELINE: Pingtung, Southern Taiwan, April 21 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A C-130 transport aircraft of the Republic of China Air Force made a successful forced landing in Pingtung Airbase on Friday night.
The aircraft, with nearly 100 soldiers aboard, left Sungshan Airport on Friday evening and was originally scheduled to land at Hualien Airport at 8:50 p.m.
But the landing gear under the nose of the plane malfunctioned when the plane reached Hualien, and the pilot decided to fly to Pingtung Airbase for an emergency landing.
The transport circled above the airbase to consume its fuel before successfully landing at 10:58 p.m. A fleet of fire engines and ambulance vehicles were mobilized before the plane landed.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN AND HONG KONG LOCK HORNS ON TAIWAN'S REPRESENTATIVE

TEXT.P: Taiwan's would-be-representative to Hong Kong Chang Liang-jen might not get a visa or work permit from Hong Kong's government after Taiwan refused to promise that Chang would not act on behalf of the Taiwan government, said Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council on Friday.

Chang is slated to serve as the island's representative to Hong Kong under the title of general manager of the Chung Hwa Travel Service, Hong Kong. Hong Kong has requested Taipei to promise that he would never directly or indirectly act as representative of Taiwan government, said Lin.

Hong Kong also wants Taiwan to guarantee that its representative will not act in a manner or issue any statements whatsoever that could be perceived by others as being made in the capacity of Taiwan representative.
Branding it the request as "very very" unreasonable, Lin said his office has refused to follow Hong Kong's requirement, because it is discriminatory and doesn't serve the interests of either side.
But Hong Kong hasn't bulged in the dispute, said Lin.
Chang was supposed to fill in the vacancy left by General Manager of Chung Hwa Travel Service Cheng An-kuo, who returned to Taiwan late last year after his work permit expired.
The Hong Kong government refused to renew Cheng's work permission because he infuriated Beijing by defending Taiwan's demand for statehood in an interview with a Hong Kong radio station.

Lin said the Chung Hwa Travel Service began its operation before Hong Kong was handed over to Beijing in 1997. He added that Cheng got his work permit in 1995 after Taiwan promised that he would not act in a manner incompatible to his status as general manager of Chung Hwa Travel service, or do any harm to Hong Kong interests. Issuing such a promise is normal diplomatic practice.
It is regrettable that the Hong Kong government under Beijing would impose harsher requirements on Taiwan's representative than its British predecessor, said Lin.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Saturday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
Four constitutional amendment bills enter second reading.
The China Times:
