DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-FINANCED SKOPJE EPZ COURTS INVESTORS
DOC.DATELINE: Skopje, April 21 (CNA) (By Tony Fang and Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: An export processing zone (EPZ) being developed near the Macedonian capital of Skopje is courting businesses from around the world to relocate their production lines in the Eastern European country.

The EPZ, located some 17 km from the capital, can serve as a gateway to the huge Eastern European hinterland for manufacturers whose overall costs will be 40 percent-60 percent lower if they set up plants in Macedonia, said Lin Chi-wu, manager of the Taiwanese-owned Skopje Development and Management Co.

Under the development plan, the Skopje EPZ will be an industrial complex covering 160 hectares. In the first of three development stages, 25 slots, each occupying about 30 hectares of land, will be developed to house small and medium-sized manufacturers, according to Lin.
Part of the infrastructure development of the EPZ, including a 500-meter long wall, has already been completed, and construction of office buildings will soon kick off, Lin added.

He recommended Macedonia as a good choice for investors from Taiwan and other parts of the world, as general infrastructure and social order are good, the people are warm, honest and hardworking, and are generally skilled and well-educated, he noted.

Nevertheless, Lin admitted that some potential Taiwan investors are still pondering factors that may keep them away from the Balkan state. These factors include the geographic distance from Taiwan to Macedonia which might contribute to a management "black hole," and fact that the nearest seaport is located some 250 km away in Greece.

According to Lin, some investors are also reluctant to move to Macedonia because they lack an understanding of the complex religious and ethnic situation in Macedonia, coupled with the fact that the whole of Eastern Europe is a completely foreign area to them.

Despite those factors, Lin stressed, Macedonia still is a good choice for Taiwan and world investors, given that there are 100 million people living on the Balkan peninsula, and consumer goods such as furniture and household electrical appliances are always in high demand.

DOC.HEADLINE: WINE MERCHANTS IN KAOHSIUNG TO CAMPAIGN AGAINST ALCOHOLISM

TEXT.P: A group of foreign wine merchants in Kaohsiung City are forming a forum to raise public awareness about alcoholism and preach moderate consumption of liquor, a forum organizer said on Saturday.

John McDonnell, a Briton who distributes alcohol in the southern Taiwan city, said the non-profit Taiwan Beverage Alcohol Forum will campaign for moderate alcohol consumption and combat the local binge drinking culture which has become more of a problem in Taiwan with the increased import of foreign alcohol.

Citing statistics compiled by the National Police Administration, McDonnell said drunken driving has caused the deaths of more than 1,500 people in Taiwan since 1995, and more than 166,000 drivers were ticketed by police for driving under the influence in 1999, compared to 145,000 in the previous year.

In Kaohsiung alone, McDonnell pointed out, 17,500 motorists were stopped for drunken driving in 1999, and 991 of them were referred to court for trial. The figures were 7,063 and 331, respectively, for the first three months of this year.

It might seem a paradox that alcohol distributors have to convince their customers to drink less to sell more, but McDonnell noted that moderate drinking is good for the health while heavy drinking damages the body, gives alcohol a bad reputation and thus hampers sales.

Although alcoholism is not considered such a serious problem in Taiwan as it is in the West, McDonnell said he is afraid it will soon mushroom into a social problem in light of the local drinking culture which encourages aggressive toasting and moronic drinking games during social gatherings.
McDonnell said his forum will cooperate with owners of local restaurants and pubs to persuade their customers to practice self-restraint in their drinking habits.

DOC.HEADLINE: EUROPEANS IN TAIPEI MOST CONCERNED ABOUT TRAFFIC AND SIGNPOSTING

TEXT.P: European businesspeople residing in Taipei feel the city needs to improve the cleanliness of its streets, the enforcement of traffic laws and its road signs, according to a poll.
The poll on quality of life in Taipei was conducted by the European Council of Commerce & Trade (ECCT), and targeted European businesspeople currently residing in the city.

The poll showed that up to 56 percent of the respondents believe that road signs in several languages would have an immediate effect on the quality of life in Taipei, showing that for those visitors who cannot read Chinese, English translations for public facilities and road signs need to be improved.
The respondents also said that easier transportation (54 percent) and leisure facilities (32 percent) would have most effect on the quality of life in Taiwan's largest city.

On measures that could best improve the quality of life in Taipei, 88 percent of those polled said that tidier streets and sidewalks is most important, followed by enforcement of traffic laws (51 percent), and increased numbers of bilingual signs (32 percent).
The poll seems to indicate that Europeans, who tend to enjoy a high quality of life, are irritated by the untidy streets and the haphazard parking of motorcycles on city sidewalks.

Meanwhile, Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou and other Taipei City Government officials, after listening to the suggestions of the ECCT on Friday, vowed to improve the situation so that the quality of life in Taipei can be put on a par with major world metropolises.

Ma noted that the city government has responded to requests from the foreign community about foreign broadcasting and now has BBC news reports on Taipei Radio Station. He claimed that the city government pays attention to the foreign voice, and said he hopes that the ECCT will continue to offer its valuable suggestions.

Chen Wei-jen, director of the Bureau of Urban Development, noted that the 2.5 million square meters of the notorious red-tiled pavement in Taipei have become an eyesore and cannot cope with the use they receive. He said that the government is planning to gradually revamp these areas by the end of 2002.
The ECCT representatives also urged Ma to launch a traffic safety campaign to curb drunken driving and other traffic violations rampant in the city.

They also pointed out that although the Taipei mass transit system has clear English signs, the English translations for street names are not uniform, which means that foreign visitors easily get lost.

Lin Cheng-hsiu, director of the Bureau of Civil Affairs, said that a bilingual Taipei city map will be distributed prior to a high-tech information congress in June, and added that the map will be also accessible through the Internet.

Ma instructed that all scheduled cultural and artistic activities must be listed in a bilingual events brochure which must be subject to regular revision and printed in English-language newspapers, so that foreigners in Taipei can take part in the city's cultural activities.

DOC.HEADLINE: GRAIN DEALERS PROTEST SKYROCKETING PRICE OF STICKY RICE

TEXT.P: Grain dealers in southern Taiwan gathered in Kaohsiung City on Saturday to lodge a protest against the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) over the skyrocketing price of sticky rice.
The dealers accused the council of first failing to monitor the supply-and-demand system for sticky rice islandwide and then failing to come up with measures to cope with rising prices.

The retail price for the local favorite used to make "tsungtzu" rice dumplings has risen to NT$220 per dou (about 6.9 kg) since early this year due to a shortage of domestic supply, and the price is expected to skyrocket to some NT$500 per dou with the approach of Dragon Boat Festival, the traditional time of year to eat the sticky treats.

The dealers' representatives said an even-larger scale demonstration will be staged in Taipei on May 20 to vent their indignation with the government. May 20 is also the date of President-elect Chen Shui-bian's inauguration.

They said the government failed to recognize the crisis of a possible shortage of sticky rice four years ago when many farmers stopped planting it because the wholesale price was too low to be profitable. Since then. the drastic domestic shortfall has seen the price surge to reflect the shortage, gradually increasing to NT$200 per dou.
While failing to perceive the shortage, the government was caught unprepared for the sudden price surge with the approach of the Dragon Boat Festival.

With prices skyrocketing, all the government has done is to order the rice to be imported, which the dealers said is rubbing salt into their wounds. They pointed out that the dealers and farmers are now being forced to swallow the bitter fruit of poor government policy and bad management.

DOC.HEADLINE: SCHOLARS AGREE EXCHANGES NEEDED TO BREAK CROSS-STRAIT STALEMATE

TEXT.P: Scholars from both sides of the Taiwan Strait agreed in a seminar on Saturday that cross-Taiwan Strait exchanges will be a major step toward breaking the cross-strait stalemate.

The seminar, sponsored by a local foundation, was presided over by Prof. Chao Chun-shan of National Chengchi University, with foundation officials and professors participating. A six-member mainland China delegation headed by Yu Keli, deputy director of the Taiwan Research Institute under the China Academy of Social Sciences, also took part.

During the closed-door seminar, the Beijing scholars showed a very keen interest in the lineup of the new Cabinet of President-elect Chen Shui-bian, which has been largely filled one month after the March 18 presidential election that saw an end to more than five decades of Kuomintang rule of Taiwan.

The Taipei scholars said that the disruption of high-ranking cross-strait exchanges have resulted in the loss of a communication channel for the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, which they said has interfered with the normal development of cross-strait trade.
Cross-strait exchanges were suspended by Beijing in retaliation for President Lee Teng-hui's statement last July that cross-strait ties are "a special state-to-state relationship."
Yu said that whatever political situation develops, the promotion of cross-strait trade, cultural, educational and agricultural exchanges will continue.

He also said that his delegation will not meet with soon-to-be-ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) officials during the trip, though media reports had leaked news of a proposed secret meeting with Yen Wan-ching, director of the DPP's Department of Chinese Affairs, leading to the cancellation of the meeting.

Yu, who had advocated "one China" principle espoused by Beijing since his arrival here on Wednesday, was criticized for forgetting how to behave as a guest, to which Yu retorted somewhat angrily that he was only exercising his freedom of speech.

Yu has already visited officials from the newly formed People First Party, the New Party, and the pro-Chinese unification group The Association for the Promotion of Peaceful Unification between the two Sides of the Taiwan Strait, but had kept his distance from the pro-independence DPP.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN TO REMAIN ON US SPECIAL 301 WATCH LIST
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 21 (CNA) (By Herman Pan and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: The Republic of China will remain on this year's Special 301 watch list to be unveiled by the Clinton administration on May 1, trade sources said on Friday.

The decision was made during an inter-ministerial meeting held earlier this week, the sources said, adding that the meeting was attended by officials from the office of the US Trade Representative (USTR), the Department of Commerce, the Customs Service, and the Department of State.

The USTR is scheduled to unveil the annual Special 301 list and Super 301 list simultaneously on May 1. The Special 301 list targets major US trade partners who allegedly fail to properly protect intellectual property rights (IPR), while the Super 301 list targets countries which have allegedly imposed unfair trade barriers against US products.

A Clinton administration official told CNA that as ROC Economics Minister Wang Chih-kang has actively promoted IPR protection and intensely carried out anti-counterfeiting crackdown, there is no justifiable reason for putting Taiwan on the more serious "priority watch list" this year as had been suggested by some US computer companies.
Nevertheless, the official said the Clinton administration cannot accept the ROC's request that it be taken off the watch list, because Taipei has yet to resolve some IPR protection problems.

When USTR officials visited Taipei late last month, they asked Taiwan to resolve some patent lawsuit-related disputes and to require its microchip makers to identify wafer OEM foundries and CD-ROM disc sources.

The official said that although some American companies, including DRAM maker Micron Technology Inc., have demanded that Taiwan be included in this year's Super 301 watch list, the Clinton administration has ruled out that possibility.

"Since the two sides reached an agreement in 1998 on Taiwan's market opening and trade barrier removal plans during their talks on terms for Taiwan's entry to the World trade Organization, we see no need to place Taiwan on the Super 301 list this year," the official noted.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA LURING OLDER FEMALE JAPANESE TOURISTS

TEXT.P: Australia's tourism promoters are running advertisements in Tokyo and other major Japanese cities in a bid to attract older Japanese women tourists following a decline in the number of Japanese tourists in 1998.

The Australian Tourist Commission (ATC) reported that the number of Japanese tourists, the biggest source of tourism for Australia, plunged to just over 700,000 in 1999 from a record high of more than 800,000 in 1997.

ATC officials said the major factor behind the decision to attract older Japanese women is because women aged over 50 years old tend to be active and younger at heart than their younger counterparts. In addition, they are more sophisticated and more experienced.
Above all, these middle-aged women are more affluent, and their husbands are at the age of retiring and can afford to travel overseas, they said.
Australia is now competing fiercely with Hawaii to lure tourists from Japan, they added.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA TO BAN INTERNET GAMBLING

TEXT.P: Already hard-hit by problems associated with casinos and other forms of gambling such as horse racing, Australia is set to impose a temporary ban on Internet gambling.

Prime Minister John Howard said he would introduce a 12-month moratorium on new online gaming licenses in order to ban Internet gambling, and his plan has received support from the major Australian political parties.

"Gambling is a very significant social scourge in Australia ... We see online gambling as particularly pernicious because it's there in the home 24 hours a day, for the cost of a phone call," a spokesman for the Democrat Party told reporters on Friday.
But the Internet industry's lobby group in Australia warned that any attempt to ban online gambling would entrench Australia's image as an "old economy."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN IS IPR PROTECTION MODEL: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: Taiwan is a model for intellectual property rights (IPR) protection, a senior Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA) official said on Saturday.

Lu Wen-hsiang, deputy director of the MOEA's Intellectual Property Rights Bureau, was responding to reports from Washington, D.C. that the Clinton administration will continue placing Taiwan on the US Special 301 watch list this year for alleged failure to eliminate IPR infringement.

Lu said the US decision is unfair to Taiwan because the Republic of China government has spared no efforts to crack down on commercial piracy and copyright infringement and has achieved remarkable results.

On Friday alone, Lu said law enforcement officers managed to crack 26 copyright infringement cases and bring to justice 27 people suspected of involvement in those cases. Moreover, NT$550 million (US$18.03 million) worth counterfeit goods and pirated software programs and video game discs were confiscated in those cases.

Under the IPR bureau's anti-counterfeiting "K Plan", Lu said a total of 277 suspects involved in 257 commercial piracy cases had been broken and NT$1.85 billion worth of counterfeit goods seized as of March 31 this year.
Lu said the US delegates to the ROC-US IPR protection meeting held in Taipei in late March had lauded Taiwan's achievements in anti-counterfeiting operations and IPR protection.
Against this background, Lu said he hopes that the Clinton administration will delete Taiwan from the annual Special 301 watch list this year.

The office of the US Trade Representative is scheduled to unveil the annual Special 301 list on May 1, which targets major US trade partners who allegedly fail to properly protect intellectual property rights. Taiwan was put on the Special 301 watch list in 1999. (BY Sofia wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: SCIENCE PARK TURNOVER UP MORE THAN 50 PERCENT IN 1ST TWO MONTHS
DOC.DATELINE: Hsinchu, northern Taiwan, April 22 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: Business turnover in the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park (HSIP) amounted to NT$123.35 billion (US$4.04 billion) in the first two months of this year, HSIP administration officials said on Saturday.
The figure represents a 50-percent increase over the same period of last year, the officials said.

Semiconductor manufacturing companies and related processors located in the HSIP posted even more enviable business turnover during the Jan.-Feb. period, enjoying a whopping 60 percent increase, the officials went on.
According to park administration tallies, turnover in Taiwan's "Silicon Valley" totaled NT$650.9 billion (US$21.34 billion) in 1999, up 43 percent over the figure recorded for 1998.
It is estimated that turnovers of all HSIP companies as a whole will reach NT$800 billion (US$26.23 billion) this year, based on brisk performances in the first two months.

Of the 291 companies in the park, 118 are semiconductor manufacturing processors and related companies, 51 are makers of computers and peripherals, 47 are companies dealing with telecommunications and opti-electronic industries, while 13 are manufacturers of precision instruments and 15 companies are involved in bio-tech production, according to the officials.

The tallies show that turnover in the semiconductor manufacturing industry in the HSIP totaled NT$72.74 billion (US$2.385 billion) in the Jan.-Feb. period, up 62.95 percent over the year-earlier level.

The computer and peripherals sector posted a combined turnover of NT$32.98 billion (US$1.08 billion) in the same period, up 22.55 percent. Telecommunications were up 21 percent to NT$5.07 billion (US$166.26 million), opti-electronics were up a whopping 141.14 percent to NT$11.55 billion (US$378.69 million), precision instruments were up 47 percent to NT$873 million (US$28.62 million), and bio-tech products were up 102.71 percent to NT$132 million (US$4.33 million).

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN MINISTER HEADS FOR MAINLAND CHINA FOR FATHER'S FUNERAL

TEXT.P: Republic of China Minister without Portfolio Yang Shih-chien departed for the mainland Chinese city of Shanghai via Macau on Saturday to attend his father's funeral.
Taiwan prohibits government ministers from making private visits to the mainland, but Yang said his visit was approved by the authorities on humanitarian grounds.

Yang's father, Yang Tung-yi, is a former professor at Fudan University at Shanghai. He died on April 14, and the Shanghai City Government is to stage a huge funeral for him, according to local newspapers.
Yang might also meet his uncle, former vice president of the People's Republic of China Rong Yiren, at the funeral, the newspapers reported.
Yang, who has served as director-general of the Industrial Development Bureau under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, was an important adviser to former premier Lien Chan on industrial policy.
He recently turned down an offer to head the Council for Economic Planning and Development in the administration of president-elect Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: PEOPLE FIRST PARTY CALLS FOR HALT IN REVAMPING CONSTITUTION

TEXT.P: The newly founded People First Party (PFP) called for a halt in revamping the Constitution by the National Assembly (NA) on Saturday, branding the draft amendments unconstitutional.

In a press conference held by the PFP caucuses in the Legislative Yuan and the National Assembly (NA), the party founded by former Taiwan Provincial Governor James Soong called on the assemblymen to stop tinkering with the Constitution in light of the fact that there is less than one month to go before their tenures expire.

Kao Pao-hua, a spokesman for the PFP caucus in the NA, dismissed as undemocratic a proposal worked out by the two major parties -- the Kuomintang and the Democratic Progressive Party -- to make the NA a forum of delegates appointed by political parties under a system of proportional representation.

Noting that only one-tenth of the population has registered as a member of any political party, Kao warned that the voices of the other ninth-tenths of the people would be excluded from the NA if such a system were to be adopted.

Under the dominance of the KMT and the DPP, Kao said, the revamp of the Constitution has degenerated into mere horse-trading between the two parities. Between them, they have stymied any sensible debate through procedural maneuvering, and have failed to solicit public opinion on issues regarding the amendments.
He criticized the two parties' plan to vote out the NA and downgrade it to an ad hoc assembly as a political plot to prevent the PFP from flexing its political muscle in a NA election.
Kao said his party members will boycott the second reading of the draft Constitutional amendments to protest the two parties' "manipulation" of the constitutional reform process.

The PFP will rejoin the session to support an amendment guaranteeing the rights of military personnel and another calling for a majority vote for the presidential election winners. Under the current system, the election is decided on a first-past-the-post system.

DOC.HEADLINE: `NO HASTE, BE PATIENT' POLICY SHOULD NOT BE COMPROMISED: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian's administration should not sacrifice the existing "no haste, be patient" government policy on mainland China-bound investment, a National Taiwan University economics professor said on Saturday.

Speaking at a seminar on policy and strategy for the new century, Prof. Chen Po-chih said the incoming government should not drop the "no haste" or "go slow" mainland investment policy simply because of token goodwill responses from Beijing.

President-elect Chen said previously that if Beijing responds with goodwill to Taiwan's calls for an end to saber-rattling and for resumption of regular dialogue, his administration will review Taiwan's "go slow" mainland investment policy.
However, Prof. Chen said his call is based not on political considerations, but was made for economic reasons.

Noting that national savings account for 25 percent of Taiwan's gross domestic product (GDP) and investment accounts for about 23 percent, the scholar pointed out that Taiwan's excess national savings make up only 2 percent of the GDP.
Against this backdrop, Chen said that if local businessmen swarm to invest in the mainland, domestic investment will certainly be affected and might even be squeezed out.

More important, Chen went on, both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) in the near future, at which time Taiwan will have to compete with the mainland on an unequal footing.

With Taiwan's current economic strength, Chen said Taiwan is finding it hard to meet the WTO's requirement for "zero tariff" trade. In contrast, Chen said, mainland China, with its immense land area, rich natural resources and cheap labor, is in a much stronger position to conduct "zero tariff" trade.

Therefore, Chen said, the new ROC government should still impose some restrictions on local enterprises' investment activities in mainland China, including limiting the lines of business they can pursue and capping of amount of investment to be allowed for each project.

Some media reports have tipped the professor as the probable new chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development in the new administration, but he dismissed the reports as sheer speculation.

Judging from the new Cabinet line-up confirmed on Friday, Chen said he is worried that the new government lacks a strong team of experts to resolve the many thorny economic and financial problems Taiwan now faces.

He suggested that after assuming office on May 20, the new Cabinet ministers should reduce their speaking and social engagements in order to devote more of their energies to inter-ministerial coordination and communication to ensure smooth teamwork and upgraded operational efficiency.

Chen, an anti-nuclear activist, further suggested that as the outgoing Kuomintang government has spent over NT$100 billion on the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project, the new government should not hastily suspend the construction project but should instead conduct a comprehensive review before deciding whether to kill or continue the construction project.

DOC.HEADLINE: ENVIRONMENTAL MISERY INDEX RISES

TEXT.P: Taiwan's environmental misery index has risen to 77.98 points over the past year, according to the results of a Gallup opinion poll released on Saturday.
The results of the survey commissioned by the private Environmental Quality Protection Foundation (EQPF) were released to coincide with the World Earth Day.
This is the sixth consecutive year that the foundation has conducted the annual environmental misery index survey with a view to understanding local people's feelings about their living environment.
The survey results show that this year's misery index is the second highest, behind only 1995's 78.72-point index.
According to the survey, 80 percent of the respondents felt that vehicle exhaust, river pollution and rampant overuse of plastic containers are the most serious or intolerable environmental issues.

EQPF Secretary-General Liu Ming-lung said the rise in this year's misery index is mainly because local people have become more worried about pollution caused by household waste water, waste plastic containers, poor water and soil conservation, noise pollution and bad smells.

Of the 20 categories of environmental issues measured in the survey, only wildlife protection shows significant progress, with more respondents feeling that the killing of endangered species in Taiwan has declined.
The telephone survey of 1,003 adult residents was conducted between April 15 and April 20.

The poll found that most respondents believe that reform-minded Chen Shui-bian's election as the Republic of China's next president will contribute positively to Taiwan's future environmental protection work.

However, the poll results also show that Chen's campaign promises to cancel the controversial fourth nuclear power plant project and oppose the proposed construction of a dam in Kaohsiung County's Meinung township have not received majority support.

Since more than half of those surveyed do not support Chen's proposals to suspend construction of the fourth nuclear power plant and the Meinung dam, Liu said Chen should not deliver on his campaign promises on the two issues after he assumes office.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC VICE PRESIDENT HOPES TO VISIT MAINLAND CHINA AFTER MAY 20

TEXT.P: Republic of China Vice President Lien Chan said on Saturday that he hopes to visit his birthplace -- the mainland Chinese city of Xian -- after he steps down as vice president on May 20.

He made the remarks while having lunch with reporters to express his appreciation for the reportage of the March 18 presidential election, in which he lost his bid as Kuomintang candidate for the country's top post.

Lien, who is presently acting KMT chairman, said that he hopes to revisit Xian at "an appropriate time" to bring the remains of his grandmother back to Taiwan for burial together with his grandfather.

Talking about KMT reform after the party's election defeat, Lien said he is resolved to engage in all-out reform so that the party can rise again. He stressed that the KMT remains an important power of the country.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Sunday are as follows:

Though the United States delayed the sale of Aegis destroyers to Taiwan, it will have an overall assessment of Taiwan's naval warfare ability and make a final decision in arms consultation with Taiwan next year, US Under Secretary of Defense Walter Slocombe says.

President-elect Chen Shui-bian reaffirms that as long as "one China" principle is not a precondition for cross-strait talks, there will be ample room for both sides of the strait to talk about.

Lin Chuan, the designated head of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS), says the top priority will be to deliver Chen's campaign promise: the youngsters will get a loan at a rate of three-percent in buying their first houses, those over 65-year-olds will have a stipend of NT$3,000 a month, and children under three-year-olds will visit the hospitals for free.
The Liberty Times:
DGBAS head says the allocation of central government revenues to local-level governments will be institutionalized in three years.
The China Post:
US snatches Elian from Miami relatives.

Armed US agents snatch Cuban boy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN-BORN JAPANESE IMPERIAL ARMY VETERAN FINDS FAME AFTER 50 YRS (I)

TEXT.P: Chien Mao-sung, 75, is a native Taiwanese who served in former Japanese imperial army during World War Two, and he is now living in Japan with special permanent resident status.
Chien drove a taxi for 30 years in Tokyo, but has recently found fame through a book about his life, entitled "I was a Japanese Soldier," which is now selling well in Japan.

Chien was born in the township of Tucheng, in northern Taiwan's Taipei County. When he was 17 years old, he was recruited into a special unit of the Japanese imperial army. He was sent to Borneo where he served as a guard in a prisoner of war (POW) detainment camp at Kuching.

Later, he formally joined the Japanese imperial army as a private. But when Japan was defeated by allied forces led by the United States, Chien found himself sentenced to a five-year prison term in Australia.

He served the complete sentence, only to be forcefully expatraited from Australia on March 3, 1951. Considering himself to be a Japanese citizen, he decided to go to Japan. He says that he can never forget the day he entered Japan, because an immigration officer told him that he was no longer a Japanese citizen. The official asked why he had not returned to Taiwan, and then issued him a temporary visitor's visa.
Chien was shocked by the immigration official's action. The realization of the sudden abandonment of his "motherland" left him feeling hopeless and helpless.

Being stripped of his Japanese citizenship had grave consequences for him. Despite his years of military service, he would not be able to receive his military pension, back-pay still owed to him. He was even denied access to his military post deposits. At the time, he didn't have enough money to return to Taiwan.

After this event, he decided to abandon his Japanese surname -- "Takenaka" -- and restored his original Chinese surname. He swore that he would not leave Japan and would not naturalize until the Japanese government apologized to him and paid him the money they owed him.

Chien said he was carrying a letter written by Gen. Hitoshi Imamura who served in prison with Chien in Australia. Gen. Imamura had promised to him that the Japanese government would treat him as a Japanese citizen.

In Gen. Imamura's letter, which was published by the Japanese Ministry of Foreign Affairs in June 1998, the general reminded the Japanese government to give the same treatment to Taiwan-born former Japanese imperial army soldiers as that given to ethnic Japanese veterans.

Chien ran away from the reception center that the immigration officials had ordered him to inhabit. He became a drifter, and wandered from place to place seeking employment. For the next 50 years, he worked as a tailor or taxi driver.

Asked why he did not return to Taiwan, as he now still holds a passport of the Republic of China, he replied that he was afraid of Taiwan's ruling Kuomintang (KMT), which oppressed ethnic Taiwanese after the so-called "Feb. 28 Incident" occurred in 1947. Relatives in Taiwan also dissuaded him from returning there, he said. (more)

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE IMPERIAL VETERAN (II)

TEXT.P: However, an forgettable thing occurred in 1972, when was at the age of 37. He and some 30 Taiwan-born Imperial Army veterans in Japan wrote a letter to Generalissimo Chiang Kai-shek in 1972, asking the President to help them seek compensation from the Japanese government, and described the unfair treatment they had recieved in Japan.
He was surprised when President Chiang responnded by summoning him along with two other letter writters to come to Chungshan Hall at Yangminshan in surburban Taipei, he recalled.
Chiang also explained why he implemented a policy of benevolence toward Japan after World War Two.

He and his two colleagues has high priase for the late president's benevolence policy, and described him as a far-sighted stateman. Chien believes that Japan could never have risen from the rubble of war to become a major world economic power if it were not for Chiang Kai-shek's benovolence policy

Four year ago, the god of good luck finally knocked on his door. Hiroichi Hamazaki, a Yomiuri Shimbun reporter, flagged down his taxi for a ride. After hearing Chien's story, the journalist decided to write a book about the unfiar treatment Chien had received in Japan. The book titled "I was a Japanese soldier," was releasd in March. Chien has since become a minor celebrity in Japan.

The Japanese ruling Liberal Democratic Party is now planning to draft legislation to pay up to four million Japanese yen to families of deceased soldiers. But this law will exclude Chien abd many of his fellow countrymen.
He says that he has recently begun to wonder wether he will ever receive compensation from the Japanese government, as he will turn 76 soon.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 23, or the 19th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1616: William Shakespeare, English playwright and poet whose body of works is considered the greatest in English literature, dies at New Place at the age of 52. His plays include historical works, such as "Richard II"; comedies, including "Much Ado about Nothing" and "As You Like It"; and tragedies, such as "Hamlet," "Othello" and "King Lear." He also composed 154 sonnets.
1616: Miguel de Cervantes, Spanish writer who is best known for his classic satirical novel "Don Quixote," dies at the age of 69.
1873: The Dutch war against the Sultan of Achin begins in northwest Sumatra, Indonesia.
1895: Russia, Germany and France protest against the cession of Chinese territory to Japan.
1897: Lester Pearson, Canadian prime minister from 1963-1968, is born. He won the 1957 Nobel Peace Prize for his part in settling the Suez crisis.
1919: Peking Teachers High School for Girls is formally established.
1928: Shirley Temple Black, American child star who went on to become US ambassador to Ghana, is born. As Shirley Temple she was an immensely popular child actress of the 1930s, starring in films such as "Wee Willie Winkie" and "Bright Eyes."
1935: Joseph Stalin officially opens the Moscow underground rail system.
1945: US and Soviet forces meet at Torgau in eastern Germany.
1946: Hsia Kai-chun, noted writer of modern Chinese literature, dies in Shanghai at the age of 63.
1949: Government forces of the Republic of China evacuate Nanking.
1962: In the biggest-ever "ban the bomb" demonstration, some 150,000 people rally in London's Hyde Park.
1965: The Soviet Union launches its first communications satellite.
1965: President Charles de Gaulle of France emphasizes his opposition to the United States' Asian policies by withdrawing French units from naval maneuvers of the Southeast Asia Treaty Organization.
1969: A Los Angeles jury decides that Sirhan B. Sirhan should be sent to the gas chamber for the murder of Sen. Robert Kennedy in June 1968.
1975: US President Gerald Ford declares the Vietnam War is over as panic grips Saigon after its Cabinet resigns.
1985: The Industrial Technology Research Institute successfully develops an amorphous-silicon solar battery of high commercial value.
1986: National Taiwan University Hospital separates a pair of 14-day-old Siamese twins, saving the life of one of the girls. The twins set a record for being the youngest to be separated.
1990: American Professor Robert Polhill is released in Beirut after 39 months in captivity by Islamic fundamentalist groups.
1990: Li Peng, premier of mainland China, arrives in Moscow for a visit, becoming the most senior Beijing leader to tour the Soviet Union in 26 years.
1991: Tens of thousands of striking Soviet workers fill the streets in Minsk on the eve of the Communist Party plenum.
1997: After 26 days of occupation by rebels, Peru's government launches a sudden attack on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima, freeing 71 hostages. Three soldiers, one hostage and all 14 guerrillas die in the attack.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man is one who sets himself seriously to order his conversation aright."

DOC.HEADLINE: EARLY MOVE TO UNIFICATION TALKS NOT IN TAIWAN'S INTERESTS: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A Kuomintang (KMT) official said on Sunday that if the two sides of the Taiwan Strait move too quickly to begin negotiations on reunification, it will not be in the interests of the people or conform to their aspirations.

Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the KMT Department of Mainland Affairs Research, was responding to President-elect Chen Shui-bian's recent remarks about the possible direction of cross-strait relations, including federation, confederation or even commonwealth.

Chang said that as national leader, Chen should forego advocating Taiwan independence, and thus avoid a war with the mainland. But he also said that starting cross-strait talks on unification too early would not be beneficial.
Chang said that a federation can have only one central government and one constitution, and the sovereign status of the Republic of China would surely disappear under such a model.
Chen has not considered the wishes of Taiwan's public in this regard, Chang said.

As for confederation, a structure formed by two or more political entities that remain as separate sovereign states, Chang said Beijing's current policy would not allow for such a model. He added that Beijing would certainly not allow a commonwealth arrangement, as it would be an even looser formation.

But Chang said that the most important point is not which reunification model Beijing deems acceptable, but rather whether Chen's administration can forge a national consensus, uphold Taiwan interests, and win international recognition.

He noted that after Chen's victory in the March 18 presidential election, his handling of cross-strait relations has been "too rash". Chang urged Chen to follow President Lee Teng-hui's example of tenacity and resilience in handling cross-strait ties.

In addition to moderating what he sees as Chen's rash mentality, Chang said that Chen should also avoid taking the naive approach of playing his cards -- such as the "three direct links" card -- too quickly. He said that Chen should maintain a strong stance in dealing with cross-strait ties.

He noted that Chen has refrained from talking about "special state-to-state relations" since winning the election. He said that this may lead Beijing to think that it could pressure Chen to bend to its will.

Chen has also said that establishing the "three direct links" with mainland China will be a major goal of his administration, but Chang said Beijing may very well turn a deaf ear to Chen's call. Though Chen could blame Beijing for such an attitude, it would also show that Chen lacks a full understanding of cross-strait relations, Chang added.
Chen said on Friday that there is room for discussion in forming a "confederation" between the two sides of the Taiwan strait to take the place of "special state-to-state relations."

High-ranking cross-strait exchanges were disrupted after mainland China reacted angrily to President Lee Teng-hui's statement defining "special state-to-state" relations across the Taiwan Strait in July 1999.

Chen also said on Saturday that as long as the "one China" principle is not set as precondition of cross-strait talks, then there is ample room for discussion on ties, including confederation, federation, or commonwealth, but that the final decision would be made by the 23 million people in Taiwan.

Mainland China has deep-rooted misgivings about Chen because of his membership in the Democratic Progressive Party, which has in the past advocated Taiwan independence. Nevertheless, Beijing has toned down its verbal attack against Chen and adopted a "wait and see" attitude in the wake of the election.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US OFFICIAL VISITS PFP CHAIRMAN JAMES SOONG

TEXT.P: Former US Assistant Secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord on Sunday visited People First Party (PFP) Chairman James Soong to exchange opinions on the situation across the Taiwan Strait.

Lord declined to comment following the hour-long meeting, while Soong told reporters that the major purpose of Lord's visit to the PFP was to gain a better understanding of party views on relations between Taiwan and mainland China in the wake of Taiwan's March 18 presidential election.

As the former US official is very concerned about the future of Taiwan-mainland China ties, Soong said they had swapped opinions on issues related to the "one China" principle and the Guidelines for National Unification.

Although Soong was reluctant to quote what Lord had said during their meeting, he pointed out that Taiwan's viewpoint on the present cross-strait situation differs from that of the United States and other countries.

The PFP chairman said that the international community thinks that the relationship between Taiwan and mainland China has come to a very critical juncture, and that Lord had suggested that the two sides should hammer out an appropriate solution to ease current tensions.

According to Soong, he told Lord that he is very much aware of the escalating tensions across the Taiwan Strait and that the new government to be led by the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must take effective measures to ease the situation.

The people of Taiwan are not willing to succumb to Beijing's rule, nor do they wish to engage in war with mainland China, Soong explained. He stressed that any move which might affect Taiwan's future must be decided by the island's 21 million people. This goes along with "the mainstream opinion among the people of Taiwan," he emphasized.

Turning to Lord's questions about the direction that President-elect Chen Shui-bian might set in his inaugural speech on May 20, Soong asserted that the DPP must first learn how to act as a responsible ruling party by avoiding making irresponsible statements and mudslinging against members of other political camps.

"Maybe each political party has different points of view from others, but we should join forces to fight for the country's common interests to fall in line with the public's expectations," he told Lord.
As Lord will proceed to mainland China after concluding his visit here, Soong also called on the Beijing leadership not to underestimate the determination of the Taiwan people.

Lord is heading a four-member delegation that also includes Douglas Paal, a former member of the US National Security Council (NSC) and current head of the Asia Pacific Policy Center; George Schwab, president of a the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP); and Professor Donald Zagoria, a senior NCAFP member and also a former member of the NSC.
The delegation arrived in Taipei late Saturday for a three-day fact-finding visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: SOUTHERN MAINLAND CHINA UNDERSTANDS TAIWAN BETTER: DPP OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: A legislator of the Democratic Progressive Party said on Sunday that southern region of mainland China has a deeper understanding of Taiwan due to long-established trade relations.

Legislator Hsu Jung-shu said that because of this understanding, people in the southern region of China do not interpret the March 18 election of the DPP's Chen Shui-bian as a bid for Taiwan independence.

Hsu had just returned from a e-commerce forum in Guangzhou, Guangdong Province, in the southeastern part of the mainland. She was the first legislator from the DPP to travel to the mainland since Taiwan's presidential election which saw the end of Kuomintang's rule of the island for more than five decades.

Hsu said that during her stay she learned that people in southern China do not interpret Chen's victory as a bid by the Taiwan public to push for independence from mainland China. This is despite the fact that Beijing has consistently maintained that the "one China" principle be a pre-condition for renewed cross-strait talks in the wake of the election.

Hsu said that the economy in northern China is behind that of the southern part, especially in the northwestern region where living conditions are poor and trade relations with Taiwan minimal. Without such links to provide a basis for understanding, she said that people there are more likely to see Chen's election as a bid for independence, adding fuel to the hawkish rhetoric from the mainland.

Hsu said that the mainland's southerners know that Taiwan is a place where people enjoy freedom of speech, and that if there is a call for independence or for unification, it will only be possible after a national consensus is forged.

She also said that though Chen's new administration has yet to confer with DPP members on cross-strait exchanges, she believes that Taiwan could increase trade and cultural exchanges with the mainland, saying that this is the best way for both sides to develop long-standing relations.
Hsu, who said her group was well received during the recent visit, will again visit the mainland in September when she will attend an international conference in Beijing.

DOC.HEADLINE: KAOHSIUNG MEDICAL GROUP LODGES COMPLAINT AGAINST TECO IN ARGENTINA

TEXT.P: A Kaohsiung medical group has lodged a complaint against the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office (TECO) in Argentina. The group claims that TECO did not protect its member rights and interests as ROC citizens visiting Argentina.
A spokesman for the group told local press that they attempted to visit Buenos Aires last week to attend a medical meeting but that immigration officials denied them entrance into Argentina.

TECO in Buenos Aires, which represents the Republic of China in Argentina in the absence of diplomatic ties between the two countries, did not protect the ROC's citizen's interests and rights in the case, he said.

Henry Chen, a spokesman for the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), said that MOFA has ordered TECO in Argentina to issue a report on the incident. He said that the results will be forwarded to the medical group.
Chen said that MOFA has also contacted the medical group to gather information and to explain measures that will be adopted.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT KICKS OFF GRATITUDE TOUR

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu kicked off an islandwide tour on Sunday to express thanks to their supporters in the March 18 presidential vote.
Chen and Lu will start their 13-day tour in eastern Taiwan county of Hualien, according to a ranking official of the soon-to-be ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).

All members of the public, whether they voted for the Chen-Lu ticket or not, will be welcome to take part in the pair's gratitude celebrations, which will be held in 23 counties and cities, the DPP official said.

DOC.HEADLINE: ELDERLY FARMERS AND FISHERMEN RECEIVE GOV. SUBSIDIES OF NT$ 79 BILLION

TEXT.P: The government has distributed a total of NT$78.57 billion in subsidies to 618,000 elderly farmers and fishermen as of the end of March this year, the Cabinet-level Council of Agriculture (COA) said Sunday.
The COA said that in order to strengthen the work of caring for elderly farmers and fishermen, it plans to establish extensive information centers and recreational facilities for them.
The COA began accepting applications for subsidies from elderly farmers and fishermen in August 1995.

At present, there are 481,200 farmers who are at or above the age of 65, accounting for 12.9 percent of total agricultural workers on the island, a sign that Taiwan's agriculture workforce as a whole is gradually aging.
The COA's future information centers for elderly farmers and fishermen will provide them with health care and other welfare measures, the agency said.
The COA plans to select 50 sites for various recreation facilities for elderly farmers and fishermen, it said.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA URGED TO STOP SMUGGLING OF WEAPONS TECHNOLOGY

TEXT.P: Mainland China has become a major source of illegal international arms and weapons technology and should take more effective action against suspected arms smugglers, a leading Bangkok-based English newspaper urged in its editorial on Sunday.

Chinese-made arms have been found in Iraq, Libya and Angola, all of which are under UN arms sanctions, the Bangkok Post said. It added that arms-related money laundering threatens to corrupt and weaken mainland China, and illegal arms dealing threatens the peace of the world.
The Post reminded China's leaders that in recent years arms merchants and smuggling rings in China are now regularly making "the biggest illegal arms deals" in the world.

"They have established companies and offices deep within the actual Chinese government," the paper said. It added that many of the big-time arms smugglers operate with the intentional or unwitting help of the central and regional governments of mainland China. (by Kuo Fang-chih)

DOC.HEADLINE: COA TO PROVIDE LOW-INTEREST LOANS FOR SEEDLING SECTOR

TEXT.P: The Cabinet-level Council for Agriculture (COA) has earmarked NT$100 million for loans to individuals and groups engaged in seedling planting and selling.
The move is part of plans to develop Taiwan as a seedling center in the Asia-Pacific region, the COA said Sunday.
The highest interest rate for the loans will be 5.5 percent, and the maximum amount of a single loan will be NT$6 million, said the COA.
It said that individuals and groups engaged in seedling planting and selling can apply for loans to establish greenhouses, or to purchase or renovate related machinery.

DOC.HEADLINE: INTERNET SURFERS HAIL CHEN'S CAPACITY TO HANDLE CIVILIAN ISSUES

TEXT.P: Most Taiwan's Internet surfers give high ratings to President-elect Chen Shui-bian's ability to handle civilian issues, while they are somewhat reserved about his dealings of cross-strait ties, a recent survey has found.

According to the results released on Sunday by Gallop's 24th poll of Internet users, 84.5 percent of the respondents think that Chen will be able to upgrade the government's efficiency, while 65.1 percent are confident of Chen's ability to maintain political stability in Taiwan.

At the same time, 64.1 percent said they believe that Taiwan's booming economy will continue to prosper under Chen's leadership, and 63.3 percent said they are supportive of point-to-point direct shipping links between Taiwan and mainland China.

However, only 51.5 percent of the public think that Chen will be able to reform Taiwan's money-dominated political culture, as opposed to 42.4 percent who expect that he will be able to bring about reform, the survey indicated.

Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) lawmaker Shen Fu-hsiung and Gallop executive T. Y. Ting attributed the surfing public's lower rating of Chen's ability to end money politics in Taiwan to a lack of faith in the government's capability to get rid of the deep-rooted problem overnight.
The DPP is to take the helm of the central government on May 20.

On the question of military conflicts with mainland China, 47.3 percent of the Internet users said that they expect he will definitely be able to maintain peace across the Taiwan Strait, while 42.7 percent said that he will not be able to avoid military conflict, according to the poll.

In contrast, 72.3 percent of those website surfers predicted that it is very likely that Chen will be able to maintain peace in the strait, much higher than 19.7 percent who said they do not believe it is likely.

UFO radio station chairman and political analyst S. K. Chao said that the results of the former question reflect the degree of the public's confidence in Chen's ability to deal with cross-strait problems, while those of the latter question indicate the public's thoughts on the possibility of war between the two sides.
Despite the fact that Chen is determined to duly address cross-strait disputes, Chao explained that the overall environment between the two sides is beyond Chen's control.

Judging from Chen's cautious attitude toward cross-strait relations following his election on March 18 as Taiwan's new president, Chao predicted that the president-elect will continue to adopt a low-profile approach and that two-way Taiwan-mainland links will continue to be "cold" over the short term.
Chao said that it is hard to predict long-term developments at present, although he feels there will be no military conflict between Taiwan and mainland China in the short term.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN CHAN SAYS HE HAS NO PLAN TO VISIT CHINESE MAINLAND

TEXT.P: Lien Chan, who will step down from the vice presidency next month, said Sunday that he has never had any plan to visit the Chinese mainland.

He told the press that he will visit foreign countries at the invitation of many foreign friends after he steps down from the vice presidency on May 20, but he has no plan to go to the Chinese mainland.
Lien made the remarks after news media reported recently that he might go to the Chinese mainland to bring back the remains of her grandmother, who died in Xian in central China in late 1930s.
