DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES PLUNGE BY 312.39 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Monday, with the benchmark-weighted price index plunging 312.39 points to close at 8,808.09.
Market turnover amounted to NT$119.58 billion (US$ 3.92 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: DOMESTIC PLANE SKIDS OFF RUNWAY, NO INJURIES REPORTED

TEXT.P: All 73 passengers and six crew members aboard a Far Eastern Air Transport Corp. plane were reported safe after the MD82 plane skidded off the runway at an airport in southern Taiwan on Monday morning.

A Far Eastern spokesperson said flight No.28011 took off from Taipei in northern Taiwan at 6:40 a.m. When landing at Chiayi Airport at 7:30 a.m. amid heavy rain, the plane skidded a few meters off the runway before coming to a full stop.
Far Eastern officials believe the downpour which made the runway very slippery at the time was the main reason for the accident.
Because of the incident, Chiayi Airport was temporarily shut down, and passengers were either transferred to the nearby Tainan airport or were forced to use rail transportation instead.

Meanwhile, the Aviation Safety Council under the Executive Yuan has sent investigators to Chiayi to investigate the incident and will return with the black boxes -- flight data recorder and cockpit voice recorder -- for analysis on Monday night.

Council Managing Director Kay Jong said that although the plane landed during heavy rains, it had a visibility of one kilometer at the time, adding that determining whether the accident was caused by mechanical failure or by human error will have to wait until the two black boxes are analyzed.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Monday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, plunging 312.39 points to close at 8,808.09.
In an atmosphere of wait-and-see, the bourse opened at 9,128.95 and fluctuated between 9,128.95 and 8,807.71 during trading.
A total of 1.92 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$101.96 billion (US$3.34 billion).
Losers outnumbered gainers 517 to 47, with 33 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with electrical stocks moving down the most at 4.0 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 3.2 percent, foodstuff stocks at 3.1 percent, cement shares at 2.9 percent, construction stocks at 2.8 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 2.1 percent, textile issues at 2.0 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.2 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING MILITARY THREAT MOUNTING: DEFENSE MINISTER-DESIGNATE

TEXT.P: Defense Minister-designate Wu Shih-wen said on Monday that Taiwan's defensive situation has become increasingly trying amid the mounting military threat from mainland China and the continued restrictions on Taiwan's weapon purchases.

Wu, incumbent vice defense minister, said Taiwan's military is facing escalating pressure as China keeps increasing its purchases of advanced weaponry while the island is seeing no improvements in its ability to acquire more advanced defensive weapons.
He made the remarks while fielding questions at the Legislative Yuan.

Wu was recently appointed by Premier-designate Tang Fei to replace him as defense minister. Wu's promotion is believed to be due to the fact that his views on the new defense laws are almost identical to Tang's.
Both Wu and Tang support the implementation of the recently-passed twin laws on defense -- the combat preparedness law and the Ministry of National Defense organization law.

Premier-designated Tang has said that one of the reasons he accepted President-elect Chen Shui-bian's offer to become premier was that he, a keen supporter of the twin laws, wanted to see to it that the newly-approved laws, which face considerable obstacles in the military's rank and file, are carried out smoothly.

Under the new laws, the combat system will be put under the jurisdiction of the Ministry of National Defense (MND). The chief of the General Staff, who previously made direct reports to the president, will report instead to the defense minister.
The general headquarters of each of the three branches of the armed forces will also be downgraded to headquarters of command under the jurisdiction of the MND.
Under the new laws, all military personnel, including the chief of General Staff, will make reports to the defense minister, who alone will report directly to the premier and the president.
Meanwhile, Wu noted that the MND has recently established an exclusive recruitment center in order to attract more young people to join the military.
Wu shunned questions on whether the ROC Air Force was presently facing severe jet fighter pilot and co-pilot shortages of as much as 35 percent.
Wu also played dumb when asked to comment on reports that the French business conglomerate Matra Group is reportedly cooperating with the ROC on establishing a missile maintenance hub in Taiwan.

Wu said all he knows on the subject is what he has read in newspaper reports, adding that he personally would welcome plans for such a cooperation, which he said would greatly reduce transportation costs to Taiwan for its missile maintenance.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Monday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for May moved down 316 points to close at 8,816, with 2,759 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for June decreased 306 points to finish at 8,850, with 73 contract transactions, while September futures moved down 223 points to close at 9,010, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Monday were: 9,132 for May; 9,156 for June; 9,233 for September; 9,306 for December; and 9,609 for next March.
Electronic (TE) futures and financial (TE) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, also moved down.
May TE futures decreased 15.47 points to close at 476, with 930 contract transactions, while June TE futures decreased 15 points to finish at 479, with 18 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
May TF futures moved down 39.2 points to finish at 915.8, with 254 contract transactions, while June TF futures decreased 15 points to close at 941, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: 'ONE CHINA, DIFFERENT DEFINITION' NOT A PRINCIPLE: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: The "one China, different definition" concept is not a principle for negotiation across the Taiwan Strait, a senior official of the Kuomintang, which will soon end its 55-year rule of Taiwan, said on Monday.

Chang Jung-kung, director of the KMT's Mainland Affairs Research Department, made the remarks after meeting with Yu Keli, deputy director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies under the Beijing-based Chinese Academy of Social Sciences (CASS).

Chang said the "one China" concept is the core of cross-strait issue, adding he has learned from his hour-long talks with Yu that mainland China is unlikely to compromise on its so-called "one China" principle which sees one China as the "People's Republic of China" and Taiwan is a province of the PRC.

Chang said the KMT government has responded to Beijing's "one China" principle with a "one China, different definition" concept, which allows each side of the Taiwan Strait to have its own definition of "one China."

The KMT government supports the concept that there is only one China, but it insists that China is now separately ruled by two equal governments -- the Republic of China government on Taiwan and the PRC government on the mainland.

Chang further pointed out that the KMT's "one China, different definition" concept emphasizes its content. "The KMT does not deem the concept as a principle for cross-strait engagement as Beijing has insisted," he noted.

Chang claimed that this "one China, different definition" concept has allowed the KMT government to maintain the ROC's sovereign status while developing relations with mainland China in the past decade.

Chang said Beijing authorities have recently tightened its "one China" principle and hardly left any flexibility on its stance. Chang said Beijing's hardline attitude toward the issue is a crucial problem the incoming government of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) must face and tackle.

Chang said he doesn't know whether Beijing's hardening of its stance on "one China" principle results from its "no confidence" in the incoming DPP government. The DPP used to support Taiwan independence, but has now softened this aspect of its party platform.

Chang suggested that the DPP government adopt the KMT's "one China, different definition" concept which he said mainland China may not fully agree, but will help forge domestic consensus and win recognition in the international community.
Commenting on Yu's hardline rhetoric concerning the "one China" principle during his stay here, Chang said Yu is an academic and that his remarks cannot be interpreted as Beijing's official stance.
Nevertheless, Chang said he believes his meeting with Yu will contribute to the promotion of cross-strait mutual understanding.
Yu arrived in Taipei last Wednesday at head of a delegation of researchers from the CASS's Institute of Taiwan Studies for a fact-finding visit.
While Yu said his mission is mainly aimed at promoting exchanges with major Taiwan political parties and groups, he has declined to meet with officials of the DPP, the ROC's would-be ruling party.

In the past few days, Yu have met with officials of the People First Party, the New Party and the KMT, as well as with executives of certain pro-unification groups here. The mainland delegation traveled to Kaohsiung on Monday afternoon to continue its Taiwan visit.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA MOVES TO CONTROL CYBERSPACE

TEXT.P: Mainland China has moved to control the internet by blocking access to overseas sites while trying to maintain the economic advantages of the information age, according to the Sydney Morning Herald on Monday.

In a dispatch from Beijing, the daily reported that the new Internet Information Management Bureau will control which news reports are published on the internet and also try to improve the quality of domestic Web sites, replacing an ad hoc system that has involved various departments.

China-based Internet providers are barred from running foreign news on their Web sites, which now must carry reports from official news outlets. Several foreign news organizations, particularly from America, cannot be accessed through Chinese providers, the daily reported.
The internet is booming in mainland China with an estimated 9 million users as of the end of 1999, and the figure is expected to surge to 20 million by the end of this year.
Most users access the Web from their home, but one in 10 make use of the growing number of internet cafes, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: S. AFRICAN SCHOLARS CRITICIZE CHINA'S HUMAN RIGHTS RECORD

TEXT.P: The arrival of Communist Chinese President Jiang Zemin on a state visit Monday again highlights the contradiction between South Africa's professed human rights foreign policy and its pursuit of national interests, pointed out two South African scholars in an article published in the weekly Sunday Independent.

Director of Studies of the South African Institute of International Affairs Elizabeth Sidiropoulos and Taiwan Asia-Pacific Researcher of the institute Monika Glinzler said that given South Africa's human rights emphasis, there has always been an expectation that Pretoria would be more vocal on this issue.
They said that the tide is turning in international relations towards recognizing the supremacy of basic human rights over sovereignty where a state undermines such rights.
South African President Thabo Mbeki's African renaissance places great importance on human rights and good governance, the two scholars said.

As part of the developing world and with a ruling party that has had historical links with China, it is in a better position than the US to impress on China the need for reform to avoid long-term social upheaval, the article pointed out.

On Taiwan, they noted that the consolidation of democracy there has made the one-China policy impractical. They added that it is inconceivable that the island should be absorbed into an undemocratic mainland state.
"Beijing's belligerence, insistence on reunification and refusal to accept Taiwan's statehood as a condition for negotiation virtually close off all avenues for discussion," they stated.

DOC.HEADLINE: MONSOON RAINS STRAND DONG HWA UNIVERSITY RESEARCH TEAM IN MOUNTAINS
DOC.DATELINE: Hualien, eastern Taiwan, April 24 (CNA) (By Deborah Kuo)

TEXT.P: A sudden downpour on Monday morning causing landslides has stranded a research team from National Dong Hwa University in the mountains of eastern Taiwan, according to sources from Dong Hwa University.

The Dong Hwa team, comprised of three professors and 11 graduate students from the university's Institute of Tourism and Recreation Management, was reported missing earlier in the day after none of the team members showed up as scheduled on Sunday evening after a two-day and two-night research expedition into the mountains.

Believing the team to be stranded because of monsoon rains pouring down in the mountainous areas of eastern Taiwan since the small hours of Monday morning, causing river levels to rise rapidly, 19 rescue police officers and aboriginal youths were mobilized and sent to areas where the team might be located.
By noon, the rescuers had made contact with the team members and were told that they were safe but awaiting help, the university sources said.
If the rains continue to subside in the afternoon, according to the rescuers, the entire research team will be safely escorted back to Hualien in the evening.
The team departed on Saturday morning and was scheduled to return from the mountains on Sunday afternoon before heading for Hualien City.
Meanwhile, monsoon rains have been reported across all of central and northern Taiwan as of noon on Monday.
In central Taiwan's Nantou County, roads were blocked as a result of mud-slides and landslides triggered by heavy rains over the past several days.

The Central Weather Bureau on Monday continued to issue warnings that the heavy rains Taiwan has been experiencing over the last two days may trigger devastating floods and landslides in central Taiwan, particularly in mountainous areas.
Weathermen said monsoon rains may also threaten areas in northern Taiwan beginning Monday.
In the capital city of Taipei in northern Taiwan, traffic jams were reported on major roads Monday morning because of the rains.
Meteorologists said the weather is expected to remain unstable throughout the week.

DOC.HEADLINE: MARCH FIGURES SHOW TAIWAN JOBLESS RATE DOWN

TEXT.P: Taiwan's unemployment rate dropped slightly to 2.83 percent in March, 0.04 percent lower than that of February, thanks to the recovering domestic economy and seasonal factors, the government reported on Monday.

Due to the continued economic upswing and an increased number of people returning to work after having found new jobs after the Chinese Lunar New Year, which usually falls in February, the number of unemployed people in Taiwan totaled 274,000 in March, representing an unemployment rate of 2.83 percent, officials from the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) said.
DGBAS officials forecast that if the economy suffers no major setbacks this year, the average annual jobless rate in Taiwan should be kept a comfortable low of 2.8 percent in 2000.
According to DGBAS tallies, Taiwan's workforce totaled 9.43 million people at the end of March, up 155,000 over the year-earlier level, and 24,000 more than were recorded in February.
Meanwhile, the number of jobless people in Taiwan dropped by 8,000 to 274,000 in March from February's 282,000.

The number of workers in the service industry increased by 16,000 in the first three months of this year, compared with 1,000 people in the industrial sector and 6,000 in the agriculture sector, the DGBAS statistics showed.

Nevertheless, according to the DGBAS tallies, the average labor participation rate was 57.43 percent in March, the lowest March level since 1983. The labor participation rate is the ratio of the working population to the population aged 15 and over.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE DECLINES INVITATION TO GIVE FAREWELL SPEECH

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui declined an invitation to give a farewell speech to Taiwan's legislature when he met with Kuomintang (KMT) legislators on Monday.

Lee, who had concurrently served as KMT Chairman before stepping down from his party position to take responsibility for the KMT's defeat in the March 18 presidential election, continued his rounds to meet with KMT legislators over party reforms.

The KMT legislators extended the invitation to the president to give a farewell speech prior to stepping down from office next month. Lee responded that time would not allow for a speech, and that arrangements for the oration would be difficult.
The president added that he had declined similar invitations from President-elect Chen Shui-bian and the National Assembly.

For most of the meeting, Lee listened to the nine legislators. But on party reforms, he said that the personnel and organization of the party all have to be streamlined, adding that the KMT has to rid itself of the impression that it is connected to "black gold" -- illegal money and organized crime.

The legislators' said that the KMT has become demoralized, and expressed the hope that Lee could step in to help. The president's response was that he has already stepped down from the party chairmanship, though he still cares about party reform.
Since he is no longer the KMT party chairman, Lee said that he will now concentrate on the working for the good of the nation.

He also told the legislators that they need to make more of an effort to campaign on their own in future elections, saying that party affiliation may no longer play as vital a role in elections as it has in the past.

DOC.HEADLINE: DEATHS DUE TO OCCUPATIONAL INJURIES TOTALED 650 IN 1999

TEXT.P: A total of 650 people in Taiwan died of occupational injuries in 1999, an average of 1.78 people per day, the cabinet-level Council of Labor Affairs (CLA) reported on Monday.
Last year, a combined 33,709 workers became injured, disabled or were killed while on the job, an average of 92.1 people per day, according to CLA Chairman Chan Hou-sheng.

Chan said Taiwan's occupational injury rate hit its highest level in 1966, with four out of every 1,000 workers dying as a result of injuries in the workplace. The rate dropped to 5.92 out of every 1,000 workers in 1987, with it continuing to fall to 4.41 per 1,000 in 1988. Even that rate was higher than levels posted in other advanced countries, he said.

Taiwan registered a rate of 0.076 deaths for every thousand workers in 1999. This contrasts with Britain's rate of 0.014 and Japan's rate of 0.024, the CLA head noted while speaking at a seminar held by a legislative committee.

Lawmaker Chien Hsi-kai of the Democratic Progressive Party further pointed out that Taiwan's occupational injury rate is five times that of Britain, three times that of Japan, and eight times that of the United States.

As hi-tech industries are increasingly playing a vital role in worldwide development, Chien expressed his opinion that the government should levy heavier punishments on business owners as an effective way to reduce Taiwan's occupational injury rate.

Chan admitted that the CLA has encountered many difficulties in promoting labor safety. A lack of manpower for government inspections, a lack of adequate facilities to protect workers' safety, and a lack of labor safety awareness on the part of corporate management all contribute to the problem, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: `ONE CHINA' PRINCIPLE CANNOT BE PRINCIPLE FOR TALKS: CHEN

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed that he cannot accept demands by mainland China that the "one China" principle be the prerequisite for renewed cross-strait talks.
Chen made the remarks when he met with a four-member delegation from the United States on Monday.

The delegation, led by former US Assistant Secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs Winston Lord, arrived here on Saturday night for a three-day fact-finding trip as part of efforts to ease tensions between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. The delegation will visit mainland China after Taiwan.

With both sides of the Taiwan Strait locking horns over the "one China" issue, Chen asked the US delegation "How can we accept that Taiwan is a part of the People's Republic of China after the people of Taiwan elected me as the 10th president of the Republic of China in the March 18 presidential election?"

Explaining why he cannot accept the "one China" principle as a prerequisite for renewed talks, Chen noted that in 1993 mainland China unveiled a white paper on the Taiwan issue and the unification of China in which it touched on Beijing's interpretation of the "one China" principle -- that there is one China, the PRC is the only legitimate government, and Taiwan is a part of the PRC.
Chen asked "how can we accept such a line of thinking?" and pointed out that this is a "serious question."

He also said that the lack of mutual trust is the biggest hurdle for improving cross-strait ties, but the dearth of trust is mainly the fault of mainland China, which has reneged on its words in the past.

Chen said cross-strait relations may be tense now, but he believes that as long as there is goodwill and sincerity on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, "we have absolute confidence in improving cross-strait relations."
He also stressed that he will support anything that will help improve cross-strait relations, even "track II" or "track III" negotiations.
"Track I" negotiations refers to the talks between Taiwan's Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland China counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS).

The consultation channel of "track I" has largely stalled after Beijing reacted angrily to President Lee Teng-hui's visit to the United States in 1995 and his statement on "special state-to-state" cross-strait relations last year.

Chen said Taiwan is positive that both sides of the Taiwan Strait had reached an agreement in 1992 where the two sides are allowed to interpret the meaning of "one China." But Beijing does not recognize that such an agreement was reached.
Chen said he called on SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu to learn about the situation surrounding the agreement last week.

Other members of the US delegation are Douglas Paal, former member of the US National Security Council and now head of the Asia Pacific Policy Center; George Schwab, who heads the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP); and Professor Donald Zagoria, senior NCAFP member.

Chiou I-jen, Democratic Progressive Party Representative to the US; and Hiao Bi-khim and Liu Shih-chung, Director and Vice Director of the DPP's International Affairs Department, also attended the one-hour meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar fell NT$0.036 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Monday, closing at NT$30.566.
The local currency opened Monday at NT$30.520 and was traded between $NT30.520 and $NT30.596.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$428.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: INDEPENDENCE PARTY CRITICIZES VISITING MAINLAND SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Independence Party (TAIP) on Monday blasted Yu Keli, deputy director of the Institute of Taiwan Studies of Beijing's Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, for his hardline rhetoric concerning relations across the Taiwan Strait.
TAIP Chairman Cheng Pang-chen said Yu, who is currently on a fact-finding trip in Taiwan, has not behaved as a guest or as a scholar during his stay here.
"Yu has instead acted like a 'high-ranking official making an inspection tour of Taiwan," Cheng claimed, adding that Yu's behavior has hurt Taiwan's dignity.
Yu stressed Beijing's "one China" principle upon his arrival in Taipei and demanded that Taiwan's President-elect Chen Shui-bian identify himself as a Chinese in his May 20 inaugural speech.
Beijing's "one China" principle downgrades the Republic of China to a local-level government under the jurisdiction of the "People's Republic of China."
Cheng said Yu's moves were impolite and less-than-subtle, reminding Yu that he has been invited here as an academic to attend seminars on the development of cross-strait relations.

Commenting on Yu's argument that his was just exercising his freedom of speech while making his "one China" remarks, Cheng said Yu apparently has abused his freedom of speech. "I think Yu had better returned to (mainland) China to advocate freedom of speech," he added.

Meanwhile, Cheng reiterated the TAIP's insistence on pursuing Taiwan independence, saying the party opposes President-elect Chen's proposal that Taiwan and mainland China can discuss the feasibility of forming an either federal, confederation or commonwealth relationship to resolve their sovereign disputes.
"We insist on pursuing Taiwan independence and oppose forging any form of ties with (mainland) China," Cheng stressed at a news conference.

Speaking on the same occasion, National Taiwan University professor Cheng Chin-jen said Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) once said in a message to its Taiwan counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF), in 1992 that each side of the Taiwan Strait can orally expressed its own definition of the "one China" principle.

"Beijing, however, has denied this agreement since the end of the first meeting between SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu and ARATS President Wang Daohan in 1993," Prof. Cheng said, adding Yu Keli's recent statement that Beijing cannot accept the "one China, different definition" concept has again proved Beijing's unwillingness to honor its 1992 agreement with Taiwan concerning the "one China" issue.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Monday, April 24, or the 20th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1731: Daniel Defoe, British journalist, novelist and economist, dies at the age of 71. His works include "Robinson Crusoe" and "Moll Flanders."
1800: The US Congress votes to set up a congressional library.
1877: Russia declares war on Turkey.
1898: Spain declares war on the United States after receiving a US ultimatum to pull out of Cuba.
1919: Chan Tien-yu, a railway pioneer in China, dies in Hankou at the age of 59.
1941: Hsieh Chin-yuan, a Chinese hero in the War of Resistance Against Japan, is assassinated and dies at the age of 37. The ROC Army regimental commander led his "800 Brave Fighters" in a heroic battle against invading Japanese troops at a warehouse in Shanghai. Shanghai was captured by the Japanese on November 11, 1937, after three months of fierce fighting.
1942: Barbara Streisand, American actress, director and singer, is born. She won an Oscar for her starring role in "Funny Girl."
1946: The ROC government postpones the convention of the National Assembly set for May 6, 1946.
1948: Lin Hsien-tang is appointed head of the Historical Research Commission of Taiwan Province.
1955: The Bandung Conference ends with five Asian states condemning colonialism by both the West and the Soviet Union.
1963: "Liang Shan-po and Chu Ying-tai," a movie directed by Lee Han-hsiang, premieres in Taipei and receives a warm welcome from a large audience.
1965: The Indonesian government formally takes control of all foreign companies in the country.
1967: Soviet Cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov plunges to Earth and dies when parachute straps on his Soyuz craft get tangled.
1970: Vice Premier Chiang Ching-kuo arrives in New York for a visit and survives an assassination attempt in front of his hotel by a pro-Taiwan independence radical.
1970: Mainland China launches "Tung Fang Hung" ("The East Is Red"), its first satellite, into orbit.
1970: The Food and Fertilizer Technology Center of the Asian and Pacific Council is inaugurated in Taipei.
1974: A 16-member Orient Trade Mission of the US Pacific Northwest International Trade Council, led by William Martin, president of the council, arrives in Taipei for a three-day business trip.
1975: Thousands of Vietnamese refugees are flown to Guam as communists move rapidly in their takeover of South Vietnam.
1976: The 1976 convention of 4-H Clubs opens in Taipei with more than 300 delegates taking part.
1981: A landslide hits a train on its way to Alishan in Chiayi County, killing 10 passengers and injuring 19 others.
1986: Wallis Simpson, Duchess of Windsor, for whom a British king gave up his throne amid great controversy, dies in Paris at the age of 89.
1986: ROC Minister of Foreign Affairs Chu Fu-sung and Paraguayan Foreign Minister Carlos Augusto Saldivar sign an extradition treaty in Taipei on behalf of their respective governments.
1990: East and West Germany agree to set July 2 as the date for economic union, a prelude to full political unification.
1996: Russian President Boris Yeltsin meets with his mainland Chinese counterpart, Jiang Zemin, at the start of a visit to Beijing.
1997: The head of states of Russia, mainland China, Kazakhstan, Tajikistan and Kyrgystan sign a pact on troop reduction along the former Sino-Soviet border.
1998: The first 22 convicts found guilty of committing genocide in 1994 are executed in Rwanda.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "A wise and good man sometimes also meets with distress; but a fool, when in distress, becomes reckless."

DOC.HEADLINE: NON-GOVERNMENT WORKER SALARIES INCREASED 3.68% IN FEB.

TEXT.P: The average salary for industrial and service sector employees in Taiwan came to NT$33,475 in February, some 3.68 percent higher than the same month last year, according to government figures.

The figures released on Monday by the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics (DGBAS) show that economic prospects on the island have made a turn for the better, resulting in higher salaries for workers.
After taking the rate of increase in consumer commodity prices into account, the average salary registered a year-on-year increase of 2.94 percent, the statistics show.

The DGBAS statistics on salaries and worker productivity indicate that the average non-governmental employee logged 159.3 hours of work-time in February, 33.1 hours less than the previous month. This due to the Chinese Lunar New Year holidays, which fell in February this year.

In addition, the government figures also show that the average production volume of the manufacturing sector during January and February this year registered an annual increase of 14.13 percent, while the productivity index increased 6.4 percent from the same period last year.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER CALLS ON CHEN

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian met with former White House National Security Adviser Anthony Lake on Monday.

Lake, who came in the capacity of a private citizen, has kept a low profile since his arrival. He has not revealed his itinerary, so his trip is less conspicuous than the four-member US delegation headed by Winston Lord, who had earlier called on Chen.

Appointed White House National Security Adviser in 1993 by President Bill Clinton, Lake is one of the most influential non-government officials to visit Taiwan since the March 18 presidential election. Therefore, despite his attempts to keep a low profile, his visit has attracted attention.

DOC.HEADLINE: SURVEY: MOST MAINLAND VISITORS HAVE GOOD IMPRESSION OF HONG KONG
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 24 (CNA) (By Mandy Wang & Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: A recent survey by a local institution indicates that most mainland Chinese visitors to Hong Kong have a good impression of the territory, which was returned to the mainland from the United Kingdom in 1997.

The survey, conducted by the Democratic Hong Kong Development Alliance, queried 1,085 mainland visitors last month. Fifty percent of the correspondents said they would visit Hong Kong again if they have the opportunity.
However, about 40 percent of the visitors said prices in Hong Kong are expensive, scenic places are few and air pollution is serious.
Ten percent complained of the complicated procedures for obtaining travel permits, especially those from such inland provinces as Hunan and Jiangsi.

The alliance said that the average mainland visitor spent about HK$600 in Hong Kong per day, and it suggested that Hong Kong authorities should provide more information on buying commodities at reasonable prices so as to maintain Hong Kong's image as a "paradise for shoppers."

Mainland Chinese visitors accounted for the largest number of tourists to Hong Kong, reaching 2 million last year, or 20 percent of the total. That figure is expected to rise to 5 million tourists in the next four years.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING URGED TO CONSIDER CHEN'S CONFEDERATION OVERTURE
DOC.DATELINE: New York, April 23 (CNA) (By Jane Huang and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: A noted mainland Chinese academic urged Beijing on Sunday to consider Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian's peace overture as a way to break the current impasse between the two sides.

Wu Jiaxiang, a close consultant of China's Communist Party former Secretary-General Zhao Ziyang, praised Chen's proposal and hailed his willingness to accept opinions from all walks of life since his victory in Taiwan's presidential election on March 18. Wu's comments were made in an article on a New York-based website.
In the face of fierce pressure from mainland China for Taiwan to start unification talks, Chen suggested last week that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait consider forming a confederation.

Wu, currently a visiting professor at Harvard University, called on Beijing to seriously take the peace overture into account, or follow the example of the European Union in achieving unification through dialogue.
"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should seize the once-in-a-blue-moon opportunity to create a win-win situation for both," he asserted.

Citing that leaders from South and North Korea, after decades of confrontation, have agreed to meet in June for a historic summit, Wu appealed to mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin to have a spirit of love, encouragement and wisdom in dealing with cross-strait affairs. "Act to be a great man, not to be a culprit," he advised.

DOC.HEADLINE: AGENDA NOT YET SET FOR CEC'S TUESDAY MEETING ON NA ELECTION

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) will hold an extraordinary meeting on Tuesday to discuss how to block the National Assembly (NA) election, as the assembly may pass an amendment to convert itself into a task-oriented body. If the assembly fails to pass the amendment, the CEC will discuss procedures related to the election.
Deputies of the NA met on Monday to complete the second and third readings of a constitutional amendment to reduce the body's powers.

However, local election committees on Monday were conducting a drawing for candidates who wish to run in the election. A spokesman of the CEC said that although the drawing was held, the its results will not be published until the constitutional amendment has been completed.

The CEC at its meeting on April 19 completed screening procedures that analyzed individual candidates' qualifications. At the same meeting, it also decided to postpone some election procedures. The CEC asked local election committees to conduct the drawing procedures on Tuesday after considering that the NA would not pass the constitutional amendment bill by April 25.

The spokesman said the CEC would not set any preconditions for the results of the constitutional amendment. The CEC must either make preparations for the upcoming election or suspend it, whether the constitutional amendment is passed or not, he stressed.
The agenda of Tuesday's CEC meeting will be open, he said. If the constitutional amendment bill is passed, the CEC meeting will discuss how to stop the upcoming election.

If the bill is not passed, the CEC will meet to discuss procedures on the scheduling of the election and the publishing of serial numbers drawn by candidates on April 24. The campaign period will begin from April 26 to May 5. The voting will be held on May 6, he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: HOTEL OCCUPANCY RATE IN TAIWAN DOWN LAST YEAR

TEXT.P: Taiwan's average hotel occupancy rate was 60.65 percent last year, a decrease of 1.53 percent compared with the 1998 figure, according to statistics released on Monday by the Tourism Bureau.
Officials of the bureau under the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC), said the decrease could be attributed mainly to the devastating earthquake that hit Taiwan last September.
The biggest reduction in inbound tourists came from Japan, the officials added.
However, hotel occupancy in Taiwan's tourist spots bucked the trend, increasing 2.36 percent over the year-earlier level, especially in places famous for hot springs.

The statistics show that the Grand Formosa Regent Taipei, the Leofoo Hotel and the Hotel Royal Taipei were the top three Taipei hotels in terms of occupancy, while in tourist spots, the Howard Beach Resort Kenting, Caesar Park Hotel-Kenting, and the China Trust Hotel at Sun Moon Lake had the top occupancy rates.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI, BEIJING SHOULD NOT FOCUS ONLY ON MILITARY: SCHOLAR

TEXT.P: The two sides of the Taiwan Strait should not devote too much energy to political and military affairs which could spell disaster to the Chinese people and lead to regional conflict, a noted Chinese-American scholar urged on Monday.
Tien Chang-ling, former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley, made the call in a speech delivered at the opening ceremony of the second world youth summit.
Tien said Taiwan and mainland China should instead focus on economic development, stressing that only a robust economy can protect a country from invasion by foreign forces.
Tien also called on the leaders of all Third World countries not to pay too much attention to "trivial political issues," but to spend more time mulling economic agenda.

In his speech, titled "New Century, New Opportunity, New Vision," Tien said the most important shaping force in the world in the past 50 years has been the development of democracy and technology which he said has in turn led to economic globalization.

Noting that globalization is an irresistible trend, Tien said many developing and under-developed countries have tended to regard globalization as a nightmare because they fear that their industries will be merged or acquired by multinational giants.
From the US viewpoint, Tien went on, globalization is mainly aimed at stimulating Third World countries to accelerate establishment of mechanisms for national modernization.

Tien said globalization-resistant countries like Japan, as well as developing countries like Taiwan and mainland China, need not worry about globalization and should instead take bold steps to speed up domestic reform and restructuring to enhance their competitiveness in the global market. "Otherwise, they will be isolated in the international community," he cautioned.
Tien pointed out that the world is undergoing a "third wave revolution" which has ushered in an era of new economies characterized by information and globalization.

He predicted that economic development in the next century will not be confined to the Internet, software, fiber-optics and telecommunications. "I believe that biotechnology, genetic engineering and the pharmaceutical industry will also play very important roles in economic development in all major countries around the world in the new century," he added.

Tien further said the world will become increasingly peaceful in the years ahead. "There will no longer be massive-scale wars like World War I and World War II. Nevertheless, there will still be regional conflicts, and the number of such conflicts may even increase," he noted, adding that potential flash points include the Balkan states, Africa, North and South Korea, and the Taiwan Strait.

Tien said he hopes the leaders on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be wise enough to avoid confrontation and devote more of their energies to economic development for the well-being of all Chinese people and for the peace of the entire Asia-Pacific region.

The four-day youth summit has brought together 220 youth leaders from 52 countries, including the host Republic of China, to meet in Taipei to discuss youth-related topics. In addition to panel discussion, the delegates will also meet with outgoing ROC President Lee Teng-hui and visit the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park, the stronghold of Taiwan's high-tech industry.

DOC.HEADLINE: NO DPP REPRESENTATIVE TO ATTEND ARATS-SPONSORED SEMINAR IN SHENZHEN

TEXT.P: Some 120 local delegates will attend a mainland China seminar on cross-Taiwan Strait relations from April 26-27 in Shenzhen, New Party Legislator Elmer Feng said on Monday.

The Taipei City legislator said the Taiwan delegation will not include any representatives of the soon-to-be ruling Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), as the party does not recognize the "one-China" principle, Feng said.

Other members of the delegation to the seminar sponsored by the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS) will include legislators and National Assembly deputies from the defeated Kuomintang and New Party and from the newly founded People First Party.
The seminar will be the first held on cross-strait ties since Taiwan's March 18 presidential election.
A second seminar, cosponsored by the Chinese Academy of Social Science, will be held in Shenzhen on May 8, with more PFP legislators participating, Feng added.

DOC.HEADLINE: A CHINESE DISSIDENT'S TONGUE CUT OFF BY POLICE

TEXT.P: One half of a young Chinese dissident's tongue was cut off by police after he wrote in December an anti-corruption slogan on the wall of a government building in Lan County in central Shanxi province, a human rights group said here Monday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said the 20-year-old dissident, Li Lusong, wrote the slogan, "Clean up corruption, clean up corrupt officials," on Dec. 10. He was arrested two days later.
During his detention, he scolded the police for beating him. The police then beat him again with an electric baton, and cut his tongue with a knife, the information center said.
Li, who is now receiving medical treatment at a military hospital in Luliang District, is unable to speak or eat solid food because of the injure to his tongue, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINESE POSITION ON PRESS FREEDOM PROTESTED IN HONG KONG

TEXT.P: Ten members of the Democratic Party of Hong Kong Monday staged a demonstration before Beijing's Liaison Office here in protest against a Chinese official's remarks on the obligation of news media to support the government.

Wang Fengchao, deputy director of the liaison office, said here in mid-April that the news media of Hong Kong have the responsibility and obligation to support the Chinese government's position on the issue of unification with Taiwan. Speeches and remarks that advocate Taiwan independence should not be treated as ordinary news items, he said.

The Beijing official made the remarks after Taiwan's vice president-elect Annette Lu said in an interview with a Hong Kong TV station that China and Taiwan are close neighbors, but history has made them distant relatives.

The demonstrators put a letter of petition, signed by over 2,000 Hong Kong people, at the gate of the liaison office before they left peacefully. The letter said that Wang's remarks are worrisome, and that freedom of the press and freedom of speech should be protected according to the Basic Law of Hong Kong. The news media of Hong Kong should be able to report different views without any restriction, it added.

DOC.HEADLINE: DRAFT CONSTITUTION AMENDMENTS TO EVISCERATE NA CRUISE SECOND READING

TEXT.P: Draft Constitutional amendments aimed at cutting down the functions of the National Assembly (NA) easily passed a second reading on Monday, and was set to go through a third and final reading later that night.
The NA decided through a vote of 291 to 8 to transform itself into an ad hoc organization made up of 300 delegates appointed by political parties according to the proportional representation system.

Under the draft amendments, the NA, empowered to ratify the Legislative Yuan's initiatives on Constitutional amendments or changes of territories, will be chosen in the new way within three months after these initiatives are put forward and have been gazetted for six months.
Should the Legislative Yuan launch impeachment proceedings against the nation's president or vice president, the NA should be chosen within three months of the impeachment being officially submitted.

The new NA delegates should meet within ten days of being appointed by their parties and their terms will run out when the NA session, which should run for no more than one month at the most, is ended.
In addition, the terms of the current NA delegates should expire on May 19 rather than in June, 2001 as had been called for in a Constitutional amendment approved in September, 1999.
That amendment, which flew in the face of public opinion, was struck down as unconstitutional in a ruling by the Council of Grand Justices in March, 2000.
The NA also voted in the second reading to lift the lifetime payment system for the grand justices, which was widely considered as tit-for-tat retaliation against the Grand Justices Council's ruling.

Assuming the amendment passes its final reading, grand justices, unless they are already common judges, will be excluded from the common judges' right to lifetime salary after their eight-year term expires.
In Monday's second reading, another bill obliging the president to issue an annual state-of-the-nation message to the Legislature was also passed.

But yet another bill which would have required a majority vote in a presidential election was voted down. The proposal initiated by the tiny opposition New Party would have provided for a second round run-off election between the first two winners in the event of no clear majority by any candidate.

The initiative was designed to broaden the mandate of the president, but was denounced as an attempt to block the election of a minority head of state such as President-elect Chen Shui-bian, who won the March 18 election with 39.3 percent of the vote.

Also killed at the second reading was a proposal to lower the number of legislators required to send a draft Constitutional amendment to the NA for ratification from 75 percent to 66 percent of the legislature, and a proposal to increase the number of legislators from 225 to 250.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT MEETS WITH VISITING NCAFP MEMBERS

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met on Monday with visiting members of the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP) led by Winston Lord, former US assistant state secretary for East Asian and Pacific affairs.
Lee told his visitors that the transition of political power in Taiwan following the March 18 presidential election has so far been implemented smoothly.

He said that he attaches great importance to the power transition and has authorized Ding Mou-shih, secretary-general to the president, to take charge of preparatory work for the transition to ensure it is implemented peacefully and smoothly.

The opposition Democratic Progressive Party's presidential candidate Chen Shui-bian and his running mate, Annette Lu, won the election, and an ad hoc committee for the transition of power led by DPP Legislator Chang Chun-hsiung has met a number of times with Ding to discuss the transition, Lee went on.
This will be the first time in the Republic of China's history that a political party has handed the reins of power to another political party, Lee noted.
During the meeting, the visitors expressed their deep concern over the situation which might develop between the two sides of Taiwan Strait after Chen's inauguration on May 20.

Lee replied that "we always hope that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will conduct dialogue based on democracy and equality. How Taiwan deals with future cross-strait issues will depend on Chen's wisdom."

The outgoing head of state said that he did not agree with the so-called "Asian Values" concept because this concept could become an excuse for totalitarian government. He pointed out that a free and democratic political system has successfully been promoted in Taiwan, and added that Asia should be able to enjoy the same freedom, democracy and human rights as Western countries.
The American visitors spoke highly of Lee's achievements in promoting Taiwan's democratization, saying it sets an example for mainland China and the Asia-Pacific area.

The US delegation, which also included George Schwab, Donald Zagoria and Douglas H. Paal, arrived in Taipei on Saturday for a three-day fact-finding visit. They had already called on James Soong, chairman of the newly established People First Party (PFP), Chen and Lu.
They will leave Taipei for Beijing to continue their fact-finding mission on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS NEED NEW FORMULA: US EXPERT

TEXT.P: With the election of Chen Shui-bian as Taiwan's next president, future progress in cross-strait relations will require a new formula that permits Beijing's "one China" policy and Taipei's quest for negotiation equality to coexist, according to an American expert in Asian affairs.

Ralph A. Cossa, executive director of the Center for Strategic and International Studies' Pacific Forum, wrote in the latest issue of the Washington-based think tank's E-journal on East Asian bilateral relations that the biggest challenge to Asia-Pacific regional stability in the past few months has been Taiwan's March 18 presidential election.
In the short term, he said, cross-strait relations seem to have suffered most, especially in light of Beijing's heavy-handed but unsuccessful attempt to influence the election outcome.

The good news, Cossa pointed out, is that since the election, Beijing has refrained from making matters worse. "We have no choice, we must learn to deal with Chen Shui-bian" was a common refrain during Cossa's post-election discussions with communist Chinese officials and security analysts, who also acknowledge that "even Chen Shui-bian is an improvement over (President) Lee Teng-hui." And Chen is waving olive branches in Beijing's direction.

However, he wrote, both sides have limited flexibility and neither side seems quite sure how best to proceed. But "one thing is clear: Future progress in cross-strait relations will require a new formula.

Leaders in Beijing are now being forced to confront the reality that almost everyone in Taiwan has long recognized -- that "one country, two systems," the formula used to incorporate Hong Kong and Macau back into the mainland -- will never work for Taiwan."

Cossa emphasized that "what is needed now is a new construct that permits Beijing's `one China' policy and Taipei's quest for negotiation equality or even `special state-to-state' relations to coexist."

Once again the United States is caught in the middle. Washington is wisely calling on both sides to exercise restraint, advising against any unilateral change in the status quo. "A less ambiguous American statement of support to Taiwan might embolden the more radical Democratic Progressive Party elements that Chen has thus far held in check, and further undermine Sino-US relations," claimed Cossa.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT DECORATES TWO US CITIZENS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui on Monday decorated Bette Bao Lord and Ross H. Munro with the Order of Brilliant Star with Grand Cordon for their long-term concern and support for the Republic of China's development.

Mrs. Lord, a member of Freedom House Inc., which evaluates human rights in countries all over the world, was given the honor for her long-time concern for ROC human rights and her contribution to the promotion of democratization in the country.
Munro, a noted American newspaper columnist, has written articles for many years in support of the ROC.
During the presentation ceremony at the Presidential Office, Lord said the decoration was a great honor for her and for Freedom House.

She added that the ROC has achieved highly praised development in many fields under Lee's leadership in the last few years, especially in the field of democratization. She also said she wanted to salute Lee "on behalf of all the peace-lovers."

For his part, Munro praised Lee's achievements in the promotion of democracy in the ROC, especially in leading the first peaceful transition of political power in this country. He said this process will be inscribed in history.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAINLAND CHINA SHOULD BE MORE DEMOCRATIC: US EXPERT

TEXT.P: The best hope for peaceful cross-Taiwan Strait reunification "lies in China gradually becoming like Taiwan -- that is, more democratic," according to an American foreign policy expert.

Richard Haass, vice president and director of foreign policy studies at the Washington-based Brookings Institute, wrote in a recent analysis that "Taiwan's recent presidential election constitutes a historical divide. Nothing will ever be the same there. The results could have repercussions equally dramatic for China. As a result, the election makes it necessary to assess and adjust American policy."
He said successive American presidents have tried to ensure that any cross-strait reunification would be peaceful through "strategic ambiguity," but this approach is under mounting pressure.

A Beijing white paper issued on Feb. 21 suggested that mainland China might resort to force simply because Taiwan was dragging its feet on talks designed to bring about a unified country. At the same time, the fact that Taiwan just elected Chen Shui-bian, a man who for years espoused independence, suggested that it could be a matter of time before he or a successor actually takes that step, pointed out the expert.

Despite these developments, Haass noted, the United States could stick with its current policy. There are, however, a number of options. One is, as House Republican Whip Rep. Tom Delay (R-Tex.) recently argued, that Washington should jettison its "one China" policy and accept that "there are, in fact, two Chinese states."

But adopting a "two China" policy could trigger the conflict over Taiwan the United States seeks to avoid, he said. Even if it did not, it would require extensive military undertakings and lead to a major falling out with mainland China that would end PRC-US cooperation regarding the Korean peninsula to prevent the proliferation of weapons of mass destruction and boost trade.

Another approach would have Washington move from strategic ambiguity to a posture of greater clarity. "We would, for example, inform both China and Taiwan that only if Taiwan declared independence would there be any question of American willingness to come to its defense," wrote Haass.

The problem with this idea is that it might prompt Taiwan to take every step short of independence -- steps that still might provoke a mainland Chinese attack that in turn would require a US response. But Beijing would still have to calculate that almost any -- and possibly all -- use of force on its part against Taiwan would be resisted with American help, he emphasized.

Taiwan, however, likely would be dissuaded from declaring independence or otherwise acting recklessly. It still would be left with some uncertainty as to the US response, and even if the United States came to Taiwan's aid, Taiwan's leaders know their economy and society would suffer profoundly in the conflict.

On balance, Haass said, "moving in the direction of greater clarity about what the United States is prepared to do appears more likely to succeed in keeping the situation between China and Taiwan calm than simply trying to sustain current levels of ambiguity. In the end, the United States maintains a vital interest in not allowing China to determine Taiwan's fate with force."

Were Beijing to succeed, he pointed out, it would not only teach its leaders a dangerous lesson but also would prompt countries in the region to lose faith in the United States, leading some to accommodate mainland China and others to develop nuclear weapons and chart an increasingly independent course.

The critical point not to be lost, Haass said, is that it is in the interest of everyone to play for time, to encourage mainland China to eschew any use of military force and to encourage Taiwan to avoid taking symbolic independence steps. And the best hope for a peaceful outcome lies in mainland China gradually becoming more like Taiwan as a democracy.

"As the difference between the two societies narrows, the chance for voluntary unification grows. In this scenario, the China that would emerge would be called China but would resemble Taiwan," concluded Haass.

DOC.HEADLINE: JORDAN'S INDUSTRIAL ZONES WOO TAIWAN INVESTMENT

TEXT.P: Jordan's five leading industrial zones are trying to attract investment from Taiwan after the government began offering less restrictive and more preferable conditions to foreign investors.
Reem Badran, director of Jordan's Bureau of Investment was in Taipei on Monday attending a seminar aimed at introducing Jordan's investment environment and policy.

Badran said the qualifying industrial zones (QIZ) in Jordan enjoy most favorable investment conditions. He added that products from the industrial zones will be exempt from quotas and customs limits when entering the US market, while export profits will be free of income and social service taxes until 2002.
After 2002, all processes will comply with the rules of the World Trade Organization, said Bardran.
The five Jordanian industrial zones are: Al Hassan Industrial Estate; Al Karak Industrial Estate; Ad-Dulayl Industrial Park; Al Tajamouat Industrial City; and Gateway Park.
Of these, Gateway Park has already attracted foreign capital from the United States and some Far Eastern countries investing in the telecomunication, electronic and computer industries.

DOC.HEADLINE: COUNCIL CHIEF-DESIGNATE TELLS OF PRIORITY FOR ABORIGINAL AFFAIRS

TEXT.P: Yohani Iskakafut, who has been designated by President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new government as chairman of the Aboriginal Affairs Council, on Monday stressed the importance of providing work for the island's aboriginals.

Yohani, who works for the Hualien-based Yushan Christian Seminary, told CNA that soon after he assumes the chairmanship on May 20, he will do whatever he can to help the country's aboriginal people rebuild their homes, many of which were damaged in last September's earthquake.
He said that some aboriginal policies of the outgoing government were laudable, but added that many others require further efforts to implement.

Among the pressing issues facing aboriginal people, he noted, is the lack of work opportunities for them, and he blamed this on the government's policy of permitting foreign workers to take menial jobs in Taiwan, thereby reducing work opportunities for aboriginals.
Yohani, whose Chinese name is Sung Kuo-hsien, belongs to the Bunun tribe of Nantou County. He is active in aboriginal social justice and welfare movements.

DOC.HEADLINE: HUGE FUNDS REQUIRED FOR OUTGOING GOVERNMENT OFFICIALS

TEXT.P: Nearly 100 ranking officials of the outgoing Republic of China government will quit or retire when President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new government is inaugurated on May 20, for which huge funds will be required.

According to a preliminary estimate, about 96 officials, including Premier Vincent Siew, will quit or retire. The allowances for their years of service to the government and for their retirements are expected to cost NT$600 million (US$19.35 million).

For instance, Siew has worked for the government for 36 years and is thus entitled to receive NT$9.73 million (US$314,000) if he chooses to take his retirement allowance in a lump sum, as he is perfectly entitled to do.

DOC.HEADLINE: 2ND INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE OF YOUNG LEADERS OPENS IN TAIPEI

TEXT.P: The Second International Conference of Young Leaders opened in Taipei on Monday attended by 220 representatives from home and abroad.
The conference organized by the Cabinet-level National Youth Commission (NYC) has as its theme "Growth and Contributions of Young Leaders - Creating the New Milestone of Global Cooperation."

NYC Chairman Lee Jih-chu presided over the opening ceremony of the four-day conference, and Premier Vincent Siew delivered a speech in which he welcomed the youth representatives from around the world. He said that mankind can make great strides in the new century only through the globalization of democracy as well as the exchange and cooperation of information technology among nations.

Siew referred to the so-called "Taiwan miracle" to introduce the Republic of China's economic achievements, and cited government statistics to show the participants that the ROC, with its economy steadily growing in the past three years, has achieved a GNP (gross national product) of US$2.908 trillion and a per capita GNP of US$13,248, ranking it 17th in the world. He also pointed out that the nation's foreign exchange reserves are the third-largest in the world.

As to political developments, the outgoing premier said the ROC lifted the 40-year martial law in 1987, held its first direct presidential election in 1996 and its second in March 2000. Although the Kuomintang lost in the most recent one and must now transfer power to the Democratic Progressive Party on May 20, the "tranquil revolution" is worthy of pride, he said.

Siew said he hopes that the youth leaders from abroad can have a better understanding of developments in the ROC and will make friends with youth leaders here to join efforts to create "a new milestone of global cooperation."

Two youth summit forums were held later in the day titled "The Outlook of Newly Industrialized Countries on Technology" and "Prospects of Internet Development in the New Millennium." Another forum titled "Economic Development and International Cooperation," is scheduled to be held on Tuesday.

DOC.HEADLINE: NATIONAL ASSEMBLY FADES INTO HISTORY AFTER PASSING AMENDMENTS

TEXT.P: The National Assembly is fading into history after after downgrading itself into a virtual ceremonial organization without much power by passing a series of constitutional amendments in a third reading late on Monday.

The NA in a second reading earlier in the day voted 291 to 8 to transform itself into an ad hoc organization made up of 300 delegates appointed by political parties according to the proportional representation system.

Under the amendments, the NA, empowered to ratify the Legislative Yuan's initiatives on Constitutional amendments or changes of territories, will be chosen in the new way within three months after these initiatives are put forward and have been gazetted for six months.
Should the Legislative Yuan launch impeachment proceedings against the nation's president or vice president, the NA should be chosen within three months of the impeachment being officially submitted.

The new NA delegates should meet within ten days of being appointed by their parties and their terms will run out when the NA session, which should run for no more than one month at the most, is ended.
In addition, the terms of the current NA delegates should expire on May 19 rather than in June, 2001 as had been called for in a Constitutional amendment approved in September, 1999.
That amendment, which flew in the face of public opinion, was struck down as unconstitutional in a ruling by the Council of Grand Justices in March, 2000.
The NA also voted to lift the lifetime payment system for the grand justices, which was widely considered as tit-for-tat retaliation against the Grand Justices Council's ruling.
Under the amendment, grand justices, unless they are already common judges, will be excluded from the common judges' right to lifetime salary after their eight-year term expires.
Another bill obliging the president to issue an annual state-of-the-nation message to the Legislature was also passed.

But yet another bill which would have required a majority vote in a presidential election was voted down in a second reading on Monday. The proposal initiated by the tiny opposition New Party would have provided for a second round run-off election between the first two winners in the event of no clear majority by any candidate.

The initiative was designed to broaden the mandate of the president, but was denounced as an attempt to block the election of a minority head of state such as President-elect Chen Shui-bian, who won the March 18 election with 39.3 percent of the vote.

Also killed at the second reading was a proposal to lower the number of legislators required to send a draft Constitutional amendment to the NA for ratification from 75 percent to 66 percent of the legislature, and a proposal to increase the number of legislators from 225 to 250.
As a result of Monday's vote, the upcoming NA election initially scheduled for May 6 but suspended pending the outcome of the NA session, will be canceled.

The NA, the supreme representative organization of the people under the Constitution, has hardly assumed its full constitutional powers since it came into existence in 1948, said local political analysts.

It powers were seriously limited in 1949 when the Nationalist government relocated to Taiwan, declared martial law and adopted a set of temporary constitutional provisions which reduced the NA to nothing more than a presidential electoral college, the analysts pointed out.

Although the temporary constitutional provisions were lifted in 1991, the NA's constitutional role was not fully restored because a constitutional amendment adopted in 1994 providing for the popular election of the president and left the NA no job other than revising the Constitution and approving the president's nominations of senior government leaders.

In addition, the NA's performance in constitutional revising in the last decade has often seen the assemblymen acting on whims and going against the public grain -- increasingly irritating the people they are supposed to represent.

Their vote to extend their own terms in September in 1999 was the last straw that caused the public to make a concerted call for the total abolition of the anachronistic bygone of a former era, and led to the vote to finally eviscerate their own organization, said the analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Tuesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
National Assembly (NA) deputies have passed the third and final reading of a historic constitutional amendment package aimed at reducing their own powers.
The China Times:
The National Assembly votes to cut own powers.

The Taipei Times:
