DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 113.03 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Tuesday, with the benchmark-weighted price index moving up 113.03 points to close at 8,921.12.
Market turnover amounted to NT$124.64 billion (US$4.08 billion)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Share prices opened low but closed higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Tuesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 113.03 points to close at 8,921.12.
Affected by heavy buying of electrical shares and other blue chip stocks, the bourse opened at 8,711.68 and fluctuated between 8,923.27 and 8,672.41 during trading.

A total of 2.06 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$124.64 billion (US$4.08 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.92 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$101.96 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 353 to 180, with 62 stocks remaining unchanged.

Five of the eight major categories lost ground, with cement shares moving down the most at 1.9 percent, followed by foodstuff stocks at 1.6 percent, construction shares at 1.5 percent, bank and insurance stocks at 1 percent, and plastics and chemical shares at 0.7 percent.
Other major categories gained ground, with electrical shares moving up the most at 2.6 percent, followed by textile issues at 1.5 percent, and pulp and paper issues at 0.1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Tuesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for May moved up 184 points to close at 9,000, with 4,218 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for June increased 180 points to finish at 9,030, with 97 contract transactions; September futures gained 195 points to close at 9,150, with four contract transactions; and December futures finished at 10 points to close at 9,000, with one contract transaction.
No transactions were recorded for next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Tuesday were: 8,816 for May; 8,850 for June; 8,955 for September; 8,990 for December; and 9,293 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, were also generally higher.
May TE futures moved up 15 points to finish at 491, with 1,490 contract transactions, while June TE futures gained 16 points to close at 495, with 36 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
May TF futures edged up 0.4 points to close at 916.2, with 248 contract transactions, while June TF futures moved down 25.6 points to finish at 915.4, with three contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: US EXPRESSES CONCERNS ABOUT INFRINGEMENTS ON HK'S FREE PRESS

TEXT.P: The United States government on Monday expressed its concern that Hong Kong's press freedom might be infringed upon by the mainland Chinese government.

Communist Chinese officials have warned Hong Kong journalists against reporting pro-independence views about Taiwan and have called for a quick drafting of anti-subversion and sedition laws in the former British colony.

In response to a press inquiry, State Department spokesman Jamie Rubin told reporters that "we would be concerned by any infringement upon the free press that has been a hallmark of Hong Kong society for so long and a hallmark of their system."
He added that "we certainly cannot support, and would oppose, any suggestion that they shouldn't be able to publish or pursue that free press."

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING LEADER'S VISIT RAISES CONCERNS OVER HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: South Africa's major opposition Democratic Party has called on the government to discuss human rights and also the issue of multi-party democracy with Chinese Communist leader Jiang Zemin who arrived in the country on Monday for a four day visit.
In a statement issued here on Monday, the Democratic Party said Jiang's visit to South Africa raises important concerns regarding the South African government's endorsement of undemocratic policies.
It said the South African government should not be seen as aligning itself with a government that denies its people basic human rights and political freedom.
The statement added that the South African government should use the opportunity of Jiang's visit to discuss the lack of human rights in his country. (J. S. Chang)

DOC.HEADLINE: NZ TRADE MINISTER URGES MONETARY UNION WITH AUSTRALIA

TEXT.P: New Zealand's Trade Minister Jim Sutton has called for the union of the Kiwi and the Australian currency in order to increase trade and to broaden the economic scale of the two neighboring countries.
The Australian on Tuesday quoted Sutton as saying that the monetary union was "inevitable."
The daily reported a new survey by Wellington's Institute of Policy Studies, to be released on Wednesday, as revealing strong business support for a currency union between Australia and New Zealand.
But New Zealand Prime Minister Helen Clark is less convinced of the merits of a single currency, the daily reported.
"I think the jury is still out on whether integrating currencies is necessarily a good thing," she said.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA URGED TO PRESSURE CHINA TO SAVE PANDAS

TEXT.P: Australian Green Party Senator Bob Brown on Tuesday urged the government to pressure mainland China to implement policies in order to prevent the extinction of Tibetan pandas, whose numbers are rapidly declining.

In an article published in the Australian, Brown, who visited mainland China last year, called on Environment Minister Robert Hill to "pressure China to save this fantastic Tibetan beast by creating large secure habitats."
The article mentions that the panda, who is native to Tibet, is disappearing because "its territory has been overrun" because of Chinese government policies.
Brown said the pandas in China are now being kept in 69 cement enclosures.
He strongly criticized the fact that in the nearby woods, hunters and farming encroachments are disrupting the little remaining panda habitat. Fewer than 1,000 pandas are left in the wild.

DOC.HEADLINE: LIEN SUGGESTS BOTH SIDES SHELVE `SOVEREIGNTY' DISPUTES

TEXT.P: Vice President Lien Chan said on Tuesday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should shelve their disputes over the issue of sovereignty and concentrate on cooperation.
Lien said that there is ample room for cooperation across the Taiwan Strait, and there is no need to waste more time and resources on the intractable dispute over sovereignty.
Lien noted that during the first high-ranking cross-strait talks in Singapore in 1993, the two sides reached an agreement that allowed each to interpret the definition of "one China."

As such, Lien said Beijing should not try to impose its interpretation of the principle of "one China" on Taiwan, especially since Taiwan long ago established its National Unification Guidelines and the National Unification Council with President Lee Teng-hui as the chairman, clearly indicating that national unification is the ultimate goal of the Republic of China.

Lien also said that although Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party has sounded conciliatory notes since his election victory, Beijing has so far not reciprocated. He said this has given the people of Taiwan a sense of uncertainty concerning cross-strait relations. Lien added that Chen should continue making more efforts in this respect.
He stressed that the ROC is willing to see the United States develop closer relations with mainland China, as long as it is not at the expense of the ROC.

Lien also recalled that during the past decades, he has contributed to enhancing US-ROC relations. He continued that although the Kuomintang will soon become an opposition party, it retains a majority in the legislature.
He made his remarks while meeting with a four-member US delegation led by Winston Lord, former US Assistant Secretary for East Asian and Pacific Affairs and a former US ambassador to mainland China.
The US delegation also called on KMT spokesperson and former Foreign Affairs Minister Jason Hu earlier on Tuesday.
Hu said the delegation is concerned about what direction the president-elect will take, and their assessment of his handling of the cross-strait issue has been mixed.

Some delegates said they have yet to see what direction Chen's policy will take and what his goals will be, while others said the public should not pin too high a hope on Chen since he has yet to be inaugurated.

The delegation, which arrived here on Saturday night for a fact-finding trip as part of efforts to ease cross-strait tensions, concluded its whirlwind trip in Taiwan and left for the mainland later on Tuesday.
During their stay in Taiwan, delegation members met with President-elect Chen Shui-bian, President Lee Teng-hui, and James Soong, chairman of the newly formed People First Party.

DOC.HEADLINE: DPP WILLING TO GIVE BEIJING CHANCE TO DETAIL MERITS OF UNIFICATION

TEXT.P: The incoming Republic of China government is willing to offer any possible opportunities for Beijing to explain the benefits or merits of unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait, the chairman of Taiwan's ruling party-to-be said on Tuesday.

"Although we disagree with Beijing's stance, we have no intention of provoking Beijing leaders and are willing to provide them with any possible opportunities to expound to the people of Taiwan the merits of unification of the two sides," said Lin Yi-hsiung, chairman of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP).
Lin made the remarks after a closed-door meeting with a four-member delegation from the National Committee on American Foreign Policy (NCAFP), a Washington-based think tank.

The NCAFP delegation, led by Winston Lord, a former US ambassador to mainland China who also once served as assistant secretary of state for East Asian and Pacific affairs, arrived in Taipei on Saturday for a three-day visit aimed at gaining a better understanding of the DPP's attitude toward Beijing after the pro-independence party won the ROC's March 18 presidential election.

During their 40 minutes talks, Lin said he had told his American guests that the DPP regards Taiwan as an independent sovereign country and insists that any change to the island's status quo must pass a referendum vote.

"It is a mainstream public opinion that any change to our political status quo must win the consent of the majority of our people through a plebiscite, and the DPP cannot violate the common wish of our people," Lin stressed.

Taiwan's ruling party-to-be used to advocate Taiwan independence but has softened this aspect of its party platform in recent years. The DPP now thinks that only the people of Taiwan can decide the island's future by holding a plebiscite .
Lin said while Beijing disagrees with the DPP's stance at the moment, the majority of Taiwan people also would not accept mainland China's "one China" principle.

Against this backdrop, Lin said, the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should conduct dialogue and exchanges through various channels to enhance mutual understanding and trust. "With mutual trust, any kinds of conflicting concepts and views can be discussed," he noted.

Lin went on to say that although the DPP disagrees with Beijing's stance, it will make every possible effort to avoid creating any trouble. "We'll not take any impolite or provocative action against either the Beijing government or its senior leaders," he added.

Moreover, Lin said, now that Taiwan is a democratic society, any change to its status quo must be the expression of popular will. "Therefore, we are willing to offer opportunities for Beijing to expound to our people the advantages of unification of the two sides," Lin said, adding that as such, he sees no reason for Beijing to threaten Taiwan with the use of force. "Beijing should use democratic and peaceful means to convince our people," he added.

Also present at the Lin-Lord meeting were Douglas Paal, a former chief of China and East Asian affairs of the US National Security Council; NCAFP President George Schwab; and professor Donald Zagoria, head of the NCAFP's roundtable discussion program.

During the past couple of days, the delegation has met with many influential politician here, including President-elect Chen Shui-bian, outgoing President Lee Teng-hui, People First Party Chairman James Soong, Kuomintang acting Chairman Lien Chan and Foreign Minister-designate Tien Hung-mao.

The delegation will give a pre-departure news conference before leaving for Beijing for a visit as part of its efforts to help ease cross-strait tension which has escalated following Chen's election as the ROC's next president.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Tuesday, April 25, or the 21st day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1719: Daniel Defoe's "Robinson Crusoe" is published in London. The novel was inspired by the exploits of a Scottish sailor and castaway, Alexander Selkirk.
1744: Anders Celsius, Swedish astronomer who devised the Celsius thermometer in 1742, dies at the age of 43.
1792: Jacques Pelletier, a highwayman, becomes the first person to be guillotined in Paris, France.
1859: Under the direction of Ferdinand de Lesseps, the construction of the Suez Canal begins. It was opened 10 years later on Nov. 16, 1869.
1874: Gulielmo Marconi, Italian engineer and inventor who shared the 1909 Nobel Prize in physics, is born. He became the first person to transmit long-wave radio signals across the Atlantic Ocean, in 1901.
1895: Lai Ho, a noted Chinese writer of anti-Japanese literature, is born in Changhua.
1898: The US Congress passes a joint resolution declaring war on Spain over events in Cuba.
1912: The Chung Kuo Ke Ming Tung Meng Hui is reorganized as the Kuomintang.
1925: Field Marshal Paul von Hindenburg becomes the second president of Germany's postwar Weimar Republic.
1927: After the national government in Nanking announces a purification movement that will entail the expulsion of Chinese communists, the communists meet in Wuhan and decide to set up a Soviet-style regime.
1930: Construction of the Chianan irrigation canal is completed.
1941: The United States and the United Kingdom sign in Washington separate but parallel agreements with China for stabilizing China's national currency. The United States provides US$50 million and the United Kingdom provides five million pounds.
1942: An accident at a coal mine in Benxi, located within Japanese-occupied China, kills 1,549 workers in the world's worst mining disaster.
1945: Delegates of 45 nations, including the Republic of China, meet in San Francisco, California, to organize the United Nations.
1946: Foreign ministers of the United States, Soviet Union, Britain and France meet in Paris to discuss the signing of a peace treaty with Germany.
1956: The Republic of China Ministry of Foreign Affairs announces the establishment of diplomatic relations with Haiti.
1962: The United States successfully launches its Saturn rocket, the largest in the world at the time.
1965: President Lyndon B. Johnson sends US troops to the Dominican Republic to maintain order after rebel followers of Juan Bosch try to seize power.
1971: T.V. Soong, former president of the Executive Yuan, dies in San Francisco at the age of 77.
1971: Some 200,000 anti-Vietnam War protesters march on Washington.
1973: The Chinese National Baseball Team leaves Taipei for Manila to take part in the 10th Asian Cup Tournament.
1974: Portugal's dictator Marcelo Caetano is overthrown in a bloodless military coup. He surrenders to Gen. Antonio de Spinola, who becomes president the following month.
1976: Mrs. Alen M. Schanel, national president of the Ladies Auxiliary of the American Legion, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1980: A US commando mission to rescue 53 US Embassy hostages in Teheran, Iran, is abandoned in the desert with the loss of eight lives when a helicopter collides with a tanker aircraft.
1982: The last Israeli soldier leaves Sinai, ending 15 years of Israeli occupation of the peninsula.
1989: Japanese Prime Minister Noburu Takeshita announces plans to resign over the "Recruit Affair," the country's biggest political scandal in decades.
1990: Violeta Chamorro becomes president of Nicaragua after beating Daniel Ortega in national elections.
1994: Tsutomu Hata becomes Japan's 51st prime minister.
1995 Ginger Rogers, American dancer and actress, dies at the age of 83. She is particularly noted for her partnership with Fred Astaire in several motions pictures, including "Swing Time," "Flying Down to Rio," and "Roberta."
Confucius' lesson of the day: "The ancient Emperor Shun was perhaps the one man who successfully carried out the principle of no-government. For what need is there really for what is called government? A ruler needs only to be earnest in his personal conduct, and to behave in a manner worthy of his position."

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE DECORATES US MAGAZINE PUBLISHER STEVE FORBES

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui bestowed a medal on Steve Forbes, president & CEO of the US-based Forbes Magazine, on Tuesday in recognition of his long-term contribution to the promotion of exchanges and cooperation between the Republic of China and the United States.

President Lee presented Forbes with the Order of Brilliant Star with the Grand Cordon during a ceremony at the Presidential Office. Witnessing the ceremony were Mrs. Forbes, Secretary-General to the President Ding Mou-shih, Deputy Secretary-General to the President Lin Pi-chao, as well as Raymond Burghardt, director of the Taipei office of the American Institute in Taiwan.

Forbes said he was impressed by Taiwan's achievements in technology development and opening its markets, adding that he is willing to continue working for further cooperation and exchanges between the two countries.
Forbes and his wife, who arrived early Tuesday, met with President-elect Chen Shui-bian and local businessmen Tuesday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: BOFT HEAD URGES MORE EFFORTS TO TAP RUSSIAN MARKET

TEXT.P: Taiwan manufacturers need to step up efforts to tap the Russian market, as Taiwan recorded a US$1.16 billion trade deficit with Russia last year, Chen Ruey-long, director general of the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT), said on Tuesday.
Chen made the remarks at a seminar on trade and economics in Russia. The meeting was co-sponsored by the semi-official China External Trade Development Council and Euro-Asia Trade Organization.
Victor Trifonov, representative of the Taipei Office of the Moscow-Taipei Economic & Cultural Coordination Commission, also attended the seminar, along with hundreds of Taiwan businessmen.

Chen noted that bilateral trade between Taiwan and Russia totaled US$1.38 billion last year with Taiwan exporting US$110 million to Russia, while importing US$1.27 billion from Russia. Taiwan thus suffered US$1.16 billion trade deficit with Russia.
Chen said 70 percent of Russian imports were raw materials such as minerals, while major exports to Russia were information technology and computer peripheral products.

Chen said that Taiwan manufacturers would do well to promote Russian sales of computer products, consumer electronics, stationery and gifts, and automobile parts and components. He noted that Taiwan suppliers have until now mainly focused on Moscow and St. Petersburg, but should widen their marketing efforts to include other Russian cities.
Taiwan businesses could also seek out Russian partners to cooperate in the textiles and machinery industries, Chen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: FORMER US NATIONAL SECURITY ADVISER VISITS FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Former US National Security Adviser Anthony Lake visited Foreign Affairs Minister Chen Chien-jen on Tuesday.

Stressing that his visit to Chien was just a courtesy call on an old friend, Lake dismissed speculation that the purpose of his visit was to convey a message from influential figures in the United States or elsewhere.

Although Lake is no longer in public office, the former White House national security adviser played an important role in arranging for President Lee Teng-hui's unofficial visit to the United States in 1995, and also during the 1996 missile crisis in the Taiwan Strait.

Lake declined to answer questions on his opinions about the foreign and cross-strait policies of the Republic of China's new government, which will be led by President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressive Party. He reiterated that his trip to Taiwan was purely private in nature.

Lake arrived in Taiwan on Thursday for a five-day visit at the invitation of China Development Corp. He will meet with local business leaders, including Acer Group Chairman Stan Shih, on the same day. He will then fly back to the United States in the evening.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK INTERNET GURU WARNS FOREIGN INVESTORS TO BE WARY OF CHINA

TEXT.P: A leading Hong Kong Internet entrepreneur has warned foreigners to be very careful when investing in mainland China because it is an uncertain market that still lacks the necessary network infrastructure, content and commerce capability.

In an interview with The Australian, Peter Yip, head of Chinadotcom, said that foreign investors in China need patience and understanding, because of stumbling blocks to making serious money in mainland China.
He said despite its huge population of 1.2 billion people, the Chinese market is still immature in terms of infrastructure, content and Internet connectivity.

"North Asia represents the greatest potential Internet market. But you have to be careful to differentiate the markets (of Japan, Korea and China.) There are different opportunities at different times," he said.
"I need to caution co-investors to work closely with the regulators in China," he added.
He said the market in Japan is mature, and Korea is energetically forging ahead. In China, state-owned enterprises are now trying to transform themselves in to online businesses, he added.

He said that it is up to foreign investors to educate and encourage Chinese managers. The other prerequisite for investors in China is a sense of reality, because it is easy to succumb to the pull of a market of 1.2 billion people.
"One has to be careful with China, that you are not overwhelmed by the size. You have to look beyond the population to connectivity," he said.

He pointed out that even though China has already about 10 million Internet users -- and could have 200 million by 2005 if mobile telephones deliver on their potential -- connectivity is still far below the critical mass necessary for e-commerce to be viable.

He said that outside urban centers such as Beijing, Shanghai and Guangzhou, only 5 percent of the population now has a telephone. He added that owners of computers in China are even fewer, because about 90 percent of China's PCs are to be found at work and not at home.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar fell NT$0.006 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market on Tuesday, closing at NT$30.572.
The local currency opened Tuesday at NT$30.561 and was traded between NT$30.561 and NT$30.615.
Interbank US dollar trading volume totaled US$409 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: A FALUN GONG PRACTITIONER BEATEN TO DEATH IN CHINA

TEXT.P: One practitioner of Falun Gong was beaten to death by police on April 21 in China, a human rights group said Tuesday.

The Hong Kong-based Information Center for Human Rights and Democracy said the practitioner, Li Huixi of Houzhen Village in eastern Shandong province, was arrested when he staged a protest in Beijing in early April. He was then sent back to his home town and was beaten to death in a temporary detention center on April 21.

The body of Li, 40, was cremated in the next morning before his family was informed of his death, the information center said. His family was later given 45,000 yuan renminbi (US$5,400) in compensation, it added.
The number of Falun Gong practitioners killed in police custody has increased to 16 since the Chinese government began to crack down on the Falun Gong spiritual movement in late 1999.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN'S ADJUSTMENT FALLS SHORT OF BEIJING HOPES: KMT AIDE

TEXT.P: Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian has noticeably adjusted his attitude toward mainland China, but Beijing still wants Chen to further clarify his position in this regard, a Kuomintang (KMT) official said on Tuesday.

Although Chen's remarks on cross-Taiwan Strait issues since his election on March 18 as the island's next president have reflected marked changes from his views in the past, they still fall short of Beijing demands, said Chang Jong-kung, head of the KMT's Mainland Research Department.

According to the KMT aide, Chen has adopted a "negative list" to express his stance on cross-strait issues. But what Beijing wants from Chen is a "positive list," which should make all relevant issues very clear, he noted.
For instance, Chen has said that he will not change Taiwan's official title, and that he will not declare independence from the mainland, Chang cited.

Despite the fact that these statements are helpful in improving Taiwan's ties with the mainland, the KMT China expert said that Chen's words still fall short of Beijing's desires, and might make the Beijing leadership think that a hard-line approach is the only solution to the Taiwan issue.

If Taiwan's new government continues to delay talks on unification with the mainland, Beijing fears that the Chinese Communist Party's image would be damaged, he said. That is the reason why Premier-designate Tang Fei has asserted that Taiwan-mainland relations have come to a critical turning point, he noted.

The period following Chen's May 20 inauguration will be a time for the two sides to review their bilateral relationship, Chang contended. He further pointed out that Beijing might link cross-strait ties to the respective entries of both Taiwan and the mainland into the World Trade Organization in June or July.

In light of fierce pressure from Beijing and the present deadlock between the two sides, lawmakers suggested on the same day that the policy-making legislature should play a more active role in two-way negotiations.
KMT Legislator Tsao Erh-chung suggested that legislators should form a delegation to visit the mainland before May 20.

Fan Yang-sheng, another KMT lawmaker, hailed Chen's changed attitude toward mainland China, but pointed out that Chen now faces less room to maneuver in bilateral talks, as Beijing has objected to the "one China, separately interpreted" principle.

Stressing that a so-called "one China" should comprise both the Republic of China and the People's Republic of China, Fan stated that the ROC is not a part of the PRC and that the two sides should seriously consider the feasibility of setting up a confederation.

Citing the increased deployments of mainland Chinese troops in Fujian and Guangdong provinces opposite Taiwan, KMT lawmaker Lee Chuan-chiao reminded Beijing that ethnic identification should be the foundation for Taiwan's unification with mainland China.
"If there is no such a base, unification between the two sides will be out of the question," Lee claimed, calling on Beijing not to place overly high expectations on Chen's May 20 inaugural speech.

The recent confederation proposal is a better solution for Taiwan and mainland China, he went on to say, adding that an incorrect estimation of the situation by the mainland would only lead to a breakup between the two sides.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT HOPES TAIPEI, BEIJING CAN JOIN WTO AROUND SEPTEMBER

TEXT.P: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Tuesday he hopes that both sides of the Taiwan Strait can be either separately or simultaneously admitted to the World Trade Organization (WTO) around September this year.
Chen made the statement during an amicable meeting with Steve Forbes, publisher of the US Forbes magazine, and several other senior magazine executives.

Chen first told Forbes that he was moved by the viewpoints of an article carried in the latest issue of the Forbes magazine, which criticized the Clinton administration for its refusal to sell highly sophisticated Aegis destroyers to Taiwan. The article was written by former US secretary of defense Caspar W. Weinberger.
Chen said he appreciates Weinberger's concern about Taiwan's security in the face of Beijing's intensified military build-up and mounting saber-rattling against the island.
The lawyer-turned-politician went on to say he believes that peace in the Taiwan Strait and stability in the Asia-Pacific are in the US national interests.

For his part, Forbes echoed Chen's view that maintaining a democratic, prosperous Taiwan is in the US interest. "The United States is obligated to provide Taiwan with necessary defensive weapons and this can help increase Chen's bargaining chips in future negotiations with Beijing," the American publisher said.

Meanwhile, Chen said he is concerned about the WTO accession of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait. "I hope both sides can join the world trade regulatory body around September smoothly," he said, adding he believes that a WTO-binding, democratizing mainland China can be a great force to ensure peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait.

Chen also mentioned the three foundations of Taiwan-US relations -- support for the universal values of freedom and democracy; expectations of peace and stability in the Taiwan Strait and the entire Asia-Pacific region; and joint efforts to promote trade and economic cooperation.
Chen said he believes that friendship and substantive relations between the Republic of China and the United States will continue to grow in the years ahead.

Forbes said he also thinks that the United States must help Taiwan cement its liberal, democratic system, adding that the US insistence on peaceful solution to the Taiwan Strait issue will contribute much not only to both sides of the strait but also to the entire world.

Stressing that helping maintain regional peace is one of US national missions, Forbes said the United States had sometimes overlooked the destructiveness of certain regional conflicts which later developed into global conflicts.
Forbes further said he has consistently espoused Taiwan's early entry to the WTO. However, he said the Clinton administration has not accepted his opinion.
Forbes also suggested that Chen's administration take bold steps to further liberalize and privatized Taiwan's agricultural, information and power generation industries.

In response, Chen said Taiwan will remove obstacles to free flow of information, capital and personnel after its WTO entry. "We'll phase out all unnecessary and outdated control and help our traditional industries upgrade production and management, while helping high-tech industries achieving further technological breakthroughs and innovation," he added.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESEARCHERS PREDICT TAIWAN'S ECONOMY WILL CONTINUE TO BOOM

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economy is expected to continue booming, with high economic growth and low commodity prices seen as likely through out the year, local economic researchers said on Tuesday.

Economic growth will be supported by robust foreign trade, rosy domestic consumption and increasing private investment, said officials of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER). The institute Tuesday revised the island's estimated economic growth for this year to 6.49 percent from the previous 6.28 percent.
However, the relentless plunge of the US stock markets will likely have a negative impact on Taiwan's exports, said TIER officials.

The officials added that other possible adverse effects on the Taiwan economy include uncertainty in cross-Taiwan Strait relations, as well as the apparent failure of oil-rich nations to agree to increase production, which is expected to keep oil prices higher than was previously hoped.
Taiwan's economic growth in the first, second, third and fourth quarter of this year is estimated by TIER as 7.02 percent, 6.12 percent, 6.77 percent, and 6.08 percent, respectively.
TIER officials also anticipate a gradual appreciation of the New Taiwan dollar quarterly this year, with an average exchange rate against the greenback at NT$30.36.

Dong Jei-bin, head of TIER's Sixth Department, pointed out that Taiwan Stock Exchange is likely to break the bourse's previous benchmark-weighted price index record, which registered over 12,000 points. He said that the index has recently entered into a "laundry" phase, with sharp gains and losses over the past two weeks.
All global stock markets are under the shadow of the volatile swings of the US markets, and the island's bourse is certainly no exception, remarked Dong.

Dong is referring to the violent gyrations experienced by the NASDAQ Composite Index and the Dow Jones Industrial Average in April's second week. The NASDAQ composite last week took its heaviest fall ever in both percentage and points terms, dropping 25.3 percent in five days. The Dow Jones joined in the dive by the end of the week.

Nevertheless, with Taiwan's overall economic expansion continuing, together with a sustained inflow of foreign capital and a loose monetary supply environment, Taiwan's bourse has good prospects for the next two years, Dong concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: HI-TECH TYCOON CALLS FOR HUMANITARIAN COMPASSION

TEXT.P: Successful business entrepreneurs are really outstanding only when they care about people, said a local high-tech tycoon on Tuesday.

Tu Chun-yuan, chairman and CEO of Silicon Integrated Systems Corp. (SIS), said the difference between business leaders and political leaders is that business officials' words count for something, while politicians always make promises that they don't keep.

Addressing the 2nd International Conference of Young Leaders, which opened in Taipei on Monday, Tu called for Taiwan business figures to make a greater contribution to the public, in addition to paying attention to their businesses.

Tu is a devout philanthropist has made donations worth NT$2.8 billion (US$91.8 million) to charity causes in Taiwan over the past three years. He vowed to his audience Tuesday that he will donate all of his fortune, worth approximately NT$28 billion (US$0.92 billion), to Taiwan's society after he dies.

Tu holds a science doctorate from a United States university, and runs one of Taiwan's leading microchip manufacturing firms. But Tu has not been confined to the boardroom, and is a life-time volunteer with the Buddhist Tzu Chi Compassionate Relief Foundation. His volunteer efforts include relief work at home and abroad, including Cambodia and mainland China.

Even today, Tu continues to sweep the streets in his neighborhood every morning that it doesn't rain, a habit he took up about five years ago after his doctor told him that he needed more physical exercise. Tu chose to serve the community rather than working out in a personal gym.
Tu told the young leaders that the past several years, during which he has devoted money as well as his heart and soul to society, have been the happiest of his entire life.

After having spent most of his life in business, Tu said that the more successful he was as a business leader, the more aware he became that a genuine leader is not just capable of making breakthroughs in his working field -- he also must know how to delegate power.
Tu stressed that only when a leader begins to care about people and makes an actual contribution to society can he be a true leader. "To give is happier than to receive," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT LEE TO DELIVER FAREWELL SPEECH AT NA CLOSING CEREMONY

TEXT.P: President Lee will deliver his farewell speech at the closing ceremony of the National Assembly (NA) on May 19, one day before he officially steps down from office.
Deputies of the NA held a marathon meeting on Monday to reduce the body's power after passing second and third readings of the constitutional amendment bill.

Deputy Lin Jung-teh (KMT) proposed that President Lee Teng-hui be invited to deliver his outgoing speech at the closing ceremony of the current National Assembly meeting on May 19. Lin's proposal followed the NA's acceptance of the constitutional amendment bill by second and third readings on Monday at midnight.
Invitations will be also extended to the international media to cover President Lee's speech and further publicize Taiwan's democratization, Lin said.
Meanwhile, all political parties -- with the exception of the newly-established People First Party (PFP) -- hailed the National Assembly's deputies for their achievement in reducing the body's power.
New Party Legislator Hau Lung-pin praised the deputies for amending the constitution to convert the National Assembly into a task-oriented organization.

Hau also called on President-elect Chen Shui-bian to convoke a non-partisan constitutional consultation forum as soon as possible to discuss issues related to the government system and parliamentary reform.

Deputy Chen Chin-teh, convener of the DPP caucus in the NA, said that the NA's acceptance on Monday of the constitutional amendment to reduce its power has restored political power to the people of Taiwan.

DPP Secretary General Yu Hsi-kun cited the benefits of the passage of the constitutional amendment bill. These include the establishment of a unicameral parliament, as well as the consolidation of power among the three main branches of the government -- the legislative, judicial and executive branches, Yu said.
Deputy Tsai Cheng-yuan, convener of the KMT caucus in the NA, said that the successful passage of the constitutional amendment conformed with the expectations of the people.

At the same time, Chairman of the Central Election Commission Huang Hsih-cheng said that a CEC meeting on Tuesday will discuss how to cancel the forthcoming NA election, in accordance with the results of the NA constitutional amendment.
The NT$200,000 deposited by each candidate as guarantee fee will be refunded to the candidates by local election committees, Huang said.
The CEC had announced that it would hold the fourth National Assembly election on May 6 if the NA failed to pass the constitutional amendment before April 25.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW PHILIPPINE REPRESENTATIVE TO ROC SET TO ASSUME OFFICE
DOC.DATELINE: Manila, April 25 (CNA) (By Timothy Sun & Shammy Chao)

TEXT.P: Rodolfo T. Reyes, the newly appointed resident representative and managing director of the Taipei office of the Manila Economic and Cultural Office, is scheduled to leave for Taipei to assume his office on April 26.

Speaking at a farewell party thrown by Republic of China Representative to the Philippines Chan Hsien-ching, Reyes said that his first priority in his new job will be to resume canceled air links between Manila and Taipei.

Upon being notified of his new appointment on April 4, Reyes had stressed that he would do his utmost to resume negotiations on the air links, and added that he thought his new position would be "more challenging than being press secretary," which was his former post.

DOC.HEADLINE: CIH VIRUS AUTHOR APOLOGIZES FOR CAUSING COMPUTER DISASTER

TEXT.P: The young Taiwan man who created the CIH "Chernobyl" virus that paralyzed computers all over the world last April 26, made a tearful apology to his victims on Tuesday, and offered to provide them with antivirus programs.

Accompanied by an executive of XLINUX, the software company for which he now works, Chen Ying-hao said at a press conference that he is very worried that the disaster he caused exactly a year ago will repeat itself this year.
He then offered two antivirus programs -- ANTICIH and SSCAN -- to help computer users to get rid of the CIH virus.

Chen suggested that users may also visit www.xlinux.com.tw and download the ANTICIH.EXE program if they are really worried about their computers, and said that as a last resort, users should not start up their computers on April 26.
Chen, who graduated from Taipei's Tatung College of Industrial Technology, created the Chernobyl virus when he was still studying at the college.

The virus, which is believed to have first attacked computers in Taiwan in June 1998, can erase data stored on hard drives and make it impossible to restart the computer by damaging the computer's basic startup program.
The virus targets computers running Windows 95 and 98 and is spread mainly via the Internet and through the use of pirated software.
It exists in at least three versions, the most destructive of which is timed to hit every April 26, the anniversary of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant disaster.

DOC.HEADLINE: M1B MONEY SUPPLY HITS FIVE-YEAR HIGH

TEXT.P: The domestic money supply continued to grow in March, reflecting flourishing business and financial activities in the country, the Central Bank of China (CBC) reported on Tuesday.
The annual growth rates of the three indices used to measure the domestic credit situation all rose throughout the month, CBC officials said.

According to CBC tallies, the narrowly defined M1A, which comprises currency in circulation and checking and demand deposits, rose 12.03 percent in March over the year-earlier level, and was up 2.73 percentage points over February's figure.

The M1B -- the M1A plus passbook savings deposits -- grew at an annual rate of 19.88 percent in March, a 67-month high. The figure was an increase of 0.83 percentage points from February. The M1B is considered by some economists as the most effective gauge of a country's credit situation.

The broadly defined M2, which comprises cash in circulation, checking accounts, demand and savings deposits, and quasi-money (including time deposits and treasury bills), grew at an annual rate of 8.23 percent in March, 0.1 percentage points lower than the February figure.
CBC officials attributed the drastically increased M1A and M1B annual growth rates in March to the bullish stock market during the period and a relatively lower comparison basis in March 1999.
They attributed the slightly lower M2 to the fact that the speed of foreign capital influx subsided during the month.

The officials said they have been closely monitoring the M1A and M1B growths -- which have been faster in the first three months of this year than those in the past several years -- out of fear that faster money supply growth may trigger heavier inflationary pressure on the domestic economy.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMIC GROWTH RATE IN 2000 EXPECTED TO EXCEED 6%

TEXT.P: Taiwan's economic growth rate in 2000 is expected to exceed 6 percent, Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD) Chairman Chiang Pin-kung said on Tuesday.
Chiang made the forecast at a forum during the Second International Conference of Young Leaders that opened on Monday and is scheduled to close on Friday.

Chiang estimated Taiwan's average annual economic growth rate over the next 10 years at 5.5 percent. He also predicted that by 2004, Taiwan's per capita GNP (gross national product) will break the US$20,000 mark and that the island's inflation rate will be less than 3 percent by then.

Meanwhile, the privately run Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER) on Tuesday revised upward its estimated figure for Taiwan's economic growth rate in 2000 to 6.49 percent from the originally forecast 6.28 percent. TIER made the revision on the grounds that Taiwan's exports have maintained a bullish trend since the beginning of the year.
However, TIER's figure is still lower than that forecast by the Cabinet-level Directorate General of Budget, Accounting and Statistics, which predicted 6.54-percent growth.
Another private body, the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research (CIER) last week also modified upward its estimated figure for Taiwan's 2000 economic growth rate to 6.66 percent.
Despite the differences among the economic forecasts, the upward revisions indicate that Taiwan's economic situation for 2000 is rosy.

DOC.HEADLINE: CEC FORMALLY ANNOUNCES SUSPENSION OF 4TH NA ELECTION

TEXT.P: The chairman of the Central Election Commission (CEC) officially announced on Tuesday that the fourth National Assembly (NA) election had been suspended.
The announcement came after the CEC met to discuss the events related to the NA election scheduled to take place on May 6 after the NA passed a constitutional amendment to reduce the NA's power.
CEC officials decided to cancel the election, and also canceled the announcement of candidates' serial numbers which had been scheduled to be published on Tuesday.

Asked whether the CEC will use national funds to compensate candidates who have already passed the qualification screening, Huang avoided the question, and said only that the decision to cancel the election was in line with the constitutional amendment passed by the assembly in a late-night session on Monday.
Local election committees will refund the NT$200,000 guarantee fees deposited by the candidates when registering.

Asked whether the CEC will prepare for the forthcoming formation of a new ad-hoc NA, Huang said no preparations have yet been made as the CEC does not know what kind of ratio system will be adopted to determine how many assemblymen each party will be allowed to appoint.

DOC.HEADLINE: BLUSTER WILL ONLY DRIVE TAIPEI, BEIJING FARTHER APART: PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian offered mainland China another olive branch on Tuesday when he said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should shelve sensitive political topics and cooperate fully in economic and technological development.

Chen made the appeal during a courtesy call on K.T. Li, an incumbent senior adviser to the president who has been lauded as "the father of Taiwan's technological development" for his contribution to the establishment of the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park and to Taiwan's economic take-off in the 1970s.

After inviting Li to continue serving as a senior adviser to the president after the May 20 presidential inauguration, Chen said that both sides of the Taiwan Strait must learn from Chinese sage Confucius' teaching that political leaders should govern in a benevolent, magnanimous manner to win the hearts and minds of people at home and abroad.

Chen said goodwill and sincerity are needed to mend the gap between the two sides and that Taiwan would ease its defensiveness if Beijing were to become more pleasant to the island's 23 million residents.
"The two sides of the Taiwan Strait must rely on goodwill and magnanimity to narrow the gap, as venomous words and saber-rattling will only drive the two sides farther apart," Chen said.

He also cited the fable -- concerning a competition between the north wind and the sun to see which of them could make a man take off his coat -- to advise Beijing to stop its military threats against Taiwan. Chen pointed out that the warmth of the sun easily prompted the man to take off his coat, while no matter how hard the cold wind blew, it only prompted the man to pull his coat even closer about him.

Noting that there is ample room for the two sides of the Taiwan Strait to cooperate in trade and technological development, Chen said he earnestly hopes that Taiwan and mainland China set aside certain thorny, sensitive political issues and cooperate with each other for mutual benefits.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING STEPS UP MILITARY TRAINING TO INTIMIDATE TAIWAN: MND

TEXT.P: The Ministry of National Defense (MND) broke silence and warned on Tuesday that mainland China has stepped up military training along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan.

"The ministry has detected that mainland China's air force is intensifying combat training and its navy has also launched training programs in waters off its southeastern province of Zhejiang and from there to the disputed Tiaoyutai islands," MND spokesman Gen. Kung Fan-ding told a routine press conference.

Judging from those activities, Kung said, the MND does not rule out the possibility of mainland China launching military exercises, even live-fire war games, either before or after the inauguration of the Republic of China's new president on May 20.
Kung said many types of mainland warplanes, including H-6 bombers and attack planes, have joined specially designed long-distance, trans-military regions training activities.

Military sources said H-6 bombers are usually deployed in mainland China's inland military regions. Their participation in military training in its frontline Nanjing military region close to Taiwan indicates that those training programs are very likely aimed at threatening Taiwan.

Tension across the Taiwan Strait has been running high since Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party won the March 18 presidential election. Beijing has been pressuring Chen to embrace its "one China" policy which downgrades the ROC to a province of the PRC. Chen has resisted Beijing's demand, insisting that "one China" could be the agenda of bilateral dialogue but not a premise.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STRAIT ISSUE COULD AFFECT WORLD IF NOT RESOLVED PEACEFULLY

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Strait issue is not just a problem for Taiwan and mainland China, it could have an adverse impact on the entire world if it is not handled properly, the publisher of US-based Forbes magazine said here on Tuesday.

Steve Forbes, who called in his own magazine for Senate passage of the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act (TSEA) to help deter communist Chinese military attacks on Taiwan, said that if the United States is unable to stick to its stance that the Taiwan Strait impasse should be resolved peacefully, it could lead to results that would exert an immense adverse impact on the entire world, not just the Asian-Pacific region.

Addressing the Taipei media over tea, Forbes noted that the United States' consistent policy, set forth in the 1979 Taiwan Relations Act, stipulates clearly that the Taiwan Strait issue should never be resolved by force and that all other negative means, including trade sanctions, embargo and use of force in the strait, are unacceptable.

Forbes noted that Taiwan's political leaders, including President-elect Chen Shui-bian, have refrained from issuing independence rhetoric in order to try their utmost not to provoke Beijing, and said Beijing should not be discontented with the situation. He added that the United States' responsibility is not to support Taiwan independence, but neither should it support Beijing imposing its will on Taiwan through force.

Forbes, chairman and editor-in-chief of the largest business magazine in the United States, wrote an editorial in the March 20 edition of the magazine calling for the Senate to pass the TSEA so as to help deter mainland Chinese military attacks on Taiwan and criticizing the Clinton Administration for condoning the mainland's increasingly threatening intimidation of Taiwan.

He added that neither President Bill Clinton nor Vice President Al Gore support the TSEA, but noted that the trend across the United States is that most Americans perceive that the Taiwan Strait issue cannot be resolved by force.
Forbes has twice expressed his own presidential aspirations, in the 1996 campaign and again in the 2000 campaign.

DOC.HEADLINE: ACER CHAIRMAN MAKES LOW-PROFILE VISIT TO BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Beijing, April 25 (CNA) (By Peng Si-chou and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Stan Shih, chairman of Taiwan's Acer Group, made a low-profile visit to mainland China on Tuesday after it was rumored that Beijing had accused him of supporting Taiwan independence.

Shih, a national affairs advisor of President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, was to attend a seminar with his mainland trade partners in Beijing on April 26 and participate in "various activities" organized by the International Digital Group.
However, Acer officials stationed in Beijing said Shih's agenda in Beijing will be kept low-profile and secret.

Mainland leaders recently blasted certain Taiwan businessmen for supporting Taiwan independence while reaping the benefits of investment in the mainland, and have warned these businessmen not to support Taiwan independence if they want to continue investing there.
Beijing officials have also canceled invitations to Shih to participate in some seminars originally scheduled to take place in Beijing in May.

Acer officials have clarified to the Beijing authorities that the group has always maintained a neutral political stance and did not support any specific presidential candidate or political party during the election. They added that any presidential candidate can ask Shih to serve as an advisor.

However, it is widely believed that Beijing would face difficulties if it should try to limit Acer's investments in the mainland, because such action would prompt other Taiwan businessmen, many of whom are also major sources of investment for the mainland, to pull out and take their money with them.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Wednesday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
The Ministry of National Defense (MND) confirms reports that mainland China is planning to launch a round of propaganda warfare, probably including live-fire war games, across the Taiwan Strait around the time of Chen Shui-bian's May 20 presidential inauguration.
The China Times:
Taipei confirms that mainland China has intensified its military drills targeting Taiwan, but Beijing says the exercises have been "normal."
The United Daily News:
MND spokesman Kung Fan-ding says mainland China is conducting unusual exercises which may signify an intimidation campaign against Taiwan before and after the new ROC government takes office on May 20.
The Liberty Times:
Mainland China's H-6 bombers are flying long-range sorties across different military regions to bases near Taiwan in a possible warm-up to a new wave of exercises intended to intimidate the island.
The China Post:
PRC-ROC ties have global impact: Forbes.
The Taiwan News:
More mainland Chinese bomber drills reported.
The Taipei Times:
Military confirms fears of mainland Chinese war games.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DROP BY 385.16 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Wednesday, with the benchmark-weighted price index plunging 385.16 points to close at 8,535.96.
Market turnover amounted to NT$141.80 billion (US$4.65 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Wednesday, April 26, or the 22nd day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1452: Leonardo da Vinci, Italian painter, engineer, scientist and one of the most versatile artists of the Renaissance, is born. As a painter, he is best known for "The Last Supper," and "Mona Lisa."
1885: Britain occupies Port Hamilton, Korea.
1925: Paul von Hinderburg, German general and politician, is elected president of the Weimar Republic. He appointed Adolf Hitler as chancellor in 1933.
1937: The civil war in Spain takes a devastating turn with the sudden and horrific German bombing of the town of Guernica, which kills more than 1,500 people.
1946: Chinese Communist troops take over Harbin and Tsitsihar as Soviet forces evacuate.
1954: The United Nations meets at Geneva and insists on free elections in Korea.
1960: The construction of the East-West Cross-Island Highway in Taiwan is completed.
1966: Mt. Kelud erupts in Java, Indonesia, killing some 1,000 people.
1971: A White House commission recommends that communist China be brought into the United Nations, with the Republic of China retaining its membership.
1972: The eleven-member Chinese track and field team returns from Manila after winning 11 gold, 2 silver and 4 bronze medals in the three-day Philippine National Open Track and Field Championships.
1974: US Congressman John T. Myers and his wife arrive in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1975: The Embassy of the Republic of China in Saigon suspends operations.
1975: Shortly before the fall of Saigon, former South Vietnamese President Nguyen Van Thieu and his wife arrive in Taipei for a temporary stay before going into exile in the United States.
1976: The Fourth Asian Writers Conference of International P.E.N. opens with some 90 leading writers of Asia, Europe and America attending.
1976: The government of the Republic of China and the government of the Republic of South Africa announce the elevation of their consulates general to embassy status.
1976: Brig. Gen. Dan A. Brooksher of the US Air Force arrives to replace Brig. Gen. David O. Williams Jr. as chief of staff of the US Taiwan Defense Command.
1983: Explosions occur in buildings occupied by the Central Daily News and the United Daily News in Taipei.
1984: US President Ronald Reagan and his wife Nancy leave for a trip to mainland China.
1985: Lei Yao-hua fails in his attempt to hijack a domestic China Airlines passenger plane to Hong Kong.
1986: A nuclear reactor at the Chernobyl plant in the Ukraine explodes, spreading a radioactive cloud across Europe, and causing grave pollution. It was the world's worst nuclear accident.
1989: Lucille Ball, American TV's queen of comedy, dies in an Los Angeles hospital after a heart attack at the age of 77.
1989: Mainland students march to central Beijing to protest government statements condemning their campaign for democracy.
1994: A China Airlines A300-600 Airbus crashes at Nagoya airport in Japan, killing 264 aboard, with only seven survivors.
1994: The first all-race elections are held in South Africa for 90 seats in the National Assembly and 400 seats in provincial parliaments.
1996: Communist China, Russia and three former Soviet republics sign a treaty aimed at reducing tensions along their common borders.
1997: Peng Zhen, a senior leader of communist China, dies in Beijing at the age of 95.
1999: NATO planes destroy the Zezeljev railway bridge in Novi Sad during the Kosovo war.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "Be conscientious and sincere in what you say; be earnest and serious in what you do: in that way, although you might be in barbarous countries, you will get along well with men."

DOC.HEADLINE: KINMEN LOCKED IN THICK FOG, FLIGHTS SUSPENDED

TEXT.P: The only civilian airport on Kinmen was closed Wednesday because of thick fog which has blanketed the entire island area since early morning, resulting in poor visibility for safe air traffic.
Shangyi Airport authorities said normal flights may resume in the afternoon if the fog clears later in the day.
Visibility was as low 100 meters at around 7:00 a.m., gradually increasing to about 1,000 meters by 10:00 a.m., still below the minimum visibility of 3,200 for safe aircraft takeoff and landings.
The Central Weather Bureau said the weather in the Taiwan area will remain unstable over the next couple of days and torrential rains are expected for Wednesday afternoon and Thursday.

Meteorologists said that monsoon rains may engulf the entire island beginning Wednesday afternoon, warning people living in mountainous areas in central and southern Taiwan to be alert against landslides.

Temperatures are also expected to decrease significantly beginning late Wednesday, dropping to 20 degrees Celsius Thursday from Wednesday's 26 degrees in the north, and to 26 degrees Celsius in the south from Wednesday's temperature of 31 degrees, weathermen said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Wednesday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for May plunged 520 points to close at 8,480, with 4,792 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for June decreased 420 points to finish at 8,610, with 163 contract transactions, while September futures dropped 352 points to close at 8,830, with 10 contract transactions, and December futures moved down 150 points to finish at 8,850, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Wednesday were: 9,000 for May; 9,030 for June; 9,182 for September; 9,000 for December; and 9,477 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, were also lower.
May TE futures moved down 21 points to close at 470, with 1,766 contract transactions, while June TE futures decreased 22.90 points to finish at 472.1, with 26 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.
May TF futures decreased 64 points to close at 852.2, with 363 contract transactions, while June futures moved down 57.4 points to finish at 858, with four contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Wednesday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, plunging 385.16 points to close at 8,535.96.
Affected by war games launched by mainland China and other financial issues, the bourse opened at 8.992.62 and fluctuated between 9,022.77 and 8,465.76 during trading.

A total of 2.33 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$141.80 billion (US$4.65 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 2.06 billion shares change hands on a market turnover of NT$124.64 billion.
Losers outnumber gainers 556 to 19, with 20 stocks remaining unchanged.

All the eight major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 6.4 percent, followed by cement stocks at 5.7 percent, textile issues at 5.6 percent, bank and insurance shares at 5.2 percent, plastics and chemical stocks and construction shares, both at 5.1 percent, foodstuff stocks at 4.6 percent, and electrical shares at 3.9 percent.
