DOC.HEADLINE: 12 STATE AND GOV'T HEADS TO ATTEND PRESIDENTIAL INAUGURATION

TEXT.P: Despite Beijing's blustering, political and government leaders from among Taiwan's diplomatic allies are still scheduled to come to Taipei to attend the presidential inauguration ceremony next month, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA) said on Wednesday.

As of Wednesday, more than two dozen political and government leaders, including a king, five presidents, four vice presidents, and two prime ministers, have promised to attend the inauguration ceremony of President-elect Chen Shui-bian slated for May 20, said Liu Chih-kung, director of the MOFA's Department of North American Affairs.
Other leaders who are scheduled to attend the inauguration include four governors, three parliamentarian speakers, and six foreign affairs ministers, Liu noted.

Liu said that ever since March 18 when Democratic Progressive Party candidate Chen Shui-bian was elected as the next president of the Republic of China, Beijing has attempted to discourage world political and government leaders from organizing congratulatory delegations to Taiwan, from making remarks congratulating Taiwan for the election, and from inviting ROC officials to visit their countries.

In related news, Liu noted, Washington's attitude is of crucial importance to cross Taiwan Strait relations, adding that the fact it sent special envoys to both Beijing and Taipei after Chen's election underlined that the US government has been paying close attention to the cross-strait issue.
Liu said the United States has so far viewed Chen's remarks concerning the volatile issue cross-strait relations in a positive way.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE ENVOY ARRIVES IN TAIPEI TO ASSUME OFFICE

TEXT.P: New Philippine Representative to the Republic of China Rodolfo T. Reyes arrived in Taipei on Wednesday to assume office.
Reyes said upon his arrival at Chiang Kai-shek International Airport that he hopes to forge good relations with all quarters of Taiwan society.

Noting that there are no direct airlinks between Taiwan and the Philippines at the moment, Reyes said he will do his utmost to push for an early resumption of direct flight services between the two countries.
Reyes, 62, said he will pay visits to the ROC's Ministry of Foreign Affairs and the Ministry of Transportation and Communications to discuss the airlink issue with relevant ROC officials.

Reyes promised to coordinate with the ROC officials to work out a mutually acceptable solution to the aviation rights issue. Nevertheless, Reyes said he cannot explain his country's stance on the issue before meeting ROC officials.

Reyes was appointed by Philippine President Joseph Estrada to his new Taipei post. A seasoned journalist, Reyes was Estrada's press secretary until early this month. He also served as former President Fidel Ramos' press secretary from July 1, 1992 to May 10, 1993.
Political observers said Reyes' new assignment indicates that the Philippine government attaches great importance to its relations with Taiwan.

The Philippines has official diplomatic relations with mainland China, but maintains close economic ties with the ROC. However, the two countries have been at odds over civil aviation issues since late last year. At the request of Philippine Airlines, Manila civil aviation authorities in mid-February prohibited Taiwan carriers from offering Taipei-Manila flight services. In response, the ROC suspended the Philippine carrier's right to operate flight services between the two countries.

DOC.HEADLINE: LOW POSSIBILITY OF CROSS-STRAIT WAR: VICE DEFENSE MINISTER

TEXT.P: The possibility of war breaking out with mainland China after Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian takes office on May 20 is low, Vice National Defense Minister T.Y. Sun told reporters on Wednesday.

Speaking after taking part in a public hearing at the Legislative Yuan, Sun said that since Chen has demonstrated a high degree of sincerity and goodwill toward mainland China following his election as the Republic of China's new president on March 18, it is not very possible that war will break out between the two sides of the Taiwan Strait under the current circumstances.

According to Sun, Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has sought to show great sincerity toward the mainland by proclaiming that he will continue to follow the steps promulgated in the Guidelines for National Unification, and that the goal of Taiwan independence in the DPP's platform will not be inserted into the Constitution.

Citing the Korean peninsula as an example, Sun said that judging from past experience, the chance of war will be "zero," even in a dangerous situation, so long as the two parties involved act with great caution.

For instance, the two Koreas have been arch-rivals since the beginning of the Korean War in 1953, but there has been no large-scale conflict since the end of that war, and the two sides are now even preparing to hold a historic summit this summer, he noted.
The vice national defense minister analyzed, however, that war could have raged at any time should either side have failed to estimate the situation correctly.

Turning to reports that US aircraft carriers are conducting military exercises in waters off the island of Guam, Sun said he has not received any information in this regard, and added that in any case, it should be routine training for the US Seventh Fleet which does not necessarily have anything to do with the situation in the Taiwan Strait.

DOC.HEADLINE: BEIJING CONTINUES TO INCREASE PRESSURE ON TAIWAN SAYS MAC

TEXT.P: Beijing has continued to increase its pressure on Taiwan since Taiwan's presidential election on March 18, sources from the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) said on Wednesday.

Analyzing Beijing's latest policies towards Taiwan since the election, MAC officials said the Communist Chinese have evidently played double-handed schemes. Beijing clearly upped the ante and kept up a barrage against Taiwan in the run-up to the election in an attempt to spook voters into not voting for candidates advocating independence for Taiwan.

During that period, MAC officials said, Beijing publicized its white paper on its one China policy and the Taiwan issue, threatening to use force against Taiwan if the island continued to delay talks on unification indefinitely.

After Chen's victory, the officials added, Beijing demonstrated a degree of moderation, probably due to the fact it had not yet clearly thought out what to do in the wake of that development, saying it would be "listening to their (Taiwan's new leaders) words and watching their actions."
MAC officials also noted that while Beijing suspended all contacts at quasi-official levels, it seems to have resumed direct contacts between its officials and Taiwan's.

While the exchanges between Beijing's intermediary body, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, and its Taipei counterpart, the Straits Exchange Foundation, have remained at an impasse since last July, Beijing has allowed officials from the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council to visit Taiwan one after another, MAC officials said.

In addition, the officials said, Li Bingcai, deputy director of mainland China's Central Office for Taiwan Affairs (previously the State Council's Taiwan Affairs Office), was quoted as having said on April 8 that pro-independence Taiwanese business and trade leaders who maintain operations on the mainland will not be allowed to "harvest any fortune" in China. It, however, remains to be seen whether Li's remarks reflect Beijing's policy, the officials added.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR DOWN ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar dropped NT$0.059 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Wednesday, closing at 30.631.
The local currency opened Wednesday at 30.571 and was traded between 30.571 and 30.659.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$584.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANADIAN MINISTER COMPARES PEOPLE SMUGGLING TO SLAVERY

TEXT.P: Canada's Immigration Minister Elinor Caplan on Tuesday described the growing trade in illegal immigrants as "akin to human slavery."
In a speech to the Canada China Business Council in Beijing, Camplan stressed that neither Canada nor Mainland China can afford to tolerate "these criminal practices."

By cramming hundreds of illegal immigrants onto rickety cargo ships, she said, smugglers "place countless lives in danger and undermine public confidence in both our immigration and refugee programs, and in the many close ties that our countries enjoy."

As she spoke, police in the mainland Chinese coastal province of Fujian staged a large crackdown on "snakeheads" -- or smugglers of human beings -- who have been blamed for shipping boatloads of illegals around the world, mostly to North America.
She vowed that Canada would "adopt tough new measures to deal with those who would abuse its immigration and refugee system."

The minister said Canada was working with Chinese officials to co-ordinate efforts and that she was visiting China to observe first-hand the initiatives China's Public Security and Frontier Defense officials are taking to halt the illegal traffic.
On Wednesday, she will travel to Fujian province, the jumping off point for many of the refugees who attempt to illegally emigrate to Canada, the United States and Australia.

The minister said the debt taken on by individuals to pay for illegal passage abroad -- running as high as US$60,000 -- typically has to be repaid "over a short and cruel lifetime of illicit activity, sexual exploitation and forced labor."
Four ships with some 600 Mainland Chinese nationals landed off the coast of British Columbia last year. About 100 of the migrants have since been returned to China.

DOC.HEADLINE: PALESTINE THREATENS TO ASK ARAB NATIONS TO BOYCOTT OLYMPICS

TEXT.P: Palestine has threatened to ask all Arab countries to boycott the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney this September to voice its anger over the erection of a memorial to murdered Israeli athletes near the Olympic Stadium.

The Australian quoted the Palestinian National Olympic Committee (PNOC) as confirming on Tuesday night that it had "grave concerns about the memorial" built last year by Olympic Games organizers to commemorate 11 Israeli athletes and officials killed by terrorists at the 1972 Munich Olympic Games.
The PNOC regards the memorial as "humiliating" to all Arab countries and has made the first threat of a political nature to the Sydney Olympic Games organizers, the daily reported on Wednesday.
"The Palestinian Authority is calling upon Arab states to consider not showing up for the Olympics in Sydney, Australia, this summer," the Australian quoted the official PNOC journal as saying.

A PNOC spokesman said on Tuesday that "it's a dangerous thing for the Palestinian people, this monument. The Israelis are executing Palestinians every day in Lebanon and Bethlehem and there are no memorials for us. This is humiliating," according to the Australian.
The memorial on Olympic Boulevard in Sydney lists the names of those who were killed and displays a short quote -- "they were swifter than eagles and stronger than lions" -- from the Book of Samuel.
It is the first memorial of its kind built outside Munich and was funded by organizers of the Sydney Games, along with leading Jews, the daily reported.
The Palestinian threat follows a recent International Olympic Games announcement that a "full house" of IOC member countries would compete in this year's sports event, the daily reported.

The Palestinians' objection to the monument supersedes an earlier concern over a plan to observe one minute of silence during the opening ceremony for the Israeli athletes killed. That proposal was rejected in February by organizers of the Sydney Games after intensive lobbying, the daily reported.
Palestine, which is yet to be sanctioned as a separate state, sent two athletes to the 1996 Atlanta Olympic Games and was planning to send a larger contingent to Sydney this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: 1ST BATCH OF 500 CONSCRIPTS TO JOIN `ALTERNATIVE SERVICE' THIS YEAR

TEXT.P: An initial batch of 500 conscripts will be assigned to do social work this year as alternative to compulsory military service, sources from the Ministry of the Interior (MOI) reported on Wednesday.
It will be the first time that the Republic of China has introduced alternative military service for its conscripts.

Of about 5,000 eligible conscripts this year, 500 will be allowed to participate in alternative service, with applicants drawing lots to decide whether they can enter the program, said Hsiao Yu-huang, director of the MOI's Department of Social Affairs.

The conscripts, who will be scheduled to report to their service posts beginning early October, will serve as caretakers in public-run nursing homes and institutions for the mentally or physically-challenged, Hsiao said.

The conscription period for the alternative social workers, all male and aged around 20, will be two years and two months. Their salaries and other fringe benefits will be similar to those for military conscripts, Hsiao added.
Before beginning their stints as social workers, the new recruits will first receive five weeks of basic military training and attend a three-week workshop for special job training.
The ROC is the first non-European country to implement an alternative military service system to ensure more efficient, fair and just use of its manpower resources.

In years to come, more young men will be allowed to serve through alternative military service, and jobs available will include firefighting, other social services, environmental protection and medical services, Hsiao went on.

Under the alternative service regulations, those who have passed special national examinations and have obtained professional licenses will enjoy preferential opportunities to land alternative service jobs, while other applicants will have to draw lots.
Those who are "unsuited" for normal military service, whether due to family factors or special religious beliefs, can also apply to do alternative service.

DOC.HEADLINE: RESPECTED HK JOURNALIST URGES BEIJING TO BE MORE TOLERANT
DOC.DATELINE: Shenzhen, Guangdong, April 26 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: A respected senior Hong Kong journalist on Wednesday appealed to mainland China to be more tolerant to help solve the cross-Taiwan Strait impasse regarding the issue of "one China."
Pok Shau-fu, publisher of the Hong Kong-based Newsdom Weekly, suggested that mainland China could state that "one China" is both a principle and also an issue for renewed cross-strait dialogue.

The two sides of the Taiwan Strait have locked horns on the issue of "one China," with Beijing insisting that the "one China" principle should be a precondition for renewed cross-strait talks, and Taipei saying that the two sides can talk about anything so long as "one China" is not a principle.

Pok said that if mainland China were to stress that "one China" is not the People's Republic of China, nor the Republic of China, but a unified new China forged by the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, it would help assuage the misgivings of ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Vice President-elect Annette Lu.
In this way, Pok said, both sides would be able to hold meetings very soon to discuss peaceful unification.
He also said that it is undeniable that a gap between the two sides exists, and time is needed to make mutual adjustments and reforms.

The unification of the two sides would be "natural" when the ideologies, living standards, social orientation, economic activities and political systems have merged and fused on both sides of the Taiwan Strait, he said.
Pok made the remarks during an interview with CNA in Shenzhen, Guangdong province where a two-day conference on anti-Taiwan independence and the promotion of unification was held.
More than 200 experts and scholars from the mainland, Taiwan and Hong Kong attended the conference.

DOC.HEADLINE: DGBAS WILL NOT REVISE UPWARD TAIWAN'S ANNUAL ECONOMIC GROWTH: OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: There is no reason strong enough to convince the government to revise upward its estimate for Taiwan's 2000 economic growth rate, a government official said on Wednesday.

Wei Duan, director-general of the Directorate General of Budget, Accounting & Statistics (DGBAS) under the Executive Yuan, noted that although some domestic private economic research organizations have adjusted upward their estimates for the island's annual economic growth for 2000, the DGBAS is unlikely to follow suit.

Wei was referring to adjustments made by the Chung-Hua Institute for Economic Research and the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research, which have revised their figures upward to 6.66 percent and 6.49 percent, respectively.

Economic growth will be supported by robust foreign trade, rosy domestic consumption and increasing private investment, according to officials of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research. The institute on Tuesday revised the island's estimated economic growth for this year from the previous 6.28 percent.
Meanwhile, various investigations involving the manufacturing sector also show robust prospects for the island's economic performance.

However, Wei said that although there is little possibility of having to revise Taiwan's economic growth downward for this year, the government still lacks a strong enough reason to adjust upward its original estimate.
The current situation regarding the island's exports is indeed very good, but that is not to say that all the economic indicators sound optimistic, remarked Wei.

For instance, he continued, export growth has been high, but import growth has been higher, and if the huge amount of imported capital goods are not put into circulation immediately, the island's economic growth this year will be adversely affected as a result of a decrease in trade surplus.

Wei said the government's estimate of 6.54 percent annual economic growth for 2000 is a rather fair figure, and second only to mainland China among the major countries of the world. Taiwan's economic performance is therefore really a great success, he concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPAN'S MAIN OPPOSITION PARTY SETS UP JAPAN-TAIWAN DIETMEN COUNCIL
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Japan's main opposition Democratic Party (DP) has set up a Japan-Taiwan Dietmen Council to promote Tokyo-Taipei relations, a party spokesman said on Wednesday.
The spokesman said the DP also plans to send a delegation to attend Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian's inauguration on May 20.
This will be the second dietmen council to be set up in Japan. The non-partisan "Japan-ROC Dietmen Council," with membership of more than 300 Japanese dietmen, has existed for many years.

The newly established Japan-Taiwan Dietmen Council, which will have 40 DP dietmen as members, will be headed by Hironari Nakano, vice president of the DP. Yukihito Sentani, director of the DP Planning Board, will serve as secretary-general to the organization.

The spokesman said Nakano will head the inauguration delegation, and added that because the election of Japan's Lower House will be held in June, the delegation will be composed of mainly Upper House members.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT MEETS FORMER PREMIER

TEXT.P: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian paid a visit to former Premier Hau Pei-tsun on Wednesday for talks on a wide range of issues.

Chen first offered his sincere apology to Hau for his impolite words and deeds against Hau during Hau's stint as premier. At that time, Chen was a legislator and joined his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) colleagues in a campaign against the appointment of Hau, a four-star general who had served as chief of the General Staff and minister of national defense, as premier.

The DPP's pro-independence stance also prompted Chen to confront Hau, a strong anti-independence and pro-unification advocate, in many question-and-answer sessions in the legislature after Hau assumed the premiership.
Chen apologized for his previous less-than-subtle rhetoric and behavior, and added that he believes history will give fair and just judgment to Hau's contribution to Taiwan.

Chen pointed out that times are changing and that both he and the DPP have also been adjusting their thinking and vision. "Nowadays, I believe that the DPP and I share common views and consensus with Hau on many issues, as we are all concerned about our national security."

The lawyer-turned-politician further said after his 50-minute closed-door meeting with Hau that as the ROC's new leader and armed forces chief, he will consistently put national interest above all and will never force the military to accept his personal ideology.
Chen said he solicited Hau's views concerning military build-up and combat preparedness, as well as cross-Taiwan Strait issues.

"Hau told me that the highest goal of combat preparedness is to avoid war, and that national security cannot simply rely on weaponry procurement and an arms build-up," Chen said, adding he agreed with Hau's views that wisdom is the most important factor in resolving cross-strait issues and that non-military strength is often critical to ensuring national security.
For his part, Hau said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should reconcile and use strictly peaceful means to resolve bilateral disputes.
Noting that maintaining Taiwan's political status quo is the mainstream public opinion on the island, Hau said he hopes Chen's administration will deal with cross-strait issues prudently and wisely.
Hau further said he generally agreed with Chen's post-election words and deeds, particularly Chen's choice of incumbent Defense Minister Tang Fei as premier. "It's a wise choice," he added.

Hau said he will be more than willing to offer his counsel concerning national affairs for as long as Chen requires it. Nevertheless, he politely rejected an invitation from the president-elect to serve as a senior adviser to the president in the incoming government on the grounds that he is satisfied with his retirement and has no intention of changing his current way of life.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC PRESIDENT-ELECT'S CHANGES NOTICED: MAINLAND SEMINAR DELEGATE
DOC.DATELINE: Shenzhen, Guangdong Province, April 26 (CNA) (By Stanley Chung and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Beijing has noticed the changes in Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian's recent attitude toward mainland China, a mainland delegate attending a pro-unification meeting said here on Wednesday.

Speaking at the opening of the meeting, Zhang Kehui, vice chairman of mainland China's National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, said the mainland authorities have noticed the efforts made by Chen to ease cross-Taiwan Strait tensions since his election as Taiwan's new president on March 18.
Zhang stressed, however, that the core issue between the two sides is that Chen must accept the "one China" principle and "admit" that Taiwan is an unalienable part of mainland China.

Because of the political background of Taiwan's new leader, Zhang claimed that the situation between Taiwan and mainland China has come to a critical turning point. Taiwan's future, and Chen's ability to maintain peace in the Taiwan Strait, have become a major focus of international attention, he noted.
If Taiwan moves toward independence, it will push the two sides toward the brink of war, he warned.
Wang Chin-ping, vice chairman of the Taiwan-based China Unification Alliance, described the meeting as a "patriotic gathering."

Stressing that the theme of the meeting is to forge consensus on ways to promote unification and dissolve pro-Taiwan independence forces, Wang blasted "certain US arms dealers and opinion leaders, and some Japanese figures," for seeking chances to split China by pushing Taiwan to the edge of war.
The meeting, attended by more than 200 academics and opinion leaders from Taiwan, mainland China, Hong Kong and Macao, will run through Thursday.

DOC.HEADLINE: OUTGOING PRESIDENT TO BID FAREWELL TO GENERALS

TEXT.P: President Lee Teng-hui is scheduled to call on the three branches of the military early next month as part of an ongoing "grateful journey" prior to his stepping down on May 20.
Lee will call on the army, navy and air force general headquarters on May 1 to bid farewell to his generals.

However, in order not to stir up an angry response from mainland China, the Ministry of National Defense has canceled its original plan to stage a troop inspection and a display of the country's new-generation weaponry.
The outgoing president will instead only have dinner with his generals, the MND said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN'S ECONOMY TO GROW AT 6.3% THIS YEAR: ADB
DOC.DATELINE: Taipei, April 26 (CNA) (By Belle Chou and Elisa Kao)

TEXT.P: Asia will once again enjoy the fastest economic growth in the world this year, with the economic growth in Taiwan projected at 6.3 percent, according to a report released by the Asian Development Bank (ADB) on Wednesday.

In its report "Asian Development Outlook 2000," the ADB said the reconstruction work in Taiwan after the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake in 1999, coupled with bullish exports, have created a boom for the country.
The ADB's economic forecast of 6.3 percent for Taiwan is close to this island's official forecast of 6.54 percent.
However, the ADB analyzed that after Taiwan's entry to the World Trade Organization, its manufacturing sector will reap great benefits, but its agricultural sector will face greater competition.

The report indicated that Asia has begun recovering fast, with growth in gross domestic product projected at 6.2 percent this year, an increase of 3.9 percent compared to last year's figure. The report added that the industrial production of the region in general has reached the levels recorded before the 1997 Asian financial crisis.
Meanwhile, the report suggested that in the Greater Chinese Area, Hong Kong should improve its pollution or risk increased medical costs and a reduction in productivity.
The ADB also suggested that mainland China should make efforts to reduce its unemployment rate, although it added that its gross domestic product growth is projected at 6.5 percent this year.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVADING TAIWAN WOULD COST MAINLAND CHINA DEARLY: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: If mainland China were to launch an attack on Taiwan, the mainland economy might regress 20 years and its leaders would face pressure to step down, a senior mainland affairs official said on Wednesday.

Lin Chon-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), made the remarks at a public hearing on the Taiwan Strait situation in the wake of the Republic of China's March 18 presidential election.

Lin said President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) has shown a great deal of goodwill to mainland China since his election as the ROC's next leader, adding: "Chen's olive branches to Beijing have almost reached breaking point."

Commenting on a Ministry of National Defense report that mainland China's air force and navy have stepped up training drills along its southeastern coast opposite Taiwan in a possible attempt to launch a new round of saber-rattling against the island to coincide with Chen's May 20 inauguration, Lin said there is still not enough evidence to prove that the mainland will attack Taiwan in the near future.
Lin said mainland China's action toward Taiwan mainly hinges on three factors -- mainland China's domestic situation, the United States' attitude, and Taiwan's action, in descending order.

He pointed out that Beijing has toned down its bellicose rhetoric against Taiwan since March 18. "This mainly reflects that mainland China is conducting an internal review and adjustment as the island's presidential result has made Beijing leaders aware that there is a gap between their understanding of Taiwan and the reality on the island."

Lin went on to say that the United States is now more active and definite in handling Taiwan Strait issues than it was between 1995 and 1996, the last time Beijing conducted large-scale and live-fire war games designed to intimidate Taiwan.

"The US government now believes that it must spell out its opposition to mainland China's use of force against Taiwan," Lin said, adding that recent frequent visits to both sides of the Taiwan Strait by incumbent and retired US officials have been mainly aimed at discouraging Beijing from taking excessive action against Taiwan.

As for mainland China's domestic situation, Lin said the mainland has been in the grip of an economic recession since October 1998 that has aggravated social unrest and has led to factional strife among mainland leaders.

Lin said while some hawkish mainland leaders, mainly military brass, favor using force to unify Taiwan, other officials prefer to squeeze Taiwan's diplomatic frontiers and suppress its presence in the world arena.

At the moment, Lin said, several other factors would restrict mainland China from launching a military attack on Taiwan, including its inability to seize Taiwan rapidly, possible US intervention, regression of its economic development by about 20 years, decline in national tax revenues, sharp increase in unemployment and possible downfall of the current mainland leadership.
Against this background, Lin urged mainland leaders to stop their bluster against Taiwan and make a positive response to Chen's olive branches.

DOC.HEADLINE: CANCELLATION OF NA ELECTION IN ACCORDANCE WITH LAW: CEC CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: The Central Election Commission (CEC) agreed on Tuesday to cancel the National Assembly (NA) election in accordance with the law, CEC Chairman Huang Shih-cheng announced on Wednesday.
Huang made the remark in response to complaints from candidates who had already passed the qualification screening process for the election, and have actively thrown themselves into the race.

The NA election was originally scheduled for May 6, but was formally canceled by the CEC on Tuesday in line with a constitutional amendment passed by the assembly in a late-night session on the previous day.

The CEC released the election gazette on March 30 following the Council of Grand Justices ruling that the extension of NA deputies' four-year terms by another two years was null and void. The NA delegates' decision to extend their own tenure had caused a public furor.
The NA passed an amendment on Monday that would virtually dismiss the 339-member organization, the function of which has been to approve constitutional changes.
By passing the amendment, the NA will transfer most of its functions to the Legislative Yuan.
In the future, NA deputies will be appointed by political parties in proportion to the number of seats the parties hold in the legislature.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI RAILWAY STATION BECOMES POPULAR RESORT FOR ALIEN WORKERS

TEXT.P: The Taipei Railway Station has become a new resort for foreign laborers in the city, with a large number of alien workers jamming the station's main hall on Sundays and national holidays.
In the past, foreign laborers mainly converged at a Catholic church on Taipei's Chungshan N. Road, the Chungshan Stadium, the Chiang Kai-shek Memorial Hall Complex and the Taipei City Zoo in Mucha.
But recently, the Taipei Railway Station has emerged as a new favorite spot for foreign workers to meet friends on holidays because the terminal is spacious and air-conditioned.
On Sundays, large crowds of foreign laborers swarm to the railway station in downtown Taipei. Many of them then sit down on the ground of the main hall, eat snacks and chat loudly.

According to a survey of 272 local passengers at the railway station, aged between 20 and 45, on April 23, 76 percent of the respondents said they felt either "bad" or "disgusting" at the noise and chaos caused by the convergence of so many foreign laborers at one of Taipei's main gateways.

Twenty-eight percent of those interviewed said they felt untold fears when they saw the convergence of a large number of foreign workers at the station; 22 percent said they were afraid that the foreigners would spoil the environment with litter and noise; 17 percent said they worried that the gathering of foreign laborers may affect public order or cause criminal activities.
While only 39 percent said the convergence of foreign laborers has caused inconveniences at the station, 90 percent said they think the phenomenon is a negative sub-culture.
Meanwhile, 67 percent said they think the Taipei City Hall is obligated to take effective measures to improve the situation.

The survey was conducted by Taipei City Councilor Chin Li-fang of the New Party. Chin said although the Taipei Railway Station is under the jurisdiction of the Taiwan Provincial Government, the Taipei City Hall should work out measures to tackle the problem since the station is located in the city.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC INVESTMENT GROUP ARRIVES IN TOKYO TO LURE JAPANESE INVESTORS
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 26 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: A Republic of China investment promotion group led by Lin Nen-chung, director of the Industrial Development and Investment Center (IDIC) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs (MOEA), sponsored a Tokyo seminar on investment opportunities in Taiwan on Wednesday.
More than 100 Japanese investors attended the three-hour seminar on Taiwan's investment climate, prospects and current economic developments.

Lin told the investors that Taiwan's economy will continue to grow after the historic transition of power on May 20. The Taiwan Stock Exchange Index has soared since the Democratic Progressive Party's Chen Shui-bian won the presidential election on March 18. Lin attributed the rising stock prices to investor confidence in the president-elect.
Chen's statements of good will toward the mainland in the past month have won praises both at home and from foreign countries, including the United States, Lin said.

Lin went on to say that Chen has already declared that his administration will continue to promote globalization and financial liberalization, in order to join the World Trade Organization (WTO) as early as possible.

"The new government will promote cross strait relations under the principles of good will and peaceful cooperation so as to secure a steady development between the two sides of Taiwan Strait," Lin quoted Chen as having said.

Other economic and trade officials also spoke at the seminar. Lu Hsin-hsiung, deputy director of the MOEA Industrial Development Bureau, briefed the attendants on Taiwan's level of industrial development and incentives for the investors.

Kao Jung-chow, director of the Economic Section of the Taipei Economic and Cultural Office in Tokyo, briefed the investors on the bonded warehouse industry in the various export processing zones in Taiwan.
Liu Chung-yung, a representative of Taiwan's Industrial Research and Development Institute, briefed the participants on Taiwan's information technology industry.
The group, comprising a total of seven members, arrived in Tokyo Wednesday for a four-day visit.

The delegation will call on a local newspaper, the Sankei Shimbun, and Japanese firms, including Furukawa Electrical Co. and Mitsumishi Material Co. The group is expected to return to Taipei on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: ADB ECONOMISTS HAIL BENEFITS OF WTO ENTRY FOR TAIPEI AND BEIJING
DOC.DATELINE: Bangkok, April 26 (CNA) (By F. C. Kuo and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: Several Asian Development Bank economists said on Wednesday that they hope both sides of the Taiwan Strait will be able to enter the World Trade Organization this year, pointing out that the much-anticipated entry will be in the long-term benefit to all of Asia.

ADB Assistant Chief Economist M. Quibria, who is from Bangladesh, said that after Taiwan joins the WTO, its labor-intensive industries will be forced to move to other Asian countries. He added that industries on both sides of the Taiwan Strait will benefit from the introduction of new technologies from other WTO members.

Lee Jung Soo, an ADB official from South Korea, said that mainland China as a WTO member will face pressure to open agricultural imports. But he added that in the long term, entry into the WTO will be beneficial to mainland China.

Shin Myong Ho, a South Korean national and vice president for the bank's western region, pointed out that after the mainland joins the trading organization, it will have to follow WTO rules. He added that this development will be beneficial to the mainland as well as other countries.
But Quibria said that although the mainland China will certainly join the world trade organization, he is not sure whether Taiwan will follow suit.
The economists made the remarks on the sidelines of a press conference to present the ADB's annual survey of the region.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN EXPEDITION TO RETRACE CONQUEST ROUTE OF GHENGHIS KHAN

TEXT.P: A six-member Taiwan expedition will head for Ulan Bator, Mongolia, on Thursday for a trek retracing the route of Ghenghis Khan.
The expedition team, consisting of four men and two women, plans to take one and a half years to finish the journey, which covers 17,000 kilometers and meanders through 12 nations.

Starting from Ulan Bator, Mongolia, they will walk across the Gobi Desert to China, and then to Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Iran, Armenia, Azerbaijan, Georgia, and Russia before ending their trek at Simferopol, a Ukrainian city on the Black Sea.
Their planned route is similar to the path taken by Ghengis Khan when he conquered most of Asia some 800 years ago.

Armed with laptop computers, mobile phones and digital cameras, the team will keep in contact with their support group in Taiwan by satellite communication. Lai Hsin-hong, leader of the team, said that his group will post daily trek reports on a specially-created expedition website (www.seetaiwan.com.tw).

What worries the expedition team most is not the 30 kilometers they are supposed to cover every day, but rather the extreme climates along the route. Temperatures that they will have to endure vary from 40 degrees Celsius at noon in the Gobi to minus 20 degrees Celsius in Georgia, where the team is expected to arrive in mid-winter next year.
They are also worried about their physical safety in Azerbaijan, where fighting is now raging between rebels and government forces.

The two female members raised concerns about their half-year journey through Iran, where they will have to follow the local custom of covering their faces with veils, said Wang Kwang-yu, one of the two female members.

The six members of the team were chosen from a pool of 324 applicants, said Lai Hsin-hong. The successful candidates were then put through four months of training. They need their countrymen's support -- both spiritually and materially -- becuase the expedition will cost about NT$36 million (US$1.2 million).
The expedition was organized by "PC Home", a local online newspaper, which is trying to recruit one hundred 100,000 supporters to chip in for the expedition costs, said Lai.
If everything goes as planned, the expedition team is expected to return to Taiwan in October next year.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY EARTHQUAKE ORPHANS TO VISIT OKINAWA
DOC.DATELINE: Nantou, Central Taiwan, April 26 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Twenty-two orphans from Nantou County, whose parents died in last September's earthquake, will visit Okinawa from April 30 to May 3.
The trip, part of a care plan for the orphans, was arranged by the Nantou County government with the cooperation of Star Cruises.

Chen Wan-chen, director of the Social Affairs Division under the Nantou County government, said that she believes such kind of psychological treatment will bring about a favorable effect on the psychological development of the orphans in the coming decade.
She expressed appreciation to Star Cruises for providing the free trip for the orphans.
The special guests of the Okinawa cruise will be accompanied by several representatives of their foster families, psychologists and social welfare workers.

Thirty-five children in Nantou County lost both of their parents in last September's devastating temblor that claimed 2,400 lives. An additional four children became orphans during last February's landslides.

DOC.HEADLINE: KMT TO COMPLETE REFORM PLAN IN MID-MAY

TEXT.P: The Kuomintang, which lost its 54-year reign of power to the Democratic Progressive Party in last month's presidential election, plans to complete its reform plan on May 17.
This disclosure was made by Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan when he met with KMT National Congress delegates from northern Taiwan and offshore counties.

He said that central-level cadres of the party have worked out a consensus on readjusting the party's future position and organization, as well as how to win the support of the younger generation, rebuild the party's image and entrust party assets.
In the coming days, Liu noted, the cadres will continue meeting with grass-roots party members to listen to their voices on party reform.
He said the reform plan will be reviewed between May 4-7 to reflect the opinions of the grass-roots party members, with the final version of the reform plan to be presented on May 17.
Acting KMT Chairman Lien Chan said that he himself will attend five seminars in the near future to hear the opinions of the party's Central Committee members and delegates to the National Congress.
He expressed the hope that all party members will speak their minds on the reform plan so that the party will be able to rise again.

DOC.HEADLINE: FISHERMEN INVOLVED IN SLAYING OF FELLOW CREW REPATRIATED TO TAIWAN

TEXT.P: Four fishermen allegedly involved in the slaying of two fellow crew members on the high seas were sent back from Western Samoa to Taiwan under armed guard on Wednesday.

Chang Ta-cheng, the Taiwanese skipper of the Taiwan fishing boat "Hsiangyu No.8"; his son, Chang Hsiao-chung; and their two mainland Chinese crewmembers, Cai Xiaobing and Zheng Minshuai, were accused of slaying two fellow crewmen in early March. At the time, their boat was operating in the south Pacific Ocean, some 500 or 600 nautical miles off the coast of West Samoa, said Taiwan police investigators.
The two victims, Sun Zhengjiang and Zhu Zigung, were mainland fishermen who had recently been recruited to work on the vessel, said the investigators.
The police alleged that Chang Ta-cheng and his son were infuriated by the two victims' job inefficiency, and ordered Cai and Zheng to attack them with stun guns and bludgeons.
The two victims eventually died from their wounds, said the investigators.
Because the alleged incident took place on the high seas, Taiwan police were called in to probe the case after the boat moored in West Samoa.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHINA POISED TO DEVALUE THE RENMINBI

TEXT.P: Mainland China is poised to allow the devaluation of its currency by widening the tight band within which the renminbi is permitted to trade, skirting around Beijing's solemn pledge not to devalue its currency.

In a dispatch from Hong Kong, the Australian Financial Review on Wednesday reported that the depreciation is expected before China enters the World Trade Organization later this year in a bid to allow Chinese exporters to compete in the global market.

The daily reported China's central bank already signalled its intention to adjust its currency controls for the first time in more than two years by allowing the renminbi to trade outside the official band of 8.2770 to 8.2800 to the US dollar earlier this month.
Most Asian countries hit by the financial crisis in 1997 are now quickly recovering following the depreciation of their currencies and strongly emerging in the world market.

China's exports did surge in March, increasing about 40 percent, but they will face greater competition after China joins the WTO and it consequently opens its market wider and further reduces its import tariffs.
Whether the current strong gains in Chinese exports will continue remains doubtful at present, the daily reported.
The only way for China to maintain the competitiveness of its exports globally is to allow its currency to depreciate, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: AUSTRALIA ENGAGING ASIA IN PRACTICAL TERMS SAYS FOREIGN MINISTER

TEXT.P: Foreign Minister Alexander Downer said Australia is committed to engagement with Asia based on practical outcomes rather than cultural bonds, the Australian reported on Wednesday.

In a speech to the Beijing Forum organized by the Asia-Australia Institute and attended by Asian leaders earlier this week, Downer drew a distinction between Asian regionalism based upon cultural factors and one based upon practical outcomes in an effort to refine Australia's approach to changes in the region, the daily reported from Beijing.

"There are really two kinds of regionalism. One is what you might call a cultural regionalism, which is built on common ties of history and mutual cultural identity. One might more broadly describe them as emotional links. That type of regionalism exists in many parts of the world. Obviously, in terms of Australia's relationship with Asia, Australia does not fit into that category." Downer told the forum.

He described the second type of regionalism as practical regionalism and said this was typified by regional institutions such as the Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum and the ASEAN Regional Forum on security.
"For us, regionalism is always going to be practical, looking at ways that we can work with our region to achieve our own economic and security objectives," he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI CITY PLANS TO BUILD CULTURAL CENTER FOR FOREIGN WORKERS

TEXT.P: Cultural Affairs Bureau Director Lung Ying-tai of the Taipei City government said on Wednesday that a plan is in the works to build a cultural center for foreign workers in Taipei.
She made the remarks in responding to a question raised by City Councilor Chin Li-fang.
According to Chin, nearly 1,000 foreign workers flock to the Taipei Railway Station on Sundays and holidays, where they have picnics, play cards and hold music recitals.

Chin said that an April 23 survey of 272 train passengers conducted by her aides indicated that 90 percent of those polled believed the foreign workers' behavior would have a negative effect on the city's image.
Lung told Chin that the Cultural Affairs Bureau has discussed this matter with the Labor Bureau, and added that a plan is being worked out to construct a cultural center for foreign workers.
Government statistics show that about 300,000 foreign workers are employed in Taiwan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:
The lead stories in major Taiwan dailies on Thursday are as follows:
The Central Daily News:
US intelligence authorities closely monitor the Taiwan Strait situation.
The China Times:
Threat of attack on Taiwan by Beijing is a bit of an overstatement right now, says US Ambassador to Beijing Joseph Prueher.
The United Daily News:
US defense officials say no sign of imminent mainland Chinese war games for the moment.
The Liberty Times:
National Security Bureau chief Ting Yu-chou doubts the wisdom of releasing news about mainland China's military drills at the moment.
The China Post:
Taiex drops 385 points over PRC military exercises.
The Taiwan News:
Shares plunge 4.3 percent on cross-strait fears.
The Taipei Times:
Visa dispute puts HK move on ice; New conditions being put on granting a visa to Taiwan's de-facto representative in Hong Kong has delayed his assumption of the post.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 5.99 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) gained ground on Thursday, with the benchmark-weighted price index edging up 5.99 points to close at 8,541.95.
Market turnover amounted to NT$112.35 billion (US$3.67 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Thursday, April 27, or the 23rd day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1521: Portuguese navigator Ferdinand Magellan is killed by the inhabitants on the island of Mactan in the Philippines.
1737: Edward Gibbon, the British historian who wrote the six-volume classic text "The Decline and Fall of the Roman Empire," is born.
1791: American painter and inventor Samuel F.B. Morse is born. A portraitist whose subjects included Lafayette, he refined and patented the telegraph and developed the telegraphic code that bears his name.
1822: Ulysses S. Grant, the 18th president of the United States, is born. After his victorious Vicksburg campaign, he was made commander in chief of the Union Army and accepted the surrender of Confederate Gen. Robert E. Lee at Appomattox in 1865 to end the Civil War.
1882: Ralph Waldo Emerson, the American essayist, philosopher and central figure of American transcendentalism, dies at the age of 78. His poems, orations and essays are regarded as landmarks in the development of American thought and literary expression.
1887: The world's first surgical removal of the appendix, an operation known as an appendectomy, is performed by American surgeon Dr. Thomas Morton in Philadelphia.
1911: An uprising in Canton, China, is foiled when revolutionaries led by Huang Shing are defeated by the local garrison. The battle in Canton is the 10th uprising directed by Dr. Sun Yat-sen after he launched a revolutionary movement against the Ching court in the late 19th century.
1937: The new Golden Gate suspension bridge linking the city of San Francisco with Marin County reaches completion after four years.
1939: The British government announces its intention of setting up a ministry of supply and introducing conscription for the first time since World War I.
1945: The Allies reject peace offers by German SS chief Heinrich Himmler, insisting on unconditional German surrender.
1949: Republic of China President Chiang Kai-shek arrives in Shanghai and reiterates his determination to suppress the communist rebellion.
1950: The Communist Party is outlawed in Australia under a bill introduced by Prime Minister Robert Menzies.
1950: The British government officially recognizes the state of Israel.
1956: Rocco Marciano, known as "Rocky," the American boxer who won the world heavyweight championship in 1952 and defended it six times, retires as undefeated world heavyweight boxing champion.
1959: Liu Shao-chi is elected "state chairman" of communist China.
1960: The ROC establishes diplomatic relations with the Republic of Togo.
1960: Syngman Rhee resigns as president of South Korea, ending his 12-year rule.
1962: Hsieh Chin wins the "best director" award in the first film festival to be held in mainland China.
1972: After a journey to the moon, US Apollo 16 spacecraft and three astronauts make a safe landing in the Pacific.
1972: Kwame Nkrumah, the Ghanaian president who was deposed in 1966 by a military coup while in mainland China, dies in Bucharest, Hungary.
1973: Jordanian Ambassador to the ROC Mutasim Bileisi returns to Amman after a two-year tour of duty in Taipei.
1974: George W. Altuater, director of the Houston Port Administration, arrives in Taipei for a three-day visit.
1974: The Academia Sinica Advisory Council votes on a list of candidates for academicians.
1974: The Taiwan Railway Administration and General Electric of the United States sign a contract for the electrification of Taiwan's western trunk line railway. GE will provide 74 locomotives and heavy trucks for the project.
1978: President Mohammed Daoud is killed in a bloody coup and replaced by Afghanistan's first communist ruler, Nur Mohammed Taraki, who proclaims the Democratic Republic of Afghanistan.
1990: Joe Slovo, leader of the South African Communist Party, returns to Pretoria to take part in peace talks with the administration of President de Klerk.
1992: The International Monetary Fund and World Bank approve the membership of Russia and 12 other former Soviet republics.
1993: Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the ROC Straits Exchange Foundation, and Wang Daohan, chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, meet in Singapore in what is the first official contact between Taipei and Beijing since 1949.
1997: The world's longest road-rail suspension bridge, linking Hong Kong to its new offshore airport, is formally opened.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Thursday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, edging up 5.99 points to close at 8,541.95.
The bourse opened at 8,587.03, and fluctuated between 8,633.39 and 8,458.40 during trading.

A total of 1.90 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$112.35 billion (US$3.67 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.33 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of 141.80 billion.
Losers outnumber gainers 390 to 163, with 41 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only two posted gains, with electronics shares moving up the most at 0.8 percent, followed by bank and insurance stocks at 0.3 percent.

Other major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 5.1 percent, followed by textile issues at 2.8 percent, cement shares and construction stocks both at 2.3 percent, plastics and chemical shares at 1.9 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 1 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEGISLATURE EXPECTED TO PASS BILL ON SHORTENING WORK HOURS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan is expected to pass a bill on Friday amending the existing Labor Standards Law to shorten the maximum weekly work time from 48 hours to 44 hours.

Legislator Chien Hsi-kun of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), who initiated the amendment bill, said passage of the bill will be a much-anticipated gift to all of Taiwan's workers in celebration of this year's Labor Day on May 1.
Shortening the work week was also one of President-elect Chen Shui-bian's campaign promises.
Chien said he will continue coordinating with the legislative caucuses of the other major political parties to work out a timetable for implementing a full-scale five-day work week system.
"I hope the five-day work week scheme can be fully implemented by July 1, 2002 to deliver on another of Chen's campaign promises to all of Taiwan's salaried people," Chien said.

He pointed out that the bi-weekly five-day work week system has now been widely implemented in Taiwan. "As a result, the average total weekly work time of local workers is now less than 46 hours. Moreover, many private enterprises have even adopted a full-scale five-day work week system. Therefore, the current Labor Standards Law must be revised to match the actual situation concerning the maximum legal work time," Chien explained.

Meanwhile, Chien said, since Taiwan's per capita national income has reached US$14,000, Taiwan must shorten its work week to meet the world trend, adding that many other countries with lower per capita national income than Taiwan's, such as mainland China, have adopted a five-day work week system.

DOC.HEADLINE: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES
