DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported positive results on Thursday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for May moved up 149 points to close at 8,629, with 3,742 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for June gained 74 points to finish at 8,684, with 107 contract transactions, while September futures moved up 66 points to close at 8,896, with 11 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Thursday were: 8,480 for May; 8,610 for June; 8,830 for September; 8,850 for December; and 8,957 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, were also higher.
May TE futures moved up 9.5 points to close at 479.5, with 1,190 contract transactions, while June TE futures gained 7.9 points to finish at 480, with 18 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
May TF futures increased 8.8 points to close at 861, with 241 contract transactions, while June TF futures moved up 8.8 points to finish at 866.8, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: US URGED TO CONTINUE SUPPORTING DEMOCRATIC TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A renowned American China expert Wednesday urged the United States to continue supporting democratic Taiwan, saying "America has always supported democracy abroad and must continue to do so at a time when this involves bigger dangers and more difficulties."

John F. Cooper, the Stanley J. Buckman professor of international studies at Rhodes College in Memphis, Tennessee, told an audience of some 200 at a World Affairs Council luncheon in Houston that the importance of Taiwan's recent presidential election lies in the consolidation of democracy, adding that it was also a crucial election in terms of relations between Taiwan, Communist China and the United States.

The March 18 election represented the first time in 5,000 years of Chinese history where political power was transferred peacefully based on the electorate's direct choice. "It is not the norm in the world. In fact, it is a rare thing outside Western democratic countries," emphasized the author of more than 20 books on contemporary China, Taiwan's political system, and cross-strait relations.

But Cooper pointed out that President-elect Chen Shui-bian will have difficulties dealing with Communist China because he was seen in Beijing as Taiwan's foremost advocate of independence from China. Beijing cannot forgive him for putting such a provision in his party's charter and for previously talking of a "Republic of Taiwan."

Chen, however, moderated his stance going into the election and has made numerous conciliatory statements since winning the presidency. But this may not be enough due to the pressure on Communist Chinese leaders because of their loss of face with Chen's election victory, according to the professor.

He said Americans fail to realize the importance of face and most of them don't know that there are different factions in the Communist Chinese government. The military, which has gained in political influence in recent years, does not like Taiwan. Cross-strait tension also raises its stock and improves its prospects for bigger budgets. The old timers, leftists, hard-line Maoists, and some others don't like Taiwan as well.

The regime in Beijing has been promoting Chinese nationalism for the past two decades to fill the spiritual or ideological vacuum created by the slow dismantling of the communist system. Stimulating nationalist sentiments also increases the importance of so-called "lost territory," which some in mainland China feel Taiwan is, noted Cooper.

The serious differences in views regarding Taiwan between the US executive branch and Congress are certainly enough to confuse both Beijing and the new government in Taipei, which has little experience in dealing with either Beijing or Washington. "Thus, while Taiwan's recent election was historic and was a watershed for bringing about a peaceful transfer of power and thus consolidating Taiwan's `role model' democracy, it has also created uncertainties and problems," he said.

But Cooper stressed that "the United States must recognize Taiwan's accomplishments. Democracy is the wave of the future around the world and America has always supported democracy abroad. That means Americans must applaud Taiwan's accomplishments, but also see that there are problems to be attended to.

DOC.HEADLINE: OXYGEN TENTS SAID USEFUL TO OLYMPIC ATHELETES

TEXT.P: Many athletes who will be competing at the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games are planning to sleep in oxygen tents to help boost their performance level and organizers appear unable to ban the activity.
The Australian Olympic Committee said there is nothing in the doping control guidelines that prohibits the use of oxygen tents nor forbids their presence within the Olympic athletes' village.
Oxygen tents have become popular recently, especially among endurance athletes such as triathletes, cyclists, and swimmers, because they allow athletes to simulate high-altitude conditions.
Australian scientists, however, said they are not sure whether the tents are actually effective in enhancing performance.

DOC.HEADLINE: ARATS OFFICIAL EXPOUNDS 'ONE CHINA' IMPLICATION
DOC.DATELINE: Shenzhen, April 27 (CNA) (By Stanley Cheung and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: A senior mainland Chinese negotiator with Taiwan said on Thursday that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait must negotiate unification on an equal footing under the "one China" principle.

Tang Shubei, vice president of the Beijing-based Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), made the remarks in response to a press inquiry after attending an "anti-independence" seminar in this southern mainland special economic zone.

Tang said Beijing's "one China" principle implies that the world has only one China, of which Taiwan is a part, and that even though China is not unified now, its territorial integrity cannot be divided.
In Beijing's views, Tang said the two sides of the Taiwan Strait are on an equal footing when they negotiate under the "one China" principle.

Under the "one China" principle, Tang explained that cross-strait negotiation is not negotiation between central and local governments, not between the PRC central government and local Taiwan authority.
Tang urged Taiwan's leaders not to think that the "one China" principle is an insult to Taiwan's dignity, and added that the principle is not intended to downgrade Taiwan's status.
Tang further said it is mainland China's prevailing consensus that the so-called Taiwan issue should not be left unresolved indefinitely.

Quoting mainland Chinese leaders, Tang said, mainland people will not hesitate to shed blood to protect China's territorial integrity if Taiwan declares independence or enshrines the "two states theory" into its constitution.

Tang also said Beijing authorities have noticed that Taiwan's new leader (President-elect Chen Shui-bian) has sounded conciliatory note on cross-strait issues. Nevertheless, Tang warned that if Taiwan is unwilling to accept the "one China" principle, "the consequence will not be peace, but a disaster, not harmony, but a conflict, not goodwill, but hostility."

DOC.HEADLINE: CABINET APPROVES 3-YEAR EXTENSION OF ROC-SWAZILAND AGRICULTURAL PACT

TEXT.P: The Cabinet at its weekly meeting on Thursday approved a three-year extension of the Republic of China-Kingdom of Swaziland Agricultural Technology Cooperation Agreement effective retroactively to January 11, 2000.

According to the Ministry of Foreign Affairs (MOFA), the ROC originally signed the Agricultural Technology Cooperation Agreement with the Kingdom of Swaziland in January 1995. The two governments agreed in 1997 to extend the pact for another three years, to Jan. 10, 2000.

Since that date, officials at the Republic of China Embassy in Swaziland and representatives of the Swazi Foreign and Trade Ministry have met for talks several times. They eventually agreed to extend the agricultural pact for another three years, through an exchange of notes, the MOFA said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRES. LEE MEETS WITH FOREIGN SCHOLARS AT WORLD CULTURAL SEMINAR

TEXT.P: Republic of China President Lee Teng-hui met on Thursday with several foreign scholars who were in Taipei to attend an international seminar on culture in the new century.
Lee warmly welcomed his guests, and then exchanged a wide range of views on cultural development with them.

Taiwan's head of state told his visitors that the main reason people have moved to Taiwan from mainland China over the past 400 years has been to pursue a free and secure life here. As a result, a new culture has gradually come to life in Taiwan, President Lee said.
In order to reconcile newcomers with earlier inhabitants, he proposed the concept of "new Taiwan people", he told the scholars.

Lee went on to say that culture develops very slowly and each nation's culture is different. Faced with the information technology era, the world's people should open their minds and accept customs from other cultures so as to create a globalized culture.

The group of foreign scholars, accompanied by Foreign Minister-designate Tien Hong-mao, called on Lee at the Presidential Office in the morning. The group consisted of Andreas Wan Agt, Benedit R. Anderson, Sohail Inayatullah, Bruno Latour, Alan Fricker, Fu-chen Lo, and Tu Weiming.
Secretary-general to the President Ding Mou-shih was also present at the meeting.

DOC.HEADLINE: SEMINAR ON TAIWAN DEVELOPMENT & CROSS-STRAIT RELATIONS TO BE HELD

TEXT.P: An academic seminar entitled "The Development of Taiwan and Cross-Taiwan Strait Relations in the 21st Century" is scheduled to be held on Friday in Taipei.

The two-day seminar will be co-sponsored by the Chinese Europe-Asia Educational Foundation and National Sun Yat-Sen University. It is aimed at making an overall review of the current issues in Taiwan, while the island is ushering in a new era. Analyses and conclusions reached in the seminar will be offered to the government for reference.
In wake of the successful presidential election on March 18, Taiwan has entered into a new chapter in its political and economic development, said the sponsors of the seminar.
The smooth operation of the island's democracy and the peaceful transition of its political power are a model for developing countries, including mainland China, the sponsors added.
Taiwan has always continued its economic growth, even during the East Asian financial turmoil, and has now become one of the world's developed countries.
The seminar will cover topics regarding political, diplomatic, and economic issues that the island is facing. It will also cover relations between Taipei and Beijing and Asia-Pacific security.
Scholars from the United States, South Korea, Britain and Hong Kong, together with local experts, are invited to attend the meeting and exchange their opinions.

The opening ceremony will be presided over by Tseng Yung-hsieng and Liu Wei-chi. Tseng is a national policy adviser to the president, as well as the chief executive of the Chinese Europe-Asia Educational Foundation. Liu is the president of National Sun Yat-Sen University.
Chiang Pin-kung, chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development, and Su Chi, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, will deliver speeches during the seminar.

The closing ceremony of the seminar will be presided over by Chang King-yuh, board chairman of the Chinese Europe-Asia Educational Foundation, who is also currently a national policy adviser to the president; and Chou Chang-hung, vice president of National Sun Yat-Sen University.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OPPOSED TO USE OF FORCE AGAINST TAIWAN: DEFENSE SECRETARY
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Jay Chen and Sofia Wu)

TEXT.P: US Defense Secretary William Cohen reiterated on Wednesday that the United States strongly opposes the use of force in resolving the Taiwan Strait issue.

"I think it would have grave consequences to all concerned should China ever seek to achieve reconciliation with Taiwan through the use of force -- economic, diplomatic and potentially even military," Cohen said at a question-and-answer session following a Senate hearing.
Cohen said the US government has sent that message to the Beijing authorities, and that "hopefully, it will be persuasive."

Cohen said he has consistently taken advantage of his contact with mainland Chinese officials, including a meeting last week with mainland navy commander Shi Yunsheng, to convey the message that the United States recognizes the "one China" policy, but also has an obligation under the Taiwan Relations Act.

"...We expect that there will be reconciliation through peaceful means and that is the only way that can come about; that they should not seek in any way to take military action or threaten Taiwan -- to taking military action," Cohen said.

Cohen went on to say that he has advocated that the Taiwanese reduce their rhetoric about independence and a movement toward independence, which the United States does not support, and that everybody back away from the abyss that has developed.

"Hopefully, the calming influence of the election (Taiwan's March 18 presidential election), and the words that have been emanating from the president-elect in Taiwan, will cause everybody to back away from the rhetoric we have seen in the past and not in any way encourage the Chinese to think that they can take military action," he added.

Before assuming his current post in January 1997, Cohen visited Taiwan and other Asia-Pacific countries in late 1996 in his capacity as a senator. During Taiwan's presidential election, he also visited Hong Kong, Vietnam, Japan and South Korea. Cohen said the visit was designed to convey the above-mentioned message.

DOC.HEADLINE: LONG-TERM MILITARY DRILLS WILL AFFECT TAIWAN: CEPD

TEXT.P: Short-term military drills by mainland Chinese troops across the Taiwan Strait will only have a temporary effect on the local bourse, but long-term maneuvers would cause a profound impact on the island's economy, said a government official on Thursday.

Judging from past experience, the local stock market will quickly be able to regain its momentum if it is affected by short term non-economic factors, such as the present military drills in the mainland's southern coastal region and the Sept. 21 earthquake last year. C. Y Hu, head of the Economic Research Department under the Council for Economic Planning and Development, said.

However, he added that investor sentiment in Taiwan will be greatly dampened if current military exercises by mainland Chinese troops in Fujian and Guangdong provinces opposite the island continue over the long term.

Meanwhile, Vice Premier Liu Chao-shiuan, who also serves as the head of the National Stabilization Fund, said the fund is closely watching the performance of the domestic stock market, which plunged 385 points on Wednesday due to reported military exercises by mainland Chinese troops.

According to Liu, the fund, set up by the government early this year to help stabilize the local bourse in case of a financial disorder or military scare, will buy shares at an appropriate time if a decision is made to do so.
Nevertheless, Liu was reluctant to reveal what level stocks must reach for the fund to begin buying, as he wished to avoid speculation.

DOC.HEADLINE: NT DOLLAR UP ON TAIPEI FOREX MARKET

TEXT.P: The New Taiwan dollar rose NT$0.019 against the greenback on the Taipei foreign exchange market Thursday, closing at 30.612.
The local currency opened Thursday at 30.650 and was traded between 30.612 and 30.660.
Interbank US dollar trading totaled US$509.5 million.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU TO ORGANIZE SEMINAR TO ADVISE PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: National Taiwan University (NTU) will hold a seminar on Saturday 29 aimed at pooling academic wisdom for the new government. President-elect Chen Shui-bian has been invited to attend the opening ceremony.
Chen Wei-jao, president of the NTU, said on Thursday that after Chen Shui-bian's March 18 election, the wisdom of his actions has been highly praised both locally and internationally.

However, added Chen, the new government is facing harsh challenges in many areas, including cross-straits relations, political restructuring, economic development, educational reform, social welfare, and environmental protection.

Chen said that National Taiwan University offers a high level of expertise among its scholars, who have always been concerned about the country. He added that NTU is especially willing to contribute its advice at this important juncture in Taiwan's history.
The seminar, which will run through Sunday, will focus on topics such as social affairs, politics, economics, technology, environmental protection, and education.
The results of the seminar will serve as a reference for the new government.
NTU will organize another seminar of this nature in late May.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT VOWS TO FACE BEIJING'S THREAT WITH REASON

TEXT.P: Republic of China President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Thursday that he will face mainland China's military threat and saber-rattling with head, heart and will.
In a speech delivered at a meeting of Taiwan's Presbyterian churches, Chen said that after he assumes office on May 20 he will also lead the ROC with head, heart and will.
"I'll carry out my duties with prudence and caution. I'll work to the extreme of my potential to serve Taiwan -- our common homeland," Chen said emotionally.

Chen said he has advocated that Taiwan should adopt a new middle-of-the-road policy and that the government and the private sector should form a partnership to jointly develop an advanced civic society.
As for the threat from mainland China, Chen said he will consistently safeguard national sovereignty, dignity and security, and put national interests above personal and partisan interests.

He called on the people of Taiwan to stand united and work together with him to pursue lasting peace, adding that he believes maintaining peace is the highest goal of reason and moral obligation of Taiwan's new leader.

Earlier in the day, Chen paid a courtesy call on Yulon Motor Corp. Chairwoman Vivian Wu for wide-ranging talks. Chen expressed his admiration for Wu's contribution to the development of Taiwan's automobile industry.

He also thanked Wu for her consenting to allow Lin Hsin-yi, vice chairman of China Motor Corp., a Yulon Group affiliate, to join his administration as economics minister. Chen said he believes Lin's appointment will inject new vitality and thinking into his government and thus help upgrade national competitiveness in the world market.

Also that day, Chen hosted a luncheon in honor of key figures of the major factions in his Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). The president-elect exchanged views with the DPP heavyweights on ways to boost internal party unity and ensure a constructive working relationship between his administration and the legislature.

Later in the afternoon, Chen also visited professor Peng Ming-min, who represented the DPP in the ROC's first-ever direct presidential election in 1996 and is also known as the godfather of Taiwan's pro-democracy movement because of his work during the martial law era. Chen invited Peng to serve as a senior adviser to the president in his administration.

DOC.HEADLINE: HK MIGHT BLOCK TAIWAN JUSTICE MINISTER-DESIGNATE'S VISIT
DOC.DATELINE: Hong Kong, April 27 (CNA) (By Mandy Wong & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: The Hong Kong government is likely to block a visit by Taiwan lawmaker Chen Ding-nan, sources at the Taiwan representative office in the former British colony said on Thursday.

Chen Ding-nan, who has been tapped as justice minister under the administration of President-elect Chen Shui-bian, has expressed his desire to visit Hong Kong to inspect the operations of the Independent Commission against Corruption (ICAC).
The plan to visit was prompted by the incoming president's intention to set up a anti-corruption organization under the Department of Justice to stamp out graft in the government.

Chen Ding-nan has asked Taiwan's representative office in Hong Kong to arrange a trip before May 10 for him, with a visit to the ICAC under the Hong Kong government as its centerpiece, said the sources.

However, the sources said they doubt the Hong Kong authorities will agree to the visit, given the tense ties between the two sides because of a dispute over a work permit for the Taiwan representative in Hong Kong.
Hong Kong denied a visa to Taiwan's would-be-representative to Hong Kong, Chang Liang-jen, because Taipei refused to guarantee that Chang would not act directly or indirectly on behalf of Taiwan.
Although Cheng Ding-nan has a valid visa issued by Hong Kong, he might still be denied entry, as was Taiwan's representative to Macau, William Li, according to the sources.

Their views were supported by an anonymous Hong Kong government official who said on Thursday that Taiwan officials should get approval from the Immigration Department before arriving in Hong Kong, even if they hold visas.

Meanwhile an ICAC spokesman said on Wednesday that the organization welcomes the chance to exchange anti-graft experience with anyone, including Chen Ding-nan, so long as he can visit Hong Kong legally.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPETITIVENESS OF ASIAN GOODS DISTRIBUTION LAGS BEHIND US, EUROPE

TEXT.P: Officials from member nations of the Asian and Pacific Economic Council (APEC) met on Thursday in Taipei to discuss the current state of merchandise distribution throughout the world and prospects for the future.
According to statistics provided by experts at the meeting, the cost of merchandise distribution in Taiwan is higher than that of Europe and the United States.

The Merchandise Distribution Association of the Republic of China (MDAROC) said the ROC government should plan a special merchandise distribution area to help the industry cut down costs and upgrade competitiveness.

The seminar was jointly sponsored by the Board of Foreign Trade (BOFT) under the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the Merchandise Distribution Association of the ROC, and the China External Trade and Development Council (CETRA).

In addition to Taiwan, delegates from the United States, Australia, Hong Kong, Japan, South Korea, Singapore, mainland China, the Philippines, Thailand, Vietnam, Indonesia, Malaysia, Mexico, Chile, Peru, Russia and Papua New Guinea attended the seminar.

An APEC survey showed that the proportion between merchandise distribution costs and the gross domestic products (GDP) of the United States in 1998 was around 10.05 percent. The ratio in Asia during the same period was 16 percent, indicating that both the cost and efficiency of merchandise distribution in Asia lagged far behind that of the United States.

Chung Jung-chin, secretary general of the MDAROC, said that the merchandise distribution industry in Asia was at the same developmental level of that of the United States in 1982. Chung urged the ROC government to set up a special merchandise distribution zone to help cut down costs and upgrade competitiveness. A BOFT representative called on merchandise distributors to cooperate with their counterparts in other member nations of APEC in the face of rapid global change.

DOC.HEADLINE: COMPROMISE NEEDED TO HANDLE CROSS-STRAIT ISSUES: US EXPERT
DOC.DATELINE: San Francisco, April 26 (CNA) (By Neil Lu and Flor Wang)

TEXT.P: Both Taiwan and mainland China should compromise on the "one China" issue as a way of breaking the current impasse between them, a senior US China expert commented on Wednesday.

Ramon Myers, a China hand at the Hoover Institute of Stanford University, told CNA that recent remarks made by Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian toward mainland China show that he is adopting a reserved and cautious attitude in his handling of cross-Taiwan Strait relations. But he stressed that Chen cannot evade the "one China" issue if he truly wishes to improve bilateral ties.

According to Myers, Chen's concept of a "Greater Chinese confederation" which would allow Taiwan and mainland China to share equal sovereignty is apparently the best choice the president-elect could have made. The incoming Taiwan president has said that he is willing to discuss such a topic with mainland leaders as long as the "one China" principle espoused by Beijing is not a precondition to bilateral negotiations.

Only under such a "Greater Chinese confederation" framework would the two sides of the Taiwan Strait be able to start talks on issues of major concern related to national defense, foreign policy and the establishment of direct trade, traffic and postal links across the strait, the China expert told CNA.

According to Myers, he wrote a letter about 18 months ago in which he made a similar suggestion to outgoing President Lee Teng-hui as an option for mending the differences between Taiwan and the mainland. However, he went on, Lee did not reply, and he abandoned his efforts after Lee aired his "two-states" theory in July last year.

However, Myers acknowledged that the Chinese communists have so far failed to respond to Chen's confederation proposal. If Taiwan compromises on Beijing's "one China, two systems" unification formula, mainland China in turn should also respond positively to Taiwan's proposal, he contended.
If this does not happen, Myers warned, the two sides may have to settle their disputes through a military approach.

Although there are probably different viewpoints in Taiwan regarding the "confederation concept" raised by Chen, Myers opined that the new Taiwan government should forge a general consensus on the issue with an open mind and work out concrete measures to serve as the foundation in negotiations with the mainland authorities.

Taiwan and mainland China, through communication and talks, should each be willing to compromise in an effort to build mutual trust and find common ground between Taiwan's "confederation proposal" and Beijing's "one China, two systems" scheme, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN GOVERNOR TO HAND OVER DUTIES ON MAY 1
DOC.DATELINE: Chunghsing New Village, Nantou, April 27 (CNA) (By Victor Lai)

TEXT.P: Retiring Taiwan Provincial Governor Chao Shao-po will hand over his duties to Lieutenant Governor Chiang Ching-chien on May 1, a provincial government official said on Thursday.
The governorship will be assumed by interior minister-to-be Chang Po-ya, who will serve concurrently in both posts, when President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new government is inaugurated on May 20.
Chao has decided to retire from over 30 years of public service to take over as director of the Kuomintang's Organizational Department.
The KMT lost its 54-year grip on power in Taiwan to Chen's Democratic Progressive Party in last month's presidential election.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIBETAN GROUP SLAMS SA SILENCE ON MAINLAND CHINA HUMAN RIGHTS

TEXT.P: South Africa's Tibetan Support Group on Wednesday slammed the lack of discussion between South African and mainland Chinese leaders of Beijing's human rights abuses during a visit by mainland Chinese President Jiang Zemin.

In a statement issued in Cape Town, the group said: "It proves we are prepared to jump into bed with the most attractively made-up prostitute on the block, irrespective of her carefully concealed diseases."
"And as we all know, diseases can be very contagious," added the group, which protested against mainland China's human rights record outside a hotel where Jiang was staying.
Upon his arrival in Cape Town from Pretoria, Jiang was taken into the hotel through a back entrance to avoid the protesters.
He arrived in South Africa on Monday for a state visit and left on Thursday afternoon.

DOC.HEADLINE: MUTUAL TRUST WILL MAKE REAL PEACE: PRESIDENT-ELECT

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian said on Thursday that only mutual trust can bring real peace to the people of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Chen made the remark during a meeting with Tsai Jen-chien, mayor of Hsinchu City, home of Taiwan's first industrial park, the Hsinchu Science-based Industrial Park.
He also promised to offer "a joyful life" to the country's people during his four-year term in office.
Amid the recent tense relations between mainland China and Taiwan, Chen said peace always lies in mutual trust, and added that he will try his best to achieve this goal.

Concerning his campaign promise to increase the number of female Cabinet officials to 25 percent of the total during his term, Chen said the goal will be achieved before his inauguration on May 20 under the suggestions of Vice President-elect Annette Lu.
During the meeting with Tsai, Chen also expressed concern about the interaction between the Hsinchu city government and the high technology companies located in the industrial park.
The concerns were aroused by recent quarrels between the city government and some high technology companies in the park over the issue of environmental protection.

DOC.HEADLINE: ROC DEFENSE MINISTER TO LEAVE HOSPITAL ON APRIL 29

TEXT.P: Republic of China Defense Minister Tang Fei, who has been designated as premier in President-elect Chen Shui-bian's new government, will be discharged from the Veterans General Hospital-Taipei on April 29.
A hospital press release said that Tang has been recovering well after undergoing an operation to remove a chest tumor 10 days ago.

Tang was also quoted as saying that he wants to hold a press conference before leaving the hospital to express his appreciation for the concern extended to him by all echelons of society during his hospitalization.
The press conference is temporarily scheduled for 11 a.m. on April 29.

Almost all the major posts of Tang's new Cabinet have been appointed through the coordination of Chen, Tang and Vice Premier-to-be Yu Hsi-kun. The new government will be formally inaugurated on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT NAMES PRO-INDEPENDENCE SCHOLAR AS SENIOR ADVISOR

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Thursday asked Peng Ming-min, president of the pro-Taiwan independence Nation Building Council, to be a presidential senior advisor, a post which Peng accepted gracefully.

Peng was the Democratic Progressive Party's (DPP's) presidential candidate in the 1996 presidential election, in which he failed to achieve victory, while Chen successfully represented the DPP in the March 18 presidential election.
After a 40-minute closed-door meeting, Chen told reporters that he will arrange an office for Peng at the Presidential Office.
The president-to-be noted that he "is lucky to be able to shoulder the cross of history," and added that he will exert caution, rationality, compassion and resolve to lead the country.
Peng, who returned from a United States trip on Wednesday night, said that many Chinese and American people he met on his visit lauded Chen for the statements he has made since winning the election.
He said that many American people are sympathetic to Taiwan's position and are willing to extend support for Taiwan so long as the people of the island are united.

DOC.HEADLINE: JAPANESE LAWMAKERS TO VISIT TAIWAN
DOC.DATELINE: Tokyo, April 27 (CNA) (By Mike Chang & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: A group of Japanese lawmakers from the three partners in the coalition government will depart for Taiwan in two batches on Friday and Saturday for a visit, according to Taiwan's representative office in Tokyo.

Led by Masakuni Murakami, head of the Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) Caucus in the Upper House, the delegation will consist of six Upper House members and three Lower House members of the LDP, Komeito and Conservative Party, the three partners in the coalition.
They are scheduled to meet with Taiwan President-elect Chen Shui-bian and outgoing President Lee Teng-hui, as well as other political and business leaders.

Conservative Party Chairwoman Chiage Ogi backed out of the visit at the last minute at the strong urging of Cabinet Secretary Mikio Aoki, who said at a press conference that a visit to Taiwan by such a high-profile delegation of coalition government partners so soon after Taiwan's choice of a pro-independence candidate as its next president could anger Beijing.
Both Murakami, Ogi and Takeo Hiranuma, an LDP Lower House member who is also a member of the delegation, are vice-chairmen of a pro-Taiwan parliamentarians' group, the Japan-ROC Dietmen's Council.
The Taiwan representative office in Tokyo said, however, that the visit underlines the desire of the coalition government to improve substantial ties with Taiwan under President-elect Chen Shui-bian.

DOC.HEADLINE: PHILIPPINE SENATE RATIFIES NON-NUCLEAR TREATY

TEXT.P: The Philippine Senate foreign relations committee has endorsed the ratification of a treaty declaring Southeast Asia a nuclear weapon-free zone.

In a report unanimously endorsed by the members, the committee said the Senate concurrence of the treaty would "enhance Philippine national security" as well as promote international peace and security.
The treaty was initially endorsed and signed by 10 Southeast Asian nations in 1995 in Bangkok.

It seeks to declare Southeast Asia free from any nuclear weapons, including the manufacture or acquisition, transportation and testing by member-states of nuclear weapons or any radioactive materials within Southeast Asia.
However, it allows the members to use nuclear energy for peaceful and economic means.
In another report, the foreign relations committee also endorsed the senate adoption of the International Convention on the Prevention of Pollution from Ships.

The treaty deals with all forms of marine pollution, including the waste discharge of oil tankers into the sea, the discharge of noxious liquid waste by chemical tankers and the carriage of harmful substances by ships.

DOC.HEADLINE: MINDANAO GOVERNOR NEEDS AUTHORITY TO NEGOTIATE WITH KIDNAPPERS

TEXT.P: The Philippine government must give Autonomous Region for Muslim Mindanao (ARMM) Gov. Nur Misuari full authority to negotiate for the release of foreigners abducted by members of the Abu Sayyaf group from Sipadan island, Malaysia.

Sen. Rodolfo Biazon, chairman of the Senate Committee National Defense and Security, said that Misuari could provide the key to the resolution of the Sipadan kidnapping because, aside from his legal and moral authority as ARMM chief, he has also intimate knowledge of the terrain in Sulu, the area of the Philippines where the hostages were taken, and is probably familiar with the abductors of the 21 hostages.

The senator made the call following reports confirming the presence of the abductors and their kidnap victims in Sulu. Because of this, he said, the responsibility of resolving the incident have been shifted from the Malaysian authorities to the Philippine government.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATIVE BUREAU CONTRADICTS INCOMING BOSS

TEXT.P: The Investigative Bureau (IB) on Thursday described its incoming boss as "not well-informed" for denigrating the IB as an overstaffed organization which should be wiped out.

In a rare public squabble between the government's investigative arm and Justice Minister-designate Chen Ding-nan, the IB said it currently has 2,820 employees, including 2,246 investigators, which is far less than the 4,637 personnel prescribed by its organic rules.
Rather than being overstaffed, the IB in fact operates at less than full capacity of personnel, the organization contended in a statement.

Contradicting Chen's comment in an interview with a local newspaper that the IB is full of divisions not provided for in its organic rules, the IB said all its divisions, such as the anti-money laundering center, the economic crime prevention center, and the anti-drug center were established with the approval of the Executive Yuan.
Chen is expected to be sworn in on May 20, and the brawl with the IB under the Ministry of Justice bodes ill for their future relationship, according to political analysts.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES UP BY 282.41 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) continued to gain ground on Friday, with the benchmark-weighted price index moving up 282.41 points to close at 8,824.36.
Market turnover amounted to NT$168.69 billion (US$5.51 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES UP ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high and closed even higher on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Friday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving up 282.41 points to close at 8,824.36.
Affected by a rebound of stock prices in the United States, the bourse opened at 8,595.01, and fluctuated between 8,860.50 and 8,478.48 during trading.

A total of 2.51 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$168.69 billion (US$5.51 billion), an increase from the previous trading session which saw 1.90 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of 112.35 billion.
Gainers outnumbered losers 470 to 86, with 42 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only bank and insurance stocks remained unchanged.

Other major categories gained ground, with plastics and chemical shares moving up the most at 4.5 percent, followed by electrical stocks at 4.4 percent, pulp and paper issues at 4.3 percent, cement shares at 3.9 percent, construction stocks at 2.8 percent, textile issues at 1.5 percent, and foodstuff stocks at 0.6 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES MIXED ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported mixed results on Friday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for May moved up 221 points to close at 8,850, with 4,001 contract transactions.
TAIEX Index Futures for June also increased 221 points to finish at 8,905, with 134 contract transactions; September futures gained 244 points to close at 9,060, with 18 contract transactions.

However, TAIEX Index Futures for December edged down 1 point to close at 8,998, with two contract transactions, while futures for next March plunged 326 points to close at 8,780, with three contract transactions.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Friday were: 8,629 for May; 8,684 for June; 8,816 for September; 8,999 for December; and 9,106 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, also reported mixed results.
May TE futures moved up 18.5 points to close at 498, with 1,867 contract transactions, while June TE futures increased 23.10 points to finish at 503.1, with 250 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
May TF futures decreased 6.0 points to close at 855, with 383 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Friday, April 28, or the 24th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1442: King Edward IV, English monarch, Yorkist leader during the War of the Roses, is born. He was crowned after defeating the Lancastrians at Mortimer's Cross and Towton in 1461.
1545: Yi Sun-shin, Korean admiral and national hero, is born.
1758: James Monroe, the fifth president of the United States, is born. His administration is remembered for the acquisition of Florida in 1819, for proclaiming the Monroe Doctrine in 1823, which declared that no European power would be allowed to colonize any part of America.
1770: Captain James Cook, British navigator, lands at Botany Bay (now in the suburbs of Sydney, Australia) aboard his ship, the Endeavoura.
1789: On a return trip from Tahiti in the South Pacific, mutinous crew members of the British transport ship Bounty set Captain William Bligh and 18 sailors adrift in an open boat. Bligh and his royal crew manage to reach Timor Island near Java on June 14 after sailing 3,500 miles.
1788: Maryland becomes the seventh states of the United States.
1876: Queen Victoria of Britain is declared Empress of India.
1902: The US Senate passes an anti-Chinese bill.
1922: War between Wu Pei-fu of the Chihli faction and Chang Tso-lin of the Fengtien faction breaks out.
1922: Dr. Sun Yat-sen issues a manifesto urging the reunification of China by peaceful means.
1936: King Fu'ad of Egypt, who became the country's monarch when Britain granted limited independence to Egypt in 1922, dies at the age of 68. His son Farouk ascends to the throne.
1937: Saddam Hussein, who was to become president of Iraq since 1979, is born.
1945: Italian dictator Benito Mussolini is shot by his countrymen, who then string up his body head down.
1952: At his own request, Dwight D. Eisenhower is relieved of duty as Supreme Allied Commander Europe. He is succeeded by Gen. Matthew Ridgway.
1952: The Treaty of Peace between the Republic of China and Japan is signed in Taipei by Foreign Minister George K.C. Yeh and Japan's special envoy, Isao Kawata.
1953: Japan is allowed self-government for the first time since the end of World War II.
1962: The Taiwan Television Enterprise, Ltd. is established in Taipei.
1963: Yang Chuan-kuang, the ROC's decathlon champion who won the first Olympic silver medal for his country in Sept. 6, 1960, sets a new world record in the sport in the United States with 9,121 points.
1963: Taiwan holds elections for the third Provincial Assembly.
1969: President Charles De Gaulle of France resigns and is succeeded by Georges Pompidou.
1974: Ambassador to the Republic of Paraguay Hu Hsin leaves Taipei for Asuncion to assume his post.
1975: Premier Chiang Ching-kuo is elected chairman of the Central Committee of the ruling Kuomintang.
1976: Delegates headed by Dr. Ku Cheng-kang, honorary president of the World Anti-communist League, leave Taipei for Seoul and the Ninth General Assembly of WACL.
1980: US Secretary of State Cyrus Vance resigns.
1988: A Republic of China delegation attends the annual convention of the Asian Development Bank (ADB) in Manila.
1992: The Afghan government cedes power to Islamic guerrillas in Kabul, ending 14 years of armed resistance and civil war.
1992: Yang Chi-chang, a police officer, is killed in an explosion while trying to defuse a bomb placed by blackmailers near the McDonald's fast food branch on Minsheng East Road in Taipei.
1995: A leaking gas line explodes at a subway construction site in Taegu, South Korea, killing more than 100 people and injuring nearly 200 others.
1996: The Ministry of Economic Affairs announces that starting July 1, 1996, imports of another 1,609 categories of industrial commodities will be allowed into Taiwan from mainland China, marking the ROC government's largest relaxation of restrictions on mainland imports.
1998: David Hempleman-Adams, British explorer, reaches the geographic North Pole, becoming the first person to reach the Earth's northern magnetic and geographic poles.
Confucius's lesson of the day: "A gentleman of spirit or a man of moral character will never try to save his life at the expense of his moral character, he prefers to sacrifice his life in order to save his moral character."

DOC.HEADLINE: EXCLUSIVE INTERVIEW WITH ROC VP LU TO AIR IN WASHINGTON

TEXT.P: In an exclusive interview to be aired here Sunday on the television program "Ask Congress," Republic of China Vice President-elect Annette Lu calls upon the Clinton administration to mediate the on-going dispute across the Taiwan Straits in order to facilitate a peaceful resolution.

Lu also expressed the hope that a more official relationship could be developed with the United States, such as allowing herself and government officials from both countries to participate in an exchange of visits.

During a wide-ranging interview with former US Congressman Lester Wolff taped in Taipei after the March 18 presidential election, Lu outlined the top policy priorities of the new government and its position on US-Taiwan-mainland China relations, said the International Information Agency, Inc. on Thursday.

Ms. Lu closed the interview with a sincere pledge to the Chinese mainland to work toward putting their differences behind them, avoiding a costly and needless confrontation, and working cooperatively for the future development of both sides of the Taiwan Strait.

The interview provides additional information on the DPP's views concerning cross-strait relations, education, democracy, and US-ROC relations, and comes as a direct response to the many critical statements issued by Communist China about Mr. Lu, pointed out the agency.
"Ask Congress" is a 30-minute public affairs program hosted by Wolff and is aired in Washington, D.C. on Sundays at 10 a.m. It is also available on the PBS satellite network.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT REAFFIRMS DETERMINATION TO PURSUE CROSS-STRAIT PEACE

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian reaffirmed on Friday that everlasting peace in the Taiwan Strait should be a goal for both Taiwan and mainland China.

Speaking to Cardinal Paul Shan, Chen said: "War will beget more wars, it will create injustice and trample on the people's dignity," and added that the "pursuit of an everlasting peace will be the highest goal of rationality and the moral obligation of a national leader."
He expressed the hope that both sides will seek detente and cooperate with each other, and echoed Pope John Paul's appeal for armistice and peace which he made in his "millennium message."
Chen said he will learn from the humility of the pope, referring to the pontiff's practice of kissing the ground when he arrives in a new land.
Chen also said he will make "listening to three voices" as his principle -- meaning that he will heed the voice of the people, the voice of nature and the voice of dissidents.
As May 18 is the pope's 80th birthday, Chen also asked Shan to convey a letter of congratulation to the pope on his behalf and to ask the pope to pray for peace in the Taiwan Strait and the world.
In return, Shan conveyed a message from the pope which contained an appeal for the abrogation of the death penalty in Taiwan.
Chen said that although the abrogation of the death penalty is a world trend, he will leave the question to the legislature, out of respect for the legislative branch of the government.

But he also said that he would study whether the president has the right to exercise the right of amnesty for death row convicts such as the controversial case of the Hsichih trio, who were convicted of murder of a couple in 1995 but are still awaiting execution, in what is now widely regarded as having been a kangaroo court.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MINISTER PROMISES NEW LOOK MOTC (I)

TEXT.P: Yeh Chu-lan, a soft-spoken, feminine legislator, will soon become the Republic of China's first woman minister of transportation and communications.

Although some people have expressed doubts about her ability to head a ministry whose jurisdiction covers a wide variety of professional fields closely related to the public's everyday life, Yeh said she has full confidence in her own ability to fulfill her mission.

Yeh, a four-term legislator, said in a recent interview with CNA that "doing her utmost in her position" has been her top concern throughout her career. "Since I entered politics more than 11 years ago, I have carried out my duties as a popularly elected representative with devotion and passion."

When President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Premier-designate Tang Fei offered her the transportation minister post, Yeh said she asked herself whether she has the passion required to take up the responsibilities of the new challenge.

"Frankly speaking, I felt a bit hesitant at first, but later, a strong sense of mission prompted me to accept the offer," Yeh said, adding that she was touched by Chen's and Tang's sincere invitation to join their team to write a new chapter in Taiwan's history.

Yeh, 51, said her priority as head of the Ministry of Transportation and Communications (MOTC) will be helping its staff get rid of the heavy "old burdens" left over from the ousted Kuomintang government.

A stalwart of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), the country's main opposition party until Chen's March 18 election victory, Yeh said the MOTC has a lot of resources, commanding the second-largest share of the annual central government budget after the Ministry of National Defense.

"However, the majority of local people are not satisfied with the MOTC's performance, particularly with regard to the island's often-crowded and chaotic traffic conditions. I believe that the root cause lies in the old ruling party's inclination to put partisan considerations above national interests," Yeh said, adding that the practice has not only hurt MOTC staff morale, but has also hindered the exercise of their professional expertise.

Noting that the MOTC has large and varied professional teams, Yeh said she believes that the ministry will be able to improve its service and efficiency so long as its 100,000-plus staff members are given fair opportunities to perform professionally.

"I assure my future working partners at the MOTC that I will let professionalism prevail while assuming all the pressures and political responsibilities," Yeh said, adding: "I'm convinced that without the burden of entangled `patronage politics,' the productivity and work quality of the MOTC staff will be upgraded significantly."
Since the ultimate target of all MOTC services is the Taiwan public, the would-be minister said she will do her utmost to bring a humanist and delicate touch to MOTC work.

"My observation is that the MOTC is basically a mammoth service industry. All traffic construction projects, from railroads, highways, airports and harbors to telecommunications, tourist and meteorological facilities, are infrastructure constructions closely bound up with people's daily lives. Therefore, I'll ask MOTC staff at all levels to uphold a sense of mission, namely, to create the greatest possible satisfaction and happiness for the people of this country," Yeh explained.
The advertising executive-turned-politician went on to say that she hopes the MOTC will emerge with a new look within six months of her taking office.

"I hope all MOTC staff members will work even harder and take the initiative to improve their services so that our people will feel a bit different about the MOTC's performance in six months," Yeh said, adding she personally alone cannot make a difference in the ministry, and that she will need the assistance of all ministry employees.

Because many MOTC construction projects involve complicated business interests, Yeh said she will establish an open and transparent mechanism under which all companies will have fair and equal opportunities to compete and bid for construction contracts. (More)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW MINISTER PROMISES NEW LOOK MOTC (II)

TEXT.P: "I'll set clear, unequivocal game rules for all contract bidders and MOTC officials to follow, and fairness as well as transparency will be my cardinal principle in handling MOTC relations with business groups and industrial conglomerates," Yeh said, adding: "With definite rules and standards in place, there will be no room for corruption and other irregularities."

During her 12-year stint as a legislator, Yeh said she has won recognition for her capability and integrity. The minister-in-waiting attributed her ability to "resist temptation" throughout her political career partly to her late husband.

Yeh's husband, Cheng Nan-jung, was a pro-democracy activist who set himself afire in 1989 to protest the KMT's authoritarian rule and suppression of freedom of speech. Yeh said she is fully aware that if her political career is smeared, it would besmirch the name of her late husband. "This conviction has kept me from temptation," she said.

Yeh further said her years in the legislature have allowed her a deeper understanding of the expectations of the public. "Since the MOTC commands billions of dollars of public funds, I plan to let the public know where all the money goes, as well as reporting on the progress of every ongoing construction project."
To facilitate communication with the general public, Yeh said she will make the MOTC the first "e-ministry" under the incoming DPP government.
According to Yeh's plan, the MOTC will unveil all data concerning budget use and progress in each major infrastructure construction project on the ministry's website.

"Any member of the public is welcome to surf the MOTC website and express their opinions or ideas concerning the ministry's work or drawbacks and development plans," Yeh said, adding: "By so doing, we'll be able to narrow the gap between our policy and public demand."

Turning to the MOTC's future development policies, Yeh said that although the BOT (build-operate-transfer) scheme has caused some controversy in the bidding processes for the high-speed railway project between Taipei and Kaohsiung and the mass rapid transit system between Chiang Kai-shek International Airport and metropolitan Taipei, the ministry will continue encouraging private investment in massive-scale infrastructure construction projects under the BOT model.

"The BOT scheme will allow the government to bring in not only private capital but also vitality and efficiency to construction and operation of public transportation and communication facilities," she said.
As for the long-planned privatization of various public transport services, Yeh said privatization is a direction and a trend because it will help enhance competitiveness and efficiency.

"All privatization plans will continue to be carried out as scheduled. Nevertheless, as transport services are closely related to people's daily lives, we'll strengthen communication and coordination with employees of transport services facing privatization in the next couple of years," Yeh promised.

She also committed herself to continuing the existing policy of liberalizing telecommunication services, saying she believes in the private sector's vitality and ingenuity. "My belief is that what the private sector can do, the government need not do, and what the local government can do, the central government need not do."

Asked about her view on President-elect Chen's campaign promise to push for direct trade, mail and transportation links across the Taiwan Strait, Yeh said she does not have any personal bias concerning the issue.

"It is a critical issue. The new government must tackle the issue with the safety of the 23 million residents of this island as its top concern. As far as the `three links' are concerned, the MOTC is just an executive body, not a policy-making unit. Therefore, our task will be to prepare some enforcement plans or rules," Yeh said.

Touching on her expectations of her new role, Yeh said that as a political appointee, she will devote most of her energy to coordination and communication to ensure the MOTC runs smoothly. "My motto will be: `Insist on what I know I should,'" she added.

DOC.HEADLINE: UNIFICATION TIMETABLE NOT HELPFUL: MAC OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official in charge of Taiwan's mainland China policy said on Friday that the setting of a timetable for the unification of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait will not help, but hinder the unification process.

Lin Chong-pin, vice chairman of the Cabinet-level Mainland Affairs Council (MAC), said that if a timetable is needed, then it should be a timetable for the full democratization of the mainland, which he said is more urgent, and more important than the unification timetable.
Lin stressed that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should seek agreement on a basis of equal footing, and not one that allows one side to impose its will on the other.

He also appealed for the mainland to move toward the path of peace and a winning situation for all sides in the new millennium, instead of using the intimidation approach, saying that the two sides of the Taiwan Strait should "speak more nice words and do more nice things" to each other.

Referring to remarks on Thursday by Tang Shubei, one of the mainland's top negotiators with Taiwan, that "cross-strait talks are not talks between the central government and a local government, not talks between the government of the People's Republic of China and the Taiwan local authorities, but equal talks under the one China principle," Lin said that he will monitor developments closely.
But he cautioned that the nation needs to pay attention to whether Beijing is saying one thing to Taiwan and another to the international community.
Lin said the MAC noted long ago that there is a gap between Beijing's statement on the interpretation of "one China" in the United States and its statement to Taiwan.

Lin claimed the calls for Taiwan independence are actually prompted by the mainland, saying that a long-term MAC survey shows that the rhetoric for Taiwan independence invariably heated up after the Tiananmen massacre, the Thousand Island tragedy, and the death of Taiwan councilwoman Lin Ti-chuan in the mainland.

The MAC, which has conducted the survey since 1997, has found that the ratio of those who say they are both Taiwanese and Chinese to those who say they are Taiwanese were roughly the same until after Lin's death and mainland China's military intimidation, when the number of those who say they are Taiwanese outstripped the number of those who say they consider themselves both Taiwanese and Chinese.

Lin also said the March 18 presidential election was a watershed in cross-strait relations, noting that although Beijing toned down its rhetoric against President-elect Chen Shui-bian of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party, cross-strait relations still have not gone back on track.

On former US Defense Secretary William Perry's words that the mainland had stepped up deployment of missiles aimed at Taiwan and that US reconnaissance planes have been intercepted by mainland planes over the East China Sea, Lin said Taiwan will pay attention to the information, and make an overall assessment of the situation.
He said that Beijing will continue to use all possible channels to apply pressure on Taiwan, and that Taiwan will continue to pay close attention.

But Lin also stressed that Taiwan will not only focus on military information, but will also monitor the political and economic situation in the mainland, as well as the attitude of the United States, Europe and Japan.

DOC.HEADLINE: TIER HEAD NOT TO ATTEND APEC MEETING IN PROTEST OVER BEIJING

TEXT.P: Wu Jung-yi, director of the Taiwan Institute of Economic Research (TIER), said on Friday that he might not attend a preparatory meeting of the Asia Pacific Economic Cooperation (APEC) forum to be held in Shanghai in May.
Wu said he is considering boycotting the meeting in protest against Beijing's attempt to lower Taiwan's status at the meeting.

Mainland China will sponsor an APEC meeting next year, and will hold the preparatory meeting from May 8-10. However, the invitation omitted the word "Taiwan" from the official TIER title -- the first time this has happened, according to Wu.

In past years, the representatives of Taiwan and mainland China have exchanged fire many times at APEC meetings. Last year at an APEC meeting in New Zealand, the Beijing delegation pressured the ROC delegation led by P.K. Chiang, chairman of the Council for Economic Planning and Development. Chiang and Wu both publicly refuted Beijing's pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: US OFFICIALS `ENCOURAGED' BY DEVELOPMENTS IN TAIPEI-BEIJING TIES
DOC.DATELINE: Washington, April 27 (CNA) (By Jay Chen & Maubo Chang)

TEXT.P: Washington is watching Taipei-Beijing ties closely and is encouraged by the present situation, Under Secretary of State for Political Affairs Thomas R. Pickering said on Thursday.
Pickering told a group of Taiwan journalists posted in Washington that Washington hopes the situation "can lead to ... a dialogue."
He made the statement one day after the Taiwan stock market nose-dived to the year's low over jitters about Beijing's military drills.

But he refused to answer questions on whether Beijing is to stage a military exercise on the eve of the May 20 inauguration of President-elect Chen Shui-bian or whether there are unusual movements of the People's Liberation Army, telling the reporters: "You're treading into an area where I don't make comments."
Pickering said he has no specific expectations for Chen's inaugural speech, saying: "That is very much his decision to make."
But, he stressed: "We hope it continues to follow very much in the path of the statements that he has made since his election."

He also steered clear of the dispute between Taiwan and mainland China over Beijing's insistence on the "one China" principle as a prerequisite to cross-strait talks, saying only that the US position with respect to "one China" is well known, and that Washington hopes Taipei and Beijing will find a way to talk.

DOC.HEADLINE: EVA AIR, QUANTAS TO JOINTLY OPERATE TAIWAN-AUSTRALIA ROUTES

TEXT.P: Eva Airways of Taiwan and Qantas of Australia will jointly operate flights on the Taipei-Sydney and Taipei-Brisbane routes beginning May 2, an Eva Air official announced on Friday.
A ceremony jointly sponsored by Eva Air and Qantas was held on Friday afternoon to mark the flight routes' inauguration.

Qantas enjoys one of the best flight safety records in the world, the Eva official pointed out, adding that Australia has become attractive as both a tourist destination and investment market for Taiwan travelers. Through the new cooperation agreement, the two airlines will be able to provide more service to both Taiwan and Australian visitors, the official said.
The Taipei-Sydney route will maintain three Boeing 767-300 flights per week, on Tuesdays, Wednesdays and Fridays.

McDonnell Douglas MD-11 jets will be used on the Taipei-Brisbane route, which will also feature three flights a week. From Taipei, flights will be on Wednesdays, Fridays and Sundays; and from Brisbane, flights are scheduled for Mondays, Thursdays and Fridays from Brisbane.

The Australian Tourism Bureau's representative in Taiwan said that Taiwan travelers visited Australia a total of 147,000 times last year. Total visits from Taiwan ranked third only behind Japan and Singapore, he said, adding that he hopes that visits from Taiwan will increase by 200,000 annually for the next five years.

DOC.HEADLINE: VALIDITY OF ROC PASSPORTS EXTENDED TO 10 YEARS

TEXT.P: The Legislative Yuan on Friday passed an amendment to the Passport Law which extends the term of validity of Republic of China passports from the present six years to 10 years.
The amendment also states that passport forgery will be subject to a maximum prison term of five years and a fine of up to NT$500,000 (US$16,000).
The move to extend the term of validity of passports has been designed to provide more convenience to passport holders and to streamline the efficiency of the issuing authorities.

DOC.HEADLINE: ISSUE OF FOREIGN LABORERS INCLUDED IN BASIC WAGE PROTECTION DEBATED

TEXT.P: The minimum wage guarantee for foreign laborers was the focus of debate in a public hearing on Friday.

The public hearing was called by legislators Yang Chiu-hsing and LiI Ching-lin of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP). Yang strongly urged that foreign laborers be excluded from the basic wage protection to help curb the mass inflow of foreign workers so as to protect the rights of domestic laborers.

Yang noted that domestic foreign laborers in Taiwan have approached nearly 300,000, saying the large number can be attributed to the fact that they have enjoyed the basic wage of the ROC nationals of NT$15,840 (US$490) per month, or the highest monthly pay among Asian countries.

This has squeezed the job market in Taiwan, Yang said, adding that unemployment is at nearly 3 percent, with a total of 280,000 jobless workers. Unemployment among aborigines is even higher, at 7.75 percent.

But some labor officials and organizations opposed Yang's views, saying that scrapping the basic wage for foreign laborers will not help raise employment among domestic workers. Elimination of the minimum wage would only force foreign laborers to work extra hours, they said. They added that foreign workers usually have to pay a substantial brokerage fee.

Hung Juei-ching, a Council of Labor Affairs official, said that the implementation of a minimum wage has no effect on real wages for domestic workers, because real wages depend on the demand for labor. In Taiwan's booming economy, the average wage for all industries is about 2.2 times higher than the basic wage.

He stressed that other nations have adopted standard labor laws for workers of all nationalities, and Taiwan should follow the international norm if it wishes to be considered a member of the world community.
He said that if Taiwan's law treats foreign laborers differently from domestic workers, efforts to enter the World Trade Organization will be impeded and Taiwan's national image will be damaged.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC OFFERS PROPOSAL TO END CROSS-STRAIT STALEMATE

TEXT.P: The current stalemate between Taipei and Beijing over "one China" could be resolved by President-elect Chen Shui-bian in his May 20 inauguration speech, according to the head of Taiwan's cross-strait policy-making body.
Mainland Affairs Council (MAC) Chairman Su Chi said Chen could suggest that both sides should adhere to the "1992 consensus."

Su made the suggestion in a speech he delivered on Friday at a seminar jointly sponsored by the Chinese Europe-Asia Educational Foundation and National Sun Yat-Sen University titled "The Development of Taiwan and Cross-Strait Relations in the 21st Century."
During his address, Su urged both Chen's new administration and the Beijing authorities to be "ambiguous" in handling the "One China" issue.
Su said that currently there are four interpretations of what constitutes "One China."

They are: Beijing's version that there is only one China, of which Taiwan is a part; the Kuomintang's version that one China is a historical, cultural and geographic concept which is currently divided, but will be reunified in the future; Chen's version that one China is a topic for discussion, not a prerequisite for talks; and Washington's version of one China.

The "One China, with each side free to express their interpretation" formula was once the best way in dealing with the "One China" issue, said Su. It was agreed between Taipei's Strait Exchange Foundation and Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait in 1992's groundbreaking cross-strait talks.
However, he also noted, that the formula has now been denied and dismissed by Beijing as simply Taipei's interpretation of the consensus, not Beijing's understanding of it.

Su went a step further, pointing out that in the face of this dilemma, the best thing the incoming president could do is try to be ambiguous on the sensitive issue by deliberately trying not to give any precise definition to the consensus.
This, he concluded, would be tantamount to "one consensus, free interpretations," which may be beneficial to a cross-strait breakthrough.

DOC.HEADLINE: SYMPOSIUM ON TAIWAN'S DEVELOPMENT AND CROSS-STRAIT TIES OPENS

TEXT.P: A two-day symposium on Taiwan's development and cross-Taiwan Strait relations in the 21st century opened in Taipei on Friday, under the joint sponsorship of the Chinese Euro-Asian Educational Foundation and National Sun Yat-sen University.

Tseng Yung-hsien, vice chairman of the educational foundation, said that building an Asia-Pacific collective security mechanism has become an urgent issue, as the world closely watches the situation across the Taiwan Strait in the wake of the March 18 presidential election.
He said that the use of force cannot resolve political differences, and added that only through a continuous dialogue can the two sides resolve their differences and increase mutual understanding.
Council for Economic Planning and Development Chairman P.K. Chiang told the symposium that the island's economy will continue to expand in line with worldwide economic growth.
He forecasted that Taiwan's real growth rate this year will surpass six percent.
Mainland Affairs Council Chairman Su Chi blamed Beijing's move to narrow the definition of the "one China" principle for the current deadlock in cross-strait relations.
He said that allowing both sides to make respective interpretations of the "one China" principle will be an effective way to break the stalemate.
The symposium has brought together Chinese and foreign experts from Taiwan, the United States, South Korea, Hong Kong, and Britain.

DOC.HEADLINE: LEE'S JAPAN TRIP MAY BE REALIZED ONLY AFTER THIS FALL

TEXT.P: Outgoing President Lee Teng-hui may be able to travel to Japan, but not until after November this year at the earliest, said Lin Chin-ching, chairman of the Association of East Asian Relations, on Friday.
Lin made the remarks in response to the plan of some Japanese parliamentarians to invite Lee to visit Japan after he steps down as president on May 20.

Lin said that Japan will witness a busy political schedule in the coming months. Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori will dissolve the House of Representatives in May to hold a general election, and Japan will host the annual summit of industrial countries in Okinawa this summer.
With such a packed political schedule in the prospective host country, he noted that if Lee wants to visit Japan, he will have to wait until November at the earliest.
Meanwhile, a nine-member delegation from the Japan-Republic of China Parliamentarians' Council arrived in Taipei on Friday night.

Led by former Labor Minister Masakuni Murakami, the delegation will visit Lee, President-elect Chen Shui-bian, Democratic Progressive Party Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung, Examination Yuan President Hsu Shui-teh, Foreign Minister-to-be Tien Hung-mao and Chen's Senior Presidential Advisor Lee Yuan-tseh.

DOC.HEADLINE: INVESTIGATIVE BUREAU DENIES INVESTIGATION INTO SHADY LOANS

TEXT.P: The Investigative Bureau (IB) denied on Friday that it is mounting a sweeping investigation into irregular loans extended by financial institutions to shoddy firms.

Ko Chun-jen, director of the Economic Crime Prevention Center under the IB, said that his division has not stopped any inquiries into economic crimes but there is currently no sweeping clean-up operation.

Ko was responding to a report in Friday's China Times Express that the IB has been asked by the Ministry of Finance to start a criminal investigation into irregular loans extended by state-run and private banks to shady firms.
The MOF had transferred to the IB evidence of the suspicious deals that it found during a special financial inspection earlier this week, according to the report.

Ko said he was mystified by the newspaper's report, and did not know of any sweeping financial clean-up operation. He added that the IB has no plans to inspect the operation of the island's banks to crack down on irregularities.
He said his division will not overstep its authority by conducting inspections on financial institutions, which falls under the MOF's jurisdiction.

Another IB official said on condition of anonymity that even if there was such a campaign, it would be carried out secretly, so that the target institutions would have no time to conceal evidence of irregularities and obstruct the investigation.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT IS CONFIDENT OF IMPROVING CROSS-STRAIT TIES

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian said in Taichung on Friday that he is confident that he will be able to break the current stalemate in cross-Taiwan Strait relations after he assumes the presidency on May 20.
He made the remarks while meeting hundreds of supporters at the Fengyuan Municipal Stadium, Taichung County, to extend his appreciation for their support in the March 18 presidential election.

He told the gathering that he is determined to pursue everlasting peace across the Taiwan Strait, and will handle the issue with a spirit of love and confidence, without resorting to "eye for an eye" tactics.
In the coming four years as president, Chen stressed that he will devote his life to the land with an unconditional "spirit of big love."
He said he will follow the example of the Pope, and will accommodate the voices of the people and pay attention to environmental protection, while acting to avoiding the occurrence of war.

Chen pledged that as the president of the 23 million people on the island, he will firmly insist on Taiwan's sovereignty, security and dignity. He added that he will not allow military conflict to occur across the Taiwan Strait during his tenure in office.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN SNUBS BEIJING'S CLAIMS OF TALKS ON EQUAL-FOOTING WITH TAIWAN

TEXT.P: A Beijing official's advocacy of talks with Taiwan on equal footing under the principle of "one China" drew fire from Taiwan on Friday.

Tang Shubei, vice chairman of Beijing's Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, told a symposium staged in Shenzhen for the purpose of promoting reunification and preventing Taiwan independence that Beijing would not characterize the dialogue between Beijing and Taipei as one between a central and a local government.
Instead, Taiwan and mainland China would be "equal" in the talks, which would be held under the principle that there is only "one China", said Tang.

Su Chi, chairman of the Mainland Affairs Council, dismissed Tang's remarks as self-contradictory, because the "one China" policy demanded by Beijing as a prerequisite to dialogue with Taiwan is "unequal in nature".
"Mainland China has often gone the extra mile, both at the negotiating table and on the international stage, to leave a false perception of inequality between the two sides," complained Su.
Meanwhile, Chang Jung-kong, director-general of the Mainland Affairs Research Department under the Kuomintang , played down Tang's statement as "nothing new."
"It is an old trick to downgrade Taiwan into an unequal position through a false form of equality," said the KMT ideology guru.
"Given Beijing's formula of 'one country, two systems' for national reunification, the final goal it pursues is to annex Taiwan as one of its provinces. That is unequal in our point of view."

Having not past over the chance for a dig at the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP), Chang criticized the former opposition party for fumbling in vain for a cross-strait strategy after being swept into power in the March 18 election.

After lambasting the National Reunification Guidelines, which had been crafted by the KMT for so many years, the DPP has nothing but the same guidelines to ward off Beijing's pressure for political talks, said Chang.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:

The Central Daily News:

The China Post:
Government takes over troubled Chung Shing Bank.
The Taiwan News:
Deposit Insurance Corp. takes over Chung Shing Bank.
The Taipei Times:
