DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN STOCK PRICES DOWN BY 47.01 POINTS

TEXT.P: The Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) lost ground on Saturday, with the benchmark-weighted price index moving down 47.01 points to close at 8,777.35.
Market turnover amounted to NT$138.95 billion (US$4.54 billion).

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI STOCK MARKET

TEXT.P: Shares prices opened high but closed lower on the Taiwan Stock Exchange (TAIEX) on Saturday, with the weighted index, the market's key barometer, moving down 47.01 points to close at 8,777.35.
Due to the lack of confidence of investors, the bourse opened at 8,835.17 and fluctuated between 8,906.67 and 8,725.38 during trading.

A total of 2.13 billion shares changed hands on a market turnover of NT$138.95 billion (US$4.54 billion), a decrease from the previous trading session which saw 2.51 billion stocks change hands on a market turnover of NT$168.69 billion.
Losers outnumbered gainers 341 to 178, with 79 stocks remaining unchanged.
Of the eight major categories, only two posted gains, with construction stocks moving up the most at 1.9 percent, followed by bank and insurance shares at 0.1 percent.

Other major categories lost ground, with pulp and paper issues moving down the most at 3.4 percent, followed by cement shares at 1.4 percent, plastics and chemical stocks at 1.3 percent, textile issues and foodstuff shares, both at 1.1 percent, and electrical stocks at 0.5 percent. (BY Ben Wu)

DOC.HEADLINE: PRICES DOWN ON TAIPEI FUTURES MARKET

TEXT.P: Prices on Taipei's stock index futures market reported negative results on Saturday when the Taiwan Stock Exchange Capitalization Weighted Index Futures for May moved down 22 points to close at 8,828, with 3,126 contract transactions.

TAIEX Index Futures for June decreased 80 points to finish at 8,825, with 102 contract transactions; September futures lost 21 points to close at 9,048, with eight contract transactions; and December futures moved down 10 points to finish at 9,250, with two contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for next March futures.

Taiwan International Mercantile Exchange reference levels for TAIEX Index Futures trading on Saturday were: 8,850 for May; 8,905 for June; 9,069 for September; 9,260 for December; and 9,495 for next March.
Electronics (TE) futures and financial (TF) futures, which are sub-index futures based on Taiwan Stock Exchange-listed electronics shares and financial shares, reported mixed results.
May TE futures moved down 3.40 points to close at 494.60, with 1,256 contract transaction, while June TE futures decreased 8.10 points to finish at 495, with 15 contract transactions.
No transactions were reported for other months.
May TF futures increased 3.0 points to close at 858, with 363 contract transactions.
No transactions were recorded for other months.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Saturday, April 29, or the 25th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1429: French military leader and heroine Joan of Arc enters Orleans, France, and defeats English forces. She was later tried for heresy and sorcery and was burned at the stake in Rouen.
1661: Cheng Cheng-kung, also known as Koxinga, a national hero and one of the Ming loyalists and resistance fighters against foreign invasion, claims Taiwan from the Dutch and chooses Anping (present-day Tainan) as his capital, in the hope of returning to mainland China one day to restore the Ming dynasty.
1667: John Arbuthnot, Scottish physician and writer, is born. He was noted for his satirical anti-Whig pamphlets published as "Law Is a Bottomless Pit" (1712) and later retitled "The History of John Bull."
1769: Arthur Wellesley, Duke of Wellington, English soldier and later the prime minister known as the Iron Duke, is born. He defeated Napoleon at Waterloo.
1818: Alexander II, the czar of Russia who emancipated the serfs in 1861, is born. He was assassinated in 1881 after severe repression of political opposition.
1863: William Randolph Hearst, American newspaper and magazine publisher, is born. Beginning with the San Francisco Examiner in 1887, he built the world's largest publishing empire, comprising 28 major newspapers.
1885: Due to the efforts of Emily Davies, the guiding force behind a committee dedicated to securing higher education for women, Oxford University decides to allow women to sit college examinations, but not to award them degrees.
1901: Hirohito, the Japanese emperor who advocated the country's unconditional surrender that ended World War II, is born. He renounced his divine status in 1946.
1903: After Russia refuses to leave Manchuria when the troops of other foreign powers withdraw from Chinese territory, and prior to the outbreak of the Russo-Japanese War, Chinese students studying in Japan meet in Tokyo and set up a "Resist Russia" volunteer corps.
1937: American chemist Wallace Hume Carothers commits suicide just two months after he patented nylon.
1942: Japanese troops capture the Burmese town of Lashio, cutting off the Burma Road between China and India.
1945: US forces in Germany liberate 32,000 victims of the Nazi concentration camp at Dachau, just northwest of Munich.
1946: Former Japanese leaders are indicted in Tokyo as war criminals.
1948: Li Tsung-jen is elected vice president of the Republic of China in the republic's fourth ballot.
1957: The first nuclear reactor goes into operation in the United States.
1969: Hsu Peh-yuen, governor of the Central Bank of China, is released from office and succeeded by Yu Kuo-hwa, who is concurrently minister of finance.
1975: The last US troops are evacuated from Saigon as thousands of foreigners and South Vietnamese are ferried out by helicopter from the roof of the American embassy.
1976: Edward Y. Kuan, ROC vice minister of foreign affairs, is named by the Executive Yuan as first ambassador to South Africa.
1976: The Sino-US Seminar on Food Science and Nutrition opens in Taipei with 24 food scientists attending.
1980: Alfred Hitchcock, the British-born film director and the screen's master of suspense, dies in Los Angeles at the age of 80.
1985: The space shuttle Challenger is launched, and Dr. Wang Kan-chuen becomes the first Chinese American astronaut in space.
1991: Earthquake rocks Soviet Georgia, killing more than 140 people.
1992: Bolivian Vice President Luis Ossio Sanjines officiates at the inauguration of the Bolivian Commercial and Financial Representative Office in Taipei.
1992: A jury in California acquits four policemen charged with beating a black driver, setting off three days of riots in Los Angeles which spread to various other places in the United States.
1993: Representatives of the Straits Exchange Foundation (SEF) and its mainland counterpart, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait, sign three agreements and a joint accord at a historic meeting in Singapore; the agreements and accord went into effect on May 29.
1994: A Kenyan ferry capsizes near Mombasa, killing 300 passengers.
1996: A worker guns down 35 tourists near the ruins of an Australian colonial prison in Tasmania.
1996: On the third anniversary of the Koo-Wang cross-strait talks, SEF Chairman Koo Chen-fu appeals to mainland China not to postpone the second round of talks so that both sides can resume their pursuit of reunification.

DOC.HEADLINE: CROSS-STRAIT IMPROVEMENTS NOT LIKELY IN SHORT TERM: KMT OFFICIAL
DOC.DATELINE: London, April 28 (CNA) (By Mark Ou and Lilian Wu)

TEXT.P: An official of the Republic of China's outgoing Kuomintang government said here that although ROC President-elect Chen Shui-bian is keen on improving cross-Taiwan Strait relations, he did not see this happening in the near future.

Jason Hu, director of the KMT's Department of Cultural Affairs, made the remarks on Friday while speaking at an annual meeting of Taiwanese businesspeople in Europe on the topic of Taiwan's situation in the wake of March 18 presidential election.

Hu noted that the impasse in cross-strait dialogue and mainland China's mistrust of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party's Chen won't change in one day, saying that he did not see how cross-strait tensions could be reversed all at once.

In his first public speech since the KMT lost the presidential election, Hu said a breakthrough in the current impasse won't occur between Chen's inauguration in May and the month of August, and probably not even before December.

The conciliatory gestures by Chen after his election victory will not have an instant effect, Hu said, adding that mainland China will also have to make some adjustments. Although there is a chance for this in the long term, the short term prospects aren't so bright, he said.

Hu said that the 22 million people living on Taiwan will not accept Beijing's claim that "one China" means the People's Republic of China, adding that Taiwan-independence rhetoric on the island will tone down as its democracy matures.
Chen's government will also not promote Taiwan's independence, and the mainland should not use Chen's past stance and rhetoric as a basis for acting against the 22 million people on Taiwan, Hu said.
Hu reiterated that the KMT hopes for the resumption of cross-strait talks and eventual peace, saying this would be a win-win situation for both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
Jao Eng-chi, vice president of the ROC's Legislative Yuan, also said that the KMT will support Chen on cross-strait relations in the KMT-dominated legislature.

The two KMT heavyweights stressed that the KMT will play the role of a real opposition party in the legislature by monitoring the new government's performance and will wait for a comeback in the next election.

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW CABINET LINEUP RECEIVES 67% APPROVAL RATING: POLL

TEXT.P: The new Cabinet put together by President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Premier-designate Tang Fei has received the approval of 67 percent of the people, according to a survey released on Saturday.

The poll, conducted by Gallop Taiwan for New Party Legislator Chen Lung-shui, gave Tang Fei the highest approval rating among all the members of the new Cabinet at 82.7 percent. He was followed by the interior minister-to-be, Chang Po-ya, at 76.9 percent; the justice minister-to-be, Chen Ding-nan, at 70.1 percent; and the chairwoman of the Council of Labor Affairs, Chen Chu, at 66.8 percent.

President-elect Chen Shui-bian's performance since the March 18 election received the approval of 81.2 percent of the respondents, although he is still 20 days away from being inaugurated as the new president.

Vice President-elect Annette Lu's popularity among those surveyed lagged far behind, with only 36.8 percent favoring her performance. Moreover, 48.2 percent said they are worried that Lu might turn out to be a political liability rather than an asset for Chen during his presidency.
The survey, carried out between April 24-27 among 1,110 adults islandwide, has a margin of error of 3 percent, according to its author.

DOC.HEADLINE: TANG CHECKS OUT OF HOSPITAL, ANNOUNCES MORE CABINET APPOINTMENTS

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Tang Fei checked out of Taipei Veterans General Hospital after fully recovering from surgery removing a benign thymoma on April 16.
Appearing at a press conference at the hospital, a smiling Tang expressed his thanks for the sympathy shown by his fellow countrymen and the care he received at Veterans General Hospital.

Accompanied by his future deputy premier, Yu Hsi-kun, the secretary-general of the Executive Yuan, Wei Chi-lin, and the director general of Government Information Office, Ching Chung, Tang announced two more appointments to the new Cabinet.

Lin Chun-Yi, a professor at Tunghai University, Taichung and the former director of the Environmental Protection Bureau under the Taiwan City Government, will become the new administrator of the Environmental Protection Administration, said Tang.
Hsu Yi-hsiung, a professor of physical education at National Taiwan Normal University has been chosen as the new head of the National Sports Council.
The new heads of the Department of Health, the Council for Economic Planning and Development, and the Atomic Energy Council have still not been chosen but will be before May 1, said Tang.
He denied reports that he was frustrated because President-elect Chen Shui-bian has not consulted with him fully before choosing many of the new Cabinet members.

DOC.HEADLINE: E. ASIA AGAIN SEEN AS WORLD'S FASTEST GROWING REGION

TEXT.P: East Asia has again become the world's fastest-growing region after a two-year interim in the wake of the Asian financial crisis, the Australian Financial Review reported on Saturday.
The economic recovery is real and such growth will continue this year and next, the report quoted the Asian Development Bank and the International Monetary Fund as saying.

Meanwhile, Australia's Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade noted that Australia is the chief beneficiary of the economic recovery as its exports to East Asia are booming with growth running at a rate three times higher than its exports to the rest of the world.

DOC.HEADLINE: DOPING EXPECTED TO BE WIDESPREAD AT OLYMPICS: REPORT

TEXT.P: A large number of Olympic athletes are expected to use banned performance enhancing drugs during the 2000 Olympic Games in Sydney this September, according to a report by Olympic security officers.

The report, revealed by the Australian on Friday, has remained confidential since being drafted last June. It warned that the drug controversies would damage the reputation of the Sydney Organizing Committee for Olympic Games, while severely diminishing social, economic and political returns and disillusioning athletes.
The report rated the impact of "doping hazards" in the high-risk category, saying they would "probably occur during each day of the Olympic Games."

More than 10,000 athletes from over 100 countries are expected to compete from the middle of September. The report recommends that pre-Games, out of competition testing, be made on competing athletes in order to reduce the number of athletes competing using banned substances.

But the Australian Olympic Committee's secretary general, Craig McLatchey, admitted that one key recommendation -- that a reliable blood test for human growth hormone (hGH) be established -- was unlikely to be met, the daily reported.

DOC.HEADLINE: EIGHT CHINESE SNAKEHEADS APPEAR BEFORE B.C. COURT

TEXT.P: Eight mainland Chinese nationals made their first appearances in the British Columbia Supreme Court Thursday on charges of smuggling people into Canada.
The charges relate to the arrival on the West Coast last August of two of the four ships intercepted by Canadian authorities carrying illegal migrants from Fujian province in China.

Canadian police said the eight men were enforcers or organizers aboard the ships. One of the alleged organizers, or "snakeheads," appeared in person before the court while the other seven took in the proceedings via electronic link-up from a jail in Prince George, B.C.
All eight are also involved in immigration procedures and a bail hearing is set for May 12 in Vancouver.
About 600 Chinese migrants arrived off the B.C. coast in four ships last summer. Most were seeking refugee status in Canada, but some have disappeared after being freed to await their hearings.

The others are being held in custody while their claims are processed. Some were ordered deported after their applications were rejected, but only a few have gone home because China has been slow in providing needed travel documents, officials said.

DOC.HEADLINE: MAC CHIEF URGES RETURN TO `ONE CHINA' AGREEMENT OF 1992

TEXT.P: Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with mainland China, on Saturday urged both sides of the Taiwan Strait to return to the agreement reached in 1992 where each side is allowed to interpret the definition of "one China."

Koo, the chairman of the semi-official Straits Exchange Foundation, made the remarks on the seventh anniversary of the first high-level cross-strait talks held between himself and his mainland counterpart Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Strait (ARATS), in Singapore in 1993.

Koo recalled that the SEF and ARATS, authorized to represent their respective governments, held the ground-breaking talks after nearly five decades of no high-level meetings between the two sides and reached several agreements on institutionalized contacts, establishing a framework for future exchanges and dialogue.
He said the 1993 talks were possible because negotiators from both sides had reached an agreement the previous year allowing for different interpretations of what "one China" meant.
Koo said the current cross-strait tensions requires a renewal of direct communication between the two sides on an equal footing and without prerequisites.
He said both sides should shelve their dispute over the definition of "one China" and try to solve the problems resulting from cross-strait exchanges in a pragmatic manner.
He reiterated that only if each side is allowed to interpret the definition of "one China" can the present impasse be broken.

Noting that the 1993 talks opened a new era of hope in the peaceful development of cross-strait relations, Koo said he regrets the fact that the long-awaited second round of talks between himself and Wang still have not taken place.

Koo also lamented the fact that the agreements reached in 1993 in his talks with Wang have still not been carried out, resulting in missed opportunities for the two sides to establish mutual trust and a delay in solving the problems related to people living on both sides of the Taiwan Strait.
He said a renewal of talks between himself and Wang would be an opportunity to solve cross-strait differences, adding that he hopes a meeting can take place soon, no matter what the location or time.

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN SHOULD NOT APPEASE BEIJING IN INAUGURATION SPEECH: POLL

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian should not try to ingratiate himself with mainland China by identifying with Beijing's interpretation of "one China" in his inauguration speech on May 20, according to a poll released on Saturday.

The poll, conducted by Gallop Taiwan at the commission of Legislator Cheng Lung-shui of the New Party, found that 39.5 percent of the respondents do not feel Chen should identify with Beijing's interpretation in order to stave off pressure from mainland China.
Some 33.2 percent said they think Chen should do so, while 27.2 percent of those polled had no definite answer to the question.

Beijing insists that there is only one China and that Taiwan is a part of it, while Taipei maintains that one China is a historical, cultural and geographic concept, and that it is presently divided, but will be reunified in the future.

On whether the mainland China will accept with goodwill Chen as the president of the Republic of China over the next four years, some 43.2 percent of those surveyed said it is "possible," while 24.7 percent said it is "impossible," and 32.1 percent said they had no answer to the question.

Mainland China sternly warned Taiwanese citizens against electing Chen of the pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party prior to the election and has only recently toned down its verbal attacks on him after his election victory.

Some 44.1 percent of those polled also said that Chen will continue President Lee Teng-hui's line on "special state-to-state" cross-strait relations, while 27.1 percent said he won't, and 28.7 percent said that it is "hard to say."
President Lee voiced the two states theory on the cross-strait situation in July 1999, resulting in angry responses from the mainland.

Of those surveyed, up to 60.1 percent said that Chen is unlikely to promote Taiwan's independence during his four year term, while only 17 percent said it is possible, and 22.9 percent said they aren't sure.

Some 56.8 percent of the respondents said they feel that cross-strait tensions could ease over the next four years, 13.9 percent said that there could be conflicts, and 29.3 percent said that the question is hard to answer.
The survey, carried out between April 24-27 among 1,110 adults islandwide, has a margin of error of 3 percent.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT PROMISES NOT TO MAKE TROUBLE IN INAUGURATION SPEECH

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian promised not to add tension to the already strained ties between Taiwan and mainland China in his inauguration speech on May 20.

He tried, however, to lower the expectation that he would solve, once and for all, the problems between Taiwan and mainland in his speech, saying it is unrealistic to expect him to solve a problem which dates back five decades and has lingered through the rules of his four predecessors.

Speaking at a forum staged by National Taiwan University on the expectations for the upcoming administration, Chen said improvements in ties between Taipei and Beijing depend on the efforts of both sides to reach out to each other.

Although he has suggested that he would not embrace Beijing's version of the "one China" principle, namely that there is only one China and Taiwan is a part of it, Chen promised to display a willingness to work toward improving ties with the mainland in good faith and to seek reconciliation, cooperation, and peace with mainland China in his inauguration speech.
Beijing suspended all contacts with Taiwan after President Lee Teng-hui in July, 1999 characterized Taiwan's ties with mainland China as a special state-to-state relationship.

Blaming Lee for the alleged deviation from the "one China" consensus upon which bilateral ties were based, Beijing has insisted on Taiwan's reconfirmation of its commitment to this principle as a condition for further talks on bettering ties and has made it known that it expects Chen to declare this in his inauguration speech.
As an advocate of Taiwanese independence, Chen bridled at Beijing's suggestion despite his keen desire to foster friendship with mainland China.

Public opinion seems to be divided on the issue, with some elder statesmen such as Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Straits Exchange Foundation, and Hsu Li-lung, a leader of the New Party, strongly urging the new leader to once again pick up the "one China" policy based on Tawian's interpretation, while about 40 percent of the public said in a recent poll that Chen should not bow to Beijing's pressure.

DOC.HEADLINE: VICE PREMIER-DESIGNATE TALKS ABOUT `ONE CHINA' PRINCIPLE

TEXT.P: The "One China" principle being advocated by the Beijing authorities must have the consent of the people of Taiwan in order to work and cannot be imposed by any single political party or leader from above, said an official of the incoming Republic of China government on Saturday.

Yu Shyi-kun, the vice premier-designate of the new administration under President-elect Chen Shui-bian, made the remark while making an address at a seminar sponsored by the Taiwan Research Institute titled "Taiwan Strait Security and Challenges to the New Administration."

Yu, who is also secretary-general of the Democratic Progressive Party, said the new government will attach particular importance to good relations with mainland China. From the geopolitical standpoint, the proximity of Taiwan and mainland China to each other means peaceful co-existence is be beneficial to each side's development, while fighting a war would be disastrous, he noted.
Beijing's insistence on sticking to the principle of "One China" will hardly win the consensus of all the people on the island, the vice premier-designate stressed.

He said the sensitive political issue of cross-strait relations should be handled in a serious and cautious manner, adding that if the differences between them and are too difficult to resolve by this generation, we should believe that our children will be wiser and more capable of resolving them once and for all. By this he was urging both sides to be patient about the process.

Peace has been listed as the top priority of the new administration, Yu pointed out, saying that the Chen administration will promote cross-strait relations in a rational manner based on the principles of "reconciliation through goodwill; active cooperation; and perseverance in the pursuit of peace," as the president-elect has advocated.

In response to Beijing's "pinning hope on the people of Taiwan to resolve the Taiwan issue," the new ROC administration will base its rule on the consent of the people concerning how it deals with issues like cross-strait relations, foreign relations, and national security, Yu concluded.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT-ELECT ASKS COLLEGE PRESIDENT TO HEAD HEALTH DEPARTMENT

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian on Saturday succeeded in persuading Lee Ming-liang, president of the Hualien-based Tzu Chi College of Medical Science, Humanities and Sociology, to head the Department of Health (DOH) in the new government.
Before meeting with Lee, Chen conferred with Master Shih Cheng Yen founder of the Tzu Chi Compassion Relief Association, to seek her approval in allowing Lee to serve in the government.
The Republic of China president-elect said that Shih Cheng Yen agreed to his request by saying that "the health of the people is the foundation of the country."
Later Chen met with the 65-year-old Lee and obtained Lee's agreement to serve as DOH director-general.
Lee told the media that he expects to assume the post with happiness and to leave the post with happiness too when his term expires.
Regarding the financial difficulties the public health insurance plan is facing, Lee said that Chen has promised to lend his support on this issue.
The American-educated physician-scholar said that he will relinquish his American citizenship before formally assuming the Cabinet post on May 20.

DOC.HEADLINE: US SHOULD NOT GRANT PNTR STATUS TO CHINA: WEI JINGSHENG

TEXT.P: Wei Jingsheng, a prominent mainland Chinese dissident living in the United States, said here Thursday that the US should neither grant permanent normal trade relations (PNTR) status to China nor support it's bid to join the World Trade Organization (WTO).

He said China is not ready to accept the free market system. The interests of American people would be hurt and the jobless rate in the US would rise, if China were granted PNTR status and admitted to the WTO too soon, he added.

Wei, who had been imprisoned for 18 years in China before being released on a medical parole in Nov. 1997, said Beijing's trade and human rights violation records should be reviewed by members of the House of Representatives before they vote in late May on measures that would give Beijing PNTR status.
Wei made the remarks at a demonstration staged before mainland China's delegation to the United Nations in Manhattan.

DOC.HEADLINE: 4,000-PLUS SOLDIERS FROM QUAKE-STRICKEN AREAS GIVEN EARLY DISCHARGE

TEXT.P: More than 4,000 soldiers from earthquake-stricken areas have been discharged from active military service ahead of schedule, said a spokesman for the Defense Ministry on Saturday.

Following the devastating temblor last September 21, Defense Minister Tang Fei issued instructions paving the way for soldiers from quake-affected areas to apply for early discharge from military service in order to return to their families and help rebuild their homes.
A total of 4,068 soldiers, including 262 from offshore islands, have been discharged in accordance with the instructions, said the spokesman.
He noted that the measure has won the appreciation of local governments and quake-affected families.

DOC.HEADLINE: TODAY IN HISTORY
DOC.TEXT:
Today is Sunday, April 30, or the 26th day of the third month of the Year of the Dragon according to the lunar calendar. Following is a list of important events that have occurred on this date in the past:
1770: David Thompson, the Canadian explorer who followed the Columbia River to its mouth in 1881 and mapped much of western Canada, is born in England.
1777: Karl Friedrich Gauss, the German mathematician and astronomer known for his contributions to algebra, differential geometry, probability theory and number theory, is born in Germany.
1789: George Washington is inaugurated as the first president of the United States in a ceremony at Federal Hall in New York.
1803: The United States buys Louisiana Territory and New Orleans from the French.
1893: Joachim von Ribbentrop, the German politician who was Adolf Hitler's foreign minister, is born.
1900: The republic of Hawaii cedes itself to the United States.
1909: Juliana, queen of the Netherlands from 1948, is born. She abdicated this day in 1980 in favor of her daughter Beatrix.
1919: The Paris Peace Conference allows Japan to take over Germany's prewar rights in China's Shantung Province, whereupon China leaves the conference.
1945: Adolf Hitler, the German dictator known as "Der Fuhrer" who reduced his country and much of Europe to ashes, commits suicide with his wife Eva Braun after bidding farewell to the few aides remaining with him in his Berlin bunker hideaway.
1946: The national government of the Republic of China issues an order moving the national capital back to Nanking from Chungking.
1948: A total of 21 American nations sign the "Charter of Bogota," setting up the Organization of American States (OAS).
1957: Egypt reopens the Suez Canal to traffic.
1967: Muhammad Ali, who first won the world heavyweight boxing crown as Cassius Clay in 1964, is stripped of his title for refusing to be drafted into the US armed forces.
1968: ROC President Chiang Kai-shek approves a set of "Guidelines for the Lives of Citizens" drafted by the National Committee of Chinese Cultural Renaissance Movement.
1973: US President Richard Nixon accepts responsibility for the bugging that took place at the Watergate apartment complex in 1972.
1974: Adm. Maurice F. Weisner, commander in chief of the US Pacific Fleet, arrives in Taipei for a four-day visit.
1975: The Vietnam War ends with South Vietnam's surrender to the communists after North Vietnamese tanks capture the Presidential Office in Saigon.
1977: Public and private buses begin joint operations in Taipei City.
1988: A South Korean college student is arrested after hurling three home-made bombs into the headquarters of President Roh Tae-Woo's governing party in Seoul.
1989: Finance Minister Shirley Kuo leads an ROC delegation to the 22nd annual Asian Development Bank meeting in Beijing.
1990: Elected ROC officials of all levels are permitted to make private visits to mainland China during recesses. Veterans who were stranded on the mainland after the nationalist government moved to Taiwan in 1949 are allowed to apply for resettlement in Taiwan.
1991: Cyclone hits Bangladesh, killing more than 125,000 people.
1991: ROC President Lee Teng-hui declares the termination of the Period of National Mobilization for Suppression of the Communist Rebellion, effective on May 1. He abolishes the Temporary Provisions and promulgates the Additional Articles of the Constitution, also effective on May 1.
1992: US General John Shalikashvili is appointed the new commander of NATO forces in Europe.
1997: Trains collide at Rongchiawan Station in Yuehyang City, in mainland China's Hunan Province, killing 58 people and injuring hundreds of others.
1998: Secessionist rebels sign a permanent cease-fire with the Papua New Guinea government to end a nine-year rebellion on the South Pacific Island of Bougainville.
Confucius' lesson of the day: "If a man takes no thought for the morrow, he will be sorry before today is out."

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN NEWS HEADLINES
DOC.TEXT:

DOC.HEADLINE: CHEN, TANG INTRODUCE NEW TEAM

TEXT.P: President-elect Chen Shui-bian and Premier-designate Tang Fei will call a joint news conference on Monday to introduce the lineup of the incoming Cabinet.
As members for most positions of the new Cabinet, which will be installed on May 20, have already been decided, Chen and Tang will use the opportunity to formally introduce their team to the public.

Following the press conference, there will be a lunch party to allow the cabinet members to meet with each other. It will also serve as an occasion for celebrating Tang's recovery from a recent operation.
Tang, who received the operation to remove a chest tumor, was released from National Taiwan University Hospital on Saturday.

DOC.HEADLINE: PRESIDENT OF CHAROEN POKPHAND SPEAKS ON INT'L COMPETITIVENESS

TEXT.P: Aiming to become Asia's leading animal protein supplier, Charoen Pokphand Group (Taiwan Area) has managed to achieve annual growth of 10 to 15 percent over the past few years.

The company currently targets yearly sales of NT$55 billion by 2005. In order to achieve this goal, company president Yu Ru-chien stressed that Charoen Pokphand needs to improve its international competitiveness.
Following are excerpts of an interview with Yu by CNA reporter Tina Han:
Q: How does Charoen Pokphand plan to improve its international competitiveness in light of Taiwan's anticipated entry into the World Trade Organization?

A: We are gearing up to accelerate the streamlining of our regional operations, and are reinforcing the integration of our key operations. Over the past four years, our company has invested NT$1.2 billion in research and development, setting up new outlets, improving production facilities, and modernizing the administrative system. We plan to back up that investment with another NT$2 billion.
Q: Charoen Pokphand has chosen to specialize in biological technology application. What are some of the issues in the field.
A: Successful use of biological technology in industrial production depends on the effectiveness of research, applications, as well as marketing. We focus our efforts on applications and marketing.

Biological research and development involves tremendous capital investment. Our company has participated in research projects alongside international research institutes, rather than initiating research projects ourselves. We have the Asian rights to the products of any projects with which we are involved.
Q: What are some of the applications for biological technology in your production and marketing?

A: In terms of meat processing, we have applied genetic engineering technology in chicken and pork production. The market reaction for genetically modified chicken is positive, and good prospects are seen for pork in three years.
Q: Charoen Pokphand has facilitated itself with commodity flow capability. Will the company orient towards e-commerce?

A: Our company produces 8,000 tons of frozen and deep frozen processed food products a month, and we expect our monthly volume will increase to 10,000 tons later this year. We have built a distribution network with 500 cargo vehicles.

We are still considering the possibility of applying e-commerce in our operations. In addition to replacing conventional practices of commodity flow, e-commerce should provide more value-added services.

However, for various reasons, agricultural products and processed foodstuffs are different from other products in terms of distribution and consumer purchasing habits. These special characteristics may make this sector less sensitive to e-commerce.

Our company has planned for e-commerce, but it is unlikely to replace conventional sales and distribution channels. At the moment, our priorities are to improve our product quality and to build the company's image.
Q: Will Charoen Pokphand adjust its investment strategies in mainland China under the new central government?

A: Basically, I believe that Taiwan's democracy is mature enough to sustain any administrative transition. As long as cross-Taiwan tensions are minimized, our company will increase its investments in mainland China. We plan to add another NT$500 million in meat processing and marketing investments there. Other investment projects involve improving the commodity flow system there.
Q: What are some of the issues of the commodity flow system in mainland China?
A: Commodity flow is a problem there due to the distance between cities and rural regions. In a market with 1.3 billion people, it is vital to facilitate the commodity flow system.
Mainland China has the advantages of a large market, abundant resources and a huge supply of manpower. If political tensions are reduced, our company will increase our investments there.
Q: How successful are Charoen Pokphand's reinvestment projects overseas?

A: We have had an annual investment return of between NT$20 million and NT$30 million from our investments in mainland China over the past three years. Although a return on our US$90 million investment in the U.S. state of Alabama has been comparatively slow in coming, we remain optimistic.
Q: What are your expectations of the new administration?
A: A stabilized economy, a harmonious society, transparency in policy making, and wiping out corruption are all important to the development of the private sector. (translated by Lillian Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: REALTEK AIMS TO BECOME THE WORLD'S NO.1 100M LAN CARD CHIP SUPPLIER

TEXT.P: Holding over 40 percent of the world market for 100 M ethernet LAN card chips, Realtek Semiconductor Co. aims to become the world's No. 1 supplier of LAN card chips.

Realtek's icon is a crab, a symbol of ambition for Chinese people. The Taiwanese company has lived up to the image, trying to grab as much of the world's market share as it can. Since early this year, Realtek has filled almost of the demand from Taiwanese LAN card manufacturers, who used to have to go to 3COM or Intel for LAN card chips.

Realtek concentrates on three production lines -- ICs for networks, ICs for consumer goods, and ICs for computer peripherals. With the fast-growing market for network ICs and shrinking demand for computer peripheral ICs, Realtek is very often identified as a network ICs designer.
Following are excerpts from an interview with Realtek's vice president Jesse Chen by CNA reporter Daphne Wu:

Q: Realtek attained a record monthly high of NT$488 million in revenues for March. First quarter revenues grew by 102 percent, and reached NT$1.13 billion. How is it possible for the company to achieve such good performance during a supposedly sluggish season?

A: Realtek revenues are up because we have been taking orders of 100M LAN card chips from firms that used to go to 3COM and Intel. Now Realtek supplies 90 percent of demand from Taiwanese LAN card manufacturers, and over 40 percent of the world market.

We expect to become the world's number 1 100M lan card chips supplier later this year. We are grateful that Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. and United Microelectronics Corp. have supported us in facilitating our production capability.
Q: What is Realtek's current production structure?

A: Of our targeted NT$4 billion in revenues for this year, 75 percent will come from LAN card chips, 20 percent from consumer electronics chips, and 5 percent from chips for computer peripherals. Revenues from LAN card chips already account for 75 percent of first quarter company revenues.

As demand for 100M Ethernet LAN card chips continues to increase, Realtek estimates that this year we will deliver between 25 million and 26 million 100M lan card chips, almost doubling the output of 1999. On the other hand, production of 10M LAN card chips will fall to between 10 million and 12 million units, as compared with our output of 13 million units last year.
Q: Is Realtek cutting down on its production of consumer electronics chips and computer peripherals for the purpose of company transition?

A: Realtek's revenues from chips for consumer electronics are expected to fall because of insufficient production capability and the loss of a key customer, Lucky Goldstar in South Korea. As to computer peripherals chips production, the demand for many items is shrinking and new products have not yet been accepted by the market.
Q: Realtek has a comparatively high share price, reflecting investors' confidence in your company. What are the prospects for the second half of this year?
A: We have targeted revenues for this year at NT$4 billion, which is considered very conservative. We made the estimate based on our LAN card chips market.
If Realtek can get orders from mainboard manufacturers such as Asustek Computer Inc., Gigabyte Technology and Micro-Star International, it will further expand our market and boost revenues.
Q: Is Realtek facing severe competition in this field? What is the life span of the 100M LAN card chip market?

A: Realtek has built the company image by supplying 90 percent of the Taiwan market for LAN card chips. LAN cards with Realtek chips are called "crab cards" here. It will not be easy for other manufacturers to catch up, because it normally takes half a year to progress from the research and development stage to mass production.
As a Taiwanese manufacturer, Realtek has the advantage of being closer to the market. Many Taiwanese LAN card manufacturers have shifted their orders from 3COM and Intel to us.
We estimate that the market for 100M LAN card chips will continue to boom for the next four years, before mass production of 1GB lan card chips takes off in 2002.
Q: What new products will Realtek unleash this year?

A: We began mass production of hub controller in February, and a new version of 100M lan card chips in March. A newly-developed 4-port high speed Ethernet receiver will be added to our production lines in May. (translated by Lillian Lin)

DOC.HEADLINE: NEW ADMINISTRATION FACES 'STARK' CROSS-STRAIT SITUATION: KMT OFFICIAL

TEXT.P: An official of the outgoing Kuomintang said on Sunday that the new administration will face a "more difficult" situation in cross-strait relations than that faced by the KMT government.

Chang Jung-kung, director-general of the KMT's Department of Mainland Affairs Research, said that cross-strait relations are "stark" and "potentially risky," as the mainland feels more urgency to tackle the Taiwan issue.

Mainland China has demanded that President-elect Chen Shui-bian accept the "one China" principle as a prerequisite for renewed cross-strait talks. Chen has responded by saying that any issue could be raised in the talks, but there should not be any prerequisites.
Beijing maintains that there is only "one China," with the People's Republic of China being the sole legitimate government and Taiwan being a part of China.
Taipei accepts the "one China" concept, but has defined it as an abstract, historical and future concept, with China being currently divided.

Chang made the remarks one day after Koo Chen-fu, Taiwan's top negotiator with the mainland, made an appeal to Beijing on the seventh anniversary of an historic meeting between himself and his mainland counterpart, Wang Daohan.

Koo, in an effort to break the current cross-strait stalemate, appealed to Beijing on Saturday to shelve the row over the definition of "one China" and return to the consensus reached by both sides in 1992, in which each side of the Taiwan Strait is allowed its own interpretation of "one China."

Chang said that Koo's appeal had been "carefully thought out." He added that Koo had aimed to convince the mainland to relax current pressure on the "one China" issue, and at the same time express his hope that the new administration will continue the policy set by its predecessor.

Chang noted President-elect Chen has said that he would continue to rely on Koo's experience in handling cross-strait relations, but Chen has yet to state clearly his stance on the different interpretations of "one China."

But Chang also pointed out that the mainland has denied that the two sides ever reached such an agreement, and that even if the new government adopts the policy, it will not necessarily lead to renewed cross-strait talks.
Chang said the policy is supported by the majority of local people, as well of the support of international community, especially the United States. Therefore, it should be adopted, he said.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIWAN POSTS US$ 1.16 B. 1'ST QUARTER TRADE DEFICIT IN AGRI. PRODUCTS

TEXT.P: The nation exported US$720 million and imported US$1.88 billion in agricultural products during the first three months of the year, resulting in a US$1.16 billion trade deficit in the sector, statistics compiled by the Council of Agriculture under the Executive Yuan show on Sunday.

The COA statistics also show that due in part to the New Taiwan dollar's appreciation, Taiwan imported a total of 445 metric tons of agricultural products, with a value of US$1,883 million. Exports of agricultural products reached 394,000 metric tons, with a value of US$720 million.
Key imports include corn, wheat, sorghum, cotton, lumber, fish powder, tea, coffee and Chinese herb.
The imported products chiefly came from the United States, Australia, Japan, Malaysia, and Thailand.
For the export market, Japan, the United States and Hong Kong were the three largest buyers of Taiwan's agricultural products.
Important export items include fresh vegetables, fresh fruits, fresh flowers, and eel.

DOC.HEADLINE: NANTOU COUNTY QUAKE ORPHANS VISIT OKINAWA

TEXT.P: Some 35 children from central Taiwan who were orphaned during the devastating Sept. 21 earthquake last year departed from Keelung, northern Taiwan, on Sunday, for a four-day cruise to Okinawa.

The trip was arranged by the government of Nantou County with the cooperation of Star Cruises, a cruise line firm. The purpose is to help the orphans come out of the shadow of losing their parents during the killer temblor, which claimed 2,300 lives in Taiwan.

The trip was part of a series of efforts launched by Nantou County to help the bereaved children. In the wake of the massive quake, Nantou Magistrate Peng Pai-hsien had asked ranking officials in the county government to help foster the orphans, and regularly visit them to learn about their daily lives.
Star Cruises has provided the trip at no cost to the children. Company president Lin Teh-hung said that providing the journey for free is a way for the firm to give something back to society.
Social workers and members of the orphans' foster families are accompanying the children on the trip.

DOC.HEADLINE: NTU PROF. CHEN PO-CHIH NAMED NEW CEPD CHAIRMAN

TEXT.P: Premier-designate Tang Fei on Sunday confirmed that Prof. Chen Po-chih of National Taiwan University will take the post of chairman of the Cabinet-level Council for Economic Planning and Development (CEPD).
Tang also confirmed that Hsueh Chi, incumbent vice chairman of the CEPD, will take the post of minister-without-portfolio in the new government.
Tang's confirmation of Chen as head of the CEPD leaves the only the head of the Cabinet-level Atomic Energy Council undecided.

Prof. Chen has been a financial and economic affairs advisor of the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) for years. He had initially turned down Tang's request to serve as CEPD chairman. DPP Chairman Lin Yi-hsiung is reported to have played a crucial role in persuading Chen to change his mind and accept the new post.

DOC.HEADLINE: YEAR 2000 NAVAL GOODWILL FLOTILLA VISITS KAOHSIUNG PORT
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, April 30 (CNA) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: The Year 2000 Republic of China Naval Goodwill Flotilla called at Kaohsiung Port, where it opened to the public on Sunday. It was the first of its six scheduled visits to domestic ports, before it sails abroad.
The flotilla was comprised of Chengkung-class destroyers, Kanho-class frigates and Chungho-class landing craft.
The flotilla, manned by graduating cadets from the Naval Academy, will first visit six domestic ports around Taiwan before going abroad on a goodwill tour.

Kaohsiung port was the first leg of its domestic tour, and it met with an enthusiastic reception from local residents. Kaohsiung civilians were invited on board to view the modern equipment installed on the warships.
The Navy also used the opportunity for recruiting purposes, touting the naval life and the Naval Academy in an attempt to lure more youthful talent.

DOC.HEADLINE: TAIPEI MAYOR MA YING-JEOU INAUGURATES TAP WATER MUSEUM
DOC.DATELINE: Kaohsiung, southern Taiwan, April 30 (CNA) (By Edward Chen) (By Edward Chen)

TEXT.P: Taipei, April 30 (CNA): Taipei Mayor Ma Ying-jeou inaugurated on Sunday the nation's first tap water museum. Mayor Ma also drank two cups of tap water to demonstrate his faith in its quality to an enthusiastic crowd.

The museum, located at the Hsihyuan Road, Taipei, was originally a pump house for the Taipei Tap Water Company. The 92-year-old building was classified as the third grade of cultural relic by the Ministry of Interior in June, 1993.
Addressing the inauguration, Ma said that a dependable supply of clean tap water is the mark of a modern country. He also assured the public that Taipei city's tap water is safe for drinking.

Tsai Hui-sheng, director of Taipei Tap water Department, said that the city government plans to build more public drinking fountains in Taipei. At the present time, more than 100 drinking drinking fountains have been set up in mass rapid transport stations around Taipei, Tsai said.

DOC.HEADLINE: PREMIER SIEW PROMISES SMOOTH TRANSFER OF POWER
DOC.DATELINE: Shulin, Taipei County, April 30 (CNA) (By David Hsu)

TEXT.P: Premier Vincent Siew on Sunday said he would ask Cabinet Secretary General Hsieh Shen-shan to meet with Premier-designate Tang Fei to discuss the transfer of power.
Siew made the remark while attending a religious activity held here to commemorate the 1,400th birthday of the Tang Dynasty's Buddhist Master Hsuan Tsang.

Referring to criticism from the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) on the recent adjustment of the Cabinet's personnel, Siew emphasized that the outgoing government's move was justified and totally legal. He urged the DPP stop its criticism on the matter and expressed hope that both the DPP and the Kuomintang (KMT) can show mutual respect while establishing a system for the transfer of power.
The KMT's humiliating defeat by the DPP in the March 18 presidential election ended its 55-year rule on the island. The DPP will take the reins of government on May 20.
The DPP had slammed the outgoing Cabinet for a minor adjustment of its personnel, adding that the "caretaker Cabinet" should let the new government decide on personnel adjustments.
